Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Deposed Religous Leader Brought To Trial


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 30, 1996 by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 839 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Ibrahim Dasuki, deposed April 20 as Sultan of Sokoto, Nigeria's supreme Muslim leader, has been charged in court for alleged inability to repay debts owed two failed banks.

The disgraced cleric is facing trial with 15 other directors of two firms which allegedly owed the collapsed Alpha Merchant and Republic Banks some 775 million naira (about 35.23 million U.S. dollars. 

Dasuki was deposed and banished by the military government. It accused him of financial impropriety and showing disrespect to the administration of Gen. Sani Abacha. Dasuki has been replaced by Muhammadu Maccido.

Dasuki was absent when the debt recovery trial opened Wednesday at the Lagos zone of the failed bank tribunal.

His attorney, Chimeje Ikeazor, told the tribunal he had no access to his client, believed banished to Nigeria's northeastern city of Jalingo.

The lawyer said he was prepared to defend his client provided he could be produced in court.

The tribunal chairman, Justice Musiliu Ope-Agbe, then adjoured the case until July 10. The judge ordered that the deposed sultan be produced in court on that date.

At least seven chief executives of failed Nigerian banks have been jailed by the tribunal, in a move the military government said was to sanitise the country's financial system.

It has also said that a failed government parastatals tribunal is to be established to try officials who mismanaged graft-ridden state-run agencies.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996

Africa News


May, 1996


Tanzania Revenue Collection Improves


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 30, 1996 by Lwaga Mwambande PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 334 words


 
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania - Tanzania improved its revenue collection to 37.4 billion shillings in April, up from 25.2 billion (1 U.S. dollar = 610 T.shs.) in the previous month.

According to a Bank of Tanzania (BOT) report, recurrent expenditure since the beginning of the 1995-1996 fiscal year in July stood at 350.4 billion shs. compared with an expenditure of 379.1 billion or deficit of 28.7 billion shs. 

The report, issued here Wednesday, said that cumulative collection for March and April was 83.8 billion shs, which is above the benchmark by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), set at 82.5 billion shs. for the period.

"The trend should be sustained to facilitate the commencement of a formal IMF-sponsored Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) in the next financial year under which multilateral donors would inject more aid into the country," the BOT report said.

It added that inflation decreased slightly from 26 percent in March to 25.5 percent in April as food prices went down but drinks, rent and tobacco prices increased.

Since President Benjamin Mkapa came to power in November, 1995, Tanzania has been recording good revenue collection.

As a result, several donor countries have resumed their assistance to the country which were suspended because of poor revenue collection.

Mkapa has made it clear that revenue collection will be strengthened. A new institution, the Tanzania Revenue authority is expected to start operations in July.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

3 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Ghana-Oil Oil Imports To Be Liberalised


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

TEMA, Ghana - The Tema Oil Refinery (TOR) in Ghana has announced that it plans to liberalise the importation of crude oil and petroleum products within the next three months.

The decision, which forms part of the government's energy reform program, will remove the monopoly from the Ghana National Petroleum Corporation (GNPC), which had hitherto been the sole importer of crude oil and petroleum products in the country. 

William Parker, TOR Chief Executive, told reporters Tuesday that the procurement of crude and refined oil products, required to make up for the refinery's shortfall, will be through competitive tenders.

Oil companies will be given a chance to import these inputs and share the cost, he added.

He said profit margins for the oil marketing companies will be set and reviewed to ensure that there are no undue price hikes.

Parker said TOR advertised the new policy as a first step towards achieving the regulation and restructuring of the oil industry in Ghana.

He said tenders will be based on open competition aimed at obtaining the best price. "It will be certainly transparent", he added.

The deregulation, he explained, "is essentially an attempt to ensure full cost recovery based on current crude prices and exchange rates as well as full processing costs and not tax importation gimmick."

Parker said changes in ex-refinery prices and corresponding maximum retail price will be posted as soon as significant changes occur in the cost element.

He said over 30 oil companies and businesses which are supposed to prove their technical and financial capabilities, experience, ability to supply and their bankers, have put in applications.

Ghana currently consumes some 1.8 million tonnes of crude a year, while the refinery has the capacity to process 1.2 million tonnes.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996

Africa News


May, 1996


Chad Chadians in Sudan Vote For Their Nation's President


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 30, 1996 by Yahya El Hassan PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 160 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Chadians living in Sudan went to the polls Thursday to elect a president for their country. 

One of Khartoum's 10 polling centres, based at the Chadian embassy, saw a good turn up with Ambassador Mohamet Fadul Makai casting the first vote.

About 220,000 Chadians live in Sudan. Most are refugees who fled decades of war in the central African country. Some 45,000 live in Khartoum, many of them as merchants and workers.

A total of 100 polling centres have been prepared countrywide, primarily in western Sudan. Polling in Chad is scheduled for June 6. Fifteen candidates are contesting the presidency, 13 of them representing political parties. Two of these are independent candidates.

Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Conditions For Dialogue With Commonwealth Set


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 30, 1996 by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria has requested a change of venue for a planned meeting with the British-led Commonwealth, from which it was suspended in November 1995 over its human rights record.

Nigeria was suspended from the 53-nation organization following the Nov. 1995 execution for murder of nine minority leaders, among them author Ken Saro-Wiwa. 

The hangings provoked international condemnation and sanctions against Nigeria.

Abuja protested the suspension and refused a visit to the country by the eight-nation Commonwealth ministerial action group set up to monitor the democratioc process and human rights in Nigeria.

After its recent meeting in London the group, chaired by Zimbabwe, decided to invite Nigeria to a meeting in London, the British capital.

But Nigeria Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi said in a letter to the group chairman, Zimbabwe Foreign Minister Stan Mudenge, that Abuja would prefer an alternative venue.

"I wish to remind in this connection that the United Kingdom at present maintains a regime of sanctions against my country which includes restriction of high level visits or contacts with Nigerian officials," Ikimi added.

He said unless it could be assured that "my delegation would have unfettered movement to and from the United Kingdom, an alternative country could be proposed for our mutual consideration."

Britain is among European Union countries that have imposed sanctions, including visa restrictions, sports ban and freezing of official assistance to Nigeria over the executions.

However, Ikimi said Nigeria welcomes the move by the Commonwealth to recognise that Nigeria "is entitled to justice and fair play on this matter as we believe that our suspension was both unprecedented and undemocratic."

Ikimi, who Wednesday received a special message from Mudenge, said the Commonwealth move would pave way for "constructive dialogue."

Africa News


May, 1996


Niger Five Contest For Presidency


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 254 words


 

NIAMEY, Niger - A former parliamentary speaker in Niger, Mahamadou Issoufou, became Wednesday the fifth aspirant to announce his intention to stand in the country's presidential election slated for July.

He was nominated by Niger Party for Democracy and Socialism (PNDS), which was in the parliamentary majority coalition of parties before the government was ousted Jan. 27 in a coup. 

Issoufou was Prime Minister between 1993 and 1994. Then he fell out with former President Mahamane Ousmane who was toppled in the January coup.

Issoufou joins four other personalities who have already filed their papers for the poll.

They include Gen. Ibrahim Barre Mainassara, the military ruler who seized power on Jan. 27. He is standing as an independent candidate.

The others are former president Mahamane Ousmane (Democratic and Social Convention or CDS), Tandja Mamadou (National Movement for the Developing Society or MNSD) and Moumouni Djermakoye Adamou (Niger National Alliance for Democracy and Progress or ANDP).

The first round of the presidential election will be held July, 7 while the run-off ballot is scheduled for July 28.

Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria United States Human Rights Envoy In Lagos


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 30, 1996 by Paul Ejime Pana,Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The United States assistant secretary of state for democracy, human rights and labour, John Shattuck, is in Nigeria for talks expected to address Washington's troubled relations with the west African country.

A U.S. diplomat told PANA in Lagos Thursday that Shattuck, the first top American official to visit Nigeria in several months, arrived late Wednesday. 

Details of his itinenary or the duration of the trip were not immediately available. It was also unclear if he would be meeting military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha.

Washington has maintained limited sanctions it imposed on Nigeria after the annulment by the last military regime of the June 1993 presidential election.

It has also called for the release of opposition politicians, including millionaire-politician Moshood Abiola, the presumed winner of the cancelled presidential poll. Abiola is facing trial for treasonable felony after he declared himself president of Nigeria in June 1994.

The U.S. government has also condemned the November 1995 executions for murder of nine Nigerian minority leaders, among them author Ken Saro-Wiwa.

In several recent statements, Washington has indicated its displeasure at the Abacha regime's politicial transition to democracy and human rights posture.

State department officials have maintained that the U.S. does not rule out any further sanctions against Nigeria, including oil embargo.

U.S. ambassador in Nigeria Walter Carrington, recalled home for four months over the executions, returned to his post in April, saying his resumption of duty did not amount to a change in Washington's position on Nigeria's human rights and democractic process.

But independent observers say Washington and its European partners are hamstrung on the measure because of their interests in Nigeria's petroleum industry.

An oil embargo could hurt the U.S., which buys some 50 percent of Nigeria's crude.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996

Africa News


May, 1996


Burundi George Moose Visits Bujumbura


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 30, 1996 by Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA correspondent


LENGTH: 414 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - U.S. Deputy Secretary of State for African Affairs George Moose arrived Thursday in Bujumbura on a one-day visit to once again try to find a solution to the Burundi crisis.

Moose, accompanied by his country's special coordinator for Rwanda and Burundi, Richard Bogosian, did not rule out the possibility of spending more time in the country "if the need arises". 

"The United States has not planned a military intervention in Burundi", he said, adding that his country was therefore "ready to bring an emergency aid (to Burundi), in case of a humanitarian disaster".

The American delegation will meet President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, Prime Minister Antoine Nduwayo as well as the defence minister and other officials.

The delegation's arrival coincided with a statement by the opposition UPRONA party in which it rejected any call by the international community to send foreign troops into Burundi.

"The current international campaign for a foreign troop intervention in Burundi, is unacceptable and abuse of our national sovereignty" said UPRONA, (Unity for National Progress), the former sole party.

According to the statement, "UPRONA will not...accept the international community to reduce to nothing the more than 30 years of freedom and sovereignty".

It recalled that "Burundi political partners reaffirmed their determination to defend the national sovereignty, particularly by refusing any foreign political or military interference in national affairs".

If by any chance the military intervention occured, "the party would not fail to call on the Burundi people to oppose resolutely the invasion", warned UPRONA in the statement signed by its chairman, Charles Mukasi.

Burundi has been hit by ethnic and political violence which killed an estimated 500,000 people since the democratically elected president, Melchior Ndadaye, was assassinated in the October 1993 failed coup.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 24, 1996 by Olu Sarr PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - Tuesday's ferry disaster on Lake Victoria and the revolt by some soldiers of the Central African Republic army, strained relations among the countries of the Great Lakes and Liberia's ongoing crisis, drew sharp responses from newspapers in Africa.

Kampala's state-owned daily, The New Vision, said that despite officials denials of overloading of the ferry the contrary appeared to be case. "Should this turn out to be true, then the authorities in Tanzania should have a more critical look at the whole transport industry and take corrective action," it said. "This, of course, does not apply to Tanzania alone. Most countries in the region, Uganda inclusive, have been losing hundreds of their people in accidents on the roads, in the air and on water," it said. "In most cases the accusing finger points to laxity in the enforcement of safety standards." 

The profit motive, it said, was why vehicles were not serviced correctly, or frequently in Africa.

Often, it added, public transport that are too old "are kept on the roads, in the air and on the lakes, hoping that God's mercy will keep them afloat." The result, it said, was "countless accidents." Whatever the cause of the ferry accident, it said, "the casualty rate has exposed our nakedness in our inability to handle disasters of this nature." Dakar's Sud Quotidien commented on the army revolt in Central African Republic: Evidence, it said, of "kaki (military) contamination" of Africa's democratic process.

This is in reference to the resurgence of military governments and revolts on the continent.

"The crisis in Central Africa underlines the degree to which the quiet giant (the army) has impeded the democratic process which she has still not yet accepted,"

L' Observateur, a Bujumbura newspaper in strife-torn Burundi, commented on the strained relations among Burundi, Rwanda and Zaire. It said the situation could lead to war.

Initially, the problem between Burundi and Zaire was one of "a crisis of confidence." This, it said, stemmed from "the (uninterupted) 30-year presidency of Mobutu Sese Seko and the relative instability of the Burundian president."

Moreover, it said, the relations between Mobutu and Burundi's first president, Michel Micombero, which was forged out of a common background and generation, "no longer prevails." Instead, it said, "a pyschological crisis" exists between both countries. Mobutu, it said, "opposed democracy" as decided at the Francophone summit at La Baule while Burundi "rushed into this endless labyrinth."

On its relations with Rwanda, the newspaper added: "Kinshasa is increasingly disturbed by the presence of a regime in Kigali which owes it nothing and whose example might be followed in Bujumbura, because of imperialism."

The government-owned Zambia Daily Mail, published in Lusaka, and the Lagos-based National Concord, a private newspaper, were dismayed by Liberia's warlords and the country's recent boat people.

"The most enduring lesson of the Bulk Challenge saga is that governments in countries of the West African sub-region should intensiify efforts aimed at ending the Liberian civil war," the Concord said.

Otherwise, it said, "fall-outs in terms of unwanted refugees and threats to peace and stability in neighbouring countries will remain."

However, it added, while the crisis lasts "no government in the West African sub-region -- not least Nigeria's -- should attempt to bury its head in the sands by keeping out those who have chosen to flee that country."

It concluded: "Perhaps, a swarm of refugees from Liberia is all the rest of West Africa needs to drive home the message that whatever it takes, the war in Liberia must be brought to an end one way or the other."

The Mail said events in Liberia "are outright shameful and disgusting," to say the least.

"It is most saddening to note that while countries in the West African region are trying to grapple with their economic problems, these are being derailed by developments in Liberia," it continued. This situation needs to be redressed, it added, so that these countries could attend to their internal problems. "This is the same message that must go out to other hot spots such as Somalia, Rwanda, Burundi and, to some extent, Sudan, where those supposed to be leading the people are at loggerheads over petty issues," it said.

But the newspaper disagreed with those who have called for extra-continental bodies to solve this and other African problems.

"Africa has now reached a stage whereby she doesn't need the so-called superpowers to resolve her problems. That would be tantamount to recolonialisation.

"African problems must be addressed by the African governments themselves through the Organisation of African Unity and not through the intervention of other powers," it said.

Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Western Financiers Cutting African Bank To Size


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 22, 1996 by Felix Njoku, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 840 words


 

ABIDJAN, Cote D'ivoire - Hopes that the African Development Bank, the continent's premier lending institution will be infused with new capital under its new management are gradually diminishing as Western financiers increasingly adopt a beggar-my-neighbour attitude to the continent.

Finance ministers and bank governors from the 53 African members and 24 other member countries have been locked in endless discussion for two days over the replenishment of the Bank's soft loan affiliate, the African Development Fund (ADF).

The ADF, the source of investment funds for 39 African members was due for the seventh three-year replenishment way back in 1993, but its share holders said they would not do so until the Bank's operations were restructured.

The "house cleaning" they asked for was initiated at the beginning of the year by its new president, Omar Kabbaj of Morocco, who replaced Babacar Ndiaye of Senegal. 

Kabbaj told the governors the exercise, which involves complete overhaul of the institution's methods of work, has seen the removal of more than 200 staff of all catergories. Many others have been down-graded, redeployed or merely asked to seek early retirement.

He said the ADB has also set up safety nets for proper loan management and recovery of arreas, which was among the demands made by the donors.

But deliberations underway here, ahead of the 32nd annual general meeting of the Bank opening Wednesday, indicate that if anything, the ADF may only get a pittance, assuming the financiers finally agree on anything.

Ndiaye in 1993 said at least the amount should be within the range of five billion dollars for the Bank to be able to tackle some of the pressing development needs of the continent.

But source here told PANA Tuesday delegates were yet to agree on about half the amount -- some 2.5 billion dollars.

"Two-and-a-half years in too long," said Zhand Zhxiang of the Chinese delegation which has so far been sympathetic to the African cause.

Conference sources say the two major financiers to the ADF --- the United States and Japan -- plan to cut their shareholdings in the Fund. This means reduced contributions for the replenishment.

The U.S. contributions would go down from 11.8 percent to 10 percent, while the Japanese contributions would move from 9.5 percent to just six percent.

Canada says it wants to reduce its eight percent share by half. Sweden says it would cut half-percentage point from its share of 4.5 percent, if Britain does not promise to do more.

Italy is yet to clear some 300 million dollars in arrears due to the Fund, while Germany claims it has problems with its parliament.

Analysts say almost all traditional donors have found one excuse or the other not to put in sufficient funds.

They say the influence of the Bank on African development would diminish considerably if the ADF continues to be starved of funds. This is because it is the primary source of investment capital for the majority (39) of the African members who do not qualify for costly loans from the adb loan window, especially at a time when official development aid has shrunk to the barest minimum.

The ADF was established in 1972, nine years after the ADB, to provide development finance on concessional terms to low-income African Countries. Its loans are interest-free (0.75 percent service charge) and are generally repayable over 50 years including a grace period of 10 years. The last replenishment was 3.34 billion dollars. It share subscription at the end of 1995 was 11.45 billion dollas.

By comparison the ABD, with a subscribed capital of 24 billion dollars at the end of last year, charges seven percent interest on its loans.

The third arm of the Bank group is the Nigeria Trust Fund, floated by Nigeria in 1976 to support needy African members. The fund, which charges four percent interest on loans, has grown from 80 million dollars at inception to 440 million dollars today.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

11 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Sudan Private Sudanese Daily Ordered To Close For Two Weeks


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 22, 1996 by Yahya El Hassan, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 534 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan - A privately-owned Sudanese daily newspaper was ordered closed for two weeks Tuesday after it published a report of a mutiny in a regional prison in which it said soldiers were involved.

Sudan's National Council for the Press and Publications said Arrai Al Akhar (The Other View), was being shut because it had violated the Press and Publications Act.

This law prohibits the publication of news that could be harmful to the national security or which offends or demoralises the armed forces of the country. 

The newspaper reported Friday that 95 soldiers, jailed for their involvement in an attempted coup in March 1995, had led a revolt at Eddewaim prison in the state of White Nile, some 180 kilometres south of Khartoum.

It said they clashed with prison guards before taking over the facility and holding its commander, a major, hostage.

The newspaper quoted what it called an authoritative source as saying the mutineers "had occupied the prison and its arms depot after a bloody clash inside the prison."

Sudanese authorities said that a small number of army officers and men had taken part in a failed coup, meant to prevent a return to civil government. This coincided with the presidential and parliamentary elections.

However, the Ministry of the Interior denied Saturday the newspaper's claim that soldiers were involved in the reported prison takeover. The ministry termed the disturbances as unrest caused by ordinary inmates who complained of inadequate rations and recreation.

The Press and Publications Council said the newspaper's account contained lies. It said none of the former soldiers took part in the disturbances and that the prison was neither taken over nor its weapons seized.

The council said the newspaper had failed to publish the ministry's denial of the account, as had all other media.

The newspaper's editor-in-chief, Mohi Eddin Titawi, said Monday that his publication's account of the prison incident was true.

He said that armed men, whom he could not identify, stormed his office Sunday and took away 20,000 copies of the newspaper that were ready for distribution. They also took away all the blue prints. He said he was expecting to be arrested at any moment.

However, the general-secretary of the influential Press Union, Abdul Malik Annaeim told reporters Monday the body would do its utmost to prevent Titwani's arrest.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996

12 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Five More Countries Join The Indian Ocean Common Market


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 22, 1996


LENGTH: 240 words


 

PORT LOUIS, Mauritius- Five countries have joined the the Indian Ocean common market known as the Indian Ocean Rim Initiative.

The five countries are Madagascar, Mozambique, Malaysia, Sri Lanka and Indonesia. They have joined the five founder members consisting of Australia, Kenya, India, Mauritius, Oman, Singapor and South Africa.

Tanzania and Yemen are also expected to join the economic grouping which eventually hopes to attract 32 countries with a combined population of 1.7 billion people and a gross national product of 1400 billion dollars and a per capita income of 700 dollars.

A working group consisting of the seven founding countries has just ratified the charter of the organization, drafted by India.

The working schedule, to be implemented as soon as the economic bloc is set up, has been prepared by Mauritius.

To date, trade exchanges within the countries of the Indian Ocean Rim Initiative represent about 20 per cent of their international trade.

Japan and Western Europe buy about 90 per cent of their oil and the United States imports more than 40 types of raw materials from the countries.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996

Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria and Liberia Bulk Challenge Finally Docks At Lagos Port


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 22, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The controversial Nigerian-registered vessel, Bulk Challenge, finally docked at the Apapa port in Lagos late Monday, after a two-week epic voyage from worn-torn Liberia.

The port's commandant, Ben Acholonu, said Tuesday the ship brought 46 passengers including 27 nigerian troops who are members of Ecomog, the West African peacekeeping force in Liberia. 

He said the Ecomog soldiers had been cleared and left for home, while the 19 civilian passengers were being detained by the port security.

Acholonu said the civilians were made up of 16 Liberians, two Guineans and one Sierra Leonean.

The West Africans, who claimed they were traders and refused to disembark in Ghana where more than 1,500 Liberian refugees disembarked, were being held for screening.

Rickety Bulk Challenge acquired notoriety for the long journey and her human cargo, most of whom were fleeing renewed fighting in Monrovia.

The ship docked temporarily in Cote d'Ivoire for the repair of a leak and was put to sea again.

She was allowed to dock in Tokoradi to unload much of her human cargo, after initially being turned away by Ghanaian authorities.

Accra said it had refused the ship berthing so as to stem the flood of refugees from Monrovia, where Ecomog is said to have provided a safe haven for the refugees.

Africa News


May, 1996


Tanzania 500 People Feared Drowned As Boat Capsizes In Lake Victoria


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 21, 1996 by Lwaga Mwambande, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 254 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania - Over 500 people were feared to have drowned when their boat capsized and sunk Tuesday in Lake Victoria, northern Tanzania.

Radio Tanzania reported that the vessel, Mv Bukoba, which plies between the ports of Mwanza on the southern part of Lake Victoria and Bukoba in northwest, had the capacity of carrying 500 passengers. 

It quoted survivors, in the worst accident in Tanzania's history, as saying that it was not possible to locate bodies of the victims because the boat was still sinking.

Rescue teams from the Tanzania police, the Tanzania Red Cross, armed forces and the Tanzania Railways Corporation (owners of the boat), were trying to recover bodies from the lake. But only 21 bodies had been recovered by 8 p.m. local time.

The cause of the accident, said to have happened around 14.00 GMT, has not been established.

The Tanzania government has announced three days of mourning.

Lake Victoria (266,828 sq. mi.) is the biggest lake in Africa and the third largest in the world. It is shared between three countries -- Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

15 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Parliament Expells Opposition MP


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 22, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 840 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Zambian parliament Wednesday expelled an opposition member of parliament, Akashambatwa Mbikisuta Lewanika, for alleged gross contempt and breach of its privileges.

Lewanika belongs to the National Party (NP), which together with the United Independence Party of former president Kenneth Kaunda, have 26 members of parliament.

Anouncing the expulsion, the speaker of parliament, told the house his exclusion was recommended by the standing orders committee, following Lewanika's letter which he cast aspersions on the integrity of the house. 

In his letter, written last March, Lewanika had disassociated himself from what he termed as "the deeply shameful" and "grossly unjust persecution of "Post" newspaper editors and a columnist.

He wrote the letter after parliament had sentenced the three to an indifinite jail term for contempt of the house, through their articles published last January. They were released in March.

Nabulyato said the standing orders committee took great exception to the accusations.

Lewanika's said in his letter that he "laid his hands off any association with acts related to the deeply shameful and grossly unjust persecution" of the three journalists by parliament.

According to Nabulyato "the assertions were derogatory to the dignity of the house and inconsistent with the standards which parliament was entitled to expect from members of parliament and have resolved that the honourable member (Mbikusita Lewanika) be expelled from the services of the house for the rest of the life of this parliament forthwith."

In addition, Lewanika had been given seven hours within which to show cause why he should not be subjected to the disciplinary proceedings of the house for his affront to the collective decision of the house.

Mbikusita Lewanika is member for Mongu in the politically conservative western region.

As the expelled member of parliament walked out, members of the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) shouted "shame, shame."

Mbikusita Lewanika's expulsion became the third of its kind in the history of the Zambian parliament.

The first was in 1968, four years after independence, when a member of the white Federal Party, Robert Malcomson, was "disciplined" for making racial slurs on African members.

He had said something to the effect that "Africans had been jumping from tree to tree not long ago," a reference to members of the then ruling United National Independence Party (UNIP) and the now defunct African National Congress (ANC) of the late Harry Mwaanga Nkumbula.

The second occured in 1970 when a veteran freedom fighter and nationalist, the late Mungoni Liso of the ANC, alleged that Kaunda's government had wasted money to hire concubines for leaders attending a Commonwealth meeting in Lusaka.

Several other members of parliament have been suspended in the past for various " less serious" offences.

One of them, a UNIP member, is still under suspension for allegedly lying to the house.

Mbikusita Lewanika loses his emoluments, rights and privileges as a result of the expulsion.

He is an outspoken critic of president Frederick Chiluba's government in which he was a cabinet minister until 1993 when he resigned, after accusing his cabinet colleagues of corruption and drug-trafficking.

Two weeks ago, Mbikusita Lewanika attacked the constitution amendment law which sought to bar some citizens from contesting the presidency.

He termed the document as a "chameleon and animal farm" type political deception which had no backing of the Zambian majority.

The amendment became law on Wednesday with an overwhelming 119-0 vote.

Mbikusita Lewanika is a member member of the Barotse royal establishment in Western Zambia, where some traditionalists are reportedly campaigning for secession from the rest of Zambia.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

16 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Parliament Enacts Constitutional Law


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 22, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga and Musengwa Kayaya


LENGTH: 534 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Zambian parliament Wednesday unanimously voted to enact a new constitution law that will bar former president Kenneth Kaunda and other Zambians whose parents were not born in Zambia from becoming president.

Under the new law, only Zambian citizens with both parents born in Zambia or are of Zambian descent will be eligible to run for the presidency.

It also bans citizens who have held the office twice before from becoming president. Traditional chiefs have also been banned from active partisan politics unless they resign their traditional posts. 

Other qualifications for the office of the president include attainment of the age of 35, membership of or sponsorship of a political party and good character.

A new requirement in the amended constitution is that the presidential candidate should have been domiciled in Zambia for a period of at least 20 years.

Kaunda had Malawian parents and held office for 27 years.

Chiluba is expected to sign the bill in June.

All the 119 members of parliament belonging to the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) of president Frederick Chiluba voted in favour. The two opposition parties represented in the house, Kaunda's United National Independence Party and the National Party, walked out of the house during voting time. There were no abstentions and votes against.

The bill has been described by the opposition, civil society organisations and other critics as discriminatory and a recipe for possible civil strife in the country.

The opposition Zambia Democratic Congress(ZDC), led by Dean Mung'omba, had earlier this year petitioned Zambian courts to rule against parliament's enactment of the constitutional amendment. An alliance of opposition parties opposed to the constitution last week said they would support the ZDC legal action.

Mung'omba Wednesday told Zambia national radio that his party would pursue all peaceful means to stop implementation of the new constitution.

He accused the ruling party of tailoring the country's supreme law to suit its own political expediency.

Chiluba recently took the constitutional debate to his MMD-dominated parliament in defiance of local and international calls to have it adopted by a constituent assembly in order to achieve wider consensus.

The ruling party has some 131 members of parliament in the 158-seat assembly.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Donors Approve 1.6 billion U.S. Dollars For African Bank


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 22, 1996


LENGTH: 507 words


 

ABIDJAN, Cote D'Ivoire - Non-regional shareholders of the African Development Bank have approved 1.6 billon U.S. dollars for the long-delayed replenishment of the African Development Fund, the concessional window of the continental finance institution.

The amount falls short of the 2.5 billion delegates had been trying to win in two-days of debate, ahead of the bank's 32nd annual general meeting which starts Wednesday in the Ivoirian capital.

But representatives of the 24 non-regional members said another one billion dollars, to be derived from the recycling of previous loans and money from unsubscribed shares, would be made available to bring the total to 2.6 billion dollars. 

The delegates, who are finance ministers and central bank governors, made the decision late Tuesday. They said the amount would be used "to support projects and programmes designed to reduce poverty and promote sound economic policy in the poorest countries of Africa through 1998."

The fund is supposed to be replenished every three years. The seventh replenishment was due in 1993. At the time, the former president of the bank, Babacar Ndiaye, estimated that the fund would require at least five billion dollars to be able to meet growing demands.

Non-regional states from the Americas, Asia, Caribbean, Europe and the Middle East held up replenishment of the fund until the bank carried out reforms and improved its management.

The new bank president, Omar Kabbaj of Morocco, had since initiated reforms. These include the removal of 20 percent of the staff across the board, reorganization of work methods and the improvement of its debt recovery mechanism.

Delegates said Wednesday they welcomed the "wide-ranging reforms underway in the bank to refocus its activities on priority needs and improve institutional efficiency and development impact."

Specifically, they cited the "sharpened institutional focus on human resource development, a far-reaching reorganization, adoption of a range of important financial reforms, including lending policies linked explicitly to borrower creditworthiness, and major steps to improve portfolio performance and address areas."

Of the 53 African members of the bank group 39 have failed to qualify for loans from the bank and have sourced interest-free investmant loans from the fund.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


18 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Kenya Kenyan Researcher Working On AIDS Vaccine


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 22, 1996


LENGTH: 560 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - A controversial Kenyan AIDS drug researcher, Prof.Arthur Othieno Obel, has said he is working on a vaccine against HIV/AIDS and that this time he intends to conform to scientific conventions.

In an interview published by a Nairobi paper, the Sunday Standard, the reseacher said he expects the vaccine to be ready "in the next six months."

Two months ago, Obel announced through the media that he had discovered an anti-AIDS treatment known as Pearl Omega. 

Since then, he has received a barrage of criticism from his professional colleagues, as well as support from non-scientists and leaders.

Obel told the Sunday Standard that in his new research, titled "Research Protocol on Proposed Development of AIDS Virus Vaccine", he intends to collaborate with institutions of repute to attain his goal.

"It is a hope that this vaccine, which will first be tried on Guinea pigs, will provide a lasting solution to the AIDS menace," said the researcher.

Obel said his proposal aims at eliminating HIV and AIDS from the face of the earth, as was the case with polio and typhoid among other previously catastrophic diseases.

Obel, chief government scientist in the office of the president, predicted that AIDS would be a thing of the past come the year 2,000. He however did not reveal the steps he was taking to manufacture the vaccine.

"The steps are very demanding in terms of both resources and brain work. This is a top notch exercise which I hope will succeed as the theoretical aspects of it appear logical and the rationale behind the work currently is foolproof," he told the Sunday paper.

Obel said the vaccine should be undergoing phase zero studies within the next three months.

Meanwhile, the Kenya Medical Practitioners and Dentists Board said Sunday that it was not after the formula of Prof Obel's Pearl Omega drug.

The board's chairman, Richrd Baraza, said his organzation was not interested in Obel's formula but wanted its efficacy established.

Two weeks ago, the board and the Kenya national AIDS committee summoned Obel to explain his unconventionally introduced drug. However, both meetings have been abruptly called off.

Detractors accuse him of not following scientific protocol while supporters insist that the embattled reseacher's drug should not be villified.

Since Obel announced the drug, his clinic at Commonwealth House in the Kenyan capital has reportedly witnessed an endless stream of patients.

"On Friday, my Commonwealth House international medical foundation offices were packed with patients from London, Brazil Botswana and Nigeria, just to name a few," Obel told journalists.

Africa News


May, 1996


Senegal and Central Africa Republic Senegal Calls For Peace In Bangui


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 22, 1996


LENGTH: 227 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - Senegal on Wednesday called on the people of the Central African republic, the international community and the OAU to restore peace in Bangui where the army mutinied on Saturday.

This is the second mutiny within a month. 

In an official statement released Wednesday in Dakar, the Senegalese government said the search for peace in Bangui is necessary to preserve the safety of people and goods, ensure the protection of foreign nationals and safeguard democracy in the country.

It is obvious that the new seeds of conflict being sown in Central Africa will seriously threaten all development policies for the continent, its populations and its youth, the statement stressed.

The situation in Bangui "is ripe with dangers not only for the Central African Republic but also for the whole central African region", the statement concluded.

According to the latest death toll by the country's Red Cross, 12 people are reported to have been killed. Property has also been looted.

Africa News


May, 1996


Central African Republic 13 American Evacuees Arrive In Yaounde


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 22, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon - Thirteen U.S. citizens evacuated from Bangui, the capital of the strife-torn Central African Republic, have arrived in Yaounde, Cameroon.

A statement released here Tuesday evening by the American embassy said the Americans were evacuated "as a precautionary measure and due to insecurity which is now prevailing in the Central African capital". 

The evacuees are U.S. government workers and citizens living in Bangui and their families.

Since the army mutinied Saturday in Bangui, some 1,000 foreign nationals have been assembled at the Mpoko airport under the protection of French and U.S. troops.

Bangui is still paralysed, with private transport and commercial activities grounded.

The few civilians who dare venture into the city's deserted streets are quickly deterred by the presence of armed soldiers in vehicles, according to eye witnesses interviewed on the phone by PANA.

Shops have remained closed following looting.

Fourteen people are reported to have died and some 100 others wounded in the violence, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross.

Africa News


May, 1996


Tanzania 100 Survive Tanzania's Worst Marine Accident


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 22, 1996 by Peter Tindwa, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 347 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania - At least 100 people have been rescued, so far, in Tanzania's worst ferry accident which occured in Lake Victoria.

The Tanzanian News Agency, SHIHATA, reported Wednesday that some of the survivors are receiving medical care at the Bugando Referral Hospital in Mwanza, on the southern shores of the lake. 

Survivors said there were about 40 secondary school students and 20 members of of the Mabatini Lutheran church choir on board. The sole survivor of this choir is Nasekile Mwakasege.

Rescue teams composed of soldiers, police, the Marine Services, the Tanzania Railways Corporation (owners of the vessel) had recovered 29 bodies by Wednesday.

At least 600 people are now feared dead.

SHIHATA's bureau in Mwanza reported Wednesday that the ferry, the MV Bukoba, was carrying about 700 people and an unspecified load of cargo. It went down at Karumo Gulf, about eight kilometres from Mwanza. It said it had a capacity for 400 passengers.

The ferry's captain, Reuben Rume, said he communicated with Mwanza Port at 7.30 a.m. and reported the ship's condition as safe. He told the port he would dock in Mwanza at 8 a.m.

A crew member of another ferry coming from Uganda, the MV Butiama, said the ship capsized a few minutes after 7.30 a.m.

The Butiama's captain radioed Mwanza of the accident and stayed near the scene.

Tanzanian President Benjamin Mkapa has announced three days of mourning beginning today. Flags will fly at half mast.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

22 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 24, 1996 by Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - Tuesday's ferry disaster on Lake Victoria and the revolt by some soldiers of the Central African Republic army, strained relations among the countries of the Great Lakes and Liberia's ongoing crisis, drew sharp responses from newspapers in Africa.

Kampala's state-owned daily, The New Vision, said that despite officials denials of overloading of the ferry the contrary appeared to be case.

"Should this turn out to be true, then the authorities in Tanzania should have a more critical look at the whole transport industry and take corrective action," it said.

"This, of course, does not apply to Tanzania alone. Most countries in the region, Uganda inclusive, have been losing hundreds of their people in accidents on the roads, in the air and on water," it said. "In most cases the accusing finger points to laxity in the enforcement of safety standards." 

The profit motive, it said, was why vehicles were not serviced correctly, or frequently in Africa.

Often, it added, public transport that are too old "are kept on the roads, in the air and on the lakes, hoping that God's mercy will keep them afloat."

The result, it said, was "countless accidents."

Whatever the cause of the ferry accident, it said, "the casualty rate has exposed our nakedness in our inability to handle disasters of this nature."

Dakar's Sud Quotidien commented on the army revolt in Central African Republic: Evidence, it said, of "kaki (military) contamination" of Africa's democratic process.

This is in reference to the resurgence of military governments and revolts on the continent.

"The crisis in Central Africa underlines the degree to which the quiet giant (the army) has impeded the democratic process which she has still not yet accepted,"

L' Observateur, a Bujumbura newspaper in strife-torn Burundi, commented on the strained relations among Burundi, Rwanda and Zaire. It said the situation could lead to war.

Initially, the problem between Burundi and Zaire was one of "a crisis of confidence." This, it said, stemmed from "the (uninterupted) 30-year presidency of Mobutu Sese Seko and the relative instability of the Burundian president."

Moreover, it said, the relations between Mobutu and Burundi's first president, Michel Micombero, which was forged out of a common background and generation, "no longer prevails."

Instead, it said, "a pyschological crisis" exists between both countries. Mobutu, it said, "opposed democracy" as decided at the Francophone summit at La Baule while Burundi "rushed into this endless labyrinth."

On its relations with Rwanda, the newspaper added: "Kinshasa is increasingly disturbed by the presence of a regime in Kigali which owes it nothing and whose example might be followed in Bujumbura, because of imperialism."

The government-owned Zambia Daily Mail, published in Lusaka, and the Lagos-based National Concord, a private newspaper, were dismayed by Liberia's warlords and the country's recent boat people.

"The most enduring lesson of the Bulk Challenge saga is that governments in countries of the West African sub-region should intensiify efforts aimed at ending the Liberian civil war," the Concord said.

Otherwise, it said, "fall-outs in terms of unwanted refugees and threats to peace and stability in neighbouring countries will remain."

However, it added, while the crisis lasts "no government in the West African sub-region -- not least Nigeria's -- should attempt to bury its head in the sands by keeping out those who have chosen to flee that country."

It concluded: "Perhaps, a swarm of refugees from Liberia is all the rest of West Africa needs to drive home the message that whatever it takes, the war in Liberia must be brought to an end one way or the other."

The Mail said events in Liberia "are outright shameful and disgusting," to say the least.

"It is most saddening to note that while countries in the West African region are trying to grapple with their economic problems, these are being derailed by developments in Liberia," it continued.

This situation needs to be redressed, it added, so that these countries could attend to their internal problems.

"This is the same message that must go out to other hot spots such as Somalia, Rwanda, Burundi and, to some extent, Sudan, where those supposed to be leading the people are at loggerheads over petty issues," it said.

But the newspaper disagreed with those who have called for extra-continental bodies to solve this and other African problems.

"Africa has now reached a stage whereby she doesn't need the so-called superpowers to resolve her problems. That would be tantamount to recolonialisation.

"African problems must be addressed by the African governments themselves through the Organization of African Unity and not through the intervention of other powers," it said.

Nairobi's Daily Nation was critical of the new Zambian law passed by parliament which bars Zambians whose parents were born outside the country from contesting the presidency.

So Kenneth Kaunda, who was the country's first president, can no longer try for another term.

"We are concerned about what has happened in Zambia because it has happened here in Kenya, in neighboring Uganda and in several other African countries previously and will happen in the future as long as there are politicians who would rather use or misuse the law to keep their opponents away from their political mainstream," it said.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

23 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large ADB Assembly Ends In Ivory Coast


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 24, 1996 by Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast - The 32nd annual general meeting of the African Development Bank ended in Abidjan Thursday, with a commitment by its share holders to do everything to put the continent's premier financial institution on a sound footing.

Finance ministers and central bank governors, representing 53 African countries and 24 non-African countries, said they were happy that after two years of near stalemate the bank was now in a position to move forward, due to the 2.6 billion dollars promised by donors for the 7th replenishment of the ADB, from which 39 African countries source investment funds.

ABD president, Omar Kabbaj, told journalists at a press briefing that the African Development Fund (ADF) should be able to resume consideration of loan applications as from June. 

But he warned : "We are going to work more like a bank than a humanitarian organization."

Kabbaj said both Africa and the bank will now move from stagnation to growth.

He said non-regional governors would meet in Osaka next month, at the instance of Japan, to consider additional contributions to the ADF.

New contributions plus the new replenishment should make it possible for the ADF and the ADB loan windows to provide loans amounting to about 2.2 billion dollars a year. This would be some 800 million dollars lower than the amount the bank could give out in its hey-days, but not too bad considering that the Asian Development Bank which is operating under more favorable economic conditions disburses some four billion dollars in loans annually.

Kabbaj also stressed the need for the African members of the bank to pay up arrears amounting to 800 million dollars. He said non-payment of these arrears, owed by some 25 countries could harm the credit rating of the bank, which has so far been good.

The issue of arrears will be a major topic on the agenda of a meeting called by Gabonese President Omar Bongo, for July 6-7 in Libreville for African leaders.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Swaziland 200 Workers Strike South African Firm


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 24, 1996 by Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 414 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland - Some 200 employees of the South African construction company, N.D. Engineering, building a giant pulp company in Swaziland went on strike Thursday over a pay dispute.

Witnesses said the strikers, armed with iron bars, sticks and lengths of timber, prevented some 700 other local and expatriate workers employed by other contractors from entering the project site after their lunch break.

Usutu Pulp Companay security guards stood by but did not intervene. There were several angry verbal exchanges between the strikers and other workers but no violent incidents were reported. 

The action began following a lunchtime meeting by Swazi casual workers and company officials.

The project is a 200-million-rand (45.66 million U.S. dollars) expansion works at the Usutu Pulp Company at Bhunya, Western Swaziland. The firm is operated by the South African Company, Sappi.

Work throughout the rest of Usutu Company premises, including the mill not connected with the expansion contract site, continued through the afternoon uninterrupted. No comment could be obtained from the contractors up to late Thursday.

Usutu Pulp Company is one of the stongholds of the Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions. It has called for nationwide worker stayaways over the past 12 months. The union's aim is to pressure the non-party Swaziland government to meet 27 labour and political demands.

A senior Usutu Pulp Company official expressed fear Thursday that unless the isolated dispute between the particular contractor company and its local workers is resolved speedily, sympathy strike action within the Usutu Pulp Company could result.

Indeed, a resumption of industrial unrest and mass action by the trade unions is the last thing the government wants at this crucial time. That is because King Mswati is rounding off a two-week trade promotion trip to Kuwait and mainland China in an effort to attract badly needed foreign investors.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Master Plan To Combat Crime In South Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 24, 1996 by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 454 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South Africa has unveiled a master plan to combat high crime levels that are threatening foreign confidence and investment in the country's economy.

The new National Crime Prevention Strategy -- approved Thursday by the cabinet -- was unveiled by Deputy President Thabo Mbeki. It will concentrate on a new approach, switching police action from crime control to crime prevention. 

"It is public knowledge that our democratic government inherited a terrible legacy from our past, of which crime is just one aspect," Mbeki said.

This is South Africa's first comprehensive national plan to crack crime in the country. Several government departments will work together to eliminate seven main areas of crime: firearms, organiszed crime, white collar crime, gender violence, violence and crime against children, violence resulting from inter-group conflict, and vehicle theft and hijacking.

The plan has been unanimously endorsed by South Africa's main political parties.

The African National Congress described the strategy as "a quantum leap forward in the ongoing fight against crime".

The National Party leader and outgoing deputy president, Frederik De Klerk, Said: "Crime and violence have been hanging like a dark shadow over our country for much too long."

His party, he said, supported the plan but would watch over its implementation like a hawk.

Inkatha Freedom Party leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi also endorsed the plan, saying he would do everything in his power as Home Affairs Minister to promote it.

Support has also come from the South African business sector, whose Business Against Crime Organization describes the new initiative as "a major step towards a coherent government approach on the prevention of crime."

The anti-crime document says the plan represents a turning point in the battle against crime.

"The strategy is based on the view that we need to build a new society, rather than simply normalise something which was never normal," it says.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Kenya Kenyan Naval Officers Sent To Site of Ferry Disaster


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 24, 1996 by Sam Mugo, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 267 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - Kenya sent 16 naval officers to Mwanza Friday to help recover bodies from a sunken ferry near this Tanzania port city on Lake Victoria.

President Daniel Arap Moi said in Nairobi that the officers, from the Kenya Navy, were experienced in rescue and retrieval operations. 

Another team of Kenyan divers arrived in Mwanza Thursday and immediately set out to the scene of the accident.

An official of the Tanzania Red Cross, Msafari Luhega, was quoted as saying that the Kenyans were well equipped.

"We know things will now move faster," he said.

Marine salvage experts from Kenya's sea port city of Mombasa are also on site. They were called by Tanzania to help retrieve the ferry, the M.V. Bukoba, which sank Tuesday with 661 people aboard and about eight kilometres short of its destination. Rescuers say 114 of these were saved.

A two-man crew from Divecon, a company which specialises in underwater cutting equipment, left Mombasa Thursday for the disaster site.

The team helped salvage Kenya's M.V. Mtongwe, a ferry that capsized in Mombasa in 1994 killing hundreds.

Another Kenyan Salvage Company, Murri International, has offered to help.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


27 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Lagos Residents Seek Refuge Behind Street Gates


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 27, 1996 by Chike Okocha, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 854 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Ndu Nwike, a lawyer who lives at Ejigbo, a Lagos suburb, was entertaining business associates and friends in his sitting room when armed robbers stormed his apartment.

Within minutes, the bandits ransacked the house, taking away valuables.

Nwike's terrified guests were not spared. The robbers took away their watches, jewels and other personal effects. 

In addition to losing his gold watch, one guest received matchet cuts for "not having money," on him.

The robbers fled in a car they had snatched in the neighborhood.

This incident sent shock waves in the neighborhood. Although neighbors reported the robbery to the police, the robbers were never caught.

Similar robberies are common in Lagos, Nigeria's economic hub, with an estimated six million people.

To protect themselves, residents have resorted to erecting gates at the entrance to their streets. Almost every street has one or more gates which are locked or unlocked at specified periods during the day.

"The gates are serving their purposes, although robbers still manage to gain entry into some areas," says Vincent Beassingar, who mans a street gate in Okota, an outskirt of Lagos.

"Armed robbers are now afraid to raid areas with gates because of the risk of getting stuck, and the residents are happier for it."

Ime Eze, a supermarket owner agrees that the gates have effectively checked the activities of night marauders.

"If anything, the theft of vehicles packed in their owners' compounds at night has been reduced to the barest minimum as a result of the gates," she added.

It is becoming a security risk for one to live in an area without the gates, she said.

But not every Lagos resident is comfortable with the street gates.

While not denying their usefulness in crime prevention, critics see many disadvantages of the gates.

For instance, they argue that some residents suffer a lot of inconvenience when they are locked out when they come home late.

Perhaps this prompted the public relations officer of the Lagos state police, Partrick Erhabor, to appeal to vigilante groups who man the gates to extend the time for locking the gates. He said early closures could be counter-productive.

A man who spoke on condition of anonymity also said the gates prevent law enforcement agents from answering distress calls by residents.

"When robbers came to my house last year, my junior brother sneaked out in time to alert the police. But they could not come early enough because all the gates on the roads leading to my compound were locked," he said.

The Lagos state commissioner of police, James Danbaba, shares this view.

He has described the erection and locking up of street gates as illegal.

The police have asked local governments to dismantle immediately the inhibiting structures, he said.

"The very existence of the gates has hampered the effective patrol of many neighborhoods where criminals hide," the police chief said.

He also said that some dubious vigilante groups inform armed robbers about the movemment of police patrol teams. Some of the vigilantes had been arrested with armed robbers.

"We have begun discussion with relevant government organs in the state on the matter, and we have found out that no group has the power to lock up a street to inconvenience others," the police commissioner said.

A local government staff, who refused to disclose his identity, said the councils "should not tell the residents how best to protect themselves when it is glaring that the police alone cannot contain the menace of the robbers."

However, the Lagos state military administrator, Col. Olagunsoye Oyinlola, recently launched "operation sweep", involving the deployment of about 4,000-strong joint police and military task-force. Armed robbers are in for hard times.

But some residents are sceptical. They prefer, instead, the relative security offered by street gates.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


28 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Crime Skyrockets In South Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 27, 1996 by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 280 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Capital offenses in South Africa have more than doubled since the lifting of the death penalty six years ago.

Figures released by the South African Police Service and the Central Statistical Service show that just under 19,000 murders were reported in South Africa last year, compared with 11,750 in 1989 when the death penalty was still in force. 

Armed robberies - including car hijacking - more than doubled from 30,500 in 1989 to almost 67,000 in 1995. Rapes and attempted rapes rose from 20,500 to almost 37,000 last year -- an increase of some 85 percent.

At the same time, the ability of the justice system to bring murderers, armed robbers and rapists before the courts has dropped from a success rate of almost 50 per cent to a mere 15 percent.

The figures show that only 10 per cent of armed robbers are being prosecuted in South Africa, 25 per cent of all rapists and 30 per cent of murderers.

Meanwhile it was announced on Friday that South Africa is to launch a master plan to combat the country's high crime levels, which are threatening foreign confidence and investment in the South African economy.

The new National Crime Prevention Strategy will concentrate on a new approach, switching police action from crime control to crime prevention.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


29 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Ethiopia Ethiopia To Mark Fifth End of War Anniversary


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 27, 1996 by Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 640 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Ethiopians observed Tuesday the fifth anniversary of the fall of the Marxist-military regime of Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam.

The day also marked the end of 30 years of civil war, the restoration of peace, as well as the advent of democracy, after centuries of feudal-monarchical donimation and 17 years of misrule by a military dictatorship.

In the early hours of May 28, 1991, a coalition of regional guerrillas, fighting under the umbrella of the the Ethiopian Peoples' Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) took Addis Ababa, which they had besieged for several days. Mengistu's war-weary huge army was in disarray and offered little or no resistance to the rebels. 

A day before, the guerillas and the crumbling Mengistu government had attended a peace conference in London, under the auspices of the U.S government.

As the peace conference was about to start, the American mediator, former U.S. assistant secretary of state for African affairs, Herman Cohen, announced on May 27 that it had been found prudent to let EPRDF forces to enter Addis Ababa to avert bloodshed and the looting of the city by Mengistu's army.

Mengistu had by then fled into exile in Harare, Zimbabwe, on May 21. He was replaced by Lt. Gen. Tesfaye Gebre-Kidan, then his deputy, as acting president. He ordered the troops to surrender their arms and let the advancing rebel forces enter the city.

The same night, Gen. Tesfaye sought refuge in the Italian embassy in Addis Ababa, where he is still staying together with two other senior colleagues of the former regime.

On the basis of the Lodon peace conference, the EPRDF assumed power as an interim government. A five-day national peace conclave, in which all opposition factions participated, was held in early July, leading to the creation of a transitional administration.

Meles Zenawi served as president of the transitional government for four years. He was sworn in as executive prime minister in August 1995 after multiparty elections were held under a newly promulgated constitution devolving power to nine ethnic-based regional states.

Meles introduced a five-year program which seeks to make the country, once synonymous with cyclical drought and famine, self-sufficient in food by the year 2,000.

Ahead of Tuesday's event, the government-owned English language daily, the Ethiopian Herald, said in its Sunday editorial that five years after the end of the civil war, the country is finaly at peace with itself.

"Above everything else, perhaps, Ethiopia remains a single entity. None of the fragmentation, even complete disintegration, predicated by the doomsayers has come to pass.

Instead, the regional states work hand in hand to build a stronger and more robust Ethiopia with devotion to duty that finds strength from mutual respect," the Herald wrote.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Varsity Teachers' Union Sues Govt Over Ban


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 27, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The Academic Staff Union of Univesities (ASUU) has taken the Nigerian military government to court for banning the striking union two weeks ago.

The union launched its strike April 9 to press for better pay and improved funding of the universities based on a 1992 agreement with the government. 

After stalemated negotiations, the government on May 15 banned all national unions in Nigeria's estimated 40 universities.

It accused the unionists of disrupting academic work and industrial harmony on the campuses. The striking teachers' pay had been frozen, while union activities were restricted to individual universities.

But in its suit, filed by lawyer Olasupo Ojo at a Lagos high court, ASUU is contesting its dissolution, which it called "illegal and unlawful," and wants the court to declare the government action null and void.

The union also wants the court to restain the national universities commission from stopping the teachers' pay or ejecting them from their official residential quarters.

ASUU is further praying the court to stop government or its agents from "harassing, intimidating, arresting or detaining" the lecturers.

No date has been fixed for hearing of the case, which observers say could further compound the dispute and cause more disruptions to campus academic work.

Meanwhile, the Nigerian education minister, Mohammed Liman, has reportedly ruled out resumption of negotiations with the striking teachers.

He told protesting teachers of the Bayero University, Kano, northern Nigeria, on Sunday to call off the strike before asking for dialogue with the government.

Liman was a lecturer at the university before he was appointed minister last year.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


31 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria U.N. Comments On Nigeria's Human Rights, Democracy


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 27, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 627 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations - The United Nations recent fact-finding mission to Nigeria has said the country's transition program to democracy "seems genuine" and warned against any attempt to interrupt or reverse the momentum.

In a 24-page report, submitted to U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the four-member mission also warned against the imposition of sanctions on the country "at this stage."

Nigeria has been under international pressure over the 1995 executions for murder of nine minority rights leaders, including author Ken Saro-Wiwa. 

The U.N. mission, which visited Nigeria at the invitation of the military government from March 29 to April 12, said imposition of sanctions could retard the progress toward positive improvement.

The mission, headed by a Togolese jurist, Atsu-Koffi Amega, said there was a general opposition to any sanctions against Nigeria.

"It was pointed out that sanctions would hurt only ordinary people and have a negative impact not only on the Nigerian society but also on the whole west African region," it said.

The report said "our meetings and discussions with Gen. Sani Abacha and others have given us the impression that the head of state is sincere in his commitment to restore civil democratic rule by Oct. 1 1998."

"While at the moment the opponents of the regime refuse to cooperate with or participate in the election process, the mission feels that this rigid posture would soften if confidence-building measures are taken by the government, the report added.

The mission's recommendations included strengthening the committees and commissions established to usher in democratic rule, inviting international observers to monitor the process and releasing all persons detained under Decree 2 of 1984.

The removal of restrictions on political and professional associations, freedom of the press, and ensuring respect for judgments of the courts, are some of the other measures.

On the trial and execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight others, the mission recommended the repeal or amendment of the civil disturbance act under which the men were tried.

The mission also recommended that the government should consider establishing a panel of eminent jurists to look into financial relief for the dependents of the deceased, as well as how to improve the socio-economic conditions of the Ogonis.

The mission's report was sent to Gen. Sani Abacha through a U.N. special envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, who visited Nigeria May 10-14.

The Abacha goverment has already conveyed to the U.N. secretary-general its willingness to implement a significant part of the recommendations, and has indicated that it was considering other aspects of the report.

In a letter to the secretary-general, Abuja said it would amend the civil disturbances act (special tribunal) to exclude members of the military from serving on it and allow for appeals against its verdict.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
