32 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Uganda Museveni Says "No" To Appointing Northerners To Cabinet


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 27, 1996


LENGTH: 427 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda - Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni has said he will not appoint ministers from his country's north where he polled poorly in the May 9 election.

Speaking at a thanksgiving service in Luwero, 65 kilometres north of Kampala, Museveni said he will not share "the political cake" with areas that voted against him, but will give them "some bits of the development cake".

Luwero town is located within the famous "Luwero Triangle", the stronghold of Museveni's National Resistance Army (NRA) during its five-year guerilla war against the governments of President Milton Obote and Tito Okello Lutwa, from 1981 to 1986. 

"When it comes to the political cake, it is another matter. Where do we get a minister from? it will mainly be according to the inputs of votes," Museveni told a huge gathering comprising of his former campaign managers and diplomats.

The people of northern Uganda overwhelmingly noted against Museveni in the may elections but he nevertheless won the polls with 74.2 percent overall.

"Now people are waiting for Kony to come from Sudan and take over government. Let them wait, that is when they will share the political cake," Museveni said.

Joseph Kony's Lord's Resistance army (LRA), who are said to be operating from neighboring Sudan, campaigned for Museveni's main opponent, Paul Ssemwogerere, who defeated Museveni in most parts of northern Uganda.

However, Museveni said people who voted against him should not worry about "the political cake", saying his government will reward them with "the development cake" by constructing roads in their areas.

"Those who did not vote for me should not worry because the president is for all people even those in prison," he said.

"It is a constitutional right not to vote for Museveni but not a crime. It is a preference though it can be wrong politically," he added.

Museveni will appoint his new government after the parliamentary elections due on June 27.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


33 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large African Development Bank And The Poor Man's Bank


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 28, 1996 by Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

ABIDJAN, Cote d'Ivoire - One would have thought that the unprecedented reforms pushed through by the new management of the Abidjan-based African Development Bank in the last six months were enough to pacify its financiers, who seem to be bent on taking control of the institution.

This has not been the case, judjing by the decisions reached by its shareholders last week in the Ivorian capital.

Bank president Omar Kabbaj told the gathering institutional and managerial reforms had cut administrative costs by 15 percent. Some 250 staff, 70 percent at the management level had been fired. Bad loans running into millions of dollars were cancelled. In short, there has been a complete overhaul of the way the bank does business, he said. 

Part of the reward was the consent to replenish the African Development Fund (ADF), the concessional loan affiliate of the bank delayed for 30 months. But the 2.6 billion dollars donors would provide over a period of two-and-a-half years to 1998, fell far short of the 3.5 billion dollars provided for the sixth replenishment of the fund which was used up in 1993.

Besides, the 24 non-regional members who grudgingly agreed to cough out the amount, may not do so until they secure an equal stake in the 33-year-old bank.

At issue is a recent report which, among other things, recommended a 50-50 percent shareholding for the 24 non-African and 53 African members of the bank. This would reverse the existing capital structure of the bank which gave regional members 66 percent and 34 percent for non-regional members.

Key African members opposed the deal, and only the timely intervention of Gabonese President Omar Bongo averted an imminent stand-off between the two sides.

Bongo has convened a "special summit" of African leaders for June 7, in Libreville, to thrash out the issue of governance, as well as problems arising from huge arraes owed to the bank by some 25 African countries.

Analysts say the Libreville meeting is historically significant in the sense that it was in the Gabonese capital that talks about opening the capital of the bank to foreigners commenced 18 years ago.

The ADB was established in 1963, and was wholly African until 1982 when it began to admit non-regional members, who took up one-third of its shares thus boosting increasing the capital base, which now stands at some 24 billion dollars.

Its statutory goals include providing loans and equity investment for the economic and social development of African countries. The bank uses its call-up capital to support loans from international finance markets for on-lending the members countries at prevailing market rates.

The Bank group includes the ADF set up 1972, with subscribed shares estimated at 11.5 billion dollars at the end of 1995. It is owned by the ADB and 24 countries from the America's, Asia, Europe and the Middle-East. The Fund provides interest-free loans to poorer African countries which number 39 at percent. It is supposed to be replenished after every three years.

The third affiliate is the Nigerian Trust Fund (NTF), set up by Nigeria in 1976, to assist the development efforts of less endowed regional members. The NTF resources were 440 million dollars at the end of last year.

The ADB group was a net creditor to African countries in the 1980s, providing credit lines averaging 3 billion dollars per annum in its heydays, a fact which helped win her three tripple 'a' ratings in 1984, which it still maintains.

However, the Bank has suffered considerable decline this decade, comparable only to the economic difficulties facing most of its regional members.

Its loan portfolio has plummeted by more than half. Debts were mounting as fast as its coffers went drying up, prompting drastic reforms, and the ongoing move to change its capital structure.

One of the arguments proponents of the 50-50 capital structure advance is that it would give the bank a wider financial base needed to make it competitive in the increasingly liberalised and market-oriented global financial market.

But critics say this is far from the point, suggesting that donors simply want to grab the bank and use it to serve their interest.

Nigerian finance minister, Anthony Ani, reiterated a long-standing position of his country to maintain the African character of the institution.

"Personally I believe that 33 percent shares held by the non-regionals in the Bank should be enough for them.. Afterall, they contol the African Development Fund already," he said.

Besides, the proposal on governance carry fundamental political implications which border on the very raison d'etre of the bank, Ani said. He suggested that the move be deferred pending full consultations of all members.

If funding is the problem, he said, Nigeria was willing to acquire the shares of poor African countries and wharehouse it for them until a time they were ready to pay and reclaim them.

Supporting this view, Kenya's deputy finance minister, Keah Benedict, questioned the excessive bias against Africans in the report, saying it consistently proposed reduction in the number of regional directors only.

"We are also pained to note that in several sections, the report has anti-African and even insulting references, which are in my view without any foundation and which should be objected to strongly," he added.

Meanwhile, other regional delegates say president Kabbaj, who supports the proposal to change the ownership structure of the bank, is receiving so much unqualified support from the non-regional delegates that they have begun to suspect there is a hidden agenda somewhere along the line.

"The rate of cooperation and praise singing is very suspicious and may not bode well for the ADB as an African development institution," a delegate who does not want to be identified said.

According to him, if Africans lose ownership of the Bank through equities and restructuring, they also lose control of the objectives and destiny of the Bank.

"What is at stake is the huge amount of money annually expended by the Bank for the acquisition of machinery and equipment and projects consultancy running into millions of U.S. dollars" one African finance analyst told PANA.

Yet, others wonder why the ADB structure should be different from other multilateral development banks such as the Inter-American Development Bank and the Asian Development Bank.

Even so, analysts say these arguments sound as logical as they appear outlandish in relation to the predicament facing the ADB.

"The African Development Bank can only remain African if Africans are ready to fund it," they added.

May, 1996


Africa-at-Large CFA Drops To An All-Time Low


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 120 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The CFA franc depreciated to an all-time low this week, opening Tuesday at the nominal rate of 522.2 to one U.S. dollar. 

Currency watchers attribute the fall of the currency, in use in 13 French-speaking African countries, to the appreciation of the greenback in relation to other major currencies including the French franc.

The French treasury in Paris has guaranteed the convertibility and rate of the CFA (African Finance Community) since 1948. The African currency was devalued by 50 percent in 1994 and now exchanges at 100 to one French franc.

May, 1996


Nigeria Shares Remain Bullish At Nigerian Stock Exchange


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 28, 1996 by Paul Okolo, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 334 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The Nigerian Stock Exchange ended strongly last week, with the all-share index moving up 68.85 points.

The index, which opened at 5581.01 on Monday closed at 5649.92 on Friday, down from the 137.07 points it gained in the preceding week. 

Analysts said the index movement was curtailed in the week in review because of the adjustment for dividend and bonus issue by big quoted companies.

In the week, Nigerian Breweries Limited and Guinness, two brewing giants which are among the largest quoted companies by market capitalisation, saw their prices adjusted to make room for dividend payments.

Some 22.3 million shares changed hands in 957 deals worth 105.6 million naira (1US dollar = 82.5 naira).

These were figures for the Lagos, Ibadan, Onitsha, Kaduna and Port Harcourt floors of the exchange.

Lagos, the main trading floor, recorded 870 deals for 19.2 million shares valued at 68.9 million naira.

In volume terms, the insurance sector led the market, trading 15.5 million shares worth 40.3 million naira.

Price gains remained strong with National Oil posting two naira to top the chart of upward moving stocks.

It closed at 34.50 naira from Monday's opening of 32.50 naira because of investors' positive perception following the company's impressive full year result, announced recently.

Union Dicon Salt, lost 4.37 naira to finish at 27.01 naira.

Kenya Trading Drops At Nairobi Stock Exchange


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 28, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent by Sam Mugo, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 240 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - Trading at the Nairobi Stock Exchange dropped in the week ending Friday, with 871,000 shares worth 32 million shillings (58.20 Kshs = 1 USD) traded, compared with the previous week's high of 1.2 million shares worth 48 million shillings.

Stock brokers said share prices remained stable while the NSE index closed 4.59 points lower than the previous week's close of 3,030. 

They said the drop in share turnover represented a 32.9-percentage fall over the previous week's returns.

Market analysts, Loita Asset Management Limited, said the market's gain was largely in industrials where East African Portland Cement, Carbacid and Total Oil led the way.

Commercials suffered the most significent reverses largely due to profit takings.

Financials and agricualturals also slipped again.

Kenya Oil Company (KENOL) last week, asked to be de-listed from the Exchange. The company's directors gave no reason for wanting to revert to private company status.

Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Mixed Reactions To U.N. Mission's Report On Nigeria


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 28, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 640 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerians are divided over the report of the recent United Nations fact-finding mission, which gave qualified support to the military government's transition programme to democracy.

Opposition members have rejected the report, while pro-government groups say they are satisfied. For a third group, "caution" is the word. 

The 24-page report of the four-member U.N. team, released at the weekend in New York, said the 36-month political transition programme by Gen. Sani Abacha seemed genuine and should not be disrupted.

It also opposed the call for sanctions against Nigeria, saying this could be counter-productive. However, it urged the military administration to release all political detainees and improve its human rights record.

The Abacha government has responded with the announcement of some political and judicial reforms.

But the Committee for Defence of Human Rights in Nigeria described the U.N. report as "heart-rendering and sad."

It said that it was "incredible" that the mission made such recommendations "when there was clear evidence that the military regime had intensified violations of rights in an unprecedented manner, not withstanding global condemnations."

The wife of detained millionaire-politician Moshood Abiola, Kudirat, also rejected the finding.

Her view is shared by another opposition politician, Remi Okunrinboye.

"Any programme without M.K.O. Abiola's release will be jaundiced," she said.

Abiola, the undeclared winner of the 1993 presidential election annulled by the last military regime, is facing trial for treasonable felony after declaring himself president of Nigeria in June 1994.

But Adekunle Ajasin, a former civilian governor and now a key official of the opposition democratic coalition called NADECO, was cautious in his reaction. He said he needed "more time for wider consutlation."

Another politician, Doyin Okupe, said it was within the prerogative of the U.N. to "endorse whatever it liked."

Abel Ubeku, the spokesman of the Political Group Committee for National Consensus, expressed happiness at the report.

"It showed that the U.N. knows that Nigerians are capable of sorting out their problems," he said.

Nigeria has been embroiled in political crisis over the 1993 annulled presidential election.

International pressure on the country heightened following the November 1995 executions for murder of nine Nigerian minority rights leaders, including author Ken Saro-Wiwa.

It was to douse the tension that Nigerian invited the U.N. to a fact-finding mission in Nigeria. The team's visit lasted from March 29 to April 12.

The mission addressed the trial that led to the executions and also assessed Abacha's political transition programme, which critics consider too long.

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Chiluba Signs Constitutional Bill


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 28, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 454 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - President Frederick Chiluba signed the constitutional amendment bill Tuesday to effect Zambia's new constitution that will bar citizens whose parents were born outside the country from becoming president.

The new constitution also officially recognises Zambia as "a Christian nation tolerant of other religions."

Chiluba put his signature to the bill at a ceremony at state house witnessed by hundreds of party officials of his ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy. The ceremony was covered live by the national radio and television. 

Excited supporters of the new law honked their car horns, blew whistles and beat drums as Chiluba signed the bill at 1100 gmt.

The new constitution prevents former President Kenneth Kaunda, who is of Malawian parents, from challenging Chiluba in this year's scheduled presidential elections.

Chiluba said that his agreement to sign the bill did not mean Zambia would be intolerant of other religions. He said that the law was not specifically aimed at the former head of state.

He appealed to Zambians to cooperate with law and security enforcement agents to thwart possible violent reaction by some political parties and other groups opposed to the constitution.

A clandestine group, calling itself the Black Mamba, and variously linked to local opposition parties and Islamic militants, has threatened to harm Chiluba and his members of parliament for passing the law.

The MMD-dominated parliament enacted the constitution last week.

The Central Committee of the main opposition United National Independence Party of Kaunda were reported Tuesday to be arranging for an emergency meeting to plan a new program of action.

Sources at the party's headquarters in the capital, Freedom House, told PANA that the meeting would be chaired by Kaunda. The former president is expected to arrive in the capital Tuesday from a three-week visit to Canada.

Opposition parties have vowed to challenge and breach the new law. The Zambia Democratic Congress, earlier Tuesday, lost an application to the Supreme Court to bar Chiluba from signing the law.

Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large OAU Chief Says Unity Can Solve Africa's Problems


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 23, 1996 by Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Organization of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim said Thursday that member states should rededicate themselves to the ideals of Pan-Africanism and unity in ending the continent's conflicts.

"This is the time to remind ourselves of our collective and individual commitments to the organization," he said. 

His appeal came on the eve of the 33rd anniversary of the signing of the organisations charter. The occasion, known as Africa Day, is celebrated each year.

His message spoke of Africa's "unfinished business" of unity. That ideal is for African states to gradually work toward a single continental government.

Salim said that during this year's observance of Africa Day, Africans must reflect on their achievements, and not just on war and political instability in Burundi, Liberia and Somalia.

Africans, he said, were making efforts to promote economic integration, consolidate democracy and end conflicts.

He described fighting in Liberia as the latest "vicious and senseless war" in West Africa. But it had "elicited a collective and honourable response from the states in the region."

He said an immediate cease-fire was needed in Monrovia and for all armed elements to leave the city. That way, Monrovia would regain its status as a "safe haven."

He appealed to Burundi's leaders to negotiate with rebels and save the country from growing degeneration. The international community, he said, had limited patience.

He said the country's leaders should accept the peace proposal laid out by Tanzania's first president, Julius Nyerere.

Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large African University In Pipeline


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 23, 1996 by Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 587 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The foundation stone and monument of the future African university will be laid Friday at Sebikotane, 35 kilometers south-east of Dakar, the Senegalese capital.

The proposed bilingual (English and French) institution is to be erected on the location of the former William Ponty School, which produced eminent West African scholars, including the late Ivorian President Felix Houphouet-Boigny.

The foundation stone laying ceremony will be among the highlights of an international conference of African intellectuals and scholars which entered its third day in Dakar Thursday. 

The intellectuals are trying to shape Africa's position in the 21st century on various crucial aspects, including integration, so as to be competitive in the emerging global economy.

Asked to explain the mechanisms of setting up the the African university, Mamadou Diouf, a history professor at Dakar's Cheikh Anta Diop university, said initially sections of Senegalese academic institutions would be reshaped and upgraded to play a regional role.

The university, which will have branches in several parts of Africa, would admit the best working graduate students from all over Africa, he said.

The students would be given top-notch training as a way of building and maintaining their capacities.

Diouf said the teaching body of the proposed institution would be constituted by non-permanent staff.

"Instead, high-calibre lecturers would be engaged on short contracts," he said.

The proposed institution would be structured along the lines of the University of West Indies, which has campuses in Jamaica, Barbados, and Trinidad and Tobago. It would be funded by states and institutions which send students on a cost-sharing basis.

"This will enable African governments and institutions to cut costs instead of having to send their students for higher training abroad," said Diouf.

Asked whether the university would not face funding problems like a host of many other African institutions, Diouf said: "We need to have funds for at least 20 years before launching it."

He said before the institution takes off, there must be a foundation catering for the pure and social sciences, to avoid falling into what he termed as the "donors syndrome."

He said Africans are capable of raising the required funds "provided the institution is removed from partisan politics and that's why there must be no permanent staff."

However, Diouf could not state exactly when the university would take off."We really need to make proper planning to avoid false starts," he added.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Three Day National Mourning For Azikiwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 23, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - As tributes pour in from across the world, Nigeria's military government has declared a three-day national mourning beginning Thursday for the country's late and first president, Nnamdi Azikiwe.

The military ruler, Gen Sani Abacha, told a delegation of Azikwe's family Wednesday that Nigeria's flag would also fly at half-mast for seven days. 

He described the May 11 death of Azikwe, 91, as "a great loss" not only to Nigeria but the whole of Africa.

The passing of the "Great Zik of Africa", as he is fondly known, was formally announced Tuesday by his family in accordance with the tradition of his kinsmen from eastern Nigeria.

An icon of Nigeria's independence, Azikiwe was governor-general of the country from 1960 to 1963 and president from 1963 until the first military coup in 1966.

Azikiwe the statesman, nationalist, orator and sportsman is remembered as much for his political achievements as his journalistic skills.

Tributes have come from both his admirers and critics, who chided him for his philosophy of political compromise.

Emeka Ojukwu, who fell out with the statesman when the former led the eastern Nigeria's Igbo rebellion, kwown as the Biafra War of 1967-70, was philosophical in his tribute.

"Many have loved, many do love and many shall love Zik, but only a few can understand him," Ojukwu said.

The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Lagos, Olubunmi Okogie, said "a great star has fallen."

He described Azikiwe as "a man of many parts who made sure that his influence was greatly felt in different positions."

Tributes from outside the country included those of the Commonwealth secretary-general, Emeka Anyaoku, and Azikewe's alma mata, Lincoln University in Pennsylvania, U.S.A.

LANGUAGE: English

May, 1996


Kenya Kenya Appoints Human Rights Team


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 23, 1996


LENGTH: 133 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya - The Kenya government has appointed a nine-member committee to investigate complaints of alleged violation of fundamental human rights and freedoms in the country.

The committee, to be chaired by a renowned Kenyan scholar, Prof. Onesmus Mutungi, will investigate complaints of alleged injustice, abuse of power and unfair treatment of any person by a public officer in exercise of his official duties.

It will also educate the public on human rights and freedoms by such means as it deems fit, including publications, lectures and symposia.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Nigeria, Libya Want ADB To Maintain African Character


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 23, 1996 by Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 667 words


 

ABIDJAN, Cote d'Ivoire - Nigeria and Libya, two big stakers in the African Development Bank (ADB), have opposed the proposal to increase the shareholding of the bank's 24 non-regional members to 50 percent, thus bringing it at par with those of its 53 African members.

"I personally believe that the 33 percent shares held by the non-regionals in the bank should be enough for them... afterall, they control the African Development Bank already", Nigeria's finance minister, Anthony Anim, told the annual general meeting of the bank which entered its second day in the Ivorian economic capital on Thursday.

Deputy governor of Libya's central bank, Breni Egeli, supported the Nigerian position saying any increase in non-regional shares in the bank "will not be okay for Africa". 

Nigeria holds the highest share of 10.1 percent share in the bank in addition to establishing a soft loan window called the Nigeria Trust Fund now worth 440 million dollars. Libya falls just above the middle range of share holders with a 3.8 percent, behind such other big stakers as Egypt and Cote d'Ivoire.

In all, the 53 African members own 66 percent of the share capital of the bank as against some 34 percent for the 24 non-regionals from the Americas, Asia, Europe, the Caribbean and the Middle East.

A report on the governance of the bank being discussed at the ongoing general assembly suggested a number of options, key among them being that non-African members acquire the same amount of shares as the regionals, as well as have the same level of control over major bank decisions.

Most African delegates oppose the proposal but would not speak up in categorical terms.

"What we are concerned about is to increase the capital as soon as possible for the benefit of the members of the bank," said Egypt's governor, Hassan Ismael Mohammed.

He added that while it would be preferable to maintain the African identity of the bank, the challenge for now is to do so with support from the non-regionals.

Switzerland, a non-regional member, also agrees that the "outsiders" had already increased their leverage in the bank and that further equity control was not necessary.

Its governor, Nicholas Imboden, said a change in the character was a higher political issue that could only be handled by African leaders at the highest political level.

This issue has for years raised the question as to who really owns the bank, set up by African governments in 1963 to foster the social and economic development of individual countries and that of the continent as a whole.

Non-regional members, which were 25 until Yugoslavia disintegrated, joined the bank in July 1982 to help boost the bank's capital base and resource mobilisation. Thus, acquisition of one-third of the bank's shares in essence changed its profile to that of an international development bank though it still maintains its original name.

Besides, the non-regionals effectively control its soft loan window, the African Development Fund, from which some 39 African members source investment.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia UN Property Looted In War-Ravaged Liberia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 23, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 480 words


 

NEW YORK, - The United Nations has said some 80 percent of vehicles belonging to its Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) were looted at the height of the fighting which erupted in Monrovia April 6.

In a report to the security council the U.N. secretary-general, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, said the Liberian fighters also made away with telephones, computers, photocopiers, communications equipment and general consumables.

The secretary-general said Wednesday that UNOMIL was currently estimating the value of the looted goods and equipment, and that it would take at least three months to rebuild the mission's logistic base. 

"UNOMIL and all U.N. agencies have been systematically looted by fighters from all factions since April 6," he said, adding that "the fighters cleaned out all U.N. offices, damaged the buildings and looted U.N. warehouses."

UNOMIL was deployed to liberia in 1995 to assist the sub-regional peace monitoring force (ECOMOG), in the implementation of the Abuja peace accord, signed by the warring factions in the Nigerian capital last year.

Only five of the mission's 93 military observers have remained in the country after the others were evacuated to Freetown and Dakar during the fighting.

But despite the looting and threat to the lives of the U.N. observers, the secretary-general has recommended that the mission's mandate be extended for three months, until August 31.

In making the recommendation, to the security council, he said though there was little that UNOMIL could do under the unstable situation in Liberia, it could still use its good offices to facilitate efforts to restore the peace process.

On the renewed fighting, the secretary-general accused the faction leaders of disregarding the will of their people for peace.

"Over the past six weeks, the faction leaders have clearly demonstrated their disregard for the aspirations of the Liberian people for peace," he said. "They have shown wanton disrespect for the U.N., ECOWAS and the international community."

He warned the faction leaders that if, through their actions, they forced ECOMOG to withdraw from Liberia, the U.N. would also end its mission in the country.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Central African Republic Congo Supports French Intervention


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 23, 1996


LENGTH: 507 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - Congolese President Pascal Lissouba has called on France to use its influence in bringing to an end the current crisis in the Central African Republic.

In a radio broadcast Wednesday, Lissouba expressed his "deep concern" at the current situation in the Bangui, the Central African Republic capital, where parts of the army started a mutiny Saturday and are demanding the resignation of the democratically elected president, Ange-Felix Patasse.

The situation was tense Thursday morning in Bangui, where troops from the French Legion intervened on Wednesday afternoon against the mutineers near the national radio station and are reported to have taken control of other strategic installations in the city. 

Lissouba said, before the French intervention to support loyalists whose lines were being broken by the mutineers, that there was in Bangui an "escalation which involved high risks for the Central African people and for the democratic process under way in their country".

This situation "is a cause for concern for the (country's) friends, among whom is Congo, a neighboring and sister nation", he said, noting that the use of arms to settle social and political conflicts was not "a good option for democracy".

Lissouba still remembers the ethnic clashes which killed more than 2,000 people in the southern areas of Brazzaville in 1993, among supporters of the opposition and government alike, and the mutiny of young conscripts last February in the same town.

"Considering the turn of events, we should strive to preserve democracy in the Central African Republic and fight against all attempts at taking power through illegal...or armed insurrection", he added.

In conclusion, he asked France to use all means to get the Central African Republic out of the crisis and called on the international community to support France's action.

In a radio address broadcast the same day in Bangui, President Patasse stressed the need to continue negotiations with mutineers, while rejecting some of their demands, especially that of his resignation.

He agreed to other demands, espcially extending to the mutineers the amnesty granted to soldiers who had mutinied in April.

Patasse said a putsch would not solve the crisis.

French commando troops for Special Operations arrived Wednesday morning at Bangui airport which is now under their control.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

46 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa House Committee Votes to End Africa Earmark


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 31, 1996


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Washington, DC - The committee in the U.S. House of Representatives with principal responsibility for foreign aid has approved legislation eliminating all earmarking of funds for sub-Saharan Africa. The proposed bill also cuts $1 billion from the foreign aid budget proposed by President Clinton for fiscal year 1997.

In a brief meeting on May 29, the House Appropriations Committee voted to eliminate funding for the Development Fund for Africa, a legislative vehicle established in 1987 to designate money for development projects in Africa. Funding for Africa projects will be drawn from the $1.96 billion the committee allocated for development assistance. The committee approved specific earmarks of nearly $5 billion in funds for Israel and Egypt and close to $1 billion for Eastern Europe and the countries of the former Soviet Union. 

The committee-approved bill also terminates funding for the Africa Development Bank and makes deep cuts in the U.S. contribution to the World Bank. The U.S. contribution to the International Development Association, a World Bank affiliate which provides substantial assistance to Africa, was reduced by almost 44 percent from the level requested by the Clinton administration.

The foreign aid funding bill, known as the "Foreign Operations Appropriation," will come to a vote in the full House of Representatives on June 5, according to committee sources. The legislation still must be approved by the Senate before it is sent to President Clinton for signing into law.

The Clinton administration had proposed $12.8 billion in aid for the next fiscal year, but the Appropriations Committee action cut total funding to $11.9 billion. The reduction for the International Development Association (IDA) from the administration's request of $935 million to $525 million accounted for almost half the total cuts. Because of severe slashes last year, the Clinton administration's IDA request this year was primarily designated to meet past obligations to the organization.

The IDA provides loans to the world's poorest countries at below-market interest rates and, according to U.S. Treasury Department officials, is the world's largest lender to projects which contribute to child survival. "For the three billion people living in the world's poorest countries, IDA is the single most important provider of concessional development assistance," Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin said last week.

In other actions taken yesterday the committee also eliminated all funds for the African Development Bank, although last year when this happened the funding was restored in a House-Senate conference committee. The committee increased funding for UNICEF above President Clinton's requested level, boosted funds for international counter-narcotics efforts and voted $600 million for programs effecting children in developing countries.

Updates on the committee's action is available from the House Appropriations Committee's web site at <http://www.house.gov/appropriations/welcome.html>.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa (DOCUMENT) U.S. Deplores Zambian Amendments


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 31, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is a State Department statement issued on May 31 deploring Zambia's decision to impose constitutional amendments "that limit the right of the Zambian people to choose their president freely":

The United States deeply deplores the decision this week of the Government of Zambia to impose constitutional amendments, on the eve of the first national elections in Zambia's democratic era, that limit the right of the Zambian people to choose their president freely. These amendments seriously threaten the integrity and credibility of the electoral process and significantly undermine Zambia's democratic development. In light of the Government of Zambia's action, the United States is reviewing its bilateral and multilateral relationship, including assistance programs in Zambia.

The warm relations between the United States and Zambia, and our partnership in Zambia's development, have been based on our shared commitment to democracy and economic reform. We have repeatedly made known to the Government of Zambia our deep concerns over these amendments and other recent actions that threaten to undermine Zambia's new democratic system. The United States urges the Government of Zambia to reverse its decision on the constitutional amendments, to renew its commitment to democracy, and to take immediate steps to ensure that this year's elections are free and fair.

Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia (DOCUMENT) Security Council Extends Liberia Mandate


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 31, 1996


LENGTH: 1307 words


 

United Nations - The UN Security Council voted to accept the recommendation of Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and extend the mandate of the United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) until 31 August 1996. Unanimously adopting resolution 1059 (1996), the Council expressed concern at the collapse of the cease-fire, the resumption of hostilities and the spread of fighting into the previously safe area of Monrovia and its environs.

The Council demanded that the factions in Liberia strictly respect the status of UNOMIL and the ECOWAS Monitoring Group (ECOMOG) personnel and called upon the Liberian parties to implement all arrangements and commitments they have already entered into, in particular the Abuja Agreement. Following is the text of the resolution:

The Security Council, 

Recalling all its previous resolutions concerning the situation in Liberia, in particular resolution 1041 (1996) of 29 January 1996,

Having considered the report of the Secretary-General dated 21 May 1996 (S/1996/362) on the United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL),

Stressing that the escalating violence is in violation of the Abuja Agreement (S/1995/742, annex) and puts the peace process at grave risk,

Firmly convinced of the importance of Monrovia as a safe haven, and noting especially the recent broader deployment of ECOMOG in the city, Emphasizing once again that the people of Liberia and their leaders bear the ultimate responsibility for achieving peace and national reconciliation,

Commending the positive role of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) in its continuing efforts to restore peace, security and stability in Liberia,

Noting the adoption of a Mechanism for Returning Liberia to the Abuja Agreement by the ECOWAS Foreign Ministers on 7 May 1996,

Expressing its appreciation to those African States that have contributed and are contributing troops to the ECOWAS Monitoring Group (ECOMOG),

Commending also those Member States that have supported the peace process and ECOMOG, including through contributions to the Trust Fund for Liberia,

Stressing also that the presence of UNOMIL in Liberia is predicated on the presence of ECOMOG and its commitment to ensure the safety of UNOMIL military observers and civilian staff,

1. Welcomes the report of the Secretary-General dated 21 May 1996;

2. Decides to extend the mandate of UNOMIL until 31 August 1996;

3. Recognizes that the deterioration of the security situation on the ground warranted the Secretary-General's decision to temporarily reduce the strength of UNOMIL;

4. Notes the Secretary-General's intention to maintain UNOMIL deployments at their present level and requests that he advise the Security Council of any significant planned increase in the number of personnel deployed depending on the evolution of the security situation on the ground;

5. Expresses its grave concern at the collapse of the cease-fire, the resumption of hostilities and the spread of fighting into the previously safe area of Monrovia and its environs;

6. Condemns all attacks against personnel of ECOMOG, UNOMIL, and international organizations and agencies delivering humanitarian assistance as well as the looting of their equipment, supplies and personal property, and calls for the immediate return of looted property;

7. Demands once more that the factions in Liberia strictly respect the status of ECOMOG and UNOMIL personnel, as well as international organizations and agencies delivering humanitarian assistance throughout Liberia, and further demands that these factions facilitate such deliveries and that they strictly abide by the relevant rules of international humanitarian law;

8. Calls upon the Liberian parties to implement fully and expeditiously all the agreements and commitments they have already entered into, in particular the Abuja Agreement, and in this regard demands that they restore an effective and comprehensive cease-fire, withdraw all fighters and arms from Monrovia, allow the deployment of ECOMOG, and restore Monrovia as a safe haven;

9. Stresses that continued support by the international community for the peace process in Liberia, including the participation of UNOMIL, is contingent on the Liberian parties' demonstrating their commitment to resolve their differences peacefully and on the fulfillment of the conditions set out in paragraph 8;

10. Stresses the importance of respect for human rights in Liberia;

11. Recalls the obligation of all States to comply strictly with the embargo on all deliveries of weapons and military equipment to Liberia imposed by resolution 788 (1992) of 19 November 1992 and to bring all instances of violations of the embargo before the Committee established pursuant to resolution 985 (1995) of 13 April 1995;

12. Encourages the members of ECOWAS in preparation for their summit to consider ways and means to strengthen ECOMOG and to persuade the faction leaders to resume the peace process;

13. Urges all Member States to provide financial, logistical and other assistance in support of ECOMOG to enable it to carry out its mandate;

14. Calls on ECOMOG, in accordance with the agreement regarding the respective roles and responsibilities of UNOMIL and ECOMOG in the implementation of the Cotonou Agreement (S/26272) and with the UNOMIL concept of operations, to provide for the security of UNOMIL observers and civilian staff;

15. Expresses support for the resolve of the ECOWAS Ministers not to recognize any Government in Liberia that comes to office through the use of force;

16. Urges Member States to continue to provide additional support for the peace process in Liberia by contributing to the United Nations Trust Fund for Liberia;

17. Requests the Secretary-General to continue to keep the Security Council closely informed of the situation in Liberia, and expresses its readiness, if the situation further deteriorates, to consider possible measures against those who do not cooperate with the resumption of the peace process;

18. Decides to remain seized of the matter.

Africa News


May, 1996


Western Sahara (DOCUMENT) Security Council Extends W Sahara Mandate


BYLINE: United Nations May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

United Nations - The Security Council this afternoon decided to reduce the military component of the United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO) by 20 per cent -- from 288 to 230 personnel -- while extending the Mission's mandate until 30 November. This action was taken on the understanding that it would not impair effective monitoring of the cease-fire.

Through its unanimous adoption of resolution 1056 (1996), the Council suspended temporarily the identification process, which aims at identifying those eligible to participate in the planned referendum. The suspension would remain in effect until both the Government of Morocco and the Popular Front for the Liberation of Saguia el-Hamra and Rio de Oro (POLISARIO) had demonstrated their commitment to resuming and completing the process without further obstacles. 

According to the resolution, today's temporary suspension of the work of the Identification Commission did not imply any lessening of the Council's resolve to secure implementation of the settlement plan. Under that plan, the parties agree to the holding of a referendum to enable the people of Western Sahara to choose between independence and integration with Morocco.

The Council urged the two parties to demonstrate the political will, cooperation and flexibility to permit resumption and early completion of the identification process. It also called on them to cooperate with the United Nation on such aspects of the settlement plan as the release of Saharan political prisoners and the exchange of prisoners of war.

While reminding the parties that it would have to consider other measures if significant progress was not made during the upcoming mandate period, the Council stressed its readiness to support resumption of the identification process as soon as the parties made that possible. It supported the Secretary-General's proposal to maintain a political office to continue dialogue with the parties and the two neighbouring countries.

The meeting, which was called to order at 12:54 p.m., was adjourned at 12:58 p.m.

Resolution Adopted

The text of the resolution adopted by the Council reads as follows:

"The Security Council,

"Reaffirming all its previous resolutions on the question of Western Sahara,

"Having considered the report of the Secretary-General of 8 May 1996 (S/1996/343),

"Noting the views expressed by the Government of Morocco as set out in the report of the Secretary-General and in the memorandum attached to the letter addressed to the Secretary-General dated 10 May 1996 (S/1996/345),

"Noting also the views expressed by the Polisario Front as set out in the report of the Secretary-General and in the memorandum attached to the letter addressed to the Secretary-General dated 23 May 1996 (S/1996/366),

"Noting also the letter dated 23 May 1996 from the Current Chairman and the Secretary-General of the Organization of African Unity (S/1996/376),

"Reaffirming its commitment to assist the parties to achieve a just and lasting solution to the question of Western Sahara,

"Stressing the importance it attaches to the maintenance of the cease- fire, as an integral part of the settlement plan,

"Recognizing that, despite all the difficulties, the United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO) has to date identified more than 60,000 persons,

"Reiterating that, for progress to be achieved, the two parties must have a vision of the post-referendum period,

"1. Reiterates its commitment to the holding, as soon as possible, of a free, fair and impartial referendum for the self-determination of the people of Western Sahara in accordance with the settlement plan which has been accepted by the two parties referred to above;

"2. Deeply regrets the fact that the required willingness does not exist to give MINURSO the cooperation needed for it to resume and complete the identification process, and that there has therefore been no significant progress towards implementation of the settlement plan;

"3. Agrees with the recommendation of the Secretary-General that the identification process be suspended until such time as both parties provide concrete and convincing evidence that they are committed to resuming and completing it without further obstacles, in accordance with the settlement plan;

"4. Supports the proposal of the Secretary-General to reduce the strength of the military component of MINURSO by 20 per cent, on the understanding that this will not impair its operational effectiveness in monitoring the cease-fire;

"5. Endorses the view of the Secretary-General that the decision to suspend temporarily the work of the Identification Commission and to reduce the number of civilian police and military personnel does not imply any lessening of resolve to secure the implementation of the settlement plan;

"6. Supports the proposal of the Secretary-General, in the context of the settlement plan, to maintain a political office to continue the dialogue with the parties and the two neighbouring countries and to facilitate any other effort that could help set the parties on the course towards an agreed formula for the resolution of their differences and encourages the Secretary- General to consider ways of strengthening the role of this office;

"7. Urges the two parties to demonstrate without further delay the political will, cooperation and flexibility necessary to permit the resumption and early completion of the identification process and the implementation of the settlement plan; notes with satisfaction that the parties have respected the cease-fire, which is an integral part of the settlement plan, and calls upon them to continue to do so;

"8. Also calls upon the parties, as a demonstration of good will, to cooperate with the United Nations in the implementation of certain aspects of the settlement plan, such as the release of Saharan political prisoners and the exchange of prisoners of war on humanitarian grounds, as soon as possible, to accelerate implementation of the settlement plan in its entirety;

"9. Encourages the parties to consider additional ways to create confidence between themselves in order to remove obstacles to implementation of the settlement plan;

"10. Decides to extend the mandate of MINURSO, on the basis proposed by the Secretary-General in his report of 8 May 1996, until 30 November 1996;

"11. Reminds the parties that if significant progress is not achieved during this period, the Council will have to consider other measures, including possible further reductions in the strength of MINURSO, but stresses its readiness to support the resumption of the identification process as soon as the parties have demonstrated the necessary political will, cooperation and flexibility, as called for in paragraph 7 above;

"12. Requests the Secretary-General to continue his efforts with the parties to break the impasse blocking the implementation of the settlement plan, and to submit a report to the Council by 31 August 1996 on the outcome of his efforts;

"13. Also requests the Secretary-General to keep the Council closely informed of all significant developments, including their humanitarian aspects, and to submit a comprehensive report on the implementation of this resolution by 10 November 1996;

"14. Decides to remain seized of the matter."


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996

50 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Sports - Soccer The World Cup Starts Here in South Africa


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Andrew Muchineripi


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Johannesburg - When the South African national soccer squad assembled for their World Cup debut in Nigeria four years ago, they drove straight to Jan Smuts Airport and flew north.

Not a single training session was held at home and the inevitable humiliation followed as the Clemens Westerhof-coached Super Eagles cruised to a 4-0 victory and eventual qualification.

South Africa launch their second attempt to reach the showpiece of international football on Saturday afternoon at the 50 000-capacity Kamuzu Stadium in Blantyre.

And while Malawi cannot be compared with Nigeria, there are other reasons to suggest that millions of Bafana Bafana supporters will not witness another heavy defeat this time round. 

For starters, South African coach Clive Barker has had his squad together since Monday, training daily at Marks Park in late autumn weather conditions ideal for footballers.

The squad are based at a hotel near the city centre which oozes warmth and friendliness and whose food would satisfy even the most discerning palate.

These factors should ensure that a happy, healthy and fit squad represents the rainbow nation, and the word from Barker that all financial arrangements have been tied up is reassuring.

The build-up to the friendly match against Brazil last month was marred by reports of threatened strikes over bonuses, and however untrue they were, damage was done.

Another significant difference between Lagos and Blantyre is that South Africa circa 1992 were a group of naive, inexperienced players trying to come to grips with international football.

Zimbabwe delivered the first blow to the myth that South Africa would conquer Africa in weeks rather than months, and then came Nigeria, Zambia and Mexico to inflict further punishment.

Coach "Screamer" Tshabalala resigned soon after the Nigeria debacle and Peruvian-born replacement Augusto Palacios instilled an element of discipline and organisation into the national set-up.

Palacios left following the heavy loss to Mexico, opening the door to Barker, a First Division footballer of no great note who had developed into a highly successful coach with several First Division clubs.

Slowly but surely a powerful team was assembled without any remarkable change in personnel. Of the team beaten in Nigeria, Mark Anderson, Sizwe Motaung, Lucas Radebe, Tovey and Philemon Masinga are going to Malawi.

The crowning glory came on February 3 1996 when Mark Williams came on as a second-half substitute and scored twice within three minutes to give Bafana Bafana victory over Tunisia in the Nations' Cup decider.

And when his charges were leading world champions Brazil 2-0 at halftime in the Nelson Mandela Inauguration Challenge last month, Barker must have wondered if heaven really could be any better.

The South Americans demonstrated why they have won the world title more times than any other nation with a stirring second-half comeback which brought three goals and victory.

But if the loss to Egypt brought the Barker boys down to earth at a crucial stage of the Nations' Cup, who can say that there were not significant benefits from losing to the Brazilians.

Victory over the Samba sorcerers would surely have left many heads so high in the clouds that even Barker might have battled to drag them down to earth.

The long-suspected defensive frailties were exposed as tiring South Africans were dragged out of position and found wanting in the speed department. Hopefully, the lessons have been learnt with the form of Motaung, who has often appeared jaded this season, showing timely improvement in a weekend Coca-Cola Challenge Cup fixture.

Goalkeeper Andre Arendse seems certain to be chosen again and if Barker opts for four at the back, Motaung, Tovey, Mark Fish and Radebe are going to be the choices.

There have been hints that a fifth defender may be added in which case Tovey would become a sweeper, Radebe would move into the middle and David Nyathi come in at leftback.

There is no reason to change the well-balanced Nations' Cup-winning midfield quartet of Innocent Buthelezi and Eric Tinkler (steel) and Doctor Khumalo and "Shoes" Moshoeu (skill).

In attack, the absence through injury of Williams means it looks like Philemon Masinga and Shaun Bartlett if Barker chooses four defenders, or Masinga if five defenders are selected.

Malawi have been playing in the World Cup since 1976 without making an impression and will rely heavily on South African-based midfielders Chancey Gondwe and Ernest Chirwali to cause an upset.

In warm-up matches, the Malawians defeated Mozambique 1-0 last Sunday through a goal from captain Wilfred Nyalugwe, and lost 1-0 and drew 1-1 with Zambia the previous weekend.

Malawi certainly rank among the tougher preliminary-round opponents South Africa could have drawn, which may not be a bad thing as it will eliminate any danger of complacency.

While victory is obviously what Barker desires, he would probably be satisfied with a draw (preferably with lots of goals) ahead of the return match at FNB Stadium on June 15.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Arts Angelique Kidjo: High priestess of Afropop


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Gwen Ansell


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Johannesburg - "My songs are like my kids," says Angelique Kidjo, gravel-voiced on the line from Paris, "so don't ask me to choose between them."

Kidjo's keeping an open phone line to South Africa to mark the launch here this week of her fourth album, Fifa. Like many singers, she saves the full power of her voice for the stage, chatting softly and breaking off now and then to respond to some query from a relative passing through her room.

But while she's unwilling to pick any favourite music, she does have a favourite memory: cutting the track Wombo Lombo with South Africans Jabu Khanyile and Busi Mhlongo. "That was a very cool experience. Busi Mhlongohas a magnificent voice; she's so professional to work with." Shrewdly, Wombo Lombo with its distinctively South African beat is scheduled as the first single release here from her album. 

The singer's first name in her native Fon is "very philosophical and mystical. It translates as: 'You can't substitute blood for paraffin to light the lamp' -- which means you can't walk on people if you want to have success." And Kidjo's own story, as she tells it, is much more that of the hard-working trouper paying her showbiz dues at every stage.

Her mother ran a touring theatrical company; her brother -- like every other aspiring young guitarist in the 1970s -- was filling the family home with the recorded sounds of Santana and Earth, Wind and Fire. And Benin was a musical crossroads for the sounds of West, Central and North Africa: makossa, rhumba, Arabic pop.

All these were sources of inspiration for the determinedly eclectic young singer. Local concerts and radio shows in Benin were followed by the inevitable pilgrimage to Paris in 1983, where she enrolled for training as a jazz singer and gigged around a hectic Afro music scene. A stint with one of Europe's favourite Afro-jazz groups, Pili-Pili, was crowned by an appearance at the Montreux Jazz Festival in 1987. Marriage to co-composer and bassist Jean Hebrail and her first album, Parakou, followed not long after.

Now Kidjo has had her first child, and that imagery dominates the interview. Her songs are her "kids"; the development of her style across the four albums is "like a child growing up"; the process of composition is "like giving birth -- some songs give you a hard time, a lot of pain."

Her talent for composition is one of the things which distinguishes Kidjo from the current crop of Afropop chanteuses. Her music has grown up as she has: last year's tough little disco queen of the Aye album, with its hit track Agolo, has been remade on Fifa. Here she is cynical political commentator (on the track Akwaba, about the "catastrophe" of CFA franc devaluation), ethno musicologist (on Welcome, with its opening a cappella chorus taken from Kidjo's field recording of Manigri Muslim women) and gentle mother crooning a lullaby (on the title track).

Irrespective of tempo, "I always write based on percussion, on how the theme would sound on percussion instruments. Then Jean has ideas to put chords, orchestrations, over that. So it starts with rhythm. And for the words, well, sometimes everybody in the house has to shut up until I get them right-- until they say exactly my own truth. The vital thing is not to lie in your songs."

Kidjo's voice, with its capacity to swoop from carrying a true, bell-like vocal line to field-holler, gurgle and growl, isn't unlike that of Brenda Fassie. The difference is that the music industry here never let Brenda grow up.

It's perhaps significant that the Beninoise Kidjo can draw on ancient traditions to create more mature material. Fifa features three tracks in tribute to vodun (voodoo), which she describes as her "first religion" and which former Benin president Nicefor Soglo declared an official faith on January 10 this year.

Commenting on Kidjo's skillfully negotiated rise to the top of the Afropop music business, Cameroonian journalist Thomas Ayeh says:" References to vodun have wide appeal -- at home, in Brazil, Haiti, Cuba,and they add that touch of exoticism for European music fans.

"Yet beyond that, in francophone Africa, we always see that people rooted in their own traditions handle the complexities and contradictions of Western institutions much more confidently than those whom the French have completely assimilated in culture."

Kidjo's reluctant to talk too much about vodun, and says: "I haven't yet used vodun rhythms even on these songs. I've just used the gods and the ceremonies as themes for lyrics. I don't know enough -- I'm not ready yet --to handle those rhythms with enough respect. That may come later."

And what of the slickly shorn crewcut which publicists crow over as the epitome of the "post-modern African woman", and cultural nationalists ascribe to reverence for those ancient women warriors, the amazons of Dahomey? Kidjo herself is a lot more prosaic: "In Africa, when you have braids, all your friends jump on your hair to help; it's a social occasion, it's fun. I cut my hair in 1985, simply because I got fed up with having to have my hair made up every two weeks in France in a salon -- which is a nightmare, and, incidentally, costs you a fortune too. My hairdresser came up with this style. It's easy and it's me."


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Southern Africa Tension Over Trade Imbalance In Southern Africa


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Lynda Loxton


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Johannesburg - Behind the bonhomie and words of solidarity at last week's World Economic Forum/Southern African Development Community economic summit in Cape Town lurked real tension that South Africa can ill-afford to ignore.

These mainly centred around South Africa's dominance of regional trade and the need to review its trade relations with its neighbours.

The Zimbabwean delegation of business people and government officials was particularly vociferous, with President Robert Mugabe hinting strongly of retaliatory action to protect Zimbabwean industries against South African imports. 

After intense discussions, South African Trade and Industry Minister Alec Erwin agreed to send a negotiating team to Harare on June 10 to review the long-stalled trade negotiations between the two countries.

Zimbabwe's preferential trade agreement with South Africa lapsed in 1992 and repeated efforts to renegotiate the pact have failed, with South Africa pushing for a multilateral trade agreement among Southern African Developing Countries states rather than individual agreements. This is tied in with efforts to renegotiate the Southern African Customs Union between South Africa, Botswana, Lesotho and Swaziland.

A massive inflow of South African goods into Zimbabwe in the past few years has threatened the viability of many industries there, with clothing and textiles worst affected.

"We have been very patient, but we think we have been short-changed by South Africa in terms of our business arrangement," said Zimbabwe's National Planning Minister Richard Hove.

At a media briefing, Botswana's President Ketumile Masire said he was also concerned about his country's trade imbalance with South Africa, but believed negotiations rather than retaliatory measures were needed.

On the renegotiation of the South African Customs Union, which is seen to have an unfair bias in favour of South Africa, Masire said: "It seems that the South Africans are much more prepared to democratise the whole thing rather than having it as one-sided as it was before.

"There are problems in that the South African economy is a much bigger economy than any of the others but where there is a will there is a way," he added.

Given the sometimes huge imbalances in regional industrial development and trade flows, it may well be that more than "will" is called for and Erwin will no doubt be kept on his toes finding a meaningful solution to the problem. His counterparts in neighbouring states are expected to keep up the pressure for some kind of action.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


53 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance South Africa's Success on the Internet


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Johannesburg - Among corporate South Africa's more dramatic -- and all too rare -- success stories is the Internet Solution (IS).

Two years ago David Frankel and Alon Apteker financed the company, then a fledgling enterprise started by three computer science graduates, to the tune of R300 000. In February, the Sankorp-affiliated Dimension Data paid R12,5-million for a 25% stake in IS, thus putting the total value of IS at R50- million.

IS started off taking corporate networks and connecting them to the Internet. It soon became obvious that security was a major barrier to using the Internet, hence the company's specialisation in network security. 

Secure in the commercial market and with a solid base, IS branched into the dial-up market. Now, the greatest potential growth is in applications. Today, IS is structured into four distinct entities:

IS connects corporate networks to the Internet via digital leased line connections. Trusted Network Solution (TNS) provides network security. Started in August 1995, it is 90%- owned by IS and 10% by the directors.

In October, IS and Persetel's Software Connection, South Africa's largest software retailer, formed a jointly controlled company Internet Connection (Icon) to provide Internet access to dial-up users. Icon is a natural extension of IS's commercial Internet access services.

Internet Solution-Commercial (IS-Commercial), the latest subsidiary, opened in January to provide Web site development, system integration and software engineering. It is 90%-owned by IS and 10% by directors.

Some 12% of turnover, or R300 000 a month, is contributed to IS by each of the subsidiaries -- TNS, Icon and IS-Commercial.

IS has a turnover of R2,5-million a month, handles a message every five seconds on average, employs 75 people (75% have technical degrees) with an average age of 26, and services 70% to 75% of all businesses in South Africa with digital leased line Internet connections. More than 225 companies are on board and the list is growing at a rate of 15 to 20 a month.

Its 50%-owned Internet Connection opened in November and already has 12,5% of South Africa's dial-up market, growing by 60 users a day that will reach 100 by July.

Focused on providing turnkey solutions around the spreading Internet revolution, IS is well- positioned to sustain such rapid growth. With some R2-million in the bank and the Dimension Data relationship, IS has financial muscle for future expansion.

It is moving beyond a supplier/vendor relationship to looking for opportunities to partner companies that understand technology.

There is potential to form business partnerships with major clients where IS provides the expertise in information technology and the clients provide the product and market. The biggest potential is in the financial sector.

Many feel that enabling organisations to take full advantage of the new markets and global opportunities for information interchange offered by the Internet has barely begun.

At the moment, IS's value chain is installation of leased lines, routers, service mail configurations, firewalls, access controls, software, web sites with interactive applications and training for staff and users.

The possibilities for publishing, entertainment, banking and other industries whose product is information-based are huge.

Consumers, though, are not impressed. People are flocking to see what the broad Internet is all about. Most are excited. Many though, are ultimately disappointed.

But the potential is there. As more and more people start to use the Internet, it will grow in popularity.

The Internet also has significant implications for internal corporate communication, the so- called intranet, which is widely used.

So far IS is an inspiration, demonstrating that companies can still thrive in the South African economy and that opportunities exist. If only there were more examples.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia Rural Life Returns to Normal in Liberia


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Melvis Dzisah


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Monrovia - To the outside world, the television images of violence and mayhem in the Liberian capital Monrovia reflect an entire country in chaos.

But Monrovia is just a small -- albeit bloody -- part of the West African nation. Outside the smoking city's gates, people in the countryside are trying to pick up the pieces of their lives after six-years of bitter civil war.

From the Ivoirian border in the north, all the way to Gbarngah -- 160km from Monrovia and the former headquarters of warlord Charles Taylor -- the countryside of Greater Liberia is relatively conflict-free. 

"To us, what is happening in Monrovia is just tales of distant troubles, we are not touched," declares Thomas Weh, a farmer at a hamlet on the Gbarngah road.

He, like many other refugees, returned home with the signing of the August peace agreement in Abuja, Nigeria, lauded then as Liberia's best hope for stability and reconstruction.

Although that agreement is now shot to pieces, the violence is yet to spill out of the capital. In the rest of Liberia, schools are functioning -- though on a limited basis -- - as are health facilities, despite supply shortages. Religious-minded people have even turned to rehabilitating their places of worship.

Around Gbarngha at least, there is little evidence of the disease and hunger that aid agencies have sounded the alarm over.

All the way along the 260km road from Logoatou on the Ivoirian border to Gbarngah, patches of forest have been cleared for farming. Villagers testify that unlike the recent past when they were threatened and manhandled by swaggering boy soldiers, the climate has changed.

"They are now very sober and tired of fighting each other so they do not harass us,'' said a farmer on the road.

During the war the Liberian countryside was the theater of conflict between the competing warlords. Then Monrovia, under the protection of the West African peacekeeping force, Ecomog, was an island of tranquility.

One Mauritanian shopkeeper at Saniquelle, a major town on the Gbarngah road, said he used to get his supplies from Monrovia after the roads were opened last September.

"But now our supplies come in from Guinea and Cote d'Ivoire." Business is not booming he acknowledged: "In war time nothing moves fast, but we are living, hoping that things will return to normal soon." -- IPS Now the situation is in reverse. Since Apr. 6, when Taylor and warlord ally Alhaji Kromah laid siege to Roosevelt Johnson and his Krahn militia turning Monrovia into a battle field, those that were able grabbed what possessions they could safely carry and streamed into the countryside.

According to observers, Gbarngah's population for example has trebled to 30,000 from the 10,000 people in April, then mainly militia and their families.

''Most of us have no homes here, so we are always on the move. We have no choice,'' explains Mary Johnson, 28. Until the fighting in Monrovia she had never been out of the city.

''In Monrovia we have a big house but that has been destroyed now making living in the capital dangerous for almost everyone apart from the warlords and the fighters,'' she says.

The Catholic Relief Service and Save the Children Fund are the only relief agencies operating in Liberia. Their limited supply of mostly rice and maize to the rural population is being supplemented by farmers whose markets in Monrovia are now closed.

A local World Food Programme (WFP) member of staff said he reckons conditions are safe enough for the U.N. agency to move in again, but ''our heads claim the situation is too dangerous for now.''

Returning villagers are not only rehabilitating their former homes destroyed in a war that killed 150,000 people and turned half of the country's pre-war population of 2.5 million people into refugees, but even shops are re-opening.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Rwanda Genocide Trials Get Off The Ground


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Chris McGreal


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Nairobi - After nearly two years of investigation into the genocide of hundreds of the thousands of Rwandan Tutsis, the first Hutu extremists accused of mass murder were finally expected to appear before the international war crimes tribunal in Tanzania late this week.

They include Clement Kayishema, the former governor of Kibuye province and the highest- ranking Hutu official so far charged by the chief prosecutor, Judge Richard Goldstone.

Kibuye had the highest concentration of Tutsis in Rwanda before the genocide and among the most comprehensive records of killing. Witnesses are expected to testify that Kayishema encouraged more than 

10 000 Tutsis to seek shelter in a stadium and church by promising protection before personally firing the shot which launched their murder.

Kayishema has previously defended his actions by arguing that he tried to stop the killings but lacked sufficient troops to do so. However, there are believed to have been significant numbers of soldiers at an army base in the town. Some participated in the murders.

Kayishema is also alleged to have led attacks on Tutsi refugees who gathered on hilltops in Kibuye province. They were still being murdered even after the French army moved into Rwanda, supposedly to protect the Tutsi population.

The two other accused also played important roles in the killing in other parts of Rwanda. George Anderson Rutaganda is the former vice- president of the interahamwe militia which spearheaded the genocide and spurred other, less willing participants into murder.

Appearing with him is Jean-Paul Akayesu, a former mayor in Gitarama province who was known as one of the most enthusiastic killers. He directed the slaughter in his village, Taba, where one of his specialties was to encourage Hutus to murder Tutsi members of their own families. Witnesses have reported that he said: "Even a Tutsi foetus in its Hutu mother's stomach cannot be saved."

All three men were arrested in Zambia. Kayishema had first fled to Zaire where he was employed by the aid organisation, the Order of Malta, as a doctor before disappearing to Lusaka where he was discovered living openly. After pleas and the appointment of defence lawyers, the trials were expected to be postponed for several weeks while the attorneys consult the accused men.

The opening of the Rwanda tribunal comes after nearly two years of underfunded and understaffed investigation which many Tutsi survivors saw as a reflection of the world's indifference to their tragedy.

More indictments are expected to follow in the coming months. They are likely to include at least one member of the defunct Hutu extremist Cabinet which governed Rwanda during the genocide. But there is no sign of an early trial for the 70 000 Hutus packed into Rwandan prisons.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
