Africa News


May, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Horror Greets Aids 'Miracle Cure' in Kenya


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Chris McGreal


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Nairobi - A senior adviser to Kenya's president is selling a government-funded "miracle cure" for Aids which, education workers say, has set back years of safe-sex projects, the most recent funded by a 26-million pound World Bank grant agreed to three months ago.

Professor Arthur Obel, a leading doctor and chief scientist in President Daniel arap Moi's office, launched "Pearl Omega" in March with much fanfare in the state press, the personal endorsement of Moi and praise from the administration in Parliament.

Since the launch, thousands of the estimated 1-million Kenyans afflicted by Aids or being HIV positive have handed over Pounds 350 for a course of Pearl Omega, which comes in a wine bottle and is 5% proof. 

Non-Kenyans are also among the buyers. In sub- Saharan Africa alone, 13-million people are infected with the virus. Within Kenya, about 60 000 of the sufferers are children.

The drug is made by Biodiversity, a company set up specifically for the purpose with government funds, and headed by Moi's former press secretary.

Professor Obel claims secret research proves that Pearl Omega causes a reversal of Aids symptoms and can even totally rid the body of the HIV virus. But he has refused to reveal what is in Pearl Omega, to produce anyone who has benefited from the drug, or to hold himself accountable to Kenya's professional medical organisations.

"My critics want to know how I get from the source to the end point," he said. "This means revealing the formula for my drug. No one knows the formula for Coca-Cola."

Critics say he has used powerful political connections to intimidate the medical profession into an uncomfortable silence. Moi's office did not respond to requests for comment.

Aids groups are outraged, arguing that there is no hard evidence to back the claims for a drug for which some people hand over their life savings.

Although a health ministry board banned the sale of Pearl Omega in pharmacies two weeks ago, Professor Obel continues to dispense it from his medical practice, where emaciated Aids sufferers pack the waiting room for the supposed cure.

Millions of pounds of foreign aid, along with tons of free condoms, have been dedicated to persuading Kenyans to take Aids seriously. But Aids workers say they are running into increasing hostility from people who say safe sex no longer matters now that there is a cure.

Unless they can be persuaded otherwise, the health ministry's estimates that the number of Kenyans infected with HIV will have risen by 60% at the end of the century, may be conservative.

Next week, the courts are to hear an application by the Kenya Aids Society aimed at forcing Professor Obel to reveal Pearl Omega's formula, to register it as a drug and to submit it to government pricing controls.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Constitutional Debate Heats Political Climate


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Brian Latham


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's vibrant but eccentric press is carrying reports claiming former president Kenneth Kaunda is training Arab "terrorists" in South Africa.

Kaunda has been barred from standing in elections, because a recent, and bizarre constitutional amendment bars "foreigners" from seeking presidential office. A foreigner has been defined in the amendment as someone who, like Kaunda, who was born in Zambia but whose parents were not. Kaunda's parents were Malawians. 

For the first time in decades, there are real fears political violence will spill onto the streets of Zambia's capital, Lusaka. While Zambians often worried about foreign raids from then-Rhodesia and South Africa because of Kaunda's support for liberation movements, not since the food riots in 1991 has there been any civil disturbance in Zambia -- and not since independence has there been any real political instability.

But as Zambia's constitutional debate hots up, opposition leaders are promising demonstrations and violence unless President Frederick Chiluba renounces his plans to prevent them standing against him in the country's elections this October.

And Zambia's press is adding fuel to the fire by alleging that ex-president Kenneth Kaunda is training Arab hitmen in South Africa, using the Johannesburg-based Kaunda Foundation as a front for the training operation.

Malcolm Freid, the foundation's head, says the allegations are "off the wall", adding that Chiluba's Movement for Multi-Party Democracy (MMD) is resorting to bizarre tactics because "it is frightened now -- very frightened".

Kaunda's United National Independence Party, UNIP denies vehemently it is training people to invade Zambia and says it is opposed to violence. But Kaunda's deputy in the party, Senior Chief Inyambo Yeta, claims rioting may be inevitable "when democracy is suppressed" he said. "Extremists will come along and their frustration will lead to trouble. I wouldn't rule out violence."

And Kaunda has vowed to break the law, whatever the cost to himself: "We broke British laws to gain independence and freedom," he said. "And I will do it again now."

Pro-MMD newspapers are stoking the fires. "Chiluba to be killed" said the Weekly Chronicle, next to a picture of Chiluba with the cross of a telescope sight superimposed on his face. And another newspaper, the Sun, which made the Arab claim, said the "terrorists" would invade Zambia and depose the MMD. The paper published an old picture of a Renamo guerrilla. Soldiers like this, pictured in Mozambique, are to move into Zambia, it claimed.

Kaunda returned to Zambia on Tuesday after attending a former heads of state meeting with James Callaghan, Pierre Trudeau and Helmut Schmidt in Canada. He was greeted by several hundred UNIP supporters at Lusaka Airport and led a peaceful demonstration into the city centre.

By the time the procession reached the city's main post office, it had swelled to more than 1 000 and Zambian police dispersed the crowd, with Kaunda asking his supporters to return to their homes peacefully. It is illegal to hold a demonstration in Zambia without giving 14 days notice.

Zambians interviewed in the streets this week said they expected trouble.

Plagued by desperate economic woes and rising crime rates, Zambians philosophically shrug their shoulders and say the controversial law to ban opposition leaders on the grounds of parentage is "unfair". "If KK is unpopular, let Chiluba prove it in the elections," was the almost universal reaction to the proposed Bill.

And Zambians do have staggering problems, even without the present constitutional crisis. Overwhelming unemployment, crime and an economy teetering on the verge of collapse are everyday issues.

Zambian businessmen worry that the country's trade imbalance is not sustainable and point to South Africa being more of a hindrance than a help.

With the constitutional crisis coming at a time of desperate economic constraints and fuel shortages, most observers feel Zambia is headed for unrest and civil disturbance which will further undermine Chiluba's attempts to rebuild his ailing country.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Cory Aquino With a Message for Mandela


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Johannesburg - The diminutive figure in the chintz-covered wing-chair is hoping her voice will hold out. Former Philippines president Corazon Aquino is about to give her umpteenth media interview of the day; will the speech she's to deliver later have to be whispered?

"I had a sore throat a couple of weeks ago ... the doctor said the only cure was to stop talking. Of course, that was impossible," she says. Of course. But one suspects that to tell Aquino something is impossible is to pull the trigger that switches her into defiant, can-do mode. 

She's in South Africa on a fleeting six-day visit -- the guest of the United States- based Henry J Kaiser Family Foundation, brought out to give the keynote address at the 1996 Nelson Mandela Award for Health and Human Rights. "It didn't take me long to decide to accept," she says. "I have long wanted to meet Mandela."

There are significant parallels between the challenges she had to confront when she was catapulted into the presidency three years after the assassination of her political activist husband, Benigno Aquino, and those currently facing South Africa. Transforming government, achieving economic growth and uplifting the poor are just some of the items that were on her task list and now top Mandela's.

Aquino might come across as everybody's favourite aunt -- the kind one goes to for strong tea and wise counsel when disaster strikes -- but she won't dream of moralising. "I don't think it would be proper for me to give your government counsel," she says, but she does have a message, and it carries the authority of wisdom born of bitter experience.

It's basically this: empower the people. Build non-governmental organisations, develop a partnership between them and government, and pave the way for people to feel part of government and the achievement of national goals.

"Having been brought into the presidency through people's power, I resolved to empower the people," she says. A new Constitution in 1987 restored democracy to the archipelago of islands where some 68-million Filipinos suffered under the yoke of dictator Ferdinand Marcos's martial law. After taking power, Aquino cast the government's protective cloak over the NGOs that had worked in the shadows against the regime, and became chief advocate for the poor.

"I'd meet with NGOs in the different sectors, listen to their grievances and requests. I'd ask them for their support for government actions.

"The fact that I survived seven coup attempts is testimony to this working -- it was only possible with the support of the majority of people, and that included most of the military. Only a very small sector of the armed forces were involved in the coup attempts."

She did not make herself available for re- election once her five-year term expired, endorsing instead her former secretary of defence, Fidel Ramos. "I always thought myself necessary only in the transition," she recalls. "I felt I had fulfilled my pledge to the Filipino people and that it was time to move on. Also, I wanted to leave the presidency with my integrity intact."

She continues to work to strengthen the NGO sector, chairing the Benigno Aquino Foundation which assists the country's co-operative movement, and can be seen, wearing her trademark yellow, at rallies endorsing political candidates.

She's the first to concede that the Philippines has its problems. Crime is rampant, and the economic boom seems to be widening, rather than closing, the gap between rich and poor. Democracy can be tedious, she says, but it has survived the strikes and coup attempts that scared off foreign investors during her reign.

"Marcos promised us bread and freedom, and we lost our freedom and he took our bread. We have been able to show we do better when we are free to choose and decide for ourselves. Your government has been in power only two years," she admonishes gently. "You must be patient."

* Dr Trudy Thomas, Eastern Cape MEC for Health, was awarded the 1996 Nelson Mandela Award for Health and Human Rights on Wednesday night in recognition of nearly three decades' work among needy children and the poor in her region.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


59 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Secret Talks Raise KwaZulu Peace Hopes


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Ann Eveleth


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Johannesburg - The secret peace talks of the African National Congress and the Inkatha Freedom Party this week have opened the door for a new beginning between South Africa's fiercest political opponents.

The talks, announced by KwaZulu-Natal Premier Frank Mdadlose, spell defeat for IFP hardliners, American constitutional lawyer Mario Ambrosini and fellow strategist Walter Felgate.

Mdlalose referred to a "third hand" in the ongoing violence, and said a mutual acknowledgement of "fatal mistakes" by the ANC and IFP and a professed move toward "consensus-seeking" governance paved the way for a fresh peace effort. A multi-party peace summit had been scheduled for June 13. 

The summit would precede the exit of the National Party's single MEC from the provincial Cabinet by one week -- an indication that the two parties, soon to be exclusive partners in both the national and provincial governments, are trying to set aside their differences.

University of Natal political scientist Alexander Johnston said the IFP's weak position as a result of its previous strategies "paved the way for the ANC to negotiate with the IFP in good faith".

IFP KwaZulu-Natal local government and housing MEC Peter Miller this week welcomed an out-of- court settlement in which his party agreed to repeal the controversial Ingonyama Trust Act, which he said had impeded housing delivery in the province.

But the move was a major backdown for IFP hardliners bent on wresting greater powers for the province via "institutional conflict".

The Ingonyama Trust Act placed three million hectares of "tribal" land in trust under King Goodwill Zwelithini and it was a key plank in the IFP's programme to force central government concessions on provincial powers.

The out-of-court settlement was forged minutes before the Act was due to be debated in the Constitutional Court. It included acceptance by the IFP that moves to amend the Act in order to remove obstacles to development fell within the central government's ambit.

The party also agreed that electoral legislation passed by the province fell outside its jurisdiction.

Two contentious Bills aimed at preventing the central government from taking over the payment of provincial traditional leaders were the brunt of disparaging comments from several Constitutional Court judges.

While the court still has to rule on these two Bills, the developments bode ill for the IFP's chances of forcing constitutional amendments through legislation.

Commenting on the latest developments, Johnston said: "Things are certainly not going the IFP's way".

The latest blows followed a series of failures for party strategists:

* In March 1995, IFP leader Mango-suthu Buthelezi led his party in a walk-out from the Constitutional Assembly in a bid to force the ANC to honour its 1994 agreement to international mediation. Earlier this month, the Constitutional Assembly adopted the final national Constitution in the IFP's absence without mediation having taken place.

* Efforts to wring national concessions out of the ANC by passing a highly federal provincial Constitution for KwaZulu-Natal ran into trouble in February, when opposition parties forced major concessions out of hardline constitutional negotiator Felgate.

* In May 1995, a secret IFP strategy document disclosed the party's intention to use "institutional conflict" to force the central government to accede to its demands. Shortly afterwards, the party's provincial MECs declared a boycott of the Intergovernmental forums through which provincial MECs liaised with national ministers.

The MECs have now quietly returned to the forums, realising nobody would protect their interests in their absence.

Felgate played down the IFP's capitulation in the Constitutional Court, arguing that the party had merely "exercised its democratic right to use the court to decide which interpretation of the Constitution is correct".

He said he saw no reason for the party to "change course. The IFP will continue to try to put forward challenges to maximise its advantage."

Pointed comments by the judges of the Constitutional Court included that certain things "had not occurred" to the drafters of the provincial legislation. It was suggested that the problem could lie with the party's constitutional adviser, Ambrosini.

A provincial government lawyer this week said Ambrosini allowed his "political agenda to cloud his legal judgment", resulting in problematic legislation. Ambrosini declined to comment.

Johnston said the IFP's hardline strategy had "revealed splits in the party". While IFP support rested primarily on identity-based and constitutional issues, Miller's comments -- rooted in a frustration over impediments to delivery in his portfolio -- "seemed to indicate that at least part of the IFP might prefer to focus on delivery issues".

Johnston said the failure of the IFP's constitutional and legislative strategy, the effects of these on delivery and the relative success of the central government's security initiatives had forced the party on to the defensive.

"The question remaining is whether the ANC will see this as sufficient reason to negotiate with the IFP," he added.

Deputy President Thabo Mbeki recently suggested some form of negotiation could be sought after the Constitutional Court decided on the fate of the provincial Constitution.

Mdlalose's announcement that IFP provincial leaders were in Cape Town discussing the breakthrough with Buthelezi, and that the ANC was similarly engaged with President Nelson Mandela, underscored the importance of this week's peace talks.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


60 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Everest Team Returns After Triumph and Tragedy


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Angella Johnson


LENGTH: 1440 words


 

Johannesburg - It seems inevitable South Africa's first expedition to Everest should have ended with recriminations and a threatened law suit following the Pyrrhic victory of its summit assault.

Internal rows, a sponsorship pull-out and a widely held assessment that the team was second-rate -- after the three most experienced members pulled out on arrival at the mountain -- have left the enterprise seeped in controversy. The rainbow nation had failed to cohere.

Instead of a hero's welcome team leader Briton Ian Woodall will return to a barrage of criticism over his decision to allow British photographer Bruce Herrod to make the final fatal ascent alone, some seven hours behind himself and South African climber, Cathy O'Dowd. 

Record-breaking British mountaineer Chris Bonnington told Radio 702 that a more experienced climber would have realised that there was only a 50:50 chance of anyone surviving the night on the mountain wearing only a down suit.

Andre Schoon, president of the Mountain Club of South Africa, joined the list of experienced climbers who have accused Woodall of making a bad judgment call. He said it was not normal for a relatively inexperienced climber to go for the summit alone. "If the summit bid was planned that way, I would consider that that inherently involved an unacceptably high risk for Herrod."

But Bonnington agreed with Woodall (39) and O'Dowd's (27) insistence that it was not unusual for a team to split up during the last stage of the ascent and fend for themselves. "Everest is a solo climb,'' said Woodall. "I was not surprised when he insisted on going on. He's a man and entitled to make his own decision."

He and O'Dowd met Herrod on their way down from the peak. They sat and talked with him for a while, but did not try to dissuade him from attempting the summit and then descending alone in the dark.

"I have enough trouble worrying about myself," Woodall told Radio 702. "The weather was perfect and he had plenty of time to make it. If he had a problem he could have radioed and we would have gone back to fetch him," he added.

But Ed February, one of those who resigned from the expedition because of Woodall's "dictatorial and dangerous leadership", said he would have tried to persuade Herrod to turn back.

"I would not have been happy with his straggling seven hours behind. That's a long time not to keep up. It is the window needed to get from camp two to the summit. Herrod did not have the experience to come down from Everest in the middle of the night."

He suggested that a possible reason for the time lag was that "Herrod had been left at camp two and then decided to set off behind his team mates. I'm inclined to think that something went very wrong before the final ascent. There are too many unanswered questions."

February described O'Dowd as being "driven by an overriding ambition to climb the mountain at any cost" and Herrod as an ego maniac in search of fame and glory.

Herrod (37) reached the top after 5pm. His girlfriend Sue Thompson said he had promised not to ascend the summit after midday. But the seduction of the mountain was too strong.

It is assumed he missed his footing and slipped on his way from the summit. His tragic death brought to 11 the number of lives claimed by Everest in its busiest month of the year, when human traffic up and down its slopes is reminiscent of a busy highway.

Well-known rock climber Chris Lomax, from Cape Town who has been mountaineering for nearly 25 years, said: "The problem is that too many inexperienced people are being allowed up the mountain just because they can pay for the trip."

Since the relaxation of the Nepalese government's once stringent numerical limit, Everest has become a chaotic playground for the rich and pleasure-seeking. It is the ultimate high and one of the country's major money-spinners.

"From what I have read it seems that all three climbers were relative novices on big mountains and probably should not have been there. The whole thing seems to have been more of a publicity stunt with a number of token figures," said Lomax.

"The whole team seem to have been mischosen and that might have been the reason for the lack of cohesion, though I do agree that at that altitude you can't really stop someone doing something they are hell-bent on doing.''

Where does that leave the perennial image of one mountaineer tied by rope to another, depending for his life on another? It would seem there is no longer a code. Today's climbers are a hard breed. Friendship, closeness to nature, building up relationships with the mountain have disappeared.

In the words of Norwegian expedition leader Jon Gangdal: "Now it's attack, in old- fashioned siege style, and climbers have to reach the summit at any price. People are even willing to walk over dead bodies to get to the top." A widely respected figure, this was his second trip to Everest and he has sworn not to return.

O'Dowd (the first woman from African to climb Everest) has confessed that she was too concerned with making her climb to the top to feel any spiritual connection with the mountain. Woodall has described how he stepped over frozen bodies in his quest for glory.

It had all started so differently for the South Africans who were sent off by a nation eager to continue making its mark in the world sporting arena after successes in international rugby, football and cricket.

Nelson Mandela (whose Children's Fund was able to raise money by sponsoring the trip) told them that by just trying they would bring honour to the nation. But from the moment they landed in Katmandu things started to go wrong.

The sole black woman on the team, Deshun Deysel, found that her name was not on the all-important permit needed to climb -- but Woodall's 69-year-old father's name was.

The 25-year-old teacher did not have the $10 000 needed to buy a new one and was not able to go beyond base camp while the others were able to make altitude acclimatising trips up the mountain.

When O'Dowd's wealthy parents decided to cough up money for Deysel's permit, it was too late for her to catch up with the programme. Mountaineering experts argue that she would never have made it in any case.

A series of rows over Woodall's dictatorial style of leadership led to the departure of Ed February, Andy de Klerk and Andy Hackland (three of South Africa's top climbers).

Woodall sold one of their vacant places to a French climber. His row with journalists from the Sunday Times, the initial and main sponsors, led to the paper withdrawing support.

According to editor Brian Pottinger an undisclosed sum had already been paid up front: "Our view is that there has been a clear breach of contract. We are considering whether to take it any further, and the matter is in the hands of our lawyers."


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


61 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Human Rights Lawyers Face Off in Truth Inquiry


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Johannesburg - Some of the country's finest human rights lawyers -- people who usually found themselves on the same side during the apartheid era -- were lined up against each other in the Constitutional Court this week.

David Soggot, SC, a Johannesburg advocate who handled some of the most important civil rights cases in the apartheid era, represents the families of Steve Biko, Griffiths Mexenge and Fabian and Florence Ribeiro in their attack against the Truth Commission's amnesty provisions.

Gilbert Marcus, SC, a heavyweight civil rights barrister and specialist on South Africa's new Constitution, is defending the Truth Commission and Justice Department against the application. 

Dennis Davis, professor of law at the University of Cape Town and star of the television show Future Imperfect, has suggested a possible compromise position to Constitutional Court president Arthur Chaskalson, himself a veteran of legal challenges against apartheid, and his team of judges.

Soggot argues the Truth Commission's abililty to give perpetrators of human rights abuse indemnity against civil and criminal prosecutions violates international law and legal rights of individuals that are entrenched in the Constitution. He says the amnesty rules also infringe international law by exonerating the state of its duty to pay compensation for damages by security force officials.

Marcus argues the postcript of the Constitution specifically calls for the creation of a truth body to promote reconciliation and states that amnesty for perpetrators of human rights abuse be used as a mechanism for achieving this. He says the Geneva Convention states, in fact, that governments should endeavour to grant "the widest possible amnesty" at the end of armed conflicts.

Davis's submission, made in the true spirit of reconciliation on behalf of the Centre for Applied Legal Studies in Johannesburg, agrees it is unconstitutional for victims to lose their right to damages from the state .

But Davis does not back Soggot's plea for the amnesty laws to be shelved. He suggests, instead, that perpetrators be given amnesty - -- thus encouraging them to come forward and confess to the Truth Commission -- while victims retain their right to state compensation.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


62 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Mbeki Mystery Raised as Truth Commission Looks Abroad


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Stefaans BrUmmer


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Johannesburg - The uncertain fate of Deputy President Thabo Mbeki's only son has edged the Truth and Reconciliation Commission's focus away from security force abuses towards the largely untold history of the liberation movements in exile -- and the organisations' lapses and injustices towards those in their own fold.

The stories told by victims of apartheid crime still dominate the proceedings of the Truth Commission, but a trend in testimony, including that last week by the missing son's mother, suggests more firmly now that both sides of the apartheid divide will have to account.

Said one of the commission's investigators, who asked not to be named: "What is weird is that there are other cases of people who are coming before the commission about people who went into exile, both ANC and PAC, who just disappeared ... The liberation armies are keeping mum about it."

A potentially more damaging story about ANC abuse in exile is likely to be heard by the Truth Commission soon. This week the father of top Umkhonto weSizwe commander Thami Zulu -- who died, apparently poisoned, days after his release from lengthy incarceration in Lusaka -- gave notice to the commission of his desire to testify. An internal ANC inquiry in 1990 failed to provide conclusive answers over Zulu's death, but did highlight persistent problems in the treatment of detainees. (See story below.) 

Whether the ANC should be held responsible for the disappearance of Monwabisi, born from a youthful romance and Mbeki's only child, is a moot point. But the nagging possibility that he was last seen in the ANC fold in Tanzania in the mid-1980s, a number of years after he was last seen in South Africa, does raise that question.

Transkei nurse Nokwanda Mpahlwa told a Truth Commission hearing in Port Elizabeth last Thursday that Monwabisi had disappeared in 1981 at the age of 21, but that friends of her son later told her they had met him in Europe and a "military camp" in Tanzania in 1985. She asked the commission to help find out what happened to him. "Put me out of my agony," was her request.

While her testimony -- and an account this week by the deputy president's father, Govan Mbeki -- suggests Monwabisi may well have reached exile and joined the ANC, Thabo Mbeki's version veers towards the likelihood that his son had never reached exile, and had possibly been the victim of an apartheid death squad in 1981.

Govan Mbeki this week told the Mail & Guardian Monwabisi had been legally adopted by his family when he was 10 years old, and looked after and put through school by his wife. In 1981 Monwabisi joined a trade school in Vereeniging, but left saying he was going to search for family in Durban.

That was the last the elder Mbekis heard of Monwabisi until after Govan Mbeki's release from prison in 1989. "I got to London after my release. There I met some of his co-students who came from the same area as he did in the Transkei. They said they had parted with him in Tanzania, when he said he was going to Cuba. I carried the search to Cuba, but also without success," he said, adding it was not clear from these accounts whether Monwabisi had in fact joined the ANC.

"It can only be the assumption that virtually all the young people (who left South Africa) were keen to join MK or to further their studies."

The elder Mbeki said Thabo Mbeki "did not have that part of the story. The story he had went as far as southern Transvaal and Durban."

Thabo Mbeki's representative Ricky Naidoo this week confirmed that was the deputy president's conclusion. "When he was told his son had disappeared and might have left for exile, he tried exhaustively to find out with ANC contacts, but his conclusion was that he had not reached exile."

Naidoo said Monwabisi had left the trade school in Vereeniging in 1981 to find Thabo Mbeki's cousin Phindile Mfeti in Durban, but never reached Mfeti, who at about that time also disappeared mysteriously. One explanation was that both, who had been involved in student politics at the time, could have been victims of an "assassination squad".

When Mbeki returned from exile in 1990 he inquired with the police, but this also failed to turn up leads. Naidoo said the disappearance had been a source of sorrow to the deputy president and "something he'd been carrying inside himself".

Thami Zulu's death, "disappearances" in the liberation fold in exile, and torture and deaths in detention centres in the frontline states, some of which have been well documented but have so far not prompted the ANC to act against individual transgressors, are likely to add to the pressure on the ANC to finally give a full account of its years in exile -- to the Truth Commission.

In the early 1990s criticism of the ANC mounted over human rights abuses in its camps in Tanzania, Angola and Zambia. The organisation responded with the Skweyiya Commission of 1992. It found serious breaches amounting to "staggering brutality" and recommended urgent action against individuals "responsible for the maltreatment of detainees". Nelson Mandela accepted the ANC leadership's collective responsibility, but insisted individuals could not be singled out.

Still under pressure, the ANC appointed the independent Motsuenyane Commission the following year. It came to similar conclusions. The ANC again accepted the findings, but argued action could not be taken against individual members as long as the National Party and security forces did not do the same. The organisation then called for the establishment of a Truth Commission to "investigate all the violations of human rights ... from all quarters".

But whether the ANC will now deliver individual transgressors to the Truth Commission remains to be seen.

The Truth Commission, for its part, may be hampered by the fact that these abuses occurred in foreign countries. Its leverage over individuals who committed crimes in South Africa lies in the fact that those who do not confess will not get indemnity and may be prosecuted in South African courts.

Members of the liberation movements who were guilty of hu-man rights abuses in the frontline states have little to fear from South African law.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Book Piracy in South Africa on the Rise


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Philippa Garson


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Johannesburg - A publisher has uncovered a potentially massive book piracy operation in KwaZulu- Natal, but believes police are reluctant to investigate.

Southern Books publisher Basil Van Rooyen was alerted to forgeries of a mathematics technical college textbook being sold at a Durban-based book shop -- Premier University Book Shop in Field Street -- earlier this year.

The book shop is owned by businessman Nel Bisseru, whose family owns various book shops, outlets and library services supplying books to the University of Durban-Westville, ML Sultan Technikon, Natal Technikon and schools and libraries. 

Van Rooyen discovered the pirate operation when another Durban-based book distributor asked him several months ago why Premier University Book Shop was still selling the textbook when his own shop had not received any more copies.

Van Rooyen said he realised something was amiss, since he knew the book was out of print. He asked a colleague to purchase the textbook from Premier University Book Shop and on examining the book, found it was a pirated version.

The forged books have been bound with "perfect binding", meaning the pages are glued straight to the spine, as opposed to the genuine articles which are "section sewn". The forged books can also be distinguished by their contrasting bold and light typeface and their softer covers, which curl up.

Armed with affidavits, including one from the printer of the genuine book, who concluded the replica had been photographed, Van Rooyen went to Durban in February.

He was under the impression that police, confronted with the evidence, would raid Bisseru's book shop. However, Van Rooyen says he was simply passed from one investigating officer to the next and discouraged from pursuing the matter.

Captain A Hemraj, from the police criminal unit in Durban, denied police were holding back on the investigation. "We are busy with the investigation which we will then pass on to the courts to make a decision."

The textbook's selling price is R42,95. According to Van Rooyen, the manufacturing cost is only six rand per book. This means the forgers could pocket a profit of R37 for every book sold.

Attempts to contact Bisseru for comment were unsuccessful.

"What we are aware of could be the tip of the iceberg. The piracy could involve millions of books which are being counterfeited. My big worry is if this kind of thing continues we'll slide to the level of countries like Burma where -- because of the levels of piracy -- - no one wants to do business," said Van Rooyen.

Owen Dean, an attorney specialising in copyright law, said police were traditionally reluctant to pursue what they perceive to be civil law infringements. While Johannesburg police have shown a willingness to act in cases of piracy of books, records, videos and computer software, "Durban has traditionally been a difficult area" -- ostensibly because of the violence and police manpower problem.

Dean encouraged publishers to pursue civil cases if they seek justice.

Technology is the biggest threat to copyright, said Dean, "because it makes reproduction so easy and cost-effective". Currently, international publishing groups are putting their heads together to find ways of maintaining ownership of "intellectual property" once it hits the information highway on the Internet.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


64 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance South African Unions May Back Privatisation


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Gaye Davis and Justin Pearce


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Johannesburg - Government and labour will square up over privatisation on June 15, at the first meeting of parties under the National Framework Agreement (NFA), signed in January.

President Nelson Mandela's statement on his return from Germany -- to the effect that privatisation was "fundamental policy" of the African National Congress and would be implemented -- will add impetus to the meeting. Public Enterprises minister Stella Sigcau followed up this week, saying she was confident the unions could be brought on board.

The NFA sets out principles and procedures for restructuring state assets and pulls together government ministries and the three labour federations: the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu), the National Council of Trade Unions (Nactu) and the Federation of South African Labour (Fedsal). 

Both sides have been preparing their positions. Stephen Rix, a researcher with the National Labour and Economic Development Institute (Naledi), which has been appointed by the union federations as the co-ordinating body for labour's research effort, said state funds had been provided for labour to employ its own advisers.

Rix said work had been done by affected unions within each of the federations, but this had to be "massaged and assessed". A key item on the agenda for the meeting was time-frames.

Part of the problem with the process, which has been in stop-start mode since government's first announcement on privatisation in June 1994, was it had run ahead of government.

"Entities that wanted strategic equity partners got going, but the government had yet to put a macro-economic framework in place," said one source.

Government was under pressure from "vultures (foreign investors) who want to buy and merchant bankers who want big fees for handling the sales", but government first had to complete the process of maximising the value of the assets it would sell through re- engineering and getting rid of loss-making entities.

A source in the Public Enterprises ministry said it was felt "enough preliminary exploratory discussion analysis" had been done and it was time to get a move on.

In an address to the World Economic Forum in Cape Town, Cosatu secretary general Sam Shilowa reiterated the federation's position that it was in favour of restructuring of state assets as a means of achieving upliftment and the goals of reconstruction and development, but was opposed to privatisation being the central tool for doing so.

In the absence of any macro-economic plan, government was looking to selling off state assets to bolster its fiscus when it should be looking at reprioritising spending and investigating what the private sector was prepared to do in terms of dealing with job losses.

Naledi economist Ravi Naidoo said Shilowa's speech was indicative of a more flexible position, but he was essentially saying the same thing. "Cosatu is saying to government, if you have a plan, come and show us how it fits into the bigger pie. You can't just say that because there's a problem with the economy we have to sell state assets because that's the trend internationally."

The left recognises the bankruptcy of a command economy, but is just as opposed to the neo-liberalism of the Thatcherite model. South African Communist Party deputy general secretary and ANC national executive committee member, Jeremy Cronin, told the Mail & Guardian of a "confused adherence to neo- liberalism by some within the ANC, who are under the illusion that one can glue neo- liberal economics on to Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP) aims". But this tendency did not represent a shift to the right by the ANC, he said.

The Thatcherite model had "never worked, and least of all in a country emerging from war or from third-world under-development". But a Stalinist model of wholesale nationalisation was equally misguided, he said, affirming the party's commitment to "the RDP model, growth through development and development through growth".

"We need business in that process. We need to find ways of encouraging the private sector into that process."

At the same time, "if the ANC became a centrist, Tony Blair kind of party it would lose its constituency".


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


65 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Profits Boost for Big Banking Group ABSA


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996 by Mungo Soggot and Justin Pearce


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Johannesburg - While Africa's largest banking group, Amalgamated Banks of South Africa (Absa), unveiled a 50% surge in profits this week, it failed to declare to what extent its figures were buoyed by the tail-end of a R1,125- billion gift from the taxpayer.

The gift was the controversial five-year secret "lifeboat" the Reserve Bank threw to Bankorp (the then parent company of TrustBank) in 1990 when Bankorp was close to collapse. Absa bought Bankorp two years later and with it, the boon of the lifeboat. The gift, or lifeboat, fed the Absa group with about R225- million a year until last October. 

Because the Reserve Bank and Absa had agreed to secrecy on the lifeboat, the banking conglomerate did not acknowledge its existence until November last year when, in a nationwide advertising campaign, it came clean.

The lifeboat has often been presented as a loan which Absa has fully repaid, but in fact it was a gift. The Reserve Bank gave Bankorp government bonds at a 1% interest rate, which Absa then sold back to the Reserve Bank at an interest rate of between 15% and 18%. The fruits of this deal were the lifeboat Absa inherited when it bought Bankorp.

Absa's upbeat financial results for the year to March -- which boasted profits of R1,13- billion -- was its first opportunity since it broke its Reserve Bank-imposed silence to explain to its shareholders how the lifeboat helped it, and them, out.

But there was no mention of the Reserve Bank package, which had originally been given to Bankorp to help it write off a string of debts owed to it, including some from the troubled conglomerate, Tollgate. None of the debts supposedly written off by the Reserve Bank's lifeboat have been mentioned in the accounts.

Absa has said nothing about repaying the Reserve Bank, and the Ministry of Finance said this week it had yet to look into possible action.

In its results, Absa also failed to note that it had enjoyed a R51-million injection from Sanlam. In 1992, Sanlam -- which was a major shareholder in Bankorp -- said it would give Absa R51-million a year for the next 10 years when Absa bought Bankorp.

Absa said Sanlam's injection was irrelevant as it went towards repaying a debt to Absa. The bank said the Reserve Bank lifeboat did not figure in the annual accounts because it had no impact on current results. Absa said it will only repay the money if there is any left over after writing off bad debts. It will deal with the Bankorp package in its annual report.

Announcing Absa's results on Monday, chief executive Danie Cronje said Absa's strategy this coming year included an offshore expansion drive. Lawyers say it is likely that higher standards of corporate disclosure abroad will force Absa to reveal more about financial implications of the the Reserve Bank lifeboat.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


66 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa The Western Cape Goes To The Polls


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 31, 1996


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Cape Town - "Trust nobody," scream the walls of a Hanover Park tenement building on the Cape Flats. Not only is the message scrawled in crude black ink, but the disrepair of the buildings, the rubbish lifting in the wind and the belligerent poverty of the area testify to the fact that politicians have not yet bought the Hanover Park community "A better life for all", promised by the African National Congress since 1994.

Yet the queue at the Hanover Park polling station this Wednesday during the Western Cape local government elections was long and patient. Residents arrived at the gates to the polling booths throughout the day, ID books in hand, to select a politician to represent them on local councils. As in many areas in the poorer parts of Cape Town, posters were few and far between, and voting was a low-key event.

"Not much problems here," said an official. "Just, people can't understand why they must vote three times. But we have explained that to them ..." He broke off to talk to an elderly man who wanted to vote, but who had not registered. As we got back into the car to continue our tour, the elderly man limped away from the polling station on his own, clutching his ID book, without having cast his vote. 

Back on the road, the line of posters got thinner and thinner the further away from Cape Town centre we went. Between Nyanga and Philippi, there were one or two ANC posters on the lampposts, and then suddenly an unexpected Democratic Party poster, stuck in the middle of shackland. On closer inspection, it became clear that the DP poster was serving as an important part of a shack wall, and was not a clear sign of support for DP leader Tony Leon. At a small squatter settlement called Phola Park, I asked a woman who she was voting for.

"The National Party," she said. "Where's your money?"

"I don't have any money," I answered.

"I vote NP if you give me money ... where's your money?"

On realising that she had no chance of getting anything, she burst out: "This is ANC, go away NP, this is ANC." As we retreated to the car, small groups of women shouted, "ANC! ANC!" and held up their fists, half in salute and half in anger. The men looked up with amusement from their card games.

Around the corner, a man festooned in ANC paraphernalia also asked for money.

Petrol pump attendant Arthur Mduzulwana was, however, grateful for an apple, and gave " a statement" to the media: "I vote for the ANC because it is going to make my life here easier ... The NP is lying. We like FW as our ex-president, but he must not gossip about the ANC as he does. The ANC will give us houses, water and jobs for all people so the crime rate is not so high. Nelson Mandela is our president."

Mandela's voting place, Westerford High School on Rondebosch Main Road, seemed a world away from Phola Park on the Cape Flats. Mandela strode out of his official residence Genadendal on Wednesday morning, with the ANC candidate, city architect Revel Fox, at his side. They were mobbed by photographers, by Fox's groupies and by curious passers-by.

Neatly maroon-jacketed school girls and boys and their families waited for Mandela with tea and biscuits and a choir performance. Local Rondebosch families were agog as he shook hands, talking here and there with his characteristic ease, and bubbles of hysteria mounted among the young people, especially the teenage girls.

"He touched my hand, he touched my hand," shouted one, staring at her thumb and forefingers as if she wanted to chop them off and preserve them in a jar of aspic until kingdom come. Mandela had impact, but most of the excitement faded after he left in the middle of the morning.

The Fox team made the boldest splash of all in Rondebosch, with a table and stands and many bright posters, swamping the other parties, which relied on posters on lampposts to make their statements.

By midday, it became clear that the winner of the best election poster award just had to go to Nando's. Posters placed throughout the city proclaimed the fast-food outlet's message: "Food for all"; "We stand for family values"; "Vote for the left and the right wing"; "No foul play"; "Against battered chicken"; "Simply the breast"; "Now you've made your mark, have your lunch".

Nando's put the other election messages in the shade. The NP had a selection, including the grim "Death penalty for murderers" and the fantastical "Save the rand". The ANC stuck to the tried and tested "Make it happen in your ward" and "Die NP het misluk".

The Freedom Front ignored the volkstaat with "Equal rights for equal service" and the Conservative Party hit out at the NP with "Geen blanke tjek vir FW/ANC". The African Christian Democratic Party preached "Morality, stability, accountability", "Ensuring your family's future" and "No slogans, just action". The DP boasted: "More meat less gravy", "Bang vir niks" and "Tough, capable, determined".

It was difficult to find many signs of the DP outside the traditionally white areas, but in Delft there was a small outpost -- a house covered with DP posters. It was the Delft undertaker's house. The undertaker, Stanley van der Bergh, brought his own touch to the DP message, adding to posters the words "Join the DP for peace" and "Set the Cape free".

He said it was probable that the Delft community would stick to its traditional voting lines of ANC and NP, but he hoped there might be a swing to the DP, "because the DP is the party of delivery and businessmen. They are the people who fight for us in Parliament, not the NP."

Election agents and party workers confirmed at different polling stations that one of the problems in this election was that people were confusing local issues with national policy, and would probably still continue to vote along the lines they did in the 1994 general election.

But this local government election was altogether much calmer and flatter than that of 1994. Despite administrative hitches and some confusion in the townships about registration, the voting process was smooth - -- unexpectedly so after the rough and ready final election campaigns, during which the NP and ANC jostled each other for the coloured vote.

An NP supporter in Mitchell's Plain was dismissive of the ANC on Wednesday. "I lost my job, you see, three years ago, in the bakeries ... It was when the unions came in. Cosatu gave money to the ANC and that is why they are a party now ... it's my money. I used to get R3 000 a month, now I am getting R250 a week and I am glad to have a job." He walked away in disgust.

ANC MPs, especially those from up-country, said they were appalled at the crudeness of the approach of some of the NP supporters they encountered.

One told this story the day before the elections: "We were campaigning in Mitchell's Plain and these tannies lifted up their skirts and said, 'See that, it belongs to FW de Klerk, not to you.'"

The MP rolled his eyes in prudish disapproval.

By the time of going to print, insufficient results had come in to be able to decide whether De Klerk got lucky on the Cape Flats, but the first signs indicated the NP was keeping the ground it won during the election of 1994.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


67 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia African Peacekeepers Claim Control of Monrovia


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 31, 1996


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Monrovia - The African peacekeeping force ECOMOG claimed on May 29 to have taken "firm" control in central Monrovia following redeployment of its troops throughout the city, the force's chief of staff said.

After a tour of the capital, Brigadier General Gabriel Anyankpele told newsmen he was satisfied that the deployment operation, which began on May 26, had been completed "smoothly and peacefully without any obstruction from any of the parties" to factional fighting which flared up in early April.

Anyankpele urged residents who have fled their homes to return and take charge of their "remaining belongings," promising that the peacekeepers would "do everything to protect them."

He said an early return of civilians "is the only was they can protect what is left of their homes." 

Anyankpele said his tour, conducted on May 28, took him to the diplomatic enclave of Mamba Point, the military Barclay Training Centre (BTC), the presidential Executive Mansion, and Monrovia's eastern Congotown and Paynesville suburbs.

Most civilians were still reluctant to return home for fear of an outbreak of renewed fighting.

For the first time in seven weeks, a convoy carrying badly needed relief food to displaced centres on May 28 drove on the Gabriel Tucker bridge (new bridge), the scene of prolonged fierce factional fighting.

In other parts of Monrovia, Liberia's only reliable safe haven for the past six years until early April when the fighting broke out, residents began cleaning up the debris left by the street violence.

Owners of stores and shops in central Monrovia were busy cleaning around their stores offering electronic devices, video players, refrigerators, spare parts and other accessories for vehicles.

Most of the streets were still strewn with human bodies and left covered with debris including huge piles of garbage, burnt vehicles, broken window panes and bottles as well as heaps of torn merchandise cartons.

Faction leader and ruling council of state member Charles Taylor, on May 28 said he was contributing some five tonnes of rice towards a government-sponsored clean-up campaign for the city.

Carey and Benson streets, which lead to Greystone near the US Embassy, where more than 20,000 civilians are refuged, have become the busiest routes in Monrovia.

The streets were also clogged by several thousand suburban dwellers heading to Greystone to trace friends and relatives unseen during the fighting.

Prices of food commodities were skyrocketing.

On the same day, a spokesman from the Ministry of Health said a team comprising personnel from the ministry, the World Health Organization (WHO), and the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), was preparing to collect bodies still lying in some streets.

Meanwhile, UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali on May 22 recommended that the 25 members of the UN Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) be maintained in Liberia until August 31, despite sporadic eruption of heavy factional fighting that has been preventing them from doing their job.

But Boutros-Ghali warned that the UNOMIL presence depended on that of African peacekeepers of the ECOMOG force and that if they were withdrawn, "UNOMIL would have no choice but to do the same."

Boutros-Ghali recalled that when UNOMIL was set up in September 1993 "it was clearly recognised that unarmed UN military observers would require the provision of security by ECOMOG in order to fulfil their mandated tasks."

However, Boutros-Ghali said that "ECOMOG has not been able to provide the level of security necessary for UNOMIL personnel to function in Liberia, or to fulfil entirely its own responsibilities as a peacekeeping force."

"This was amply demonstrated by the events of the past few weeks," during which factional fighting erupted in Monrovia, Boutros-Ghali said.

The UN Secretary General also said that the problem of looted equipment during the unrest had to be addressed.

He said the UN was currently attempting to assess the value of goods and equipment looted by Liberian fighters, which included 80 per cent of UNOMIL vehicles taken, and many destroyed.

During the wholesale looting, UNOMIL telephones, computers, photocopiers, communications equipment were among the stolen items, he added.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


68 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Algeria Archbishop Vows To Stay Despite Monks' Murder


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 31, 1996


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Algeria - The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Algiers, Monsignor Henri Teissier, vowed on May 27 that Christian priests planned to stay in the country despite the recent murder by extremists of seven French Trappist monks.

In an interview here by the daily La Tribune, Teissier, who is French said: "We decided to stay because we know that we have the support of our friends and all those who work with us, as well as our neighbours who accept our presence and who have cultural and friendly relations with us."

The archbishop added that he did not doubt the authenticity of the communique from the Armed Islamic Group (GIA) which said that the seven monks kidnapped in March had been killed.

Following the announcement, France reiterated its call for its 300 or so nationals still in Algeria to leave the country or risk the same fate as dozens of foreigners killed by fundamentalists in the last four years. 

The extremist groups, the Armed Islamic Group (GIA) and other fundamentalist Islamic groups, launched an armed insurrection against the secular authorities after the army stepped in to cancel the second round of legislative elections in January 1992, which the now banned Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) was poised to win.

The vow to stay on in Algeria came as protests and controversy were mounting against extremists over the murder of the monks.

In Paris, French police said that around 10,000 people took to the streets on the evening of May 28 to protest the murder of the seven monks in Algeria.

The crowd, which included Prime Minister Alain Juppe and politicians from all parties as well as trade union and religious leaders, met at the Place du Trocadero, many wearing white carnations.

Two huge banners were unfurled, reading: "If we are silent, the stones will cry out." A minute's silence for the dead was followed by music from Samuel Barber and Gustav Mahler.

The extremists Armed Islamic Group, one of the most radical groups fighting the Algerian government since it annulled elections in January 1992, said it killed the Trappist monks last week, nearly two months after their abduction.

Juppe made no comment, but signed a book of condolences. French Foreign Minister Herve de Charette however said: "We did all in our power to get the monks out of the claws holding them." The rally was called for by Education Minister Francois Bayrou, who said it was to demonstrate the solidarity of all sections of French society.

Among the religious figures was Cardinal Jean-Marie Lustiger, the archbishop of Paris, leaders of the Jewish community in France and the Imam Mehdi Rouhani, spiritual leader of the Muslim Shiite community in Europe.

The former Socialist Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy said: "It was the least we could do to honour those who were massacred and to demonstrate our readiness to unite against barbarism."

Earlier on May 27, trade unions had urged their members to participate and the rector of the Paris mosque's Muslim Institute, Dalil Boubakeur, had also urged "all Muslims of France whatever their opinions to take part in this gathering."

The mufti of Marseille Mosque Soheib Bencheikh likewise called on Muslims of France to attend the demonstration in protest at the killing of the monks whose murder was claimed by the Islamic Armed Group (GIA).

A memorial mass was celebrated on May 26 for the monks at the Cistercian Abbey of Aiguebelle in south-west France. Father Yves de Broucker, the superior used the occasion to call for "reconciliation" in Algeria.

"Let us pray that the fate of our seven brothers may sow the seeds of reconciliation among the Algerian people and peace for the Church of Algeria," he said.

The abbey of Notre Dame d'Aiguebelle near Monjoyer in the Drome region, founded in 1934 the monastery in Tiberihine near Medea in the Atlas mountains, where the seven monks were seized during a raid in March.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


69 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Central African Republic Mutineers and Government Negotiate


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Bangui - Soldiers in the Central African Republic who led a 10-day mutiny against the regime of President Ange-Felix Patasse began direct negotiations with the government on May 29, only two days after they returned to barracks without pre-conditions.

The negotiations would be attended by the Archbishop Joachim N'Dayen of Bangui and League of Human Rights President Nicolas Tiangaye, who had acted as mediators at the National Assembly throughout the crisis.

The mutiny left 43 people dead, 11 of them soldiers, and injured 238, Patasse said on May 29 in an address to the nation, quoting Red Cross figures. Of the injured, 212 were civilians and 26 were soldiers. 

A European diplomatic source here had earlier said that the civilian casualty toll was 32 killed and 212 injured in the bloody revolt before it ended on May 26, and that most of these civilians were killed or injured by stray bullets.

Mutineers, who were estimated by a French military source to number about 500, out of a total 4,000 Central African Republic troops, had previously negotiated only with General Bernard Thorette, in charge of the French military operation that supported the government during the conflict.

Fighting had taken place between mutineers and loyalists, as well as between rebel soldiers and French troops sent in to prop up the Patasse regime in this former French colony where Paris maintains one of its key military bases in Africa.

The rebel soldiers agreed on May 26 to a general return to the Kasai military barracks in the eastern part of Bangui, after Patasse promised them amnesty, ending the fighting.

Negotiations on May 29 would focus on the preparation of an amnesty law, an informed source said.

Meanwhile, opposition groups in the Central African Republic on May 28 laid out their conditions for entering a government of national unity under President Ange Felix Patasse in the wake of a 10-day mutiny.

The umbrella group, Democratic Council of Opposition Parties (CODEPO) called for a change in the constitution to give the Prime Minister more powers, and for it to nominate a premier.

It also called for a conference of national reconciliation, for arms given to civilians during the mutiny to be handed back, for a consensus between the army and Patasse, and an amnesty for the mutineers.

Patasse, in an accord signed with the rebel soldiers on May 26, had already agreed to an amnesty.

He said then he was taking steps to form a government of national unity which "will call on all legal political groups and civilian society."

The mutiny was sparked by attempts to disarm soldiers who had taken part in another mutiny a month earlier over unpaid wages.

A French Foreign Ministry spokesman said in Paris that a government of national unity was essential to restore stability to the Central African Republic.

The spokesman said the accord, which was brokered by the French military commander in Bangui, was being implemented with the return of mutinous troops to their barracks, leaving French troops to patrol the city.

Africa News


May, 1996


Burundi Massacres Continue as France Washes Its Hands


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 31, 1996


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Bujumbura - At least 59 people have been butchered in Burundi following an attack by Hutu rebels on Tutsis at a displaced people's camp in the eastern part of the country, the Burundian army officially announced on May 29.

The army had initially said at least 51 people died in the May 28 attack by Hutu rebels who set fire to 74 huts in the camp at Butezi, in the eastern province of Ruhigi.

Defence Ministry spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Longin Minani said another 25 people were seriously injured and that many others were missing. He said the assailants had also been involved in an earlier attack on the Tutsi-dominated army in the neighbouring province of Gitega. 

The military announcement came only hours after the French government announced in Paris that it was suspending its military cooperation because of "security problems" and the political deadlock paralysing this tiny central African country.

In a statement, the French Foreign Ministry spokesman said that all of 23 French military advisers that were in Burundi as at April 15, will have left the war-torn country by June 9.

"The minimum conditions necessary for military cooperation to function well are no longer there. We have therefore decided to suspend our military cooperation with Burundi until a comprehensive political settlement has put an end to the violence and committed the country to the path of national reconciliation," the spokesman said.

Burundi has been in the throes of ethnic violence for more than two years since an attempted coup in October 1993 in which Melchior Ndadaye, Burundi's first President from the majority Hutus, was killed.

A former Belgian colony and UN trusteeship, Burundi achieved independence in 1962.

France had less than 10 civilian advisers in Burundi, but they were also being reduced, the spokesman said.

Meanwhile, UN officials are seeking commitments from member countries for a possible emergency operation in Burundi, which has been ravaged by new violence between Tutsis and Hutus, UN sources said on May 28.

UN peacekeeping chief Kofi Annan chaired a planning meeting at UN headquarters with representatives of several countries, including France as an observer, a UN official said. A similar meeting was held on May 10.

The official said Annan was giving priority to a negotiated solution in the African state but that rapid "contingency" plans were being examined in the event of a wider outbreak of violence.

France had refused to attend the earlier session organised by the United States, claiming that only countries willing to join a UN force should participate. Paris was also irritated that the meeting was held at the US mission rather than at UN headquarters.

Attending the May 28 session were at least seven countries, including the United States, the Netherlands, Canada, Norway, Belgium, France and Britain, according to a UN source.

Some African countries are willing to participate in a Burundi operation, but if an emergency mission is organized, the main element would be Western countries, diplomats here said.

The United States is prepared to offer logistical support but no troops, the sources said. No Western power was willing to head the mission.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


71 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Nigerian Rights Groups Condemn UN


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 31, 1996


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Lagos - Democracy campaigners in Nigeria have strongly condemned a reported endorsement by a United Nations fact-finding mission of military ruler General Sani Abacha's three-year plan to return the country to civilian rule.

The Campaign for Democracy (CD) - a coalition of human rights groups - was reacting on May 28 to a story filed at the weekend by the New York correspondent of the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN), which quoted a report of a recent UN team to Nigeria as saying that the three-year transition programme was genuine and that no attempt should be made to interrupt or reverse it.

The mission, according to the NAN, also warned against imposition of sanctions on Nigeria because such a step could "hurt only ordinary people" and have a negative impact on Nigerian society and the whole of West Africa.

But in a statement, the contents of which were made known here on May 28, the CD said that the report of the UN team, if it truly endorsed the three-year transition programme, "only reinforces our conviction of its duplicity (...) its compromise." 

"We believe that the mission, which last April 13 ended its two-week assignment to Nigeria, was "pre-meditated and pre-arranged," the CD said.

According to the statement, the UN report "believes the global clamour for democratic recovery in Nigeria" and has also "betrayed a genuine appreciation of the issues at stake in Nigeria's political crisis."

The report of the UN four-man team, a copy of which was presented recently to General Abacha in Abuja by a special envoy of the UN Secretary-General, Boutros Bourtos-Ghali, is yet to be made public in Nigeria.

During its two-week stay in Nigeria, the UN team investigated the execution last November 10 of writer Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight of his Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People (MOSOP) companions, the human rights situation in Nigeria and the regime's plan to return the nation to democracy.

The delegation held talks with General Abacha, detained Chief Moshood Abiola, top government officials, prosecution and defence lawyers in the trial of Ken Saro-Wiwa and visited oil-rich Ogoniland, the community where the executed activists originated, and also held talks with many pro-democracy, human rights and professional groups.

Before leaving the country, the leader of the delegation, Koffi Atsu Amega, a Togolese, described the human rights situation in Nigeria as "terrible".

The sudden about-turn was the more surprising to human rights activists here particularly when it comes only a few days after the Nigerian government had announced plans to undertake a series of democratic reforms, notably proposing to exclude military personnel from special courts in which civil disobedience cases are heard.

The measures, contained in a letter addressed to UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali from Auwalu Hamisu Yadudu, legal advisor to Nigeria ruler General Sani Abacha, and made public at the UN on May 24, addressed in particular the Ogoni tribe, and were taken following a report from a UN fact-finding mission in Nigeria, a spokesman from the world body said.

The document said the Civil Disturbance Act that led to the conviction-- and eventual hanging -- of Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight others "will be amended" to prohibit military personnel on the tribunal and to allow for the appeals of verdicts.

It also said the government will investigate whether there are "peculiar ecological and environmental problems in the Ogoni area."

Saro-Wiwa, an Ogoni activist, had accused oil giant Shell of ravaging parts of the Niger delta by reckless drilling for oil.

But the letter from Yadudu said Abacha had also ordered the "immediate review of the cases of all persons currently being detained without trial" under a 1984 decree and that "very shortly, such persons will be released based on an assessment of the individual merit of each case."

The letter also said the 1984 statute, known as Decree No.2, which allows people suspected of "acts prejudicial to state security" to be detained without trial, will be changed to allow for a review every three months of those cases.

In addition, the government said it will repeal the 1994 Decree No.14, which suspends courts' ability to issue writs of Habeas Corpus, generally a step in the court appeals process.

The proposed repeal of the laws was seen by human rights groups and lawyers as amounting to an admission by the government of guilt in the case and called on the authorities to translate it into practice by removing decrees that remove power of courts from entertaining certain cases in which the government had interest.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
