Africa News


May, 1996


Ethiopia Police Holding Missing Lutheran Official


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Addis Ababa - It has been established that an official of the Ethiopian Evangelical Church Mekane Yesus (EECMY), earlier on reported to have been kidnapped by unidentified persons here is being held by the police.

A EECMY official, who spoke to APS on condition that his name would not be disclosed, said Haily Terfassa Tasse, who is the administrator of one of the church's hostels in the Ethiopian capital "is being held at the Central Police Station, here."

The church official said Tasse, went missing on April 17, when he was reportedly kidnapped by unidentified persons, while driving to one of the commercial banks in Addis Ababa.

The April 23 edition of Urgent Action, an update bulletin of cases brought to the attention of the London-based human rights organisation, Amnesty International, reported the disappearance of Hailu Terfassa Tasse, 52. 

"His whereabouts remained obscure for a couple of weeks. However, now he can be visited by his wife," the church official told APS in a telephone interview.

He said the major reasons for Tasse's detention would be suspicion that he is having links with the Oromo Liberation Front (OLF), which is fighting the government for self-determination in the south of this Horn of Africa country with a population of over 50 million people.

The church official further told APS he has already visited Tasse at the police station and also confirmed that the suspect's wife also paid her husband a visit.

"I spoke to him and he told me he was being held at the police station since April 17 and that he has not been 'treated badly'. Asked what he (Tasse) was likely to be charged with, the church official was non-committal.

He however disclosed that the church was trying to get their employee released on bail, but by the time of going to press these efforts had not been successful.

Asked whether kidnapping of church personnel was common, the church official said; "Tasse's was the

first in the EECMY since the overthrow of Mengistu Haile Mariam's Derg government. However he cited cases of employees of the church who have been detained but released later on related issues.

"We hope Mr. Tasse will be released soon", the anonymous official said.

In its URGENT/ACTION update dated April 23, 1996 citing dissappearance and fear of torture Amnesty International expresses fear that "his (Tasse's)family have been unable to trace him in police stations but his car was reportedly later found at the Central Police Station."

"Amnesty International fears that he may be held in a secret detention centre and could be at risk of ill-treatment or torture," says the human rights report.

The report describes Mr. Tasse as a prominent Oromo elder, adding that "many members of the Oromo nationality (or ethnic group) have been detained without charge or trial since February 1996 on suspicion of having links with the OLF, which is fighting the government in the Oromo region."

Ethiopia's population comprises 45 per cent Muslims, 40 per cent Orthodox Christians while the remaining 15 per cent is shared among Protestants, Evangelicals, Roman Catholics and other faith. The EECMY which is Lutheran, was instituted in Ethiopia in 1958. It has a membership of some 1.6 million Christians.

EECMY became a member of the Lutheran World Federation (LWF) in 1963 and is affiliated to both the Geneva-based World Council of Churches (WCC) and the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC).

Ethiopia is ranked second after Tanzania in the category of African countries with the highest number of Lutherans. Tanzania has an estimated 2.2 million Lutherans, Ethiopia 1.6 million, Madagascar 1.5 million, South Africa 829,000, while Namibia has some 700,000 Lutherans.

There are some 7 million Lutherans in Africa out of a total world population of 54 million.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


73 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large African Churches Challenged on Wealth Distribution


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Limuru, Kenya - A church consultation here has reminded African churches of their onus to challenge laws that perpetuate unequal distribution of wealth among the African people.

The May 21 o 24 meeting here, some 30 kilometres west of Nairobi, also called for research and implemention of new economic methods that would encourage income generation towards self-reliance.

The 18 para-church organisations in Kenya and local Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs), also highlighted the need for churches to teach and promote a biblical work ethic for all in the society.

The 85 participants were mainly drawn from Kenya but Botswana, Nigeria, Tanzania and the United States were also represented. 

On spiritual concerns, the participants said; "we should feel obliged to repent as individuals, local churches and groups, of our lack of faith in God, to supply for the needs in the work He has called us to perform.

"We should also feel obliged to repent of the failure to faithfully administer the resources entrusted to us and the failure to be accountable to God, to His people and to each other," they further recommended.

They also emphasized the churches' need to seek divine intervention to enhance a spirit of renewal in doing God's work in Africa with resources from the continent.

The participants added; "We should also make efforts to return to a clear and consistent teaching of scriptures on giving and self- reliance, in our personal lives and churches too."

And on leadership, the consultation participants called on churches in Africa to ensure that future partnerships between them and donor partners are characterised by mutual respect, trust, full participation, clear understanding, equal contribution and distribution of resources.

The church in Africa should recognise and utilize human resources and other skills whenever possible in the local churches and organisations, the participants further stressed.

They also stressed the need for churches to be exemplary role models encouraging simpler life-styles and honouring the Creator.

The consultation on self-reliance, was organised by the local churches in Kenya and coordinated by Mr. McMillan Kiiru, a consultant with a Nairobi-based NGO, Lenmac, and a former General Secretary of the Fellowship of Christian Communicators in Africa and Madagascar (FOCCAM).

In his introductory remarks, Mr. Kiiru said although the church seems to be struggling in the search for resources to fulfill the Great Commission, it is "my conviction that there are adequate God-giving resources, which need to be mobilised and developed.

"But this, would require a change of attitude and practice as well as making efforts to reduce our vulnerabilities and increase our capacities, not least our faith in God," Kiiru said.

He also stressed the need to develop a greater sense of ownership and commitment to the Church by Africans themselves and more so through financial support.

Financial support from the West, he stressed, has been coupled with foreign leadership and influence with programmes, which, he added, have not been culturally appropriate, reveal paternalistic attitudes, mismanagement of available resources, lack of accountability, fightings and quarrels within the church, a spirit of competition and duplication of efforts.

According to Mr. Kiiru, mission policies, regulations, historical practices and philosophies have often

contributed to and even encouraged a dependency syndrome by the African church. "Western funding has in the past been used for theological education, missionary outreach, development projects, pastors salaries and even buildings for Christian worship, Mr. Kiiru further told the consultation.

He noted that the Church in Africa has struggled with limited success to create a more indigenous Christian movement by raising support for her ministries locally. "This can partly be blamed on poverty which characterises the continent as well as a mentality that Africans are too poor to give to their own church," he added.

The meeting was addressed by among others the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) General Secretary, Rev. Jose Chipenda, the former General Secretary of the Presbyterian Church of East Africa (PCEA), Rev. John Gatu, the current chairman of the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK), Rev. Zablon Nthamburi, who is also the Presiding Bishop of the Methodist Church here and Dr. G. Ikiara of the University of Nairobi.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Kenya Christians Join In Worldwide March


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Nairobi - An estimated 20,000 Christians on May 25 converged at the Kenyatta International Conference Centre (KICC) grounds here, for interdenominational prayers for the government, families and the country's youth after a five-kilometre walk, "March for Jesus", marked by 15 million Christians in 180 nations worldwide.

The Christians who had marched into the city from five directions singing God's praises, prayed that justice would prevail in Kenya's parliament and judiciary.

Delivering the day's sermon, Bishop Muyu of Gospel Tabernacle said that trouble is brought by disobedience. "There are some serious consequences to every disobedience," he said. Like Jonah in the Bible, one must be quick to understand the cause in order to deal with the problem. "The answer for Kenya is not to flee from the presence of God," he advised. 

After a session of thanksgiving, confessions and supplications were made on behalf of Kenyan youth for deliverance from alcoholism, drugs and premarital sex.

The congregation also prayed for the government and the economy.

Relating to the gathering what had ensued from the previous "March for Jesus" held in 1994, the steering committee chairman Rev. Ibrahim Omondi of Dove Fellowship recalled that the shilling which had been experiencing "high fever" at the time was "healed" and concerning the infamous 1992 to 1994 land clashes, we today celebrate the end of tribal land clashes.

Of devil worshippers, another prayer concern, Rev. Omondi said they were now in the country "illegally", after the institution of a probe committee by the President.

Kenya, with a population of 25.7 million people experienced an inflation rate as high as 110 per cent in 1992 and a negative growth rate from 1992 to 1994, after which a three per cent growth rate was recorded.

The exchange rate of the US dollar to the shilling in 1994 stood at 1$ to between shs 60 and 70. Today the dollar has stabilized at about shs. 58. The land clashes too, started in 1992 and ended in 1994, while the probe committee comprising spiritual leaders, educationists, social workers and lawyers was instituted January 1995.

The interdenominational march, entirely funded by the Kenyan churches, was the result of joint efforts by church leaders mainly of evangelical, pentecostal and mainline church background, although other churches and the general public were invited.

Christians comprise 70 per cent of the population, with Roman Catholics accounting for 18 per cent while the rest are Protestants.

A "March for Jesus" event comprises a praise march and a prayer assembly. Among its purposes is to publicly affirm and declare love for Jesus, to share His love, to repent and publicly humble, to praise the person of Jesus Christ and not to parade personalities.

This was Nairobi's second "March for Jesus".


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


75 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Tanzania Lake Victoria Disaster Ferry Not Insured


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Mwanza, Tanzania - Divers from Kenya, South Africa and Tanzania are hampered by extreme dark conditions as they try to free hundreds of bodies still trapped in the compartment of the ill fated Lake Victoria ferry, MV Bukoba.

More than 400 bodies have been recovered from Lake Victoria since the unprecedented marine tragedy occurred on May 20.

Lt. Commander Ahmed Hamisi of the Zanzibar Navy said working conditions 100ft under water are dreadful. The divers had succeeded in cutting an access through the hull but lack of underwater lighting and the fact that the bodies had swelled and become more tightly packed had made their work "very difficult." 

Thousands of people are still camped by the lakeside in the port town of Mwanza awaiting to identify their loved ones for private burial, but many late recovered bodies are beyond identification except for peculiar features or clothing. The final death toll is expected to reach 1000, twice the carrying capacity of the ferry.

The ship which had chronic balance problems flipped over side ways at about daybreak while nearing Mwanza after an overnight trip from Bukoba on the western shores of Lake Victoria.

During an ecumenical prayer service for the dead at Mwanza stadium President Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania said an inquiry would be instituted and those responsible punished." Most of the recovered bodies were interred at Igara near Mwanza.

Rukiya Shamte of the Tanzanian Railways Corporation has meanwhile announced the suspension of Captain Jumane Rume in charge of the ill fated vessel as well as six officials of the Marine Department of Tanzania Railway who are in charge of the MV Bukoba. She said it was a routine safety enquiry after any accident.

A number of extremely disturbing facts have emerged about the MV Bukoba. First, Tanzania Railway officials said it was not insured. Secondly, the Belgian company that had supplied the ferry had already gone under. The ferry design was known to have stability problems but it was probably assumed that Lake Victoria was inherently safer than other seas.

Lastly, rescuers who cut the hull a few hours after the vessel capsized - but still remained afloat - ignored the pleas of local fishermen who told them the craft would sink once the trapped air escaped. Hundreds of people still trapped in the lower compartment at the time were still alive and banged frantically from inside. They perished 15 minutes after the hull was cut by the rescuers. The MV Bukoba now lies 100 ft under water.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


76 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Sudan Sudanese Women in Exile Celebrate


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 31, 1996 by Santino Makur Kot


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

Nairobi - Celebrations marking the second anniversary of the Kenya-based Sudanese Women's Association in Nairobi (SWAN) on April 27, were a milestone in the progress of Sudanese women who fled to neighbouring Kenya following civil war at home.

The event which coincided with the association's annual general meeting, was also attended by members residing in Lake Victoria's port town of Kisumu in Western Kenya, some 340 kilometres north-west of Nairobi.

SWAN, comprising southern Sudanese women exiles in Kenya, was registered in 1994. A non-charitable organisation, it encourages its members to work for a living, espousing commitment to a workable peace process in the Sudan. 

Speaking to APS, Mrs. Carla Tongun, the vice chairperson of the association, stated that despite the differences at home particularly as Southerners engage in factional fighting, the SWAN members, who are wives of those fighting, have worked together peacefully. This alone is a step towards peace and reconciliation among the Sudanese people, she added.

"The peace process cannot succeed unless the common people come together as they are the ones suffering and affected by the war particularly women, children and other vulnerable persons. Peace should be approached at the grass roots level and our leaders should be told to follow, not ask to be followed," Mrs. Tongun asserted.

The SWAN anniversary celebrations were also attended by other women groups, among them the Sudanese Women's Voice for Peace (SWVP).

Formed in February 1994, SWVP carries out peace related activities at the grass roots level while SWAN tackles social development programmes. The former also advocates peace initiatives and networking with regional and international peace movements.

Members of SWAN mainly face health and nutritional problems, and are generally poor, with war and poverty, related illness.

The association's main objective is to encourage channels of communication, consultation and interaction among and between diverse groups of Sudanese women who are living in Nairobi and Kisumu. It also identifies and prioritizes economic, social and educational needs of members, with the view of acquiring skills and knowledge to enable them become self-sufficient. Such efforts can help the group seek sisterly affiliation with other women groups in Kenya such as the Women Finance Trust (KWFT) which works with rural women groups.

A focal point for Sudanese activities in Nairobi, SWAN also coordinates educational programmes. About 37 women and two men recently underwent a six-month basic English language course in Nairobi conducted by teachers who are mainly from among the Sudanese women.

The ability to read, write and speak basic English is crucial for these women as this skill will help them join such courses as tailoring. Already, 36 of them are beneficiaries of tailoring courses. Out of this lot, 12 have already graduated and are putting the acquired skills to good use in their homes.

In the kindergarten project, 125 members have received partial scholarships for kindergarten-aged children. Without this basic education, Sudanese children cannot enter good primary schools in Kenya generally and Nairobi in particular.

More than 40 per cent of SWAN members cannot communicate in English and Kiswahili, Kenya's official and national language respectively. For a regular meeting of SWAN, discussions have to be translated into between five and eight languages.

Since 1995 some 81 women have benefitted from SWAN's English language courses.

But funding has been erratic. Sponsors do not always honour their pledges on time, which makes implementation of projects very difficult. From 1994 to 1995, SWAN's income totalled Kshs.4,158,688.00 (US$71,700) while expenditure stood at Kshs.3,602,615.00 (US$62,114). The United Nations Fund for Women (UNIFEM) is the major donor through the UN Women in Crisis programme.

Regarding overall development, the SWAN vice chairperson urges women to work hand in hand with men for progress. "A woman is a source of stability in the family and in the society as well," she says.

Through SWAN, Sudanese women living in this East African country have also attended regional and international seminars like the UN Women's Conference in Beijing, China last year.

They have also taken part in workshops on HIV awareness, nutrition, Christian growth and leadership courses, mostly sponsored by the UN Women in Crisis, Caritas Netherlands, and International Refugee trust (IRT).

As SWAN prepares women to realize their role in future leadership in the Sudan, Mrs. Tongun is very optimistic that when peace comes to the country, the association members, most of whom are involved in various self-sustaining activities, will be the resource people for rehabilitation.

Says one of the trainees Mrs. Yolanda Ilorya; "The English ,language training which I have acquired was good , but the six months was too short. I wish it could be extended."

Nevertheless, she was full of praise for the association. "SWAN is doing nice work for the Sudanese women in Nairobi, but they have financial constraints. If these women could get more help, they can support many Sudanese women who are suffering in Nairobi city with their children through education, feeding, health services and accommodation. Now they have trained many women in tailoring, taught them hygiene and granted loans despite the financial difficulties they encounter," she told this writer.

Sudan has been involved in civil war for the past four decades, resulting in dramatic displacement of the population. The war, including inter-factional fighting has further exacerbated the people's suffering caused by recurring droughts and floods. The current civil war involving the Khartoum government and the liberation groups in the south began in 1983.

Thousands of refugees have fled to neighbouring countries of Central African Republic, Kenya, Zaire, Uganda and Ethiopia. While thousands more have sought political asylum in other countries worldwide, millions more have been internally displaced.

The crisis has left miserable images of destroyed property, family separations, mental and physical disabilities, and the overall destruction of the social, cultural and economic fabric that held society together.

Women have often watched helplessly as the different warring parties ravaged their homes, forcing them into camps within Sudan or into exile in neighbouring countries, trailing with them the young, elderly, and the disabled.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


77 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zimbabwe Heated Debate on "Mercy Killing" Rages


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 31, 1996 by Dingaan Mpondah


LENGTH: 1854 words


 

Nairobi - The Final Exit Society (FES)-Zimbabwe, a pressure group advocating for a new law which will allow voluntary euthanasia for people afflicted with terminal illnesses or those with incurable diseases such as cancer or AIDS, is convinced human beings have a right to chose to die with dignity or what is generally referred to as "mercy killing."

But a host of other people - especially the Church sees the issue of "mercy killing" differently. Reacting to a report published in a local newspaper, the Sunday Mail, in early May, Father Oscar Wermter, SJ, the Social Communications Secretary of the Zimbabwe Bishops' Conference lashed out at the report entitled Everyone has a right to die with dignity.

He contended; "Certainly! (to dying with dignity). But no one has the right to kill. Not even a terminally ill person. Doctors and nurses are ethically obliged to preserve life. They must never be allowed to be dispensers of death..." 

On the other hand, the euthanasia campaigners insist that the medical fraternity, by prolonging the life of terminally ill people, whether with the aid of life-supporting machines, such as oxygen tanks, catheters, etc, are, in their view being "cruel" as such people - who will still die anyway, must be allowed to make their own decisions concerning their own lives and be left to die with dignity.

Meanwhile, an association for the welfare of prisoners and ex- convicts, the Zimbabwe Association of Crime Prevention and Rehabilitation of the Offender (ZACRO), at about the same time appealed to the government to stop wasting scarce resources by keeping terminally ill prisoners in jail, especially those showing symptoms of the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS). The state should release all prisoners in this category, says ZACRO.

ZACRO secretary general, Sam Muyamba who led a tour of Zimbabwe's largest prisons in March 1996 with his organisation's national executive, said estimates given to them by the Ministry of Health and Child Welfare indicated that at least one out of every ten prisoners suffered from HIV or AIDS.

There are around 22,000 prisoners in the country's jails - far exceeding the carrying capacity of 16,000, while the cost of feeding one prisoner is said to be almost Zimbabwe dollars 700 (about US$70) every month.

"Given such estimates, it therefore becomes clear that many prisoners are suffering from HIV or AIDS. So by releasing such prisoners, Government would save thousands of dollars in the process," said Mr Muyamba.

Fr. Wermter made a passionate appeal to all mankind and to Zimbabweans in particular to do everything possible to care for their dying fellowmen.

"We all have the duty to care for the dying and stand by them until their last breath. Enormous progress has been made in alleviating pain and severe stress of incurably ill patients. Just ask the dedicated workers of Island Hospice Service, (a special home for the terminally ill which was set up by churches in Harare several years ago). The churches make strenuous efforts to teach people home-based nursing care of their relatives with AIDS. We do not need to speed up dying. We need to give more care, and more resources to the living, including those whose life is coming to its natural end," he said.

"The Catholic Church insists on the inviolability and dignity of the human person from the moment of conception until the natural death," (Pope John Paul II, speaking in the Catholic Cathedral, in Harare on September 11, 1988). Our technological culture wants to manage and engineer everything, even life and death. But we have to observe limits: our human dignity is only respected if we accept life and death from the hand of our Maker," explained Wermter.

On social responsibility as Africans, Fr. Wermter noted; "One of the best traits of African culture is the great concern shown for the ill and respect for the elderly. Are we now putting pressure on the terminally ill to end the burden that prolongation of life will impose on others? Are we caving in under the impact of AIDS? Is AIDS brutalizing us?

"There is no moral obligation to artificially prolong a life which is clearly coming to its natural end by using extraordinary means. But the Church will always resist giving "medical authorities statutory powers to end the life of a terminally ill patient, i.e. active euthanasia," concluded the Communications Secretary of the Bishops' Conference.

Yet those who support euthanasia say among other things, that they desperately need a law which adequately caters for those willing and voluntarily prepared to take their own lives either due to boredom, unbearable mental suffering or other circumstances.

The campaigners urge the government to set up an euthanasia committee comprising some Members of Parliament, professionals such as doctors, lawyers, human rights groups and members of the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace (CCJP). This committee would give sufficient legal protection to doctors, thus preventing them from being accused of murder.

Before one wishes to end his/her live, a doctor has to consult the euthanasia committee for counselling and verification of the person's viewpoint to determine if it is voluntary death. The doctor will then go ahead and a person is quickly rested, the pro-euthanasia lobbyists say.

"Voluntary euthanasia is a new concept in Zimbabwe which, if recognised, will give the medical authorities statutory powers to end the life of a terminally ill patient, as is the case in such countries as the Netherlands," claims a founder member of the controversial organisation, Jeanette Lamb.

FES-Zimbabwe, now a member of the World Federation of Right to Die Societies, was set up following the visit to Zimbabwe early in 1996 by the secretary general of the Voluntary Euthanasia Society of London, John Oliver, who addressed several organisations on the sensitive and controversial subject.

But should terminally ill people have the right to die peacefully without prolonged suffering through assisted suicides?

"The Voluntary Euthanasia Society believes that this (decision) should be the lawful right of individuals in carefully defined circumstances and with utmost safeguards, if and only that is their expressed and sustained wish," says Lamb.

She says with voluntary euthanasia, terminally ill patients in Zimbabwe would be allowed to indicate their wishes in advance about life prolonging medical treatment should they become incurably ill.

"Unlike Christians and others who say God alone can give and take life, we think that there are circumstances in which concern for the quality of a person's natural life should override the desire to preserve it at all costs," says Lamb.

According to Lamb, humanists consider euthanasia (voluntary) a moral right when the sufferer's life is hopeless. But, she stresses, there must be no prospect of relief before death and the sufferer must have made it clear that he or she would rather die with dignity at a time of their own choice than continue to live in suffering or with loss of dignity, or both.

"Humanists consider there should be no reasonable prospect for recovery or cure and the judgement as to whether the condition is intolerable must always be made by the sufferer, either at the same time or beforehand," says Lamb.

Among examples she cites where a sufferer might consider life to be hopeless are serious physical suffering, loss of personal dignity, loss of the power of understanding either completely, as in a coma, or partially and progressively, as in dementia, and the loss of power to act so that the sufferer becomes unable to do things that have given meaning to his/her life.

Lamb argues, although it is right for society to define conditions and establish protection, it is not up to others to overrule a person's wish to die. "Where life is hopeless, to refuse immediate release from suffering is merely to postpone the inevitable with no intervening benefit," she adds.

The purpose, may be to end the pain and distress, either mental or physical, which the sufferer is experiencing or the wish may be unselfish, to end the burden that prolongation of life will impose on others.

"In either case it is inhumane and lacking in respect for society to deprive an individual of the right to choose a painless and honourable way out of the situation," she says.

She describes as "unreal" the fear that unscrupulous families will use the pretext of "voluntary" euthanasia to hasten the deaths of elderly relatives for their own gain and against the old person's will.

Lamb believes that doctors and medical staff should not be asked to act in any way they consider morally wrong but should equally not infringe on the rights of others.

And a researcher, J.A. Gordon of Harare opts for rational analgesia as the solution to the question of euthanasia and says that in his opinion the answer to any form of euthanasia is definitely "No! No! No!".

According to Gordon, mercy killing is neither legal in Britain nor Holland. However, in Holland it has been tolerated under certain circumstances which in fact, cover both voluntary and non-voluntary euthanasia and allows for euthanasia under certain conditions which lead to abuse.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

78 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Dangers Behind Lucrative Rush For Gold


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 31, 1996 by Wafula John


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

Nairobi - As sub-Saharan Africa's gold mining countries open up by the day to foreign mining companies in response to liberalization demands from international money lending houses, they run the risk of squandering away this much valued natural resource instead of benefiting from it as do other gold mining countries in the South.

In search of sub-Sahara Africa's gold today are said to be transnational corporations "and an aggressive new breed of junior mining companies which are now jostling in a headlong rush to stake their claims," reports the May 1996 edition of the London-based PANOS Media Briefing publication entitled, The Lure of Gold; How Golden is the Future?

PANOS reports that these companies are being made welcome as never before. Of the 70 countries in the so called Third World which have changed their mining laws to attract foreign companies, 31 are entirely in sub-Saharan Africa.

Such countries as Ghana, Ethiopia, Tanzania, Mali, Eritrea and Namibia are said to be "holding out a raft of incentives, from the lifting of foreign ownership restrictions to reduce taxes and the boosting of profit repatriation." 

The report adds that some sub-Saharan countries are tripping over each other in courting foreign companies for their bids for gold mining as the sale of state assets gains momentum.

Such entitlement as "allowing tax-free imports, differing royalties and similar payments, and permitting the expatriation of up to 100 per cent of the profits and even the export of all the gold mine," are being used to lure gold mining companies into impoverished Third World countries, more so in sub-Saharan Africa.

The Lure of Gold warns that the costs and benefits may be a tricky task for poor countries striving for sustainable development. "Without new safeguards," cautions the publication, "the lustre of gold may well turn out to be as illusory for developing countries as the fabled El Dorado."

Global demand for gold today is said to be higher than ever before. This has boosted prices and profits. The demand, for example, rose from a record 3,573 tonnes in 1992 to 3,642 in 1995. Most of it ends up in the so called East Asian Tigers.

PANOS, quoting the Commodity Research Bureau, says the African continent has 31 per cent of the world's known resources of gold. On the other hand, exploration targets suggest that in 20 years' time, about half of global gold production will derive from indigenous peoples' territories mainly in sub-Saharan Africa.

This, according to observers, poses a number of questions. For example who will benefit financially from the gold mining process in the region?

On the one side of the mining game in sub-Saharan Africa are giant conglomerates which are fast staking their claims on African minefields. These are mainly Australian, British and North American companies. They include BHP Minerals -- Australia's biggest conglomerate, CLUFF of Britain, London-based Rio Tinto Zinc (RTZ), and Anglo American.

That some of these giant companies have been allowed by legislation in some cases, to repatriate as much as 100 per cent of the profits they make from African goldmines and even export all the gold mined, poses grave danger to impoverished sub-Saharan African countries.

These worries are not only based on the fact that sub-Saharan African countries will be looted of this precious resource through such uneven arrangements but also that indigenous populations, on whose land most of the gold struts, will end up being evacuated to less promising land and at their best only benefiting marginally as cheaply paid labourers.

However some countries in the region seem to have already visualized this looming danger and are putting legislative checks into place. Says Pepukai Gwata, the First Commercial Secretary at the Zimbabwe High Commission in Nairobi, "all the gold mined in the country is by law sold to the Central Bank which refines it, keeps some in the national reserves, sells some to internal users, mainly for jewellery, and exports the rest."

Zimbabwe is more of an exception in Africa rather than the norm. Other than the fear of large corporations which are said to be merging "as they seek to exploit the Third World better," there is also mounting suspicion of a growing number of "junior groups of companies" also referred to as "wildcats," who are increasingly putting their claims on sub-Saharan goldmines.

These "wildcats" are said to be arousing fear and suspicion as they encroach on traditional small scale mining grounds. The Lure Of Gold estimates that in Africa, small scale miners produce up to 20 per cent of the continent's gold.

"In the sub-Saharan region, more than 1.5 million people work in the informal mining sector, while in Zimbabwe the figure is put at 100,000," the publication reports.

In Tanzania, the Central African Republic and Sierra Leone, the total gold output today is said to come from small scale miners. The PANOS publication estimates that in 20 years time, half of the global gold production will derive from indigenous peoples' territories. Most of it by then will no longer be owned by indigenous peoples, thanks to the incessant penetration of "wildcats".

A Canadian government working group is said to have identified some 200 Canadian "wildcats" operating outside their home country by 1992. By 1995, that figure had trebled and virtually all were exploiting mines in the Third World. Such companies are said to be mobile, relatively inconspicuous and hence enter indigenous territories much more easily. Presently, they are said to be opening up new fields of exploitation in such sub-Saharan countries as Ethiopia and Ghana.

And with the regional governments' policy shifting inexorably away from state controlled mining to liberalization and hence foreign mining, many gold fields currently mined by millions of small scale miners in Tanzania, the Central African Republic, Ethiopia and Namibia, for example, will inevitably be licensed to foreign concerns, probably "wildcats" who eventually hand over their operations at sumptuous profits to giant conglomerates. "In this way," says the PANOS publication, "the big corporations still continue to hold their sway."

As this emerging process of "resource grabbing" takes root in the region, one might want to know what the indigenous peoples' stake is, both in owning the resources and the profits to be made off them.

In Zimbabwe, "if you discover gold or any other minerals on your land you surrender it to the state. You can only continue owning that piece of land if you have prospecting rights," Gwata told this writer.

Other than fears for indigenous peoples' rights over their lands, natural resources and the proceeds thereof, observers are also concerned about environmental degradation and related health hazards.

According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), "mining is one of the world's most hazardous sectors causing more than 15,000 deaths annually." South African miners feature at the top of this casualty list. These deaths are poised to increase in sub-Saharan Africa owing to increased mining activities.

Furthermore gold mining is said to have potentially heavy environmental costs as it usually involves the use of cyanide and mercury in the casting process. Both are very toxic substances.

Cyanide is particularly singled out as having severe environmental impact. It is extremely poisonous to people, wildlife as well as plants. Hence extensive mining in sub-Saharan Africa is a potential danger to people's health and the entire environment.

Other environmental problems anticipated include widespread excavation of top soil leading to severe loss, and widespread felling of vegetation.

Bearing these consequences in mind, The Lure Of Gold warns that if the South, more so sub-Saharan Africa, has to benefit "from gold mining, the economic and environmental regards are imperative. This may involve a recognition of mining as a national strategic industry and developing mining policies which ensure that a fair share of the vast profits go towards local communities and sustainable development practices."


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

May, 1996


Business and Finance Zambian Bank Charts New Course


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 31, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - Standard Chartered Bank has been accused by its 'small' customers of ditching them for big corporate clients.

Some 'small' customers complained that the minimum account balances the bank is demanding are just a way of politely telling them to leave as it steers towards a corporate banking policy. 

"I had to close my account because I could not afford the new balances," carped Mulenga Musonda of Lusaka in a walk-in interview yesterday. "I cannot understand why a bank which has previously been very people-inclined should do this."

And Paul Tembo, a small-scale businessman, who claimed his account had been closed by the bank, said the bank was trying to change its clientele to cater for only a small elite group like the way Citibank and Stanbic are doing.

"But they are definitely going the wrong way around and just upsetting everybody in the process," Tembo charged in a walk in interview in Lusaka yesterday. "Now that the market is liberalised, we can always go elsewhere."

Efforts to get comments from the bank yesterday proved fruitless.

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Zambia's Chief Justice Backs Women


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 31, 1996 by George Jambwa


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - Democracy must be synonymous with equal representation for women, demanded Chief Justice Matthew Ngulube yesterday.

Speaking during the official opening of the training of women candidates for local government and general elections two day workshop in Lusaka, justice Ngulube charged that democracy must be made to respond to womens' concerns.

"If we think back to the days before 1964, men fought side by side with the women. So where are the women in power now?" asked Ngulube, adding: "Whereas men have made headway, women have lagged behind and no nation, let alone a democratic one, can afford to leave behind more than half of its population and expect meaningful development to be attained." 

The Chief Justice noted that women comprise less that 10 per cent of the members of parliament and legislators around the globe and yet the constitute the majority of voters.

"Democracy need not be perceived simply as an ideology, rather it should be viewed as a practical tool to embrace women and what they stand for," justice Ngulube advised.

Justice Ngulube, however, said that women themselves were hesitant to run for office and urged them to change the equations, remove the long standing barriers and open the windows of opportunity.

Justice Ngulube advised women to develop their own vision of their future saying "the government would not rescue them".

"Gains will only be attained through sustained struggle that is, the women's struggle," justice Ngulube advised. "Working in coalition, women's NGOs should consolidate the women's stand and effectively contribute in the task of eradicating poverty, increasing human rights awareness, reducing violence, peace making and education."

The Chief Justice also observed that there was a general lack of support for women in politics from men who feel threatened or believe that wives should stay in the home.

"The importance of political training for prospective and potential candidates is self-evident," Justice Ngulube observed, adding: " Civic education and consciousness raising activities would help all citizens to recognise that women must be equally engaged in governing."


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996

Sports - Soccer Zambia: Defender To Miss Sudan "Battle"


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 31, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Lusaka - Elijah Litana, Zambia's Saudi Arabian based central defender, will miss tomorrow's World Cup qualifier against Sudan in Khartoum, disclosed Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) treasurer, Musa Kasonka, in an interview in Lusaka yesterday.

"We have been informed by the Saudi Arabians that Litana has some injuries and will not be released to play against Sudan," Kasonka revealed. "But we are sure that Joel Bwalya will join the team, he was actually supposed to have joined the team today (yesterday)."

And FAZ yesterday disclosed that skipper Kalusha Bwalya will certainly play in the return match.

"Kalusha arrives next week for the return match against Sudan," Kasonka disclosed, "and we have actually already paid for his lodging at one of the hotels in Lusaka."

May, 1996


Business and Finance New Zambian Bank Notes Finally In


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 31, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - The Bank of Zambia's high denominated notes are in the country and ready for distribution.

Announcing the arrival of the notes at a press briefing in Lusaka yesterday, Bank of Zambia deputy governor Situmbeko Musokotwane however admitted CAMDEX, a company owed money by the central bank, had blocked their shipment. 

"Although CAMDEX did have an injunction to stop the shipping of the notes to Zambia, the efforts by the Bank's (BOZ) solicitors in the United Kingdom's appeal court to remove the injunction were successful," Musokotwane disclosed. "The bank notes are therefore freed of any encumberances."

Musokotwane, however, assured the security of the notes had not been compromised by the injunction.

"Even during the time when there was an injunction on them, the new notes never left the premises of Thomas De La Rue, the company that printed them," Musokotwane said. "The security of these notes has therefore not been compromised in any way at all."

And speaking at the same press briefing, Bank of Zambia secretary, Chilufya Mbalashi, revealed that CAMDEX International was owed 86 million and the debt dates back to 1982.

CAMDEX International bought off the debt, which Bank of Zambia had failed to service, from the central bank of Kuwait.

Mbalashi also disclosed that the CAMDEX injunction was dropped after CAMDEX and the court found that the notes were valueless.

Asked about what the CAMDEX loan meant for, Musokotwane said it might have been for "the boosting of foreign exchange reserves" whose supplies were rather erratic during that time.

And without stating who else the bank owed money, Musokotwane disclosed that the country was still "highly indebted" and had no capacity to pay all its creditors in full.

Business and Finance Zambia's Fuel Crisis Explained


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 31, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - Indeni Oil Refinery is struggling with a technical fault which has existed since March this year causing the plant to produce impure premium petrol and less kerosene.

A source from Indeni's Ndola plant confirmed yesterday that the plant had been struggling to repair the technical fault which has affected the purifying process since March. 

And a highly placed representative from the oil industry confirmed that Zambia has been receiving her crude oil shipments on schedule, contradicting rumours that the country had been failing to pay for oil supplies and suppliers had decided to halt oil shipments, leading to the fuel shortage.

"No such thing has happened though there has been a problem in the refining process which I expect to be rectified by today," he said, insisting: "The engineers have finally dealt with the problem."

Last week, energy minister Edith Nawakwi announced that the fault would be quickly attended to.

But though the refinery had set the re-opening date as May 28, operations failed "due to lack of hydrogen", Indeni explained in a statement yesterday.

And some motorists have complained about the quality of petrol.

"The engine takes some time to settle in the right rhythm and sometimes the car has even started misfiring," complained Lusaka taxi driver Joe Silinda in an interview yesterday. " I was very surprised because this car is new but after checking I realised it must be the fuel which was not go

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia President 'Knocked Out' With New Zambian Constitution


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 31, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba has scored his own goal and knocked himself out of the presidential race with his new Constitution, charged opposition ZDC in Lusaka yesterday.

Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) deputy general secretary, Azwell Banda, claimed in an interview yesterday that President Chiluba has not established his origins beyond any reasonable doubt.

"Chiluba has not conclusively established his origins," Banda claimed yesterday. "It is strange that a person who knows that his background is unclear should sign such a constitution." 

Banda said it was a natural consequence of "their own insanity" if President Chiluba doesn't qualify.

"If there are any political parties investigating Chiluba I think it is perfectly in order because the amended constitution supports them," Banda said. "We have always warned that such amendments may lead to ethnic cleansing."

Banda insisted there was totally nothing wrong with investigating President Chiluba's origins.

"After all that is what Chiluba has been doing to leading member of the opposition," Banda said. "Chiluba will have to establish beyond any reasonable doubt that he is Zambian."

And National Salvation Party president David Kasuba, in a statement released in Lusaka yesterday, said President Chiluba had passed a constitution which would set back Zambian progress because of its divisive nature.

Zambia Congress of Trade Unions chairman, Fackson Shamenda, said yesterday the government should not try to force Zambian to accept its constitution.

"It is unfortunate that the government has decided to ignore the calls of the people for a consensus," said Shamenda in a telephone interview from Ndola yesterday.

And special assistant to UNIP president, former president Kenneth Kaunda, Muhabi Lungu said his party would fight the amended constitution legally.

"We will use the courts to fight this constitution," he said.

Minister of Information and Broadcasting Amusaa Mwanamwambwa refused to make any comment on the matter.

"Frankly, I have no further comment to make on a subject which has long been debated, especially to allegations made by people who have no conclusive evidence," he said.

Banda said it was only logical that the citizens of Zambia would wish to establish the roots of the current President seeing that the constitution now demands it.

"We are satisfied at ZDC that when the interests of the nation collide with the interests of one man, then the interests of the nation must prevail," Banda said. "They have sown the wind, and they will reap the storm."

May, 1996


Zambia Christian Radio Pays Royalties


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 31, 1996 by Sheikh Chifuwe


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - The yet to be launched Radio Christian Voice became the first radio station in Zambia to pay royalties to the writers of music played on their station when they presented the Zambian Copyrights Society (ZAMCOPS) with a K5.84 million cheque on Wednesday.

Presenting the cheque to ZAMCOPS chairman Jagari Chanda, the station's manager, Philip Haggar, said the money would also help to fight copyright piracy. 

"We are delighted to be able to take the lead in presenting this cheque to ZAMCOPS," Haggar said. "We have been waiting for the formation of a collection and distribution society, to support Zambian musicians, and we are pleased to see it being started in such a professional and enthusiastic way."

Haggar added that his station supports the efforts of ZAMCOPS and urged other radio stations to recognise their obligations to pay the authors of the music which they play on their stations.

Chanda has, meanwhile, taken a swipe at Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation (ZNBC) for not recognising the artists whose music they play on radio and television by way of paying royalties.

"We have suffered enough because some radio stations like ZNBC are playing our music for free and we shall not allow such a thing to continue any longer," Chanda warned. "Musicians live on music, therefore, what is due to them should be paid."

Africa News


May, 1996


Art, Culture and Entertainment Britain's Black Voices On Tour


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 31, 1996 by Goodson Machona


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The long awaited Zambian tour of Britain's leading professional all-female a cappella group, the Black Voices, is finally on.

"The Black Voices will be visiting Zambia from 13 to 18 June, 1996 under the auspices of the British Council," announced British Council deputy director, Shoba Ponnappa, in a statement issued in Lusaka last week.

The group, which plays a blend of gospel, calypso, reggae, spiritual and popular contemporary songs, was initially scheduled to tour Zambia some two months ago but due to vagaries which Ponnappa declined to divulge, they could not. 

While in Zambia the group will put up jams at the Lusaka Playhouse on June 13, Ndola's Savoy hotel on June 15 and Lusaka's Intercontinental Hotel on June 17.

"On June 14 and 17, they will be conducting workshops for Zambian musicians at the British Council," Ponnappa said, adding that the workshops will cover historical information on the development of black music together with practical ways of using different material and harmony.

"The aim of the workshop is for Zambian and British musicians to share ideas and music, learning songs and rhythms from each other," Ponnappa said.

The group, which comprises five female vocalists, was formed in 1988 and has over the years travelled extensively around the world and built up an enviable reputation.

Outspoken British member of parliament, Bennie Grant, once described the group thus: "Black Voices reminded me that the best musical instrument is the human voice."

For British Arts Council music director, Kenneth Baird, "the heartfelt commitment and the rich blend of voices in this acappella group, who present themselves with considerable style make for performances that are both moving and memorable".

But Ponnappa couldn't have put it more succinctly: "Their music speaks to the world and has been described as either infectiously exuberant or quietly moving."


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


87 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Sudan Egypt and Ethiopia Differ Sharply Over Sudan Sanctions


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London) May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

London - Following the National Islamic Front (NIF) regime's failure to comply with the UN Security Council Resolution 1044, the governments of Egypt and Ethiopia differed sharply last month in New York over the issue of sanctions to be imposed upon the regime in Sudan. It became clear in each country's presentation to the Security Council that the Egyptians were opposed to any sanctions being imposed, whilst the Ethiopians wanted the strongest of measures to be taken. This appeared to reflect the Egyptians' desire to use the sanctions issue as a means for placating the regime in Khartoum and the Ethiopians' desire to deal with the issue as a criminal rather than a political matter. The NIF regime, naturally, issued statements appreciating the Egyptians stance, in sharp contrast to the views of the Sudanese public who saw the Egyptian position as a hypocritical turn around.

Last 26 June and the days immediately following it, President Mubarak and the Egyptian leadership were visibly shaken by the assassination attempt on the streets of Addis Ababa. Pre-empting any official investigation, the Egyptian government immediately apportioned the blame for the incident on the NIF regime. The Egyptians tried to usurp the official investigations in Ethiopia, believing that the Ethiopians would perhaps not do a thorough job. This attitude angered and frustrated the Ethiopians but at least did show that the Egyptians wanted to get the heart of the assassination plot. 

Clear Evidence: When the Ethiopian authorities announced their findings and implicated the NIF regime in the plot, the Egyptians were more than pleased and started to cooperate with the Ethiopians as to what further steps to take. The two countries jointly took their evidence to the UN Security Council and worked together to ensure the unanimous approval of Resolution 1044 on 31 January of this year.

Unfortunately, having secured the resolution, and with the threat of sanctions being imposed, the Egyptians, for reasons best known to themselves, began to manoeuvre with the Khartoum regime. It seems tht the Egyptian authorities wished to gain some kind of hold over the regime by presenting themselves as the people who stopped sanctions being imposed. It is now believed that some kind of deal was being struck concerning the large numbers of Egyptian Islamic Fundamentalists terrorists based in Sudan.

The Egyptians ambassador to the UN, Nabil El Arabi, told the Security Council that the issue of the assassination attempt and the three terrorists accused of conspiring in it was a matter for the Egyptian authorities alone and something that Cairo would competently deal with. As a co-sponsor of the original resolution, this was a bizarre positoin for the Egyptians to take and it only served to increase the suspicions that Cairo and Khartoum had brokered some kind of secret deal. Why did Egypt go the Security Council in the first place if it wanted to deal with the matter on their own terms with Khartoum?

Playing the Southern Card: A public statement issued in Cairo by the ministry of foreign affairs at the time that the Security Council was debating the issue, said that the Egyptian government could not accpet any economic or military sanctions being imposed on Sudan. Egypt did not want to be responsible for punishing the Sudanese people. In addition, the statement said that an arms embargo would hand victory in the civil war in Sudan to the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), which would lead to the political separation of the South from the North. Egypt would not allow the Southern rebels to defeat Sudan's national army. Furthermore, Egypt would not allow Sudan's national security interests to be violated. It was a characteristically pretentious performance.

Egypt's colonial and patronising attitude towards Sudan was unlikely to win votes from the Sudanese public as a whole, and did little to endear Cairo to the Khartoum regime either. However, the Egyptians have repeatedly intervened in Sudanese matters, especially when they have concerned events in Southern Sudan. For instance, in the first phase of the Sudanese civil war, 1955-1972, Egyptian military intervention on behalf of Khartoum is very well documented. In 1994, the Egyptians were instrumental in persuading the Arab League of Nations to pass a resolution condemning the call for Self-determination for Southern Sudan. The language of that resolution was implicitly racist as was the notion that an organisation, which by its own definition of an Arab does not represent eighty percent of Sudan's population, could pass judgment on the motivating forces behind the conflict in Southern Sudan.

During the same year, President Mubarak, as chairperson of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) prevented the SPLA from attending the OAU meetings in Cairo as observers and then failed to mention the Sudanese conflict in any of his major speeches. He reviewed all of Africa's other conflicts, but somehow managed to overlook the problems of Sudan, the one closest to his own country.

Ethiopia's Reaction: Undoubtedly shocked by Cairo's volteface at the Security Council, the Ethiopian government insisted that the toughest sanctions be imposed upon Sudan. The Ethiopians said, rightly, that the terrorist crime committed on Ethiopian territory could not be allowed to go unpunished.

In a clearly worded statement, Addis Ababa said it would be wrong for any one country to imply that it alone cared for the interests of the Sudanese people. Ethiopia was also a close neighbour of Sudan and was also a friend of the Sudanese people. However, the NIG regime was using terrorism against its own people and their friends in neighbouring states, and as such ought to be treated as the criminal in truly is. From their own close contacts with Sudan, the Ethiopians added that the Sudanese people have demanded comprehensive sanctions to be imposed upon a very unpopular NIF regime.

The Ethiopians circulated a draft resolution in New York which demanded sanctions such as a complete arms embargo and the barring of Sudan Airways' flights to any member state. The national carrier could not be left out of any call for sanctions because it had clearly been used to fly the terrorist suspects out of Addis Ababa following the assassination attempt.

UN Resolution: In well known UN style, the Security Council examined the extreme position of the Egyptian government, contrasted it with that of the Ethiopian government, and arrived at what it believed to be a fair compromise. Light sanctions would be imposed upon Khartoum and they would be gradually increased by increments if the regime continued to fail to comply with Resolution 1044. By their muddle-minded manner of dealing with issues, the Egyptians have just managed to make a laughing stock of the world body. How can any member of the ordinary public be expected to respect UN Security Council resolutions if it finds a member state guilty by unanimous vote and yet fails to ensure appropriate punishment for the crime? Whatever Egypt may think they have achieved by their behaviour at the UN, they have encouraged Khartoum to continue its criminal ways. And next time, maybe Mr. Mubarak or any other Egyptian leader the NIF is targeting may not be so lucky. Then it will be too late to ask the world community to do something.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

May, 1996


Kenya (DOCUMENT) U.S. Republican Institute Sees 'Hope' for Kenya


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 30, 1996 by Gregory Simpkins


LENGTH: 1760 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is the summary and conclusion of a report on Kenya issued by the International Republican Institute:

On the surface, Kenya appears to be no closer to achieving the democracy many hoped for when the country repealed its law mandating single-party rule in 1991. Despite the creation of enduring opposition parties and a multiparty election in 1992, there are those who remain pessimistic that the government of President Daniel arap Moi will ever genuinely accept pluralist democracy in this East African nation.

Even positive developments, such as the March 1 meeting between President Moi and the leaders of the three main opposition political parties turned out to be less momentous than first hoped. President Moi pledged to take action on the design of the national identity card and other issues aimed at opening up the political environment in advance of the anticipated 1997 general elections. Still, lower level functionaries continued to clamp down on the political opposition.

A joint opposition rally in Meru involving Michael Wamalwa of the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy - Kenya (FORD-Kenya), Mwai Kibaki of the Democratic Party (DP) and Martin Shikuku of the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy - Asili (FORD-Asili) was broken up by police wielding clubs and using tear gas. The license for the meeting was suspended by local authorities early on the morning of the rally unbeknownst to the organizers. Other licensed political meetings also have been disrupted. 

The Kenyan government, which had pulled back a repressive political party regulation bill last year in response to local and international pressure, has reintroduced the measure in Parliament. A repressive media bill was pulled back last year ostensibly for reworking, but it is reportedly about to be pushed again in the current parliamentary session. The political environment is still significantly tilted in favor of the ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU), and restrictive laws that hamper the operation of a multiparty democracy remain on the books.

Yet despite the current circumstances, there is much cause for optimism that Kenya's political problems can be solved in the near future and that steps are being taken even now to lead to such solutions.

Economic indicators are positive for Kenya, and the government has taken measures to deal with corruption that have led to arrests and suspensions of major government officials and resulted in hundreds of millions in revenue from correctly collected tariffs. Legislative oversight by opposition parliamentarians appears to be successfully guarding against the kind of financial manipulations that helped the ruling party amass a war chest to bribe opposition politicians and voters in the 1992 elections.

Opposition political parties and elements of civil society are attempting to coalesce around commonly accepted changes in the constitution and election procedures before the next general elections. The government and the ruling party also have pledged in two separate Parliamentary motions to cooperate in an examination of the country's political environment. Meanwhile, a coalition of civic groups and the three main opposition political parties co-sponsored a May conference to discuss constitutional reform.

Although the country's political parties are all mired in leadership struggles, democracy in internal party affairs is beginning to be practiced, if somewhat painfully. This promises to lead to a greater commitment to democratic practice generally. The leaders of the three main opposition parties and their top lieutenants began meeting quietly during late summer and fall of 1995 to discuss an alliance that would begin on a parliamentary level and then broaden to include other national pro-democracy forces. In late November, the formation of the National Alliance was announced.

Opposition party defections, which have caused nearly two dozen by-elections since the 1992 general elections, are becoming more difficult for the ruling party to manage successfully. The advent of issue-oriented politics by all parties threatens to make defection more costly, both in financial and political terms, for all concerned. Moreover, if the opposition Alliance can join in a lasting partnership with civil society, threats by ruling party officials to defect to the opposition might come to pass.

Women compose the majority of the Kenyan electorate and the overwhelming percentage of actual voters. Civic and voter education conducted since 1992 appears to have had the impact of causing grassroots women and female leaders to take a more active stand for their rights in a variety of situations. More than 30 Kenyan women's organizations have agreed on the goal of electing more women to Parliament and local councils. This should have a profound impact on the next elections.

Newer political leaders now on the scene and those being developed promise to reform Kenyan politics not only over the long term, but perhaps in time to improve the conduct of the anticipated 1997 general elections. Frustration with the old guard is rising within all the country's political parties. It remains to be seen, though, whether young leaders will find a more promising opportunity anywhere other than their current parties. Events during the next several months may decide whether the new wave is a genuine phenomenon or merely rhetoric.

Looking at Kenya's political scene from the West, many observers are inclined to throw up their hands at the seemingly self-destructive tactics used by politicians in the East African nation. Yet democracy is messy even in the West. British Prime Minister John Major has had to survive numerous challenges to his authority. Since the Republican capture of the U.S. Congress in the 1994 elections, scores of Democrats in Congress and in state legislatures throughout America have defected to the Republican party. Canada's Progressive-Conservative party was defeated so totally in the last elections that it barely exists as a national entity. Japan has seen the last four prime ministers fail to finish their terms because of official corruption and political instability.

Certainly it is true that Kenyan politicians are not advancing democracy as had been hoped in the heady days after the reinstitution of multi-party democracy in 1991. Still, it would be a tremendous underestimation of the political scene to assume that no advances are being made or are possible. For the most part, Kenya's political opposition knows what is wrong but has felt powerless to address those problems because of the government's intransigence. The law has been used to stymie democracy rather than support it, but now politicians and members of civil society are joining forces in a long overdue coalition to entrench democracy in Kenya.

Changes in the constitution and other laws and election procedures would provide a more competitive political atmosphere. This would allow opposition parties to develop normally by permitting them to reach out more effectively to voters. Aggressive enforcement of laws against vote fraud could better guarantee free and fair elections in Kenya. This would mean that no party has a lock on the vote and would be forced to be mindful of the public will. Continued and enhanced civic education could significantly reduce the percentage of uninformed voters and uninvolved citizens. The creation of new jobs and economic opportunities for the average Kenyan could reduce poverty, and therefore render Kenyan voters less vulnerable to manipulation. None of these possibilities is beyond reach.

Anything can happen in the Kenyan political environment, as has been proven by history. Daniel arap Moi started his political life as a lesser player in the now-defunct Kenya African Democratic Union. He went on to become Kenya's third Vice-President, and as President, he has recreated the ruling party in his own image. The current opposition parties did not exist five years ago, but they now have entrenched supporters throughout the country. With the empowerment of women and the rise of young political leaders, great changes are possible in Kenya. It was not easy in the past and will not be easy now, but with the right conditions, reform is more possible now than it was in 1991.

Donor nations must not lose hope. The political opposition is working harder to practice the democracy it preaches. It may have taken a circuitous route to get there, but internal democracy is underway. Civil society is no longer content to sit on the sidelines critiquing the political action. Religious organizations and NGOs will be major players in 1997 -- one way or another. There is a window of opportunity to create a new political order in Kenya. This chance will not last forever. If the challenge of political reform in Kenya is not accepted now, this lost opportunity will be lamented for generations to come.

For information contact the International Republican Institute, 1212 New York Avenue, N.W., Suite 900, Washington, DC 20005-3987. Phone: 202 408-9450. Fax: 202 408-9462. Email: iri@iri.org


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

May, 1996


United States and Africa (DOCUMENT) Awards Gala for South African Initiative


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 560 words


 

New York - Following is an announcement by "Reach & Teach USA," a non-profit initiative by major U.S. corporations to promote South African development:

South African Ambassador Franklin Sonn and American Express will appear jointly at the first annual Reach & Teach USA Awards Gala June 5th at the Waldorf Astoria in New York City.

The Awards Gala is intended to recognize and honor those who have helped to bring about fundamental and positive change in South Africa. Ambassador Sonn was one of the founders of Reach & Teach and has been a key advisor to the organization. The American Express Foundation partnered with Reach & Teach to develop and implement a curriculum to introduce secondary school students and adults to the private sector, and in particular to career opportunities in the Travel & Tourism industry. Their early support has contributed greatly to the success of Reach & Teach. 

In addition to the Awards Gala, Reach & Teach USA will be hosting an Issues Forum at The National Arts Club earlier in the day entitled, "Education and Job Training in South Africa: The Importance of Building Bridges."

The panelists will include Dr. Aaron Motsoaledi, the Minister of Education for the Northern Province; John Samuel, Deputy Director General of Education; and Professor Merlyn Mehl, Chairman of Reach & Teach and CEO of the Independent Development Trust, South Africa's largest development organization. The moderator will be Stanley S. Litow, President of the IBM International Foundation and a member of Reach & Teach's board.

Among the corporate supporters who have made a commitment to the Awards Gala are Kellogg Foundation, American Express, the Open Society Institute, Bankers Trust, IBM, J.P. Morgan, Avon, Sears, TRW, The Health Foundation and DuPont.

Reach & Teach USA is a national not-for-profit organization established in 1994 to develop partnerships with U.S. corporations, foundations, and organizations to bring about a dramatic improvement in the quality of South Africa's education and job training system.

Together with its South African partner, Reach & Teach USA is introducing innovation and technology-based curricula into many of South Africa's provinces, communities, schools and classrooms. The programs currently being implemented use state-of-the-art technologies and methodologies to enhance learning at all levels. Furthermore, young and old are provided the knowledge and skills they need to prosper personally and economically.

For more information about the events on June 5, contact Kate Fleming at (914) 694-6183. In South Africa, contact Terry Salter at (011) 448-4175.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Democratization of Nigeria Labour: To be or Not to be?


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 31, 1996 by Austin Avwode.


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Lagos - When last Monday Ahmed Dusau, sole administrator of the Nigeria Labour Congress, informed labour correspondents in Lagos of "government's determination to hand over NLC to democratically elected officials," he exuded the confidence of a prophet. But barely 24 hours after, a meeting of 27 industrial unions held in Lagos saw labour leaders taking a position that has cast a cloud of uncertainty on the possibility of achieving the goal of fully democratizing the NLC in the next few days.

Gusau had spoken glowingly of government's resolve to end the rather protracted democratization process of the NLC this week. And as the man who is saddled with that onerous task, he decided to set up two committees, the accreditation committee and the conference conduct committee. He assured that members of the committees would be tested veterans. 

Among the things to be considered for accreditation are the payment of check-off dues by unions and the conclusion of bye elections by state councils. As at last Monday about 60 per cent of the state councils were said to have concluded their elections as directed by the NLC sole administrator. Four unions, the National Union of Banks, Insurance and Financial Institutions Employees, the National Union of Petroleum, Energy and National Gas Workers, NUJ, and National Union of Railwaymen are said to be defaulting in the payment of their check-off dues. As for the conference conduct committee, it is to make arrangements for accommodation, information and all other things deemed necessary for a smooth conference to hold.

According to Gusau, the time-table for the conference, scheduled to hold at Abuja, is such that all state councils are expected to round of all bye elections by May 27. The next day would be for the arrival of delegates to the conference, the high point of which is the election to be held between may 29-31. Gusau said that the election would be based on the 1995 NLC constitution as approved by the government. On the contentious issue of Decree 4 of 1996, he explained that all laws in respect of the congress would be applied.

But labour leaders would have nothing to do with the Gusau arrangement. Twenty-seven out of the 29 unions which met at the National Union of Postal and Telecommunication Employees secretariat in Lagos, complained that "eight days to May 29, the sole administrator has neither held any meeting nor informed the unions of any plan to hold the conference on the said date." They also alleged that the trade unions have not been involved in the preparations for the conference, which is not in consonance with the provisions of the NLC constitution. The labour leaders then re-affirmed that industrial unions and state councils would participate only if an NLC conference convened on the basis of the existing constitution of congress with regards to delegates to the conference and the eligibility to contest any elective office of the congress, among other things.

They further said that in the light of the above, the Trade unions (Amendment) Decree 4 of 1996, section 7 of which has technically sidelined potential candidates for the election on the grounds of not being "card carrying members," as well as the guidelines issued March 2 by the labour minister, could not be the basis for convening a truly democratic and legitimate conference.

While the leaders pledged that no union would embark on strike action because of this position, they condemned the attitude of some veterans who have offered themselves to be used by the government in realizing its aims. They, therefore, resolved to take their case to Sani Abacha, the head of state, whose government they described as a "listening one."

The resolution of the labour leaders which formed part of the communique issued at the end of the meeting, is nothing short of a boycott of the conference. Last week, Labour leaders were resolute in their demand for the review of Decree 4, especially section 7 of it. Speaking on the issue to Theweek, A.B. Dania, senior deputy general secretary, Textile and Garment Workers Union, said that the decree seeks to create artificial demarcation between card carrying members of the unions and their leaders. he said that it had never been so, as all the veterans necessarily grew from the rank and file of the unions.

In his words, "No one can be a leader without having graduated through the rank and file of the union." He was categorical that the conference would not hold except the demands of the unions were met.

On his part, Hassan Sunmonu, past president of the NLC and the current secretary-general of Organization of African Trade Unity, warned that "Nigeria may become a laughing stock in the international labour community if the election of officers for the NLC is conducted under the guidelines given by the minister of labor." He further said that any president elected for the congress on the basis of the guidelines and decree 4, of 1996, would not be respected nationally and internationally.

Issue cover date: June 2, 1996

LANGUAGE: English
