Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Azikiwe's Burial Is Another Bone of Contention


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 31, 1996 by Taye Ige


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Lagos - Like his death and its delayed announcement, burial plans for Nnamdi Azikiwe, Nigeria's political icon who passed on, May 11 a t 92, may be mired in controversy.

After 10 days during which it had been scavenged by the media, Chukwuma Bamidele Azikiwe last Tuesday finally announced the death of his father, Nnamdi Azikiwe. He confirmed that the Owelle of Onitsha and Nigeria's first and last ceremonial president passed on exactly at 4.45 p.m. Saturday, May 11.

Chukwuma's announcement came after the completion of the different traditional rites necessary for the broadcast of the death of an Owelle, one of the six highest titles in Onitsha, to which Azikiwe, according to Chukwuma, was appointed in the 70's. What had delayed the completion of the rites was the prolonged absence of 73-year old Ofala Okagbue, the Obi of Onitsha, who is abroad on medical check up. The monarch reportedly delegated Valentine, his nephew, to stand in for him as chief coordinator of the rites. 

In announcing the death of his father, Chukwuma also confirmed Onitsha as the late sage's final resting place. According to him, the 92-year old one time premier of defunct Eastern Region will be interred at the Inosi Onira family compound at their Ogbeabor village in the commercial city.

Chukwuma later led a delegation of top family members to Aso Rock where he formally informed Sani Abacha, the head of state, of the death of the former Nigerian president. The head of state promptly ordered a three-day national mourning for the former Nigerian senate president and first indigenous governor-general. The national flag would fly at half-mast for the period of the national mourning.

About the time Chukwuma was meeting Abacha, the constitution of a 31-member all Igbo panel to coordinate the funeral was also being announced. Already, the committee was reportedly working on a proposal it hopes to submit to the federal government as soon as the mourning period it declared is over. The committee intends to ask the federal government and the governments of the seven eastern states to pick the bill for Zik's burial, on a day yet to be fixed. There are speculations that the foremost nationalist would be buried October 1 as part of activities to mark the country's the country's 36th independence anniversary.

The speculation that Zik's burial will be delayed for close to five months is already proving a source of potential rift in the family. Uche, Zik's wife of 22 years, is reportedly kicking against the idea. She said her husband detested corpses staying for months in the morgue. She told reporters: "I want him to be buried soon. While he was alive, he criticized the keeping of corpse for a long time...He never felt happy."

Far more capable of generating controversy is the accommodating approach seemingly preferred by the Azikiwes in the burial arrangements for their father as against the restricted, conservative requirements of Onitsha tradition.

Sounding a note of warning, Chukwuma declared when he spoke to reporters last Tuesday: "It was his (Zik's) wish that he should be brought home and interred according to our tradition. But we will amend and bend things respecting the fundamentals. We will accommodate all the various tendencies... We will reach out to all the people that have valid claims of association with our father." These, according to him, include Nsukka to which Zik retired after his active political career, and Zungeru, his birth place in Niger State.

Indications of a possible clash have already started to manifest. Twice Olisa Mortune, the traditional prime minister of Onitsha and member of the group of the six capped chiefs among whom Zik counted on till his death, stormed out of the press conference at which Chukwuma formally announced his father's death. After entreaties from the eldest of Zik's sons he returned after first walking into his Volvo car in annoyance. He was said to be protesting alleged violation of tradition by the Azikiwes. This, he reportedly alleged, had become clear from their extending hands of friendship to the corps of reporters who had swarmed around Zik's abode at both Nsukka and Onitsha since the elder statesman died. To Mortune, the reporter' effrontery in reporting Zik's death ahead of the Onitsha Ndichie (council of elders) amounts to an unforgivable desecration of his people's culture.

Will Zik get a prompt burial, and in accordance with Onitsha tradition, or are the remains of the erstwhile publisher of the largest Newspaper chain in Nigerian journalism annals set for a long stay in the morgue? That is the puzzle to be resolved in the he weeks ahead.

Issue cover date: June 2, 1996


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


92 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria "Nigerians Aren't Helping Abiola"


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 31, 1996


LENGTH: 3147 words


 

Lagos - Mamman Nasir, former president of the Court of Appeal, and now chairman of the Transition Implementation Committee, discusses the incarceration of Moshood Abiola, the transition programme, and the judiciary.

Theweek: As chairman of the Transition Implementation Committee, can you give us a self-assessment of the journey so far towards democracy?

Nasir: To start with, What is transition itself? I believe your interest is in the transition programme announced by the head of state on 1st of October, last year. Our committee was charged with the responsibility of ensuring a successful transition. This transition involves all the matters, all the decisions which have been passed on from the constitutional conference to the government of the federation, which the government has accepted almost a hundred per cent. For ease of reference, you may recall that the present administration upon coming to power appointed the constitutional conference of about 360 delegates. Out of this number, 270 were elected and 90 approximately were nominated. This conference discussed all concepts of Nigeria's national life, and in one full year's deliberation, submitted the draft constitution and so many recommendations. And the conference said, if we practice this constitution and we apply the following recommendations, we are more likely to get a stable government. This is what the present transition programme is all about. 

Now, this programme is already being implemented. There is marked improvement even in the preparation of the annual budget and improving the economy, in trying to clean some of our bad practices, e.g. in the banking sector. We are improving the infrastructure, roads, hospitals, education, and so on. In addition, there is a much greater liaison between the private sector and the government. The sum total of all these is that we are now getting a direction. Now, the constitutional conference said that unless we improve the economy, we improve the lot of the ordinary man, we improve the social services, we improve our roads, we make Nigerians more friendly to each other and to have a sense of brotherhood, there is no amount of election that will bring democracy. All that will happen without these necessities will be an election and after a short period, the military will come back. In other words, we are after a durable democracy, a real democracy by the people and for the people.

Q. How much of these has the government achieved?

A. Oh, no! It's not for the government to achieve this. It's for you, myself and everybody else to team up and fulfill our own side of the responsibility. For example, government can't come and compel me to be your friend, but I know it's in my own interest to be friendly with the next-door neighbor. So, government counts on all of us to team up, on all of us to be honest, on all of us to work hard. If we all cooperate, instead of dissipiting energy, fighting each other, then Nigeria can be very, very great because we have all the talents, we have the resources, we have everything, it's now a question of teaming up, face one direction and Insha Allah, the result will be in everybody's interest.

Q. As chairman of the transition committee, what are the misgivings about the local government election?

A. You would agree with me that Nigerians positively responded in support of the elections by coming out en masse to participate, contrary to what few people said that the elections should be boycotted, that nobody should come out. At the end of the exercise, some people were not happy with what happened. In a human society, you cannot have anything happening without somebody saying he is not satisfied, even in a family. And if you take the size of Nigeria, those grumbling are few and they have been given a chance to go to election petition tribunal, after the tribunal you can still go and appeal. So personally, I am happy with the result and I am also very happy that some people have gone to the election tribunal to air their grievances, because if you say every Nigerian is happy, it means a hundred per cent Nigerians have been suppressed. In a human society, you can't talk of a hundred per cent agreement. It has never happened, at least as far as I know.

Q. To me and to a lot of people, the arrangement was quite untidy. For instance, there was no voters register; people got to the polling centers and were allowed to vote. We also find that a lot of people were disqualified even on the day of the elections. So, what measures are you putting in place to ensure that these do not happen in subsequent elections?

A. Except that we allowed people to vote without being registered, nobody has yet told me that no-Nigerians voted. All the people who voted are Nigerians. Now, what happened was this: If you go to the rural areas, this little village community level, they all know each other. What surprised all of us was the size of the electorate. That one made it almost impossible to get the people registered by 2 to 4 p.m. In many respects, the people themselves lined up and they were counted. If there is complaint about that one, whoever is not happy can still go to the tribunal. But I never heard anybody say some people came from Rivers State and there were voting in Ondo State. Or some people came from Cameroon and they were voting in Adamawa State. Nobody complained that way. So, from the experience, so many things will happen. For example, the intention now is to get a voters register. In other words, the next elections will be based on a voters register. From the turnout, we now learn we need more people to register the voters. We also now learn that Nigerians are democratic and know how to exercise their rights. You always know that Nigerians are democratic. Whatever you think, they come out to exercise their rights. That's the government's goal. Let everybody participate in public life, economic, social, political and so on.

Q. Since the dream of your committee is to ensure a democratic arrangement, don't you think one of the problems you have is the detention of people? Isn't the committee thinking about how to solve this problem?

A. Before the end of this transition, government will break all roadblocks, which are against democracy. I can assure you about that one. This government is determined to build a strong democracy. Whatever is happening now is to remove all our malpractices, where you believe you have to be hostile to the society before you can acclaim yourself as a political leader. This one I am tailking generally. I am not talking in respect of any particular person. This government says, "look, let us sit together, let us re-organize ourselves, let us get every Nigerian on board so that we can participate in the next administration, whether a very serious politician before or whether you never participated in politics at all. This time around, we all meet together and decide what should be done for Nigeria. We don't want a situation where you get 20 odd people all saying "we want to be president," some of them even change how they walk just because they personal intention, they want to contest election. No, we want you, the ordinary Nigerian, to show who will be president. We want you at your party level to nominate who should contest which office. I can't come and say I am the president because I have money. We want you now to dictate who should contest any office in the constitution. Now that we are rotating all the offices, we are likely to have more satisfaction, more contentment from the society. I have my views, but my views are absolutely irrelevant. The most important view is that of the people when they form their political parties, get them registered. Our own now is to assist in helping to formulate the bringing up of all of us into the system. I am not interested in which association is registered as a political party. I know some must be registered. But I do not want anybody to say that "this association is mine, so I must be the president." I want the people to say "this is our association," then they say in the party, "now that we are registered, who will be senator, who will be member of the house of assembly, who will be president? Remember, if this man is president and we are rotating, then somebody must be prime minister." The party must then think of how to share the posts in the best way it can get the best result and I hope that, with our present understanding of our country, the party will cut right across, nobody will form a party which is only supported in one particular corner. We hope the political leaders will go all out and get support. We have a common philosophy in Nigeria, we have no political difference as to what we should do for our people. We know it's identical. So I hope all those with intention to play politics should try to trace their friends all over the federation and team up. It is which one is more trusted by the people rather than which one has the best philosophy. We will do our best and build Nigeria on a more sound footing which must be on the basis that the electorate are supporting the government elected by them.

Q. Let's get to the unresolved issue of June 12. During the interim administration, you were appointed chairman of a panel that was to investigate what happened to the elections. You would have probably found a way out if not for Wada Nas, now minister of special duties, who got a court order to stop your committee. What is the way out of June 12 crisis?

A. I have at least two answers. The smart one is to say that the court order which stopped me from doing the enquiry as far as I know has not been revoked. So I cannot talk on it. (Laughter) But, more seriously, I have links with Abiola's family, Abiola's friends, Abiola's sympathizers. I think we have overflogged this issue at the expense of Abiola himself. We are not helping him. We have to remember that the Nigerians who are now overseas campaigning are no longer talking of June 12, they are now talking of human rights, because that is the thing that will continue to give them money out there. They are no more fighting for Abiola or June 12. They are now fighting for fundamental human rights. They went to Ogoni. They went to everything.. My candid view is that we have overflogged Chief Abiola's case. Abiola was never declared a president in Nigeria. Shehu Shagari was declared president, three months in office, he was removed. Nobody shouted. If we are arguing, then we should go back to 15th January (1966) when our political leaders were removed or killed. June 12 is not higher than the removal of Alhaji Shehu Shagari and is definitely lower than when the prime minister was murdered. Chief Akintola was murdered. Alhaji Ahmadu Bello was murdered, Brigadier Ademulegun was murdered. All these were part of our history and, upon that, we had a civil war. All these did not break Nigeria. I hope anybody with interest in the welfare of Chief Abiola will please allow this thing to take its simple, straight forward, elementary course. In my view, that will be much better for Chief Abiola and Nigerians as a whole. We should use the experience to make sure that we don't allow the military to come again. Then there will be no more June 12. But if we now continue to talk about June 12, we are really whipping up a dead horse. I am sorry that is my very blunt opinion.

Q. Don't you think if we allow the cancellation of June 12 to go unchallenged, there will be future cancellation?

A. That is why I use June 12 as the last straw which broke the camel's back. After this time, nobody can try it again. The only way to do it is to get good government. You see, the whole history of that election leading to June 12 is best not mentioned. As far as I am concerned, let us use June 12 as the last straw.

Q. What would you propound as the solution to the June 12 problems?

A. Now, it is in everybody's interest that we get a solution to Chief Abiola's case. If we are sincere, it is best undiscussed in the press. I think we should deal with the matter somewhere else. You see, anybody coming to the press now is merely trying to boost his ego. Not for Chief Abiola, but for himself. See what is going on in court, lawyers arguing who will represent him. My upbringing in the practice is that, if someone says I am not wanted, I go. But see what is going on. People politicize issues to the expense of every person in the society. No Nigerian would say he hates Abiola. But people are making them to believe that Abiola would have been the worst president in Nigerian, because he was supported by only a small fraction of Nigerians. No. If we want to help him, the best way is to reduce making political stories. Go somewhere else and look for solution in his won interest.

Q. The judiciary was indicted by former President Babangida as one of the reasons for annulling the June 12 elections because of the conflicting rulings on the validation of the election. How do you assess the judiciary?

A. Now, the judiciary is not at fault because the judiciary has done nothing wrong. Whoever goes to court, the judiciary must listen to him even if it is simply to tell him, sorry, I have no jurisdiction. What a court cannot do is to say you can't enter. Everybody can enter a court. But the court can say: "I hear your very beautiful argument, but, I have no jurisdiction." What happened before the annulment was that the judiciary gave one judgment in Abuja, another gave an order in Lagos, another gave another order in Benin, another gave an order in Abuja. That time, the judiciary allowed itself to be dragged into a corner. Because of this, at the constitutional conference, we now said all these election cases will now go to a special federal court, the constitutional court. The difference is this: a high court in one state is not bound by the decision of a high court in another state. But this constitutional court is bound by its own decision. So, if there is a decision in Lagos, that decision is binding on all other states. That was the idea of the conference so that the judiciary will not be dragged into the arena. We limited it to this federal Court so that nobody will give contradictory judgment and one hopes it will help.

Q. What did people like you and former Chief Justice Bello do at that point in time?

A. Strictly speaking, if a magistrate grade three is charged with a case, no justice, no president should interfere with what he is doing. He should be allowed to finish his case. You don't advise judges as to what they should do. The chief justice could not interfere. In any event, the chief justice is not in charge of a state high court.

Q. At the constitutional conference, the recommendation was made that there should be rotation of the presidency. It was approved. But the government did not go further to say how the zones are going to benefit. Why was that so?

A. You know this was a highly political matter. The best way to get it done is for the politicians to put their heads together and see how best to do it. If I have my way, the next government will be a national government. In any event, the conference has decided and it is now in the constitution. If a party has 10 per cent of the seats in the national assembly, it has to be represented in the cabinet. So, we are now working towards a national government. Let us give the political leaders the honor that they too can sit and work things out. If they do, it is likely to be more durable than enforcing it on them.

Q. You have a lot of faith in General Abacha. I want you, from your privileged position, to assess what manner of man he is?

A. The best way is to interpret what he has done so far. That will tell you the type of man he is. He is not claiming anything more than what your are claiming as a Nigerian. He believes that it is Allah in his wisdom that put him in that position. I will do my best. You can get your own interpretation by analyzing what he has done so far. Examine what the critics have said, examine what the people in his favor have said, compare them with what has actually happened; things which were almost impossible can now become possible in Nigeria. Quietly without making noise, this man has achieved a lot as a matter of what is happening in the society. That is why I say we should analyze and educate our people as to what is going on. It is a silent revolution. You see, nobody before had the courage to probe anybody. My analysis is that, analyze him on the basis of what he has done so far, compare the negative and the positives and, with all due respect, be honest to yourself in deciding the truth.

Issue cover date: June 2, 1996

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Another Sad Year for Nigerian Football


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 31, 1996 by Jaiyeola Ajasa


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Lagos - Just like last year, football fans in Nigeria may not have the chance to savor a continental cup triumph as things are once again beginning to fall apart with the three clubs representing the country. For those that felt the score draw Rangers International pulled in Cameroon was good enough, the 0-1 lost to Unisport was devastating. Now, the country will have to wait till next year for another chance at the Confederation of African Football Cup. 

The story was the same in far away Zimbabwe when Shooting Stars, playing in the second leg, second round of the Champions cup, lost 1-3 to Power Dynamos. Although Super Eagles' chief coach Shaibu Amodu blamed the loss on altitude problem, many football fans see it as a lame excuse. Amodu, who is on secondment to the Ibadan side, also spoke of lack of concentration which he said accounted for the goals the Nigerian side conceded.

Shooting Stars, however, moved to the quarter-finals having defeated the Zimbabwean side 5-1 in Ibadan. Playing against an obviously more experienced Gabonese side, Winners Cup campaigneers, Katsina United, debutants in continental championships, held out until the last 10 minutes when they allowed in three unreplied goals. Officiating was said to be questionable, but the Nigerian clubside reportedly played below average. The host, Mbilinga scored their last two goals within four minutes, one of which was a penalty.

Although Katsina United have a chance to redeem their image when they square up with the Gabonese side for the second leg, only a miracle will see them getting a quarter-final berth. In the first round when they met Etoile du Congo who beat them twice at home in a second leg match that witnessed a replay, the team was not too impressive. Despite an army of coaches that included Zachari Baraje who just returned from Oman and Kelechi Emetole, the team failed to impress. So, it would be a daunting task for them as they aim to pull four goals behind Mbalinga to move forward in their quest to lift the Mandela trophy.

With Shooting Stars not looking too impressive despite their array of stars which sole administrator, Taiwo Ogunjobi promised will bring home the Skeou Toure Cup to Nigeria for the first time, Nigerians are beginning to brase up for another bleak year on the continental level. Godfrey Esu, who until recently was head coach of the Ibadan side, believes the same story will continue to be told until certain measures are taken. ESL, who now coaches Nigerdock, believes the best clubsides don't always get to represent the country. This, he says, is because "officiating should be looked into at both home and away matches of the league. Except we improve on that area, we can't really get the true champions."

For Austin Akosa, CAP instructor, the professional league is far from matching the name it is being called. "The results we have got so far from the continental matches show the level of coaching in the country." Taking a rather hard look, he believes that something is wrong with the pattern of coaching in the country. "We have to go back to the drawing board," he says.

Issue cover date: June 2, 1996


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


94 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Sting of UN Report Lessened by NAM


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 31, 1996 by Amos Esele


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Lagos - Sani Abacha's new foreign policy measure aimed at wooing friends from outside the West may have received a huge boost last week. Speaking to the press Tuesday in Abuja, Walter Ofonagoro, information and culture minister, disclosed part of this new policy plan. He said that the government would host a three-day meeting of the Non-Aligned Movement in Abuja. The hosting of the conference, is to show the world "that we are still highly accepted by the international community."

Outside the non-aligned nations, however, the Abacha regime continues to acquire more enemies. Last week witnessed an increase in the ranks of those calling for sanctions against Nigeria for her lowly-rated human rights record and uncertain transition programme. But far worse for the nation's image is the United Nation's report prepared by the five-member fact-finding team that toured the country last month. The report is said to be unfavorable to the government which had expected to launder its battered image by hosting the mission from the world body. 

For the new champions of sanctions against the country, a new body called the Inter-Action Council was formed last Tuesday. The 24-member council is made up of mostly ex-heads of government in Europe. Included in the exclusive list are former president Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France, ex-chancellor Helmut Schmidt of former West Germany, ex-president Mikhail Gorbachev of the former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and Pierre Trudeau, former prime minister of Canada. At a meeting held in Vancouver, Canada, last week, the former leaders of the industrial world expressed disappointment with the Abacha government's continued imprisonment of their Nigerian counterpart, Olusegun Obasanjo, for alleged coup plotting.

They said they believed Obasanjo has not been tried in a properly constituted court and therefore should be set free immediately. Failure to heed their plea, the international statesmen warned, would not be taken lightly. They recommended the freezing of the foreign assets of Nigerian leaders, the suspension of visa issuance to Nigerian leaders and the stoppage of air links between Nigerian and the rest of the world.

A week to the oldies' meeting, Nigeria had been the subject of a fierce bipartisan debate in the United States Congress. Nancy Kassebaum, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations sub-committee on African Affairs, had authored a bill which was co-sponsored by 22 other senators. The bill called for the imposition of oil embargo on Nigeria. Though the bill could not sail through the house, Peter Tarnoff, U.S. undersecretary for political affairs, who testified before the committee, said the Clinton administration plans to deal with the problem through consensus among its allies. This is expected to top the agenda in Lyons, France, at next month's meeting of heads of eight industrialized nations.

By contrast, the UN report is more direct, unambiguous and damaging. On the setting up of the Auta tribunal that tried the Ogoni Nine, the report recognized the constitutional provision for the setting up of tribunals such as those for armed robbery and drug trafficking. But it carpeted the government for flouting its own law which states that such a special tribunal must be set up after a report by a duly constituted investigation committee.

The trial itself, said the report, followed a procedure that was not fair. It condemned the inclusion of military personnel in the tribunal, the maltreatment of Saro-Wiwa and others in detention and the hasty manner in which the Provisional Ruling Council ratified the tribunals' judgment without "the records of the proceedings which were not yet completed" at the time of the PRC meeting.

The team made some bold recommendations on the Ogoni crisis. It urged the government to repeal the Civil Disturbances (Special Tribunal) Act of 1987 and let the criminal courts handled such cases in future. Alternatively, members of tribunal should not included the military, members should be appointed on the recommendation of the chief justice and judgment should be appealable. It recommended the improvement of the economy, education, health and welfare of the Ogoni.

Issue cover date: June 2, 1996


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


95 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Abacha's Terror Tribunals


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 31, 1996 by Muyiwa Akintunde


LENGTH: 3027 words


 

Lagos - Several weeks before the event, he had made it a habit to skip state functions even after elaborate arrangements had been made for his reception. For millions of Nigerians who have no access to the inner recess of the Presidential Villa, the only way they could know that all was well with their head of state was through his prime time appearances featuring courtesy calls by numerous envoys and other dignitaries. But, last Monday, Sani Abacha, the head of state, dismissed speculations that it was in his character to keep away from public glare. 

That morning, a workshop on crime prevention and control, organized by the Ministry of Internal Affairs, was to get off the ground in Abuja. Abacha was due to attend and government sources even told Theweek that he confirmed his coming. But, as the programme was being delayed, it was feared that the head of state might do an en core of the December, 1994, episode which was believed to be one of the factors that made the Federation of International Football Associations invalidate Nigeria's hosting right for the World Youth championship last year. On that occasion, Nigeria kept the world waiting for 95 minutes for the draws of the ill-fated championship. Abacha, who had earlier assured the organizers of his presence, reportedly declined to attend at the last minute. Even then, it took so long to sort out who should represent the head of state. Initially, it was said to have been agreed that Oladipo Diya, the chief of general staff, who is generally know as the "gamesmaster-general of the federation" because of his penchant for sports, would fit the bill, but Abacha was said to have changed his mind in favor of one of his confidants, Jeremiah Useni, minister of the Federal Capital Territory, Abuja. This time, Abacha ended the suspense by making himself available at the workshop.

As the programme progressed, the head of state was invited to give a keynote address and flagg off the workshop. And by the time he was through with his speech, it was no longer in doubt that he was set to bare his fangs on corrupt public officers - past and present - and their collaborators. He lamented that in 25 years, Nigeria had invested more than N53 billion in parastatals which were worth only N900 when their assets were privatized in 1992. His countenance was that of gloom as he explained: "The colossal waste of public funds through mismanagement, fraud, embezzlement and other white collar crimes have contributed in no small measure to the poor state of our economy and social services. No administration worth its name can allow this unacceptable situation to continue." What next? Abacha again: "We have consequently resolved that all those who contributed to the failure of our public institutions and parastatals through monumental mismanagement of public funds will be held to account to ensure that present and future executives of such institutions operate according to set rules and procedure." Emphasizing that there would be no "sacred cows," the head of state confirmed the speculations about the coming of yet another anti-corruption tribunal-the Failed Companies and Parastatals Tribunal.

Until Abacha delivers on his promise to release the legal framework for the tribunal, it remains uncertain how far the dragnet would extend in the regime's ethical war. Whether or not they might be a victim of the crusade, some Nigerians have taken sides with Abacha. One of the prominent supporters of the war is Hammed Kusamotu, Chairman of the National Republican Convention, which collapsed with other political structures in the aftermath of Abacha's coup in November, 1993. As far as the lawyer could understand, the new tribunal "is a queer necessity." He goes on to explain in an interview with Theweek: "That means that this is not what it is, but what it ought to be, that is that nobody should corner public fund and put it in his pocket. Those parastatals have not served the purpose for which they were set up and far worse, the officials take them as their personal property."

That view tallies with that of Ndaeyo Uko, a Lagos journalist. He says of the new tribunal: "I think it is useful. If it will help to sanitize the system, it is okay by me." He would not be dragged into the belief that Abacha was out to bring his adversaries to their feet, through the anti-corruption war. His query: "Let's look at it this way, if somebody should blow up a prison to free the inmates, would the prisoners ask what his intentions are"?

Is Abacha then the Messiah Nigerians have longed for to clear the proverbial Aegean stable? To many Nigerians, he does not have the credentials to embark on an ethical war. His legendary wealth is said to include a multi-million Naira mansion in his home town, Kano, and business interest that spans the aviation, oil and hospitality sectors. In the famous Newswatch interview David Mark, the retired brigadier-general who fled the country after falling out with the Abacha regime, described the Ministry of Defense as a "sore point and a no-go area." For years in the Babangida era, Abacha was in charge of that ministry. And believed to be buried inside the former Defense Headquarters are the secret files of the inferno that wrecked the skyscraper three years ago, the report of the Hercules C-130 plane crash which wiped out a generation of young military officers in 1992, the cost of the Liberian war operations and the audit reports of the defense budgets.

In the opinion of his army of critics, Abacha has not come to equity with cleans hands. Listen to Ayo Obe, president of the Civil Liberties Organization: "People say let it (the anti-corruption crusade) start from the top. There is no point blaming the civil servant because his wife got government contract. The thing we know is that poverty is not in their lexicon, I means those at the top. We all know what it takes to build a house in Nigeria today, yet the top men are building houses all over the place. I am not saying you have to be a saint to eradicate corruption, but in politics, appearance is as important as reality. During General Murtala Muhammed's time, he was ready to sin no more and divested himself of his wealth and people were ready to follow him."

Yinka Odumakin, publicity secretary of the National Conscience Party, supports the CLO president. Says he: "All these tribunals are mere window dressing to hoodwink the masses. $12.4 billion was reportedly missing in the dedicated account during the gulf war era when he (Abacha) and Babangida were the key actors. His cosmetic reforms are to broaden his base, demonize everybody and make the masses helpless. He is out to discredit the elite. Even as we know that they (the elite) still have one or two questions to answer in terms of our money, it should be done minus Abacha."

Well, it appears Abacha has convinced himself, just like Uko, that all he requires to win the war on corruption is the will, and not his credentials. Asked if Abacha has the moral right to fight an ethical war, Uko goes philosophical: "Even the Pope has no right to wage any ethical war. However, to wait for a saint before we start something of this sort is to wait for ever. Tell me three people in this country who you think are qualified to wage such a war there may be none. He is qualified, so he has to continue." And so has Abacha.

In the beginning, the regime was a bundle of contradictions in many respects, including its attitude to corruption. In his maiden broadcast as head of state, Abacha spoke of the resolve of the regime to be "firm, humane and decisive. We will not condone nor tolerate any act of indiscipline." He said that probe panels would be set up on the military, the police, the customs, the judiciary, the Nigerian Telecommunications Plc, the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, the National Electric Power Authority, the banking industry and the higher educational institutions." But a few days later at a gathering of senior military officers, Diya contradicted his commander-in-chief when he said that the administration would not waste time dabbling into probes. What it would rather do is to stem further acts of corruption and abuse of office.

However, events took a U-turn many weeks after when Abacha instituted one panel after the other to pry into the records of several organizations. Among the first set to be probed were some of the acting military administrators who served for three weeks before the administration appointed the first batch of substantive military administrators. The board of inquiry, headed by Oladayo Popoola, former military governor of Oyo State, set out on January 3, 1994, to investigate the brief tenure of four colonels - Dauda Nimyel (Borno State), Ezekiel Coker (Kano), Linus Olorogun (Sokoto) and Abel Akale (Osun) - and two police commissioners - Pius Ahonkhai (Akwa Ibom) and Wadi Ali (Yobe). Of the lot, only Akale was found not guilty on charges of misappropriation of funds and abuse of office. The military court and the army council were said to have been so ashamed of the conduct of the three indicted colonels that they were retired from the army. In the case of the police officers, they were placed on suspension on February 22, 1994, following Diya's instruction to Ibrahim Coomassie, the inspector-general of police. Last year, the police council was said to be waiting for its army counter part to cast the first stone before it censured the commissioners. Now that the army council had done that, it is not clear the next step the police would take.

Having dealt with members of his primary constituency, Abacha moved on to other areas. Among the parastatals that he beamed the searchlight on was the NNPC which had a 10-member probe panel headed by Emmanuel Abisoye, a retired major-general. It was to examine payments in excess of N1 million made by the corporation in the last three years in order to identify recipients of any dubious transactions, the amount involved and how to recover them. The panel was also charged with the task of examining thoroughly the present structure, organization and function of the NNPC and make appropriate recommendation for improvement. The re-organization that took place at the NNPC last year, leading to the exit of Chamberlain Oyibo, its group managing director and many other senior officials may not be unconnected with the unpublished report of the panel.

For the Nigerian Customs Service, believed to be Nigeria's bastion of corruption, the eight-man panel was led by another retired major-general, Paul Tarfa. Among other areas, it was asked to compare and examine Customs operations in other countries, especially that of Indonesia to serve as a possible model for Nigeria. Like the other panels, the report of the Tarfa team has not been released but it is believed to have recommended three redeployment of Samuel Ango, the brigadier-general, who was appointed the sole administrator after the suspension of Bello Mohammed, the comptroller-general, his six deputies and 22 assistants.

And when last year, Anthony Ani, minister of finance, exposed a N8 billion scam on the clearing of 2,500 non-import duty report containers at the ports, several customs officials were arrested along with customs licensed agents and officials of major shipping firms. In executing the war at the ports, the government introduced sweeping reforms in duty collection and appointed professional accounting firms to take the job of duty collection from customs officials. Despite the slow pace by the accounting firms and the closure of the ports for several weeks, the new order remains in place to the displeasure of customs men and their collaborators.

Other avenues for easy money are equally being blocked. These include hard drug trafficking, advance fee fraud (well know as 419), and money laundering. Commanding the troop in this sector that has earned Nigeria a bad name in the international community is Musa Bamaiyi, a hard-knuckled major-general and chairman of the National Drug Law Enforcement Agency. In one fell swoop last June, he sealed off the premises of 30 car dealers in Lagos, demanding to know the source of their wealth. He impounded about 800 vehicles in the process. Bamaiyi then directed his attention to prominent Nigerians, including sect leaders. Among his victims who spent weeks at the NDLEA detention camp were Sat Guru Maharaj-ji, a controversial spiritual leader, Temitope Joshua, founder of the crowd-pulling Synagogue Church of All Nations, and Fela Anikulapo-Kuti, the Afro Beat King.

Perhaps Abacha's fiercest battle is that against fraud in the banking sector. Last year, he promulgated the Failed Bank (Recovery of Debts) and Financial Decree No. 18 and set up five tribunals to try bank chiefs and others said to be involved in the multiple financial malpractices that grounded about 50 banks in the last three years. At least 200 bank chiefs are in detention at the Federal Investigations and Intelligence Bureau, Alagbon, Lagos where their detention camp is derogatorily referred to as the "Banking Hall." Among those in the police net are Femi Adekanye, former executive chairman of Commerce Bank Limited, and Ralph Osayameh, ex-managing director of the bank, both former president of the Chartered Institute of Bankers of Nigeria. Already, the tribunals have jailed at least eight bank executives, including Bello Abubakar, former managing director of Gamji Bank, Onwochei Odogwu, ex-managing director of Kaptial Merchant Bank, and Christopher Anyaegbunam, former director of Group Merchant Bank and son of Fred Anyaegbunam, retired justice of the Supreme Court.

One of the factors which the government claimed led to the fall of Ibrahim Dasuki as the 18th sultan of Sokoto last month was the prospect of his appearance before the Failed Banks Tribunal. The dethroned monarch and 15 other directors of two companies are being accused of complicity in a N775 million owed Alpha Merchant Bank. Dasuki's defense is that he had resigned as director of the indebted company at the time the loan was negotiated and secured. Other big shots now being investigated by the tribunals included Arthur Nzeribe, a controversial politician, and Anthony Hannaniya, a retired major-general and corps marshal of the Federal Road Safety Commission.

For now, the new tribunal on Failed Companies and Parastatals may end up being the most all embracing. Giving the nature of the Nigerian economy, virtually all business outfits survive on government contracts which are largely un-executed. In this light, it is believed that Abacha may employ the new law to whip his adversaries in line. Those who may be arraigned before the tribunal may include his political opponents who are believed to be creating problems for the administration, particularly in the international community. One of such victims may be Moshood Abiola, now in the 23rd month of his detention for proclaiming himself president.

As soon as Abacha announced the coming of the Failed Companies and Parastatals tribunal, the news was abroad that Abiola may have to answer for the multi-billion Naira telecommunications contract which he won for the International Telephone and Telecommunications in the 1970s. ITT was to have provided telephone lines all over the country under the National Telecommunications Implementation Project. That Nigeria's telecommunication system remains in the Dark Ages is blamed on the failure of ITT to execute the contract. Now that the government is said to be keen on probing the more than 20-year old contract, the move is seen as part of attempts to break what is considered Abiola's steel-like will in the struggle to have his presidential mandate honored.

Will Abacha see the struggle to make Nigeria a corrupt-free country to the end? Or, will this last initiative end up like his War Against Against Indiscipline and Corruption that was abandoned midway? The answer is in the womb of time.

With Amos Esele, Austin Avwode, Felix Ojogwu and Ukpong Kalu Mba.

Issue cover date: June 2, 1996


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa (DOCUMENT) U.S. Welcomes Peacekeeping Moves in Liberia


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is the text of a statement by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns on Liberia on May 29:

The United States congratulates ECOMOG (ECOWAS Monitoring Group in Liberia) on its recent deployment throughout Monrovia and welcomes the firmness the peacekeepers have shown in moving armed faction fighters out of the capital. ECOMOG's action has restored peace to Monrovia for the first time in nearly eight weeks. With the peacekeepers deployed, a more secure environment now exists which will allow easier access to and delivery of humanitarian assistance for the one million Liberian civilians in Monrovia.

The United States will continue to provide logistics assistance for ECOMOG and will be working to ensure that this assistance is delivered in a timely manner to strengthen ECOMOG's effectiveness. We are also continuing our diplomatic efforts, working in concert with ECOWAS, the UN, and the OAU, to encourage a negotiated end to the war in Liberia.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


97 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa (DOCUMENT) U.S. Team In Africa For Burundi Talks


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Washington, DC - Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs George E. Moose is visiting Africa with other U.S. experts to discuss the "ongoing crisis in Burundi," with leaders in the region. Following is the text of the announcement by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns on May 29:

A senior interagency team led by Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs George E. Moose departed Washington on May 27 for Paris, Nairobi, Tanzania, Kigali, Bujumbura, and Kampala. Assistant Secretary Moose will hold meetings with key regional leaders, focussing on the ongoing crisis in Burundi.

The purpose of this mission is to follow up quickly and forcefully on the progress made during recent visits to the region by National Security Adviser Anthony Lake and Assistant Secretary Moose.

This mission is a part of our ongoing preventive diplomacy efforts in Burundi, intended to stop the violence and encourage all parties to negotiate seriously towards national reconciliation. Throughout his trip, Assistant Secretary Moose will emphasize the high priority the U.S. places on the success of the negotiating efforts of former Tanzanian President Nyerere.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


98 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa (DOCUMENT) U.S. Official To Nigeria For Talks


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 30, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Washington, DC - John Shattuck, the assistant secretary of State for democracy, human rights, and labor, arrived in Nigeria yesterday for two days of talks with government officials and non-governmental groups and individuals, the U.S. State Department announced. Following is a statement released May 29 by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns:

John Shattuck, assistant secretary of state for democracy, human rights, and labor, arrives today in Nigeria for two days of discussions with a broad range of groups and individuals, including government officials, members of non-governmental organizations, and advocates of human and worker rights and democracy. 

The United States is deeply conscious of Nigeria's regional and economic significance and is profoundly interested in the progress of Nigerian democracy, peace, and stability. We are deeply concerned by the steady deterioration in human rights since November 1993. The United States strongly believes that Nigeria's people can succeed in building a better future if stable, democratic government is allowed to thrive.

I would reiterate our friendship towards the people of Nigeria and our desire for good relations grounded in a shared commitment to the universal norms of human rights.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


99 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa House Committee Votes to End Africa Earmark


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 31, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Washington, DC - The committee in the U.S. House of Representatives with principal responsibility for foreign aid has approved legislation eliminating all earmarking of funds for sub-Saharan Africa. The proposed bill also cuts $1 billion from the foreign aid budget proposed by President Clinton for fiscal year 1997.

In a brief meeting on May 29, the House Appropriations Committee voted to eliminate funding for the Development Fund for Africa, a legislative vehicle established in 1987 to designate money for development projects in Africa. Funding for Africa projects will be drawn from the $1.96 billion the committee allocated for development assistance. The committee approved specific earmarks of nearly $5 billion in funds for Israel and Egypt and close to $1 billion for Eastern Europe and the countries of the former Soviet Union. 

The committee-approved bill also terminates funding for the Africa Development Bank and makes deep cuts in the U.S. contribution to the World Bank. The U.S. contribution to the International Development Association, a World Bank affiliate which provides substantial assistance to Africa, was reduced by almost 44 percent from the level requested by the Clinton administration.

The foreign aid funding bill, known as the "Foreign Operations Appropriation," will come to a vote in the full House of Representatives on June 5, according to committee sources. The legislation still must be approved by the Senate before it is sent to President Clinton for signing into law.

The Clinton administration had proposed $12.8 billion in aid for the next fiscal year, but the Appropriations Committee action cut total funding to $11.9 million. The reduction for the International Development Association (IDA) from the administration's request of $935 million to $525 million accounted for almost half the total cuts. Because of severe slashes last year, the Clinton administration's IDA request this year was primarily designated to meet past obligations to the organization.

The IDA provides loans to the world's poorest countries at below-market interest rates and, according to U.S. Treasury Department officials, is the world's largest lender to projects which contribute to child survival. "For the three billion people living in the world's poorest countries, IDA is the single most important provider of concessional development assistance," Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin said last week.

In other actions taken yesterday the committee also eliminated all funds for the African Development Bank, although last year when this happened the funding was restored in a House-Senate conference committee. The committee increased funding for UNICEF above President Clinton's requested level, boosted funds for international counter-narcotics efforts and voted $600 million for programs effecting children in developing countries.

Updates on the committee's action is available from the House Appropriations Committee's web site at <http://www.house.gov/appropriations/welcome.html>.


LOAD-DATE: June 3, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

May, 1996


Ethiopia Meles Outlines Five Years Record


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 946 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ato meles Zenawi, chairman of the Council of the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) said his front has more than ever before penetrated more than ever before penetrated the society through mobilisations for development and various undertakings.

Ato Meles who is also the Prime Minster of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia said the EPRDF has won popular support. 

In an interview with Abiotawi Democracy, organ of the front in connection with May 28, the 5th anniversary celebration of the demise of the Derg military rule, the chairman said the EPRDF is winning the support of the people based on the common goal of striving fro development and democracy.

The political image of the country over the past 5 years was mainly characterised by the transition from war to peace and from dictatorship to democratic system and by the deepening of the democratic experience and culture of the people.

On the present condition and future roles of political forces in the country, Prime Minister Meles grouped the political forces into the EPRDF and those affiliated to the EPRDF, as well as those non-EPRDF political parties legally operating and represented in the parliament and those who alienated themselves from the process.'

Political organisations who alienated themselves are not inclined to accept the alternative of a legal, peaceful political process, he said adding unless they take the right path, they go on withering away.

He said Ethiopia, except with Sudan, has a strong and close ties with her neighbouring countries.

The country also enjoys almost similar relations continentally while her relationship with the international financial institutions and donor and creditor institutions and countries is satisfactory, Ato Meles said.

May, 1996


Eritrea Ethiopia Endorses Eritrea - Yemen Pact


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 25, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa -Ethiopian Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin lauded the signing of an arbitration agreement between Eritrea and Yemen as a victory also of the peace loving countries of the sub-region.

The France-brokered agreement was signed in Paris by Eritrean foreign Minister Petros Solomon and his Yemeni Counterpart Abdukarim Al Iryani and was witnessed by foreign ministers of Ethiopia, Egypt and France. 

On arrival at Bole International Airport from Paris, Ato Seyoum said Ethiopia will continue exerting efforts towards the successful implementation of the agreement together with the countries chosen to arbitrate and observe the process.

Under the accord Eritrea and Yemen have agreed that France monitor military manoeuvres around the disputed Hanish Islands, he said.

Pursuant to the mandate given to her, France will immediately report the U.N. Secretary General boutros Boutros Ghali any military movements around the islands, the minister said.

Ato Seyoum said the two sisterly countries agreed to renew their relations.

Under the pact, Eritrea and Yemen will each choose two of the five members of the international tribunal and the four will pick the chairman, he said adding they, moreover, have agreed to respect the decisions of the tribunal.

He said the two sides also agreed on the selection by the International Court of Justice of the fifth member of the tribunal, if they lose confidence in the choice of the four.

Africa News


May, 1996


Ethiopia Government Receives 80 Percent of Needed Food


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 25, 1996


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Addis Ababa -More than 80 percent of the 206,000 tonnes of relief food required for this year has entered the country, a government official said.

At a news conference he held with local journalists here Wednesday Ato Simeon Mechale, Commissioner of the Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission said efforts are under way to secure the remaining amount of relief food until the end of 1996.

There are 2.8 million people in the country who needed relief food this year, he said. 

Most of the needy are in Wollo, Gondar, Tigray, North Omo of the Southern Peoples' and East Hararge zones of Oromiya regional states, the commissioner said.

Regarding the activities undertaken during the last nine months, he said training's were given of staff members of regional bureaux of the Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission and agricultural professionals on policy familiarisation and employment of mechanisms of early warning system.

The commissioner said workshops and seminars have been organised for personnel of regional agriculture, education and health bureaux and other pertinent government representative organisations with the objective of raising their awareness on the disaster prevention policy.

The commission has not been able to raise the level of knowledge of disaster prevention regional representatives through training because of frequent transfers and changes of persons in some regions he said, adding that as a solution it has been decided that two regional representatives be sent to take part in trainings.

Ato Simeon said the commission is selling it numerous heavy-duty trucks to private businessmen in accordance with the policy on the transfer of transport services to the private sector.

The commissioner said the sale of the trucks is in line with the government policy to leave the transportation of relief grain and commodities to the private sector. He added that a strategic relief fleet is being established, and 55 four wheel drive trucks have been obtained from the German government for this purpose.

The fleet will be used to transport emergency relief aid to areas where private truck owners, mostly because of difficult terrain, refuse to go.

Regarding the current food reserve, Ato Simon said that it was dependable, and of the 307,000 metric tonnes required, 270,000 metric tonnes has been obtained. Efforts are being made to obtain the remaining until the end of this fiscal year, he added.

Another problem cited by Ato Simeon was lack of awareness on the part of government agencies and other relevant bodies regarding the fact that implementation of the national policy required their full participation.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia U.S. Supports UN Extension in Liberia


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 23, 1996


LENGTH: 934 words


 

United Nations - Text of a statement on May 28 by U.S. Ambassador Edward Gnehm, the deputy U.S. representative to the United Nations, during a Security Council meeting to decide whether to continue the mandate of the UN Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL):

All of us have watched in horror over the past two months as Liberia has descended from hope into despair. Driven by warlords, Liberia has careened off the road to peace and national reconciliation.

Only a few months ago, we spoke hopefully of the Abuja peace agreement, of Ecomog's pioneer role as a regional peacekeeping force and of the important contribution which the United Nations, particularly UNOMIL was making to the peace process. A transitional Council of State had been installed and we looked forward to elections in August. We expected Liberia's leaders to complete the remaining steps required under Abuja so that Liberians could finally enjoy the peace they have sought for six long years of civil war. Now the secretary-general tells us in his report that fighting is seriously jeopardizing the Abuja peace process and has reversed the gains made over the past few months. 

As Ambassador Albright observed after her visit to Monrovia in January, the problem in Liberia is a struggle among a few elites for power. In April, these faction leaders demonstrated their commitment to their own interests rather than the good of their people. They re-ignited the violence, turned Monrovia from a safe haven into a war zone, and looted the equipment of relief agencies whose only goal was to help the Liberian people. Today fighters openly drive convoys of stolen United Nations and NGO (non-governmental organization) vehicles around Monrovia. My government was forced to conduct an emergency evacuation of most of the international community from Liberia. Only a few UNOMIL military observers remain and the fighting often precludes them from any attempt to carry out the most basic tasks of their mandate. We are outraged by the looting of the U.N., the NGOs, the churches, the hospitals, and the homes of Liberian people.

What can we do? The answer is not to abandon Liberia. We agree with the views of the secretary-general in his report -- the international community must remain engaged in the efforts to provide relief and bring peace to the people of Liberia. The regional countries of ECOWAS (Economic Community of West African States) have taken the lead in this respect. The meeting of their foreign ministers in Accra on May 7 developed a plan to restart the peace process. This "Mechanism For Returning Liberia to the Abuja Agreement" provides concrete steps, including restoration of the cease-fire, withdrawal of all fighters from Monrovia, deployment of ECOMOG throughout the city and restoration of Monrovia as a safe haven, needed to re-start the peace process.

These steps are necessary if there is to be continued international involvement. This is the message that my government delivered to the Liberian parties through high-level delegations we sent to Monrovia in the past weeks. We commend the ECOWAS countries for their clarity of purpose and their dedication in the face of tremendous difficulties. We believe that the Security Council must support this important initiative by the countries of the region.

The Accra meeting has given Liberia yet another chance to return to the path of peace. Once again, Liberia's leaders must decide what course to pursue. We hope they will implement the recent agreements reached in Accra. The Liberian warlords must order their forces to disarm and leave Monrovia in peace. ECOMOG commanders must reassert their control of Monrovia. And the Council of State must begin to act like the transitional government envisaged in the Abuja agreement.

By the end of this week, the Security Council must decide on the future of UNOMIL.

We are heartened by the continuing commitment of the ECOWAS states and by the steps ECOMOG has taken to deploy throughout Monrovia. We encourage them to continue such efforts. Therefore, we support extending UNOMIL's mandate for three months. We do so because we have not given up hope for Liberia; hope that Liberians will take hold of their destiny and recover their country from the grip of those who only wish to destroy it; hope that law and order can again be brought to Liberia; hope that Liberia can be liberated from war.

Over the next three months my government will be watching closely to see if any of these hopes are fulfilled. If not, we and the Security Council will have to re-evaluate our approach. Again, we urge all those in Liberia, particularly the faction leaders, to use this time to meet the conditions ECOWAS has laid out and offer their people the chance for peace they deserve.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


104 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Egypt U.S. Media Group Protests Editor's Prosecution


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) May 27, 1996


LENGTH: 694 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director of the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) to President Muhammad Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. May 24, 1996:

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) is very concerned about the ongoing trial of opposition editor Magdi Hussein. Mr. Hussein is appealing a conviction under a controversial press law that is currently being revised by parliament. We are writing to ask that the appeal of Mr. Hussein and the prosecution of other journalists be postponed until the parliament has finished its review of this law. The next hearing of Mr. Hussein's appeal is scheduled for May 28. 

On January 31, a Cairo court sentenced Mr. Hussein, the editor in chief of Al-Shaab, biweekly organ of the pro-Islamist Labor Party, to serve one year in prison with hard labor, and pay a E (Egyptian pounds) 15,000 fine, and E501 in compensatory damages. The conviction stemmed from charges that Mr. Hussein's paper had libeled Alaa Hassan el-Alfi, the son of the interior minister, Gen. Hassan el-Alfi, by publishing an article that accused him of refusing to pay his bills at a Cairo hotel and trying to bully its managers when they demanded payment. Mr. Hussein has appealed the conviction. On May 8, he was arrested and held for two days for refusing to pay the fine prior to the conclusion of his appeal.

Mr. Hussein was tried under Law 93 of 1995, a series of amendments to the penal code pertaining to crimes of publication passed by the People's Assembly and subsequently signed by Your Excellency. Its provisions sharply increase the penalties for crimes of publication and expand the scope of punishable offenses. Penalties for libel have been dramatically increased under Law 93. The minimum jail term for anyone convicted of slander was raised from 24 hours to one year, while the minimum fine was raised from E20 to E5,000. If the slander is directed at a public official or government employee, then the penalty is even harsher -- up to five years in prison and/or a fine of up to E20,000.

At least 20 journalists have been tried or are currently being prosecuted under Law 93. CPJ has written to Your Excellency on several occasions urging the government to repeal Law 93. A bill that would amend Law 93 is currently being debated in parliament.

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists dedicated to the defense of our colleagues' rights throughout the world, CPJ believes that Mr. Hussein is being prosecuted merely for having exercised his right as a journalist "to seek, receive, and impart information and ideas through any media, and regardless of frontiers," guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations' Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

The use of Law 93 against Mr. Hussein and other journalists is a clear violation of the principles of the Declaration of Sana'a on Promoting Independent and Pluralistic Arab Media. which were agreed upon by journalists from the entire Arab world, and endorsed by the UN and UNESCO. If Mr. Hussein's conviction and sentence are upheld, press freedom in Egypt will suffer a serious blow.

CPJ respectfully urges Your Excellency to instruct the appropriate judicial authorities to postpone Mr. Hussein's appeal hearing and the prosecution of other journalists who are being tried under Law 93 until the revised press law has been enacted.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

May, 1996


Zambia Rains Could Wash Out Harvest


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency (Lusaka) May 26, 1996


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - The Meteorological Department (MET) headquaters here this morning was flooded with inquiries from worried farmers who wanted to know if current freak rains, will continue to destroy their crops.

MET acting Senior Forecast Officer, Mr Jacob Nkomoki, said farmers phoning in from as far as from Mkushi and Choma called to find out if the current rains, which they said had washed out their harvests especially that of cotton and maize. 

Mr Nkomoki said although this was not a rain season, the drizzle the country was experiencing is as a result of convergence of the moist north-westerlies and dry north-easterlies from the equatorial low pressure area.

He said tomorrow the country expects more rainfall expecially in Eastern province where more rains is expected and later it will spread to many parts of the country.

Mr Nkomoki said from yesterday's rains, Lusaka International Airport recorded 22 millimetres, Kafue 11 millimetres, Solwezi 11 millimetres, Mount Makulu two millimetres and City Airport seven millimetres.
