106 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Scorpions and Hyenas Invade Parliament


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 27, 1996 by Fred M'membe (Column)


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

Lusaka - Although Members of Parliament are entrusted by the people to protect the nation from misrule, because of greed, insatiable appetite for money, fear of losing jobs and business opportunities, they are prepared to see the country go to the dogs.

Success for our Members of Parliament has not meant risky defence of principles but ability to trade and comprise democratic ideals for economic and political advantages without shame.

Our most 'successful' Members of Parliament today are not those who, like Akash-ambatwa, Rodger Chongwe, Katongo Maine, John Mulwila, Emmanuel Kasonde, Rolf Shenton, among others, have stood by democratic principles - however short their stay in Parliament, but those who have sold their souls to become ministers and stay in the National Assembly.

There is little doubt that our Parliament is no longer the voice of the people. It lacks the guts to speak for the people, because doing so requires courage and a bit of selflessness. 

And as spineless as it is, our Parliament can only do what involves less risk - it can only support the government; it can only fulfill the wishes of President Chiluba. In doing so it has stopped to be a Parliament of the people and has become President Chiluba's tool - a mouth piece of his government.

Our Parliament is a people's weapon that has been captured by scorpions and hyenas and turned against the nation. And it would be naive for the people of Zambia to expect protection from that which is under siege from scorpions and hyenas.

For our Parliament to become useful again, the scorpions, hyenas and vultures have to be driven out of it. And this can only be done by the people themselves.

And scorpions, hyenas, and vultures cannot be expected to protect and promote people's interests.

Scorpions protect and promote scorpions interests. Hyenas have not been known to be our good friends and vultures have always been opportunistic.

I have tried very hard not to write about what happened in Parliament last Wednesday. But I have failed.

It has been extremely difficult for me to remain silent on the passing of the Constitution of Zambia (Amendment) Bill in parliament, and the expulsion of Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika from Parliament last Wednesday.

Not to oppose the constitution amendment deceit, or corruption, and Akashambatwa's expulsion from Parliament , I need to suppress in me what is best in human beings - courage, love for justice, anger against evil and compassion for the downtrodden.

To remain silent to President Frederick Chiluba's fraudulent and fascist constitution and Akashambatwa's clearly unjust exclusion from Parliament by Speaker Robinson Nabulyato, I need to commit suicide as a thinking being.

Parliament is in many ways a platform and public court where different interests contend and fight it out in debate. But without an independent umpire or Speaker, fair debates and judgments are impossible.

While a Speaker is generally expected to be independent and fair, Nabulyato is required to be loyal to President Chiluba and the ruling MMD - at whose pleasure he serves.

Nabulyato cannot continue to be Speaker if he stops running Parliament as per President Chiluba's whims.

And Nabulyato, as one who was resurrected from a political grave by the President and the MMD, all his thoughts of fairness and justice must have been replaced by the single 'need' of keeping President Chiluba happy.

Simple logic, however dictates that the Speaker and indeed all members of parliament, should be loyal to Zambia and national interest should automatically come before loyalty to one man.

But in President Chiluba's Zambia,the politics of poverty and sycophancy make logic sit on its head. Zambia's history clearly demonstrates the need for a good non partisan constitution that is not based on the interests of the political leadership in power at the moment.

The tides of public opinion continually shift but the value of a good constitution? is unmeasurable.

Today's popular political leaders may be tomorrow's dictators. And today's rejected 'political' stones may be tomorrow's nation's corner stones.

Initial leaders of our country's independence struggle, like Harry Mwaanga Nkumbula, fell out of favour with the rank and file membership of their parties but today they are glorified by the same people who despised and insulted them.

When Simon Mwansa Kapwepwe left UNIP in 1971 to form the opposition UPP he was called all sorts of names by ruling party cadres like Sikota Wina, who are today singing praises to the memory of the man they so viciously fought.

Former president Kenneth Kaunda, one of the most popular leaders of our country's and indeed the region's liberation struggles, was in 1991 rejected by his political 'fans' who felt he was a dictator who had brought untold misery unto them.

President Chiluba, probably the most popular trade unionist in our country's history, replaced Kaunda as the new Moses almost five years ago but today he would be lucky to even get anywhere near Purgatory.

Chiluba, the trade unionist, the people's choice, the bulwark of the anti-corruption struggle, and a champion of democracy and justice is today considered the negator of all that.

But Kaunda is no longer the hated dictator of 1991. His popularity has since then increased greatly to enable him give a good challenge for the presidency.

President Chiluba is today considered anti-people and anti-justice. The Chiluba of today awards salary increments without negotiations to parliamentarians but denies civil servants decent wages.

The Chiluba of State House is seen as being permissive to corruption and drug trafficking.

The Chiluba of Plot 1 turned a blind eye to the criminal plunder of University of Zambia land by his ministers, friends and probably by himself.

Chiluba, the President of the Republic of Zambia, as opposed to the trade unionist, believes in repression. In March 1993 he declared a state of emergency that enabled him to arrest, detain and maim some members of opposition UNIP. And his Parliament detains journalists indefinitely without trial.

The Chiluba of today, as opposed to the Moses of 1991, adopts and enacts a fraudulent constitution that robs many citizens of their rights and downgrades their citizenship just preserve his hold on power.

People change! Some people would, however, say they don't change; we simply didn't know them and we are permitted to know them better.

This being the situation a "good" constitution, that is tailored to cater for President Chiluba, or to cut out former president Kaunda's political come back, is necessary.

The expulsion from Parliament last Wednesday of National Party member of parliament Akasham-batwa confirmed what I have always said that our National Assembly is not a people's Parliament.

Akashambatwa's expulsion also confirms that our Parliament can't even fairly arbitrate in conflicts between members of the executive and other citizens.

Whenever there is a conflict between anybody and the executive - even over non partisan issues like the constitution - our Parliament always acts as the defender of the government.

When Akashambatwa criticised Parliament's detention of Post editors without trial, at the instigation of the executive through Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda, and asked for them to be taken to court or set free, the Speaker behaved in the most dishonourable way by condemning and expelling him from the National Assembly.

But the principles Akashambatwa was defending were same ideals that Parliament should have been defending.

Now, it seems, anyone who comes into collision with President Chiluba's government should expect to also be attacked and, in some way, punished by Parliament.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


107 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Police Confirm It Was a Bomb


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 28, 1996 by Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Lusaka - Lusaka's Hotel Intercontinental would have gone up in flames, causing extensive damage to property and human life, had police not detonated the bomb found in a briefcase last Thursday.

Police sources confirmed to The Post yesterday that bomb experts had found what they are calling low grade bombs in the briefcase picked up in one of the hotel's toilets.

Police said the bomb, which was in many respects similar to the one which blew up part of the security wall at State House a fortnight ago, would have ignited a fire in the hotel building. 

"The bomb was a simple home made one from ordinary cells. It was in itself not bound to cause much damage to the hotel building," the police source said. "But there were small plastic containers the size of drinking bottles, which had petrol in them and were stashed in the same brief case."

Police said the explosion would have lit up the petrol causing a fire which could have eventually affected the electrical system in the hotel building with a possibility of setting the building ablaze.

"We are not looking at a guy or guys who are merely playing games, because with every attempt there is a potential threat to human life and property," the source said.

There was panic at Hotel Intercontinental last Thursday when a man claiming to be part of the Black Mamba phoned the hotel warning them of the bomb and urging them to evacuate their guests from their rooms because there was a bomb in a brief case within the hotel. The bomb was expected to explode within 30 minutes of the call.

On suspicion hotel staff identified an unaccompanied briefcase which had been lying in a toilet near the hotel lobby for sometime. Their guess was right.

Zambia and South African police experts, called in to help track down the Black Mamba and check its likely bomb attacks, later opened the case and found the bomb.

"It is not an issue to ignore it as a mere scare," the source said. "The bomb was real, not as fatal, but its location was strategically dangerous."

The first bomb attack by the Black Mamba was a fortnight ago when they brought down parts of the security wall at State House, close to President Chiluba's official residence. They are understood to have used "simple explosives made from radio cells".

The Black Mamba has warned of deaths of selected government officials and the National Assembly Speaker for passing what it has termed as a discriminatory and dictatorial constitution against popular will.

So far police have been fishing widely making random interrogations of people at the slightest suspicion.

By yesterday they were still interrogating former Zambia Air Force Captain Selemani Pangula over the matter. They have also claimed the Black Mamba is using public telephone booths to announce its attacks.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


108 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Zambia 'Reduced to Sodom and Gomorrah'


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 27, 1996 by Lucy Sichone (Column)


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Lusaka - The Movement for Multiparty Democracy is currently running an advertisement which shows a clip of KK predicting chaos and violence if MMD was voted into power in the general elections in 1991. Then in typical the "Emperor is not naked " style that is characteristic of MMD, the advert concludes that KK lied. Apparently the Zaireans in government are happy that they have achieved what Owen Sichone calls the Zaireanisation of Zambia in a record of five years where it took their brother Mobutu some 30 years of anarchical management of the richest country in Africa.

The MMD campaign advert of KK has made me acknowledge what I believe is the most fearsome characteristic of the former President viz his vast and accurate knowledge of human scoundrels which enabled him to contain and use them in the governance of Zambia, be it in the trade unions or elsewhere for 27 years without their breaking out like the plague and destroying the fabric of society in the manner in which they have done over the past five years. 

From what must have been obviously an intimate knowledge of his former colleagues in UNIP and the unions, KK described the "Nazis" in government as frightened little men who would bring chaos, violence and disunity in the country. And we all cried sour grapes, yet it is now clear that not even KK's knowledge and caution to us about the Frankenstein Monsters the people liberated KK's captivity prepared for the chaos and violence that has been unleashed against the country by the MMD government, parliament, police force (Francis Ndhlovu), drug traffickers, thieves and the bastard Christianity which has brought drought and out of season rains as punishment for the desecration of a God whose one description is Holy.

Zambia has been reduced to a Sodom and Gomorrah where drug traffickers stand on the hallowed steps of the Supreme Court (repeat Supreme Court) and demand of the heroes in DEC that are fighting a relentless war against the sin that is drug trafficking that they should leave them alone to continue destroying lives, perpetrate murder and use their blood money to rule over.

First and foremost, I would like to apologise to the DEC that as a citizen of this country and a voter I have allowed a situation of total and complete anarchy in which an individual like Sikota alias Saddam Hussein Wina and his spouse properly arraigned on drug trafficking charges can threaten and ridicule a people's institution responsible for the social, political and economic well being of the nation at will and continue to masquerade as leaders. Secondly, I would like to disassociate myself from a belief that citizens deserve their leaders. I do not deserve the Winas and I do not recognise their leadership and therefore Quett Masire, Nelson Mandela and indeed Mungole and his boys should not hold me accountable for the actions and utterances of these representatives of a corrupt and unjust party in government.

The choice of the Supreme Court steps as the venue of an address to the nation warning the DEC to allow the trade in drugs to be conducted in peace also signified the surbodination of the judiciary to a parliament and executive dominated by drug barons, thieves, racists etc.

That is why Wina accused the DEC of having a political agenda thereby paraphrasing a provision from the MMD Constitution which provides for the dismissal of judges who who may be courageous enough to find against the Winas of the consequences. Wina's performance at the steps of the Supreme Court defined in stark and naked terms the nature and purpose of the devil's covenant that has just been enacted as the Republican Constitution. It is a document intended to entrench and protect criminality of the worst order in the MMD bastard Christian nation.

I am sure that the Wina-type of press conference is not the last; it is merely the first in a long and macabre parade of MMD leaders who would have defrauded the Bank of Zambia out of millions of kwacha, beaten up women, murdered ordinary people in cold blood, consigned an entire nation team to the ocean, committed genocide of the youth through drug trafficking and so on ad infinitum at which they will stand outside the Supreme Court telling the people of Zambia, bereaved families, children, men and women whose lives have been destroyed by drugs, the judiciary, the DEC, men of integrity in the police and ACC, that there is nothing we can do about it; the blood shedding, the robberies from the public treasury, the drug traffickers are all protected by the Constitution enacted for we the murderers and robbers in MMD for our protection and continuity and against the people.

Consequently and in conclusion I would like to give notice that I am not bound and I will not consider myself bound by the Wina Constitution (The MMD has merely reproduced Wina's submission to the Constitutional Review Commission- it should be called the Wina document).

To this effect, I intend to take measures within my capacity as a woman, mother and human being to protect myself and my basic fundamental and inalienable God-given rights from a law made in Sodom and Gomorrah. The Bible says that if only there had been ten or five resistance fighters like myself Sodom and Gomorrah would not have been buried under volcanic lava.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Kaunda Drives Through Lusaka In Spite of Police


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 29, 1996 by Masautso Phiri


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Lusaka - Police yesterday failed to prevent UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda from driving through the town centre soon after his arrival from Canada.

Police, who stationed officers at various points along the route from Lusaka International Airport, were unable to stop the more than two kilometre long UNIP motorcade.

According to UNIP's Peter Lishika, both Inspector General of Police Francis Ndhlovu and commanding officer for Lusaka division Wynter Kabwiku emphasised that former president Kaunda should not be allowed to drive into the city centre on his arrival. 

"The two officers were emphatic that Kaunda should not drive into the city. Ndhlovu even suggested that Kaunda visits the city three days after his arrival," Lishika disclosed in an interview last night.

Former president Kaunda drove into the city's Freedom Way, Cairo Road and Church Road amid chants from his supporters of "No Kaunda, No Election" which overshadowed the ruling party's own march to State House to witness President Chiluba's signing of the Constitution (Amendment) Bill.

"An attempt to stop us was made at Lusaka Central Police Station. I saved the police from action which would have brought shame to this nation," former president Kaunda said in an interview at his Kalundu home. "I told the people that time for action will come and when I tell them to act, they should act."

The UNIP president, who claimed his party was in a stronger position, told chanting supporters, who gathered at the party's Freedom House headquarters that nothing would stop him from standing as UNIP's presidential candidate in this year's election.

"There is no question of anybody stopping me from standing unless he can exhume my parent's bones or my umbilical cord from where they were buried," president Kaunda challenged.

Earlier Kaunda told hundreds of supporters who gathered at the airport to meet him that President Chiluba's constitution had introduced a new apartheid in this country.

"It's apartheid being introduced by thieves. We fought it in colonial times and won. We are going to win this one too," Kaunda declared. "This is a second liberation and we are in a happy and stronger position. They have no hope at all."

And alluding to the signing ceremony of the Constitution (Amendment) Bill, Kaunda, who was not referring to the same time frame, said: "In 1953 whites celebrated after federation was created but ten years later the people won. We will first fight in courts. I don't think the courts will fail."


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Chiluba's Constitution Criticised


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 29, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba and Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition parties and civic organisations yesterday criticised President Chiluba for assenting to the Constitution of Zambia (Amendment) Bill.

The Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace (CCPJ), which had campaigned heavily for a constituent assembly mode of adoption of the constitution, called Chiluba's assenting "a narrow victory".

"The lack of euphoria and joy by the majority of Zambians is indicative that this victory has been won at great cost by the MMD," CCPJ chairman Father Joe Komakoma said in an interview yesterday. 

Father Komakoma added that there was need for the MMD to discuss with various interested groups to arrive at a consensus.

"It is never too late, let us sit down and consider this as a nation," he advised.

Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) president Dean Mung'omba said President Chiluba's action was expected.

"He means no good, he wishes to stretch society to the limit," Mung'omba said. "It is a selfish way to govern, it is very sad."

Mung'omba said President Chiluba's only intention in the constitution was to bar some people from contesting the elections.

Liberal Progressive Front chairman Roger Chongwe said political parties had done their best to conscientise the public about the dangers but its was now up to the public.

"If people are happy with Chiluba's law then so be it, we have done our work for the country," he said. "It is up to the people to accept this discriminatory constitution or tell him they don't want it."

National Party general secretary Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika said the assenting of the Bill is a betrayal of the original cause of the MMD.

"The signing of the bill signifies his own failure to democratise. He has failed to rise up to the required level of statesmanship," Lewanika charged in an interview yesterday, adding: "This is indicated by the fact that the whole signing process was turned into a petty party affair."

Lewanika also attacked President Chiluba for what he termed "addressing an illegal procession at State House".

"Chiluba is being hypocritical by saying he is law abiding when he was presiding over a march which took place without 14 days notice to the police," Lewanika said. " He showed the way of breaking law and destroyed his credibility to hold somebody else to the standard of being law abiding."


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

111 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


LANDMARK CONSTITUTIONAL BILL SIGNED AS LAW Zambia


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency (Lusaka) May 28, 1996 by Lewis Mwanangombe


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

Lusaka - The Constitutional Amendment Bill, which passed through the three customary stages of Parliament last week, was today signed by President Frederick Chiluba into law at a colourful function held at State House.

Mr Chiluba appended his signature to the new law at 13:05 hours (11:05 hours GMT) amidst waves of whistling, ululations and rolls of drumming from thousands of ecstatic Movement for Multi-Party Democracy party supporters who turned up for the occassion clad in campaign t-shirts and body wrappers.

The signing of the new law came four hours after the Supreme Court of Zambia threw out the Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) application for a grant of stay, to refrain President Chiluba from endorsing the Constitutional Amendment Bill - with no costs.

Making a ruling, Chief Justice Mathew Ngulube sitting with Justice Bonaventure Bweupe, Justice Matthew Chaila, Justice Denis Chirwa, and Justice Westone Muzyamba reaffimed the high courts refusal to grant ZDC a stay in April. 

He said the case had very little legal facts thereby making it difficult for the appellants to argue substantially.

The Chief Justice said the Supreme Court had no choice but to reaffirm the decision of the High Court and the bench consequently referred the matter back to the subordinate court.

Chief Justice Ngulube also noted that it was not impossible for Parliament to have used Article 79 to amend the Republican Constitution as the appellants put it, but that the case required more time to prepare a detailed judgement.

And speaking after the judgement was delivered ZDC President Dean Mung'omba told his supporters that the ruling was 'shameful'.

He said the people of Zambia have been denied justice by the highest court in the land.

He assured his supporters that the fight was still on despite the outcome of the ruling.

ZDC last week appealed to the Supreme Court against the High Court's refusal to grant them a stay.

At the same time as the Supreme Court was delivering its judgement against the ZDC, hundreds of MMD supporters begun gathering for a grand six kilometre march from the Freedom Statue in down-town Lusaka to State House.

The thousands of singing, whistling and banner waving supporters brought traffic to a halt as they wound their way uphill from the assembly point to the seat of government.

As the hour struck 13:00 (11:00 hours GMT) motorists supporting the government on the Constitution let loose a cacophony of hooting, whistling and ululations, not only in Lusaka, but spontaenously in all other major centres of the country.

These were supporters of a movement which was urging citizens throughout Zambia to ''honk for Zambia - Zambia for Zambians''. Where there was no car horn supporters were being urged to beat drums, whistle or bang any object that would yield maximum noise.

At State House, where the President was signing the bill, a mighty and deafening roar went up at 13:00 hours as Mr Chiluba emerged from State House and walked majestically to where the instruments to be signed were waiting for his attention.

As the President appended his signature to the Bill, bringing all speculation which had surrounded the exercise to an end, an even greater sound errupted from the assembly which took a great effort to control.

Speaking afterwards President Chiluba reiterated his earlier contention that the new law was not aimed at any Zambian in particular.

''This Constitution, as amended is not aimed at protecting or including one person or excluding anyone individual person. Some of our people have the impression that this was intended to exclude Dr Kaunda - far from it,'' Mr Chiluba said.

He observed that even the composition of the Mwanakatwe Constitutional Review Commission had favoured members of opposition parties in that it was broad based.

He noted that Non-Governmental Organisations had been represented in full force together with Chiefs, representatives of the Church and professional organisations like Law Association of Zambia and Press Association of Zambia in addition to members from opposition parties and the ruling party.

''The idea was to dispel any fears that anybody might have that in fact we are going to doctor, change or alter anything from the recommendations of the Review Commission. This composition shows that we have no desire to doctor it,'' Mr Chiluba said adding that nobody should, therefore, turn round and accuse government of tampering with the submissions.

He described the collated data, opinions and wishes of the people as submitted to the Review Commission as 'a plebiscite' adding that the point of restricting the presidency to an indegenous person was not new as it had been submitted even to the Mainza Chona Commission of 1972. The submission even then was that for anybody to aspire to the position of President, he or she must be an indegenous person whose parents are Zambians.

But the government of the day ignored this submission totally and the question then was not about the mode of adoption but this submission itself. ''Because of propensity for power UNIP ingnored it,'' Mr Chiluba observed adding that it had also ignored a submission that the President should only serve for two terms after which ''he should go farming, lecturing, or sit down tired'' - which would have brought the politics of Zambia in line with those of Europe.

''There is no one individual who can outlive their own generation. You will be relevant for a particular time and after that ideas will look quite strange to you,'' he said amid much cheering and laughter from the audience.

Mr Chiluba recalled that between 1964 and 1991 Americans had changed Presidents five times, the British - about four times, while the Germans, and the Italians ''more than 20 times'' while Zambians had 'remained stuck with one leader.'

''There is nothing wrong with the leader continuing if there is a democratic process. But Zambia is not all together a parliamentary or presidential system but a corruption of both,'' he added.

Mr Chiluba noted that though some people were complaining of having their rights infringed in fact they were forgeting that their rights even in Europe would not be recognised.

Turning to the opposition United National Independence Party, Mr Chiluba recalled how he had wanted to help make provision for former President Kenneth Kaunda stand 'for the last time in coming elections' but that his plans had been frustrated by the very people whom he had wanted to help - UNIP.

He explained that at Committee stage he had arranged with the Ministry of Legal Affairs to include a 'proviso' which would have enabled Dr Kaunda to stand on the post of President, 'for we know he has no support' but at the last minute this plan had been frustrated by UNIP who staged a walk out after earlier endorsing a submission from nominated Member of Parliament Vincent Malambo which entailed that only a person who had not served two terms could stand on the position of President could aspire to become President of the Republic again.

Mr Chiluba pointed out that he was not driven any other consideration but to fulfill the wishes of Zambians in signing the new bill.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Zambian Mine Sale Plan Is Out


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 29, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Lusaka - The government has finally confirmed the privatisation of Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) giving details of how it will be carried out. Finance minister Ronald Penza promised donors at the Consultative Meeting in Bournemouth last January that the government would quickly privatise the conglomerate in line with country's cooperating partners' demands for transparency and good governance.

Speaking at a press conference at the Ministry of Finance yesterday, Penza announced that cabinet has accepted the recommendations of the Rothschilds Report on the privatisation of ZCCM. 

The privatisation will be conducted in two stages with the first being the unbundling of ZCCM's major interests into four packages. The second will be the sale of shares in the remaining entities of ZCCM to the public and other international investors.

By mid-1997, the government hopes to have concluded negotiations of the first stage. The four packages are:

- the Konkola Deep Mine and Concentrator together with the Mufulira Mine, Concentrator and smelter and refinery;

- the Nchanga mines, tailings leach plant and concentrator together with the Nkana mines, concentrator, smelter and cobalt plant;

- the Baluba and Luanshya mines and concentrator, the decommissioned Luanshya smelter and Ndola refinery and the Chambishi cobalt plant; and

- ZCCM's electricity transmission, distribution and generation assets which have been owned and operated by ZCCM over the years.

The first package comprising the Konkola Deep Mine has been the subject of negotiations between ZCCM and the government on the one hand, and also of negotiations between the consortium led by Anglo American Corporation and the government over the past two years.

Penza confirmed that talks with Anglo American are leading to an agreement for the transfer of majority interest in Konkola Deep to the Consortium. The Consortium is in turn to commit itself to finance the development of the Konkola Deep Mining Project.

In the second stage of the privatisation, ZCCM is to remain a single holding company with minority shares in the packaged interests. However, even these minority shares may be all be off-loaded onto the market by 1998 for the public and any other interested investors.

The packages will be negotiated by the Zambia Privatisation Agency.

ZCCM's other assets including schools, hospitals, and non-mining subsidiaries have all been recommended for private ownership.

And on the resolution of ZCCM's formidable debt burden, Penza revealed that the debt stock would be covered in the negotiation over the packages.

"Where, for example, government was supposed to own 80 per cent, it might only remain with 20 per cent," he said.

He also confirmed that by 1997, ZCCM would have finished with its retrenchment exercise. "We will not leave the trimming of the workforce to the new owners," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia Team Gets Additions For Qualifier


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 29, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - Professional players Elijah Litana and Joe Bwalya have been included in the Zambia national soccer team that leaves for a World Cup qualifier against Sudan today.

Trainer Rolad Pouslen, has picked an 18-man final team that includes premier side new comers Rumlex's centre forward, Cosmas Banda and Hector Chilombo as the only two new faces that were not in the Zambian side that clinched a bronze-medal finish at the Africa Cup of nations that were held in South Africa.

"I expect Joe Bwalya to join the team in Sudan, I talked to him recently and he promised he is coming for the match. But for Litana, though I haven't talked to him, FAZ officials have promised that he is also coming," said Poulsen in an interview yesterday at the BP sports complex where he was having a final work-out. 

Also in the team are goalkeepers James Phiri, Davies Phiri, defenders Hillary Makasa, Jones Mwewa, Harrison Chongo, Mordon Malitoli, while Alex Namazaba, John Lungu, Vincent Mutale, Kenneth Malitoli, Aggrey Chiyangi are the midfielders.

The team's attacking system will be centred on Dennis Lota, Mwape Miti and Andrew Tembo.

And Poulsen, who disclosed that he had decided to put Shy Kumwenda, Edward Kangwa and Limbi Mbewe on stand-by, announced that he will only travel to Sudan with Ashios Melu as his assistant while the two other assistants, Fighton Simukonda and Patrick Phiri will join the team when it returns because of the limited number FAZ has asked the coaching staff to provide for the trip.

Meanwhile, Lota said he feels Sudan could prove tough to Zambia's quest for a smooth passage to the 1998 World Cup finals slated for France.

"They haven't lost at home and that is an indication that they are a tough team," warned the player in an interview yesterday at the Intercontinental hotel.

During the run up to the SA '96, Sudan, who were placed in Group Four, held Egypt 0-0, Algeria 0-0, beat Uganda 3-1 and went on to record another 2-1 win over Tanzania, but it was only in the away matches that they lost out.

But Lota was confident that Zambia would still play a tough match against Sudan.

"The major advantage we have is that we have played together for some time and with all the preparations we have had we will surely give them a good game. The game will be tough but we will try to at least manage a draw," Lota said.

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Trade Union Congress Warns of Strikes


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 29, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - The imposition of a wage freeze by the government will attract industrial unrest, the Zambia Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU) warned in Lusaka yesterday.

Issuing the warning in an interview yesterday, ZCTU vice-president Austin Liato wondered why "it was only the workers who were made to sacrifice during the restructuring of the economy", when emoluments of members of parliament and other politicians were last week increased without even debate. 

"As far as we are concerned at the ZCTU, enough is enough," Liato carped. "Workers are already receiving meagre salaries and we feel we have sacrificed too much."

Liato added: " If anything it is the worker who is sacrificed in this restructuring of the economy."

Liato was reacting to a government circular issued by Secretary to the Cabinet Aldridge Adamson, dated April 17 this year, stating that all grant aided institutions should be informed that there would be no salary and wage increments funded by the government this year.

But Liato said the action was tantamount to "slavery" by the government on an already over taxed worker due to government's failure to broaden the tax base.

"We are not going to sit back and watch the government encourage slavery," Liato warned. "If the government does not rescind its decision then there will be industrial unrest in this country."

Liato wondered why the government was dictating on industrial terms when the rest of the economy was liberalised.

" It's a contradiction by the government. It's surprising because the government on one hand has liberalised the economy," Liato said. " The labour movement should also be allowed to bargain but in this case we were not even consulted before the decision was arrived at."

May, 1996


United States and Africa Aid Proposals Favor Ethiopia and South Africa


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 29, 1996


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Washington, DC - The Clinton administration's proposals for bilateral aid to Africa in fiscal year 1997 allocate 20 percent of all funds to just two countries -- Ethiopia and South Africa.

Although a House Appropriations Committee subcommittee has already prepared revisions that likely will change these figures substantially, the Clinton administration's draft proposals for Africa aid in fiscal year 1997, which begins this October, provides some guidelines to U.S. policy priorities in Africa. 

The U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) Congressional Presentation for Fiscal Year 1997 requests a total of $975.9 million for Africa. This total includes $704 million allocated to development projects through the Development Fund for Africa, $20 million in Economic Support Funds for demining activities (primarily in Angola), and $252 million in food aid.

The following figures for each country include all categories of direct USAID to Africa.

(figures in 000s)

Angola 44,473

Benin 17,453

Burundi 2,500*

Eritrea 18,700

Ethiopia 100,758

Gambia 500

Ghana 49,739

Guinea 15,024

Guinea-Bissau 5,934

Kenya 25,228

Liberia 51,996

Madagascar 20,624

Malawi 35,000

Mali 32,750

Mauritania 753

Mozambique 46,000

Namibia 8,500

Niger 8,000

Nigeria 7,500

Rwanda 58,290

Senegal 23,500

Sierre Leone 10,852

Somalia 6,206

South Africa 100,000

Sudan 10,053

Tanzania 21,000

Uganda 46,387

Zambia 18,600

Zimbabwe 19,200

Regional Programs 170,350

Total 975,870

(DFA 704,000)

(Food Aid 251,870)

(ESF 20,000)

source: USAID Congressional Presentation FY 1997

*Burundi humanitarian assistance included in Rwanda total

May, 1996


Nigeria UNSG Outlines Nigeria's Reaction to Fact Finding


BYLINE: United Nations May 24, 1996


LENGTH: 680 words


 
United Nations - Sylvana Foa, spokesman for the secretary-general,
told correspondents at today's noon briefing that the secretary-general
had sent to the President of the General Assembly and to the secretaryNigeria as well as the interim response from that Government.
general of the Commonwealth, the report of the fact-finding mission to

The secretary-general was encouraged by both the cooperation that his
special envoy, Lahkdar Brahimi, had received from the Nigerian
Government as well as by its interim response. The secretary-general
believed the response provided him with a good basis to pursue his good
offices as requested by General Assembly resolution of 11 March. 

This morning, she continued, the secretary-general had spoken with
South African President Nelson Mandela and had told him about the
progress made in regards to Nigeria's fact-finding mission report. He
had also told President Mandela about efforts made to resolve the
problems in the Bakassi Peninsula. The secretary-general had also spoken
with the President of Cameroon, Paul Biya, regarding the Nigerian
willingness to discuss the situation in the Bakassi Peninsula.

In its interim response to the recommendations to the fact-finding
report, the Government of Nigeria had made five points, Ms. Foa said.
The first was that the Civil Disturbances Act -- under which Ken Saroamendments.
Wiwa and eight others were tried and convicted -- would have two

The first amendment would exclude members of the armed forces from
serving on the Special Civil Disturbances Tribunal. The second said its
verdicts and sentences must be subject to judicial review, at the
appellate level, before confirmation.

The second point made by the Nigerian Government stated that the Oil
and Mineral Producing Areas Development Commission would be directed to
look into whether there were peculiar ecological and environmental
problems in the Ogoni area, Ms. Foa said. "The Federal Government will,
with vigour, join the concerted efforts currently being undertaken to
reconcile all parties in the Ogoni region."

The third point said the head of state had directed the immediate
review of the cases of all persons currently being detained without
trial under decree No. 2 of 1984, as amended, Ms. Foa said. Very shortly
such persons would be released based on an assessment of the individual
merit of each case. Point number four made by the Nigerian Government
was that decree No. 2 of 1984 would be amended to allow for the periodic
review of each case by a body comprising the Chief of General Staff, the
Inspector General of Police and the Attorney General of the Federation
at an interval of three months. That decree presently permitted the
detention of persons, suspected of engaging in acts prejudicial to State
security, without trial and for an indefinite period.

Finally, the interim response stated that the 1994 decree which
ousted the jurisdiction of courts to issue a writ of habeas corpus to
persons detained under decree No. 2 of 1984, would be repealed, Ms. Foa
said. The Nigerian Government had also told the secretary-general that
other aspects of the report were currently under serious consideration.
The secretary-general would be closely following the implementation of
the undertakings in the interim response, she added.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


117 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Rwanda Rwanda Calls for Immediate Response to Deaths


BYLINE: United Nations May 24, 1996


LENGTH: 1107 words


 
United Nations - At a press conference at Headquarters this morning,
Manzi Bakuramutsa, Permanent Representative of Rwanda, told
correspondents that his country was calling for an emergency meeting of
the Security Council to take immediate action to prevent genocide in
eastern Zaire, where at least 3,000 Tutsis of Rwandan origin were
surrounded by the same extremist forces that had massacred 1 million
Tutsis and moderate Hutus in Rwanda two years ago.

Mr. Bakuramutsa emphasized that despite strong pleas by the
International Committee of the Red Cross, Medecins sans Frontieres and
other groups, the United Nations and the international community had not
taken corrective action to halt the bloodshed. Medecins sans Frontieres,
an international humanitarian organization, had warned that unless
urgent action was taken at least 3,000 Tutsi families were likely to be
massacred by armed extremists. On 12 May, approximately 100 Tutsis
living in Zaire were slaughtered in an attack on a Trappist monastery in
Mokoto. More than 65,000 had fled their homes in Zaire's Masisi region
since April to escape ethnic violence. The conflict in Masisi had
displaced approximately 250,000 since late last year. 

He went on to say that the extremists were the same military forces
of the former Rwandan government who had fled to Zaire in 1994 and now
operated there with impunity. He said they were receiving support from
soldiers of Zaire and thus from the Government of Zaire. Three countries
-- the United States, Belgium and France -- had supposedly agreed to
pressure President Mobutu of Zaire, but the "troika" was no longer
performing its task. He pointed out that while President Mobutu had been
denied a visa to visit the Carter Center in Atlanta, Georgia, United
States, he had been given a visa to enter France. France was obviously
giving support to the President of Zaire.

The United Nations could have taken action, he continued, but the
Security Council did not seem to know what was going on in Zaire. That
indicated a negligence on the part of the United Nations regarding
Rwanda. There seemed to be a double standard at work in the United
Nations when it came to dealing with problems of some small countries.
Many of the things the United Nations wanted to do in Rwanda ran counter
to the needs and wishes of its Government. Whatever solution the United
Nations had brought to the problems in Rwanda seemed to be the
inappropriate one.

He cited the example of the "famous office" that the United Nations
wanted to establish in Kigali. The purpose of the office was not clear.
Rwanda had no problem with the establishment of the office and was quite
willing to accept it, but the United Nations kept talking about it and
could not decide what the office would do. Instead of dealing with a
situation where people were dying, the United Nations seemed more
interested in such things as the disposal of "unserviceable equipment".

The United Nations was incapable of dealing with the group that was
infiltrating into Burundi, Rwanda and now Uganda, he said. Rwanda had
advised the United Nations for a long time on what action could be
taken, but the United Nations did not listen. The Organization claimed
to be consulting with the Rwandan Government, but it ignored what the
Government proposed. Rwanda wanted help in addressing the situation in
Zaire, before it was too late and the people were exterminated. The
problems of the region had been addressed in pieces and not in a
holistic manner.

To a question about the overall picture in the region, the Ambassador
stressed that the culture of impunity was the greatest problem facing
the region. People who had committed genocide were not punished. Such
impunity encouraged those same people to continue their killing, to
continue to attack Rwanda. It sent a message to the people in Burundi to
do the same.

When asked what Rwanda expected from the Council and from the
Organization as a whole, he replied that the Council should condemn the
situation and take action. He had written a formal letter to the Council
President requesting that action be taken and had spoken with a
representative of the Non-Aligned caucus in the Council. He noted the
action that the Council had taken in Sudan over just two people who had
been accused of criminal activity. Why couldn't they take as much action
in the situation in Zaire where there were many more criminals?

The five permanent members of the Council were aware of the
situation. However, while the people who were responsible for the
killing in Rwanda were moving with impunity throughout the world, some
members of the Council appeared to be protecting them. Although the
United Nations always seemed to do things that harmed rather than helped
Rwanda, such as the arms embargo or the continuation of United Nations
Assistance Mission for Rwanda, he wanted the Organization to face its
responsibilities.

What was the Government of Rwanda prepared to do to protect the
people in Zaire? a correspondent asked. Mr. Bakuramutsa replied that the
Government was not weak and would take action if necessary. Rwanda,
however, respected international law. The Government would not allow the
continued killing of its citizens and of those people who identified
themselves with Rwanda. It could take action to defend its people in the
same way that France defended its own language.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
