Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Growth Rate Rises for Africa's Economies


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 1440 words


 

United Nations - Following is a statement issued by the United
Nations Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) on May 23:

The African economy experienced its highest annual growth rate since
the beginning of the decade in 1995, with the overall gross domestic
product (GDP) climbing by 2.3 per cent during the year compared to 2.1
per cent in 1994 and 0.7 per cent in 1993, according to the "Report on
the Economic and Social Situation in Africa, 1996" issued by the
Economic Commission for Africa (ECA).

"This is a further positive confirmation of the recovery that has
taken place in Africa in recent years," said the report, which was
released earlier this month. Only three African countries experienced
negative growth in 1995 compared to 14 the previous year; eight
countries recorded 6 per cent growth compared to two in 1994.

The improving economic situation also bodes well for the
implementation of the unprecedented United Nations System-Wide
Initiative on Africa, a 10- year, $25 billion endeavour aimed at
ensuring basic education, improved health services delivery and food
security on the continent, among other objectives. The Initiative, which
was the result of a consensus between African governments and their
development partners on how to meet the continent's major challenges,
was launched in March by Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and
United Nations agency heads. 

Another indication of the positive economic upturn was that the
region's 33 least developed countries also recorded a positive economic
performance for the first time since 1992, with total GDP increasing to
2.4 per cent in 1995 compared to -2.4 per cent and -1.6 per cent in 1993
and 1994, the report said.

Although these average growth rates for the continent mask variations
in country and sub-regional performances, the report noted that for the
first time since the 1970s numerous national economies are now growing
faster than their populations. This is "a welcome sign that overall
growth trends in Africa are beginning to gather momentum towards the
recovery evident in the global economy", the report said. Nineteen
countries (five in southern Africa and eight in eastern Africa)
experienced GDP growth in excess of Africa's current 2.9 per cent
population growth rate.

But even with the recovery in GDP growth rates, the continent's share
of aggregate world trade and output remains far below its percentage of
world population. Africa's share in world trade has fallen steadily over
the years, from 5 per cent in 1980 to 3.1 per cent in 1990, to 2.3 per
cent in 1995, and 2.2 per cent in 1995. The decline of Africa's
percentage in the trade of developing countries as a whole has been even
more dramatic: from 14.9 per cent in 1980, to 10.9 per cent in 1990, and
6.4 per cent in 1995. Compared with the 1980s, Africa's GDP in the 1990s
has accounted for less and less of the global GDP.

In addition, Africa's share of the world's population is on the
increase: it reached an estimated 12 per cent in 1995. Therefore, the
continent's overall GDP growth rate has yet to keep pace with its
population growth rate. Given a population growth rate of 2.3 per cent
in 1995, average per capita income actually declined 0.6 per cent for
the region as a whole.

The report noted that in addition to the problem of a rapidly growing
population, many of the factors responsible for the weak economic
performance in Africa over the years are still present. Nevertheless,
the prospects of the continent emerging from these problems and
challenges are better than ever.

"Africa is no longer an undifferentiated mass of poorly performing
economies", the report said. "Differences among individual African
countries and groups of countries with the potential for rapid growth
and socio-economic transformation have persisted, but current
indications are that the capacity of African societies and economies for
real and sustained growth are being increasingly realized."

The eight countries with the most impressive GDP growth rates in 1995
were Burkina Faso (6 per cent), Cote d'Ivoire (6.6 per cent), Ghana (6.9
per cent), Kenya (6.1 per cent), Malawi (6.2 per cent), Mali (6 per
cent), Togo (6.7 per cent) and Tunisia (6.7 per cent), the report said.
The recovery in GDP growth was related mainly to a strong performance by
the manufacturing sector and a modest rebound by the mining sector, the
report said.

The manufacturing sector recorded a positive growth rate of 4.2 per
cent in value added in 1995, mainly because of the availability of
better input supplies and improvements in the importation of raw
materials for agro-allied industries. Capacity utilization, encouraged
by remedial policy measures such as the rationalization of industries
under structural adjustment programmes, was a main contributor to the
positive growth, the report said.

Extensive reforms in the mining sector over recent years have lead to
increased exploration and mining investment in several countries, the
report noted. But the overall improvements in the mining sector were
related to an almost 20 per cent increase in mineral and metal ore
prices and a 7.9 per cent increase in the oil sector. Copper prices were
27.3 per cent higher in 1995 than in 1994, while prices of other
minerals and metal ores also increased: of nickel (30 per cent),
aluminum (22.3 per cent), cobalt (19.9 per cent), lead (14.6 per cent)
and iron ore (6 per cent).

Growth in the agricultural sector -- the traditional mainstay of most
African economies -- was lacklustre. According to the Food and
Agriculture Organization (FAO), the incidence of drought in the third
quarter of 1994 and the first quarter of 1995 precipitated famine
conditions that affected some 10 countries in the northern, eastern and
southern subregions.

Overall, agricultural output in the region stagnated. There was a
drastic reduction in per capita agricultural output in some subregions,
with the growth rate decreasing from 4.2 per cent in 1994 to 1.5 per
cent in 1995. The loss was more pronounced in the northern, southern and
eastern subregions than elsewhere. The southern sub-region registered a
negative 7 per cent growth rate for 1995, while the eastern subregion
recorded a negative 3 per cent. West Africa performed better, but its
agricultural growth rate still fell from 5.8 per cent in 1994 to 4.2 per
cent in 1995.

Africa's external trade benefitted from price increases for primary
commodities, which according to ECA provisional estimates boosted export
earnings by 1.1 per cent in 1995 compared to a 4.9 per cent increase in
1994.

For further information, please contact: Africa Recovery, Room S-931,
United Nations Headquarters, New York (tel. 212-963-6857) or Information
Service, ECA, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia (tel. 251-1-510-172).


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


119 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Truth Commission Seeks Clarification of Accused Rights


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Cape Town - Following is a news release from the Truth And
Reconciliation Commission dated May 24:

The Human Rights Violations Committee of the Truth and Reconciliation
Commission will seek to clarify the rights of alleged perpetrators of
human rights violations after two divisions of the Supreme Court
expressed conflicting opinions on the issue.

A meeting of the committee, held in Johannesburg today, resolved to
take legal steps to resolve differences over how much notice alleged
perpetrators have to be given if victims want to name them at commission
hearings. 

Pending clarification being obtained, the committee adopted
procedures aimed at giving persons proper, reasonable and timeous notice
of hearings if evidence detrimentally implicating them is heard.

The Cape Supreme Court last month ordered the commission to give
"proper, reasonable and timeous notice". However, in a judgment on
another matter in Port Elizabeth this week, the South Eastern Cape
Division of the Supreme Court disagreed with the Cape Town judgment. Mr
Acting Justice R G Buchanan said he did not believe prior notice need be
given to someone detrimentally implicated.

The Human Rights Violations Committee also took note of today's order
from the Cape Supreme Court requiring that it should give two retired
police officers at least 30 days' notice of a hearing at which they
would be named. The committee will abide by the ruling. It will,
however, oppose the confirmation of the order when the court hears full
argument on the matter on June 13. It will also contest the allegation
that it acted in contempt of last month's court order.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


120 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa Clinton Reports to Congress on CAR Mobilization


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is the text of a letter dated May 23 from
President Clinton to the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the
President Pro Tempore of the Senate concerning deployment of Marines to
the Central African Republic:

On May 19, 1996, heavy fighting broke out between government forces
and mutinous troops in the capital city of Bangui, Central African
Republic. Early reports suggested that some 200-500 renegade soldiers
were firing weapons, including rockets and artillery, and that they had
called for troops from outside the capital to join them in the mutiny.
During the fighting, prison guards reportedly abandoned their posts and
prisoners were observed loitering around the prison. Although neither
the American Embassy nor American citizens have been directly targeted,
heavy fighting has been reported around the American Embassy, which has
sustained some damage from stray rounds. At one point, government
forces indicated an intention to assault a rebel stronghold very near
the Embassy, but were dissuaded by the Ambassador. 

On May 20, due to the rapidly deteriorating security situation and
the resultant threat to American citizens and the Embassy, I ordered
the deployment of U.S. military personnel to provide enhanced security
for the American Embassy in Bangui and to conduct the evacuation from
the Central African Republic of private U.S. citizens and certain U.S.
Government employees. Approximately 32 U.S. Marines entered the capital
city in the early morning hours on May 21 and immediately took up
positions in and around the American Embassy compound. They also
deployed to the international airport in order to assist in processing
evacuees and act as liaison with French military forces already
positioned there. Evacuation operations began later that day, involving
a U.S. KC-130 cargo aircraft operating into Yaounde, Cameroon. Further
evacuation flights are planned. Additional U.S. forces may also be
deployed in order to provide a means of safe passage for evacuees to the
airport and to provide additional security at the American Embassy if
required.

The Marines involved in this operation are from the Marine
Expeditionary Unit currently operating off Liberia. Although U.S.
forces are equipped and prepared to defend American lives and property,
I do not anticipate that they will become involved in hostilities. U.S.
forces will redeploy as soon as evacuation operations are complete and
enhanced security at the American Embassy is no longer required.

I have taken this action pursuant to my constitutional authority to
conduct the foreign relations of the United States and as Commander in
Chief and Chief Executive.

I am providing this report as part of my efforts to keep the Congress
fully informed, consistent with the War Powers Resolution. I appreciate
the support of the Congress in this action to protect American citizens
and the American Embassy in Bangui.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


121 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Kenya Media's Difficult Task In Peace Making


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996 by Wafula John


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

Nairobi - "Suddenly there were gun-shot sounds in the air, houses
blazed away madly, people screamed in pain, we too took off..." narrated
42-year- old Cleophas Budi to a hushed audience of media practitioners
and Non-Governmental Organisations' personnel.

Budi's trembling voice went on; "As I ran past Carol, my six-year old
daughter, it occurred to me that I should turn round and pick her..."
But he never picked Carol up and never saw her alive again.

Budi, who sustained a deep sword-cut that runs from his right eye
brow to the nape of his neck is also semi-paralysed on the left side of
his body. This makes him walk with a painful jerky ungainly gait. 

Cleophas Budi was narrating his experience through the infamous
ethnic violence that ravaged sections of Kenya during the run-up to the
first multi-party elections in 1992, and the period immediately after
the elections.

The ethnic clashes, largely blamed on the government in its attempt
to discredit multi-partism, were responsible for the death of over 1,500
people, the displacement of 56,000 others and the destruction of
property estimated at hundreds of millions of shillings; according to a
September 1992 parliamentary select committee report.

The May 17 to 20 meeting, financed by the Kenyan National Council of
Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) and coordinated by Peace-Net was
convened to discuss the Kenyan media coverage of conflicts. Peace-net is
a peace and development networking group of the National Council of NGOs
set up in September 1993 as a response to ethnic violence which rocked
parts of the country from October 1991.

Speaking at the Limuru workshop, some 30 kilometres west of Nairobi,
renowned journalist and lecturer in mass communication at Tangaza
College, Nairobi, Fr. Renato Kizito said, "it is tragic that violenceFr. Kizito noted that "not only are the media giving more room to
based journalism abounds."
violence, not only have they nourished the growing atmosphere of
violence in the world, they have also become more violent themselves."

Fr. Kizito called for united effort by socially-responsible
communicators to end stereotypes that often result in violence.

However, a section of the local press later absolved the local mass
media and their scribes from actions that promote violence in the
country. Writing in its May 20 editorial page, The Daily Nation, Kenya's
mass circulation daily commented;"... this concern about the violence
and rot in our society is justifiable, but blaming the media for it is
failing to see the underlying factors."

Many Kenyans affected by the bloody ethnic clashes which rocked parts
of the country believe that the government and its various
administrative organs deliberately orchestrated ethnic violence, fanned
it out and are now unwilling to decisively resettle displaced victims of
the violence. To date, most of the victims have not been resettled,
leave alone being compensated.

"The underlying factors" referred to by the Daily Nation's editorial
include what most groups working in the realm of peace and
reconciliation in the affected areas see as "political unwillingness" to
resolve what is now referred to as "the ethnic clash problem,"
conclusively raising fears of renewed ethnic bloodletting come next
general election scheduled for 1997.

In an earlier Peace-Net meeting of March 27 to 28 the Chief Executive
Officer of the NGO Council, Mr. Murtaza Jaffer, had warned; "Let us make
no mistakes about it, the level of violence ... political and otherwise
... appears to escalate as we approach the 1997 election year."

To date the government has not attempted to give a rational
explanation of the causes of the late 1991 to 1993 bloody ethnic
conflicts which initially seemed like simple land disputes between the
Kalenjin and the Kikuyu, Luo and Luhya ethnic groups living mainly in
the Rift Valley and Western Provinces of the country, preferring to
blame opposition parties for it.

Lamenting about this tendency, a participant in the seminar, Mr.
Wanyama Masinde, a journalist and editor of Clashes Update, a National
Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK) publication on local ethnic clashes,
opposed the "blaming of the ethnic clashes problem on the opposition
parties as it runs across the whole administrative structure." This
tendency, he added, will only worsen the situation rather than improve
on it.

But perhaps what heightens the fear of renewed ethnic violence most
is, according to one participant, "a feeling of being cheated, a feeling
of lack of justice by most victims who are still displaced and
traumatised."

"As we preach peace we should also preach justice. Most victims of
the ethnic bloodletting are still very traumatised and are asking
questions which someone must answer. The victims are asking, who is
going to give me my house? Who is going to give me my property? Who is
going to give me my children? Someone must answer these disturbing
questions. Someone must be responsible for these crimes. We cannot just
talk of peace and reconciliation without incorporating justice.

Perhaps Cleophas Budi's experience on that dreadful drizzly evening
at Kapsokwony, about 500 kilometres west of Nairobi (on the slopes of
Mount Elgon) best illustrates this view.

Budi explained that he regained consciousness several weeks later but
could not recognise the strange environment that was Kenyatta National
Hospital, Nairobi where he had been flown by "good samaritans." "I thank
God because I am one of the lucky ones. I never thought I could live
again. It was like resurrecting from the world of the dead."

During his two years of hospitalization, Budi underwent several
operations which included a replacement of part of his skull with an
artificial bone flap.

Today he has to live on drugs just so as to maintain his balance. He
has lost ability to work with his left hand and walks with difficulty.
"It is very very difficult for me," he told this writer.

But the shock that met him after leaving hospital made him shed
bitter tears of helplessness. "I cry a lot, especially at night," Mr.
Budi said. Carol, his three year old daughter had been stabbed to death
on the

day her father's skull was crushed. His nine acre piece of land had
been claimed by the "warriors," nine head of cattle shot to death and
his house and documents razed to ashes.

Nobody has been charged for the loss suffered by the Budis. Together
with his wife and two teenage daughters, Budi now lives in a dilapidated
grass shack in his original homeland.

Commenting on the dynamics of rebuilding peace, Ret. Major John Seii
told the seminar that "in the process of rebuilding peace, we discover
that there are unwilling partners. In peace building, there is nothing
known as the way," he said. We have to pool together ideas and use them
collectively in the process of peace searching, he added.

Such organs as the church, fora like workshops, intermarriages,
responsible community leaders and the mass media should be used to
foster peace and reconciliation, he suggested.

Observed one participant, "We are photocopying ideas which have
failed in Rwanda, Somalia and Bosnia. Some are practical locally. We
should also look for original conflict resolving practices from our own
cultures. There in lies a solution to some local conflicts.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


122 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Labour Conditions Unsafe For Women Entrepreneurs


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996 by Juliana Omale


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

Nairobi - Women working in the informal sector in Africa are
generally exposed to a "job environment" that denies them the
opportunity to lead more independent lives and raise their status. This
is compounded by their low access to credit, which stifles
entrepreneurship and productivity.

Kenyan women have a reputation for being a hardworking lot, but when
it comes to entrepreneurship, they face serious problems inhibiting
their entry and survival in small and medium enterprises.

Like millions of women throughout the developing world who support
themselves and their families through small manufacturing businesses and
petty trade activities, Roselyn Mungai's two year-old retail tyre
business in Nairobi still has its share of hiccups. 

Businesswomen face so many obstacles, it is a wonder that we manage
to exist at all," says the 38-year old single mother of two who gave up
a career as an accountant to concentrate on business."

According to the United Nations Development Fund for Women (UNIFEM),
almost all low-income women are economically active and women are major
contributors to the global economy and to the survival and well-being of
households, communities and national.

Yet they lack access to the economic means to increase the output of
their labour and to claim the benefits that result from it.

UNIFEM identifies credit, savings and other financial services as one
of the critical and most direct tools for putting resources into the
hands of rural and urban poor women producers.

Ms. Mungai did what many Kenyan women do. Rather than seek the
services of private money-lenders known as "shylocks" (whose interest
rates are exorbitant), she sought the support of friends and
acquaintances in a similar predicament and formed a welfare

group to raise funds and loan one another on a rotational basis to
support their businesses.

The group has since been able to access credit amounting to Kshs.1
million (about US dollars 17,860) since 1994 from the Kenya Women's
Finance Trust (KWFT), a Kenyan NGO that supports the economic
empowerment of women who are already in economically viable businesses.

According to KWFT's managing director, Dr. Jennifer Riria-Ouko, over
3,000 loans have been disbursed to women in economically viable
businesses since 1992.

"We target women in micro, small and medium enterprises, assisting
those who would otherwise have no access to credit, whereas banks tend
to look at entrepreneurs who will survive," she says.

Commercial lending institutions require that borrowers have a stable
source of income out of which the principal and interest on loans can be
paid according to the agreed terms. However, the incomes of many self"The formal financial system is difficult to penetrate," says Dr.
employed women tend to be precarious.
Riria-Ouko.

Another stumbling block for women entrepreneurs seeking credit from
commercial lending institutions is that lenders prefer dealing with
large loans in small numbers to minimise administration costs, whereas a
large number of small loans are needed to serve the poor.

Although the Trust's interest rates are at par with the current
market rates, clients have been able to sustain a 98 per cent repayment
rate on loans and to diversify their enterprises.

"This is proof that women are credit worthy," she says.

But despite the intervention of KWFT and agencies committed to the
economic empowerment of women, the barriers which make life next to
impossible for women struggling in the informal sector persist.

Ms. Mungai lists illiteracy and the yawning information gap as a
hindrance to the advancement of women in business.

"It is important to be informed. Kenyan women may be a hardworking
lot but they are not always well informed about what they are venturing
into," she says. Moreso at a time when the high levels of unemployment
and cut-backs in public sector employment leave women vulnerable to
retrenchment.

She adds that she is interested in venturing beyond the Kenyan border
into Uganda and Tanzania, but is intimidated by the bureaucracy
involved, the taxes and lack of adequate information on the import"Government customs officers need to set up a forum for dialogue with
export market.
businesswomen. We need education on conducting our businesses legally,
and more information on the line dividing a legitimate transfer of goods
across the border and smuggling."

According to a United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (ECA)
pocket reference publication, Gender in Africa - the Issues, the Facts,
improved access to credit for women results in multiple social benefits,
such as better educated children, poverty alleviation and increased
productivity.

Credit is also important to assist women take advantage of
opportunities for self employment because their informal sector
enterprises may develop to become part of the formal sector.

Globally, the number of rural women living in absolute poverty has
risen by 50 per cent and the feminisation of poverty is growing.

The situation is worsened by the globalisation of the economy,
compounding the effects of gender bias which in various forms prevents
women from obtaining the education, training and health services, child
care and legal status to escape their poverty.

UNIFEM prescribes access to and control over economic resources,
assets and opportunities so that women may benefit from them on a
sustainable and long-term basis.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


123 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Kenya Church Council Prepares Voters For Elections


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996 by James Macharia


LENGTH: 2040 words


 

Nairobi - Last February, the National Council of Churches of Kenya
(NCCK) announced that all its members should pursue non-partisan
politics as Kenyans prepare for the 1997 general elections.

The umbrella body, which leads more than 15 million Protestants,
representing over 70 per cent of Kenya's Christian population, aims to
reclaim the autonomy of the global church acting within its domain as a
social pacifist.

Formed originally as the Christian Council of Kenya in 1943, the NCCK
represents 47 member churches and 10 para-church organisations.
According to the chairman, Bishop Zablon Nthamburi, the umbrella council
of churches is the second largest church body of its kind in the world Among its goals stated in its mission statement, the NCCK aims to
and the largest in Africa.
"strive to be a model and living witness of Christian faith to member
churches and the society." 

Issuing the directive to be non-partisan during the NCCK Round Table
Conference held at the Limuru Conference and Training Centre in
February, Bishop Nthamburi said the church - a consistent if
controversial watchdog of the government even before the multi-party era
when it was christened the "unofficial opposition" and a voice of the
voiceless - has seen the light at the end of the murky political tunnel,
which can only be arrived at by, in his words; "the churches' obligation
to educate voters on their socio-political rights."

The council chairman describes the approach by the body as a "newcountry by disseminating civic, voter education as well as information
found prophetic role in a changing world. "It will play it out in the
on constitutional rights, freedoms and obligations of the individual and
to campaign for levelling of the landscape for all parties.

"We intend to build a viable society politically, economically and
socially by teaching the rights of a voter, human rights as well as
constitutional rights of a citizen and women rights. This is mainly in
preparation for the forthcoming election process but we will later focus
on land rights, poverty and the education system," said Nthamburi in a
recent interview with this writer. He notes that such rights must be
agitated for actively as "they will not be given on a silver platter by
President Daniel arap Moi's government."

Indeed this has become the council's new-found faith that Kenya's
political salvation lies in empowering voters and lobbying for
meaningful constitutional changes to create a level playing field for
all political parties. This reflection is well presented in a document
entitled, Kenya, Our Common Future: Constitutional and Electoral Reform,
which was first unveiled on May 4, 1995 at the Limuru Centre where
clergy, lawyers, diplomats and non-governmental organisations met at the
invitation of NCCK.

The NCCK Executive Committee has formally approved the document as a
blueprint to mark the boundaries of its political involvement. The
chairman who is also the presiding Bishop of the Methodist Church in
Kenya, says in a multi-party era, a church may have a leader and
congregation members who follow different parties, thus the need to
clearly distinguish the NCCK as non-partisan in intent and purpose so as
not to divide the flock. It is for this reason (church divisions) and
political disillusionment with the fragmented opposition parties that
the erstwhile oppositionist body now wants a hands-off approach to
politics.

It is only last year that the Rev. Sammy Chepkwony of the Eldoret
Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) Diocese, Rift Valley Province,
teamed up with Rev. John Wango of the Nambale diocese to form the rival
Regional Fellowship Churches of Kenya (RFCK), registered on July 28, for
reasons, among others, that "the NCCK has become too political." The
RFCK which touted itself on inception as non- partisan politically has a
membership of 40 churches, including three CPK dioceses.

On the issue of a disjointed opposition in Kenya, Nthamburi regrets
that politicians have failed to give the people an alternative agenda
and instead concentrated on jostling for leadership and fractious
wrangles. "The church is disappointed with the opposition's inability to
sell their agenda to the public as they are just engaged in squabbles
and shouting," he says.

Kenyans recall the clout that the NCCK wielded in its political
pronouncements and the respect with which the government handled its
criticism in the early 90s. It is this involvement that earned the
council the label and following of an unofficial opposition party and
one of its members, the more than two million strong (Anglican) Church
of the Province of Kenya (CPK), was tagged "Church of the Politics of
Kenya" by the ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) party.

Moses Shiribwa, a project assistant says the civic education
programme kicked off in 1991 to lead voters by equipping them to read
the various political party manifestos and interpret them. "However, the
electors were overtaken by the euphoria of the new multi-party system
and ended up voting on ethnic lines and personalities," he laments.

Since then, he says, the church has followed up with several training
seminars for trainers, who then train their various congregations
countrywide. So far, says Shiribwa, over 4,000 such trainers have
received civic training and based on the multiplier effect on their
congregations, it is estimated that more than 1 million church-goers are
receiving similar education, given that each trains about 300 members.

"It is only in hostile areas like Baringo or Elgeyo-Marakwet and the
so-called KANU zone in the Rift Valley Province that we are yet to
penetrate, not to mention arid areas like Garrisa and Isiolo in North
Eastern Province," he says. However, this impasse has been overcome by
transporting people from these areas to as far as Taita Taveta and
Wundanyi in the Coast Province, to train them in what have now become
known as inter-district seminars.

The training seminars are addressed by a cross section of experts
among them lawyers, political scientists, educationists, human rights
activists and NCCK's own line-up which includes such outspoken clergy as
Rev. Dr. Timothy Njoya of the Presbyterian Church of East Africa (PCEA)
and Rev. Japheth Gathaka, the former director of the council's Justice
and Peace Commission.

The lectures mainly address issues dealing with the rights of a
citizen and his/her role in a multi-party democracy. The church body has
also sponsored the production of several books on this subject to be
given free to learners. Some of the titles include Dr. Nick Wanjohi's
Multi-party electoral process in Kenya. His more recent, Challenge of
Democratic Governance, states in chapter 7; "The end of every multigreat challenge to all - Kenyan citizens have no option but to take a
party election in Africa today presents great satisfaction to many and a
noble but demanding responsibility to participate in the governance of
their country. Ignoring this role may shift back the gear which was put
in place in 1992."

In the rural areas, the NCCK plans to sensitise would-be voters on
the importance of elections, voter registration and voting rights by
simplifying the technical or legal jargon which is also translated into
the respective vernaculars.

A two-day workshop held at the Limuru Centre at the close of last
year as a trial run for using the stage to reach the youth with the
democratisation message, was hailed as "a great idea that should have
caught on long ago, particularly in the light of the participatory
nature of theatre."

Shiribwa says plays and music are effectively used in rural markets
and churches to portray either political parties, or election procedures
of co-operative societies. These usually generate discussions thereafter
and the audience can contribute their views. The annual budget for the
civic education programme is Kshs. 19 million (US dollars 333,000)
partly donated by church donors in Britain.

As far back as 1993, the then NCCK General Secretary Rev. Samuel
Kobia, unveiled plans to particularly counter KANU's monopoly on the
electronic media scene by establishing an independent source of news as
well as airing civic education programmes. It was revealed then that
donors to finance the project were being sought, but the greater
hindrance has been the government's delay, otherwise read as refusal to
licence locally based private stations. Media sources here say there are
over 60 applicants awaiting approval to operate broadcast stations.

"We might be the last ones to get the licence because of the
government's fear of critical media, for we are still seen as the
opposition in disguise," says Nthamburi, noting that all should be given
a chance now that the airwaves have formally been liberalised.

The NCCK recommends constitutional change such as the introduction of
the office of prime minister which will relegate the presidency to a
non-executive one, "in order to ensure a clear separation of power
between the government and the political party in office." Accordingly,
the president is expected to be above party politics, while the prime
minister should be a nominee of the party in leadership, but not the
head of such a party. In a move akin to that in South Africa, the
Christian council wants a constitutional provision to permit the
formation of a coalition government.

"We agree the Constitution does not change overnight. It is a process
you cannot just switch on and off. It has to be participatory and based
on informed judgement," said current General Secretary Rev. Mutava
Musyimi at the Limuru conference.

According to the NCCK blueprint the civic education and
constitutional change process should be done eight months before the
elections to allow for voter education and logistical planning.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


124 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Sudan Khartoum Creates Commission To Investigate Slavery


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Khartoum - Sudan has created a commission to investigate claims of
slave dealing in the south of the country, amid charges of continued
human rights violations.

Justice Minister Abdel Basit Sabdarat formed the panel on May 19, to
"look into reports by UN Human Rights rapporteur Gasper Biro concerning
the existence of slavery and forced disappearances in Sudan."

The commission head, Ali Ahmed al-Nasri was reported saying the panel
would tour the country and submit a report in August. 

"Due to the ongoing war in the south, many people have disappeared or
been abducted by rebels," Nasri said.

Biro said in his report in April that the existence of slavery in
Sudan was "no longer debatable," warning of "an alarming increase in the
number of reports on cases of slavery, servitude, slave trade and forced
labour."

The abuses are concentrated in the south where 1.2 million people
have died since 1983, in a civil war between the mostly Muslim north and
rebels from the mostly Christian and animist south.

"The abduction of southern civilians, men, women and children has
become a way of conducting the war," Biro's report noted, slamming the
"total passivity of the government" as "tacit political approval of
slavery."

But despite efforts to improve its human rights standing among the
international community, the London-based human rights watchdog Amnesty
International has charged that Sudan, whose current government seized
power in a 1989 military coup, continued to violate human rights,
including arbitrary killings, abduction of children and torture.

Suspected government opponents are subjected to ill treatment and
incommunicado detention, the human rights organisation said in a
statement released on May 23.

"While Sudan's ambassadors are busy telling the United Nations that
violations do not occur, the government's security forces are rounding
up suspected opponents in the capital and attacking civilian targets in
the war zones of the south, deliberately killing adults and forcibly
abducting children as a tactic of war," it said.

Elections were held last March, ostensibly to move from a military to
a civilian government, but the polls, boycotted by the opposition, "have
not made any difference to who holds power or to systematic repression
as a method of securing control," Amnesty said.

It said the abduction of children by government forces and allied
militia "is a growing feature of the civil war which began in 1983,"
when the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) took up arms to end
domination of the mainly Christian and animist south by the Arabised,
Muslim north.

Since the start of the civil war, more than a million people have
been killed and millions others either displaced locally or forced to
flee into exile in neighbouring countries.

But Amnesty claimed on May 23 that some of the children affected by
the war were held for ransom, some were taken into "domestic slavery,"
and others "ended up in government schools run like armed camps, where
some children have been shot while trying to escape."


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


125 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Algeria Extremists Say They Killed French Monks


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Paris - Algerian Muslim extremists say they killed seven French monks
kidnapped in Algeria two months ago.

In a communique, a copy of which was released here, the Armed Islamic
Group (GIA) said: "We cut the throats of the seven monks."

The statement which bore the number 44 and the usual signature of the
fundamentalist GIA said the monks had been killed on May 21, and
justified the killings by accusing the French government of not wanting
to negotiate with it. 

The French Foreign Ministry said if the killings by the GIA were
confirmed, all French people would react with "amazement, indignation
and condemnation."

The GIA has been one of the most radical groups fighting the Algerian
government since it annulled legislative elections in January 1992.

The monks were kidnapped on March 27 from their isolated monastery at
Tibehirine, 100 kilometres south-west of Algiers, and in a communique
dated April 18 and addressed to "France and its President Jacques
Chirac," the GIA threatened to "cut the throats" of the monks unless the
group's members detained in France were released.

"We are offering to exchange your prisoners for ours and we have a
precise list of names, and we will name for now only brother Abdel
Khaleq al-Ayayda," the earlier communique stated.

In the communique, the GIA, the most hardline of armed fundamentalist
groups fighting the Algerian authorities, had said the Trappist monks
were "still alive and in good health," the international ArabicThe communique, signed by GIA head Abou Abdel Rahmane Amine (alias
language paper, Al-Hayat said.
Jamel Zitouni), claimed responsibility "20 days after the kidnapping to
show the entire world that the infidels (the Algerian security forces)
are incapable of defending themselves and even less capable of
protecting others."

The three-page GIA statement said three other missionaries seized in
the Medea region were also still alive, but that ten Algerian soldiers
were killed while searching for the French monks in the area.

The hardline statement, issued in the Egyptian capital, Cairo on
April 26, stipulated there would be "no dialogue, no truce and no
reconciliation" with the military-backed authorities in Algeria.

Al-Hayat also reported that "French and Italian Catholic
authorities...have been in contact with the group which kidnapped the
seven French monks since mid-April."

On April 12, Father Lois Samson, an official with the Trappist order
in Rome, received word from a colleague who visited Algeria that the
seven monks were still alive.

On April 14 in Tunis, Pope John Paul II made a plea for the release
of the monks, some of whom are elderly and three of whom are in fragile
health.

More than 200 alleged Islamic fundamentalists are being held in
France awaiting trial on terrorism-related charges involving a bombing
campaign last year, believed to have been inspired by the GIA or
logistical support and arms smuggling networks for the GIA.

Judicial sources said it would be difficult to establish which of the
200 were GIA members unless the organisation provided a list of those it
wanted exchanged for the seven monks.

Armed Islamic groups have been fighting the military-backed Algiers
regime since the government cancelled a second round of elections in
January 1992. The violence has left up to 50,000 people dead.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


126 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Catholic Order Marks 50 Years In Africa


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Nairobi - The year 1996 is a celebration period for the Catholic
Order of Maryknoll Fathers (Society). It marks the 50th anniversary of
the society's pastoral work among Africans.

William Collins, Albert Good, Louis Bayless and Joseph Brannigan, the
first four missionaries of this congregation, arrived in Musoma,
Tanzania in August 1946.

"After nearly two months of their journey that began in New York,
USA, the four arrived in Musoma, Tanzania on October 23. This was to
become the beginning of their missionary work on the African continent,"
explains a brochure put out to mark the golden jubilee. 

In an interview with APS here on May 22, Rev. Fr. Joseph Healey, the
society's social communications coordinator for Tanzania, said the
jubilee year is being marked in series.

"We organised a regional symposium on "Mission" in Nairobi between
January 9 and 11. We marked it in Musoma (Tanzania) on May 17, at
Nyegina parish in Musoma area on May 19, and we intend to end the
celebrations in Shinyanga on October 15," said Fr. Healey.

According to Fr. Healey, there are 94 Maryknoll priests currently
serving the Catholic church in Kenya, Tanzania, Ethiopia and Egypt.

"The majority, 38, are in Tanzania and 29 in Kenya," says Fr. Healey.
In Tanzania, for example, they serve in eight Catholic dioceses namely
Dar es Salaam, Iringa, Geita, Musoma, Mwanza, Rulenge, Shinyanga and
Singida. In Kenya, the Maryknoll are working in the dioceses of Nairobi,
Machakos and Garissa. There are two Maryknoll priests in Ethiopia, while
Egypt has one.

"But in all they are scattered in different professional areas such
as medicine, teaching and communications both within and outside
pastoral areas," Fr. Healey elaborated.

Apart from ordained priests, the Maryknoll order also has brothers,
sisters and lay missionaries.

To date, some 43 Maryknoll sisters serve the Catholic church in
Tanzania, Kenya, Sudan, Zimbabwe, and Namibia.

Asked what he sees as future challenges for the society in the years
ahead, Fr. Healey mentioned the growing urbanization process being
experienced by many countries on the continent.

He singled out single mothers and erosion of African values as
possible outcomes of this process, whose effects on the lives of the
African people will be great.

He also said the future work of the society, both in Africa and
elsewhere is likely to be affected by a new phenomenon, as religious
vocation among young Americans is not growing fast.

"Unlike in the past, young Americans are no longer attracted by
religious life as it happened before," says Healey. The average age of
most of the Maryknollers currently serving the Church in Africa is soon
going to be 60 years -- meaning that the bodily energy will have some
effects on their priestly life," he added.

Unlike other religious orders, the Maryknoll society does not train
African priests for service. "We are a national missionary society,
hence we do not train local people for our society," Fr. Healey
explained.

But he noted that the missionaries do a lot of work for the church,
towards promoting various religious vocations among the local people.

At the Musoma celebrations (May 17) whose climax was a holy
eucharist, retired Tanzanian Cardinal Laurent Rugambwa hailed the
Maryknoll missionaries for their pastoral contribution to the growth of
Christianity in Africa and Tanzania in particular.

"We are here to mark yet another milestone of the pastoral growth
among the African people. For the last 50 years, the Maryknoll
missionaries have made their own contribution towards that goal. We must
thank them dearly for this," he told a huge congregation which included
the African regional superior for the Maryknoll society in Tanzania,
Rev. Fr. John Sivalon and the overall superior general for the society,
Rev. Fr. Kenneth Thesing.

In his address, Rev. Fr. Thesing reminded the congregation that "the
commemoration of 50 years of the pastoral work of Maryknoll missionaries
among African people was not the end of the journey, but the beginning
of yet another pastoral journey."

"We would like to assure you that, we intend to continue with the
same spirit in our pastoral commitment," he added.

Meanwhile, the society has proposed that its 1996 Mission Award be
given to the Nairobi-based ecumenical movement, People for Peace in
Africa, in recognition of its efforts towards peace-keeping and
reconciliation in Africa.

According to Fr. Healey, the organization has been proposed partly
because, "since its founding in 1989, it has facilitated peace talks
between warring factions of the Sudan People's Liberation Movement Army
(SPLM/A), arranged and facilitated meetings for rival Somali factions in
the Kenyan capital, and helped a group of young Somali journalists
launch a reconciliation and peace journal for Somali communities in
Somalia and Kenya.

People for Peace has also responded to the victims of "ethnic
clashes" in Kenya, especially through workshops organized throughout the
country.

It has also conducted reconciliation workshops for Rwandan women
leaders from both Tutsi and Hutu ethnic groups as well as accompanied
the Nuba people, who are victims of "ethnic genocide in the Sudan,"
according to Fr. Healey, who is also the editor of the Maryknoll
Overview, a regional publication for the society in Africa.

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Amended Constitution Bars Kaunda From Elections


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambian parliament has passed a controversial bill that
amends the constitution to effectively bar former Zambian President
Kenneth Kaunda from contesting elections later this year.

The bill, overwhelmingly supported by the ruling Movement for Multiwas taken on May 21.
party Democracy (MMD), underwent minor modifications when the final vote

The most controversial clause says both parents of a presidential
candidate should be Zambian by birth. This was modified to add the words
"or descent" and the stipulation that the presidential aspirant should
have lived in Zambia for 20 years. 

The former president has therefore been technically disqualified to
stand in the elections, which must be held by November, as his parents
came from Malawi at the turn of the century.

Kaunda, now 72, ruled Zambia for nearly three decades from
independence from Britain in 1964, and has vowed to break the law if he
is barred from standing.

Surprisingly, almost all Members of Parliament for the opposition
United National Independence Party (UNIP) -- who boycotted the debate
last week were in the house and participated actively in deliberations.

UNIP, the country's largest opposition party, walked out of the House
throughout the earlier debates in protest against the citizenship clause
and the ruling party's failure to address other pertinent political
problems in Zambia.

President Fredrick Chiluba is expected to sign the constitutional
amendment bill within 21 days before it becomes law.

The amendment will now pit Chiluba against Kaunda in a direct
collision course, with the former vowing that he will sign it into law
while the latter has threatened that he will organize civil disobedience
throughout Zambia to make the country ungovernable.

On May 9, Chiluba warned that in case Kaunda went ahead with his
disobedience threat, the followers of the former president would be
treated as "lawbreakers".

But Kaunda maintained that he and his followers would "break the law"
until "the prisons are too full to contain us," and that because
Zambians were hungry and desperate, uncontrollable violence could be
unleashed.

The question of whether Kaunda is a "genuine" Zambian has been the
centre of the dispute between the government and Kaunda's opposition
United National Independence Party since the former President announced
last year that he would make a comeback in politics by opposing Chiluba
in the next presidential elections scheduled for later this year.

He was born in Zambia to parents who immigrated from neighbouring
Malawi, while the new constitution requires that presidential candidates
must have been born to Zambian parents.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


128 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Uganda Women Seek Redress For Post-Election Wife-Beating


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Kampala - An upsurge in wife-battering has been reported throughout
Uganda in the aftermath of the recently concluded presidential elections
won by President Yoweri Kaguta Museveni.

The local press has reported a number of cases where women have been
beaten and invariably intimidated for supporting, actually voting for or
celebrating the victory of a candidate their husbands did not favour.

In one incident, Jesca Kasiri of Nawandyo Iganga District, Eastern
Uganda, was allegedly beaten into coma by her husband, Peter Kolwa,
after she revealed to him she had voted for Museveni. In Mukono
District, middle-aged Karim Lubega of Kikuba Nkima village, is suspected
to have beaten his wife, Rose Namubiru, 40, to death. 

In yet another case, Vice-President Dr Specioza Wandira Kazibwe, a
woman herself, was prompted to order the police to arrest one Joseph
Bukenya of Ngogwe village, Bukulula sub-county in Masaka District, about
100 kilometres south-west of here, for allegedly assaulting his wife,
Prossy Nakyanzi, who voted for a candidate he did not support.

Nakyanzi broke her leg and sustained severe injury on her eyes. The
police were said to have been indifferent prompting the Vice- President
to visit the woman and order for the arrest of Bukenya who was said to
be hiding.

However, Prossy has pleaded for clemency for her husband with whom
she said she has six children and whose support she feared to lose
should the husband be imprisoned.

Now the women's Alert Group for the Uganda Women's Network (UWN), has
petitioned the Government to intervene and put a stop to the
"intimidation and harassment of wives by their husbands and to treat any
such violence as 'serious crime' and not 'domestic dispute". UWN
comprises several prominent women, women groups and men interested in
the protection and promotion of women's rights.

"Both in the local press and from the districts - for instance
Luweero, Mukono, Kampala and Mpigi - it has been reported that women
have been intimidated in different ways," said the UWN with "a sense of
great shock and disappointment."

In a two-page open letter to President Museveni and the Chairman of
the Interim Electoral Commission (IEC) the group said: "Women have been
threatened with withdrawal of family support; they have been beaten,
killed, thrown out of their homes; had their voters' cards grabbed from
them or destroyed."

"Since the presidential elections, women have been accused harassed
and assaulted by different groups for having voted for one or the other
candidate," the Alert Group added.

The group urged Government and the IEC to tell all Ugandans that
women's rights are human rights and to re-emphasise the fact that women
have rights as citizens of Uganda. The women also want

reassurance that the Government will protect them and their property
during and after elections. They further urged that police should be
called in where there is intimidation harassment and violence.

In another development, the May 17 to 20, 1996 edition of The
Monitor, a local privately-owned newspaper that publishes three times a
week reported that Edward Mizaki, 30, a bicycle mechanic of Arua market
in Arua, West Nile, could eventually lose his wife Betty, 23, to Paul
Drani after Museveni, whom the latter supported, won the presidential
race.

The two men staked Uganda Shillings 100,000 (US$1000) each and signed
an agreement before local administration officials. But Mizaki who did
not have the money at hand instead offered his wife Betty.

Officials have now pleaded with Drani, 27, to leave Betty alone and
accept instead Uganda Shillings 300,000 (US$3,000). Mizaki was
subsequently allowed some time find the money failure of which he would
forfeit his wife. The Monitor was unable to obtain the views of the
affected wife, Betty Mizaki.

Meanwhile nominations for the parliamentary elections closed here at
16:00 hours on May 21. Mrs Flora Nkurukenda, Deputy Chairperson of the
Interim Electoral Commission, said parliamentary elections will take
place on June 27 while those for district women representatives will be
conducted a week earlier on June 20.

In the new constitution women have 39 additional elective seats, one
for each district, in the otherwise 214-seat National Assembly. Women
are also free to contest in any of the other 214 parliamentary
constituencies.

Following several affirmative actions by Museveni's National
Resistance Government in the last ten years, Ugandan women have become
very active politically. A fairly big number intends to contest the 214
parliamentary seats.

Yet more women could find their way to the National Assembly on the
ticket of other special interest groups such as the disabled, the Uganda
People's Defence Force (UPDF) and others. However, most of these are
elective seats and the women will have to fight for them.

Museveni, 52, first came to power in January 1986 when his rebel
National Resistance Movement (NRM) and Army (NRA) became the first
wholly indigenous African guerrilla force ever to capture state power.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

129 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Churches Asked To Consider Income-Generating Ventures


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 654 words


 
Limuru, Kenya - Leaders and representatives of various churches and
church organisations in Africa meeting hare to discuss self reliance and
funding for churches, have been advised to seriously consider income
generating ventures for church and church institutions in the face of
scarce resources particularly from traditional donor partners.

Addressing about 100 delegates at the Limuru Conference Centre here,
some 30 kilometres west of Nairobi, the General Secretary of the All
Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) Rev. Jose Chipenda pointed out that
material resources previously donated to churches in Africa by partners
from the North, may no longer be as readily forthcoming, as these donors
are also experiencing financial difficulties within their
constituencies.

Chipenda noted that the effectiveness of the work of the Church will
be affected because in future, "churches will no longer be able to
secure many cars, computers and sophisticated equipment as before." 

Delivering the key address at the May 21 to 22 Church Consultation of
Self Reliance, the AACC General Secretary emphasised that churches and
church related institutions are at cross-roads as they address their
financial viability with regard to support from Northern partners.

Noting that previously generous contributions from overseas partners
have encouraged recipient churches to start ambitious projects that were
not necessarily generative in nature or self-sustaining, Chipenda
reminded African churches that it is imperative they also seek ways and
means of sustaining their operations in the long run.

However, he acknowledged that self-sufficiency cannot be achieved 100
per cent because, business being a two-way venture means that
"superpowers also need small countries like ours."

On possibilities that churches can exploit to generate revenue,
Chipenda said it is important that one reviews the effectiveness of the
infrastructure "because revenue cannot be generated from the blue."

"Necessary enabling environment should be created such that the
personnel involved in the management of the scarce financial resources
are re-equipped with the necessary skills in financial management,
accountability and other skills," the AACC head advised.

He reminded workshop participants of the crucial role played by human
resources that understand the intricacy of finances. Churches should
have very sound management of finances so that problems that have been
experienced in the past are addressed adequately, he added.

Saying that AACC plans to hold a workshop for financial managers of
member churches, Chipenda also urged churches to come together and study
the requirements of some financial institutions that may assist them.

He cited the Holland-based Ecumenical Development Cooperative Society
(EDCS) which gives loans to churches at a lower interest rate compared
to any other financial institution.

The AACC head also proposed that churches that have properties that
can be developed (such as freehold land) should seek advice from experts
with the aim of securing funds to develop such land into revenue
generating projects.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


130 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Tanzania Negligence Cited In Ferry Disaster


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Bukoba, Tanzania - It appears negligence contributed substantially to
the ferry tragedy on East Africa's Lake Victoria that is officially
believed to have claimed as many as 500 lives, according to reports that
began to emerge two days after the tragedy on the morning of May 21.

Some of the 120 survivors of the accident - about 30 bodies have been
recovered so far - said, as it became obvious that the M.V. Bukoba was
sinking, the captain sent frantic distress signals to the destination
port of Mwanza and other passing ships. But the radio room is said to
have been unattended.

Furthermore even as the boat capsized but continued to stay afloat
from around 8:00 a.m. on the fateful day, well meaning rescue workers
reportedly punctured the hull in the hope of allowing people caught up
in the superstructure to escape. 

Unfortunately, the opening allowed water to gush in thus sealing the
fate of the people inside, many of whom could have been otherwise saved.

Tanzanian President Benjamin Mkapa has described the tragedy as "a
national disaster" and decreed three days of national mourning. He said
a commission of enquiry would be instituted immediately.

It is feared among the dead were two Catholic nuns, Sisters Bertilla
and Rozita Ros of Italy and the Philippines respectively. The final
death toll in the M.V. Bukoba disaster could be much higher than the 500
estimated by government authorities.

The marine vessel originated from Bukoba a port on the western shores
of Africa's largest fresh water lake, Lake Victoria on the night of May
20. Officials claimed there were 500 to 600 people on board the M.V.
Bukoba, one of a number of steamers that regularly ply the Lake Victoria
ports of Bukoba,(Tanzania) Port Bell and Jinja (Uganda) and Kisumu
(Kenya).

However other reliable witnesses told Tanzanian journalist A.
Kabeneri that while the ferries are regularly overcrowded, they had
never seen them as crowded as on the ill fated trip on May 20. As we
went to press, only about 40 people are said to have survived the
tragedy and scores of bodies had already been picked up.

The steamer is said to have struck submerged rock about eight
kilometres from its destination port of Mwanza at about 8 O'Clock.
However there were earlier reports that the M.V. Bukoba had been poorly
maintained and came close to a catastrophe in March and April.

Ali Mazuo, a resident of Mwanza said although the accident occurred
at about 8 O'clock part of the superstructure of the steamer was still
visible from hilly areas of Mwanza at mid-day the same day.

Huge crowds of wailing relatives and other anxious people gathered at
the wayside trying to get any news from rescue operations. Early news
indicated many passengers were trapped in the lower decks where franting
banging noises could still be heard four hours after the tragedy.

An indication that the ill fated ship carried well beyond its
capacity was based on the assessment of a taxi driver in Bukoba who
said; "I have never seen so many people trying to board the ferry
before."

He estimated that more than 200 people had to be turned back by
Tanzania Railway authorities (who are responsible for the steamers)
because the ship could simply not take any more passengers.

Steamer services on Lake Victoria which is shared by the three East
African countries namely Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania play a critical role
in connecting inland areas of Tanzania because the road and rail
networks are inadequate.

Steamers also link Uganda to Tanzania's port of Dar es Salaam on the
Indian Ocean. Uganda is a landlocked country that is connected to export
markets through Kenya's coastal port of Mombasa and Dar es Salaam.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


131 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zimbabwe Defence Industries Deny Producing Land Mines


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Harare - Zimbabwe is losing lucrative contracts to supply dry rations
to United Nations agencies because it is among countries that have been
identified as manufacturing land mines, after the world body declared a
world moratorium on the production of these deadly weapons a few years
ago.

But this Southern African country denies ever having produced land
mines, according to Zimbabwe Defence Industries (ZDI) general manager
Ret. Col. Tshinga Dube, who is challenging the authenticity of the UN's
information.

According to an Inter Press Service (IPS) daily journal report on
January 25 this year, the UN Under-Secretary-General for Humanitarian
Affairs, Peter Hansen, had hinted that the UN, was preparing a list of
companies that manufactured land mines so that they could be barred from
supplying goods and services to the world body.

The UN estimates that there are 110 million landmines planted
worldwide with between two million and five million laid each year. 

Meanwhile, the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and the UN
High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) have already decided to bar
purchases by their agencies of goods supplied by landmine producing
companies.

The report listed a number of countries, Zimbabwe among them, charged
with manufacturing landmines unearthed in Cambodia, Mozambique, Angola
and Afghanistan. The four countries are said to be fighting a losing
battle against the mines.

IPS said the newly-established UN Demining Database listed Russia as
the main supplier of landmines found in the four countries, followed by
China, the Czech Republic, the United States, Italy, South Africa and
Vietnam. Other countries were Zimbabwe, Pakistan, Singapore, Belgium,
Germany, Portugal and France.

"Our defence industries have never acquired any landmine technology.
No country can ever witness any purchases of landmines from Zimbabwe,"
says Col. Dube, adding that there could be confusion between a landmine
and a Claymore mine.

ZDI stopped making Claymore mines more than four years ago, following
an order from the Ministry of Defence to stop production of anything
called a mine. The order came in the wake of an announcement by the UN
of a moratorium on the production of landmines.

The Claymore mine is made of two plastic semi-circular cases clipped
together containing explosive and shrapnel. It can either stand freely
or be detonated remotely by use of a battery connected by a cord a safe
distance away.

If the mine has not been detonated it is repacked and stored and only
deployed when next required, unlike a landmine or anti-personnel mine
that can be left buried or lying around waiting for a victim.

The technology for making the Claymore mine was inherited from the
former Rhodesian defence industry at independence in 1980.

"In spite of the argument that we put against classifying a landmine
together with the Claymore mine the order (by the Ministry of Defence to
stop production) stood. As a result ZDI was forced to destroy all stocks
of Claymore mines. Our defence industries have never been a secret even
to some diplomats accredited to this country. We welcome any UN agencies
to come and inspect our industry," Colonel Dube says.

He adds that ZDI "strongly believes that the idea of clustering our
country together with big countries who may have the technology to
manufacture landmines is an effort to keep us out of any UN business."
All efforts to supply services to the UN have failed.

"The UN peacekeeping force invited tenders to supply dry ration
military packs for its forces in the region and Zimbabwe was delighted
that we had been the only country in Africa that was short- listed with
other countries like Israel, Malaysia etc.

"We continued to get telefaxes from the peacekeeping office that we
must hold our prices from over a year, then everything went dead. As a
result, our forces operating from even countries as close to us as
Angola and previously Somalia have to rely on rations from Australia,
New Zealand and other far away countries," Col Dube says.

Ironically, ZDI itself is actually heavily involved in the mine
clearing operations in Zimbabwe. Most of these mines were planted by
Rhodesian and South African forces during the liberation struggle.

The ZDI had its roots in 1939 when the Southern Rhodesia government
was required to mobilise resources for the Second World War,
manufacturing pistons and bombs which were sold to South Africa.

The industry was closed at the end of the Second World War. But it
was resuscitated during the Unilateral Declaration of Independence (UDI)
years (from November 1965), and by independence in 1980 the list of
locally-made items included combat clothing, military vehicles, mines,
mortars, small arms and weapons spares.

However, at independence, the companies manufacturing military
hardware stopped production of the same. And because of emigration, the
technology acquired during the UDI years was lost.

The Zimbabwe Government re-established the industry in order to save
foreign currency and for security reasons.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


132 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Anti-Polio Campaign To Benefit 50 Million Children


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 28, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Nairobi - Over 50 million African children will be vaccinated against
polio in a major immunization campaign beginning June this year.

The World Health Organisation (WHO) regional Office for Africa
expresses hope that international partners will meet about 50 per cent
of the total cost of US$.20 million for the National Immunization Day
(NID) operational costs, says a document released by the WHO Africa
regional office in Brazzaville, Congo.

Entitled "Overview of Polio Eradication in the African Region," the
WHO document says 25 African countries have already been earmarked for
the immunization campaign. About US$5 million is expected from Rotary
International while further support of US$100,000 will be given by the
United States Agency International Development (USAID). 

The WHO regional office says the immunization campaign will run from
June 1996 through January 1997.

The regional director for Africa has established a committee for
"Polio-Free Africa", to promote polio eradication activities in
countries of our continent, says the WHO document, adding that South
African President Nelson Mandela has been invited to become its
chairman.

The WHO regional office also notes there is a request to the
Organisation of African Unity (OAU) General Secretary to include the
issue of polio eradication on the agenda of the next summit slated for
July 8 to 10 next year in Yaounde, Cameroon.

"In the framework of the six steps For a Polio-Free Africa concept, a
social mobilisation Kick Polio out of Africa campaign will be launched
to promote national immunization days and other polio eradication
activities in the African region," says the WHO document.

But WHO nevertheless notes that although polio is still endemic in
many countries of Africa, its occurrence has declined in recent years.

Says the document, "Reported incidence of polio has declined from
3,935 cases in 1995 to 1,991 cases in 1994 and 1,512 cases in 1995."

It adds that the partnership between WHO, Rotary International, the
United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and the Centre for Disease
Control and Prevention in the USA, will help governments generate the
US$ 60 million a year which will be required to provide vaccine supplies
and support the operations of the national immunization days.

The document says Africa has one of the lowest immunization coverages
in the world. In 1994, when over 80 per cent of the world's children
were immunized against polio during their first year of life, only about
half of all African children under one (54 per cent) were immunized
against polio.

In Chad, less than one in five children were protected, while in
Angola, Cameroon and Zaire less than a third of the children in this age
group were immunized against polio according to the WHO document.

But even in countries where immunization coverage rates are as high
as 70 per cent, perhaps 25 per cent of newborns each year will remain
unprotected against polio, the document further says.

Some estimates indicate that the major anti-polio immunization
campaign in Africa, a programme that will be repeated again in 1997 to
1998, is estimated to cost close to US$ 33 million.

Countries to be involved in the campaign will organise national
immunization days, during which two doses of oral polio vaccine must be
administered to all children under the age of five years, four to six
weeks apart.

The countries earmarked for the campaign include Kenya, South Africa,
Angola, Burkina Faso, Central African Republic and Equatorial Guinea,
among others.

An official at the WHO Kenya Office told APS, the selection of
beneficiary countries for the immunization campaign has been based on
the fact that these have "accepted and organised health programmes that
would easily facilitate this campaign."

He added that participating children will be below five years of age.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

May, 1996


Zambia Three Groups To Defy Constitution


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 22, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 1024 words


 

Lusaka - Oppositions Zambia Democratic Congress(ZDC), Liberal Progressive Front(LPF) and Inter-Africa Network for Human Rights and Development (AFRONET) yesterday vowed to defy President Chiluba's constitution.

They also challenged the international community to take drastic action against President Chiluba's government for adopting the constitution without national consensus.

ZDC president Dean Mung'omba charged at a press briefing in Lusaka yesterday that President Chiluba had betrayed the trust of the international community who he had promised that he would consider consensus in adoption and amendment of some of the contentious clauses. 

"We encourage our citizens not to obey unjust laws," Mung'omba said, declaring: " It is a matter for which we are prepared to die for."

Mung'omba warned that despite the MMD passing its own bill into a constitution, the fight is not over - it had just started.

"We shall stretch the limits of the law to fight this discriminatory, divisive and racist constitution," Mung'omba charged. "And in the event of violence breaking out, Chiluba will be to blame."

LPF chairman, Roger Chongwe, said at a separate press briefing that the current Zambian Parliament was "like the Parliament in Nazi Germany which passed laws to persecute Jews and the South African Parliament in the apartheid era".

"Parliaments worldwide have had a history of passing good laws and bad laws. This constitution is a bad law because it creates divisions and classes within the Zambian society," Chongwe charged. " Any law which has no legitimacy should not be accepted."

Chongwe said President Chiluba's constitution was an embarrassment to the people of Zambia.

AFRONET executive director, Ngande Mwanajiti, accused the government of having ignored other people's views.

"It appears many views have not been listened to indicating that mighty is right," Mwanajiti said in an interview yesterday. "The democratic process should find a solution to the problem if there is any."

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Southern Africa Region's Rights Activists Meet In Zambia


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 22, 1996 by George Jambwa and Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - The fifth Southern African Legal Aid and Legal Advice Regional workshop opened at Lusaka's Pamodzi Hotel yesterday to evaluate and discuss the way forward in the fight against human rights violation.

Shehnaz Meer, in charge of secretariat, said the intention of the meeting was to find the way of working together to promote human rights in Southern Africa. 

Sheer observed that human rights abuse in the region was increasing at an alarming rate and it was high time a formula was found.

"Human rights abuse is increasing everyday and at it is increasing at an alarming rate,"Sheer said in an interview. "The purpose of this meeting is to evaluate the abuses and discuss the way forward of how we can help reduce violation of our rights."

Among other issues to be discussed are land policy and its effect on human rights and how South African farmers and investors moving into Africa are exploiting employees.

The workshop will also look at how to consciences and mobilise people against death penalty, crime, police and human rights.

And speaking at the same function, wife to late Malawian political detainee, Orton Chirwa, Vera, who is the executive director of the Malawi human rights group, Centre For Advice, Research and Education on Rights (CARER) disclosed that the human rights record of Malawi has improved since the introduction of multi-party politics.

"I can say that Malawi's Human Rights record has improved since we had elections in 1994. Our press is now very free to attack and question the action of the government. We no longer live in fear as was the case in the past," Vera said in an interview yesterday.

The meeting which ends today has drawn participants from Namibia, Malawi, South Africa Mozambique, Zimbabwe and the host Zambia.

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Another Opposition Leader Disqualified


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 23, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - ZDC president Dean Mung'omba has also been disqualified, by the Constitution (Amendment) Bill which was passed by the ruling MMD, from contesting this year's presidential elections, claimed the party's general secretary Derrick Chitala yesterday.

Chitala, who telephoned The Post at 20:30 hours, to announce his party's predicament, said almost all Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) top leaders have been disqualified by the amendment.

"Chiluba introduced, at the committee stage, clause 34 (3) (g) on page 7 of the Constitution of Zambia (Amendment) Bill which requires one to have 'been domiciled in Zambia for a period of at least 20 years,"Chitala said. "This disqualifies Mung'omba, our vice-president Dr. Mutukwa, Chulu Kalima and myself." 

When contacted Mung'omba said the 20 year domicile requirement rules him out.

"I was away from 1974 to 1985," Mung'omba said. "And depending on the way this 20 year is calculated I'm out."

Mung'omba joins UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda and his vice-president senior chief Inyambo Yeta who are already disqualified by President Chiluba's constitution.

Former President Kaunda is caught by the clause that requires ones parents to been born in , or originated from, Zambia.

And Yeta is barred by a clause that stops chiefs from participating in active politics without abdicating their thrones.

But Chitala maintained the 'constitution fight' was not over.

"In his lust for power Chiluba has declared Zambia a one party state," Chitala charged. "We will continue to fight this injustice in the courts, but if we fail our legal battles we will resort to all other necessary means until justice is restored in our country."

Chitala said the MMD's constitution puts Zambia as a good example of a despotic regime.

"It concludes that Chiluba is a despot," Chitala said. "This country under Chiluba is worse than Romania under Ceausescu ."

And Liberal Progressive Front chairman Rodger Chongwe said if followed seriously, the constitution leaves only National Party president Humphrey Mulemba as President Chiluba's challenger.

"I have never come across such a provision in any constitution anywhere in the world, Chiluba has become a mercenary," Chongwe charged." We believe that the President cannot carry out an electoral process without subverting it if he can subvert a document like the constitution."
