Africa News


May, 1996


Ethiopia Jailed Champion's Race For Justice


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Duncan Mackay


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Johannesburg - His moment of glory is replayed every day on a television screen in the International Olympic Committee's museum in Lausanne. A dark, slender man in green vest and black shorts, his silken stride personifying the natural, unbound runner as he moves towards taking his place in the pantheon of Olympic greats. Meanwhile, thousands of miles away the star of the video, Mamo Wolde, the 1968 Olympic marathon champion, languishes in Addis Ababa's central prison having been detained without formal charge or trial for almost four years.

It was in mid-1992 that Wolde was arrested during a round-up of people suspected of involvement in the former Mengistu regime's Red Terror torture and execution campaign of the late Seventies but his case did not come to light until a year ago. Amnesty International, who are campaigning for his release, said they had never seen any evidence to suggest that Wolde, a local government official at the time, had been implicated in human rights abuses. 

It seems extraordinary that the Ethiopian government, in view of Wolde's international celebrity status, have not bothered to substantiate the allegations. They have cited the problems of reconstituting their judiciary after the civil war, which ended five years ago this month, as the main reason for their not bringing more than 1 700 suspects to trial. Housed in a section of the prison known as the "End of the World", it is not surprising that the 64-year-old Wolde has become depressed during his detention, and there have recently been fresh fears about his health.

The IOC and International Amateur Athletic Federation have each contacted the respective Ethiopian Olympic and athletic organisations to try to have him released. But since those officials are also members of the government, it has been a fruitless policy. "Wolde is among the third tier of people who may be brought to trial and that means it could still easily be months before he's charged," said Kathy Daniel of Amnesty International's East Africa section.

As well as continuing to campaign on his behalf, the IOC has also given Wolde's wife, Aberash, a small stipend each month to help her support herself and her family.

Wolde is one of only four Ethiopians to win an Olympic gold medal. His career spanned four Games, starting with the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne at which Ethiopia competed for the first time. Wolde finished last in his heats of the 800 and 1 500m and was a member of the 4x400m relay team who also finished last in their heat. But in Mexico City in 1968 he scaled the peak when he succeeded legendary countryman Abebe Bikila, the 1960 and 1964 winner, as Olympic marathon champion. He won by more than three minutes a week after taking the silver at the 10 000m. Four years later, at the age of 40, he won the bronze in the marathon at the Munich Games.

Sporting success brought Wolde promotion to the rank of captain in the Palace Guard of the ageing Emperor Haile Selassie. In 1974, however, Haile Selassie was overthrown by Ethiopian military leaders who, under Mengistu Haile Mariam, created a violent communist government known as the Dergue. Under Mengistu, it was the Amhara ethnic group who held sway. They make up roughly 30% of the new democracy's population and, in an ironic twist of fate, many claim they are being persecuted by their government, because of what happened in the past.

The most prominent Amhara runner is Haile Gebresilasie, the world 5 000 and 10 000m record holder and world 10 000m champion, whose heroes naturally included Wolde. Gebresilasie's brother Tekeye, an international marathon runner, is one of six Ethiopian athletes who were recently officially granted Dutch citizenship after seeking political asylum there.

As the wind of change continues to blow through this continent it is not just Ethiopian athletes whose careers, it is claimed, are being used as political footballs. Abdi Bile, the 1987 world 1 500m champion, has been banned for life by Somalia's Olympic Committee for "misconduct" and the American-based runner currently faces being barred from international competition, including this year's Games in Atlanta. "What has Abdi done? Nothing," said Brad Hunt, his agent. "This is purely political. There was a change in leadership. They're out to screw Abdi."

At least Bile is able to take his case to the IOC and IAAF. Wolde does not know how many more nights he must spend in prison for a crime he claims he did not commit, or even how he can get justice. This is one marathon he wishes he was not involved in.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


137 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Arts South Africa's Ocumba Sounds Off In American Market


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Sean Badal


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Johannesburg - The video for Qcumba Zoo's haunting new song, Cloud Eyes, features a harsh, dystopian wasteland -- sort of Mad Max meets Tank Girl. Amid the whirling dervishes, elfin band member Tsatsiki runs amok with a flame thrower -- a purple, bulbous, plastic Seventies gizmo that looks like a plaything for a psychotic Generation Xer.

Lead singer Levannah, swathed in guerrilla chic and sporting a Mohawk tuft, has a voice that would induce cardiac arrhythmia in an ageing record producer. It's that beautiful. If there's any resemblance to cultish New Age San Francisco band Crash Worship, it ends with the pagan rituals. 

In the flesh, the extraordinarily articulate, and strangely monikered, Levannah -- an Assyrian goddess apparently -- swiftly disavows any millennialist tendencies on behalf of the group.

"We hate being boxed, which, I suppose, is a very human thing to do. But we do not espouse any particular philosophy or lifestyle. We look for and celebrate originality in different ways. Our philosophy is to be eclectic. We try to live it in our lifestyles and in our music."

The group's eclecticism is doing them proud. August last year saw the debut release of their single The Child Inside. The song, a mournful dirge to the rigours of childhood traumas carried into adulthood, has "done very well", says Levannah. Their new single, Cloud Eyes, is currently in third spot on the Radio 5 charts.

Most importantly, the group have been signed by American record label Arista, whose clients include the original happy trippers, The Grateful Dead. The deal, negotiated by music promoter David Gresham, is a six-album promotion and distribution package -- no small feat for an untried, South African group.

The group launches an album at the end of this month, and then leaves for the US on a promotional visit.

Qcumba Zoo planted its roots a long time ago, says Levannah. "I met Owl (the band's instruments and programming expert) about five years ago while we were still students. He asked me to do occasional vocals for the music that he was creating. We then had a band called Ocean Road -- did the flea-markets, coffee-shops, bars and ... Witbank. Yes, don't laugh, there are people there who had been living lives of quiet desperation until we showed, and, suddenly, there was something they could identify with -- the music, the spirituality. It's a big thing for us. If you look at our fan mail, people are keen to share their ideas about their beliefs and values."

These multi-cultural distillations are firmly reflected in their music and identities. While Levannah assuages the fears of dysfunctional adults with Celtic murmurings, the background music has echos of everything from Brian Eno's ambient sounds to techno-shamanistic ritual wails.

Outwardly, the group's appearance wouldn't make them oddities at a Zippie (Zen Inspired Professional Pagan) festival. This combination of mythologies from past and present don't make them slaves to commodity fetishism, insists Owl.

"We have an external and internal side. And we believe that balance is important. If fetishism means being hooked on a series of external precepts, then it's unhealthy. The spiritual side of life is very important to us."

The spiritual renaissance of the world at the end of the century, including the fallout into doomsday cults, spiritual narcissism and organised religion, is happening for a reason, says Levannah.

"Man has lost touch with his spirituality, and there's a definite movement to recover that ground. I don't believe that we have done everything there is to do and that the world is sliding into degeneracy. If enough people believe, there's a point of critical mass that tips the scales. It can only make the world a better place to live."

Being part of the global village is integral to the group's identity, says Owl. "We're on this planet together, but at the same time we haven't forgotten that we're in Africa and what we're creating is African. We have a vast pool of resources to draw from and we are making use of that. Yet, the music we're creating is not African in the sense that we conform to that curio image of Africa. That has got to change. There are just too many cultural differences to draw from."

Opening the cages: Levannah, Owl and Tsatsiki of Qcumba Zoo -- "We hate being boxed ... we look for and celebrate originality in different ways".


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


138 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Arts "Hoop Dreams" Debuts in South Africa


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Andrew Worsdale


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Johannesburg - When Hoop Dreams was released in the US and Europe, it was greeted with resounding critical acclaim. A three-hour documentary, it offers a remarkably optimistic and warm study of two black Chicago high-school students who dream of breaking out of their disadvantaged inner-city lives -- not through formal education, but rather by way of the fickle "hoop dream" of basketball.

At the time, critics like Siskel and Ebert, Michael Medved and the Mail & Guardian's Derek Malcolm expressed outrage at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for failing to recognise it with a nomination for best documentary -- let alone for best picture. But knowing the Oscars for the cynical industry endorsement they are, this shouldn't come as a surprise. 

Made over a period of four-and-a-half years and culled from some 250 hours of raw footage, Hoop Dreams is a collaboration between Steve James (director and editor), Fred Marx (producer and co-editor) and cameraman Peter Gilbert -- each of whom are award-winning documentary-makers in their own right.

The film follows the highs and lows of the lives and dreams of William Gates and Arthur Agee; their enrollment at St Joseph's Catholic high school, their attempts at receiving basketball scholarships for school and college, family hardships, sporting injuries and the like. In other words, it's an epic journey of triumph and tragedy in the inner- city -- where a scholarship is likely to be a young athlete's only way out.

The contrast between the two boys' careers is the film's central conflict and its strongest point. Gates is, at the outset, the more likely to make his way to basketball stardom, whereas Agee's family problems take their toll on his athletic quest. However, as the story progresses, we witness an uncanny reversal of fortune. There's plenty of drama, but events occur without any dramatic contrivance -- because this is the stuff of real life.

Yet, at the end of an extremely long haul, Hoop Dreams is still a very American piece of cinema; wearing its sentiment on its sleeve and full of repetitive sermonising and quaint philosophising about sticking to one's dreams. Even so, you leave the cinema convinced that it's got its heart in the right place.

Mixing 16mm film footage with Hi-8 and Betacam video, the film's rough style helps undermine some of that sentimentalism and optimism -- making it a refreshing change from all those ghetto movies that wind themselves up into a depressing frenzy about drugs and the dissolution of community and family life. You don't have to be a basketball fan to enjoy Hoop Dreams, but it would probably help. In a country like America, where the sport is an obsession, the film has become wildly popular. Here, who knows?


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

May, 1996


Arts Review: Winter Jazz Festival


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Gwen Ansell


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Johannesburg - Jazz festivals haven't had good press recently, and a number of sponsors are getting chilled around their pedal extremities. All praise, then, to Bavaria and SAfm for keeping the faith and staging their second Winter Jazz Festival at the Bass Line Club in Melville from May 29 to June 5, with a different band every night. 

The festival gives space to a number of the club's stalwarts -- George Lee, Bheki Khoza, Gito Baloi and Alan Cameron -- to stretch out in larger ensembles or with new material. It also introduces some new combos which may bear watching for in the future. The electrifying trio led by drummer Lulu Gontsana with Wessel van Rensburg and Herbie Tsoaeli has expanded to take in reeds and horn and become Gontsana's Jazz Machine -- nothing wrong with an old name when the approach is as new as tomorrow.

Reedman Steve Dyer (still probably best known for Afrojazz radio hits like Umkhumbane and Hondayi) has put together a six-piece which unites modernists like pianist Paul Hamner and drummer Barry van Zyl with veterans like trumpeter Stompie Manana for what could be an intriguing night.

And trumpet and EVI master Bruce Cassidy has assembled an 11-piece big band, the Hotfoot Symphony Orchestra, to present a varied repertoire including compositions from Cassidy himself. But whether the material is new or standard, the playing will be some of the best the Gauteng area can offer. Put this in your diary -- all of it.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


140 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Is Manuel Tough Enough For Finance?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Reg Rumney


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

Johannesburg - One cannot help feeling sympathy for new Finance Minister Trevor Manuel.

Not that he is a man who elicits pity -- after entering Parliament, a dynamic Manuel enthusiastically took on the task of breaking down the high protective wall of import taxes built up during apartheid, shrugging off criticism from business and unions that he was being too hasty.

Then he was appointed finance minister -- and witnessed the rand plummet, as if in judgment. His every remark is scrutinised and he has even started to become the butt of jokes, though the press and public retain too much respect for our new wave of politicians to mete out the same kind of ridicule heaped on the last real Nat finance minister, Barend du Plessis, who was characterised as a failed IBM typewriter salesman. 

The words of finance ministers -- and central bankers -- tend to be inspected, like the utterances of the Oracle at Delphi, for hidden signs of economic policy.

Manuel's immediate predecessor Chris Liebenberg and Reserve Bank governor Chris Stals made a few innocuous remarks at the Frankel Pollak Investment Conference in February about not supporting the rand at all costs after it had begun to slide. The currency tumbled.

Manuel himself will surely rue his remark about the "amorphous market". Amorphous or not, markets are merciless in punishing doubters.

And they are not really that amorphous. Markets consist of people like the woman who phoned me this week to ask, "Why has the rand fallen? Is it because of Manuel?"

She wanted to know whether she should delay exchanging the dollars left after a trip to the United States in case the rand declined further. And by not putting her dollars back into the market, she contributed in a small way to the rand's decline.

She and a host of otherwise sharp foreign exchange and bond dealers are ignorant of Manuel's better qualities. They are not concerned that a finance minister needs to be a skilled politician, able to fend off the spending demands of his cabinet colleagues, rather than a technocrat.

Commentators unsympathetic to the present government have seen the collapsed currency as a weapon to rail against an imagined policy of economic welfarism, and Manuel as the fall guy. After all, it was the massive capital flight and consequent rand dive after the Rubicon speech in 1985 that spelled the beginning of the end for the finger-wagging former state president PW Botha.

Governments live by the rule that their problems were all caused by their predecessors, but Manuel at least can say with a straight face that the host of economic problems the country faces are inherited from the previous regime.

Chief among these is the unemployment problem. At least a third of the potential workforce is without employment. In the industrialised West, unemployment approaching 10% starts to cause social upheaval.

And if anything has changed since Derek Keys took Du Plessis's place in May 1992, it has been for the better. Even the recent rand devaluation arguably promises to help economic growth through increased export revenue as long as gains are not eroded by inflation -- and the rand does not continue its free fall.

Why did Keys not face the same scepticism about his ability to handle the job as Manuel?

Keys, a darling of the media, was lucky enough to have the job during a transitional euphoria when an extra tax could be sneaked in as a "transition levy". He came in at the beginning of the thaw in the cold recession years. He also quit before the going could get tough, and he left without ever detailing his reasons, circumstances that now would mortally wound economic confidence.

The day was only partly saved by the appointment of banker Chris Liebenberg as his successor, a man with less flair but a great deal of attention to detail. Manuel could learn something from Liebenberg, and the classic advice to economic authority figures: say little, and only what is unexceptional.

Manuel's comments probably strike the conservative investment community as a bit too creative.

As our new finance minister delivered his response to criticism in a snap debate in Parliament last week on the rand, you could see the temper that lurks under his usual affability. For a politician he is a shade too sensitive.

But though Liebenberg's style was reassuringly grey, even his sober pronouncements were proven to have the wrong -- or no -- effect eventually.

Manuel cannot rely on serene silence for very long.

In the end, investors will be satisfied with nothing less than a clear economic "vision", a business euphemism for the removal of exchange controls and privatisation.

Although controls only remain for residents, and the first gradual steps to remove them have been taken, investors would probably like bolder steps. On privatisation, however, government seems paralysed.

"Restructuring", or "equity partnerships", is not enough.

At the very least, investors inside the country and out will want to know what is to be privatised or not, and when.

Does Manuel have the necessary authority to impose a detailed economic strategy -- or extract it from Cabinet -- soon? Can he persuade the government to cross the unions?

Whatever slings and arrows Manuel may have had to endure up to now, they are nothing compared with the political flak faced by finance ministers who introduce structural adjustment programmes.

As the new Hungarian finance minister, Peter Medgyessy, told Time magazine recently: "Someone who agrees to be finance minister never assumes he will be one of the most popular politicians in the country. This is true everywhere in the world."

Reg Rumney is Economics Editor of SABC-TV News


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


141 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Reserves Crisis Could Send South Africa To IMF


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Simon Segal


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Johannesburg - Will South Africa have to go to the International Monetary Fund (IMF), led by Michel Camdessus, for financial assistance? If the recent outflows of capital are not quickly reversed, many analysts believe the country will have little option but to apply for an IMF facility.

At about R10-billion, South Africa's reserves are uncomfortably close to five weeks' worth of imports.

With official statistics for the first quarter not yet available, the best barometer of capital flows is foreign investment in South Africa's equity and bond markets.

>From a net inflow of R4,5-billion in January and February, there was a net outflow of R1,9-billion in April. This recovered to a net R750-million inflow in the first half of May. 

Clearly, total capital inflows would have slowed since the rand crisis started in February. From the second half of 1994 to end-1995, there was a net capital inflow of R30,8-billion (there was a net R51,7-billion outflow from 1985 to mid-1994, accounting for a loss of at least 2% in gross domestic product in each of these years).

Capital flows are significant. Reserve Bank governor Chris Stals talks about a net capital inflow of around $1-billion to achieve a growth rate of 5%.

The problem is that a large part of South Africa's capital inflows are portfolio investments, which are volatile and unpredictable.

South Africa, it is true, survived a far more serious reserves and capital account crunch in the run-up to the April 1994 elections. But thereafter the new government enjoyed a honeymoon period, as foreign investors gave it the benefit of many doubts.

These doubts are now coming home to roost, as reflected in the rand's plunge and slowdown in net capital inflows.

South Africa's quota at the IMF, based on its annual subscription, which in turn is related to the country's size, is 1 365-billion (R7,5-billion) in special drawing rights (SDR). IMF credit is available in tranches of 25% of a country's quota.

For drawings under the first tranche, members have to show efforts to overcome their balance of payment problem. First tranche drawings are not phased or subject to performance criteria.

Upper credit tranche drawings are made in instalments associated with stand-by or extended arrangements. These typically seek to overcome balance of payment problems through structural policy reforms and are conditional on meeting performance criteria.

A country can borrow up to 100% of its quota over a year and 300% over five years. IMF money is cheaper than commercial credit.

Politically, IMF money is a hot potato as it comes with conditions that Cosatu, and many in government, consider unpalatable.

But for others, including some in the Reserve Bank and finance ministry, it is a blessing in disguise because it forces fiscal restraint and potentially restores investor confidence in South Africa.

Typically, IMF money would be conditional on cutting the Budget deficit from about 5 to 6% of GDP to nearer 3%. The IMF would also want to see progress on privatisation and higher savings.

With the normalisation of international financial relations, the government is able to raise new funds on the international capital markets. It is budgeting for R2,5-billion in foreign loans this year (R1,8-billion in 1995/1996) out of a total gross borrowing requirement for 1996/1997 of R45,1-billion.

During its first two years in power, the government of national unity has raised three foreign loans:

* A Y30-billion Japanese samurai bond at 5% in June.

* In December 1994, $750-million was raised at 9,6%, then 193 basis points above the equivalent United States Treasury rate. It now trades at a premium of 152 points. The premium has fluctuated between 135 (this year) and 350 points (in early 1995 just after the Mexican debt crisis).

* In January this year, a 10-year Eurosterling bond was raised at 9,38%, 190 points above the equivalent British benchmark bond. This was the government's first 10-year loan.

While increasing, South Africa is still under-borrowed in terms of its $20,7-billion foreign debt ($18,6-billion), some 23,5% (22,9%) of GDP.

US credit rating agencies Standard & Poor's (S&P's) and Moody's pronounced South Africa's rand bonds two notches better than investment grade. S&P's raised its rating of South Africa's foreign currency debt one notch to BB+, still short of investment grade. Moody's and Japan's Nippon Investor Services have rated South Africa's foreign currency borrowing as investment grade.

Foreign borrowing becomes expensive when the rand depreciates. The 100-million bond, for instance, now costs some R660-million to redeem, against R560-million when it was issued earlier this year.

The last time South Africa went to the IMF was in 1993 when it sought SDR615-million under the IMF's Compensatory Finance Facility (repayment starts in the fourth quarter of this year). But this was effectively drought relief.

The last time South Africa used a stand-by facility was in the early 1980s.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

May, 1996


South Africa Housing Hardest Hit By Rate Hike


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Madeleine Wackernagel


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Johannesburg - Amid signs that the money market shortage is easing, thereby taking the heat off interest rates for the time being, growth forecasts for this year are being rapidly scaled down, with housing and private consumption expenditure hardest hit.

The Building Industries Federation of South Africa (Bifsa) cut its original growth projections for the industry in half -- to 5% -- when the first rate hike was announced. The banks' move last week has seen expectations scaled down even more, says Ian Robinson, executive director. 

"If rates stay at current levels, we expect 4% growth in the building industry this year thanks to the projects already on stream. The impact will be most severe next year when new work dries up due to the interest-rate squeeze; we project negative 3% growth for 1997 with a turnaround in 1998 and 1999," says Robinson.

The low-cost housing market, despite its heavy reliance on subsidies, will suffer as the cost of supplementing the subsidies rises. Says Johan de Ridder, chief executive of the National Housing Finance Corporation: "Higher interest rates have a direct impact on affordability and indirectly on the cost of components. Hardest hit are the people on the margin, who could only just afford the payments before the rate rise.

"This move will have a severe impact on the bottom end of the market. The result will be a higher default rate."

Boosting the subsidies is not a viable option as the government is under pressure to cut expenditure. Housing Minister Sankie Mthembi-Nkondo says the issue is being debated but the decision lies with the Ministry of Finance.

Meanwhile, the Bureau for Economic Research has revised its original growth forecasts to 3% from 3,5% for this year and has ruled out 4% for next. Says Pieter Laubscher: "Even if the rate hike is reversed in the short term, the harm to the economy has been done. Private consumption expenditure is now estimated at 3,2 to 3,5% from an earlier 4,2%, while the housing market will continue to stagnate.

"The lower rand should benefit exports of gold and agricultural products; however, this level of interest rates is punitive in light of the inflation rate."

With a real interest rate of 13 to 14%, South Africa is way out of line with the rest of the world, where averages of 3 to 4% are more common. But such rates only serve to encourage further short-term capital inflows, not fixed, long-term investment.

Says Asghar Adelzadeh of the National Institute for Economic Policy: "We don't want short-term capital; that's what got us into this mess in the first place. High interest rates won't necessarily attract foreign investment, but strong economic growth will. We need to establish the environment for domestic investment first, then the foreign capital will follow."

Business and Finance South Africa's Synfuel Plant in Pipeline


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Johannesburg - Sasol is considering building a synthetic fuel plant using gas as a feedstock, says managing director Pieter Cox. 

He said gas would cut out the expensive "gasification" step of Sasol's oil from coal synthetic fuel process.

Sasol, which provided the technology for the Mossgas fuel-from-gas plant, was keeping an eye on Mozambique's Pande gas fields and those off the Namibian coast.

Cox said the construction of a gas synfuel plant -- probably abroad near cheap gas resources -- was increasingly likely given the continuing improvements in Sasol's synfuel technology.

But he said because of government's decision to phase out Sasol's tariff protection for synfuel production, it was unlikely to build another fuel-from-coal plant in South Africa.

Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Scaling Down Stalls Over 'Racist' Salary Scales


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Rehana Rossouw


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Johannesburg - Racial differences in salaries between white and black teaching staff is bedevilling the project to scale down teacher training in the Western Cape.

On Wednesday, about 800 chanting students and lecturers from six colleges marched to the Western Cape Education Department (WCED) to demand an end to discrimination.

The department aims to reduce the number of colleges in the province from eight to four by merging some and closing others. Negotiations to achieve this have stalled over the issue of salaries. 

At a protest meeting recently, Hewat College of Education vice-rector Sidney Scheepers said student enrollment had dropped from 900 to 380 students. The college, which has trained teachers since 1941, was only allowed to enroll 60 first year students this year.

"The department is saying it is too costly to train teachers at between R15 000 and R30 000 each. These kinds of decisions are taken for all reasons besides education," Scheepers said.

Hewat and former House of Assembly-administered Cape Town College of Education began negotiations about merging in 1997. They discovered Hewat lecturers were paid lower salaries than their Cape Town College counterparts, at an average of R13 000 a year.

"We understand that this is a legacy of apartheid, but it is completely out of line with the Educators Employment Act of 1994 and could have been corrected in the past two years," Scheepers said.

"It also means that members of our staff taking retrenchment packages will be severely disadvantaged if their posts become redundant."

In a petition addressed to Western Cape MEC for Education, Martha Olckers, the marchers warned negotiations on the restructuring of colleges would be "in jeopardy" if she did not redress the inequalities by the end of this week.

A spokesman for the WCED admitted there were inequalities in salaries and said they were being addressed in a working group which has been established.

The staff at Hewat and Cape Town College had been informed of its discussions at three meetings this year.

At Wednesday's march, students also protested the closure of colleges and the department's decision not to grant them bursaries this year.

"The retrenchments of teachers throughout the country and the scrapping of their posts means that students at our colleges are being trained for unemployment," Scheepers said.

Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa MPs Must Now Register Their Assets


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Johannesburg - Parliamentarians who lie about their assets in the Register of Member's Assets will be fined a month's pay, and those who leak confidential information to the public from the register will have to pay half a month's salary as a fine.

African National Congress MP Johnny de Lange was overruled by the Rules Committee when he argued for harsher penalties for MPs who leaked confidential information about their colleagues to the public. De Lange claimed that such leaks "could ruin somebody's life".

The rules of the register form part of the code of conduct for parliamentarians adopted by the Rules Committee in Parliament this week.

The adoption of the code, after months of anxious discussion in Parliament, should mean that the register will be set up within the fortnight.

The register will have two parts -- a confidential chapter and a chapter for public scrutiny. The latter will list an MP's assets without attaching a value to them, and the confidential section will list their corresponding value.

Parliamentarians will have to list their financial holdings, payment for jobs done outside Parliament, directorships and partnerships, consultancies, sponsorships, gifts and hospitality, benefits, foreign travel, land and property and pensions.

The register will be published for the first time two months after it is set up and then once a year on April Fool's Day.

The register will be overseen by an Ethics Committee made up of Parliamentarians of whom the ANC will be in the majority.

The code of conduct also prohibits lobbying by members and forces them to declare their interests, if any, in a debate, budget vote or representation in which they participate.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996

May, 1996


South Africa Journalism Under Attack (Editorial)


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Johannesburg - he African National Congress has now developed a fine tradition -- probably in the name of improving its public communications -- of releasing a regular Friday statement criticising the Mail & Guardian.

Last week's was particularly interesting, because it did not attack the content or conclusion of what was, by any international standards, a not unbalanced analysis of the likely presidency of Thabo Mbeki. The ANC attacked the legitimacy of undertaking what was a standard journalistic exercise.

It may be obvious, but it seems necessary to remind the officials of Shell House that the enemies of democracy are not those who ask probing questions, or who are sceptical of authority, or who subject leaders to scrutiny, but those who kill and cheat and steal in such a way that it dashes all our hopes for the new South Africa.

We also this week received a missive from no less than Nobel Prize winner Nadine Gordimer accusing us of "yellow journalism" for reporting that former KaNgwane chief minister and current Parks Board chief Enos Mabuza was implicated in a probe into corruption in the one-time homeland.

It is true that Mabuza may have been the favourite homeland leader of the Gordimer set, but it is difficult to escape the fact that he was linked in the auditor general's report to two problems: that he acquired, without tender, a publicly-owned 19 hectare farm for a few thousand rand; and the accusation that some of the unaccounted millions in loans to the homeland occurred during his leadership. Mabuza may have a sturdy defence, and may want to refute the evidence, but that is what he will have to do.

Is Gordimer suggesting we refrain from reporting official inquiries into corruption?

Surely not.

147 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Mine Ban Provokes South African Labour Outcry


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Johannesburg - Water Affairs Minister Kader Asmal -- already embroiled in the toughest jobs-versus-environment dilemma he has faced since taking office -- is now squaring up to organised labour over the ban he slapped on a marginal gold mine from pumping contaminated water into the Blesbokspruit wetland.

The Grootvlei Gold Mine near Springs on the East Rand, which is pumping 100-million litres of contaminated underground water per day into a nearby wetland, says it will be forced to close down the mine and sack about 2 000 miners by the end of June if the minister sticks to his guns.

And it appears the corporation that manages the mine, Randgold, has some support from an unexpected quarter. National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) assistant general secretary Gwede Mantashe sent an urgent memorandum to cabinet members this week asking them to consider measures that could protect the wetland and save workers' jobs. 

Nine out of every 10 workers at Grootvlei belong to NUM and the gold mines in the region form one of the union's most important power bases. And as a major affiliate of the Congress of South African Trade Unions, the miners' organisation has substantial support in government circles

If the ban extends to other mines in the area that pump polluted water into the vlei -- where high concentrations of iron, manganese, nickel, lead and especially ferric hydroxides have killed thousands of fish and threatened the resource base of the wetland -- thousands of miners could find themselves out of work this year.

While the union has criticised management for failing to control the pollution problem -- thus forcing the minister to take punitive action -- a delegation from the labour organisation visited Asmal this week to express its worry about workers' losing their jobs.

Union representatives told the Mail & Guardian that, while they were concerned about the fate of the wetland, the prospect of mass retrenchments posed a far greater national problem -- and Mantashe's memo to cabinet outlines the "enormous economic implications" if solutions are not found.

Randgold says that the 6 000 people employed underground by five mines in the immediate vicinity of the Blesbokspruit provide 50 000 dependants with their livelihood from salaries and wages that total R122-million a year.

During the controversy last year over the siting of a new steel mill at Saldanha Bay, Asmal went on record as saying that environmental concerns had to be balanced against the need to create and protect jobs for rural communities.

But Blesbokspruit is an internationally protected wetland that sustains a number of bird and fish species and also acts as a natural filter for water that flows into the Vaal River. The minister, as custodian of the country's water resources, was obliged to protect it from destruction by pollution -- and now finds himself caught in a classic jobs-versus-environment bind.

Asmal was forced to withdraw the permit allowing the mine to pump water into the wetland last week because mine management had reneged on an agreement -- made before the permit was issued -- to clean the water to "within tolerable levels" and employ consultants who would monitor the ecological impact of its activities.

NUM's memo urges cabinet to allow temporary pumping for another two weeks while the mine completed construction of temporary "settling ponds" that will remove polluting iron oxide and other metals from the waste water.

Officials in the water ministry say Asmal is concerned about the miners' security and wants a negotiated solution to the conundrum he has inherited.

The minister this week acknowledged 6 000 jobs were on the line and said he would decide about lifting the ban by the end of next week -- and this move would be influenced by his assessment of the settling ponds' ability to mitigate the pollution.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Tanzania Children Drowned In Ferry Tragedy


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Chris McGreal


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Mwanza - More than 450 people, many of them schoolchildren, are believed to have drowned after a Tanzanian ferry hit a rock and capsized on Lake Victoria this week. Only 120 people have been rescued and 25 bodies recovered. 

The disaster happened about 32km northwest of the Tanzanian port of Mwanza, at the southern end of Lake Victoria. Two other ships spotted the MV Bukoba capsize and a number of vessels came to the rescue. But despite their efforts, the ferry, owned by Tanzanian Railways, is reported to have sunk so swiftly that there was little hope for most of the passengers crammed inside cabins and the hold.

Many of the passengers were children returning home at the end of the school term, survivors said. The lake's ferries are also popular with foreign backpackers.

A spokesman from the Tanzanian transport ministry said the ferry was carrying 433 people -- its legal capacity -- but survivors and Radio Tanzania put the figure at 600. "There was no proper procedure for ticketing," one man told Radio Tanzania.

Salim Nsoma, principal secretary at the Tanzanian ministry of transport, said that the search would continue, despite the poor chance of finding survivors. Crocodiles and hippopotamuses are among the dangers in the lake.

Tanzanian President Benjamin Mkapa declared three days of national mourning.

Nsoma said the MV Bukoba had recently passed a seaworthiness inspection. However, Tanzanian railway sources said the ageing vessel had been due for retirement.

The ferry was among many which ply Lake Victoria, usually with passengers travelling between Tanzania, Kenya and Uganda. Traffic on Africa's largest lake is largely unregulated since the collapse of the region's trading bloc, 20 years ago, and the disintegration of the joint East African Railways.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


149 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Uganda Lake Victoria's Carpet Of Death


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Chris McGreal


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

Johannesburg - They call it the AIDS of the Water. The sprawling islands of rippling green plants drifting across Lake Victoria might have been created for a deranged science fiction saga. But in villages along the Ugandan shore the invasion is all too real, and spreading fast.

Uganda is grappling with a plague of Eichornia crassipes, or water hyacinths. Although the plants are strewn across the lake, contaminating shores from Tanzania to Kenya, the prevailing winds carry most of the weed to Uganda. There it brings the economic life of villages to a near halt, contaminating water supplies, clogging the country's hydro-electric dam and threatening to wipe out fish stocks.

Scientists warn that the hyacinths are altering the biology of Africa's largest freshwater lake. Fishermen fear being marooned in their canoes for days when the weeds sweep in to surround their boats. 

Ugandans living beside Lake Victoria say that, after Aids, which has eradicated whole generations in some villages, the water hyacinth is their most serious problem.

A single hyacinth can multiply to a million plants each year. Casting an eye across the lake from Nakiwogo, a small village near Entebbe, barely half of the water between the shore and horizon is visible. The rest is hidden below a vast and impenetrable carpet of hyacinth so thick that in some places children can walk on it.

Nakiwogo relies for its survival on fishing, its ferry to villages across the lake and as a landing stage for food and goods destined for Uganda's capital, Kampala.

These days, the ferry usually does not move; weeds clog the water supplies to the village and towns further inland; and the fishing is a disaster.

"Even if I can get a boat out, when I try to pull the nets out of the water, the fish are already rotten," said fisherman Godfrey Damurira. "The weeds trap and kill the fish in the nets and by the time I get to them they've been dead for days. Once I was out in my canoe and suddenly the weed surrounded me and I was trapped for a day. I couldn't move the canoe."

The hyacinths originate in the Amazon. They are thought to have been brought to Rwanda by Belgian colonists as an ornamental plant for their ponds. With no natural predators in the region, the plants flourished.

About seven years ago the hyacinth made its way down the Kagera river and into Lake Victoria -- the same route the bodies of thousands of murdered Tutsis were swept along during Rwanda's genocide.

Although the hyacinth was first spotted in the lake in the late Eighties, it was only three years ago that anyone thought it a problem.

The young hyacinth has small aerated sacs to keep it afloat. As it grows, its roots develop the feel of a thick feather mattress. Fed by the flow of sewage into Lake Victoria, hyacinths shoot up to three times their usual size.

The south-easterly wind racing across the lake drives the plants together, their roots intertwining to lock into ever-expanding drifting islands. Some as large as 24ha have been spotted. As the plants die they decompose into a thick mud which clings to the roots, helps to feed the rest of the growing island and solidifies the impenetrable mass.

As the islands drift on to the shore and are blown away again, they pick up vermin and mosquitoes, and provide a haven for other plants and snakes.

Uganda's fisheries commissioner, Faustino Orach-Meza, estimates there are 6 000ha of the weed in Ugandan waters alone, and the area covered is doubling every month.

Clumps of weed sweep past the source of the Nile where Lake Victoria becomes Africa's most famous river. A mile downstream, they gather around Uganda's hydroelectric dam at Owens Falls. About 70 000 tons of weed press against the dam's outer wall and engineers wonder how much weight it can take.

The weed already clogs the screens protecting the turbines, forcing periodic shutdowns and raising fears that one day it could bring them to a halt and cut an important source of power not only to Uganda but its neighbours. For years the dam acted as a barrier to the weed, but eventually seeds or young plants made it past the turbines to be swept on towards Sudan and Egypt. The next stop is the Aswan Dam.

Port Bell, Uganda's main port, is so clogged by hyacinth that it can take hours for the large steel hulls of the ferries from Tanzania to cut their way through the weed. The Ugandan government is considering shifting operations to a more sheltered port where the plants might be easier to control.

Orach-Meza fears the greatest threat is to the ecological balance of Lake Victoria. "When the hyacinth completely covers an area, it prevents light penetrating the water and that causes a chain effect, because there's no plankton growth and this cuts the food chain to other life in the lake," he said. "It also affects convection currents and the levels of oxygen in the water. That is all having an impact. If nothing is done, the problems are likely to increase."

The hyacinths are not the first man-made disaster to hit the lake. After the Second World War, colonial British fisheries officers introduced Nile perch, believing they would prove a boon to village fishermen. The perch devastated some of the 300 species of tilapia, and are themselves once again in decline.

Scientists fear the hyacinth will destroy fish breeding grounds and eventually wipe out most of the tilapia and perch. In doing so it would devastate the economy of lakeside villages, which catch about 200 000 tons of fish a year.

In Nakiwogo, they have given up trying to fight the weed by hand. "At first we tried to pull it. But since the weed has insisted on multiplying we've given up. You pull it out and before you've finished it's back again," Damurira said.

Others have offered help. Britain despatched a machine designed to scoop up pond weed and algae from rivers. Its rump is stamped with the Prince of Wales Award for Innovation. On Lake Victoria it clogged up and broke down on its first outing. Today the grey contraption, which resembles a miniature combine harvester, sits idle between a ship and miles of hyacinth at Port Bell.

Other schemes have been hampered by disagreements between Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania about how to tackle the hyacinth, and disputes over the use of herbicides. The Ugandan government is now putting its faith in the promise of two large harvesters from Holland, and in billions of weevils, which proved effective against a similar problem in Australia.

"We've already released a few but the rate of multiplication of these weevils is very, very slow compared to that of the weeds," said Orach-Meza. "You need billions, so they're not having an impact at the moment. For the moment the weed is growing faster than the biological agents."

There is also a scheme to use herbicides, but the three governments disagree about the dangers involved. "But I think, whatever happens, we can only bring the plant under control. We can't eradicate it," said Orach-Meza.

The problem opened new horizons for a while for the Nakiwogo Women's Fishing Group, a collective of 50 widows, disabled women and mothers lacking means of support. When the weed ruined their fishing, they started shipping timber. The group's treasurer, Anne Mpimbo, said they discovered that larger boats laden with wood could sometimes navigate through the hyacinths, whereas lighter fishing canoes could not, and timber trading was far more profitable.

Alas, now even the timber operations have virtually ground to a halt as the hyacinth continues to thicken on Nakiwogo's shores.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


150 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zimbabwe Mugabe Seeks Larger Economic Stake For Blacks


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Harare - As the race debate in Zimbabwe heats up, President Robert Mugabe has aligned himself firmly with hard-line blacks wanting a greater slice of the economic cake.

After his recent cabinet reshuffle, Mugabe slated both Zimbabwean whites and multi-national companies operating within the country.

But some of Mugabe's criticisms are not ill-founded. The multi-national corporations have done less for black advancement in 16 years of independence than most of the country's homegrown industrial giants. Anglo American, Lonrho and Zimasco, (formerly part of Union Carbide's empire,) have mainly white senior management structures. 

However, Zimbabwean business is largely family-owned, with the overwhelming majority of people employed by small businesses. Commercial farmers, nearly all of whom are white, employ about 350 000 people, almost as many as South Africa's gold mining industry.

It is not these whites, though, that affirmative action activists and government are complaining about when they say whites are obstructing black empowerment in Zimbabwe.

Blacks, agitating for control of Zimbabwe's economy, claim 98% of Zimbabwean business is in white hands. And although that figure is obviously absurd, because government owns 40% of the sector in its own right, few whites openly challenged the claim.

Behind closed doors, whites complain and criticise their black counterparts, but they have yet to find a rational representative to articulate their case and present a measured response to the government's increasingly shrill accusations.

In the meantime, shadowy but wealthy black businessman Roger Boka places full-page advertisements in the state-owned and -controlled press, comparing white Zimbabweans with snakes or claiming white accountants employed by white businesses are really former operatives of Rhodesia's notorious Selous Scouts. Mugabe has described the adverts as "understandable".

But Zimbabwe's principal human rights organisation, ZimRights, sees it differently. "It looks like white bashing to me," said Makusha Mugabe, who runs the ZimRights information department.

"While we appreciate the need for some kind of redistribution of wealth, we do not think any reverse racism, or racism, is justified. Affirmative action should not be for the Bokas, but for the majority who are landless, not those who are already rich."

Many ordinary Zimbabweans are deeply sceptical of the two organisations representing black businesses, the Indigenous Business Development Corporation, and the Affirmative Action Group because statistics they quote are so obviously unreliable. They see the two groups practicising cronyism with the small amount of funds allocated by the government delivered to pals and members of the ruling elite.

Neither organistion has delivered any meaningful training or funds to assist aspirant entrepreneurs among the impoverished black majority. Their rhetoric is about taking away white businesses rather than expanding the economy.

"I feel they want to kick me out," said a white businessman who is too frightened to be named. "This is my home and Mugabe is my president, but all this talk of how we are always wrong and how we don't belong is making me seriously worried for my future."

Whites over 30 were almost universally a part of Ian Smith's security forces at some time during the war, so nearly all whites are equally tainted.

Mugabe's huge propaganda machine spares no expense to remind people of the cruel injustices perpetrated by Smith's administration.

That Mugabe's government removed little from Smith's statute books is rarely referred to. Nor is reference made to Mugabe's intolerance of those who do not come from his Zezuru clan, nor of his tribalism, demonstrated by the massacres in Matabeleland in the Eighties.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


151 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Swaziland Swazis Remain Without Prime Minister


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by M&G Correspondent


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Mbabane - Swaziland is without a prime minister two weeks after King Mswati III sacked Prince Mbilini at a meeting of the Swazi nation at the Royal Cattle Byre in Lobamba.

Swazis have been anxiously awaiting a new prime minister, whom the king promised would be appointed after recommendations from a 21-man Swazi National Council appointed two days after the sacking.

At present acting deputy prime minister Sishayi Nxumalo is in charge. King Mswati is on a state visit to Kuwait and was a guest at the inauguration of Taiwanese President, Lee Teng-hui. 

Prince Mbilini's sacking was the climax of six years of pressure for democratic change.

The prime minister's dismissal was not a show of political change, but it calmed the tension. Prince Mbilini was the seventh and most unpopular prime minister in Swaziland since independence in 1968.

During his tenure there were two mass stay-aways orchestrated by the powerful Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions. The latest, in January, brought the country to a standstill for eight days.

Political and pressure groups which have sprung up over the six-year period and the trade unions, have dismissed the sacking of Prince Mbilini as insignificant, saying the real answer to the country's problems was to change the whole political system to bring about democracy.

Swaziland only allows one political party to operate, the Imbokodvo Party. All the country's political ills have been blamed on this system which is the royal family's power base. It has promoted nepotism and favouritism among those in high places and with royal blood.

When the king summoned the nation to the cattle byre, many political commentators expected he would remove the notorious King's Decree of 1973, proclaimed by his father King Sobhuza II, which banned political parties, vesting all authority in the king's hands. But he did not remove the ban.

On the same day, the king opened a people's parliament at the cattle byre, where all Swazis, for the next few days, were to speak their minds on any subject they chose. He appealed for tolerance among those with differing views.

These talks revealed there was clear division among the "progressive", mostly urban forces who strongly advocated the unbanning of political parties, and the "conservatives", led by princes who questioned the wisdom of such a move, claiming it would destabilise Swaziland's peace.

After 23 years of one-party-state politics, many people have become indifferent and are not aware of their rights. Many Swazis do not realise they do not enjoy basic human rights, such as the right to own land.

While there is no law against this, married women cannot acquire a passport or travel document without their husband's approval.

In the rural areas, women are not allowed to acquire land on their own. The bulk of land (Swazi National Land) is in the hands of the King and is distributed through chiefs. -- The Swazi Times

There is also a decree giving the king power to take land from those who have title deed to a property.

Because of the people's love and loyalty to the king, those in positions of power and privilege have used Mswati's name to blackmail others.

Chiefs are answerable only to the king and are deeply conservative. They still have power to evict whoever they feel is disloyal, hence the people's fear of expressing political opinions.

It is because of a lack of vocal opposition the royal family can continue to claim it is only a minority in the urban areas who want change. The majority live in the rural areas and it is impossible to test their political will.

The authorities have argued that the country's political system is unique, because consultation is done at grassroots level through what is called the Tinkhundla system. The system is largely dominated by the chiefs.

It was to explain this system of government that Presidents Mandela, Mugabe (Zimbabwe) and Masire (Swaziland) were recently invited to Swaziland for three days of talks.

While there is an elected Parliament in Swaziland from 55 Tinkhundla consultation centres, the discussions and resolutions taken at the cattle byre over-rule whatever may be decided in Parliament.

However, this system, which goes back through centuries of tradition, has lost popularity because it is dominated by royalty and hangers-on, who later victimise those with different opinions.

In 1991, one member of parliament lost his seat because of what he said at the cattle byre which did not go down well with the authorities.

In February, then Acting Chief Justice Ben Dunn was demoted to an ordinary judge and replaced with a South African advocate because of a judgment he made releasing union leaders during the mass stay-away. Many people are, therefore, afraid in Swaziland.

When the King announced the composition of the Swazi National Council, there was little reaction from the public, because the majority of people who live in the rural areas are indifferent to politics, and the minority, in the towns lost faith in progress following the King's failure to remove the 1973 decree which outlaws multi-party politics.

When King Mswati returned to the kraal on May 11 to close the talks, he acknowledged the nation was expecting him to announce a new prime minister, but said the National Council had not had time to come together and nominate people for the position.

It can safely be predicted that while rural folk will accept whatever they are given, most urban dwellers will ignore the King and continue to pile on the pressure for an overhaul of the whole political system.

A new prime minister will be powerless, in the present system, to make any meaningful change to Swaziland's political life.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa ANC Attacks Story on Deputy President Mbeki


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Johannesburg - The Mail & Guardian's analysis last week of what kind of president Thabo Mbeki is likely to make ("Mbeki: Fit to rule?") has drawn a flood of response.

Mbeki's party, the African National Congress, viewed the article as "a sinister and unjustified attempt to cast aspersions on his political integrity" and "unfair". 

In a statement released within hours of the newspaper hitting the streets, the ANC Department of Information and Publicity said the M&G "is seeking to undermine public confidence in the ANC as a whole -- not through legitimate criticism, but through disparaging portrayals of its leadership" and its approach "lends itself more to political propaganda and shameless mud-slinging (rather than in-depth and critical commentary)".

This was "the latest volley in what appears to be a concerted media effort to denigrate -- without valid grounds -- leadership figures within the ANC".

The ANC accused the paper of portraying Nelson Mandela as flawless, "while criticising unfairly other ANC leaders, the intention being to distance ... Mandela from his colleagues ... It is malicious, dishonest and should be condemned".

Six advisors to Mbeki, who featured in the piece, wrote to distance themselves from a statement that Mbeki's staff "see the president, with his notorious tendency to shoot from the hip, as, at times, a handicap for Mbeki".

"We state categorically that no such statement was made ... we place on record our respect for the president and most certainly value his judgments and immense contribution," the six said.

153 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Parties Battle For The Western Cape


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Rehana Rossouw


LENGTH: 1827 words


 

Johannesburg - Coloured voters are once again the prize as Wednesday's Western Cape local government election gears up for a battle of the titans between the National Party and the African National Congress.

The NP were the victors in 1994 when coloureds chose them to rule at provincial level; this time round all the other parties -- except the NP -- are predicting a swing to the ANC.

The ANC enters the election with two advantages. It has already won 12 uncontested ward seats and the constitutionally entrenched 50/50 clause gives them half the wards in African areas.

The party's real battle will be to win the second, proportional vote. If it wins a majority here, the scene could be set for the Nats to lose control of the only province it governs in 1999. 

Coloured voters comprise almost 60% of the electorate and an overwhelming 68% of them voted for the NP in 1994. The ANC did surprisingly well in the November elections in Cape rural towns, gaining 43% of votes in coloured areas and a majority of seats. This bodes well for the ANC's rural vote next week, but is not expected to have much impact on voters in the metropolitan area.

In the past two weeks, the metro campaign has been bruisingly robust. National leaders of political parties have been glad-handing bemused voters in townships and suburbs across the Peninsula and have taken every possible opportunity to swipe at the opposition.

National politics has provided excellent fodder for the campaign. The NP and the Democratic Party make much of the ANC's national Education Minister's strategy to retrench teachers and the Freedom Front (FF) has received an unexpected boost from the NP's decision to quit the government of national unity.

It has been a relatively clean campaign, except for complaints by the ANC that the NP has whipped up racism to win support; and charges from the NP that they have been prevented from campaigning in African townships.

The ANC is confident of winning more seats than any other party next Wednesday. Its campaign has focused sharply on local issues, its candidates have an impressive track record in community affairs and heavyweight national leaders have been roped in to help spread the message that the party is able to govern effectively.

President Nelson Mandela is casting his vote in Newlands and has been campaigning ferociously in coloured areas in Cape Town. A substantial amount of his time has been spent in one-to-one meetings with families and interest groups.

The ANC is confident of winning the majority of votes in the central substructure, the largest in the metro with almost 500 000 voters. Central has a budget of R2-billion -- one-quarter of the provincial budget -- and will be an important development agency. If the ANC performs well there in the next two years, it will have a convincing message for voters in 1999.

The party's prospects are not as bright in the second-largest substructure, Tygerberg. In this amalgamation of Afrikaans-speaking white and coloured areas thrown together with Khayelitsha, it faces tough opposition from the NP and the FF.

In the rural areas, the ANC is contesting every one of the 27 transitional representative councils. The party should easily improve on the 9% of votes it won there in 1994, but its campaign has been bedevilled by farmers refusing access to candidates.

Apathy among coloured voters would serve the ANC well. It has lost support from teachers, who traditionally are very influential in coloured areas. African voters gave more than 90% of their votes to the ANC in 1994 and are likely to flock to the polling stations once again.

"People have seen through the lies of 1994 when they were told the ANC would take away their houses, their jobs and even eat their dogs in NP election propaganda," said ANC Western Cape leader Chris Nissen.

"That has not happened. What has is that the ANC's Reconstruction and Development Programme has provided them with free health for their children, feeding schemes, the extension of municipal services and sport and recreational facilities."

With a clear win of 53% of votes in the 1994 elections, the NP goes to the polls next week with an advantage. Party leaders and campaign workers say they have not noticed any decline in support and are satisfied that their voters will flock to polling stations next week.

NP leader FW de Klerk and his wife Marike have been hard at work in the province, making more appearances at rallies and walkabouts than provincial leader Dr Dawie de Villiers.

The NP's infrastructure is much more sophisticated in rural areas than any other party and it enjoys overwhelming support from farmers.

The party is making brave forays into African townships, fielding five candidates largely drawn from councillors in former black local authority councils. It is likely to win two wards, in Site C, Khayelitsha and Mfuleni.

Two complaints of intimidation have been made by the NP during the campaign. Western Cape Premier Hernus Kriel said he was turned away from the Mfuleni township by a mob of protesters and Marike de Klerk said she was prevented from addressing squatters in Milnerton.

The NP's MEC for Local Government, Peter Marais, is confident his party will "trounce" the ANC next Wednesday. "Unless the lie factor is very high, the NP has the support of 80% of the voters in the Cape. Black people are still very ethnic when it comes to voting and will probably support the ANC, but their enthusiasm has waned a little.

"The ANC has no coloured leaders who can excite the people like I can."

The DP does not stand much of a chance of regaining the hold on local government it enjoyed until interim councils replaced whites-only municipal rule in Cape Town.

The party's biggest advantage is that it controlled the Cape Town City Council for years and has a track record in municipal affairs. But the DP has not made major inroads in African areas and has no record of community work in coloured areas.

Nevertheless, the party has made a brave effort, with national leader Tony Leon working hard in the metropole. The DP will perform well in its traditional support areas along the coastline and will win some wards comfortably.

The dark horse in the local election will be the Freedom Front which has won unexpected support from NP members confused by their party's decision to withdraw from the government.

The party was also caught slightly off-guard by the enthusiastic response to some of their policies from coloured voters who agree with their campaign to preserve Afrikaans and limit the influx of jobseekers to the Cape.

It should easily improve on its 2% of the vote in 1994 elections. The FF is fielding 33 candidates in wards in the traditionally Afrikaner northern suburbs and has surprised its rivals with the support they are winning.

"We are the refuge of people who have lost their faith in the NP and we are slowly building the foundation for a hectic campaign in 1999," said the FF's Western Cape MPL Eleanor Lombard.

The PAC is fielding only eight candidates in the central substructure, so its hopes rest on drawing support on the second ballot form, where voters choose a party. (In the first ballot, voters choose a candidate for their ward.)

The African Muslim Party and the African Christian Democratic Party are not expected to perform very well, except among people holding strong religious views.

The 50/50 arrangement favours ANC

The Western Cape's demographics has resulted in a unique power-sharing arrangement which could have a major effect on the outcome of the elections.

Clause 245 of the interim constitution allocated 50% of the wards to former white, coloured and Indian areas and 50% to former black local authority areas.

The ward vote counts for 60% of the total in local authorities with the proportional representation party vote making up the other 40%.

The clause was intended to allocate more wards to areas with a smaller amount of voters -- in every other province this meant former white local authority areas -- than there normally would have been.

But in the Western Cape, where whites, coloureds and Indians are the majority of the population, the opposite has been achieved and 50% of wards were allocated to former black local authority areas.

The 50/50 arrangement thus favours the African National Congress, which won over 90% of the African vote in the 1994 elections.

There are six substructures in the metropole: Central (496 490 voters), Tygerberg (418 321 voters), Helderberg (69 853), Eastern (107 471), Northern (57 789) and Southern (165 625).

There are 27 transitional representative councils in rural areas and 152 000 registered voters.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


154 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa InKatha Takes Up Case Of ANC Suspect


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 24, 1996 by Anne Eveleth


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Johannesburg - The Inkatha Freedom Party this week called for the Natal North head of the National Investigation Task Unit, Captain Mandlenkosi Vilikazi, to be charged with defeating the ends of justice, in connection with allegations that he "sprung" an African National Congress suspect from police cells and tampered with a murder docket pending against him.

The IFP call comes amid moves by national Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi to probe allegations that Vilikazi's unit was responsible for the apparent torture death of an IFP suspect arrested by the unit.

In a graphic illustration of the twisted web underlying KwaZulu-Natal politics, Vilikazi slammed the allegations as a "blue lie" and explained that the suspect, Khulenkani Khuzwayo, had been placed in a witness protection programme "more than six months ago" because of fears arising from his role as a witness in several cases handled by Vilikazi's unit.

"Khuzwayo was taken out of police custody following his arrest two weeks ago in connection with a murder case. He appeared in court and was remanded to Eshowe prison. When I learnt that he had been remanded to the same prison where several of the people he is testifying against are held, I approached the prosecutor and asked that he be released into Mandini police cells," he said. 

Vilikazi said the investigating officer in the case -- Eshowe CID Detective-Sergeant John Zulu -- had failed to inform the magistrate of the danger detention in Eshowe prison posed to Khuzwayo. The IFP cited Zulu as the person who had "discovered that the accused was sprung from custody at the Nyoni police cells without his authorisation".

Cases in which Khuzwayo was due to testify included murder charges against local IFP-aligned induna Mandlengqondo Mathonsi, a torture case against the Umfolozi Internal Stability Unit and another against Falakhe Mkhwanazi -- a youth the IFP has accused Vilikazi's unit of torturing.

Vilikazi said Khuzwayo had subsequently appeared in court and was remanded again in a witness protection programme in the Western Cape. The only changes made to the docket against Khuzwayo had been entries reflecting the change in his detention order, and an entry by Vilikazi explaining why he had taken possession of the docket, Vilikazi said.

The IFP also alleged Vilikazi -- together with two other ANC members -- had been present when Vilikazi's unit "assaulted" and arrested IFP member Ngiyane Mhlongo, who later died in custody. Vilikazi said Khuzwayo was in the Western Cape at the time of Mhlongo's arrest.

Mhlongo's arrest and death in detention 11 days later led to a public outcry this week, following a report by independent pathologist Dr Reggie Purumal which concluded that Mhlongo had died of wounds consistent with "assault or torture".

Conflicting police statements on the cause of Mhlongo's death, the similarity of police claims that the suspect "slipped and fell" with the notorious response of apartheid police to the death in detention of anti-apartheid activists, and the suggestions of brutality in Perumal's assessment led Mufamadi this week to appoint KwaZulu-Natal Police Reporting Officer, advocate Neville Melville, to supervise an urgent investigation into the death.

Vilikazi said he welcomed the probe. Denying the allegations that his unit was linked to Mhlongo's death, Vilikazi said his unit arrested Mhlongo on April 17, questioned him unsuccesfully, took him to court on April 18, and "that was the last my unit saw of him, so it's due to the prison's failure to protect him that he died".

Mhlongo had been imprisoned at Eshowe prison, together with his co-accused, the same induna Mathonsi against whom Khuzwayo was due to testify.

The IFP alleged Vilikazi's unit had tortured at least nine suspects linked to the party and had arrested at least 32 IFP members, "many of them on trumped-up charges, as part of a blanket swoop on IFP activists".

Vilikazi responded that his unit had investigated cases based on the complaints of victims, not political parties.

"The IFP has a big problem if, after we have arrested criminals who are killing innocent people, raping the community, burning houses and stealing from people's houses after they have fled, it is then claiming those people are IFP members."


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
