Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa Solons Ask Clinton To Back UN Action in Liberia


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 23, 1996


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Washington, DC - Text of a letter on Liberia from five Democratic Senators and one Democratic House member to President Clinton, delivered May 23. The signatories include Russell D. Feingold (WI), Diane Feinstein (CA), Patrick J. Leahy (VT), Carol Moseley-Braun (IL) and Paul Simon (IL), as well as Rep. Donald Payne (NJ):

We wish to express our deep concern about the recent tragic developments in Liberia and our belief that a new, bolder approach is needed from the United States and the international community.

We have strongly supported the role of the ECOMOG forces since their initial deployment. Given the most recent fighting, however, it appears that the West African peacekeeping operation does not have the adequate resources or capabilities to restore security to this war-torn country. In the absence of a strong peacekeeping force, the major factions have engaged in actions that seriously violate the terms of the Abuja Accord, signed on Aug. 19, 1995. Demobilization efforts have been unable to proceed as scheduled, and major armed conflict has returned to Monrovia. 

We believe that a long-term resolution of conflict in Liberia cannot be effectively realized without the strong involvement of the international community and the United Nations. We, therefore, urge you to propose and advocate among the other members of the U.N. Security Council the augmentation of the existing U.N. mission into a peacekeeping force to be sent to Liberia as soon as possible. The force, which should be drawn from interested African states, including troops from existing ECOMOG forces, should be placed under the authority of the United Nations. The United States can play a role in providing appropriate transportation and logistical assistance.

In our view, the presence of a more robust U.N. force could bring about a cessation of the current round of fighting and could help create an environment in which humanitarian assistance, demobilization and implementation of the political transition process outlined in the Abuja agreement can resume.

The United States has a long an unique relationship with Liberia and her people. For this reason, we have a responsibility to take the lead in helping formulate ways to address this tragic situation. Continued hostilities in the country will only add to the humanitarian disaster and lead to increased regional instability. Accordingly, we have a compelling national interest to take a more active role in securing peace.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


156 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Ethiopia Women Complain Of Harassment


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 22, 1996


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Addis Ababa - Gulit, a small plot of land where women display agricultural or other products for sale, is one of the easiest options for women in search of a means to meet basic needs.

Many pick this informal business which demands but a patch and two are three birr as initial capital. Mostly a domain of women, many of them family heads, Gulit business involves carrying sacks of goods and many other problems.

It is, however accepted as a blessing by most or at least those approached by focus on women "We feel disadvantaged only when we realise that there is no job security for us, when we are chased now and then," said one of the traders. 

The traders especially at Merkato are dispatched all over. They display their goods everywhere; at the pavements and sides of shops and even on the roads and streets from where they think they could better catch the eyes of many buyers.

Such competition by the sellers, no doubt, contributes to the traffic jam and it makes conditions favourable for pick-pockets and other offenders, a situation rampant at Merkato. To avoid this and other chaotic situations police try to clear the streets off these informal traders. Sometimes it looks as if these traders and police play hide and seek. The trader's strife for survival on the one hand and the police duty of maintaining law and order on the other remain incompatible. The traders, in their haste to run from the police drop and lose some and sometimes a great deal of their commodity.At times, they also suffer physical damage as a result.

Rahimush Miskata, an informal trader, said that she sustained a slight injury from a car crush, a year ago, while she was running away from a policeman.

Rahimush and her husband lived on framing in the southern part of the country before they came to Merkato two years back. She said they left their plots to her in laws to join the city life which she said "is more rewarding and worthwhile."

Rahimush also complained of "the guards of shop owners hired to chase us from the areas adjacent to respective shops. I tell you, policemen are a million times more compassionate. These guards throw our goods into ditch waters and beat us severely."

Zenebech Kassa head of a family of four children said she had no choice but Merkato to sustain her family. replying to the question of whether her children go to school, the woman said, "Did you talk about schooling? I don't even earn enough to feed them properly."

Zenebech also complained on the police and especially the private guards whom she said have aggravated her problem.

"What we need is a putch. We do not mean to prosper over the experience of other traders. Ours is a business of survival," she said.

Another information trader Ethemanch Asfaw said that she did not know where to apply for a piece of land to display and sell her goods formally.

Mistre Teferi, 14 sells sweet potatoes in the same way. A resident of Kebele 30 of Woreda 7, Mistre join Merkato after the death of her mother, a year ago.

Mistre has no idea on how to slip out of this life but she looks forward to continue her education and lead a 'stable' life "focus on women" had also talked to W/ro Elizabet W/Gabriel of the Women's Affair's Bureau of Region 14 on how the bureau has been trying to ease the problem.

The education and public relations department head said it was to early for the three-years old bureau to go to great length to alleviate the problem. "We had, however, approached the Project Office for the Creation of Small Scale Business Opportunities for women if we can jointly work to reduce the problem" she said.

The project office has already completed a study and other preconditions to install 100 Gulits in kebeles of nine woredas in the capital. Twenty of the Gulits each accommodating 16 traders are readily available and 320 women drawn from various kebeles are attending orientation on how to go about the business.

The women will also be given some money as their initial capital, according to the department head.

Elizabet said that her bureau takes a great deal of the responsibility to raising funds for and facilitating other preconditions to complete the remaining 80 Gulits and hand them to other women in the shortest possible time.

Moreover, the department head pointed out the need for concerted effort of the community, charities and the government to curb the problem.. "Minimal contributions by the relatively big traders who are opt for getting the sides of their shops clear from the women could make a difference," she said.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Ethiopia Ministry Readies Fight Against Corruption


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 22, 1996


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Addis Ababa - Justice Minister Mahiteme Solomon yesterday told parliament that his ministry has set up various departments with a view to monitoring human rights violations and controlling piracy of government money.

The departments, the minister said would facilitate the work of the ministry geared towards controlling crimes targeted at government revenues and money as well as human rights.

Ato Mahiteme said the ministry has already deployed relevant professionals to the newly established departments. 

He said the departments, besides their routine works, have the duty of investigating the cause and manner of commission of the crimes, devise new working methodologies, undertake researches aimed at effecting the issuance of various laws.

In a bid to fight corruption and crimes, the ministry had tried to solicit aid from foreign governments, which the minister said, have shown desires to help the country.

Based on the Federal Constitution, the Ministry of Justice will draft various bills over the next five years so as to realise the individual, child, women and people's rights, Ato Mahiteme said.

Amending the existing penal, civil and commercial codes as well as procedures of penal and civil laws is part of its work, of which the ministry had already begun work on the improvement of the penal code with the help of foreign experts, he said.

The minister said his ministry has begun implementing its plans to train regional judges, prosecutors and police. About 600 regional and district judges are currently undergoing a six month training in Addis Ababa, he said.

He said the ministry is following up 500 cases of corruption and embezzlement in Addis Ababa and regional states while it has filed charges on half of them.

Meanwhile, Woizero Tadelech Haile Michael, Minister in Charge of Women's Affairs in the Office of the Prime Minister said at the parliament, her office having a serious manpower and financial problems was unable so far to penetrate rural areas to overcome problems of women.

She however said projects enabling rural women to generate incomes, enjoy the benefits of appropriate technologies and get milling services were completed and be launched by the end of this month.

Since the establishment of the Women's Affairs Bureau, efforts were made to set up various offices in the different regional states while studies are being carried out to find solutions to problems of women.

May, 1996


South Africa Mandela Appoints Deputy Ministers


BYLINE: South African Communications Service May 23, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Cape Town - Statement issued from the Office of the President by Acting President, Thabo Mbeki, May 21:

President Nelson Mandela has decided to appoint the following Members of Parliament as Deputy Ministers, to fill some of the vacancies created by the decision of the National Party to withdraw from the Government of National Unity:

Lndiwe Sisulu-Guma - Deputy Minister of Home Affairs

Manto Shabalala - Deputy Minister of Justice

Father Smangaliso Mkhatshwa - Deputy Minister of Education

While the Deputy Ministers-designate will formally assume their positions on 1 July 1996, it is expected that they will, in the intervening period, liaise with their respective Ministers and the outgoing Deputy Ministers, so as to familiarise themselves with their new tasks and ensure as smooth a transition as possible.

Combined with the recommendation of the ANC leadership to the caucus, for the nomination of Baleka Kgositsile as the Deputy Speaker of the National Assembly, the promotion of two additional women into senior leadership positions in Government further confirms the serious intent on the part of Government and the ANC to ensure that women play a critical role in the transformation of South African society into one based on non-racial and non-sexist principles. 

In the interest of fiscal discipline, no further appointments are being considered at this stage. However, the effectiveness of government as currently constituted will be kept under review, and adjustments made if necessary.

159 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Ethiopia Establishes Eight Weather Stations


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 21, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Addis Ababa - The National Meteorological Services Agency announced here Saturday that eight major weather registering and reporting stations have been set up with a view to helping the nation-wide effort of developing the agricultural sector of the economy by building the early-warning weather-forecasting capacity of the country.

Ato Engida Mersha, acting head of the meteorological forecasting and agricultural early warning project, told the Ethiopian News Agency that five of the stations were established in Gewane, Mehal Medda, Lalibella, Tippi and Sawilla in South Omo Zone the remaining three in the Amhara, Tigray and South Ethiopia national regional states.

The stations at different sites are meant to register and report the direction and speed of wind, humidity, amount of rain-fall and temperature, he said. By so doing, Ato Engida said, they will be instrumental in providing the agency with the necessary and essential climatic information. 

The agency, according to Ato Engida, will use the facts it obtains from the stations to corroborate the information it receives via satellite so as to provide the public in general and the peasantry in particular with up-to-date meteorological data.

The agency, he said, can safeguard the public from the threats of wild fire, untimely rain, frost and other dangers by forecasting the weather with the help of climatic information it collects from reliable sources.

Ato Engida stressed the contribution of the agency to farmers who, on the basis of the information they get from meteorological services, have managed to sow seeds suitable for a given season and harvest good yield as the result of which they could pay taxes on time.

According to the standards of the International Meteorological organisation, the major weather stations in Ethiopia are very few in number, the acting head said, adding there is plan to increase the number from 95 to 120.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


160 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Ethiopia Electorate Briefed On Council Election Procedures


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 21, 1996 by: Asfaw Gemmeda


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Addis Ababa - Kebeles in Region 14 held meetings last Sunday in preparation for the council elections to be conducted a week later. The meetings were chaired by election executives who worked as co-ordinators and also gave the briefings.

Topics on which the briefings focused included: allocation of election constituencies, number of kebele council members to be elected and of candidates in each constituency procedures of registration of voters and casting ballots. Kebele residents attending the meetings were acquainted with the different emblems of the candidates and instructed on how to mark or indicate the emblems they chose. 

Candidates fielded for the election were introduced to their respective constituencies, most of them by the Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF). The attendants were informed of the importance of the kebele council elections and urged to cast ballots for competent and honest candidates whom they believed will serve them with devotion if elected.

Ethiopian Press Agency reporters who covered woredas 22, 24, 25 and 7 observed the conduct of the meetings in some of the kebeles and interviewed some of the election executives, candidates as well as voters. Following are some of their views:

Ato Daniale Mamo of Woreda 22 and head of Kebele 03 election constituency said that registration of candidates was completed and that 30 among them have passed the final test. These candidates who were fielded by the EPRDF ruling coalition, were earlier presented to the electorate and screened, he added. According to Ato Daniale, all the necessary materials for the registration of candidates were received promptly and those needed for the registration of voters will arrive during this week ahead of election day. He asserted that no problems were encountered so far.

Ato Nigusse Balcha, head of the electoral board office of Woreda 22, indicated that the candidates will keep on campaigning from 18 to 24 May. He pointed out that 208 candidates are running, of whom 202 are fielded by EPRDF. Six are independent candidates.

Asked why the residents of Kebele 02 and some others in the same woreda did not show up on time, he said that this was mainly due to Sunday's social engagements such as Idir, religious and funeral services. He hoped that people would turn up for the meeting at around 10 a.m. next Sunday.

Ato Mekonnen Argaw, head of the electoral board office of Woreda 24, on his part told the reporters that the woreda comprises ten kebeles, 43 electoral constituencies. He said 433 candidates are campaigning for the May 26 election, 430 of whom were fielded by EPRDF. The remaining three running independently.

Ato Mekonnen, who said that no problems have been encountered so far, stressed the difference between the former kebele elections and the present ones as follows: "Unlike in the past, the registration of voters and casting of ballots will be conducted the same day. This makes the election process smooth and enhances maximum participation, of kebele resident," he concluded.

From among the voters, Ato Desta Azene, aged 42 and an employee of the Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission, had this to say about the briefings given at Kebele 13 of Woreda 24;

"I could learn about the forth coming kebele council election directives from the briefings given. Previously, when the candidates were evaluated, I could keep in my memory as to what sort of candidates I should vote for. "I attach great importance to the present kebele council elections for they serve as a bridge between the government and the people and can make great contribution to the implementation of the five-year peace, democracy and development programme."

A lady voter, woizero Alem Belay, aged 28 and married, also said that she is posted to vote for the right candidates who will devotedly work for the success of the government's development strategy which aims at alleviating problems of kebele residents and the society at large.

Woizero Alem, who advocated the widest participation of women as both voters and candidates, said that women must organise themselves in order to fully possess their rights of equality with men. she finally noted that efficient, honest and devoted candidates should emerge triumphant in genuinely democratic electoral proceedings.

Ato Sisay Lema, one of the 18 independent running, candidates campaigning in Kebele 07 of woreda 25, complained that the election executives did not "treat them equally" with the candidates fielded by EPRDF.

But Ato Fantu Yimmer, Chairman of the administrative body of the kebele, dismissed the complaints as baseless. "They are the ones who caused problems to hamper the smooth conduct of the briefings and discussions," he reported.

Ato Anteneh Debre, member of the election executive committee of Woreda 7, told reporters that briefings and discussions were conducted at 14 kebeles of the woreda. According to him, 507 candidates are running, 470 were fielded by EPRDF, three by Tgri-Wurdgi Unity Party and 34 are independent ones. Turnouts at last Sunday's meetings in all the kebeles were "satisfactory" and election executives were fair in the introduction procedures, he added.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


161 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa State Department Describes Evacuation from Bangui


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 23, 1996


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Washington, DC - Following are the comments of State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns during the daily briefing on May 22 regarding the Central African Republic:

The situation continues to deteriorate in Bangui. As you know, we've implemented an ordered departure for all non-essential personnel.

Secretary Christopher talked to General Shalikashvili this morning about the very, very good assistance our diplomats are receiving from the United States Marines. 

I can tell you, as of late this morning our time, all Americans are believed to be safe in the Central African Republic. We are advising all Americans to defer travel to the Central African Republic. We have formally issued a travel warning.

As you know, we evacuated 13 Americans yesterday. Today, we are evacuating approximately 55 Americans. Of those Americans, most are dependents of our official personnel -- some personnel who are non-essential, several Peace Corps volunteers, and some private American citizens. They will be evacuated from Bangui by U.S. military aircraft.

I can also tell you that France has come to the aid of the United States and American citizens today. French troops rescued 10 American Peace Corps volunteers, who were caught in a cross-fire in downtown Bangui. We're very grateful to the French troops who rescued our Peace Corps volunteers and brought them to safety.

The French troops stationed in Bangui -- I believe there are over 2,000 of them -- have provided protection to all foreigners in Bangui. They have transported a number of Americans to safety and to the airport for evacuation.

We are in good and constant contact with the French Government. We greatly appreciate the French Government's actions on our behalf in this extremely dangerous situation.

As for our Embassy, we have no plans to close it. Our Embassy will remain in Bangui for the time being. We will, of course, want to assess that on a day-to-day basis. We are drawing down some of the personnel, and I would expect that they'll be an evacuation of most of the Americans who live in the Central African Republic, and I believe there are 252 of them.

Q: Do you any details of this rescue?

MR. BURNS: I don't have any more details than that, but it comes on good authority. It comes from our Embassy in Bangui itself.

Q: It's an interesting little story.

MR. BURNS: It is an interesting story. I simply was told that they were caught in the cross-fire. They were pinned down. They could not move, and that the French troops came to their rescue, gave them protection, and brought them to the airport for evacuation. They will be evacuated.

Q: Is there any indication that the people were targets of the fighting, or, as you said, cross-fire?

MR. BURNS: It's hard for me to say from this distance. We don't believe that foreigners, in general, have been targeted over the last couple of days although foreigners, as we've found in Monrovia and Beirut in the past, can be
victims -- unintended victims -- of the fighting, and that's why we've advised American citizens not to travel to Bangui. We are advising those in Bangui and the Central African Republic to leave. We're providing that transportation via U.S. military aircraft.

The Marines will remain in Bangui to protect our Embassy and to protect the Americans there and to bolster our security forces there.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


162 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa Groups Ask U.S. Lead on UN Intervention in Liberia


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 23, 1996


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is a statement by 14 American humanitarian agencies, released May 17 by InterAction, the American Council for Voluntary International Action, a membership association of more than 150 U.S. non-profit organizations. The news release is entitled, "In Response To The Growing Crisis In Liberia, Call For The Creation Of A United Nations Peacekeeping Force":

The prolonged crisis in Liberia has forced nearly a third of the country's population to flee their homes and seek refuge abroad. An additional 40 percent of the population has become internally displaced within Liberia, dependent on others for their survival. The nation's infrastructure is in ruins. Hundreds of thousands of children are unschooled and tens of thousands have been transformed by the warlords into 'boy soldiers.'

The most recent fighting has brought the conflict into Monrovia, resulting in a total breakdown of law and order. Relief agencies and international organizations, which have been providing essential humanitarian services for the majority of the capital's citizens, were forced to leave Liberia. With their offices looted, their vehicles stolen and the lives of their staff at risk in the continuing chaos, it is not clear what assistance they will be able to provide. Relief activities in the countryside also have been disrupted by the spreading conflict. 

Years of negotiations have failed to resolve the conflict among Liberia's warlords. The pleas of the Liberian people for peace continue to be ignored by those leading the various armed factions.

In order to bring an end to suffering of the Liberian people, the undersigned agencies urge:

* That the United States government recommend to other members of the United Nations Security Council the formation of a United Nations peacekeeping force which would be sent to Liberia as soon as possible. The goal of this operation would be to restore security so that conditions can be created that make possible (1) the resumption of humanitarian assistance, (2) the demobilization of combatants, and (3) a political process which will lead to free and fair election of a government of national unity.

* That the U.S. government take the initiative to see that, while units from other peacekeeping-force contributors are being mobilized, the ECOMOG units on the ground in Liberia be brought under the authority of the United Nations. After consultation with ECOWAS, the high command of ECOMOG would be replaced by personnel appointed by the United Nations Security Council. Once under United Nations command, ECOMOG would receive equipment, training and other services provided by donor countries through a fund designated by the United Nations solely for supporting U.N. security operations in Liberia.

* That those West African governments which have provided refuge to almost a million Liberians be commended and encouraged by the U.S. government to maintain open borders for Liberians fleeing their country by whatever means. Particular attention should be paid at this time to the urgent humanitarian needs of persons fleeing violence by sea.

* That the international community be encouraged by the U.S. government to provide more generous support to those West African governments assisting Liberian refugees. The U.S. government should increase its own level of support to those governments.

* That political aspects of the peace process be addressed at a senior level by the U.S. government as acceptable levels of security are achieved by the U.N. Peacekeeping Force in Liberia. It is clear that Liberians and the international community have grave doubts about the viability of the transitional power-sharing arrangement that was created by the Abuja Accords. Nevertheless, it is recognized that the cooperation of the warring factions would be a component of a successful peace process. With this consideration in mind, the U.S. government is urged to ensure that the United Nations permits a role for the Transitional Government created by the Abuja Accords, only if the warring factions participate in a comprehensive demobilization program.

* That the U.S. government take the lead in seeing that the donor community provides sufficient funds for a serious disarmament and demobilization program which will offer combatants the prospect of successful reintegration into civilian life.

* That the U.S. government, in conjunction with the United Nations Security Council, take vigorous steps to see that nations in the West African region and elsewhere comply with the existing United Nations arms embargo on Liberia.

* That the United States naval vessels currently off Monrovia, or replacements with similar capabilities, remain on station off Liberia.

Endorsed by: Adventist Development and Relief Agency International, Africare, American Refugee Committee, CARE, Church World Service, Episcopal Migration Ministries, Friends of Liberia, International Rescue Committee, Refugees International, Southeast Asia Resource Action Center, Trickle Up Program, United Methodist Committee on Relief, World Relief, World Vision US.

For more information, contact Mike Kiernan, InterAction at 1717 Massachusetts Ave. NW, Suite 801, Washington, DC 20036 Phone: (202) 667-8227, ext. 132; or Friends of Liberia at 703-528-8345.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


163 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Terrorism Dawns for Government Foes


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 13, 1996 by Isaac Umunna


LENGTH: 3387 words


 

Lagos - It was like the proverbial writing on the wall. The two private security men guarding house number 16, Felicia Koleoso Street, were engrossed in a discussion with some of their colleagues in the high-brow neighbourhood when a Datsun car pulled up at the adjacent Agbakor Street junction, off Opebi in Ikeja in the wee hours of Monday, April 29. The security men became curious when the car remained parked at the spot for several minutes. At about 1:30a.m., they moved to the junction and accosted the two occupants of the car, who were apparently not in a hurry to leave the area.

Curiosity turned to alarm when the security men noticed a jerry can of petrol and some empty bottles of Ragolis spring water filled with fuel. The tow men were promptly arrested and ordered not to move an inch. On interrogation, one of the men claimed to be from Jigawa State. His companion, who wore long tribal marks across the cheek, gave Benue as his state of origin. The strange men were handed over to a police patrol team which soon arrived at the scene. 

As if on a hunch that the two suspects might not be subjected to the full rigours of the law, the security men asked of the identity of the leader of the police patrol team. They were not obliged, but were simply told that the policemen were members of a crack police squad code-named the Thunder Team, and from the Oduduwa Road police division - the Lagos State police command.

To the night watchmen, the episode of that Monday morning held no special significance until around 5 a.m, last Wednesday when Maxwell Duah, the resident security man at 16, Felicia Koleoso Street, started hearing some strange voices around the compound. He peered into the darkness and was startled to find that the intruders, who had started scaling the fence to gain access to the compound, wielded guns. The men, said to be about eight in number, also had with them a jerry can of petrol, as well as, empty bottles of Evian spring water, filled with fuel.

Duah dived for cover and watched in disbelief, as two of the invaders made straight for the security post, apparently expecting him to be there. Finding nobody there, the men came out of the place almost as soon as they had gone in. Within the next few seconds an explosive device rocked the security post, wrecking it and reducing the two chairs, a bed and a table there to rubbles.

With the first part of their mission accomplished, the intruders lobbed what is suspected to be a grenade into the light blue Subaru Turbo car marked LA 1391 AP and belonging to Funso, first son of Alani Akinrinade, the retired army general whose house was the target of that dawn raid. As the car exploded and burst into flames, the attackers advance toward the oval-shaped, cream-coloured storey building. They broke the front door, gained entrance into the main building, sprayed the place with petrol and set it ablaze.

Funso was roused from his sleep by guttural sound of exploding devices and burning materials. From his room upstairs he saw raging tongues of fire threatening to swallow their posh duplex. Instinctively, the young lad dashed into the bathroom, leaped through the window, landed on the lawns and slipped into hiding.

In about 15 minutes, the operation was over. The messengers of doom bolted into the early morning darkness. leaving behind a massive inferno. By the time neighbours and men of the fire service could answer the frantic messages of the distressed household, the entire ground floor of what used to be a beautiful duplex lay in ruins. Gone were wears and bedding, kitchen utensils, air conditioners and refrigerators.

Also turned to ashes were the rug carpets, furniture, electronics, framed photographs, art works, souvenirs, mementos, service medals and various awards that once adorned the main sitting room. The hanging balcony was burnt, as were the roofs and ceilings. The beams, walls and pillars cracked. The sliding doors and windows, along with the aluminium accessories and burglary proof, were destroyed. of the nine rooms in the house, only two of the upstairs rooms survived the assault. On the ground floor, the lone survivor was a glassed photograph of the absent owner of the house.

Though defaced by heat, the photograph lay protected behind the solid glass encasement, which shielded it from the fire. In the midst of the ruins in what was once a tastefully furnished sitting room, the photograph of Akinrinade in a general's uniform, painted a perfect picture of a man determined to soldier on, no matter the obstacles on his way. And that is exactly what the one-time Chief of Defense Staff has done since early 1994 when he enlisted fully in the pro-democracy crusade. As a staunch member of the National Democratic Coalition, Akinrinade has never hidden his determination to see to the enthronement of democracy in his fatherland. Nor has he ever masked his readiness to bear the consequences of the struggle. It was to keep his dream of democracy alive that he went on voluntary exile later in 1994 to shake off security operative on his trail, and help to internationalise the struggle. Before he left the country in the wake of a renewed crackdown on opposition figures, the erstwhile minister of agriculture had engaged in running battles with security agents. On one occasion, he was arrested and briefly detained along with some other NADECO leaders for their alleged anti-government activities. On another occasion, armed security men stormed his now-destroyed house but met his absence.

Speculations are rife that last Wednesday's attack on the retired general's house could signal tougher times for those in the opposition. In some quarters, the feeling is that the dastardly operation might have been masterminded by either government agents or apologists desperate to avenge the recent spate of attacks on military facilities. The wave of urban terrorism in the country entered a new phase last month with blasts on two military barracks in Lagos, headquarters of the Nigerian military establishment.

First to be hit was the Ikeja cantonment which was shaken by a powerful explosion around 7:30 on the night of Saturday, April 13. The blast came hot on the heels of a power blackout, killing a corporal and at least a civilian. Upwards of 30 other people received varying degrees of injuries. The cause of the havoc was in an unmarked Peugeot 504 station wagon parked minutes earlier near the mammy market by an unidentified man. The car was burnt at the front and rear, while three other vehicles at the scene of the explosion were badly dented, their windows shattered.

April 25, the terrorist moved over to the air force base, also in Ikeja. Around 8 o'clock that Thursday night an explosive device believed to have been hidden in a parked Volkswagen beetle car, went off in the base. The white beetle car was mangled, the engine compartment shattered to expose the crank shaft. This time, however, there was no loss of lives or serious cases of injury. The main victim is said to be a boy who lost his sense of hearing due to the impact of the explosion. He is receiving treatment at the air force medical center. Those behind the explosion are yet to be traced, but the owner of the car used for the operation has been picked up as a principal suspect by the air force police.

Before the blasts in the barracks, the known target of the urban terrorists were civilian facilities. First to taste the wrath of the miscreants were some leading opposition figures. Segun Osoba, accomplished journalist and Third Republic governor of Ogun State, was among the earliest victims. On August 24, 1994, nine gangsters attacked his Dolphin Estate, Ikoyi home in Lagos. They overpowered the two guards at the gate and stripped them naked. In the event, the hapless guards were rescued by their colleagues, who opened fire on the assailants from the back of the house. After a fierce exchange of fire, the gangsters retreated, leaving two security men in a pool of blood. The wounded guards were later taken to the hospital by policemen from patrol 19 unit of the police headquarters.

The experience of the security men at the Anthony Village chambers of militant Lagos Lawyer, Gani Fawehinmi, was more gruesome. They had been caught unawares by gunmen who opened fire on the premises from close range around 3.30 a.m. on August 26, 1994. By the time the guns stopped booming, blood was spattered all around the gate to tell the story better. Two of the guards, namely Mohammed Tworm and Jubril Ema, were critically wounded and had to be placed on Suleiman's Chevrolet Lumina car marked AD 111 GM, smashed the rear windshield, doused the back seat with kerosene and lit a match. They then reached for the air conditioner serving Suleiman's room and attempted to set it ablaze, obviously to create a full-scale inferno to be blamed on electrical fault.

Within days, explosive had come into the picture. The setting was Block A14 in the western wing of Apo Village, Abuja, which once served as quarters for delegates to the defunct national constitutional conference. The apparent target of the terrorists was Muyiwa Oladeimji, an elected conference delegate from Osun State and June 12 campaigner. Shortly before 6 a.m. on September 2, 1994, Oladimeji and some guests, who had debated political developments in the country until 2 a.m., were rudely woken by two ear-splitting explosions. The law maker and his guests were unhurt, but much damage was done to the flat. The aluminium doors and windows were twisted, the louvres broken into bits. The rear entrance of the flat, as well as. parts of the next flat occupied by Yemi Adedeji, another delegate from Osun State, was partly destroyed.

Beko Ransome-Kuti, a leading pro-democracy activist, and Ebenezer Babatope, the first minister of transport under Sani Abacha, a general and head of state, were to experience their own bomb scare later that year. Babatope's house in Lagos witnessed a largely harmless explosion thought to be the brainchild of people angered by his sudden abandonment of the pro-democracy struggle to serve the military government. In the case of Ransome-Kuti, some petrol bombs were allegedly hurled into his residence but were immediately defused to ward off disaster.

From October 1994 the terrorists shifted attention to public places. Taht month, the 10-storey headquarters of the New Nigerian Development Company on Ahmadu Bello Way, Kaduna, was rocked by an explosion. Substantial damage was done to the fifth and sixth floors of the building. Kaduna residents were yet to get over the shock of the incident an explosive device shook Modibo House where the Kaduman arms of the Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria and the Nigerian Television Authority are located.

This time last year the message of terrorism was forcefully brought home to top government functionaries when a bomb explosion at the Ilorin Stadium disrupted the launch of the Kwara State Family Support Programme. In attendance to witness the macabre drama were Abdulkarim Adisa, works minister, Alwali Kazir, erstwhile chief of army staff, Adamu Iyam, Kwara State military administrator, as well as , his kebbi, Ogun and Osun states counterparts. For the impressive crowd that gathered for the ceremony, it was a big shock when midway into the singing of the national anthem, the arena reverberated with a sound reportedly heard tow kilmeteres away. The stadium dissolved in chaos, as everyone scampered in different directions. At least five persons lost their lives, while some 30 others got away with injuries. Some NADECO activists were arrested and interrogated, but were soon let off the hook.

Five months into the new year, indications are that the terrorist are back with a vengeance. Since January, there has been a fresh wave of blasts. January 18, as Nigerians mourned the tragic death, the previous day, of Ibrahim Abacha, eldest son of hte head of state and 14 others in a plane crash, a bomb shook Durbar Hotel, Kaduna. The incident took place around 4.15 p.m and ironically, the chief casualty was one Y.Y. Yusuf, believed to be the possessor of the five-kilogramme bomb. The device, said Muktar Ibrahim, assistant police commissioner in charge of the state investigations and intelligence bureau "was made of foreign components and packaged inside a video cassette and locally assembled." The bomb, explained the police, was powerful enough to demolish the hotel if it had been expertly handled. Thanks to Yusuf's supposed inexperience, the bomb exploded prematurely, with minimal results. It killed Yusuf, wounded Sara Luka, a Durbar Hotel worker, and damaged the toilet,the front office and the banquet manager's office.

The next day, just after 1 p.m., another bomb went off in one of the male toilets at Mallam Aminu Kano International Airport. The bomb destroyed two of the seven toilets and knocked down a portion of the rear wall of the departure hall of the airport.

As it were, the bomb was a crude one, locally fabricated and incapable of doing much harm. The main aim of the person who planted it might have been to frighten the multitude of dignitaries then flocking to Kano to condole the head of state and his family. Following the blasts in Kaduna and Kano, some Yoruba leaders in Kaduna were arrested, quizzed on their political views and then released. Like in the previous cases. police investigations are belived to have reached a dead end. The police, according to Dickens Sanomi, until lately an assistant inspector-general of police, are ill-equipped to ensnare the terrorists who appear determined to perpetuate their reign of terror. The terrorists, in Sanomi's words, are "people of great wits, politically motivated" and ingenious enough to leave no trace when they strike.

Sanomi, who recently retired from the service, appeared to have read the mind of the government when he propounded the theory of politically-motivated blasts. It is said that in government circles, the spate of balsts, especially the recent ones in the military barracks, is believed to be the handiwork of NADECO activists abroad. Instructively, the assault on Akinrinade's house came three days after a Lagos-based weekly magazine reported alleged fears by the government that the blasts might be an indication that its foes had penetrated the barracks. The report claimed that "investigating authorities . . . have narrowed the bomb explosion at the Ikeja military authorities to be behind the blast at the cantonment. "Military investigator," claimed the report, "are said to have described them (Akinrinade and other suspects) as desperate and frustrated after failing to destablise the Abacha junta."

Incidentally, the thinking among Akinrinade's family and friends is that the attack on his Lagos house is aimed to intimidate him to abandon the pro-democracy struggle. But that seems unlikely. As a close relation of the retired general told Theweek, was aware that the struggle would be long and costly. On the destruction of his house, the relation said: "He would naturally be shocked, but as a soldier, he would take things in their natural stride; after all, the deed has already been done."

It is such commitment to the pro-democracy struggle by Akinrinade and his co-travellers in NADECO abroad that seems to be driving the embattled Abacha administration to wits end. Determined to fend off further attacks on its soft underbelly - military facilities - the military regime has ordered that new security measures be put in place in the various barracks.

The measures, recently spelt out by Fred Chijuka, director of military information, involves a ban on the parking of vehicles near the b arracks. Vistors to barracks nationwide would also be thoroughly screened. Hear Chijuka: "Ladies who carry bags into barracks, military men and other civilians will be properly screened. It will cause a lot of inconvenience on all of us, but there is no other way of doing it because these things (the blasts) are done by human beings."

By last week, the measures announced by Chijuka were fully in place. At the Ikeja cantonment, Blade Gate, which used to be closed around midnight before the explosion, is now closed at 6 p.m. The barracks is patrolled throughout the night. Wanderers who are unable to satisfactorily explained their mission in the barracks are arrested and detained.

The security at Ikeja air force base is even tighter. The main gate is now opened only two times during the day - from 7 t0 7.30 a.m. when people are supposed to go to work, and from 3.30 to 4 p.m. when they are expect back. The pedestrian gates are open till 8 in the night, although only visitors who show their identity card are allowed in. Inside the base, the drinking parlours and the mammy market, which used to operate till dawn prior to the blast, now close shop at 8 p.m.

Nsikak Eduok, chief of air staff, visited the base on Thursday afternoon. He spoke with senior officers, apparently on the bomb scare and ways to prevent a re-occurrence. Theweek learnt that Chuma Nwankwo, commandant of the base, has been re-deployed to Kaduna. It could not be confirmed if the development has anything to do with the embarrassing blast at the base. In these days of sporadic, unresolved terrorist attacks, it is not only people's lives and property that are at risk. The jobs of those charged with ensuring security in the barracks and other strategic government facilities are equally at stake.

With Yusuph Olaniyonu, Taye Ige, Felix Ojogwu, Ukpong Kalu Mba and Rufina Nsofor.
To contact The Week, telephone (301) 565 2753 in the United States, e-mail: Theweek@primanet.com. Web: http://www.afrika.com/theweek

LANGUAGE: English

164 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Youth To Shell - 'No, Not Yet!'


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 27, 1996 by Wisdom Dike


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lagos - In a move characteristic of the Ogoni struggle, the youths of Ogoniland under the umbrella of National Youth Council of Ogoni People (NYCOP) have rejected the plans set out by Shell Petroleum towards resumption of oil exploitation in the area.

This is contained in a statement issued in Port Harcourt and signed by Needam Befii, acting secretary-general of the association. The Youths insist that oil activities can only resume in Ogoni when certain conditions are met. Insisting that the demands contained in the Ogoni Bill of Rights are still relevant, the youths maintained that Shell and the Nigerian government must fulfill the terms of that document. 

Disturbed by the recent meeting of some Ogoni traditional rulers with the Rivers State government on the Shell plans, the youths warned that only discussions involving MOSOP (Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People) and decisions approved by its leadership can be binding on the Ogoni. It also demanded the withdrawal of all military and para-military troops stationed in Ogoniland "before any meaningful negotiation can take place." If further stated that the Ogoni people were prepared to lay down their lives if their demands are not met.

Worried by these pronouncements, some Ogoni chiefs, Theweek learnt, have advised the government to beef-up security in Ogoniland to forestall any unfortunate incident. Shell management was said to be worried by this development which has stalled plans articulated by their consultants on ways to return to Ogoni.

A MOSOP activist told Theweek that nothing can bring Shell back to Ogoni land even in the next 50 years. His words: "we seem to lose our sense of history so quickly. How can this generation of Ogoni forget the pains of the death of their people and allow Shell to come back. Any other company can drill in Ogoni, not Shell. The pain is still there and the anger very much afresh."

Shell management in Nigeria had offered to clean up the oil spill in Ogoni and work out acceptable community development programme for the people. The offer is seen as a Greek gift.
To contact The Week, telephone (301) 565 2753 in the United States, e-mail: Theweek@primanet.com. Web: http://www.afrika.com/theweek


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Cameroun Dangles Oil Carrot


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 27, 1996 by Uze Ndu


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Lagos - The ministry of Foreign Affairs has intensified efforts at investigating information which filtered into the country from the Republic of Cameroun. The fear last week in Abuja is that this might be the beginning of renewed hostilities between Nigeria and Cameroun over the ownership of the Bakasi peninsula.

Cameroun is said to be offering mouth-watering incentives to oil prospecting companies, in the form of tariff concessions to such companies willing to prospect for oil in the disputed area. Oil firms which accepted to operated in the area would have unimpeded rights to prospect oil in Bakasi, now classified by a recent Camerounian law as "marginal fields." The companies have an option of paying compensation to Cameroun in cash or in kind. Sources say the deal is primarily designed for oil companies that are mainly based in France. 

Cameroun is laying claims to its Law No 95/13 which was passed by its National Assembly last August 8, and signed into law by Paul Biya its president. Section 4 of the law gives special concessions to oil prospecting companies which accept to embark on mining activities in the area. The law is divided into 11 sections with emphasis on promoting the production of liquid hydrocarbons in "marginal fields" identified within the sedimentary zones of the Camerounian territory and extending off-shore up to a limit of its territorial waters.

Nigerian government officials at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs who got wind of this law from Nigerian officials in Cameroun are said to have warned that Cameroun's action is bound to have serious implications and consequences on the dispute between her and Nigeria over the ownership of Bakasi. This new development, they said, should be viewed seriously by Nigeria because of its long term implications for relations between the two countries especially concerning border matters.

Only recently, Cameroun announced with a lot of fanfare the discovery of crude oil inin Rio Del Rey area of Bakasi. And to give legal backing for its action, Cameroun had to promulgate Law No 95/13. The director-general in the political affairs divisions of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has been liaising with officials from the cabinet secretariat in the office of the secretary to the government of the federation to investigate the matter. Already, a memo which originated form the International Economic Co-operation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is said to have been brought to the attention of the head of state. The memo pointed out the danger signals over the Camerounian action, urging the government to act swiftly to prevent Cameroun from further worsening the conflict which is being handled by the International Court of Justice. The renewed hostilities, which Nigeria maintained was sparked off by Cameroun on April 24, is not unconnected with the determination of Cameroun to enforce its law No 95/13. The state for the current hostilities, sources say, was set February 3, when soldiers on both sides exchanged fire power.

Since then, Walter Ofonagoro, the Nigerian information minister, and Augustine Knochu, his counterpart in Cameroun, have said that the conflict was sparked of by the other side. While Cameroun claimed that Nigerian soldiers first launched an attack on her gendarmes, Nigeria maintained that it was Cameroun that ambushed Nigerian soldiers on patrol, while, in self-defense, they fired back.

Fred Chijuka, Nigeria's director-general for defense information, said that the heavy fireworks, which were heard in Calabar two weeks ago, indicated that the attack was being launched by the Camerounian side. "Otherwise, the sound would have been heard this way at all, because the forces would be directed towards Cameroun," he argued.

Intelligence reports indicate that with the mouth-watering offers being made by Cameroun, some oil companies in Nigeria may have started subterranean moves to sponsor aggression on the side of Cameroun so that they can eventually gain the rights to oil prospecting in the area. Since section 3 (d) of the laws in Cameroun stipulate that any establishment, their subsidiaries or affiliates wishing to undertake exploration and appraisal work within the free sedimentary zones could do so independently, or in partnership with the government, many oil companies may jump at such an opportunity that will enable them to engage in unwholesome oil deals.
To contact The Week, telephone (301) 565 2753 in the United States, e-mail: Theweek@primanet.com. Web: http://www.afrika.com/theweek


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Washington Tightens The Noose


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 27, 1996 by Chigbo Anichebe


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Washington DC - The United States Congress sent a strong signal to the Nigerian leadership under Sani Abacha, that Nigeria must move towards a new political and economic structure and improve its human rights records or face the prospects of strict economic embargo.

According to Nancy Kassebaum, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Sub-committee on African Affairs, Nigeria, once seen as a rising economic star in Africa, has fizzled into one of the 20 poorest nations in the world as a result of corrupt and ineffective leadership. The committee met in Washington last Wednesday to consider a bill authored by Kassebaum and co-sponsored by 22 other senators calling for imposition of oil embargo and other sanctions against Nigeria. 

In his testimony before the sub-committee, Peter Tarnoff, the United States undersecretary for political affairs, said the Clinton administration also believes that a broader consensus and a stronger message will ultimately result in more effective measures against Nigeria. Tarnoff told the sub-committee that "it would be a grave mistake to conduct business as usual with Nigeria in the absence of significant progress towards a credible programme for the return of civilian democratic rule and respect for human rights. he said that the Clinton administration will raise the issue of Nigeria at the summit meeting of the eight industrial nations in Lyon, France, next month in the hope that the heads of state will condemn Nigeria's actions. he also noted that "while we prefer collective measures we have not ruled out further unilateral actions by the United States."

Tarnoff noted that the UN resolutions and Commonwealth recommendations along with the measures that the European Union and the United States already have in place demonstrate that the international community will not permit the gun to impede democratic progress or disregard human rights with impunity. He pointed out that the Clinton administration will not wish Nigeria to become a pariah state that might use if s influence and resources recklessly and irresponsibly. he however assured the sub-committee that Washington will be willing to deal with Abacha if he restores habeas corpus and an independent judicial process which does not rely on special tribunals and release all political prisoners.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


167 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Foreign Minister's Future in Doubt


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 27, 1996 by Emmanuel Ado


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Lagos - Since Tom Ikimi, minister of foreign affairs, got to know that Wada Nas, minister of special duties, left for China two weeks ago, on an official assignment, Ikimi has been terribly worried. And he has every reason to be. Unlike before his celebrated China goof where he reportedly described Ibrahim Babangida as Nigeria's reigning head of state, Ikimi was not informed of the urgent assignment that Nas was to undertake in China.

Not being a stranger to the vicious Aso Rock politics, Ikimi concluded that the government might after all be interested in getting to the root of the China debacle. And going by Nas' reputation as the hatchet man of the Abacha administration, Ikimi, is said to have convinced himself that his days in the cabinet are numbered. 

Theweek authoritatively learnt that Nas' mission to China is to investigate Ikimi's alleged goof, which is said to have made the Abacha government a laughing stock in diplomatic circles. Nas is to confirm the authenticity of the report that Ikimi reportedly referred to Babangida as the Nigerian head of state, three years after he was forced to step down. Nas is to also find out if indeed Ikimi kept the Chinese prime minister waiting for two-and-half hours, and that he refused to pay parking fees to the Chinese aviation authorities for the presidential jet which conveyed the delegation to China.

Sources told Theweek that Nas has had an extensive discussion with the Chinese authorities and one Illela, a Nigerian journalist with the BBC, based in China. Nas' trip is said to have become necessary because members of the Ikimi delegation have not been helpful. They reportedly described the report on Ikimi as false. But going by the Nas mission, the government seems to have accepted the interim report of the three-man committee that Ikimi committed the offense. Theweek learnt that part of Nas' brief is to tender an unreserved apology to the Chinese government, which, according to sources, has lodged official complaints to the Nigerian government over Ikimi's conduct.

The government is said to be going the extra mile to get to the root of the China debacle because, as one of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, it is banking on China to help veto any sanctions against Nigeria. Due to the face-off between the Abacha government and the international community, the government has embarked on an aggressive economic mission Asian and Latin American countries. No month passes without a government official visiting any of these countries, including Iraq, as it has placed its survival, in the event of sanctions, them.

The three-man committee investigating the Ikimi affair is expected to submit its report within the next two weeks. Going by the haste with which Nas is going about the assignment, the committee is very likely to meet its deadline. But as is the style of Abacha, no immediate action should be expected. In fact, Nas was said to have complained to a friend that, but for Abacha's cautious style, Ikimi would have been removed. Nas cited the Ibrahim Dasuki affair that took Abacha almost one year to dispose of. And, for effect, he reminded his friend that the Dasuki affair has not been fully accomplished, giving a hint that government might still move against Ado Bayero, the emir of Kano. Late last year, Nas had accused two high-ranking traditional rulers, one in the North West and the other in the North Central, of teaming up with the National Democratic Coalition not destabilize the country. It was the beginning of Dasuki's woes.

If and when Ikimi gets the boot, he may take it in his strides. His case might be like that of Uyorchia Ayu, the former senate president who served in Abacha's first cabinet as education minister. Nas was said to have plotted his exit. It was Nas that reportedly told the head of state that Ayu had ordered the Nigerian High Commission in London to settle the bills incurred by Bola Tinubu, an opposition politician in exile, on car hire services, as well as pay the school fees of the son of Justin Tseayo, former director-general of the National Institute for Policy and Strategic Studies.

Indications that Abacha would soon move against his men is becoming clearer each day. Like the last time, Abacha has refused to release capital allocations to the ministries.
To contact The Week, telephone (301) 565 2753 in the United States, e-mail: Theweek@primanet.com. Web: http://www.afrika.com/theweek


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


168 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria "Father of the Nation" - Azikiwe


BYLINE: Theweek (Lagos) May 27, 1996 by Isaac Umunna


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2494 words


 

Lagos - Six months shy of his 92nd birthday, Nnamdi Azikiwe, father of the nation, dies without witnessing the emergence of the great Nigeria dreams.

Twice - in 1976 when he had a delicate surgical operation, and in 1989 - he was widely reported to have died. On both occasions the news turned out to be a gaffe.

But this time it is for real, Nnamdi Azikiwe, Owelle of Onitsha and foremost nationalist, is no more. His death, May 11, brought to an end a seven-month battle by doctors to save his life. Zik, as he was fondly called had suddenly taken ill late last October. For two weeks he was treated at His Onuiyi haven, Nsukka, home by Onuorah Ekpechi, a professor of endocrinology and Zik's personal physician for some 30 years. Rather than improve, Zik's condition worsened. November 14, the patriach was admitted at the University of Nigeria Teaching Hospital, Enugu, on Ekpechi's advice. 

By then Zik was partially unconscious and, to borrow Ekpechi's words, "in very poor health condition." For days after his admission, the sage was very weak and experienced severe pains. he could not eat well, nor was he able to ease himself unaided. Ekpechi had to spend upwards of six hours a day to attend to his celebrity patient, who was certified to be in a state of acute medical emergency.

Over the next weeks and months the health of the elder statesman improved or nose-dived depending on the state of his mind. On March 22, Ekpechi told Theweek that the Owelle had recovered to the extent that "he effortlessly fed, clothed and eased himself without much help. He discusses freely and normally, enjoys watching the CNN (Cable News Network) with all the commentary appropriated to the aspects of the programme." Even then the doctor admitted that Zik was "not back to his usual state of health." He equally admitted that medical facilities in the country were inadequate to ensure appropriated treatment of the ailing legend.

Aware of such limitations, the Sani Abacha administration had February 16, offered to fly the father of the nation abroad for better medical care. The offer was made through a delegation led by Jeremiah Useni, a lieutenant-general and minister of Abuja, the federal capital territory.

As exclusively reported by Theweek in its April 8 edition, the elder statesman rejected pleas by the government, as well as his friends and relatives, to seek treatment abroad.

Reason: He felt that the inevitable end was near and as a thoroughbred nationalist, preferred to die in his fatherland. In the story in question, Zik was reported to be so disgusted with the sorry state of affairs in Nigeria that he wished for death.

For a man who dedicated his life to the struggle for the emancipation of his countrymen form the clutches of colonialism and misrule, the past few years brought excruciating mental and emotional agony. On October 1, 1960, when he proudly took the oath of office as the first indigenous governor-general, Nigeria was touted as the giant of Africa and potential leader of the black race. Soon, those lofty dreams were up in smoke. So monumental was the crash that as at the time of his demise, black Africa's most populous country had become classified among the poorest nations in the world.

Going by Ekpechi's explanation in an interview with this journalist last week, Zik's frustration dated back some three decades. According to the renowned endocrinologist, by 1965, barely two years into Zik's tenure as Nigeria's first president, the celebrated nationalist was already reeling with bitterness about the state of affairs in the country. Reminiscing about the early days of his association with Zik, Ekpechi said: "We journeyed from Lagos to Nsukka, and often he sent for me and we will sit and talk. During one of those several talks, he said: 'I am so unhappy about what is happening in the country.' He said that this is not the country he fought for."

After the great one had poured out his heart, Ekpechi, then an exuberant youth of about 30, summoned up courage to advise him to resign as president "because the problem of your health has to do with the state of the mind." Zik thought about the young man's advice fro some minutes and felt that it made sense. he accepted it. Ekpechi asked him what it was that gave him the greatest pleasure. Zik: "Writing and fighting for the common man." His young friend urged him to do just that. Zik seemed ready to play along, for "the following two weeks he dispatched vehicles to Lagos to collect the remnants of the Pilot Press, (with which Zik as a fearless journalist published a chain of anti-colonialism newspapers from 1937 to 1960) to bring back home. He was to resume fighting. That was in 1965."

Somehow, things never worked out that way. On his youthful doctor's advice, the president, who was afflicted by a "succession of illness," went to London to see the Queen's physician. With his health soon back to normal, the idea of returning to his old love - journalism - drifted away from his mind.

Unknown to Zik, the early '60s, the events of which had made him frequently ill, would turn out to be regarded as Nigeria's golden years. Genuine democracy and economic development for which he yearned, were to take back seat in the scheme of affairs from January 15, 1966, when the military rudely interrupted the country's fledgling democratic experiment. A countercoup six months later and a gruesome three-year civil war that raged from 1967, literally wiped off whatever gains were recorded by the country after independence.

Believing that the situation could still be salvaged and that he had a role to play in that, Zik offered himself for president at the advent of the Second Republic in 1979. He failed, as his Nigerian Peoples Party lost to Shehu Shagari's National Party of Nigeria in the elections. he tried again in 1983. Yet another failure. The veteran politician sensed that he had exhausted his luck and promptly bade the soap-box a permanent good-bye. As it were, the military struck once more December 31, 1983. From then, Zik and other patriots prayed for a return to civil rule, which he hoped would chart the course of a great Nigeria.

When Zik left for Canada for medical checks shortly before the June 12, 1993, presidential polls, it was with the expectation that on his return, he would be received by a democratically elected president. But that was not to be, as the military government of Ibrahim Babangida chose to annul the result of the election. Zik bristled with disappointment when he learnt of the unfortunate development. "From the legal angle, "the sage later told Moshood Abiola, presumed winner of the election who visited him in his Nsukka home October 5, 1993, "Since our democracy is based on the rule of law, whatever is done that is contrary to law will be undemocratic and will not represent the view of the majority of our people." He questioned "the legality of the cancellation of an election which was said to be free and fair." lamented the political grandmaster: "This cannot be what we fought for, because we fought for Nigeria to become a democracy based on the rule of law." He counseled!

that "a mistake was made and if a mistake was made, it should be rectified." Three years later, Abiola remains in detention for attempting to reclaim his supposed mandate, w while the Abacha regime has spurned global entreaties to respect human rights and quickly return power to civilians.

For Zik, the ultimate heart breaker was to come last October 30, when Ken Saro-Wiwa, the Ogoni folk hero, was convicted alongside eight other activist, the climax of a controversial murder trial. The hasty hanging of the men November 10 touched the raw nerves of the international community, which rained sanctions on the country, turning her into a pariah. Seiko's heart literally stopped beating. As exclusively reported by Theweek early last month, the health of the ex-president reached a crisis point with the Ogoni debacle.

Like a pendulum, Zik's condition dramatically swung to the valleys two weeks ago. march 10 the patriarch went into a coma. As if it was meant to be a bad omen, Patrick Okolo, the Owelle's townsman and chief medical director of UNTH, died that night. Okolo, who became UNTH boss four years ago, had been seriously sick since early last month, the health of the ex-president reached a crisis point with the Ogoni debacle.

Zik woke up some hours later but only briefly - for a final glance at the world which he always said he was fond of and not in a hurry to leave. By 11 p.m. that Saturday, it was time for the legendary nationalist to drink of the cup he alluded in one of his works, Thenatosis" "One day, we must vacate this bounteous earth and travel to a world beyond our ken. All human problems will by then abate."

A member of the medical team that attended to Zik in his last hours told Theweek that it was a miracle that the political icon survived for the much he did. Said the source: "Zik was in bad condition the whole of that week to the extent that we did not know that he would survive up to Saturday when de died."

According to hospital sources, one of the laboratory tests carried out on Zik during his days in UNTH suggested "renal problems or renal involvement: which means in the lay man's explanation, that he may have died of kidney problems." The sources explained that the kidney connection was not unusual for a man of Zik's age. Other subsequent tests on the elder statesman indicated that he had arthritis. Theweek learnt that during his stay in the hospital, Zik often complained of general weakness and severe pains. To ensure that details of his illness remained a top secret, Zik's name was neither written on his folder, nor were his diagnosis, tests and prescriptions.

Those who were with Zik in his last minutes were Uche, his wife, duty nurses and Ekpechi. According to hospital sources, Zik did not struggle with death when it came. "He simply gave up, " said a source. By the time he passed on, the elder statesman's kidneys were said to have been so badly damaged as to ensure that he died quietly. Immediately he gave up, Uche shouted at the top of her voice and started weeping. Ekpechi, who reportedly was also in tears, bravely put up a manly face and consoled her. It was Ekpechi who made the first contact with the government and Zik's son, Emeka, who was said to be in Abuja at the time his father died. Others that were contacted were Chukwuma, Emeka's elder brother, Emeka Ojukwu and Chekwas Okorie, a politician and cultural crusader based at Enugu. The same evening Uche was said to have checked out of the hospital to the family home in Nsukka. She later left for Onitsha.

Zik's body was removed to the Eastern Nigeria Medical Centre, also in Enugu, later in the night, by UNTH ambulance in the company of Ekpechi, Ojukwu, and other unnamed Onitsha indigenes and officials of the Enugu State government.

Expectedly, news of Zik's death threw the nation into mourning and people spoke glowing of his priceless qualities. In his tribute, Adeniran Ogunsanya, arguably the closest political associate of the former president, described him as a rare breed. "The great Zik," said Ogunsanya, one-time chairman of the disbanded NPP, "was ready to stand his ground at all cost when he thought it was wiser for the sake of the unity of the country... He refused to accept the use of tribalism to achieve some of those things he set out to achieve. he never believed in tribalism. He never took decisions behind our back. Consensus was the word."

Although his death has been confirmed by authoritative sources, Zik is yet to be officially pronounced dead. As an Onitsha high chief, tradition dictates that only the obi-in-Council, in consultation with his family and ndichie (elders) could announce such a development. The announcement would. however, have to wait until the performance of certain rituals, a process which could take all of a month.

As at press time, a flurry of meetings involving Zik's family, Onitsa ndichie, the Obi-in-Council and the government were being held. The consultations would serve as a prelude to the formal announcement of the passing away of an accomplished athlete, journalist, scholar, politician, leader and freedom fighter. Also being discussed at the various meetings are plans for his burial.

Meanwhile, the man of history remains technically alive pending the official proclamation of his death. Even after that much-awaited proclamation, the Zik of Africa would continue to live in the hearts of those whose lives he touched in several ways during his eventful sojourn in the planet very much after his heart

With Louis Onyia, Enugu and Amos Esele.


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Ethiopia Over 11,900 Candidates Registered in Addis


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 18, 1996


LENGTH: 870 words


 

Addis Ababa - Representative of the Region 14 Electoral board yesterday said his office has started verifying the candidature endorsement signatures of the over 11,900 independent and party affiliated candidates for the upcoming kebele council elections to be held on May 26 in the capital.

According to Ato Assefa Tadesse 11,620 contestants are fielded by EPRDF, four by the tigre Worji Nationality Democratic Unity Party (TWNDUP), while the rest 290 are independents. 

The deadline for candidates registration expired Wednesday he said adding verification of candidature endorsement signatures is expected to be completed today.

Meanwhile, of emblems of candidates which include among others balance, spear and shield, elephant, cup, tractor and sickle were made official yesterday it was learnt.

Likewise, some eligible voters here in the capital expressed readiness to cast ballots to candidates who are trustworthy and capable of discharging their duties and responsibilities.

Ato Anteneh Tekaligne, resident of Kebele 02 in Woreda Six said the public have promoted its appraisal experience which would have a positive bearing in carefully electing kebele council members.

Ato Abera Ahmed and Ato Assefa Teferi, residents of Kebele 33 in Woreda 3 and kebele 03 in Woreda 13 respectively said winners of the election to be held recently would have the responsibility to initiate the republic for development undertakings in a bid to improve living conditions.

Independent candidate Girma Desalegn, resident of kebele 03 in Woreda 13 on his part said he has solicited candidature endorsement signatures without any problem and if elected is ready to contribute his share towards alleviating social problems specially the pressing shortage of residential quarters.

EPRDF fielded candidates, in Woreda 3 kebele 33, Woizero Asefash Tesfaye and Ato Haile Selassie Gebre Selassie pledged to translate into practice the five year development plan if elected.

Zambia India Assured Of Support


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia will continue to work closely with the government of India to enhance and consolidate the warm relationship, President Frederick Chiluba said today.

In a congratory message which was sent to newly elected Indian Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, Mr Chiluba said the warm relationship which exist between the two countries should even further be strengthened for the benefit of the people. 

He explained that the challenges that lie ahead for the newly installed Indian premier were enormous but that people of India has shown the confidence in him because of his vast experience in public and party services.

Mr Vajpayee, from the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) succeeded P. V. Narasimha Rao to become the first Hindu nationalist Indian premier.

May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Women Declare For Peace


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency May 19, 1996


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - The Women's Lobby Group has issued a declaration of peace in the African region which strongly condemns all sorts of violence and threats to peace currently taking place.

Chairperson Ms Gladys Mutukwa said in an interview that women in Zambia and other African countries condemn the perpetrators of violence as women are the most vulnerable when wars breakput in their countries.

Ms Mutukwa said the lobby group will soon send the declaration, which also calls for the inclusion of women in peace negotions, to the organisation of african unity (oau). 

She regretted that although women are the ones who suffer most when wars break out, they are left out when it comes to peace negotiations.

"The declaration seeks for the recognition of women in peace negotiation processes through out Africa," she said.

The declaration was one the resolutions passed at the just ended regional workshop for women in politics.

Ms Mutukwa also condemned the recent bombing of State

House outer wall and for which the "Black Mamba" group has claimed responsibility, saying there are better methods of resolving grievances. She said as a non-partisan group, the Women's' Lobby discourages any threats to peace be it from the ruling party MMD or the opposition.

And Ms Mutukwa said the lobby group is working flat out to ensure that more women participate in the forthcoming presidential and parliamentary elections as part of the implementation of the beijing platform of action.

She said the area is still critical as most of the women in the world are left of out in the political arena which is important for national development.

Ms Mutukwa said most governments continue using women for entertainment and hospitality purposes only other than political decision making.

"This trend will continue seeing lopsided developed in Africa and Asia as key players in national development remain passive," she lamented.

She said to that effect, the organisation will soon link up to Internet and in this way get connected to all women's' lobby groups in the region so that they share information on potential women leadership who can also represent their respective countries in internal affairs as well as at international organisations like the OAU and COMESA.

Ms said the network will be operational in four months time with the help of the donor community who have shown willingness in the area.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA
