Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Mining Company Disputes Pollution Charges


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 20, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela and Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) has not paid to the government charges for air pollution since 1994, claims the Ministry of Mines.

But ZCCM insists that they pay K38 million every month for emissions of sulphur dioxide from the mines at Mufulira and Nkana Divisions.

The emissions have been identified through medical research as contributing to the high incidence of lung disease on the Copperbelt. 

And ZCCM safety unit manager, Francis Imasiku, assured journalists attending a one week workshop on ZCCM at the Zambia Institute of Mass Communications last Friday that the mining company now has an environmental programme to guard against air pollution.

However, permanent secretary in the Ministry of Mines, Joseph Phiri, in reply to a Post query last Friday, said Nkana mine pays only K3. 5 million per month and has not yet started making the remittances.

He said government expects an average of K39 million from Mufulira Division.

"To date ZCCM have not started paying the money. The divisions have applied to the government to reduce the charges. And when they do pay, the money will be used as part of the appropriation in aid by the mines safety department," Phiri said. "Through the implementation of statutory instrument 119 of 1994 (Mineral Resource Extraction Regulation), ZCCM Nkana Division is supposed to pay government an average of K3.5 million per month in parafiscal charges."

Phiri said government was only expecting payment from the Nkana and Mufulira Divisions "which are the only divisions venting sulphur dioxide".

Imasiku said ZCCM had undertaken a study to lessen the amount of sulphur dioxide in the air "which medical experts have found to be a cause of various lung diseases amongst the mining community".

"At Nkana mine, sulphur dioxide is being used in the manufacture of acid so that there might be reduced amounts in the air", he said.

"Environmental issues are of great concern to us. We pay K10 per kilogramme of sulphur in the air and this can be costly to the company," he revealed. "We pay K38 million per month to the government for this sulphur."

Imasiku also regretted that government had let ZCCM take over the inspection of their manufacturing investments.

"The government factory inspectorate is practically dead," he said.

"ZCCM had long abandoned waiting for the government inspectors in matters concerning their sawmill factory in Kitwe which falls under Mulungushi investments."

However, Imasiku commended the government mines inspectorate which he said though shorthanded, did its best to carry out its duties effectively.

"The presence of a government inspectorate acts as a stimulant to the company which will do its best to maintain safety standards," he said.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia Triumphs


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 20, 1996 by Reuben Tonga and Elias Kamanga


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia yesterday maintained her regional reputation as a powerful soccer nation after silencing Taifa Stars of Tanzania 1-0 in a cliff-hanger victory at Lusaka's Independence Stadium .

The match, which was played to a barren crowd, with spectators one would expect to find at a corrupt politician's burial, saw the Zambians who were playing with almost the whole team that played at the Africa Nations Cup in South Africa penetrate the Taifa Stars' goal area with a clear chance by Kenneth "Bubble" Malitoli missing the back of the net by the might of the towering Tanzanian goalie, Rifati Saidi.

Parading one of the hottest frontlines involving Dennis Lota, and Mwape Miti as twin strikers, with Andrew Tembo and Malitoli attacking from the midfield, Zambia failed to get any goal in the first half. 

But it was only five minutes into the second half that Zambia clinched the winner via a Hillary Makasa spot kick which came after Kenneth Malitoli, skipper of the day, had his sole-move inside the Taifa Stars' danger zone rewarded with a hard tackle from central defenders, Abdala Huseni Msheri and Paul John.

The spot kick itself was a classic with Tanzanian goalie, Saidi, diving in the opposite direction and the ball going in through the other direction.

"The match has been good, and what I observed was that we only have to work on a few areas, mostly in re-organising ourselves from midfield. But I am impressed with the performance though we missed a lot of chances," said Poulsen who rested Dennis Lota, Mwape Miti; Alex Namazaba, for the Rumlex duo: Cosmas Banda and Limbi Mbewe and Zanaco's Edward "Bubble Brown" Kangwa.

And Taifa Stars trainer Mzee Kheri, whose side is gearing up for a World Cup qualifier, said his team has learned some lessons from the match.

"I think Zambia has given us the best preparations and we are now ready for any team. The match was important because it has helped us look at some problems in the team," said Kheri.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambian Federation Tables Constitution


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency May 20, 1996 by Keegan Mumba


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - In a bid to enhance the development of soccer government has written a proposal to the world soccer governing body FIFA, to study and approve the draft Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) constitution to permit "outsiders" to be given chance to stand for elections.

Speaking in an interview today Minister of Sport, Youth and Child Development Lt-Colonel Patrick Kafumukache explained that government wanted to "liberalise" FAZ constitution as regards elections so that it will allow every person to contest the elections because of constant squabbles in the association. 

He revealed that the interim FAZ committee will continue performing the duties until the draft has been sent to FIFA and acknowledge government proposal. he pointed out that the controversial FAZ elections will be held after hearing from FIFA.

According to the current FAZ constitution it allows the individuals with proven soccer clubs and associations record affiliated to FAZ to contest for the elections at the annual general meeting after a four year term.

"There will be no closed shop. Every person willing to be elected into FAZ shall lodge a nomination to stand and it will help promote the standard of soccer," he said.

During the debates for the postponed FAZ elections which were scheduled to take place in Kabwe this month some of the team officials in the midlands ruled the government proposal as being clearly "off-side" to allow every "jim and jack" to contest the elections.

They claimed that soccer just like any other institution required persons with adequate soccer knowledge to avoid the number one sport being thrown into the "dust bin."

There has been an "outcry" from FAZ about interference from the government but government denies. However it is FAZ council meeting which adopt and approve the constitution.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: May 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


175 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia South Africa Denies Mercenary Claims


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 21, 1996 by Goodson Machona


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Lusaka - The South African government has dismissed as false claims by The Sun, a weekly news paper owned and controlled by MMD chairman Sikota Wina, that opposition UNIP was training mercenaries in their territory.

And UNIP has described as "stupid" and "malicious" claims that the party has entered into an agreement with former manager of Circuit Holdings, Malcom Fried, to turn his Johannesburg farm in South Africa into a training camp for its mercenaries.

South African High Commissioner to Zambia, Sam Sterban, who spoke through his secretary, expressed ignorance about the alleged training camp or the mercenaries. 

"He says he does not know any more than what he has read in The Sun newspaper," the secretary said. "But he has instituted investigations and will let you know if anything comes up."

And a spokesperson for the South African department of foreign affairs in Pretoria, Clara Kaesewetter, denied any knowledge of the mercenaries.

"If the High Commissioner there is not aware, then our department hasn't got any further information," Kaesewetter said in a telephone interview yesterday, stressing: "The South African government is against the training of mercenaries in South Africa or any part of the world and steps have been taken to curtail such activities."

UNIP vice-president, senior chief Inyambo Yeta, said in an interview yesterday that the allegations were "a lot of lies" and dared police to arrest those it thinks are involved.

"It's just not true," a visibly annoyed chief Yeta said, adding: "These stupid and malicious allegations have been going on for a long time. There has been talk of UNIP getting cars from President Nelson Mandela and now they are saying we are training mercenaries in South Africa. If they have evidence why don't they come and arrest us?"

However, according to a front page story in The Sun issue of May 20-26, 1996, 200 UNIP cadres and mercenaries have already been taken out of the country and are camped at the same farm for military training.

And, in a separate interview, former president Kenneth Kaunda's press assistant, Muhabi Lungu, denied that former member of the central committee in the UNIP government, Alexander Kamalondo, was recuperating at Freid's farm, as alleged by The Sun .

"Kamalondo is a very sick man and yes, he is in South Africa," Lungu said, asking: "But how can a sick man recuperate at a military training camp? That is ridiculous."

Lungu also explained the association between UNIP and Malcom Freid.

"He is running the Kenneth Kaunda Peace Foundation in South Africa," Lungu said. "There is no secret about that."

Force public relations officer, Francis Musonda, could neither confirm nor deny whether the alleged mercenaries were the ones Inspector General of Police, Francis Ndhlovu, was referring to when he claimed last year that an opposition party was training mercenaries in a neighbouring country.

"I am not the one who made that statement so I cannot comment on that," Musonda said. "Get in touch with the Inspector General and get a comment from him."

When contacted over the mattter, Information minister and government spokesman, Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, referred all queries to the Inspector General of Police.

"I would like to refer you to the Inspector General of Police. He is the only one competent to deal with such issues," Mwanamwambwa said.

Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Peasant Farmers To Control Zambian Bank


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 20, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - Peasant Farmers Union of Zambia chairman, Patrick Kayeka, on Friday disclosed that his organisation was planning to buy 60 per cent of the shares of Lima Bank, a farming lending institution.

Kayela said the union was setting up a Peasant Farmers Investment Fund to be launched on June 28 and expects over 700,000 peasant farmers to contribute the capital. 

According to a draft of the proposed plan, the peasant farmers' union is to collect about K60,000 from peasant farmers to start the fund that will be managed by Zambia National Commercial Bank - the bank with most branches all over the country.

Kayeka said copies of the proposed plan had already been made available to both the Zambia Privatisation Agency and the agriculture ministry.

A campaign has already been launched by the union to encourage the peasant farmers to contribute towards ownership of the "limping" Lima Bank.

The union expects to raise K42 billion from the over 700,000 peasant farmers over two years.

"We'll soon start holding seminars and workshops to let them know the advantages of owning the bank in a bid to recapitalise the institution for their own benefit," Kayeka said in an interview on Friday. "Four provinces have already been visited."

The provinces visited are Eastern, Southern, Western and Central Provinces and the received response has resulted in the setting up of farmers committees to facilitate the payments prior to banking.

Under the proposed shareholding of the bank, the government, bank management, transporters, other agro producers will each have a share holding of 10 per cent.

Agricultural minister Suresh Desai confirmed receiving the plan but could not disclose the government's stand on the matter.

Business and Finance Lusaka Air Routes To Be Decided This Month


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 21, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - Intercontinental routes will be allocated at a sitting to be held at the end of this month, disclosed Ministry of Transport and Communication permanent secretary Ronald Mukuma in an interview yesterday.

"We still have not designated any airline on the Lusaka- London and the other intercontinental routes but we will be sitting before the end of this month," Mukuma said. "The delays to allocate the routes had been as a result of trying to find a suitable airline that would smoothly service the routes."

Mukuma, however, maintained the Lusaka- London route was still vacant contrary to an earlier statementa by the transport ministry deputy minister Gilbert Mululu that it had been allocated to Alliance Airline.

And the results of the airworthiness test of Aero Zambia's newly acquired Boeing 737 may be delayed as the ministry has maintained that not all documentation has been submitted.

"Up to now they still have not submitted all documentation," Mukuma claimed, "which is why the tests have been delayed."

Last Thursday, Aero Zambia management challenged the ministry to state what documents had not been submitted but the permanent secretary is yet to disclose missing the ones.

Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance 'New' Hybrid May End Shortage Of Chickens


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 21, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - Shortage of chickens in the country may end with the re-opening of Lusaka's Hybrid Poultry Farm's hatchery.

Speaking in an interview on Sunday, Hybrid Hatchery Farm assistant manager, Singani Mutyambe disclosed that the go-ahead to resume production was given by veterinary officials from the Ministry of Agriculture after a series of examinations of the premises. 

"We expect our first hatching after the closure on May 30 with about 55,000 birds but we've continued sample taking of the produce despite the veterinary clearance to ensure that the infection levels remain at Zero," Mutyambe said.

He revealed that a total of 90,000 eggs valued at K61million were destroyed last month after the discovery of the disease affecting the day-old chicks.

Mutyambe attributed the source of the disease to the company's other farm, Green Valley Farm, the egg source.

Mutyambe said this development led to the halting of production at Green Valley Farm and the Hatchery, with the former having all its parent breeders slaughtered in a bid to eradicate the disease.

"Among the measures taken to control the outbreak were the vast re-washing of the hatchery, strict monitoring of traffic and the introduction of foot bath for both vehicle entering the premises," he said.

Agriculture minister Suresh Desai yesterday promised to give a press release on the matter after studying the report.

And Zambia National Farmers Union executive director, George Grey, last Friday cautioned farmers from sourcing day old chicks from Zimbabwe saying the country had suffered a serious outbreak of Newcastle disease.

LANGUAGE: English

179 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Arts, Culture and Entertainment New CDs Feature African Musicians


BYLINE: Xenophile Records May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Danbury - Jaojoby, Salegy!. Jaojoby (pronounced "Dzo-Dzoob") Eusebe is Madagascar's king of "salegy," the exciting 6/8 dance rhythm of the hottest local guitar band dance music of this Indian Ocean island. Recorded live and kicking in a small Antananarivo studio and later mixed in London by Ben Mandelson and Ian Anderson, Salegy! was the first-ever CD of authentic Malagasy salegy. The mesmerizing groove is punctuated by unbeatable three part vocals, tight as they come, and guitars which often reverse mainland Africa practice by having a muted tone on the lead and a harder edge on the second player. Released in Madagascar in 1992, this album still gets in airplay the daily. 

Jaojoby's career at the top of his musical form spans 20 years and his music is heard regularly in night clubs, bars and bush-taxis, while his songs are covered by bands all over the country. From 1976 through the early 80's (when the local recording industry collapsed), several of Jaojoby's salegy singles reputedly sold over 60,000 copies in Madagascar. Salegy! showcases Jaojoby's latest and hottest group that he started in 1988, and all of his most popular songs. As well as heavily featuring salegy, the band performs other local rhythms like sega, watcha-watcha, sigoma and even put their unique spin on James Brown-style funk.

While Xenophile label-mates Tarika have played a large role in popularizing Malagasy roots music world-wide by touring their compact, semi-acoustic line-up, the financial logistics of touring a 9-piece electric band abroad have kept Jaojoby as one of Madagascar's best secrets.

This is about to change. Jaojoby finally made a triumphant European debut with his band in France in 1994 (and is due back there for a lengthy tour in the summer of 1996). With Xenophile's world-wide re-release of SALEGY!, Madagascar's king of salegy should ascend to many more thrones. SALEGY! -- Xenophile #4040.

Chief Stephen Osita Osadebe, Kedu America("Greetings from America")

Since the late 1950's, Chief Stephen Osita Osade has been pursuing his musical muse. It was during this time the young singer made a trek from the rural village of his birth to Lagos, the capital city of Nigeria and the center of the pop music scene known as "highlife". Starting as a backup singer with popular highlife band leader Stephen Ameche, Chief Stephen soon blossomed into a band leader of renown. In fact a history of highlife reads like a Osadebe bibliography, and in the early 1980's Osadebe released the album that would come to define the genre: Osandi Owende, the first and only platinum record to be awarded a Nigerian artist.

Now on Kedu America (Greetings From America), "The Consistent Highlife King", returns, letting (getting) loose on an album of scintillating polyrhythmic African drums, jazzy horn lines and sultry, repeating guitar riffs that further exemplify why Chief Stephen, "The Doctor of Hypertension" is the undisputed ruler of the Nigerian dance hall. KEDU AMERICA ("Greetings From America") -- Xenophile #4044.

Both CDs are available from Xenophile Records, 43 Beaver Brook Road, Danbury, CT 06810. Phone: 203 730-0333. Fax: 203 730-0345.


LOAD-DATE: May 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Arts African Film Festival Winner Gets US Release


BYLINE: Kino International Corp May 21, 1996


LENGTH: 254 words


 

New York - Kino International Corp, the New York-based distributor of foreign and classic motion pictures proudly announces that African filmmaker Cheick Oumar Sissoko's acclaimed film GUIMBA: THE TYRANT will receive a U.S. theatrical release.

Grand Prize Winner at FESPACO (Africa's preeminent film festival), GUIMBA will have a limited two-week run at New York's Cinema Village Theater, beginning May 24. 

Following the New York engagement, Kino plans an ambitious theatrical and non-theatrical release in major cities and universities in the U.S. Classroom screenings will also be offered shortly thereafter. GUIMBA will play in Philadelphia on July 25-28 (at the International House) and in Atlanta on July 5-7 (as part of the national Black Arts Festival).

For more information on GUIMBA (including plot synopsis, cast and credits and a selection of color photos) visit Kino On-Line on the World Wide Web. The address is:

http://www.kino.com/guimba.html

For information, contact Kino International at (800) 562-3330 or (212) 629-6880.

Africa News


May, 1996


Central African Republic U.S. Calls For Peaceful Resolution Of Unrest


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is the text of a statement issued by Nicholas Burns, U.S. Department of State spokesman, on the situation in the Central African Republic:

The United States is appalled to learn of further unrest in Bangui and condemns the violent actions, including the taking of hostages, carried out by members of the armed forces of the Central African Republic. We call on all parties to resolve the situation peacefully, through a negotiated settlement which respects the rule of law. We believe that the concerns of the military should then be addressed by the Committee established for that purpose in April.

Reaffirmation of civilian rule in Bangui is the only solution which respects the will of the people of the Central African Republic. We call on all troops to observe the proper role of the military in a democratic society, which is to serve at the command of duly elected civilian authorities. Legitimate grievances must not be expressed or addressed through violent and undemocratic acts.

The United States underscores its determination to work with the international community to press for full restoration of civil order in the Central African Republic.

Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa Clinton Reports to Congress on Liberia Deployment


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 21, 1996


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is the official text of a letter on Liberia from President Clinton to the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President Pro Tempore of the Senate, dated May 20, 1996:

On April 11, 1996, I reported that U.S. military forces equipped for combat had entered Monrovia, Liberia, for the purpose of evacuating American citizens and certain third-country nationals from that strife-torn city. This letter is provided, consistent with the War Powers Resolution, to update the Congress on the continued deployment of U.S. forces, including the response by those forces to several isolated attacks on the American Embassy complex on April 30, 1996, and May 6, 1996.

As of this date, U.S. forces have evacuated over 2,300 persons from Monrovia, including over 470 American citizens. The U.S. Special Operations and U.S. Army Europe forces that conducted the initial evacuations have been replaced by U.S. Marines assigned to a Marine Amphibious Ready Group offshore in the immediate vicinity of Monrovia. Approximately 280 Marines and other U.S. military personnel from the total U.S. force of 2,500 are currently ashore at the American Embassy complex. In addition to protecting American lives and property at the Embassy complex, the mission of these forces is to maintain the capability to conduct further evacuations if circumstances warrant. 

On April 30, 1996, three separate attacks occurred against the American Embassy complex reportedly involving fighters from several factions. In the first encounter, a U.S. Marine was grazed by a round fired by one of the attackers. The Marines did not return fire, and the injured Marine was able to return to duty on the same day. In the second attack, a Marine was struck by plywood splinters dislodged by an incoming round. During this attack, the Marines returned fire, killing two or more attackers. During the final encounter, approximately 40 to 50 attackers, while apparently engaged in a pursuit of fighters from another faction, fired on the Marines. After the Marines returned fire, one of the attackers fired again. The Marines again returned fire, this time killing two or more attackers.

Separately, on May 6, 1996, unknown factional forces fired upon the Embassy complex. The Marines returned fire with machine guns and automatic weapons, driving off the attackers. No U .S. forces were killed or injured in this encounter. One member of the attacking force may have been wounded.

Finally, on May 11, 1996, a U.S. Marine walking on the Embassy compound was struck by a stray round. The Marine was slightly injured. He was treated and returned to full duty. This incident was the result of stray fire between warring factions and appears not to have been directed at the Marines or the Embassy.

The Marine commander reported that during these attacks, U.S. forces opened fire only upon persons who fired upon the Embassy complex. In the judgment of U.S. military commanders, these attacks are sporadic incidents and do not represent an intent to mount a concerted or deliberate attack against the American Embassy or the Marines. We do not intend that U.S. Armed Forces deployed to Liberia become involved in hostilities. Nonetheless, our forces are equipped and prepared to defend American lives and property if necessary.

Our goal is to redeploy U.S. forces once there is no longer a need for enhanced security at the Embassy and a requirement to maintain an on-scene evacuation capability.

I have directed the continued deployment of U.S. forces to Liberia pursuant to my constitutional authority to conduct the foreign relations of the United States and as Commander in Chief and Chief Executive.

I am providing this report as part of my efforts to keep the Congress fully informed concerning this important deployment of U.S. forces. I appreciate the support of the Congress in this action to protect American citizens and our Embassy complex in Monrovia.


LOAD-DATE: May 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


183 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Briefing On Mandela's Germany Visit


BYLINE: South African Communications Service May 21, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Cape Town - Briefing issued by: Office of the President on President Mandela's Visit To The Federal Republic Of Germany, May 21-23, 1996:

Introduction

1. The visit is an opportunity to strengthen relations between South Africa and Germany, our major trading partner and one of the leading foreign investors in South Africa. In addition it should have a positive impact on relations between the regions to which our two countries belong.

2. Germany has committed substantial resources, manpower, skills, technology and financial support towards growth and development in South Africa, and they are ready to do more. Germany is also the driving force behind closer relations between the EU and SADC states. 

The program for the visit

1. During the three days of the visit the President will be holding talks with government as well as meeting business leaders and opposition parties. Broader engagement with the people of Germany will include an address to the Bundestag; meetings with civic leaders Bonn and Berlin; media events and the opening of a cultural exhibition on South Africa in Berlin.

2. The formation of a high-level intergovernmental Binational Commission, to co-ordinate and deepen bilateral relations, will be a matter discussed with government. The focus of a meeting with business and investment leaders will be the launch of a "Southern Africa Initiative".

German policy towards south africa and southern africa

1. Central to current German policy towards Africa is a commitment to assist in promoting sustainable development within a context of democracy ad human rights. Nearly two thirds of all development aid channeled to Africa is of German origin.

2. Both government and opposition in Germany are committed to help prevent the marginalisation of South Africa and Southern Africa take root.

3. The Southern Africa Initiative, to be launched during the President's visit, will promote German private sector involveent in the region's economic growth ad development through trade, investment and joint ventures.

4. Relations between South Africa and the European Union are strongly influenced by Germany's leading role in the EU, and Germany has been the driving force behind encouraging closer co-operation between the EU and SADC states. Half of Germany's development assistance for South Africa is in the form of its share - the biggest - of the EU's budget for South Africa.

South Africa's relations with Germany

1. The consideration being given to a Binational Commission reflects the dramatic increase in bilateral relations between South Africa and Germany over the past two years.

Economy relations

1. Germany's stake in the South African economy makes it an important partner. Over 300 German firms employ 59 000 people in South Africa, and a survey by the German/South African Chamber of Commerce in late 1994 found that more than half were considering increasing their investments in South Africa. The German government is also positive about South Africa's long-term potential and the contribution it can make to the region and the continent.

2. The main thrust of continued investment in South Africa originates from German firms already here, principally in the automotive and chemical industries. Most new investment enquiries also relate to the automotive industry or to tourism - reflecting South Africa's position as a principal destination for German tourists. An Investment Protection Agreement, signed when Chancellor Kohl visited South Africa last year; is expected to encourage small and medium firms to invest in South Africa.

3. Trade between Germany and South Africa is imbalanced. German exports to SA are twice the volume of goods going the other way, and they consist primarily of high value capital equipment and finished products compared with the raw materials and semi-manufactured goods we export to Germany.

German development assistance

1. German development assistance to South Africa, bilateral and via the EU, amounted to some DM 170m during 1995. Previously channeled through NGOs before South Africa had democratic government, it has now been put on a government-to-government basis through agreements signed when Chancellor Kohl visited South Africa.

2. The assistance is concentrated mainly on, vocational and further training; rural housing and development; small business; democracy; provincial administration; unemployment. It includes as an objective the development of Southern Africa as a region.

Bilateral relations

1. The rapid growth in bilateral relations in the past two years is reflected in the agreements that have been signed recently or soon will be. Already agreed are provisions for investment protection and for co-operation in development; mineral and energy affairs; posts and telecommunications; and air services. Expected soon are agreements relating to culture; science and technology; financial matters; sport; and merchant shipping.

2. At another level, co-operation takes place through the twinning of our Provinces and German federal states. Western Cape, Gauteng and Eastern Cape have already formed such partnerships and more are being explored.


LOAD-DATE: May 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


184 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zimbabwe Some NGOs May Add to Suffering of AIDS Victims


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996 by Tim Chigodo


LENGTH: 1542 words


 

Harare - Life is terrible for most people living with HIV/AIDS in Zimbabwe. Society shuns them. For the employed, the work place is a hostile environment, thereby condemning them to the grave before they die.

Some victims of the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) have been kicked out of houses they were renting by their landlords soon after their HIV status is know, and sometimes property belonging to HIV positive people has been thrown out by landlords. 

This has driven most AIDS sufferers into silence and many victims do not tell close relatives about their HIV status until they develop full-blown AIDS, because they fear being blamed or condemned. However, a few people have come out in the open and are being used by non-governmental organisations to encourage others to live positively with the infection.

Some of the HIV positive people have managed to survived for about 10 years and most of them are still going strong. Emily Shonhiwa Mazviepasi of Mutare, south-east of the capital Harare says; "I knew that I was HIV positive in 1990 and I have come out in the open as a way of showing others that someone with HIV can survive for over 30 years.

Her late husband had been in and out of hospital for a very long time and finally diagnosed to have TB2. He later tested positive and died of AIDS six years ago "but I am still going strong because of hope and a proper diet."

The 39-year-old Mazviepasi is one of the scores of HIV positive people who have come together to form the Zimbabwe National Network for People Living with HIV/AIDS (ZNNP+).

With branches and support groups nationwide and guided by the theme, "Hope is Vital," ZNNP+, teaches survival techniques and how to live positively with HIV/AIDS thereby increasing the chances of survival.

"We teach that HIV stands for Hope Is Vital. It is not AIDS that kills but the despair and psychological pressure caused by lack of hope and stigmatisation. If one has the HIV virus, it does not necessarily mean that he/she has AIDS. In fact you can be a carrier of HIV for many years but without having AIDS, said leader of ZNNP+, Lynde Francis, who told participants at an AIDS reporting workshop that she had managed to survive with HIV for 10 years.

Despite the obvious success that has been scored by ZNNP+ as more and more people join the organisation as support groups, some NGOs dealing directly or indirectly with the AIDS issue have been accused of "using" the infected people to enrich their pockets. Generally Zimbabwe and anywhere else

Worldwide, the majority of people with the deadly virus do not declare their status publicly and, as a result, the few that have come out were being used to give "live" testimonies in workshops/seminars organised ostensibly "to raise money to assist them." But once donated, the money disappears.

Not only that, some international development organisations have come up with AIDS documentaries for either "research" purposes or for television, promising the participants "lots of money" but later reneging on the promises.

"We never get a cent and yet millions of dollars are being raised through us. We are being used and yet we are suffering," said Gertrude Usaiwevhu (37) of Zvimba communal lands, who has lived with HIV since 1990.

Several NGOs had formed retail outlets in some local centres ostensibly to help people with HIV/AIDS but pocketed the earnings.

Medical doctors and church-related organisations argue that the issue of HIV/AIDS had been "blown out of proportion" and genuine victims were used as "pawns". According to Sister Noreen Nolan of the Mashambanzou AIDS Drop-in Centre in Harare; "People with HIV/AIDS are just like any other person suffering from the many diseases that exist in this world. There are lots of people with cancer or hepatitis and nobody is making an issue out of them... I don't think those living with HIV/AIDS should be given special treatment."

But not all people with HIV/AIDS have learnt to live positively with the killer disease. Most HIV positive people, particularly divorcee women and housewives, blame society and the next man/woman for their status and "fight back" by spreading the incurable disease.

"I was divorced after I tested positive for HIV. My mother in-law chased me away saying, hatigari nemunhu ane AIDS pano (we cannot stay with a person affected by AIDS). My husband refused to go for a test saying it was my AIDS, and yet as a housewife, I never entertained any other man. At times he would sleep out for about three days...it's very infuriating indeed," said Linda Banya (26) of Mbare, now member of a cooperative at Mashambanzou.

Some HIV positive people admitted they were having unprotected sex with many partners without bothering to warn them of their status. "Although I ask for a condom if the man insists on using it, I don't care...after all I got this disease from my former husband and was chased away in the process," said a Mbare-based 27-year-old HIV positive woman.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


185 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Neighborhood Pressure Forces Sudanese Turn-About


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

Nairobi - In a refreshing turn of events, the beleaguered Sudanese leader Omar El Bashir, has told Islamic radicals and fundamentalists using Sudanese territory to wage war against neighbouring countries to leave Sudan "immediately."

Sudan's neighbours, particularly Egypt, Uganda, Ethiopia, and Eritrea, as well as others further afield like Saudi Arabia, have regularly accused the National Islamic Front (NIF), who are the real rulers of Sudan, of sponsoring and condoning the activities of terrorist organisations bent on destabilising their nations.

Egypt and the United States engineered the limited United Nations sanctions against Sudan that became effective on May 12. Both countries say Sudan has for a number of years operated secret camps where foreigners train as assassins. One such camp, at El Haj Yussef, is believed to have been the training base for the Egyptian militants who attempted to kill Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia mid last year. The UN security council's limited sanctions against Sudanese diplomats is in response to the failure by Sudan to hand over some of the people who were allegedly involved in the abortive attack on Mubarak. 

El Bashir has also come under increased military pressure from his aggrieved neighbours - Uganda, Eritrea and Ethiopia. Each of these nations has a bone to pick with Sudan which lacks the financial resources to cope with a sustained military campaign against the regime.

El Bashir's order against all dissidents using Sudan last week said; "Everyone who has activities against his government or another government and who lives in Sudan, must leave immediately." The order was reported by the Arabic language Al Wasat, generally accepted as reliable.

El Bashir must be particularly worried about Eritrea, its neighbour to the east. Eritrea has made it quite clear that it has opened up training camps on its territory for the benefit of the Opposition Alliance whose aim is to overthrow the NIF regime in Khartoum. The Opposition Alliance used their base camps in Eritrea last month to launch a "successful" military operation against a Sudanese garrison in the Kassala area of north-eastern Sudan. They are led by a professional soldier, formerly in the Sudanese Army, Abdel Aziz Osman.

Eritrean President Isaias Aferworki said in an interview recently that by his own estimation, the regime in Khartoum is very weak. "The morale of the military is very low and the logistical support for their fighting men inadequate."

He doubted Sudan had a capacity to take on Eritrea in a direct military confrontation and dismissed Sudan's much touted 1 million strong militia, saying it was not a credible military force.

Observers say the "successful" operation by the Opposition Alliance forces in Kassala last April must have badly unnerved the regime in Khartoum because the region east of Khartoum is Sudan's breadbasket. Colonel Osman said the military garrison fell in less than one hour, "proving that the NIF regime is supported by a very weak military."

Ethiopia is another neighbour of Sudan which is angered by the Khartoum regime's brazen disregard for the territorial integrity of a neighbour. Ethiopia blames Sudan for the abortive attempt on the life of Hosni Mubarak of Egypt last year as the President arrived for an Organisation of African Unity (OAU) summit.

Relations have deteriorated considerably. Last February, Sudan accused Ethiopia of allowing the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) of John Garang to use military bases in Ethiopia to launch a quick attack on Sudanese garrison towns in Upper Nile and Blue Nile regions. Sudan said Ethiopian tanks had actively taken part in those attacks, a charge denied by the SPLA.

Sudan's neighbour to the south, Uganda, has a more serious problem with rebels said to be supported by Khartoum. Following his landslide victory in the presidential elections on May 9, President Yoweri Museveni warned Bashir he would not kneel down to him. He charged that Sudan was using guerrillas of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) who have committed numerous atrocities in northern Uganda, to further its islamic fundamentalist ambitions in the East African region.

"Most people do not understand the international dimension of the rebellion in the north. Uganda's misfortune to share a border with a neighbour who sees us as a frontier to further fundamentalist incursion into the rest of Africa," said the victorious Museveni at his swearing in ceremony on May 12.

Museveni warned Bashir to withdraw support from the rebels and pull them back to an internationally monitored holding facility near Juba or face the consequences. One implication of Museveni's tough talking is that Uganda would reserve the right to offer much greater support to the rebels of the SPLA. Sudan has regularly charged that Uganda is the SPLA's biggest backer in recent times.

Observers believe that with El Bashir's decree requiring rebel movements to leave Sudan, the days of the Lord's Resistance Army in Gulu and Kitgum Districts of northern Uganda are numbered. Similarly the West Nile Bank Front of Juma Oris are likely to disintegrate since both guerrilla organisations cannot be sustained internally in Uganda.

Furthermore, the Uganda rebel groups appear to have anticipated Bashir's decree, which caused them to declare a ceasefire in early May. The rebels of the LRA desperately wanted Ugandan presidential loser Paul Ssemogerere to win the elections in Uganda, hence their door-to-door campaigns for him in the last days before the elections. Museveni lost badly in the West Nile, Gulu, and Kitgum areas of northern Uganda where he obtained an average of 10 per cent of the votes cast.

This was attributed to the activities of the rebels who promised the people that peace would return to Uganda upon the defeat of Museveni. Ssemogerere promised the rebels that he would negotiate with them.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


186 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Uganda How Museveni Won Big


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996 by Robert Kizito


LENGTH: 2187 words


 

Kampala - Uganda presidential poll is over and this East African country has a new national chief executive, Yoweri Kaguta Museveni. Contrary to earlier predictions that Museveni would win only a marginal victory, he got an overwhelming majority.
Museveni garnered 74.2 per cent of the valid votes. His closest rival, veteran politician Dr. Paul Kawanga Ssemogerere of the Inter-Political Forces Cooperation (IPFC) or simply IPC, obtained 23.7 per cent.

Political upstart, Mohammed Kibirige Mayanja, 46, a University administrator and education planner polled a poor 2.1 per cent. Of the 6.2 million votes cast, only 196,130 ballot papers or 3.2 per cent were invalidated. An impressive 75 per cent of the registered voters turned out to cast their vote. 

Museveni won in 32 districts out of the country's 39, which included the eight districts in Ssemogerere's (and Mayanja's) home region, Buganda in central Uganda. The region had the highest number of registered voters as well as votes cast.

Ssemogerere, 64, overwhelmed Museveni, 52, in the remaining seven districts mainly in parts of Eastern Uganda and in the North, whose discredited hold on power and the army Museveni almost single- handedly terminated in 1986 when he shot his way into power.

Museveni banned partisan political activity but not political parties, in favour of what has been characterised as a "home grown movement style of democracy." Under the system individual rather than partisan participation is the principle modus operandi.

He also pledged that his ascendancy to the pinnacle of power was not simply a "change of guard" but a transformation that would usher in fundamental changes. These would include the return of "power to the people" and the restoration of democratic governance.

A Constitutional Commission set up in 1992 to collect views on an appropriate future constitutional text, subsequently saw the enactment in late 1995 of constitution by a Constituent Assembly comprising directly elected representatives who arguably embodied every shade of opinion in the country. The new constitution incorporates the ban on partisan political activity, a matter that is to be subjected to a national referendum in the year 2001.

The next most important step in the process was the presidential race of May 9, 1996 that Yoweri Kaguta Museveni has just won. This will be followed by parliamentary and local government authorities elections.

Despite protests and accusations of vote-rigging and other malpractices by the vanquished candidates, diplomats, monitors, local and foreign observers, and the Uganda Joint Christian Council (UJCC) have endorsed the results. According to press reports, polling agents of the losers at nearly all the 15,567 polling stations, have also endorsed the results.

Unlike the first ever post-independence (October 1962) multi-party polls of December 1980, only one ballot box was used this time. The empty boxes were opened, inspected and sealed in the presence of monitors, voters present, observers and local candidates' polling agents.

Ballot papers were marked in secret and the vote was actually cast in the open, unlike 1980 when open vote-casting was not used.

Also in 1980, the counting and verification was not done at the respective local polling stations. Instead, ballot boxes were transported all the way to the capital, Kampala by "official" election organisers for counting.

The arrangements for the May 1996 presidential elections made rigging of an opponent's votes or stashing of rigged votes in a candidate's favour difficult. This explains why candidates' polling agents promptly and with much ease endorsed the results.

Against this background, diplomats, monitors, local and foreign observers also quickly endorsed the results. The Italian envoy in Kampala, Marcello Ricoveri, termed the losers protests "the usual complaints." Italy currently holds the presidency of the European Union.

"The opposition has complained extensively about a lot of things - their usual complaints, but from what I have seen and heard, the elections have been fair." Noting isolated incidents of poor administration by the Interim Electoral Commission and bias by some election officials, he said: "All the same I don't see how the opposition can claim rigging as a reason for loss of the elections."

Giving its verdict, the National Organisation of Civic Education and Election Monitoring (NOCEM), an independent coalition of 12 voluntary NGOs said: "In spite of the shortcomings pointed out above, the results to a great extent reflected the will of the people of Uganda which should be respected by all." The coalition includes among others, The Uganda Law Society, the national journalists association and human rights groups.

Except for the partisan (pro-Museveni) conduct of local administration officials, the short comings listed by NOCEM do not seem serious enough to affect the overall results. By and large the shortcomings bordered more on administrative lapses, ineptitude and clumsiness rather than deliberate dishonesty.

For example, in the insurgency infested areas in Northern Uganda where soldiers of the Uganda People's Defence Forces (UPDF) formerly NRA were heavily deployed, Museveni lost miserably. This tends to obliterate the accusation that voters were intimidated.

On the other hand evidence abounds that both camps intimidated each others supports, but most likely with no official sanction. Violence and unsavory language were equally perpetrated by both camps.

In another verdict the 100-strong International Observer Group said that during the elections, they saw very few cases of intimidation or efforts to influence voters in the vicinity of polling stations. The result reflected the polling process which they observed on election day, they declared in a statement.

"Overall, the International Observer Group believes that the procedures of the poll were carried out in a transparent manner and in accordance with the Interim Election Statute," the statement said.

However, "the monitors did not rule on whether they considered the election free and fair, apparently because of Museveni's ban on political parties operating which means Uganda's political system falls short of Western-style democracy," reported the semi-Government daily news paper, The New Vision. But the opposition is not impressed and is now threatening to boycott the forthcoming parliamentary poll scheduled for June.

In the case of the just-concluded presidential race, it is generally believed that intimidation, vote-rigging, and malpractices in general were not really the issues that are responsible for Ssemogerere's poor showing. Reasons for the heavy loss of the otherwise formidable opposition candidate, Dr. Paul Kawanga Ssemogerere must be found elsewhere.

Ssemogerere was formidable if for nothing else because he was a joint candidate of the two oldest existing and well-established political parties: the Democratic Party which he leads, and Uganda People's Congress (UPC) whose leader technically is still the discredited Dr. Apollo Milton Obote who now lives in exile in Zambia. This "unholy alliance of documented bitter enemies" cost the opposition several votes especially in the South.

In the case of Buganda, Ssemogerere lost additional votes when he unwittingly singled out Ugandans of Rwandese extraction for "unbecoming utterances, intimidation and innuendos." Similar utterances by Obote in the early 80s prompted many Banyarwanda to join Museveni's rebel army in the bush in droves.

In retrospect, observes a Ugandan lawyer who is a political activist, it is largely the Banyarwanda, one of whom is Ssemogerere's own Legal Advisor and Deputy National Chairman, that makes Ugandan nationality a sensitive issue.

Today, nearly one third of Buganda's population of about 4.5 million people comprises indigenous Banyarwanda (and their cousins in Western Uganda) and people who pass as Baganda but actually carry Banyarwanda and other blood. Some of these people's ancestors arrived in Buganda (and Uganda) in mid-1800s to meet a manual labour shortage and their contribution to the Buganda economy especially, is not any less important than the African-American's contributions to the economy of the United States of America.

On the other hand, Museveni used his incumbency and the State machinery at his disposal as well as his miraculous track record to maximum advantage. For example, he gave favours and privileges, though well in advance of the elections, where he rightly predicted votes would later matter as in the case of women.

The opposition failed to offer anything to counter Museveni's socio- political and economic performance in a country and populace that past regimes had thrown to the dogs for nearly a quarter century.

Instead, in the eyes of many voters, the opposition sounded dim- witted, theatrical and only interested in entering State House each time it tried, but unconvincingly, to ridicule the National Resistance Movement (NRM) Government's track record. Ssemogerere himself served in the NRM Government for nine years resigning only last year to contest the Presidency.

But Museveni's campaign team must also be given due credit. While Ssemogerere was in carnival showing off his new-found big-wig friends in the opposition alliance wherever he went, Museveni's big shots were busy campaigning door to door in the respective home areas. The team was most creative, going as far as using television, radio and print media adverts for the first time ever in a Ugandan election.

The team left nothing to chance. For purposes of the elections, the team chose to adopt and to give to the Interim Electoral Commission Museveni's less-used name, Kaguta, as the candidate's first name. In the alphabet order by which the candidates names and pictures were arranged on the ballot papers, Kaguta comes first as opposed to the other two candidates' names. With hind sight to the illiteracy rates in their motherland, the team new that a picture coming on top could be advantageous.

The Electoral Commission was accused of announcing 700 new polling stations on the eve of the elections for which it was impractical for the opposition to appoint polling agents. This is an accusation that could stick if only the opposition also provided particulars of these polling stations, including among other things, the names of officials who manned them and the total number of votes cast at the stations.

The opposition will therefore need more than unsubstantiated allegations to take the big prize away from the guerrilla marshal- turned civilian leader, Yoweri Kaguta Museveni, the man supporters and adversaries alike love to hate.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Kenya Outspoken Anglican Elected Bishop of Mt. Kenya


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Nairobi - The Rev. Peter Njenga, the Provost of All Saints Cathedral, Nairobi was on May 11 elected the fourth Bishop of Mt. Kenya South Diocese.

The new Bishop will be consecrated on June 30, 1996 at St. James Cathedral, Kiambu, some 25 kilometres north of here. 

The Dean of the Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) the Rt. Rev. Dr. David Gitari announced Njenga's election at St. Peter's Church, Ol Kalau, about 130 kilometres north-west of here the same day, just before delivering the sermon during the funeral of the late Bishop Laadan Kamau, the former Bishop of the Diocese of Nakuru who retired in 1989.

Said the Acting Archbishop of the CPK; "As we bury our beloved Bishop Laadan Kamau, a new bishop has been "born on this same day." There was much jubilation from the mourners on learning that the Provost of All Saints Cathedral has become the Bishop of Mt. Kenya South.

The Rev. Peter Njenga joined the Church Army Training College in January 1962 and completed his studies of evangelism in November 1963. He was commissioned a Church Army Captain on November 30, 1963.

After serving as an evangelist for a number of years he joined St. Paul's United Theological College in 1968 and was awarded a Diploma in Theology from the University of Makerere in 1971. He proceeded to St. John's Nottingham Seminary in 1974 to study theology and was awarded a Bachelor of Theology Degree after successful completion of the course in July 1977.

After serving in a number of parishes in Mt. Kenya South Diocese, he was inducted and installed as the Provost of All Saints Cathedral, Nairobi on February 27, 1983. He has served as the Provost of the Cathedral for 13 years. His stay at the Cathedral has been greatly appreciated and admired for his courage and prophetic ministry.

Provost Njenga who shed tears of joy on being declared the new bishop, is best remembered for a war of words with the ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) party officials following the brutal evictions of slum dwellers in Muoroto village which is within his Cathedral parish. According to Njenga, the 1990 eviction claimed seven lives but establishment politicians vehemently denied this.

Mt. Kenya South diocesan Chancellor Mr. Githu Muigai, described the elections as very peaceful and "very, very spiritually conducted. There was no politicking."

Reporters and spectators were kept out of the cathedral during the elections. The cathedral resounded with claps and later prayers when the winner was announced. Rev. Njenga got 88 votes against his closest rival Rev. David Njoroge who garnered 68 votes.

On his consecration he will become the fourth Bishop of Mt. Kenya South. His predecessors include the late Bishop Obadiah Kariuki, the late Bishop Sospeter Magua and the recently retired Bishop George Njuguna.

Bishop Njuguna who was retired in public interest following allegations of moral misconduct and misappropriation of church funds, has predicted violence in the diocese saying there will now be two bishops in the see. But so far indications are that there might be peace.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia Ecumenical Appeal For Liberian Refugees


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Geneva - The World Council of Churches (WCC) and the Lutheran World Federation (LWF) have issued a joint appeal for $794,000 to provide emergency services to suffering Liberians.

The appeal was sent out early this month by Action by Churches Together (ACT), a worldwide network of churches and their related agencies instituted by both WCC and LWF in 1995 to respond to human need through coordinated emergency response and common identity.
The ACT Executive Secretary, Mr. Hugh MCcullum, expressed hope that ecumenical partners will act swiftly to the appeal. 

Escalated fighting began in Liberia's capital, Monrovia on April 6, sending civilians scampering for safety outside the capital as well as into neighbouring countries. The West African country has been ravaged by civil war since late 1989, and numerous efforts to bring warring factions to an amicable accord have proved futile.

"The situation that has seen many Liberians flee their country, calls for urgent action and it is our hope that the ecumenical partners will act swiftly to the issue at hand," said McCullum.

He pointed out that the appeal will follow another one of US dollars 100,000 for the Christian Council of Ghana. "The decision was taken today (May 15) after receiving information that the ship carrying hundreds of Liberian refugees has been allowed to dock at Takoradi, Ghana by the Ghanaian authorities," McCullum added.

The ACT Executive Secretary said the present appeal comes after an earlier one of US dollars 500,000 on April 18. The appeal mid-last month was meant to be used to equip the ACT/LWF office in Abidjan, Ivory Coast following recent losses in Liberial's capital. It would also help stockpile medicines and other relief goods, ready for transport to the small west African country, currently facing serious civil war as a result of renewed fighting between various factions mainly in the capital Monrovia.

Meanwhile, the General Secretary of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), Rev. Jose Chipenda says churches in Africa are faced with another challenge in the wake of the current crisis in Liberia.

"It is sad that a crisis should surface in Liberia now, not long after similar ones in Rwanda and Burundi. The churches on the continent have no choice but to face the challenge as the situation demands," he told APS in Nairobi.

Chipenda said the AACC is currently liaising with international ecumenical partners and local churches within countries neighbouring Liberia in order to give the crisis the attention it deserves.

Rev. Chipenda also briefed APS on the May 5 to 9 meeting of the Fellowship of Councils of Churches in Eastern and Southern Africa (FOCCESA), which took place in Maputo, Mozambique.

He said delegates drawn from the two regions strongly felt that "the church should continue to respond to emergencies unreservedly."

FOCCESA also welcomed the recent decision by the AACC to decentralise its refugee and emergency services. Similar committees for Western and Central Africa are being established, noted the AACC General Secretary.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


UGANDA Christian Council Urges Losers To Accept Defeat


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 494 words


 
Kampala - The Uganda Joint Christian Council (UJCC) which monitored the May 9 presidential poll in Uganda, has urged opposition leaders Dr. Paul Ssemogerere and Mr. Mohammed Mayanja to concede defeat gracefully.

In a report published on May 14, the UJCC noted that despite some shortcomings and some anomalies in the election process, the whole exercise was a fair and authentic representation of the views and aspirations of Ugandans.

In the presidential poll, the incumbent won a landslide victory scoring 74.2 per cent of the popular vote out of the 6.2 million votes cast in Uganda's first election in 16 years. His main challenger Dr. Paul Ssemogerere managed 23.8 per cent while less than two per cent went to Mr. Mayanja. 

The UJCC statement was signed by its chairperson Emmanuel Cardinal Wamala and its coordinator Rev. Canon James Ndyabahika.

The UJCC urged the victor, Yoweri Museveni to show magnamity and statesmanship by extending the hand of cooperation to all those who challenged him or did not vote for him.

As UJCC released their statement, Dr. Ssemogerere's Inter Party Political Forces Cooperation (IPFC) met all day on May 14 to consider a boycott of the parliamentary elections due in June. Ssemogerere has charged that there was extensive rigging in the presidential poll but international and local observers have dismissed his claims, saying the Uganda elections were a wholly transparent exercise.

Ssemogerere was defeated by Museveni in his birthplace, Kalangangala in the Ssese Islands and in Masaka District where he resides. Observers believe he is on his way out as a politician.

Although Ssemogerere is boycotting the parliamentary polls, many of his colleagues say they will participate in the elections, warning that to fail to do so would allow Museveni to have absolute control of the affairs of the nation.

A statement issued by the IPFC after the meeting on May 14 said: "Any Ugandan wishing to participate in the forthcoming parliamentary elections may do so well knowing that the rigging machinery is still in place."

Meanwhile, following his colourful swearing in on May 12 that was witnessed by five regional presidents, President Museveni promised to work with some "good elements" in the opposition but ruled out reconciliation with Ssemogerere, whom he called "a traitor."


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
