190 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Sierra Leone New Freetown Regime Wins Cease Fire Accord


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Abidjan - Sierra Leone's rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF), has agreed to a "final ceasefire" and will give up its armed struggle against the government in Freetown, the Ivory Coast Foreign Minister Amara Essy announced on May 15.

"RUF is turning its back once and for all on armed struggle," Essy told a press conference in the Ivorian economic capital.

Some 10,000 people have died since RUF leader Foday Sankoh launched his rebellion in March 1991 against Sierra Leone's now-defunct one- party state, and around half of Sierra Leone's 4.5 million people have fled the devastated country. 

Ivory Coast has sponsored peace talks since April 24 between the rebel fighters and the new government of President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, formed after elections in February and March.

Essy said committees were on May 15 continuing to discuss practical measures such as disarmament and the rebels' return to normal life.

The Ivorian Foreign Minister warned, however, that the two sides did not share the "same philosophical approach to this peace."

Sankoh has yet to recognise the legitimacy of Kabbah, Sierra Leone's first democratically elected chief executive in three decades.

The rebel leader vehemently opposed the elections, claiming that the civil war prevented most people from voting.

During the April talks Sankoh never used the words "president" or "government", preferring instead to speak of his "brothers on the other side of the table."

Sankoh first called a ceasefire on March 17, the day Kabbah was voted into office, and attended it on April 24.

News of the agreement came only six days after Sierra Leonean state radio alleged that more than 100 civilians had been killed by rebels in southern Sierra Leone.

The "massacre" at Bendu-Malen in the Pujehun district on May 6 was reported by local hunters who returned from Bendu-Malen where they had been monitoring the current ceasefire between the government and RUF rebels.

Quoting journalists in the area, the radio said most victims were between 50 and 75 years old, while teenage captives were taken to the main rebel base Camp Libya in the south.

One journalist who accompanied the hunters said children under five years were abandoned by the rebels who later moved on to Mattru near Jimmy Bagbor chiefdom also in the south where 16 other civilians were beaten to death by the rebels.

A promised government statement on the incident did not materialise, with observers believing that it could have been withheld in order not to jeopardise the peace negotiations in Abidjan.

However by the time of going to press, the RUF leader denied having heard about the agreement to a final ceasefire. He said although he was not a member of the delegation at the peace talks, he would have been informed about the agreement and the RUF would have to make a decision.

But he was reported saying; "I am not saying that the Ivorian Minister was lying about this agreement....We are still negotiating."


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia Refugees Leave Ships; Monrovia Fighting Worsens


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Takoradi, Ghana - Thousands of desperate Liberian refugees left a rusty and leaking freighter at this Ghanaian port on May 14 after more than a week at sea in appalling conditions, as the captain said he had been forced to take them.

Ghana, which turned the ship away on May 13 after letting it dock briefly, finally gave permission for the "Bulk Challenge" to discharge its human cargo after the United Nations and the European Union promised aid for the refugees.

The Nigerian-registered ship, packed with more than 3,000 refugees fleeing fighting in war-torn Liberia, had been turned away several times from other west African ports as well since it left Monrovia on May 5.

As the ship roamed the sea with conditions worsening on board, international pressure mounted on West African states to take in the refugees. 

The UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in Geneva said the first refugees headed for a reception centre in the village of Essipong, 10 kilometres from the port, which lies some 200 kilometres south-west of the capital, Accra.

The freighter's captain, Roland Pudie, said late on May 14 that he was "forced" by West African peacekeepers in Liberia to embark his passengers in Monrovia port and vowed that he will "never, never convey passengers on my cargo vessel again."

He said he had been hired by another Nigerian, Tom Ipawe, to "convey cargo from Monrovia to San Pedro," but at Monrovia, ECOMOG "forced" him to take the passengers, desperate to escape the factional bloodshed there.

In Sierra Leone, meanwhile, a second ship, the Victory Reefer carrying almost 1,500 refugees fleeing Liberia, docked in Freetown.

The ship had been anchored off Freetown since May 12 and aid agencies had warned of a humanitarian disaster if the refugees were not helped.

However, authorities there maintained only Sierra Leone nationals, who were the majority on board, would be allowed off the ship, with a port official saying he did not know what would happen to the rest.

The refugees ordeal came amid reports of new heavy fighting in Monrovia, which left at least 15 fighters dead on May 14, as rival militias renewed efforts to increase their areas of control in the Liberian capital.

Many of the dead were gunmen of Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), butchered with bayonets and lances by fighters of several factions dominated by the rival Krahn ethnic group. NPFL fighters, however, said they had killed 27 Krahns, but this could not be confirmed.

Some of the fiercest battles took place around the Greystone compound, a makeshift home for some 20,000 Monrovians displaced by the six-year civil war in the west African country. The compound is just yards from the United States Embassy.

The Krahns had earlier advanced into the NPFL-controlled area around Greystone by passing themselves off as factional allies of the NPFL - - there is little to distinguish one militia from another as only the most senior officers wear uniforms.

The May 14 clashes broke out between 4:00 a.m and 5:00 a.m. (0400 and 0500 GMT) after an NPFL assault was met with a powerful counter- attack by the Krahns, who pushed the NPFL back past the United States Embassy, towards the Greystone compound, looting as they advanced.

Heavy fighting was also reported on the morning of May 14 on two bridges linking the city to Bushrod Island, site of Monrovia's freeport and several hospitals.

The bridges are the only access routes available to aid agencies delivering water, food and medical supplies into the city.

The renewed clashes followed two days of relative calm in Monrovia, where on May 13 residents had begun to return to the streets to assess the damage to their homes.

On several occasions on May 13, "generals" from rival factions had put down their guns to negotiate small scale cease-fires with their opposite numbers.

The recent unrest in Monrovia broke out on April 6 when "government forces" loyal to Taylor and his fellow member of Liberia's interim council of state, Alhaji Kromah, tried to arrest Krahn faction leader "General" Roosevelt Johnson.

Armed Johnson loyalists clashed with the "government forces" and within a day, fighting and violent looting had spread to much of the city.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


192 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Churches Urged To Exploit Radio For Evangelization


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Nairobi - Churches have been challenged to exploit the increasing popularity of radio among local communities in Africa.

Prof. Stephen Talitwala, the vice chancellor of Kenya's Daystar University told guests at a dinner organised by leading Christian radio stations here; "We should not at this juncture spend more time discussing the impact of radio as a means of communication among local communities in Africa, for it is already there and is being effectively felt. Our concern now should be how effectively churches can exploit radio for evangelisation among such communities." 

The May 10 dinner was organised jointly by the Trans World Radio (TWR) and the Far East Broadcasting Association (FEBA). Both Christian broadcasting radio stations beam to Africa from Manzini, Swaziland and Seychelles, on the Indian Ocean island off the East African coast.

Guests who included clergy and Christian communicators based their discussion on the theme; "God Speaks Through Radio".

Stressing the impact of radio as a means of communication in comparison to television and print media, Prof. Talitwala noted that in Kenya, for example, there are 3 million radio sets, representing 13 radios for every 100 persons, compared to only 250,000 television sets, or one for every 100 persons.

According to Prof. Talitwala, the print media isolate the majority of Africa's population, who can neither read nor write. "In this regard, the power of radio is unmatched when measured against these other media," he emphasised.

But he cautioned the Church in Africa, that it will have to invest heavily in training of personnel, establishment of and equipping communications centres in order to realise this goal.

Mr. Kwame Rubadiri, National Director for Trans World Radio noted that while his organisation has enough funds to run radio programmes on Short Wave, churches should give financial support to enable TWR air such programmes on national radio stations.

"It is one thing to be heard on our shortwave, but another to relay our programmes on the Kenya Broadcasting Corporation (KBC), for example," said Mr. Simba Lombo, the FEBA Coordinator for East Africa.

According to some estimates, Neno, a TWR production aired five days a week through KBC, costs nearly Kshs.900,000 (about US dollars 15,790) per month.

Addressing the guests, a Nairobi lawyer, Fred Ojiambo, called on African Christians to wake up to the realisation that "God is in dire need to see them committing their resources for His good work."

Pauline Ngunjiri, who is currently coordinating promotion for TWR among churches and clergy in Africa, said the dinner was part of that campaign.

Leah Gachegu, the Audience Relations Manager for FEBA, said the idea of selling the good name of FEBA and TWR among churches and their clergy in Africa is central to the propagation of the Christian ministry through radio.

TWR which beams its religious programmes from Manzini, Swaziland, broadcasts in 25 African languages, while its Kiswahili broadcasts reach some 42 million Africans in East and Southern Africa namely Burundi, Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire. "Many of them are Muslims, and radio is their only contact with the gospel," says a TWR brochure.

FEBA beams religious programmes for Africa from the Seychelles on the Indian Ocean. It broadcasts in 43 languages. Its Kiswahili programmes benefit Christians in the East and Central African countries of Kenya, Mozambique, Rwanda, Uganda, Burundi, Tanzania and Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


193 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zimbabwe Zimbabwe Intensifies Family Planning For Disabled


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Harare - The Zimbabwe National Family Planning Council has of late increased its efforts towards selling family planning concepts to disabled persons in this country.

Although previous calls for family planning programmes for the disabled went unheeded, the ZNFPC has now stepped up its efforts through government, non-governmental organisations and the public.

"Preference for large families is still high especially in rural areas. The blind people are the most affected," said ZNFPC's programmes and Communications Manager, Mr. Godfrey Tinarwo. 

The population of the disabled parents is increasing at an alarming rate and yet most disabled parents are poor, illiterate, unemployed and underprivileged. These social problems are making it difficult for the parents to sustain their large families.

Efforts by the ZNFPC are expected to improve the current sad state of affairs. Urban centres are common sights of children of disabled parents who roam the streets begging and even demanding money from passers-by.

However, before the government, NGOs and the public can come up with suitable project proposals, the disabled society should understand the importance of smaller families which are easier to sustain, taking into account the current high cost of living.

Mr. Tinarwo said it was wrong to blame the disabled persons for their desire for large families. "Research has shown that for long, the disabled society has not had access to family planning information. Some disabled persons live in remote parts of the country," he explained.

In November 1994, organisations representing disabled people held a congress in Victoria Falls to identify and discuss problems affecting them in relation to family planning.

Since then, the ZNFPC has been working closely with care organisations dealing with the disabled. More workshops, seminars and meetings took place to enhance efforts towards the achievement of dissemination of family planning literature to members of the society who are disabled.

"We now produce special family planning literature for the disabled people including braille for the blind. We even use the media to reach many people," noted Tinarwo. According to Mr. Tinarwo, ZNFPC is going to use such promotion strategies as door to door lectures, distribution of pamphlets, use of braille and sign language for the blind and deaf respectively.

"We are also going to distribute posters of disabled persons who have successfully used family planning as well as training some of them who will go out to benefit their colleagues," Tinarwo added.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


194 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Swaziland Under Pressure, Swazi King Agrees to Changes


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Ludzidzini, Swaziland - King Mswati III has relented to political pressures from his subjects and announced some constitutional changes in his kingdom, But critics said these did not go far enough.

The Swazi monarch, who has been ruling his country by decree, kicked off the reforms by announcing on May 8 the sacking of the 74-year-old Prime Minister Mbilini Dlamini with immediate effect.

"I have decided to retire grandfather Prince Dlamini because, like in a relay, the one who fades needs to be replaced," the Swazi monarch said, without giving reasons for replacing the Prime Minister, who had held the post since 1993.

Mswati also announced that he had set up a people's Parliament at Ludzidzini, 80 kilometres south of the capital Mbabane, which would start hearing constitutional submissions by ordinary Swazis from May 9. 

Two advisory bodies, a Constitutional Committee and the Swaziland National Council, will also be set up from May 9, Mswati said, without elaborating.

President Nelson Mandela of South Africa, Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and Ketumile Masire of Botswana, had been designated by the king to attend the first session of the People's Parliament, but a spokesman for Mandela in Pretoria denied the president would be visiting South Africa's tiny neighbour in the near future.

However, political and trade union leaders left the May 8 meeting in disgust after it became apparent that Mswati, who has absolute authority over his 900,000 subjects, had no intention of lifting a 1973 decree which bans political activity.

The Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions (SFTU) secretary-general Jan Sithole described Mbilini's sacking as "window dressing." He said only the lifting of the 1973 royal decree -- made by King Sobusa II, Mswati's father -- would solve the country's problems. Sacking Mbilini, he added, was like "changing the bottle top of a Coca Cola bottle and then telling people it is Fanta."

In his budget speech in April, the monarch promised an overhaul of the country's constitution, saying it had to be "reviewed like a car which needs to be serviced."

Opposition political parties who have formed the Swaziland Democratic Alliance (SDA) have joined the Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions in demanding political reforms and an end to a state of emergency imposed in 1973 by Mswati's father, King Sobusa II.

Alliance members and SFTU leaders said they would hold urgent talks to discuss the implications of Mswati's statements. Last January, unprecedented demonstrations called by the SFTU, coupled with a crippling civil service strike, paralysed the country, sandwiched between South Africa and Mozambique.

Leaders of the two groups have warned of further industrial action if political reforms are not forthcoming. But the new move was immediately lauded by President Ketumile Masire of Botswana and South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo, who paid brief visits to Swaziland on May 9 to endorse a new political initiative by the Swazi king.

Their visit to the Lobamba Royal Kraal at his Ludzidzini village, 80 kilometres south of the capital, coincided with the first day's proceedings in a "People's Parliament," set up here by Mswati in response to demands for political reforms.

More than 4,000 Swazis turned up for the "parliament", a series of consultative public meetings between residents and government leaders.

Masire, who with his counterparts from South Africa and Zimbabwe, Nelson Mandela and Robert Mugabe, has been pressurizing the monarch to end his absolute rule in the tiny southern African country, said he was "delighted" at the new initiative.

"Change is inevitable and change will come, but change must not control you, you must manage change. We are delighted at this exercise. We believe it will bear good fruits for the future of your country," Masire told the gathering.

Nzo, who apologised for Mandela's inability to attend the meeting, stressed the need for peaceful negotiated reform in Swaziland and declared: "It is heartening to see this type of imbizo (gathering) where people are peacefully working to adopt a long-lasting democratic solution to Swaziland's problems."

"Speaking from our experience in South Africa, you must find a solution which will peacefully encompass all the differing opinions and views in Swaziland," he added.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


195 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Truth Panel To Assess First Month of Hearings


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 627 words


 
Durban - South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, appointed by President Nelson Mandela to probe human rights abuses during the apartheid era, convenes May 21 to assess the first four weeks of devastating testimony.

"We have stared at the beast of our dark past in the eye and survived," commission chairman Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu told reporters as the full 17-member commission concluded hearings in this KwaZulu-Natal port city.

Deputy chairman Alex Boraine, was reported by the South African Press Agency (SAPA), as saying that the commission hoped to present an interim report to Mandela by June, which "will include our preliminary views on the testimony that has come before us." 

The closure of the four-day Durban sitting on May 10, signalled the end of the commission's largely symbolic first round of hearings launched in mid-April and heard in East London in the Eastern Cape province, Cape Town, Johannesburg and here.

The commission has heard more than 140 cases of police brutality, political assassinations, disappearances, abductions, torture and deaths in detention spanning three decades.

During the hearings on May 10, one of South Africa's most colourful and controversial political figures accused senior members of Nelson Mandela's African National Congress (ANC) of human rights abuses during the apartheid era.

Pat Hlongwane, whose political career has taken him from the black liberation movements to the white right-wing, told the Truth and Reconciliation Commission here how he had been beaten, jailed and driven underground by the ANC.

The testimony was received with skepticism and amusement by the audience, and Hlongwane himself at one point turned around to face the crowd, flashed a toothless grin and cackled mischievously, drawing further laughter.

In general, the allegations raised at the commission were deadly serious, and Tutu, who was often moved to tears during the hearings, told a media briefing on May 10 that he had been stunned by the "depths of depravity" which had emerged in testimony.

However, he had also been struck by the willingness of victims to forgive their torturers and captors, as well as their refusal to "buckle under intense suffering, brutality and intimidation.

"We are realising we can transcend the conflict of the past. It gives me great hope for this beautiful land. We believe it is possible for our country to be healed and for us to close the door on this dark past so that blacks and whites, coloureds and Indians may be able to go forth together into this glorious future that God holds out before us," said the Cape Town Archbishop.

Archbishop Tutu said the commission wanted to hear as many people as possible over the next 18 months to two years, but there was clearly not enough time for everyone to appear before the body.

In future, smaller hearings will be held with only one commissioner and possibly a member of the commission's human rights violations committee in attendance, he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


196 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Cairo Conference Focuses on Religious Fundamentalism


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 20, 1996


LENGTH: 960 words


 

Cairo - Egypt is to host an international conference in July on the threat posed by religious fundamentalism.

The July 24 conference, sponsored by the highest Sunni Muslim authority in Egypt, Al-Azhar, will group Muslim clerics, experts and Arab officials, says Mohammed Ibrahim al-Fayumi of Egypt's Ministry of Waqf or Religious Property.

He said late April that the meeting would focus on the "phenomenon of international terrorism" arising from fundamentalism and "the position of Islam and other religions towards religious extremism."

Fayumi, quoted by the government daily Al-Akhbar, added: "All the Waqf and Islamic Affairs ministries from Arab and Muslim countries, more than 40 muftis as well as many academics from 200 countries or international organisations will take part." Eastern experts from European countries, former German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and representatives of Muslim minorities in countries such as Bosnia, Chechnya and the United States will also attend the forum in the Egyptian capital. 

The sheikh of Al-Azhar, Sheikh Mohammad Sayed Tantawi, called for such a conference last December to "show the world the true face of Islam which rejects violence."

The latest announcement comes shortly after the massacre on April 18 of Greek tourists at a Cairo hotel had uncovered an extensive Islamic fundamentalist influence, building up quietly in the slums at the foot of the country's famed Giza pyramids.

The government press warned on April 29 that the Talbiya neighbourhood had become a "new Imbaba", referring to the north Cairo slum which armed militants controlled until a massive police invasion dislodged them in 1992.

Hundreds of fundamentalist sympathizers have been arrested in Talbiya since the slaughter at the nearby Europa hotel, when gunmen mowed down a Greek tour group, killing 18, in the country's worst ever anti-tourist attack.

The Jamaa Islamiyya (Islamic Group), Egypt's main armed extremist group, claimed responsibility for the attack, sparking fears of a revival of violence after police claimed it had broken the militants.

But police and inhabitants of Talbiya say that although fundamentalism has made inroads into the large slum in southeast Cairo, it has "nothing to do" with more extreme violent groups.

Talbiya, just five kilometres from the pyramids, is one of the "unplanned areas" that sprung up without authorization around Cairo in the 1980s. Most of its 100,000 residents have electricity and water, but few of the roads in its maze of alleys are paved.

Like elsewhere in Cairo, many women wear the Muslim veils covering their hair. However the more fundamentalist "niqab," the black shroud covering the whole face except for the eyes, is also frequent.

Two non-violent Islamic groups -- the Pakistan-based Tabligh wal- Daawa (Call and Preaching) and the Salafiya, a reform movement born in Egypt in the late 19th century -- have a strong presence in the area.

Their influence spread in Talbiya under the view of authorities who have judged them "not a danger at the present time," a police source said.

But the groups, which have no legal status, are under intense surveillance, "because theoretically it is easier for the Jamaa or Muslim Brotherhood to recruit among regular citizens," the source said.

Authorities accuse the Muslim Brotherhood of links to armed groups even though the banned organisation claims it has renounced violence.

A police station is to be opened in the slum for the first time while residents said a survey began on April 26 to pinpoint fundamentalists.

"There is no presence here of the Jamaa or the Muslim Brotherhood," said a Tabligh wal-Daawa sympathiser, who asked not to be named.

"Our religious lessons at the Al-Rahma mosque (across the street from the Europa hotel) have been forbidden since the attack, but freedom will return once the attackers are arrested," he said.

"We only remind Muslims of their religious duties without entering politics, and we offer social services," he said.

Most Talbiya residents praised the groups. "They help the poor with charity given by the rich. They support schools and just rented a boarding house for a widow. They are very polite and ask for nothing in return," a local carpenter said.

But the government weekly Akhbar al-Hawadith warned that Talbiya was a "time bomb" and "a base for drug dealers and terrorists."

"Nobody knows what goes on there and those responsible for several attacks have found refuge there," the weekly Rose al-Yusef said.

Egypt has been battling a violent anti-government campaign by Muslim militants that has cost more than 1000 lives since March 1992.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


197 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology (DOCUMENT) Address by South Africa's Mbeki to G-7 Information Meeting


BYLINE: South African Communications Service May 15, 1996


LENGTH: 2694 words


 

Johannesburg - The following is the text of the opening address by South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki to the to the Information
Society and Development (ISAD) Conference in South Africa.

President Santer, Honourable Ministers and Commissioners Your Excellencies Ambassadors, Heads of Delegation and Representative of International and Regional Organisations Ladies and Gentlemen

I am honoured to convey the greetings and best wishes of our President Nelson Mandela who also asked us to extend, the very warm welcome of the people of South Africa to all participants to this Conference, and especially to those who come here from far away lands. Welcome.

Some wishes do get realised! Fifteen months ago, addressing the G7 Conference on the Information Society in Brussels, we asserted that entry into the Information Society should not be reserved for the G7 members and other Developed countries, and that the debate about the information society is indeed of relevance to all humanity. On that occasion, we proposed that the G7 initiative therefore be broadened to include a wide cross-section of developed and developing countries.

Thanks to the determination and endurance of President Santer, the European Union, the G7 countries, our fellow developing countries, the various international and regional organisations involved, and the exceptional inter-ministerial team that South Africa assembled to prepare for the hosting of this event, here we are, and I take great pleasure in opening this crucial Information and Development Conference. 

Since the G7 Brussels Conference, many events have occurred on the international scene as well as in South Africa. We wish to mention some of them here because we believe that they are of relevance to this Conference.

On the international front, we witnessed the birth of a bold United Nations-World Bank Initiative for Africa. This multi-billion dollar Initiative places people and education at its centre and attempts to refocus international aid away from traditional assistance patterns and towards more sustainable and interactive development models.

Last September, the ITU held its Telecom '95 Conference in Geneva during which President Mandela, addressing the Conference, insisted on the value of information, on the necessity of linking technology to people, and on the priority of education and training.

Telecom '95 presented the participants with ever advancing technologies and, at the same time, reminded us of the sad and ever widening gap between rich and poor, between literate and illiterate.

The path towards the information Society is not free of delicate and complex problems. We have observed the intricate and challenging discussions in the context of the World Trade Organisation on the provision of basic services. We regret that those discussions did not reach a positive conclusion.

Similarly, the issue of intellectual property rights continues to be a bone of contention among the nations and deserves, in our view, serious and fair consideration by the international community as a whole. Intellectual property, an important pillar in the building of Global Information Society, requires recognition, respect and protection.

In the midst of these and other difficulties, the corporate world is engaged in major processes leading to new mergers. Global alliances, with attendant restructuring, are being forged in various combinations, among hardware and software entities, telecommunications carriers, cable operators, satellite companies, publishing empires, broadcasting and media groups, and so on.

All these reorganisations are justified by their authors as natural and logical. Whatever the nervousness this activity may generate, it certainly demonstrates confidence in the future of the information and communication sectors as growth areas.

Like all of you here, we follow these developments and observe them carefully in the context of our own Reconstruction and Development Programme and our guiding principles in the information sector.

On the national front, as you know, our new Constitution was adopted by an overwhelming majority of South Africa's freely elected representatives a few days ago, on the 8th of May 1996. This historic document is itself focused on the development of a people-centred society, for whose realisation information and communication are central.

Incidentally, if you wish to consult our Constitution, you will find it at the following internet address: www.constitution.org.za.

As the South African government, we have issued two White Papers, one on broadcasting and the other on telecommunications. Both papers are now being circulated for comments. Several national fora on a variety of information and communication related topics have been established. They are essential participants in our policy making efforts, including the definition of our regulatory framework, which the White Paper seek to address.

Against all these activities the challenge of building the basic information and communication infrastructure, both in South Africa and in most developing countries, remains colossal and perhaps not even properly understood. For this reason the so called 'Media Revolution' seems to be substantially ignoring the developing world.

We need to ensure that the path to the Information Society does not widen the gap between rich and poor, developed and developing countries. The tragic irony we might confront, is that this technology which has enormous potential to benefit all humanity could serve to entrench and widen this gap.

Without seeking in any way to evolve an apocalyptic vision, we must contend with the nightmare that could derive from the consequent rebellion of the poor against the rich on a global scale.

The fundamental reason for this conference is to enable all of us as representatives drawn from both worlds, to grapple with these issues and not to allow the future of human society to fall victim to human ingenuity itself.

Of course, we are conscious that infrastructure will not be built overnight and that the access of the masses to information and communication tools will not become reality in a short time period.

But the time has come for all of us to act swiftly by focusing on the problems and to built common strategies on how to seize the technological opportunities presented to us today for the benefit of all nations, developed and developing alike.

Hence the timeliness of this Conference.

This Conference is unusual in many respects. Unlike most international conferences, specific in nature, drawing interest from particular industry or government sections, and often assembling participants from one economic origin, (either developing or developed), this gathering is global and multi-disciplinary, as clearly reflected in the list of our honoured guests.

Another feature of this conference is that the topics to be addressed, while all coming together from information and communication perspectives, run across a series of traditionally separate compartments (education, health, trade and industry, management, telecommunications, broadcasting, culture, science and technologies, finance, etc.).

This diversity leads, we believe, to yet another interesting feature. Although equipped with our respective guiding principles and values, we all come to this Conference open-minded, ready to learn and to interact.

It would be folly if one attempted to participate in this event on the basis of pre-conceived ideas and ready made solutions. We wonder if that could even be possible given the ever changing nature of the scene, the complexity of the debate, and the novelty of the propositions at hand.

In exploring the structure and content of the Conference programme for both the Ministerial meetings and the Fora sessions, we find that it reflects the overwhelming richness of the Information Society and Development theme itself, and holds for us the perspective of an exciting and instructive outcome.

Behind the seemingly endless and diverse list of inter-related or totally desperate discussion items, there appear to be three distinct pillars around which this Development Conference is conceived: infrastructure, content and finance.

On the first one, as mentioned earlier, there would be no Information Society without proper infrastructure and delivery mechanisms adapted to the global development needs of the people.

We are not talking only of the rich neighbourhoods in major cities, but also of the small villages and townships, rural and remote areas; not only of residential, industrial and downtown business districts, but also schools, hospitals, colleges and universities.

Content in news, educational, cultural and entertainment programmes, songs, games, etc., plays a pivotal role in the building of the Information Society.

Therefore the creation, production and formulation of content must be encouraged at all levels, not only at the national level of all developing countries but, within the same nation, at the local and community levels, to ensure that developing nations do not remain information consumers of a content conceived by others.

Infrastructure allows for the transformation of people inspiration, creativity and artistic, literary and scientific skills into the production of education and entertainment works shared by all.

The third pillar of this construction is finance. I hope that the participants will find time to concentrate on this important question and engage in exchanges, irrespective of their national or social affiliation.

It would also be useful that, beyond the official government exchanges, the industry itself, as well as the banking and finance sectors, participate in this interaction among these three pillars, leads us to discuss the indispensable co-operation among the three players, government, business and communities.

It has been demonstrated that government plays a pivotal role in the building of the Information Society. If this vision is not shared within and outside government, then the road ahead becomes more difficult.

Ample examples exist from developed countries themselves where, in spite of the predominant doctrine for minimal intervention, government acts as a catalyst for the establishment and consolidation of the Information Society.

Often, and in co-operation with international and regional organisations, government contributes to the Information Society through tax and other incentives, using existing parastatal companies, regulatory agencies, educational institutions, etc.

There is, however, a crucial public policy dimension which rests on the shoulders of the government and on the people's elected representatives - ensuring that this Information Society supports and enhances the objectives of development, empowerment, economic development and preserves the constitutional values on which the whole national edifice is built.

One of the concerns we expressed in Brussels pertains to the lack of an adequate regulatory framework to deal with the overall flows of information and cultural products.

The realities of imbalance and domination between North and South must be dealt with more by empowering the South through co-operation and openness and mutually beneficial contributions rather than censorship and control.

This concern is still with us. Permit me, Ladies and Gentlemen, to raise it again in the hope that renewed attention be devoted to it in this Conference.

But government is not the only player. The private sector is entitled and indeed encouraged to play its role. Beyond the status of an information technology user, industry and trade must encourage training, foster internal communication by using modern technologies, invest in long term initiatives, and assist schools and hospitals with communication and information equipment and systems.

In turn, these actions benefit the people and the business community alike, making the people better and more educated workers, more powerful consumers, significant investors, better doctors, nurses, entrepreneurs and teachers, and increasing their numbers.

To government and business, one must add communities and organisations of civil society. From trade unions to churches and charitable organisations, to municipalities and civic groups, all these art part of this endeavour.

Their role is essential because they convey the untouched, unprocessed sentiments of parents, family, youth and women, and therefore instruct us on the reality, nature and magnitude of their true needs, aspirations and potential.

We, in South Africa, strive to nurture and consolidate the tenets of a people-centred-society, creating, while using the means of information and communication a Learning Nation where innovation and knowledge are promoted, protected and rewarded.

We wish success to all the participants in this Conference which we consider as a milestone on the road to better international co-operation. We trust that your conclusions, distinguished delegates, will be followed by concrete initiatives and renewed interaction.

And in spite of your heavy schedule, I urge you to find the time to enjoy our beautiful country. This is your home!

Thank you very much.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

May, 1996


Ethiopia Court Hearing Witnesses To Attack on Mubarak


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 16, 1996


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Addis Ababa - Court sources said the Federal High Court has begun hearing testimonies of witnesses of the special prosecutor against three Egyptian terrorists who allegedly attempted to kill President Hosni Mubarak in Addis Ababa last June.

They said the witnesses appeared before the court which considered the cases of the alleged terrorists in cameral last Friday. 

According to the sources, the court has adjourned ordering the special prosecutor to present additional evidence justifying its charges against the defendants.

Of the alleged international terrorists, nine had illegally entered into Ethiopia and involved in the June attempt to murder the Egyptian leader.

Five of the alleged assassins, sources said, were done away with the same day by the Ethiopian security forces, while the suspects whose cases are being considered by the court were apprehended four days later in Addis Ababa.

Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large African GDP Up, Trade Deficits Down


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 18, 1996


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Addis Ababa - The growth rate of African Gross Domestic Product (GDP) rose from 2.7 percent two years ago to 3.7 percent while the deficits went down by two percent from seven percent a year earlier due to tighter budgetary controls, the president of African Export-Import Bank siad.

At a press conference held yesterday at ECA, Mr. C.C Edordu indicated that the satisfactory economic progress of Africa has created a favourable condition for the operation of the bank which he said was established with a view to bringing about, among others, the stimulation and elargement of Intra-African trade as well as Africa's share in global trade. 

Since its commencement of operation in 1994, the bank approved a 141 million dollars loan grossing an income of 12 million U.S. dollars in its first year of operation and netting a profit of 6 million, Mr. Edordu said.

The bank has also the aim of diversifying African export goods and facilitating financial services and loans in a bid to make African trade competent in the global trading activities, the director noted.

He listed the low involvement of Africa in the global trade, the less diversified export goods and the few trade partners as deterrent factors in the bank's activities.

The bank, whose headquarters is in Cairo, has over a hundred shareholders from among African governments, African and non African financial institutions, and private investors.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Ethiopia Witness Says Derg Buried Emperor's Aides


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 18, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Addis Ababa - The sixth witness of the prosecutor against senior Derg officials said he had seen when the 59 officials of Emperor Haile Selassie were buried en masse in late 1975 here at the Addis Ababa prison house.

The witness, a former prison inmate, gave a brief account of how he took part in the digging of a huge mass grave and helped to bury the 59 high ranking officials in broad day light on November 1975.

The witness told the court that in the wee hours of the night he and scores of other prisoners collected the bodies of the executed officials and taken to the huge grave where the ill-fated burial ceremony was conducted. 

The witness said the executed high officials were dumped into the grave their corpses mixed with limestone.

The witness, 40, said the number of officials butchered at the time was 62 and cited the names of four of his fellow inmates who look part in the diging of the huge grave.

The first Bench of the Central High Court also heard the testimony of an old man who, said, was present during a meeting of the then military ruling council which decided the death of the 59 former high official of the imperial regime.

The 64 year old witness told the court that the participants of the meeting, chaired by former dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam, voted for capital punishment with a simple majority.

Two senior officials including the then foreign minister Ketema Yifru escaped the penalty while 59 others were grossly executed the witness said.

He recalled the names of 37 senior Derg officials who took part in the meeting.

Upon request, the witness who was cross-examined by defence lawyers pointed his finger at defendant Gessess Wolde kidan and identify him as one of the participants of the meeting.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


201 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia (DOCUMENT) UN Official Says Liberians Want Intervention


BYLINE: United Nations May 16, 1996


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

United Nations - Liberian opinion leaders are strongly suggesting that the United Nations should take over the country as a trust territory, James Jonah, Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Liberia, said at a Headquarters press briefing this morning.

Responding to questions on his visit to the region, he said leaders of Liberian civil society groups he met in Sierra Leone, in Ghana and even in camps in Liberia were of the view that "there's no way out at the present time in Liberia, either for the Abuja Accords or any other peace plan". He did not know whether the proposal would be appealing to Member States because of the costs involved, "but this a proposal of a significant number of Liberians in and outside of Liberia". 

Asked for his personal view of the proposal, he said he thought it was a good idea, but he was also fully aware from his own involvement with the United Nations and the Security Council that "there's no taste for it". It could not be implemented if governments were not willing to assume the costs and the danger, as the warlords would try to make it as difficult as possible for the United Nations to operate a transitional system in Liberia. He had informed the Security Council of his personal reading of what he believed was the wrong lessons of the situation in Somalia which had put "us in a very serious position in Africa -- the tendency of governments to say we're not going to get involved because of the costs in blood and resources". He said it was a very dangerous idea which had to be re-evaluated. Governments had seen the results of such attitudes already in Rwanda.

Responding to further questions, he said the Liberian opinion leaders felt that United Nations trusteeship was the only way left. Everything had been tried, including what Mr. Jonah described as the "big gun theory" -- which was getting all the warlords together and letting them sort it out. "They have not sorted it out and what we have here is a tragic scene of refugees on the high seas and no place to land. That is really tragic." The Liberian situation was the tip of the iceberg of similar ones elsewhere.

Asked about the use of "crack" by the armed elements in Liberia, Mr. Jonah described it as "a cancer in the body politic of Africa". He said young boys and girls were kidnapped by the armed factions from villages and then given drugs. "That is the way they are kept in line", he said, adding that "it reminded him of an old British policy of giving soldiers a pint of beer". He said he had stated at a briefing of members of the Security Council that it was time "the world focused on this very dangerous tendency among armed elements". He said the use of drugs was widespread and not limited only to Liberia and Sierra Leone.

What was the implication of the failure of west African leaders to hold their summit on the situation in Liberia in Accra last week? Were they getting fed up with the situation in Liberia, as generally believed? a correspondent asked. It was true that some leaders felt that way, Mr. Jonah said, noting that the scheduled meeting was the fourteenth by Heads of State of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) on Liberia alone. He gathered it was not a failure as such, but some of the leaders had felt there was no point attending when the two principal warlords, Charles Taylor and Alhaji Kromah, had indicated that they would not be present. The meeting had consequently been held at foreign ministers level with the summit rescheduled for early August to give the factions more time to "shape up".

He told a questioner that reports of involvement of the Economic Community of West African States' Monitoring Observer Group (ECOMOG) troops in stealing in Liberia could be exaggerated. He did not detect any organized large-scale looting by them during his visit, but he did hear of individual ECOMOG soldiers being involved. There had also been similar cases of commerce by ECOMOG troops trading in arms.

Mr. Jonah said he had informed the Security Council about a case of a vessel landing in Guinea with a good quantity of looted materiel. He said a responsibility had to be established. Without justifying their actions, he said many of the soldiers had not been paid for months. It was important that ECOMOG be given support for its job in Liberia.

Would action be taken against those individual soldiers responsible for looting? a correspondent asked, to which Mr. Jonah replied that such action rested with governments of the troop-contributing countries. The situation in Liberia, he said, was one of complete chaos, with no government to speak of. Under those conditions it would be very difficult to identify those responsible.

Asked whether it was possible to organize elections in Liberia before the achievement of genuine peace, as was done in Sierra Leone, Mr. Jonah said there were many differences although he did not believe it could not be done. There were too many armed factions in Liberia, while Sierra Leone had only two. "We were lucky in Sierra Leone to have a vibrant civil society voice -- women's groups, the press and church leaders who were very vocal and could not be cowed by the government. In Liberia it's extremely difficult for any one to open his mouth. These civil society groups have all gone underground." He also said that the fighting in Sierra Leone was confined to a section of the country, mostly in the east and south and intermittently in the north, while in Liberia, it was a generalized situation. Drawing on the Namibia experience in which South African forces there were confined to specific areas and monitored, Mr. Jonah said it was possible to envisage a similar programme in Liberia, "if there is no way out" there. Armed elements could be confined and monitored but not fully disarmed. It was a possibility that should be explored, he said.

Asked why the warring factions could not live together, he said it was "a very difficult issue for Africa". There was no incentive on the part of those armed elements to make peace, he said, adding that they were prosperous under the prevailing circumstances. They were engaged in commerce, whether in timber or diamond trade. "It is very lucrative", Mr. Jonah said. It was a problem that had to be addressed. It was not a question of their inability to live together because of ethnic differences. The faction leaders were not enemies, but were schoolmates, even relatives. They could be seen together at conferences, but would resume fighting on their return to Liberia. What was happening in the country was, in a way, a commercial war.

Asked whether the peace process in Liberia was on course or dead, he said that as far as he could judge, there were difficulties in implementing it. The West African Foreign Ministers had been able to propose what he termed "sensible ideas" to put the process back on track. The question was whether the faction leaders would accept them. He hoped the process would be back on track; otherwise some countries might pull out from the endeavor altogether.

Noting Mr. Jonah's description of the Liberian situation as a commercial war, a correspondent commented that there had been a couple of situations where the United Nations had imposed sanctions on rebel groups such as UNITA in Angola and Khmer Rouge in Cambodia. Was there some kind of action that could be taken to stop their trading, weaken their position and force them to the peace table? the correspondent asked. Mr. Jonah said sanctions had been imposed on Liberia about three years ago, but what had to be done was more than that. Those who engaged in commerce with the warlords were often not Liberians, or Africans. In many cases, they were Europeans and their governments are aware of what was going on. The businessmen were "covertly encouraging" those trading in illicit diamond mining and timber in exchange for weapons. "If there are no buyers they will not continue with the trade. I think one has to look deeply into that." The governments concerned should look into their laws to bar their nationals from engaging in trade with "warlords who are only concerned with enriching themselves, and in the process impoverishing their country and bringing about the loss of innocent lives".

Would he recommend some form of a transitional authority in Liberia or a "United Nations presence across the board"? Mr. Jonah noted that there was a transitional government in place in Liberia. He personally did not like such transitional bodies because of their tendency "to continue forever".


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


202 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa (DOCUMENT) U.S. Makes Pledge For Liberian Refugees


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 19, 1996


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is the text of a statement released by the Office of the White House press secretary after a meeting May 17 between Vice President Al Gore and United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Sadako Ogata:

Vice President Gore today met with United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), Mrs. Sadako Ogata on the situation in Liberia and pledged an additional $1 million for UNHCR's regional program for the Liberian refugees in the region.

The United States released immediately $25,000 in emergency funds from the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) to assist the Government of Ghana in addressing the urgent needs of the Bulk Challenge refugees. The United States has provided $68.4 million so far this year for refugee assistance in Africa, including for Liberians. The UNHCR staff is working with the Government of Ghana, the Red Cross and non-governmental organizations to provide food, shelter and emergency medical care to these refugees. Vice President Gore told High Commissioner Ogata, "We stand ready to provide additional funding if UNHCR's emergency funds prove insufficient in the current crisis.'" The United States welcomes the decision of the Government of Ghana to disembark Liberian refugees from the cargo freighter Bulk Challenge. This action by President Rawlings and his government to allow life-saving aid and refuge for these suffering people is not only consistent with its international responsibilities under the OAU and Geneva Conventions, but also a model for other nations. 

The United States deplores the continued fighting in Liberia that is the cause of this new outflow of Liberian refugees. Responsibility for this humanitarian catastrophe rests squarely with the faction leaders. The United States strongly reiterates its call on the faction leaders to end the senseless fighting in Liberia, reestablish the cease-fire, restore Monrovia as a safehaven and recommit to the Abuja peace process.

The United States will continue its diplomatic efforts, in concert with ECOWAS, the U.N. and the OAU, to encourage a negotiated settlement in Liberia, and is ready to support any Liberian government that comes to power peacefully.


LOAD-DATE: May 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Malawi Malawi Congress Party Seeking Redress


BYLINE: Malawi News Online May 17, 1996


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Blantyre - The opposition Malawi Congress Party (MCP) is challenging a 1993 High Court ruling that awarded the current Finance, Economic Planning and Development Minister, Aleke Banda, US$35,000 (MK300,000), after he sued the MCP for defamation, for accusing him at a rally - the proceedings of which were given live broadcast on the national radio the same day - of stealing money from the Press Corporation Limited (PCL).

Counsel for the MCP, George Kaliwo, said the registrar of the High Court erred in law and fact in its ruling. He argued that the status of Aleke Banda in society did not warrant such damages. He also argued that the MCP was not represented during the hearing which led to the court accepting as evidence, Banda's view of his own reputation.

Counsel for Banda, Pondomo Msiska, said it was not his client fault that representatives of MCP did not turn up when the case was heard. The hearing is to continue

May, 1996


Malawi World Bank Lends Malawi Mk1.6 Billion


BYLINE: Malawi News Online May 17, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Blantyre - The World Bank announced May 4 it will extend about US$107 million (MK1.6 billion) in credit to the Malawi government to help in fiscal restructuring and deregulation programmes. A statement from the World Bank office in Lilongwe said the credit will be financed through the International Development Association (IDA),to help generate growth in the economy. 

The facility will, in addition to supporting public expenditure, planning and management, finance public sector reform and tax and tariff systems, adopt policy measures that will broaden the participation of poorer Malawians in the economy and help remove constraints on pricing and marketing of small-holder produce.

May, 1996


Malawi Housing Authority In Dispute With Tenants


BYLINE: Malawi News Online May 17, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Blantyre - Malawi Housing Corporation (MHC) has raised rents by 279% in the last 12 months. At a recent meeting in Blantyre, tenants said, with the backing of the Consumers' Association of Malawi (CAMA), that if the corporation did not back down they would seek a court injunction to force it to reduce rents. MHC, a parastatal organisation, is undergoing restructuring to bring it into line with the government's privatisation program.

The minimum monthly rental for a three bedroomed house with electricity and running water in high density areas is US$167 (MK2500). The minimum wage in Malawi is US$30 (MK450).

Africa News


May, 1996


Somalia Camels Inoculated To Halt Epidemic


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 15, 1996


LENGTH: 738 words


 

Negelle - The Somalia agricultural department said some 13,000 camels were inoculated between March and April this year in a bid to prevent camel epidemic rampant in four woredas of the zone. 

Over 300 head of cattle have so far died from the epidemic that spread in Dolo Ado, Liben, Moyale and Arero woredas, the department head, Ato Usman Ali said.

Since when the inoculation began, the epidemic has shown a sign of abatement, he said and expressed fear that lack of adequate medicine might made full control of the disease impossible.

The head called on governmental and non-governmental organisations to provide the necessary support for the fight against the epidemic.

Ethiopia Federal Judges Take Oath Of Office


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 15, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Addis Ababa - Judges appointed to the federal courts of the Ethiopian Federal Democratic Republic yesterday were sworn in at the House of Peoples Representatives.

The appointment of the judges, nine for the supreme, 23 for the central and 24 for the magistrate, was approved at the 30th regular meeting of the House held here last Tuesday. 

Ato Kemal Bederi appointed as President of the Federal's Supreme Court and Ato Menbre-Tsehay Tadesse, as vice president as well as the other judges took oath, pledging to discharge their responsibilities with devotion.

In a related development, the House of the Peoples Representatives during the session also endorsed the proclamation issued on the loan agreement reached between the Ethiopian Government and the International Development Agency as well as the draft document issued to improve the proclamation on income tax payments.

According to the economic affairs committee of the House the loan to be used for the national food grain project will reinvigorate the five year development programme as well as the capacities of institutions which carry out researches on seeds.

The document on income tax payments is believed to improve the country's trade activities and attract foreign investors.

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Post Libel Case Resumes


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 15, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Lusaka - Divisional police prosecutor, Teddy Nondo, was yesterday told Post editors will not accept a mock trial in their criminal libel cases with President Frederick Chiluba.

Talking to Nondo before resident magistrate Betty Musonko came into the court room to resume trial, Post editor-in-chief Fred M'membe claimed the story that appeared in yesterday's Times of Zambia alleging that he and the paper's special projects editor, Masautso Phiri, and their lawyers failed to show up at court for trial was part of the state's "dirty tricks".

M'membe and Phiri are in court for a story their paper published on June 13, 1995 alleging that President Chiluba's Zairean lover, with whom he has an eight year daughter, was detained by the state in connection with a Post article concerning the President's biological father Luka Chabala Kafupi. 

"Our records and those of our lawyers indicate that the case was supposed to come up on May 14 and 15," M'membe told Nondo, asking: " Where did the prosecution get May 13?"

The two editors warned that they will not accept anything short of a fair trial and the political or social status of President Chiluba will not be accepted as a basis for denying them justice.

"It doesn't matter whether it is god Chiluba who is the complainant or any other such emperor, we have to get a fair trial," M'membe said. "Short of this there will be no trial. We will stop coming to court and you can send us back to Chimbokaila."

The duo warned that this time, unlike the first time the matter was brought before the court, they will take no mistreatment from anyone - be it President Chiluba, the chief justice, the magistrate or the President's prosecutor.

"We know the Chief Justice ruled that President Chiluba is above the law and not equal before the law with us, but we once brought to court, expect fairness," M'membe carped. " Otherwise just convict us without a hearing."

Phiri accused the state of trying to round up all the defence's witnesses so that it becomes difficult for them to defend themselves.

"You must have had a field day yesterday," Phiri remarked in reference to Monday when Nondo and President Chiluba's aide, deputy minister Eric Silwamba, who is the main prosecutor in the case, paraded the state witnesses in court.

But prosecutor Nondo took the charges calmly and simply strolled out of court.

Nondo denied that there were any "dirty tricks" in the mix-up of dates.

And soon after the defence and the prosecution were seen joking and laughing with each other in a rather more friendly atmosphere.

When queried about his apparent patching up with deputy minister Silwamba, M'membe said: "Eric has been a friend of mine for many years, he is still my friend and he will continue to be my friend. This case and this government will one day come to pass."

Defence lawyer Sakwiba Sikota, who had held up the start of the trial because of commitments in the Supreme Court, said when the case resumed that as far as he knew, the trial was supposed to resume yesterday and continue today and not Monday. He apologised for the mix-up and proposed that the trial resume today and continue tomorrow.

And Silwamba raised no objections to the adjournment.


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Sports - Soccer News From Premier Soccer League


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 16, 1996 by


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Lusaka - Visiting English referee David Eagle has been appointed to handle this Saturday's FAZ Premier Division league soccer match between City of Lusaka and Kabwe Warriors at Woodlands Stadium.

The Englishman is in Zambia on an assignment with Lonrho and extended his business trip to refereeing. He also held a meeting with RAZ chief Kabungo Katongo and Confederation of African Football CAF instructor Chileshe Mukuka.

Referees Association of Zambia general secretary Lawrence Siloya announced in Luanshya that Eagle would handle the match with Gibson Lukoshi and Steven Lungu as his linesmen.

Eagle who has been in Zambia for two weeks, is a senior referee in Solihull and watched the clash between Rumlex and City last weekend and was impressed by the performance of the two teams and refereeing standards.

Eagle is expected to leave for England next Tuesday after showing Zambian soccer fans how the game of football can be handled 'the English way.'

Meanwhile the first of the six foreign internationals on the Zambia national team arrived home on Tuesday saying he was in tip-top condition for next month's World Cup game against Sudan.

Half-back Harrison Chongo who turns out for Saudi Arabian First Division Al Tawun said he was looking forward to joining residential camp after a short rest.

''I'll need a few days' rest and time to see my family in Mufulira before I can be ready to join camp, but I am looking forward to it,'' he said at Lusaka International Airport.

Chongo said his central defence partners for Zambia, Elijah Litana, who also plays in the Saudi league would be home next week as the season in the oil-rich gulf kingdon had closed for a break.

May, 1996


Zambia Zambian Parliament Press Update


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency May 15, 1996


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Lusaka - Parliament today wound-up debate on the 1996 Constitution Amendment Bill and the Constitution of Zambia Bill paving way for amendments to be passed in the committee stage tomorrow.

To enter the committee stage the Bill mustered 121 votes against the two cast against it by Mongu Central MP, Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika and her sister, Dr Inonge (Senanga), both of whom are on the opposition National Party ticket.

The two bills, however, passed without the contributions of UNIP members of parliament as well as Sikongo MP, Simon Zukas (MMD), Lusaka Central MP, Dipak Patel (MMD) and Solwezi central MP, Humphrey Mulemba (NP). 

Earlier Speaker of the National Assembly, Robinson Nabulyato, had curtailed debate on the Bill after 37 members debated it for two consecutive days in addition to the two days of the previous week.

The Speaker said further debate will only create repetition which would be at the expense of other parliamentary work.

Winding up debate leader of the House and State Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda assured that there was nothing racist or hostile about the Bill. Brigadier-General Miyanda (retired) urged opposition MP's to reconsider their opposing stand and contribute to the amendments in the 1996 draft constitution at committee stage.

And the Constitution of Zambia Bill, which in essence gives legality to the Amendment Bill also went through to committee stage where all the amendments including submissions made to the Mwanakatwe Constitution Review Commission will be made.

The bill also provides for the legal printing and publication of the amended constitution, saving and transitional provisions of existing offices, institutions and law and the succession of property, assets, rights, liabilities, obligations and legal proceedings.

Other bills presented today were the Zambia Institute of Mass Communication (ZAMCOM) repeal bill to repeal the Mass Communication Bill of 1991 and the Ministerial and Parliamentary offices Emoluments Amendment Bill to amend the 1992 act. They will come-up for debate tomorrow.

OPPOSITION United National Independence Party (UNIP) members ended their parliamentary boycott this afternoon after the conclusion of the contentious Constitutional (Amendment) Bill debate.

The group of UNIP parliamentarians walked in when the House was considering the Land (Amendment) Bill which passed through second reading with no debate.

Thereafter, Environment and Natural Resources Minister, William Harrington presented the Action for Smoke Damage (prohibition) (repeal) Bill for second reading.

Moving the motion, Mr Harrington said the Act which was enacted in colonial time had to be repealed because it had become old fashioned, oppressive and repulsive.

He said that an investigation taken in 1988 revealed that there was an increase in the number of people reporting to clinics complaining of sneezing in the wind ward direction of Mufulira and Luanshya mines.

The minister further told the House that about 'millions' of tonnes of caborn dioxide were polluting the air annually.

He added that about one million people in the country were exposed to dangerous sulpher dioxide, carbon monoxide and other air impurities arising from smoke from mines and industries.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Zambian Maize "Glut" Tempts Company To Export


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency May 15, 1996


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Ndola - An imminent glut of mealie meal on the market has prompted Indeco Milling to look outward for the export of the commodity and other by-products of maize to Zaire and Burundi.

The company intends to export brewer's grit to beer manufacturers in Zaire and Burundi. 

Acting General Manager of the firm Andrew Luombe said the enquiries for brewer's grit by brewery plants in Zaire and Burundi made when government banned export of maize last year would be revisited.

He said the ban has now been lifted and it would help to improve the market which would have been choked because of the abundance of maize.

The company had to adjust the price of mealie meal by a considerable margin on may 2 because of hightened supply of maize.

The wholesale price of breakfast is k11,300 from k13,000 per 25kg bag and k9,400 from k10,300 per 25kg bag roller.

Mr Luombe said the company was, however, still able to sell its products because of the high quality despite competition from hammer mills dotted all over the town.

The company is at the moment also producing mealie meal for Mulungushi Investment and Sunvest Milling on contract following increased capacity of the plant after Commissioning of another mill.

May, 1996


Zambia 'Post" Defamation Case In Court


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency May 15, 1996


LENGTH: 480 words


 
Lusaka - A 36-year-old Chingola woman today denied before the magistrates court that she was President Frederick Chiluba's lover as alleged by the independent Post newspaper.

The woman, who said she was a businesswoman, gave her name as Mununga Muzyinga Clementina and told Lusaka Magistrate Mrs Betty Musonko that she has never met President Chiluba in her life and that it was not true she had a daughter with him although she was unmarried with three children from three different men.

Ms Mununga Muzyinga of House number 26, Bulanda Street, Maikulile in Chingola was testifying in a case of defamation of President Chiluba by Post newspaper Managing Director and Editor-in-Chief, Fred M'membe and special projects editor, Matsauso Phiri emanating from a June 13 Post pulication in which it was alleged that the President's Zairean lover Clementine Mutshinga Kabondo, in apparent reference to Ms Mununga, was detained and interrogated in connection with the Kafupi story and her photograph appeared in the edition. 

Ms Mununga both denied that her name was Kabondo and that she ever knew the alleged President Chiluba's alleged 'father' Kafupi Chabala.

She also denied that she gave the Post the photograph saying the picture could have been acquired from her friend Marianne who was the custodian at the time.

Asked by Divisional Prosecutions Officer, Teddy Nondo, names of the fathers of her children, the woman who said she was a Luvale from Zambezi district said her eldest daughter born in 1981 was Kailu Kainga whose father she remembers him as Mateyo. The second, a son, was Sydney Malama whose father was Sai Malama and the last one Bridget Lumba whose father was Lumba.

The woman told the court that the Post story was a mere fabrication which made her unhappy.

Earlier, the court dismissed two defence applications which had been put forward to stop proceeding with the trial until State House deputy minister, Eric Silwamba testified and that two other cases of defamation involving the same accused persons be joined together on one charge sheet.

Mrs Musonko adjourned the case to June 19 and 20 for cross examination and continued trial.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

213 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia UNIP Releases Its Manifesto


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 15, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition UNIP will commit itself to democracy and a lasting foundation for plural politics through the establishment of viable institutions which will ensure citizens' participation in national issues, promised party president Kenneth Kaunda in Lusaka yesterday.

Speaking at a press conference to launch the 1996 UNIP manifesto at Pamodzi Hotel, president Kaunda complained about the rapid deterioration in the quality of life of Zambians since the MMD came to power in November 1991.

"In 1994 the decline was 7 per cent and in 1995 it was 4 per cent while the population continues to grow at 3.4 per cent," Kaunda said. "The economy has been grossly mismanaged and abused as evidenced by an unstable macro-economic environment as indicated by high inflation, high unemployment and unstable exchange rates." President Kaunda, who partially conceded that the economy had started to decline under his government, blamed the deterioration on the liberation struggle in the Southern African region and the "the energy crisis which tripled the cost of oil in 1973, inducing a worldwide recession". 

" The need to sustain development against the background of these overwhelming factors forced the government to start borrowing from the international money markets," president Kaunda explained. " Our consultations with the World Bank and International Monetary Fund then affirmed the need to sustain development." The UNIP president also reiterated his earlier claims that the privatisation programme was his government's 'baby'.

"There is ample evidence that the MMD is doing what we left. If you check the 1989 budget speech of my former finance minister late Gibson Chigaga, you will find everything that MMD are doing," president Kaunda said, asking: "Who copied from who?"

President Kaunda also complained about the level of political maturity. "Thirty two years after attaining nationhood we are trivialising important national issues and developing personal constitutions," Kaunda said.

And president Kaunda vowed to defy the law if the Constitution bill is passed to bar him from contesting for presidency. "To bar me from standing one has to go and dig out my umutoto( umbilical cord), dig all the bones of old man David Kaunda and Hellen Kaunda from Lubwe Mission in Chinsali," Kaunda challenged. "Without that there is no hope at all."

But Finance Minister Ronald Penza said Kaunda should go ahead and exhume his mother if that pleases him but Zambia would not again allow him to rule. Kaunda re-affirmed his support for the UNIP walk-out from Parliament saying " UNIP did not want to legitimise criminal acts". "We fully support our colleagues for what they have done as almost all political leaders and other interested parties, including the Mwanakatwe Commission, recommended consensus as the approach to the adoption of the constitution." President Kaunda also charged that MMD chairman Sikota Wina's last week's accusations of interference in Zambia's internal affairs by Botswana president and chairman of the Frontline heads of state, Quett Masire, for suggesting that a meeting be convened to address "the crisis in Zambia" showed the extent to which the MMD was detached from "reality".

"It's surprising that they are saying there is no crisis," president Kaunda said. "This is not reading the situation correctly."


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance South African Cosmetics Links With Zambia


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 15, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - Two local companies have been appointed joint distributors of South Africa's Justine range of skin care products in the country.

The companies, Douceur Beauty Cosmetics and Bellwood Investments Corporation, won distributorship of the leading South African cosmetic products range, Justin and Avon, which is one of the world's largest seller of skin care products. 

Speaking in an interview at the inauguration of the beauty products on Monday, the two companies' spokesperson Margaret Nkula disclosed that the two companies will hold a two day exhibition at Lusaka's Pamodzi Hotel to introduce the Zambian public to the skin care products.

Similar workshops, to be conducted by the group's international marketing manager Estelle Von Mollendorf, will be held in Ndola and Kitwe.

"The workshop is targeted at professionals in business, women, diplomats, potential distributors, wholesale and retail assistants and also media personnel," Nkula said.

And speaking in an interview last Wednesday London based professional beautician, Cynthia Lewis, disclosed that good cosmetic products were difficult to find in Zambia.

"The only problem we have in our industry is the acquisition of high quality beauty products," Lewis carped. " This forces us to import whenever we need the products."

And with an annual turnover of R16 billion, the Justin and Avon group are one of the largest direct sellers of beauty skin care products which include fragrances, toiletries and cosmetics.

The group has been the official sponsors of the Miss South Africa and Miss World contests during the last four years.
