Sports - Olympics Judo: Association Attacks Zambian Association


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 15, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - The Judo Association of Zambia (JAZ) has launched a scathing attack on the Zambia Olympics and Commonwealth Games Association (ZOCAGA) for dropping two judokas from the list of Zambian sportsmen and women going for the "Atlanta 96" games.

Judo chief, Mohammed Bachher, in a recent interview in Lusaka expressed surprise at the decision by ZOCAGA to drop the only judokas, Moola Lipile and Hilter Shakaungu, moaning that it was unfair. 

"None of the people from ZOCAGA has ever been to a Judo tournament to assess the strength of our judokas and suddenly they decide, without even informing us, that they are dropping judokas. This is unfair," moaned Machher.

According to ZOCAGA boss, Patrick Chamunda, the decision to drop the judokas was reached because of the poor training programmes they had.

"The Judokas have not had very serious preparations, hence the decision to drop them. We are only carrying the six athletes and six boxers in whom we have confidence," said Chamunda in a press statement recently.

Sports - Soccer Zambian Team Appoints Captain


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 16, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - ZANACO goalkeeper James Phiri has been appointed national team acting skipper in the absence of the inspirational Kalusha Bwalya.

National team camp manager, Solly Pandor, when confirming the appointing of the Zambian national team's first choice goalie, explained that it was a normal appointment. 

"I can confirm that James is the captain of the national team, and he is the one that was in charge of the team while in Malawi. It is just a normal appointment," said Pandor.

Pandor, who further disclosed that former deputies to Kalusha Bwalya Kenneth 'Bubble' Malitoli and Aggrey Chiyangi will remain assistants, however insisted the appointment was not based on the performance of the players.

"We just appointed him captain and we could have even appointed any other player if we wanted but this is not because of how one plays. Aggrey is the second assistant to James while Kenneth is the third," explained Pandor.

217 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Zambia Talks Mining Deal With Investors


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 15, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Lusaka - Talks between the government and private investors on the Konkola Deep Mining Project have to be concluded soon to avert a possible copper 'drought' due to delays in implementation of the project.

According to Konkola Division general manager, Ben Chileshe, the government has been working out the modalities of a joint private venture with a host of other investors led by Anglo American.

The consortium of investors, which includes mining giants such as Gencor and Western Mining of Australia, is contributing about $650 million in capital for the project though they are yet to agree with the government on the division of interests. 

ZCCM hopes that the implementation of the Konkola Deep Project, which can only start producing revenue in eight years time if it were started in the next few months, will increase Zambia's copper production as well as make it more competitive on the world market.

Upon completion, production at Konkola is expected to increase from the current two million tonnes of ore to six million tonnes, representing 50 per cent of Zambia's copper production.

Zambia is currently producing 300,000 tonnes of copper annually.

"We are also concerned that if we don't get the investment soon then the country might lose revenue as Nchanga Open Pit Mine, a major copper producer, is closing down," he said.

Chileshe disclosed that the current production cost of 68 cents per pound of Konkola copper was not favourable as it reduces the profit margin.

He revealed that when Konkola Deep is finished, it will be producing at a cost of 32 cents a pound, over half the former cost.

However, Chileshe said the Mufulira smelter is tied to the Konkola Deep Project as it has been identified as the refinery for Konkola ore because there is no smelter at Konkola.

This means that in this first step towards the privatisation of the mines, both Konkola Deep and the Mufulira Smelter are being negotiated in a single package.

The $650 million being contributed by the consortium is to be used over eight years in a programme which will see a new shaft system being installed and the re-training of staff, among other things, to raise mining standards to internationally competitive levels.

And of the 5000 workers employed by Konkola, 1,000 workers will have lost their jobs by the end of the privatisation process because the company is departing from labour intensive methods.

Chileshe said the reduced work force will be able to produce more because about 250 machines will replace the use of underground labour.

However, he said employment should not be of much concern because the privatisation of the mines would create diversification in the industry.

"We will need these new machines coming in to be maintained so other private satellite companies can be formed to service our organisation thus creating employment," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Sports - Olympics Appointment of British Volunteer Defended


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 15, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - National Sports Council of Zambia (NSCZ) chairman, Patrick Chamunda, facing pressure over the appointment of a British volunteer as sports council acting general secretary, has defended the move as "the best for the Council".

In an interview recently when he announced the team for the Atlanta Olympics fund-raising committee, Chamunda said he saw nothing wrong in his appointment of Mary Nicholson as general secretary. 

"Why should people start questioning the appointment of Mary, personally I do not see any anything wrong in appointing her. The reasons why people could start asking why we appointed her could only be because she is from Britain and, not a Zambian, but she has proved she can help," said Chamunda.

But a number of leading sports administrators have questioned the morality of the appointment, when qualified Zambians are around to take up the job.

"This is an insult because in the first place, she is just a volunteer and as such must not be in a position like the one she now has. And secondly does her appointment mean that there are no Zambians who can do what she is doing?," wondered a sports administrator.

219 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa (DOCUMENT) Tarnoff Says U.S. Will Continue to Pressure Nigeria


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 16, 1996


LENGTH: 2560 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is the text of the prepared statement on Nigeria by Peter Tarnoff, under secretary of state for political affairs, for the Africa subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, May 15:
Good afternoon. I welcome the opportunity to appear before the committee to discuss our policy objectives toward Nigeria. It so happens that Nigeria was my first foreign service post and I have retained a strong interest in its development.

Introduction

We cannot ignore Nigeria's size, population and impact in Africa. It has considerable influence on the West Africa region for better or worse.

Our principal interest remains to have a stable, democratic Nigeria with which the U.S. can pursue productive, cooperative relations. We do not wish to see Nigeria become a pariah state that might use its influence and resources recklessly and irresponsibly. We have a profound interest in restoring the rule of law in Nigeria, a nation where, as secretary Christopher has put it, "disdain for law protects the drug trade even as it harms ordinary citizens." Separate and apart from our concerns on democratization and human rights, we note Nigeria is a major supplier of heroin to the United States. For the third year in a row, Nigeria was denied certification for not being cooperative in counternarcotics efforts or working on its own to meet the goals of the 1988 U.N. Convention on Counternarcotics. 

The Nigeria situation, regarding the transition to civilian government and respect for human rights, is becoming increasingly more serious. We have been working diligently with the international community to develop approaches aimed at prompting the Nigerian leadership to re-think its current direction. We are continuing our consultations on new measures with the European Union (EU), the commonwealth and others. We believe that a broader consensus and a stronger message will ultimately result in more effective measures. Nothing is off the table, including the options contained in pending legislative proposals in both the Senate and House.

Let me begin, however, with a review of the situation in Nigeria as it has developed since December, 1995.

Human Rights

A U.N. human rights fact-finding team, mandated by the U.N. General Assembly resolution passed last November, recently completed a two-week visit. Although the team's report has not yet been released, we understand that in a final press briefing, the team leader, Justice Amega of Togo, described the human rights situation in Nigeria as "terrible" and the political situation as "terrifying." Additionally, on at least two occasions, security forces attempted to prevent the team from interviewing human rights activists. The team did, however, speak with Ogoni leaders, human rights activists, and with chief M.K.O. Abiola. While we welcome the regime's acceptance of this first independent fact-finding mission to look at Nigeria's human rights performance, we deplore the further deterioration of the human rights situation. For example:

(1) Mrs. Kudirat Abiola, wife of chief M.K.O. Abiola, who is still imprisoned pending completion of his trial on treason charges, and two others were arrested in Lagos May 7 and arraigned May 8 on charges of conspiracy and false publication. Three were released on bail on May 8 after entering not guilty pleas. A trial date was set for May 28. If convicted the three face prison sentences of up to seven years.

(2) Additionally, within the past months several prominent Nigerian activists have been arrested, including activist lawyer Gani Fawehinmi and journalist Nosa Igiebor. Offices of the Guardian newspaper were set on fire, thousands of copies of Igiebor's "Tell" newsmagazine were seized, and Nadeco's offices were raided. Nineteen Ogoni activists, held since May 1994, await trial by the same tribunal which condemned Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight others to death last November.

(3) The government of Nigeria recently disrupted two conferences co-sponsored by the U.S. government. The first in Jos, on the "dilemmas of democracy," organized by the African Center for Democratic Governance, was crudely disrupted by security forces on March 13. The second, the fifth annual meeting of the American Studies Association of Nigeria at Kaduna, was canceled by security forces on March 25 without explanation at the last minute. The meeting had attracted participants from many African countries and several Nigerian academic institutions.

The United States is gravely concerned about these incidents and the arrests and continued detentions of persons expressing views contrary to those of the government. They raise serious doubts about the government of Nigeria's commitment to democratization and the stated goal of returning the government to civilian rule.

Transition Program

Nigeria has completed the second quarter of its three-year transition program. Even judged by its own timetable and against its own criteria, the regime's record is not good. The draft constitution was not promulgated as called for by the original program; rather it was "approved" by the Provisional Ruling Council (PRC) on the eve of general Abacha's October 1 speech. Although decree two ostensibly lifts restrictions on political activity, decree one created a new criminal offense for "undermining" the transition program, a crime punishable by up to five years imprisonment.

The regime did establish an electoral commission, the National Electoral Commission of Nigeria (NECON), several transition committees and issued enabling decrees to give them a legal mandate. NECON, however, had problems organizing and managing the local government elections held in March.

Non-partisan local government elections using an open ballot system were held as scheduled on March 16. There were many reports of irregularities during and following the elections, including disqualification of candidates for "security concerns" even after they had been elected. Moreover, decree six, signed by Abacha before the elections, but released after they had been completed, permits the removal from office of any elected local government official at the option of the head of state, and in the case of chairmen, replacement by sole administrators. Decree six is totally inconsistent with democratic values and principles.

U.S. and International Action

We believe it would be a grave mistake to conduct "business as usual" with Nigeria in the absence of significant progress towards a credible program for the return of civilian democratic rule and respect for human rights. Earlier this year, we began an intensive round of consultations with the international community on possible new strong collective measures aimed at persuading the government of Nigeria to speed its transition to democracy and respect the human rights of the Nigerian people. These consultations continue and we are pleased with the progress we have made thus far in encouraging like-minded states to bring pressure to bear on the regime.

The United States co-sponsored successful resolutions in both the U.N. General Assembly and the U.N. Human Rights Commission that expressed concern over human rights abuses and called for restoration of civilian, democratic government. The Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group (CMAG) met in London on April 23 to review the situation in Nigeria following Nigeria's refusal to accept a commonwealth visit. The meeting recommended that commonwealth member states implement new measures to register their continuing disapproval of developments in Nigeria. Among the recommended measures, which are similar to those the U.S. and European Union already have in place, are:

-- visa restrictions on members of the Nigerian regime and their families;

-- withdrawal of military attaches, termination of military training, and an embargo on arms exports;

-- downgrading of cultural and educational links;

-- downgrading diplomatic missions; and

-- banning sporting contacts.

We intend to raise the issue of Nigeria at the summit meeting of the eight in Lyon, France, late next month in the hope that the heads of state will condemn Nigerian actions. We welcome the decision by the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group and we would hope that all commonwealth member states would adopt these measures. We are especially encouraged by their willingness to consider additional measures in consultation with the U.S. and the EU.

The European Commission has undertaken a study of possible new measures. The EU study, due to be completed in late May for an early June meeting of European foreign ministers, will review a broad range of possible measures to encourage transition to a democratic and stable Nigeria. We are pressing the EU and commonwealth countries to take further action, and while we prefer collective measures, we have not ruled out further unilateral actions by the U.S.

Liberia

At the same time, it is important to remember the humanitarian tragedy unleashed in Liberia. Nigeria has been an important player in past attempts to bring peace to Liberia, and we have every reason to believe that it will continue to play a significant role in resolving the present crisis in Liberia. Nigeria contributes approximately 80 percent of the troops to the largely self-supporting West African peacekeeping force, ECOMOG. In addition, Nigeria was instrumental in brokering the Abuja Peace Accord in August 1995. Although the Abuja peace process has been sorely tested by over a month of death and destruction perpetrated by factional fighting, we maintain that the Abuja framework represents Liberia's best hope for a lasting peace. We will continue to work in partnership with Liberia's neighboring countries -- including Nigeria -- and others in the international community to restore peace in Liberia. This will not deter us, however, from continuing to press the Abacha government to improve the human rights situation in Nigeria and speed its transition to civilian democratic rule.

Conclusion

The U.N. resolutions and commonwealth recommendations, along with the measures the European Union and the United States already have in place, demonstrate that the international community will not permit the GON (Government of Nigeria) to impede democratic progress or disregard human rights with impunity.

As Assistant Secretary George Moose said in December, we once again call on the government of Nigeria to:

-- accelerate the transition process with steps that are politically meaningful;

-- release all political prisoners now;

-- restore habeas corpus and an independent judicial process which does not rely on special tribunals now;

-- legalize political parties now;

-- and restore the independence of labor unions.

Last November, immediately after the hanging of Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight Ogoni, the president announced new measures against Nigeria including:

-- the recall of Ambassador Carrington for consultations;

-- a ban on the sale and repair of military goods and services to Nigeria;

-- an extension of the ban on visas to include all military officers and civilians who actively formulate, implement, or benefit from the policies that impede Nigeria's transition to democracy;

-- a requirement that Nigerian government officials visiting the United Nations or the international financial institutions to remain within 25 miles of those organizations;

-- that we begin immediate consultations on appropriate U.N. measures to condemn the executions.

In closing, let me say that we will continue to stress the overriding importance of respect for human rights in our bilateral relations with Nigeria. We will continue to press for a credible transition process built on the active and inclusive participation of the Nigerian people. We will press for a genuine dialogue with the government of Nigeria.

As we continue to consult with the international community on new collective measures, we are encouraged by the positive movement thus far by international groups. We are mindful that any new action will be much more meaningful once a consensus is developed. All options, including those contained in pending legislative proposals in your bill and in Congressman Payne's, remain on the table.

Thank you once again for this opportunity to come before your committee and discuss Nigeria. I appreciate your interest.


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Sports - Olympics South Africa: Five More Join Olympic Team


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 17, 1996 by Julian Drew


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Johannesburg - On Thursday the National Olympic Committee of South Africa (Nocsa) announced five new additions to the Olympic team For the Centennial Olympic Games which take place in Atlanta in July.

Canoeist Ruth Nortje was the only one of the five new members who seemed to be a certainty for Atlanta after her stunning performance at the sprint canoe Olympic qualification regatta in Seville last weekend. Nortje became the first local canoeist ever to mount the medal podium when she won the final of the individual 500m kayak (K1-SOOm) in a new South African best time of 1:52.18.

At last year's world championships in Duisburg the top eight boats qualified automatically for Atlanta. In Seville the top four boats earned Olympic places and after winning her semi-final on Sunday morning she made sure of her place on the Olympic team by putting in a tremendous finishing burst in the final that afternoon. 

Nortje (27) went to live in America in November 1994 but she found it very tough training in the cold American winter last year and did not fare well at the world championships where she failed to reach the semi-finals.

This February she went to Florida to escape the icy grip of winter and trained with the American and Canadian squads. That stint did wonders for her form and confidence and at the South African sprint trials in April she set a personal best of 1:56.00. But even that didn't prepare anybody for her world class time in Seville.

Although there are no official world records for canoeing because of the large variance in wind and water conditions, her time, which was recorded in calm conditions in contrast to the strong cross winds earlier in the week, is just over two seconds outside the fastest time ever recorded. In Barcelona such a time would have earned her the bronze medal, and although it is premature to say she is a medal prospect in Atlanta, she is expected to reach the final.

"Last year I really struggled in America and I'm just very relieved that things have finally come right for me," said Nortje. She is competing in a regatta in Milan this weekend and will probably stay on in Europe for another regatta in Budapest in two weeks' time. She will then return to South Africa to train under the national team's Hungarian coach, Nandor Almasi.

In shooting, South Africa had to qualify for Atlanta through the African championships in Cairo last year and six local shottists earned places. But in line with Nocsa's policy of only sending top class competitors who can reach the semi-finals or the top 16 of their events, these shottists were required to prove themselves in international competition.

At the world cup event in Atlanta three weeks ago most of the world's top marksmen took part to get a feel of the Wolf Creek Shooting Complex which will stage the Olympic shooting competitions. Jaco Henn in the free rifle 60 shots prone and Melville Hains in the skeet 125 shots did the best out of the South Africans and they have been selected for the Olympic team.

Henn (21) is extremely young for an international shottist and he came 12th from a field of 110 in his best discipline which uses a .22 calibre rifle. With a maximum score of 10 per shot Henn scored 593 in his elimination round out of a possible score of 600. In the qualifying round for the eight-man final he shot a score of 594. The highest scores of the day were two rounds of 597. "The elimination round was quite tricky because it was windy and it kept blowing from different directions.

"I was very happy with my performance overall and it was good experience for the Olympics. Its really great to know that I'm finally going to the Games," said Henn.

Hains (35) came 15th out of 130 competitors in the skeet competition which consists of five rounds of 25 shots with a shotgun at clay pigeon targets from eight different positions.

Seven South African wrestlers qualified for Atlanta at the All Africa Games but because they didn't compete at last year's world championships they were sent to a top tournament in Greece at the end of February to see how they would perform in the international arena. Andrew Davidson in the 100kg freestyle and Tjaart du Plessis in the 62kg freestyle both finished fifth at the tournament which earned their tickets to Atlanta.

The 16-member Olympic hockey squad of Brian Myburgh, Brad Milne, Shaun Cooke, Craig Jackson, Craig Fulton, Bradley Michalaro, Gregg Clarke, Gary Boddington, Alistar Fredericks, Wayne Graham (captain), Kevin Chree, Charles Teversham, Greg Nicol, Mathew Hallowes, Grant Fulton and Murray Anderson are all included in the 20-man squad that will compete in a four nation tournament in Australia at the end of the month.

They will be hoping to come through unscathed from this tour and the three-test home series against Spain in June, for injury at this late stage would be a cruel blow indeed.

With the Olympic team now standing at 72 there are just a few places to be filled before the final line up for Atlanta is known. Tennis should name its team in the next week while rowing must nominate the people who will crew the men's lightweight coxless fours boat and the women's coxless pairs boat which have already been selected. There is hope of another boat also qualifying at a regatta in Switzerland early in June.

Nocsa is hoping Claude Cloete will make it through the final modern pentathlon qualifying competition in Rome next week, but Nocsa president Sam Ramsamy has said it will consider applying for a wild card if he doesn't qualify. A wild card enables athletes from developing countries to compete at the Olympics without qualifying, thus ensuring universality at the Games.

LANGUAGE: English

221 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Art South Africa's 'Nomathemba' Stirs Washington


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 17, 1996 b Jeff Stein y


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Washington, DC - It's tempting to think of Washington, DC, in terms of Johannesburg, two black cities where the whites have most of the money. In fact, the two cities have a lot in common, which anyone who's spent time in both places would be reminded of after seeing Ntosake Shange's "Nomathemba," vibrantly staged and enthusiastically received at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts over the past month.

That's a long way of getting around to saying that this musical love story, performed by a cast of 23 and featuring the legendary Ladysmith Black Mambazo (whom even American teenagers know about here thanks to their parents' Paul Simon records), is so generic in its plot and characters, that it could be adapted and reset just about anywhere in the world. Forget apartheid, in other words. This is a post-apartheid soap opera, set to music. And a very good one. 

Which doesn't, one suspects, especially trouble Shange or Ricardo Khan, who developed Nomathemba at New Jersey's African-American Crossroads Theater and made a deal with the Kennedy Center to bring it to the premier showcase in America's capital. It's had a spectacular month-long run.

"I am interested in the very specific dream of African America ideas," Khan told The Washington Post, "but I am also interested in what happens when you connect those specific dreams to artists from other countries. There is ... electricity out there."

Plenty of the voltage was supplied by the beautiful, sinuous, Cee Cee Harshaw, who plays Nomathemba, a "modern" Kwazulu village girl who tires of her dithering, boastful boyfriend and flees to Johannesburg to put a little sizzle into her life. Of course, the big city hands her more than she bargained. Meanwhile her boyfriend Bongani, engagingly played by Ntare Mwine, eventually realizes what he's lost and goes off to find her, along the way hilariously falling into the hands of a con man (Leelai Demoz) in a dreary workers hostel. Guess what, though? Boy gets girl. Nomathemba and Bongani find each other and return home and live happily ever after (we hope).

Hope, of course, is what this touchingly naive but invigorating musical is all about -- hope in the face of loss and suffering, and thus a metaphor for the apartheid years if one wishes to read it that way. From where I sat, though, Nomathemba was a universal love story for the chaotic, violent, or merely alienating transnational age we live in.

This week Kwazulu, next week Liberia. Or the Anacostia section of Washington, DC, where the descendants of North Carolina slaves still live in depressing, if often, noble, squalor. That Nomathemba is a distinctly South African drama, buoyed throughout by Joseph Shabalala's joyful rhythms and hymns, takes nothing from it, of course. When the audience rose in three standing ovations at the end, we were applauding as much for the thing as the play.


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


222 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa TV: Challenges of the Truth Commission


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 17, 1996 by Hazel Friedman


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Johannesburg - There are moments in history which stand out like candles in a darkened room, illuminating the horrors of the past while also casting light on the promise of redemption and healing. The Truth and Reconciliation Commission finds itself at such a moment.

And whether it emerges as a beacon of hope or as a surface salve for incurable wounds forms the basis of If Truth Be Told, a three-part documentary produced by Steven Markovitz and directed by Mark Kaplan. 

Call it what you will: spectacle, theatre, group therapy, exorcism or catharsis. From the most cynical perspective, the truth commission is riveting television viewing. It has all the components of a bestseller: intrigue, tragedy, bizarre plot twists and even some light relief, within the context of an otherwise harrowing epic. Most importantly, it does not have to be hauled from the mausoleums of distant history; it is living, breathing testimony to a country that still has heroes and to people struggling to come to terms with the brutal past.So it comes as a disappointment that the series, though moving and timeous, doesn't really live up to its mission statement -- "to explore issues facing the truth commission".

Part one focuses on Siphiwo Mtimkulu, an Eastern Cape student leader who was detained and tortured before disappearing in 1982. The film attempts to reconstruct the weeks before his disappearance, as well as his period in detention.

But while the story is poignant and significant, both as a personal tragedy and as a example of the fate met by some of South Africa's brightest political stars, once its emotive appeal has begun to wear thin, the film becomes a series of talking heads, interspersed with crudely enacted inserts.

Out in the Open, the second episode, deals with a different set of problems -- condensing a seminal but complex phase of apartheid history (the 1980s) into a coherent narrative, without becoming a confession-session for the perpetrators of human-rights abuses, or a promotional video for the truth commission itself.

It meets the first two challenges, although there appears to be some embarrassing confusion as a photograph of Matthew Goniwe is identified as Fort Calata. But despite its attempts at maintaining a sober, critical perspective on the issue of the truth commission, it doesn't manage to transcend its in-house approach to the subject.Happily, the ambit of the third part -- The Rights of the Wronged -- is broadened to include debates on the viability of the commission, with reference to similar models in Chile, Argentina, Rwanda and former Yugoslavia. But again laudable intentions get trapped within the talking-heads syndrome, at the expense of dramatic footage of witnesses giving evidence.

Most importantly, it allows the family members of murdered activists to express their pain, their desire for justice and their misgivings about the effectiveness of the truth commission as a catalyst for healing and reconciliation.


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


223 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Stock Index Shows Signs Of Recovery


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 17, 1996 by Simon Segal


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Johannesburg - The fallout of the rand since mid-February has contributed to the Johannesburg Stock Exchange's All-Gold index (ALGI) rising to levels last seen at the end of 1994 and the Industrial index (ALII) falling to wipe out this year's gains.

A declining rand has boosted prospects for South Africa's troubled gold producers which export their output. The ALGI surpassed the 2 000 level last week for the first time since December 1994. By May last year the index was below 1 400 and 1 300 by October. It has been rising ever since to reach 2 000 last week, still below its highs of near 2 500 in September 1994. 

The poor performance of South Africa's gold mining sector is reflected in the ALGI's performance, which was at the same 2 000 level at the beginning of 1987.

In sharp contrast is the performance of industrial firms. In January 1987, the ALII was around 1 500. This week it is just under 8 000 and was near 8 600 at the beginning of the year before the rand crisis.

The JSE's Overall Index has dropped from just under 7 000 in April to 6 745 last week before recovering to 6 845 this week.

The indices were adjusted in March to include all firms except pyramid companies. Previously, firms accounting for 80% of market capitalisation were included.

In dollar terms, the JSE has appreciated far more. Foreign investors have not deserted the exchange and thus, as a group, have not contributed significantly to the rand's decline. So far foreigners have bought a net

R3,1-billion in equities this year, peaking at R1-billion in February before falling to R478- million in March, R319-million in April and R224-million in the first two weeks of May.

In 1995, net foreign purchases on the JSE were R4,8-billion. In that year, share trade on emerging markets accounted for 9% of the total value of world share trade or some $108- billion out of nearly $12-trillion traded. The JSE thus attracts less than 1% of foreign investment in emerging equity markets.

The JSE might be the 12th largest exchange in the world but its main problem is liquidity. As a portion of total market capitalisation the JSE's turnover is only 6%. In 1995, Turkey saw the heaviest turnover (247%), meaning that the average share changed hands more than twice. The turnover ratio in the United States and Japan was 75% and 34% respectively.


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance SA Telkom invests in satellite multinational


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 17, 1996 by Aspasia Karras


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

Johannesburg - Despite Telkom's claims that it is unable to finance a universal service without a strategic equity partner, it has invested $20- million in a multinational satellite company, ICO.

As one of 47 telecommunications companies to invest in an operation with an equity of $3,5- billion, ICO intends to invest a sixth of that in Africa. ICO vice-president Pat McDougal sees the investment as directly in the spirit of the Information Society and Development Conference.

"The conference is trying to extend some of the fruits of the global information society to the less developed areas of the world, in South Africa's case to the less developed areas in the overall economy." 

The idea is that the satellite constellation will allow people to make calls and connect anywhere in the world, cutting through the problems of different cellular networks and areas that are too remote and too expensive to be covered. "In the African infrastructure it is a good way to leapfrog."

While from the end-user's perspective by 2000, the potential for coverage all over the world, using the satellite's roaming mode, is encouraging, the fact is that the average rural dweller will still find the cost exorbitant.

McDougal says "The average cost of a call will still be about $1. It will never come down to 5c, which would make it a truly universal service, but it is the next step down in terms of universality." The only possible cheap access will be through the wireless call box.

For Telkom, the reason to invest is clear: from the financial aspect the company will benefit, and it complements its general plans to roll out a universal service. From an ISAD perspective the investment is positive in that it shows the potential of developing countries to leverage international projects for both economic and developmental purposes.

@ Manuel -- end to rand-slide in sight

Depreciation of the rand offers 'a window of opportunity for exports', said the finance minister in defence of the rand crisis. Lynda Loxton reports

Finance Minister Trevor Manuel this week strongly defended government's handling of the rand crisis and predicted that the rand's dramatic slide against the dollar would soon be over.

But opposition parties took advantage of a snap debate in parliament to blame the rand's slide on everything from government's support for Cosatu in the lock-out wrangle to its friendship with Cuba and Libya, perceived antipathy to the market and the delay of the KwaZulu-Natal local elections.

Manual shrugged off these barbs and said: "Let us not be taken in by the shorter fluctuations ... Let's retain our focus on the long term. This deemed crisis, I assure you, will soon pass."

The debate, relatively muted and sparsely attended, despite recent panic in the media about the state of the rand, had been called by the Democratic Party. DP finance representative Ken Andrew said that "the prevalence of cynicism and even hostility towards markets" on the part of the government needed "urgent attention".

Manuel said it was important to "recognise market imperfections. The market certainly is not perfect.

"The question is whether this depreciation is all detrimental to the economy and whether there is a need for all doom and gloom."

Before the rand crisis, business leaders had argued that the rand was overvalued and "industrialists complained that they were being squeezed out in the export side," Manuel said.

Despite this, the depreciation of the rand had not been met with relief "and we have to ask our exporters to take a second look at the situation".

It would be best if they took account of the depreciation and did not "bang on the door of my colleague (Trade and Industry Minister) Alec Erwin and appeal for the reinstatement" of export incentives now being phased out.

"Depreciation, I am saying, offers a window of opportunity for exports. The concern at the moment is about volatility and where it will settle," Manuel said.

He and several African National Congress parliamentarians said that the fall in the rand had been underpinned by the fact that growth had been stunted by the previous government.

Isolation had forced it to run current account surpluses to offset capital account deficits. After the 1994 elections, the new government was able to run current account deficits and import foreign capital to help boost growth.

"However, much of it was short-term and susceptible to sudden changes in sentiment," he said.

That change in sentiment had been owing to higher bond rates in the United States, which led to the withdrawal of funds from several emerging markets; allegations that the rand was over-valued and rumours about President Nelson Mandela's health.

"We have to expect that the exchange rate in the short term will be affected by speculative capital flows. But what is more important for us in government is to focus on policy co- ordination," he said.

"It is about the management of the fiscus in a different way as outlined in the budget of March 13, which will see in this fiscal year significant tightening-up."

This would include the establishment of an expenditure evaluation unit, better collection of taxes and excise duties, the establishment of a debt management office, better cash management and "generally a tightening-up of the fiscus".

On monetary policy, he said that "we should avoid strangulation of the domestic economy by relying only on interest-rate hikes.

"We also have to ensure that the gains of devaluation are not eroded in the current round of (wage) negotiations which could affect the wage price cycle."

Manuel said that South Africa had to work towards policies that would allow a real effective exchange rate shaped by a range of supporting policies.

"We have our finger on the pulse; we are more than competent; we will deliver on what we promised," he said.


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


225 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Universal Connectivity For Africa?


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 17, 1996 by Aspasia Karras


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Johannesburg - Jay Naidoo, minister of posts telecommunications and broadcasting, injected some levity into the otherwise serious proceedings at this week's Information Society and Development Conference in Johannesburg. "One person, one Internet connection," became his catch phrase.

It was the first time the Group of Seven (G7) -- the leading industrial nations -- and the developing world had gathered to discuss information issues. A large number of projects, including the United States's Leland Initiative, geared to fulfill Naidoo's hopes in Africa, were launched, and decisions made regarding the priority status of some of the G7 pilot projects launched two years ago for the developing world. 

US vice-president Al Gore heralded the thresholds the world was crossing as it entered the new information revolution. As his image flickered on 12 satellite screens, he said the developing world would benefit from accepting the principles laid down at the Brussels G7 convention in 1995.

Tsepho Ranto, president of South Africa's National Community Media Forum, highlighted the potential areas of concern. "I am more interested in what the conference is going to do for South Africa. We are interested in deliverables and we need to unpack the G7 pilot projects."

At Deputy President Thabo Mbeki's request, representatives from 40 countries and 18 international organisations converged to begin a dialogue that would attempt to bring a common understanding and collaboration between the developed and developing countries, working towards "common principles".

The principles call for the liberalisation of the telecommunications markets and substantial privatisation. As understood by Gore, these are private investment; "robust competition; smart flexible regulation as practised by our Federal Communications Commission; open access, and universal service".

How then can these principles be translated into equitable principles for the developing world, which after all, is neither a unified constituency nor has the same set of needs?

Federal Communications Commission chairman Reed Hunt explained the US position. "We recognise that the developed world has something to offer to the less developed world -- take South Africa's cellular technology. It has built the second-largest digital network in the world, while the US is still on analogue. The developing world simply does not have to repeat the same policy mistakes, they can go straight to the cutting edge."

Concerns about the protection of local markets, state regulation and control in the face of an increasing divide between a "two- tier society -- of information haves and have-nots" as president of the European Commission Jacques Santer pointed out, are central to the debate.

Hunt said: "International communication products are unique in that they are co- operatively produced; the result is the modern network. Governments limit this growth by trying to manage this process. They should rather try to manage the entrepreneurial advantage. Telecommunications businesses grow like weeds and present the opportunity for a whole new class of trade."

The debate is inherent in the principles, and the question is, do they add up to universal service? Hunt argues that the Chilean, Peruvian and Columbian models prove that they do.

"By opening their market, the Chileans have introduced 12 new operators, achieved 14% market growth, and created thousands of jobs. It is a good idea to welcome foreign investment. South Africa is being cautious, and not as open."

The European Commission appeared to take a less hard-hitting line. In his opening remarks, Santer was buoyant but practical: "Let us build a fresh approach to sharing and disbursing these exciting technologies to benefit everyone. It will not be easy. Let us be honest. We are burdened with rigidities: old ways of thinking, bureaucratic inertia, institutional overlapping, conflicting priorities and new economic orthodoxies that will make direct government transfers of aid and assistance even more difficult in the future -- as we trim government expenditure. That is why public-private partnerships will be so vital in the next millennium."

But how will the developing world balance development needs with access to markets? How will it guard against merely being the recipient of aid packages in the form of interactive software, or simply becoming a large market to access?

Edwin Blake of the National Information Technology Forum asked: "Will this conference serve to develop South Africa or under-develop it? Who will be served by opening ourselves up to a marketing exercise, without developing our own software and applications?"

A National Information Technology Forum and Cosatu delegation member said: "We must ensure that information technology is able to address social and development needs. If we simply accept the G7 principles without qualifying them, it will be disastrous. Developing countries are late-comers to the party and will only get titbits.

"Universal access could come to mean techno- imperialism. The information society has to have involvement from all participants, otherwise it will be a society that does not benefit everybody, and which people do not buy into. The debate between competition and liberalisation is problematic, because even developed countries have interventionist governments."

The call from Mbeki was clear: our preconceived notions of what is right in each context must be challenged; the urgent need to define a regulatory framework between the north and south must receive renewed attention.

The conference has laid the ground for debate, but it is clear from the chair's conclusions that the principles are now a product of a compromise position. The Brussels principles remain intact, but they are qualified by the developing world's needs for a universal service and diversity in applications and cultures, in order to ensure socio-economic development.

Whether the conference will have some effect in narrowing the gap is to be seen. Naidoo's point is: "The issue at hand has gone beyond the aid paradigm, even though aid is an important component. The shift from commodity- based economics is redefining our perspective. Entering into dialogue is important, as it allows us to address those principles that will best address our needs, while redefining roles and entering into partnerships will help us to look at the benefits of creating jobs and providing services."

Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large New Focus For Unctad


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 17, 1996 by Madeleine Wackernagel


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Johannesburg - In the world of international conferences, talk does not come cheap. It cost R18-million to host 3 000 delegates from 188 countries for the ninth United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (Unctad). But aside from re- affirming South Africa's renaissance on the international stage, what did the fortnight of talks achieve?

Four years ago, at the Cartagena conference, Unctad was searching for a role. Economic power had shifted during the 1980s towards the Bretton Woods institutions -- the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (Gatt) -- and Unctad's place among the international forums was under threat. 

With the transformation of Gatt into the World Trade Organisation (WTO), there was talk of abandoning Unctad altogether. It was felt the overlap between the two organisations was too great; there was only room for one trade body. But Gatt rounds leaned heavily towards member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development (OECD); least developed countries (LDCs) and developing countries in general lacked the facilities of industrialised countries to lobby their cause.

As Xavier Carim, deputy director of foreign trade relations at the Department of Trade and Industry, explains, Unctad is the only organisation with a mandate to operate on behalf of the developing world. And, indeed, it has played an important role in enabling a convergence between North and South on issues of trade and economic policy.

The Cartagena conference heralded the need for a new approach to development issues. "We have to guard against complacency, we must be pro- active and innovative and in doing so point to concrete roles Unctad will play," said Unctad IX president and Trade and Industry Minister Alec Erwin at the opening.

Judging by the Midrand Declaration, the conference went a long way to achieving a new focus. "Key advances were made in attaining greater understanding of development strategy, including the implications for development of liberalisation and globalisation," says Carim. "From the extreme polarisation of views seen in the past there has been real progress towards consensus."

And the conference served to put Africa, as the poorest continent, back on the map. "It was an important victory for the South, reinforcing the place of LDCs in the global economy," says Rob Davies, an African National Congress MP.

And as the next WTO meeting in Singapore nears, the importance of Unctad's role as facilitator for the LDCs, helping to put their case to the WTO, was underlined. Multilateral investment agreements are high on the agenda for the December meeting; foreign direct investment, as South Africa is well aware, is critical for economic growth. So LDCs will be looking to Unctad to emphasise the developmental objectives as well, says Carim. "It is imperative that any deal reflects the interests of all developing countries and Unctad will provide that support."

South Africa will also benefit from its reintegration into the Unctad framework -- not only from the R30-million cash injection into our economy thanks to the delegates' spending, but more importantly from the gold mine of policy research and analytical information that forms the backbone of Unctad's work.

In addition, contacts made between private and public sector at the conference should bear fruit in terms of investment and trade deals.

And as president for the next four years, South Africa has ample opportunity to wield its influence and strengthen Unctad's focus. Any initial anxiety when Trevor Manuel withdrew due to the Cabinet reshuffle was dispelled as Erwin very quickly made his mark.

Indeed, the Midrand Declaration is a significant departure from the usual UN language. While this is only the beginning, the document offers some hope that consensus will translate into action.


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

May, 1996


South Africa New Hope For The Fuel Industry


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 17, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Johannesburg - Fuel industry players hope the African National Congress's takeover of the mineral and energy affairs portfolio, following the National Party's exit from government, will speed up reform in the sector.

"There is probably going to be more action and less politicking," and "there should be fewer somersaults -- Penuell Maduna won't have to be looking over his back the whole time," were the typical comments from a snap poll this week.

Pik Botha's charm and political agility were not enough to push through the massive energy policy changes needed to bring South Africa's fuel industry out of the dark ages. As a high profile NP minister with an exclusively NP team, until the recent appointment of Susan Shabangu as deputy minister, he was often politically paralysed. 

It was a tough battle raising the crucial support needed from the finance and trade and industry departments, which have stepped up their involvement in the industry, particularly the sale of Mossgas. A three-man team, including special advisers Charles Stride and Paul Jourdan from the finance and trade and industry departments, and mineral and energy affairs director general Gert Venter, steer policy on the industry.

The NP stigma also meant the department felt obliged to negotiate and consult with every interest group or "stakeholder" in sight, making swift decision impossible.

Botha's department of 25, all NP, is badly understaffed -- a senior official recently noted that United States Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary's entourage on her trip to South Africa last year was larger. And those that there are have dedicated their lives to administering the "crow's nest" (as Botha puts it) maze of fuel industry regulations that needed to be reformed. Players are hopeful that Maduna will be able to breathe life into it.

Botha announced this week that he was quitting politics, ending an extraordinary career.

The shake-up at mineral and energy affairs coincides with the International Energy Agency's (IEA) report on South Africa's energy sector. The department has indicated it will refer to the report when drafting its White Paper on energy policy, and some commentators hope Maduna, currently deputy home affairs minister, will kick off by considering some of its recommendations.

The agency, which is part of the Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development, says it favours dismantling many of the "complex webs" of price controls and trading restrictions spawned by the sanctions era. These include fixed margins for fuel retailers, who are protected from excessive competition by the rationalisation plan that bars new entrants to the retail market.

In return for these benefits, the oil companies have to tolerate state financial support to Sasol.

Although deregulation has been advocated by commentators who say the industry has stagnated by receiving guaranteed profits just for being in South Africa, there are many in government -- not only in mineral and energy affairs but also in trade and industry -- who favour the old regime. There is also an influential group keen on maintaining or even stepping up government involvement in the industry.

Apart from deregulation, the other main issue facing Maduna will be the fate of the Central Energy Fund (CEF) group of companies at the heart of boycott-era oil policies. The CEF includes state exploration company Soekor and its oil trading arm, Strategic Fuel Fund (SFF).

The IEA recommends the privatisation of Soekor and says there is little justification for the country-to-country oil deals that are the SFF's bread and butter, arguing that these deals were of little use to refiners who needed to pick their oil to suit their needs. It says government support to SFF should be confined to ensuring South Africa has an adequate strategic oil stock.

The report's portrayal of the many vested interests and cosy set-ups characterising the industry offers a stark reminder that even with his political clout Maduna's job as fuel industry reformer will not be easy.


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996

May, 1996


Namibia Nujoma Looks to South Africa for Capital


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 17, 1996 by Madeleine Wackernagel


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Johannesburg - Armed with a package of incentives and reassurances of labour stability, President Sam Nujoma of Namibia was in Johannesburg this week to woo investors. On his first state visit to this country, Nujoma stressed the economic bonds between the two countries -- South Africa accounts for 80% of Namibia's imports and 35% of exports.

"It is therefore natural that we should look to South Africa, among others, for capital, technology and managerial skills as Namibia embarks on a new era of economic reconstruction and development, based on the principle and strategy of diversification of its economy," Nujomo told a business delegation in Johannesburg.

But South African investors may not be that easily convinced. Experience has shown that not all companies are welcome -- although Hanno Rumpf, permanent secretary at the Ministry of Trade and Industry, was quick to set the record straight. "There is no law against investing in Namibia, and we welcome competition," he says. 

South African Breweries may beg to differ. Its plans to open a plant in Tsumeb were roundly thwarted by the local brewer and it has not made another attempt since, says Andre Parker, managing director of Indol Internationaal, SAB's international arm. The company has been approached by a consortium of Namibian investors to take a minority interest in a brewery, with SAB as the managing partner, but so far the government has yet to approve the project.

By contrast, says Parker, setting up in Zambia and Mozambique was no problem; indeed, SAB's international beer interests showed a 31% increase in profits in the year to end-March, with Africa playing a substantial role in that rise.

"Namibia will have to do more than pay lip- service to free market economics," says a leading analyst. "If it wants to promote foreign investment, it will have to keep politics out of business."

Rumpf was adamant: "We are not biased against South African companies; all we want is a level playing field. In the SAB case, there was an issue of transfer pricing and unfair competition."

SAB wonders whether he means simply competition. "So far we have not been allowed to compete at all," says SAB.

Michael Crawford, deputy chairman of RPP, says the company will not give up attempts to develop a shopping centre in Windhoek, despite the legal wrangles of the past three years. "Namibia is not anti-investment," he says, "we lost our application on grounds of a technicality. The problem was with the local authority and the zoning laws. We still hope to put up a centre with Pick 'n Pay in the near future."

Namibia realises it will have to offer something more if it is going to compete against South Africa in manufacturing. That's where the export processing zones (EPZ) come in: enterprises will be exempt from corporate income taxes, customs duties, sales and transfer taxes, and stamp duties.

Furthermore, says Steve Galloway, director of the Namibia Investment Centre, the unions have recognised that the country needs foreign investment -- and that guaranteed continuity of production is vital to the process. "No strikes will be tolerated," he says. In Walvis Bay, an area earmarked as an EPZ, the unions have agreed to a five-year no strike, no lock- out deal.

Manuel de Castro, mayor of Walvis Bay, was excited about the possibilities. "We are closer to the markets of Europe and America than Cape Town and Durban; all the necessary infrastructure is in place to make Walvis Bay a boom-town."

Indeed, with the opening of the Trans-Kalahari highway, Walvis Bay will be 500km closer to Gauteng. "At the end of the day, economics must dictate which port or sea route should be used for imports and exports, and in this context, Walvis Bay has definite advantages over Maputo. Regional governments and businesses should therefore take cognisance of this fact," says the mayor.


LOAD-DATE: May 17, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa De Klerk Could Lose Post in Nats Reincarnation


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 17, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Johannesburg - National Party insiders said this week the party was willing to sacrifice both its name and its leader, FW de Klerk, to renew the party, making it able to compete with the African National Congress in the 1999 elections.

This dream of a "New Party" keeps the Nats fired up at a time when many former Cabinet members are regretting the loss of their perks. And a number of NP caucus members realise that by losing Cabinet seats the party has lost status in the eyes of black supporters.

The older faction in the NP are rolling up their sleeves in anticipation of rough-and- tumble with the ANC in Parliament. Younger members are looking ahead to a party to eclipse the Nats' unfortunate past. Such a "New Party" holds the best hope for their political futures. 

NP assistant secretary general and senator David Malatsi, 36, said this week that he saw himself playing a prominent role in the "New Party" -- one free of the baggage of the past.

Party strategists are reluctant to commit themselves openly to the "New Party" idea at this stage, but behind the smoke of opposition talk they are weighing up strategies.

Already it is said that a new party would more than likely abandon the present NP name, logo and motto. It would be the kernel of a broad political movement that would reflect the demographics of the country, and fulfil the role of a strong opposition.

The Nats are expected to enter a period of "introspection", according to Malatsi, culminating in a bosberaad at the end of June, during which the NP will discuss the idea further. It will then start to approach a number of groups -- including other political parties, civil and religious organisations, people "with the same sort of values as the National Party" -- in search of support.

The Nats have less than three years to pull this rabbit out of the hat. The anti-defection clause in the Constitution, preventing politicians from crossing the floor, will shore them up in the national and provincial parliaments until the 1999 elections, preventing drastic changes in the political landscape until then.

During that time, the Nats will be laying the ground rules for post-1999 opposition and grooming a new team of leaders of the right gender and colour. The party is hoping to use its political academy to " breed" new leaders.

"We'll teach them administration, how to organise in an area, how to organise branch meetings, how to participate in debates so that they do not get a shock when they come to Parliament. Parliament was quite a culture shock to some people ... they were vociferous outside, but then came in here and quietened down," said Malatsi.

Most importantly, the Nats are going to have to apply their minds to wooing black votes. A senior NP source admitted this week that the NP, despite its electoral forays into black areas, still did not understand the black electorate and had no idea what was going down in the townships.

Malatsi agrees: "The politicians can't just come in at election time and make promises and think that they will get the vote. They must work with the people. For example, the National Party must send some of its support people -- lawyers, doctors, builders -- and help the black people in the townships over the weekends. They must be there in their hour of need. Then they will vote for the National Party, for people who help them."

Malatsi contributes to a soup kitchen out of his own pocket, and his wife does social work with the aged. He is also concerned about communication with black people. When the Nats pulled out of government, he got an anxious call from his wife asking what they would do now that he had forfeited his job.

"If I have to explain in my own home that withdrawing from Cabinet does not mean leaving Parliament, imagine how many people out there got the wrong idea," he said. He said he had received many complaints from black NP supporters about the NP's withdrawal -- people who felt the party was shirking its responsibility to the country.

While waiting to mature into legitimacy, Nat MPs are going to be developing their oppositional muscle -- and many admit it is not going to be easy. Already they have targeted the economy as he main site of struggle, although ANC secretary-general Marthinus van Schalkwyk noted this week that NP economic policy was 99% the same as the Democratic Party's. Other opposition parliamentarians are sceptical about what an opposition can achieve.

Freedom Front MP Corne Mulder said: "There are only so many tricks in the book of the opposition -- you can walk out, you can hand over a memorandum, you can get very angry at press conferences, but that's about it."

DP leader Tony Leon asked, "If Inkatha can be in Cabinet and be an opposition party, why can't they?"

Africa News


May, 1996


Zimbabwe Mugabe Government Acts to Limit Press Freedom


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 17, 1996 by Richard Saunders


LENGTH: 1747 words


 

Harare - The Zimbabwean government's recent raid on the Zimbabwe Mass Media Trust is a worrying benchmark in the life of the national press, and sends ambiguous signals about the ruling party's commitment to continuing a programme of political liberalisation.

For 15 years the trust was paraded by President Robert Mugabe's government as concrete proof that Zimbabwe would not go the way of many neighbouring countries in crushing the standard-bearers of freedom of speech and mercilessly reining in the media.

So the surprise announcement by Director of Information Bornwell Chakaodza that the trustees had acceded to the government's demand for an effective veto over a supervisory role within the organisation came as a shock -- particularly because the same official had recently marked World Press Freedom Day by declaring Zimbabwe "an oasis of press freedom".

These moves involving the amendment of the trust's founding deed come after several years of government attempts to undermine, marginalise and otherwise weaken the trust.

In 1981 the non-partisan trust was set up by the government to manage the majority shareholding in Zimpapers, the country's only national newspaper chain, which until then had been controlled by Argus. At independence, the government was anxious to remove the South African presence in the national press, but was sensitive about alienating skilled locals and potential investors. 

The trust emerged as an innovative solution, combining public ownership with politically independent management. A board of trustees was appointed and made self-perpetuating; and the government claimed it would have no further direct operative role in the body.

For a while it seemed to work. However, Zanu (PF) wasted little time in undercutting and surrounding the trust, by fostering a culture of financial and managerial dependence on the Ministry of Information, and ensuring the ruling party's influence inside trust- controlled media with the help of strategically placed party adherents.

As it happened, this combination of pressures, and especially Zanu (PF's) back-door access to Zimpapers and Ziana (the national news agency also placed under the trust's control in 1981), made the trust mostly irrelevant as a key media player within a few years of independence. When ruling party leaders ordered a series of editorial dismissals at Zimpapers starting in 1985, trustees were given no space to intervene, and were informed that firings and hirings were a "company matter".

In the past there was always the hypothetical possibility of calling the editors of the partisan Zimpapers to account, by appealing to the tenets of fair play and tolerance set forth by the trust. Now even that small space for principled intervention has collapsed.

"Many people used to give Zimpapers the benefit of the doubt because the trust was there", says Judith Todd, a campaigner for press freedom and one-time member of the Zim- papers board of directors. "They argued that claims of government control of Zimpapers were exaggerated. The very fact the trust was there made people think twice. No longer."

Simba Makoni, Zimpapers' managing director, has yet to see the revisions to the trust deed. The first he heard of the matter was a brief news item on the front page of the Sunday Mail and, despite his inquiries, there has been nothing since.

The Mass Media Trust itself has not commented. Observers are now wondering if this is a sign of resistance -- or submission.

Richard Saunders is an academic specialising in Zimbabwe media matters and is concluding a book on the Mass Media Trust

@ Uganda has a new president -- or is he?

YOU could be forgiven for thinking Uganda has a new president. Yoweri Museveni won a landslide victory in last weekend's election under a surname -- Kaguta -- which he had reduced to a mere initial since his youth.

He rediscovered its full potency when he realised that being known as Museveni would place him in the middle of the ballot paper. As Kaguta, his was the first of the three names on the list.

The tactic might have been a little risky had it not been for the large photograph by which many voters identified their man. But it was seen in some quarters as further evidence that, far from being a convinced democrat, Museveni is treading a well-worn and dangerous path.

The Americans are leading the charge to warn that he is heading towards the kind of one- party dictatorship the continent knows only too well.

At the heart of the issue is Museveni's ban on multiparty politics. He has long argued that party politics would rub salt into the wounds of the ethnic and religious divisions that lie behind the country's decades of bloodshed.

Michael Southwick, the United States ambassador to Kampala, is having none of it. Although Museveni has yet to tell the Ugandan public, he has informed Western envoys that he would like to maintain the "no-party state" for at least another 15 years. Southwick argues that if Ugandans are not permitted free political activity, it will marginalise alternative voices and eventually lead to a new era of repression.

"If you keep it locked up in a bottle you risk an explosion, because it will take increasing repression to control. Eventually Museveni has to come around because the donor base of support will be lost, and with that will go confidence and investment," he said.

Besides the implicit threat to cut off aid, the US suggests that Uganda's economy is less sound than is widely thought. Even though it has grown faster than any other in Africa in recent years, the US points out that foreign donors remain crucial, as they meet about 40% of government spending. Other countries, including Britain, have increasingly come round to challenging the party politics ban, although less stridently.

The Ugandans counter that the US is trying to impose its own political ideology. And according to Museveni's chief political commissar, Eryra Kategaya, the US ambassador is not doing it very subtly: "I don't think he's a democrat. He treats us like a small boy. He lectures us, and very rudely too. He doesn't want to listen to other points of view."

Kategaya argues that, if party politics is not the root of all Uganda's evils, it certainly helped bring them to the fore. "There is a tendency here for political groups to exploit the miseries of groups for their own ends. They make the place impossible to govern."

The election campaign reinforced Museveni's point. Uganda's two main political parties, which are legal but forbidden to operate, are the same ones that existed through the years of terror.

Museveni campaigned on two linked themes: that his government has produced 10 years of stability and growth after nearly 20 years of barbarity and incompetence under Idi Amin and Milton Obote, and that Africa must develop its own democratic systems which emphasise consensus-seeking, not confrontation.

Neither did the opposition do much to allay fears that politicians widen the schisms in society. Among other dubious charges, Museveni's opponents accused him of introducing Aids in the north to wipe out the Acholi people.

Despite the US warnings that foreign aid could be in jeopardy, it seems unlikely that the US or its allies want to bring one of Africa's success stories crashing down.

For all its problems, Uganda remains the most stable country in the region. Zaire is slowly imploding, Rwanda is struggling to recover from genocide with the threat of another war hanging over it, Tanzania's economy is in the doldrums, and to the north is the US's new pariah, Sudan.

But perhaps it is Uganda's eastern neighbour which offers the best evidence that intent is all-important. President Daniel arap Moi was forced down the multiparty route, but Kenya can hardly be considered a democracy. There is freedom of speech for those prepared to risk arrest and beatings. Opposition political parties are constantly harassed. Their supporters are even murdered.

In Uganda, the only known politically related detainee during the elections was a man who called Museveni a bastard.

l There were only 100 independent observers for 15 000 voting stations in the elections, according to some political analysts monitoring the polls.

Analysts who had predicted a close call for Museveni are sceptical that those who monitored the elections were qualified to call the polls free and fair, given the sparseness of observers.

There were also reports that the military, obviously loyal to Museveni, had separate polling stations which did not come under any scrutiny at all.
