Africa News


May, 1996


Burundi Calls For Peace Fall On Deaf Ears in Rwanda and Burundi


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996 by a Special Correspondent


LENGTH: 2317 words


 

The security situation in Burundi and Rwanda, two former Belgian colonies scarred by conflict between Hutu and Tutsi ethnic groups, continues to slide towards anarchy despite recent international efforts to bring an end to the persistent ethnic slaughters in the two countries.

Reports of new massacres, further population displacements and disruption of humanitarian assistance abound in the tiny central African nations that are ranked among the world's Least Developed Countries (LDCs).

During an official visit to the Kenyan capital, Nairobi last month, UN Secretary General Boutros-Ghali made an urgent appeal on April 30 for an end to escalating violence in Burundi and strengthened dialogue there.

A UN statement said the secretary general, who was in the Kenyan capital from April 28, gave "two urgent messages" to Marc Faguy, his embattled special representative in Burundi, to be delivered to Hutu President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya and Tutsi Prime Minister Antoine Nduwayo.

Faguy, a Canadian, was under fire from the Tutsi-dominated United Party for National Progress (UPRONA), which shares fragile power with the Hutu-dominated Front for Democracy in Burundi (FRODEBU). 

UPRONA president Charles Mukasi had demanded earlier last month that Faguy be fired, accusing him of lying, and of supporting dialogue with Hutu guerrillas who are attacking civilians and clashing with the Tutsi-dominated army.

Ntibantunganya also appealed 10 days earlier for talks between all factions, but UPRONA is adamantly opposed to talks with the guerrillas, accusing them of genocide.

Faguy briefed Boutros-Ghali on the situation in the central African country, and on recent inconclusive talks in Tanzania between UPRONA and FRODEBU, the statement said.

Those talks were held under the chairmanship of former Tanzanian president Julius Nyerere, who warned the participants, according to conference sources, that the guerrillas could win the civil war if no talks were held with them.

Since then, reports of massacres have continued in Burundi, with Burundi's militant Hutus on May 5 accusing the country's Tutsi- dominated army of slaughtering more than 200 civilians in operations.

But humanitarian sources contacted by telephone in the Burundi capital, Bujumbura were unable to directly confirm reports about the civilian massacres in Buhoro, central Burundi, in revenge for an attack by Hutu militants, although such reports had reached them.

On May 5, Burundi's national radio had reported that five people, including four patients, had also died overnight when rebel Hutus attacked a hospital in Bujumbura.

Some 100 Hutu rebels attacked the Kamenge university hospital, in the northeast of the capital close to the hills where the rebels are hiding, apparently in search of medical supplies.

The hospital's director, Dr. Juma Kariburyo, cited by the radio station, said a security guard had his throat cut and four patients died in shooting.

The attackers raided medical cabinets and food supplies, witnesses said. Unconfirmed reports said the attack ended when a unit of the Burundi army, based nearby, intervened.

French charity Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) - Doctors Without Borders, protested the attack and called on both sides in the Burundi conflict to respect the neutrality of medical centres.

In April, two health centres in southern Burundi, at Makamba and Rutovu, were raided by rebel Hutus.

In a statement released in Geneva on May 4, the International Committee of the Red Cross denounced the attack calling it a 'serious violation" of international humanitarian law, which states that all medical facilities, their staff and patients "must be strictly respected."

Clashes between the Hutu guerrillas and the Tutsi-dominated army have left hundreds dead in recent weeks.

Ethnic violence erupted in Burundi in October 1993 when Melchior Ndadaye, the country's first elected president from the Hutu majority, was assassinated in an abortive coup attempt by the army.

The death toll in 1995 was put at about 30 a day. The current fighting is raising fears of all-out civil war in this tiny central African country.

In Rwanda, ethnic slaughter continues unabated as defeated Hutu militiamen continue their struggle to overthrow the new minority Tutsi-dominated Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA) of the ruling Rwanda Patriotic Front (RPF), with genocide being alleged on both sides.

On May 7, at least 86 people were killed by the Tutsi-dominated Rwandan army in a prison escape attempt last month at Muramba in northwest Rwanda, a Hutu refugee group said on May 6.

The Rally for Return and Democracy in Rwanda (RDR) said reliable sources had spoken of 86 people confirmed dead in the incident on April 10, and unconfirmed figures went up to 153.

A Rwandan army spokesman said on April 29 that the death toll was 19, comprising inmates of the jail, "infiltrated elements" who had tried to free them, and their accomplices.

He denied reports that the army had killed innocent civilians, as alleged by United Nations human rights observers, who put the number of those killed at around 30.

Muramba is near refugee camps in neighbouring Zaire populated by Hutus who fled Rwanda in the wake of the 1994 massacres of more than half a million Tutsis and moderate Hutus.

They include former Hutu soldiers and militia who are accused by the authorities in Kigali of carrying out guerrilla operations in Rwanda.

Addressing his final press conference in Nairobi after the April visit, Boutros-Ghali called on the world to take action to prevent crises rather than "spending 10 times more" to quell them after they had exploded.

Boutros-Ghali acknowledged at a press conference at the end of a three-day conference of UN agency heads which discussed a new 25 billion dollar initiative to reverse Africa's marginalisation, that much of the criticism of the United Nations role in Rwanda's 1994 civil war had been justified. "I agree with many of the criticisms," he said, but added that "if member states are not ready to participate," then there was little the United Nations could do.

UN troops pulled out of the tiny central African country earlier this month despite continuing clashes there between Hutu guerrillas and the Tutsi-dominated army, and the presence in surrounding countries of 1.7 million Hutu refugees who fear they will face retaliation at the hands of the minority Tutsis if they return.

The Blue Helmets left after the Kigali government refused to agree to a renewal of their mandate, accusing them of doing nothing to halt the slaughter of more than 500,000 men, women and children during the war by Hutu extremists.

In Rwanda, Boutros-Ghali said the United Nations had not been able to obtain the mobilisation of the international community until after the genocide had taken place.

The worsening situation in the two countries prompted the United States government to announce on May 6 that it would despatch a team to Burundi and Rwanda to check out the alleged massacres in ethnic conflicts in the two neighbouring African countries, which have a similar ethnic mix -- about 80 per cent Hutus and 14 per cent Tutsis.

The department's top human rights envoy, John Shattuck, and the special coordinator for the two countries, Richard Begosian, were due to leave Washington late May 6 for the mission. Although Begosian has already arrived in the region, the visit by Shattuck has since been cancelled. The assistant secretary for democracy, human rights and labour, was expected to visit Rwanda to assess the efforts by an international tribunal to prosecute those responsible for massacres in 1994 that claimed more than half a million Tutsi and Hutus.

In Burundi, he was expected to investigate an April 26 massacre of civilian Hutus near the village of Mtoye in the northern province of Gitega.

State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said information available indicates that more than 230 people were killed and "it appears that elements within the military or the Tutsi militia may have been responsible for this massacre."

"We certainly deplore the continuation of violence and the escalation of the violence in the last couple of weeks in Burundi," he said. "We would call on all sides to abandon violence and to pursue a more peaceful expression of their political differences."


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


241 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia Few Citizens Believe Ecomog Is Neutral


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996 by Nernlor Grudah


LENGTH: 1734 words


 

Nairobi - The latest carnage in the Liberian capital, Monrovia, was not entirely unexpected. If anyone, especially the Economic Community of West African states (ECOWAS) ECOMOG, thought the contrary, they were deluded.

Many, particularly Liberians believe the present state of affairs in the West African country was prompted by the ill-advised and misguided policy the Economic Community of West African States adopted at the initial stages of its intervention in the Liberian conflict in 1990. To understand this, it is important to revisit the establishment of ECOMOG.

To begin with, there were two plans of action -- one concealed from other ECOWAS member states and successfully implemented within the overall programme, leading to the devastation of Liberia. The other was a publicly declared intention by ECOWAS to peacefully resolve the conflict, and regarded by many as a noble task and the first African solution to an African problem. 

It was former Nigerian military dictator Ibrahim Babangida, who floated the idea of a "peacekeeping force", ostensibly to stop further bloodshed in Liberia. But in essence, it was a cover-up to avenge the loss of his joint business empire in Liberia with the late Liberia's military dictator, Samuel Doe.

Through the business partnership between the two dictators, Babangida received more honours in Liberia than in his home country. The University of Liberia established the Babangida School of International Relations, of which Doe was the first student, and the highway between Sierra Leone and Liberia was named the Babangida Highway.

The civil war was launched by Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) in 1989 as a popular uprising against one of the worst, disastrous misrules in Africa. Doe subsequently requested Babangida to intervene and end the rebellion.

But to be seen not to be directly involved, Babangida sought the formation of ECOMOG as a smoke-screen guided by the subtlety of "regional stability." ECOMOG was hastily assembled in Freetown, Sierra Leone, following a similarly arranged ECOWAS leaders' meeting in Banjul, Gambia, which excluded the Taylor group.

That meeting, chaired by then Gambian President, Sir Dawda Jawara, selected Dr. Amos Sawyer as interim president. ECOMOG was rejected out of hand by Taylor as a Nigerian ploy to save Doe. The express purpose of the intervention force, when it landed in Monrovia in August, 1990, was to separate the warring sides and make the Liberian capital a safe haven.

Unfortunately, however, ECOMOG not only fought alongside an NPFL splinter group led by Prince Johnson, the Independent National Patriotic Front of Liberia (INPFL), and the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), but it also declared total war against the mainstream NPFL, with both ground and air attacks.

NPFL was eventually pushed out of Monrovia by the combined force, while the other armed groups were allowed to stay. It must also be noted that AFL had been transformed by Doe into a tribal army -- almost all key positions including army chief of staff were held by his Krahn tribesmen.

Moreover, no sooner had ECOMOG arrived in Liberia than Babangida single-handedly removed the Ghanaian commander and replaced him with a Nigerian. Meanwhile, from its base in Sierra Leone, ECOMOG was busy organising the United Liberation Movement for Democracy in Liberia (ULIMO), mainly drawn from Krahn AFL refugees and immigrant Mandingo traders who supported Doe to protect their business.

Later, the Nigerians also allegedly helped organise the Liberia Peace Council (LPC), headed by Doe's former Education Minister, George Boley, himself a Krahn. All these groups, except the NPFL, operated and issued their war statements from Monrovia. The capital became more and more militarised, instead of demilitarised.

Another significant aspect to remember is that throughout the war, the Krahn-dominated AFL has regarded the rest of the non-Krahn population as supporters of the NPFL. Little wonder, then, that the AFL carried out massacres of civilians such as the one in Harbel (Firestone Rubber Plantation) and that at the Paynesville Monrovia suburb, under the nose of ECOMOG, in areas controlled by the "peacekeepers."

The bellicose between Nigeria and the NPFL continued until General Sani Abacha seized power, when Nigeria, which is the largest contributor to the ECOMOG force, softened its stand. This led to signing of the Abuja peace accord (August, 1995), described by many as the last chance to bring about lasting peace to Liberia.

The accord provides for the faction leaders to share power alongside civilians on the transitional state council until democratic elections are held in August this year. The costly blunder made by ECOMOG in taking sides, put it in a precarious position, hoping that the worst will not happen while the transitional government was still in power.

ECOMOG was unable to drive the armed groups of its former allies from the city and take control of overall security. As a result, it was forced to also give NPFL free access to Monrovia, which is now home to more than a million displaced people from various parts of the country.

It, therefore, came as no surprise when fighting erupted on April 6, over attempts by the interim government to arrest deposed ULIMO-J leader, Roosevelt Johnson, on charges of murder. Johnson was ousted in March by senior commanders of his Krahn faction of ULIMO and subsequently dismissed by the interim government as Rural Development Minister.

One of Britain's leading dailies, The Independent, was more scathing in its attack on the US and Nigeria for their approach to the war and praised Taylor's policies in areas he controls.

"The importance of Taylor's policies and the stability of his rule in Greater Liberia have only been recognised in retrospect. At the time, the US government, worried about Taylor's links with Libya, allied itself with the Nigerian component of ECOMOG and its attempts to weaken Taylor's control," says the paper.

The Independent goes on: "Neither country was willing to let Taylor take over -- the Nigerians because the then President Babangida had been a close associate and relative of Doe. While diplomatic and aid

officials in Liberia now discuss Taylor's charisma, his consistency and his economics degree, back then the talk was of the atrocities committed by his fighters, his cocaine habit and his megalomania."

According to the British daily, ECOMOG is widely acknowledged to have conducted a covert campaign against Taylor during the ceasefire, through its support and funding of ULIMO, a new rebel army set up among Krahn and Mandingo refugees.

If West African leaders, together with the international community, still intend to implement the Abuja accord and put the peace process in Liberia back on course, they must demand the withdrawal of all armed groups from Monrovia, including the so-called Armed Forces of Liberia.

The AFL lost its status as a national army when Samuel Doe transformed it into an ethnic Krahn army, thereby making it one of the main instigators of the civil war. Representatives of the Council of State, including the warlords, must be allowed only a few bodyguards while overall security in the capital must be in the hands of ECOMOG and the United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL).

This could not have been put more aptly by the White House in a statement condemning renewed fighting which broke the ceasefire that took effect on April 19. "We urge all factions to restore the ceasefire immediately, withdraw their fighters and weapons from Monrovia, return the capital to its status as a safehaven for the city's one million inhabitants and negotiate a lasting peace in Liberia," said the White House statement.

The statement follows an upsurge of fighting after the Executive Mansion (State House) was attacked by fighters loyal to ULIMO-J leader Roosevelt Johnson on April 29, as council chairman, Wilton Sankawulo and main faction leader Charles Taylor were meeting there to reassure residents that security has returned to the capital.

Former Taylor's foe, now ally, Alhaji Kromah of ULIMO-K, was also at the meeting but left earlier before the attack. Both men are vice- chairmen on the council.

Reports say Taylor and Sankawulo were forced to flee under a hail of gunfire. The mansion is close to the Barclay Training Centre (BTC) military barracks in the city centre, where Johnson's forces, backed by the AFL and George Bolay's Liberia Peace Council (LPC) have been holed up for the last one month.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


242 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Uganda The Real Issues In The Presidential Poll


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

Nairobi - Uganda used to be the "Pearl of Africa". However more than 20 years of bad government since the sixties reduced a great country to its knees.

Current President Yoweri Museveni, the man who helped redress the country's negative image since he took over in 1986, won another five years in office, pledging "to consolidate gains." Although it is generally accepted that the presidential polls last week were a measure of the people's appreciation of the incumbent's rule in the last 10 years, critical issues remain to be resolved. 

Mr. Museveni 52, used the advantages of his incumbency and his proven track in restoring the rule of law in Uganda to draw large crowds wherever his campaign trail has taken him, including Buganda, the home region of Dr. Ssemogerere. More than 25 per cent of Uganda's 8.4 million voters are Baganda, Uganda's largest and (generally considered) most progressive ethnic group.

This was the first presidential poll in Uganda in 16 years. Dr. Ssemogerere, a lack lustre former school teacher is reputed to have won the 1980 presidential poll, which was allegedly rigged for Milton Obote who returned for the second time in 1980. Obote first ruled Uganda from 1962 to 1971 when he was overthrown by Gen. Idi Amin. The 1980 presidential elections were declared valid by a Commonwealth observer team.

Ironically Ssemogerere has allied with the same Milton Obote this time around to try and remove Museveni from power. The alliance between Ssemogerere's Democratic Party (DP), and the Uganda People's Congress (UPC), of Milton Obote is called Inter Party Coalition (IPC).

But millions of Baganda and members of other ethnic groups have little liking for Obote whom they blame for the atrocities which characterised his regimes from 1962 to 1971 and 1980 to 1985, the latter term which ended when he was overthrown by General Tito Okello, who was himself toppled by Museveni's National Resistance Army (NRA), in 1986.

In the eyes of the Baganda, Obote's biggest political mistake was the move to abolish the traditional kingdoms in Uganda in 1966. The King of the Baganda, Sir Frederick Mutesa II, fled his kingdom and died a pauper in London in 1969.

Thus while many Baganda would have supported Dr. Ssemogerere, his alliance with Obote has cost him substantial support among his own Baganda people.

Obote was also blamed for the atrocities in the Luwero Triangle area, near Kampala, where more than 300,000 people perished due to army atrocities during the war of liberation conducted by the NRA.

Many northerners particularly Acholis have never forgiven Museveni for his guerrilla war against Obote and General Okello, both of them northerners. There is currently an anti-Museveni insurgency in the north led by Joseph Kony, of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA).

Kony has perpetrated unbelievable crimes against his own Acholi people including rape, maiming by amputation of limbs or cutting off of lips.

During a campaign visit to the north of the country, Ssemogerere received overwhelming support from the Acholi when he said he would "bring Kony to State House" to negotiate with him and thus end the insurgency in Gulu and Kitgum Districts of northern Uganda. Women sang praises for Ssemogerere saying they were "tired of war and being bitten by mosquitoes," a reference to the fact that they sleep outside their huts to avoid marauding Kony guerrillas.

Museveni, by contrast is looking for a military solution to the problem asserting "Kony is a Sudanese supported criminal."

Another critical issue is federalisation which the Baganda call federo. The federal status of the kingdoms in Uganda were abolished in 1966 when the monarchies themselves were violently uprooted.

Museveni has since the early 90s restored the kingdoms but the monarchs in the four traditional kingdoms of Uganda have only limited power and are viewed as cultural institutions.

The opposition, including Ssemogerere who is from the Baganda tribe, say the restoration of the kingdoms is superficial. They call it byoya bya nswa ("termite wings") a derogatory term meaning "useless."

Ssemogerere has therefore regularly campaigned on federo. He has promised the Baganda in particular, a full federal status. Unfortunately his party is allied with Obote who abolished the kingdoms in the first place (1966).

Secondly, many other tribes in Uganda consider Ssemogerere an unbridled tribalist ready to serve the interests of his home region without caring for the rest of Uganda.

Mayanja Kibirige, a former University Administrator has concentrated his electioneering on development issues as well as peace and security to explain what he would do should both Kony and Juma Oris of the West Nile Bank Front, another guerrilla force in north-western Uganda, turn down his peace overtures.

Museveni throughout his campaigns told the Baganda that Ssemogerere is a weakling who was "merely a conduit for the return of Obote." He said he was alarmed by the fact that the issue of return of Obote was drawing large crowds into Museveni's rallies.

He had told the people of Lango District, Obote's home district, that he would return Obote (now in exile in Zambia) and offer him a fulfilling position as a retired Head of State. In Buganda, Ssemogerere changed tune entirely and said he had never made any such promises. Museveni described the grey-haired Ssemogerere as a "trickster who will plunge the country back into the abyss."

During Museveni's last political rally in Kampala, Baganda women sang "tewagala mirembe" (we want peace) in appreciation of Museveni's restoration of peace and security for the majority of Ugandans.

Poverty has been a major factor in the electioneering. Mayanja and Ssemogerere say they would cut down expenditures on defence and use the money for health and education. Museveni agrees that an overwhelming majority of Ugandans live in abject poverty but blames past regimes for it.

He argues that in the last 10 years of his rule he has improved the situation tremendously. "I have brought in investors to "milk" so we may be able to pay for your children's education." His election manifesto claims the first four children in any family will receive free education.

Museveni blames the opposition in Uganda for "trying to reap where they did not sow." He says the economy is already on the mend. "Ten years ago we managed only 44 million US dollars in taxation collection. Today we rake in nearly 700 million US dollars.

But the opposition say it is this kind of efficiency in the collection of taxes that is killing initiative in Ugandans. Ugandans are burdened by taxation, they claim.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


243 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Canada Donates Food For Refugees In Kenya


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996


LENGTH: 534 words


 

NAIROBI - The Canadian Government has donated 300 metric tonnes of foodstuff for refugees residing in Kenya.

The foodstuff include 200 metric tonnes of soya bean oil and 100 tonnes of lentils (Canadian beans). News of the donation was contained in a press release dated May 8 from the Kenya Office of the World Food Programme (WFP). 

The WFP Nairobi office said the food will benefit the estimated 175,000 refugees residing in Kenya, adding that a second ship is expected to deliver to WFP a further donation of Canadian food commodities for the same refugee programme on May 15.

According to the WFP press release, the consignment which will arrive via the coastal port of Mombasa comprises some 134 metric tonnes of soya bean oil and 460 tonnes of lentils, bringing to 8,710 metric tonnes, the amount of foodstuff the Canadian Government has donated to WFP, Kenya Office since July 1995.

The contribution, valued at Kshs.280 million (US dollars 4.9 million) includes the monitoring and logistics cost. A large part of this donation arrived in Kenya last November when the World Food Programme received a shipment of 6,210 tonnes of wheat flour.

The WFP also talks of another donation of 5,110 metric tonnes of wheat flour from the French Government, at the cost of Kshs.84 million (US dollars 1.47 million).

A WFP official told APS the two donations will go a long way to boost the organisation's food capacity for thousands of refugees residing in Kenya.

Statistics availed to APS by both WFP and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) here, indicate that by March 31, 1996, Kenya had 126,162 Somali refugees, 43,647 Sudanese, 5,700 Ethiopian, 518 Ugandan, 220 Zairean, 52 Rwandese, 52 Burundian and nine from other nationalities.

WFP says the 175,000 refugees in Kenya reside in the seven refugee camps situated mainly in northern Kenya.

WFP constantly buys Kenyan maize from local suppliers to support the refugee operation. "Currently 1,975 tonnes of maize, valued at Kshs.24 million (US dollars 421,000 ) are being purchased from the National Cereals and Produce Board in Garissa, using funds donated to WFP by the German Government. This brings the total of Kenyan maize purchased by WFP this year to 7,100 tonnes, worth Kshs.84 million," the press release stated.

The European Community has provided a large part of the funds to support WFP's local procurement efforts which began in July 1995 and end in December 1996.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


244 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zaire Eastern Region Major Source Of Endangered Parrots


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

KAMPALA - More than 50 talking birds, African grey parrots (kasuku in Kiswahili), have been seized while in transit through Uganda since the beginning of the year. Most originate from Eastern Zaire according to Customs and Wildlife authorities in Uganda. 

But Wildlife officials in this East African country believe this is the tip of the iceberg in an operation whereby, many of the parrots either die of suffocation and hunger or are successfully hidden and eventually find their way mostly to the Arabia Peninsula where handsome prices of as much as US dollars 300 are paid per bird.

Zaire as a signatory to the International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) convention for both flora and fauna, has an export quota allocated to it but individual trappers pay little heed to this rule given the lucrative nature of markets for smuggled birds.

The Commissioner for Wildlife in Uganda, Mr. Moses Okua said at the beginning of May that nine baby parrots had been seized at Entebbe Airport. "That consignment originated from Eastern Zaire," he confirmed.

The exporter did not have the relevant documents allowing cross- border movement or transfer of endangered species. What the exporter, said to be Rwandese had, were simple Zairean documents of little international validity, the wildlife official explained.

Kenyan Wildlife officials have also regularly confiscated African grey parrots originating from Zaire, sometimes by air or by land. Truckers play a big role in transporting these birds since they are able to supplement their incomes through smuggling activities.

The Director of the Uganda Wildlife Education Centre Mr. Wilhelm Moeller pointed out that transit through Uganda and Kenya is a favoured route for the smugglers. In March authorities confiscated six parrots at the common Kenya-Uganda border post of Busia.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


245 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Eastern Zaire Major Source Of Endangered Parrots


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

KAMPALA - More than 50 talking birds, African grey parrots (kasuku in Kiswahili), have been seized while in transit through Uganda since the beginning of the year. Most originate from Eastern Zaire according to Customs and Wildlife authorities in Uganda. 

But Wildlife officials in this East African country believe this is the tip of the iceberg in an operation whereby, many of the parrots either die of suffocation and hunger or are successfully hidden and eventually find their way mostly to the Arabia Peninsula where handsome prices of as much as US dollars 300 are paid per bird.

Zaire as a signatory to the International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) convention for both flora and fauna, has an export quota allocated to it but individual trappers pay little heed to this rule given the lucrative nature of markets for smuggled birds.

The Commissioner for Wildlife in Uganda, Mr. Moses Okua said at the beginning of May that nine baby parrots had been seized at Entebbe Airport. "That consignment originated from Eastern Zaire," he confirmed.

The exporter did not have the relevant documents allowing cross- border movement or transfer of endangered species. What the exporter, said to be Rwandese had, were simple Zairean documents of little international validity, the wildlife official explained.

Kenyan Wildlife officials have also regularly confiscated African grey parrots originating from Zaire, sometimes by air or by land. Truckers play a big role in transporting these birds since they are able to supplement their incomes through smuggling activities.

The Director of the Uganda Wildlife Education Centre Mr. Wilhelm Moeller pointed out that transit through Uganda and Kenya is a favoured route for the smugglers. In March authorities confiscated six parrots at the common Kenya-Uganda border post of Busia.

246 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Uganda Women Issue Their Own Manifesto


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996


LENGTH: 894 words


 

KAMPALA - Days before Ugandans went to polls to elect their president, women organisations in the country issued a no- nonsense "women's manifesto" for the attention of candidates and voters especially women voters, during and after elections.

"Unless the presidential candidates identify themselves with our manifesto, they can be sure they are not going to get women's votes," the Chairperson of the Uganda Women's Network (UWONET), Mrs Mande Mugisha, said in an interview here.

"As voters, women would like to see that issues of interest and concern to Ugandan women are addressed by those aspiring to be leaders of this country through the presidential, parliamentary and local council elections," Mrs. Mugisha said.

Uganda Women's Network organised a meeting on April 25, 1996, to put women's issues on the election agenda. Apart from providing a forum to a cross section of women and men to discuss issues of concern to the women of Uganda in particular during the elections, the meeting adopted a "women's manifesto" highlighting issues that women and men working for gender equality in society consider important for the attention of both candidates and voters particularly women voters. 

The 11-page, seven-point manifesto highlights the following issues: Peace, stability and unity in diversity; gender balance, equality and affirmative actions; poverty and economic empowerment of women; violence against women; protection of the rights of the family, orphans, children with special needs and the aged; people with disabilities; and women and health.

Among other points, the manifesto states that peace is a pre- requisite for the attainment of equality between women and men. Although women rarely have any role in the decisions leading to armed conflicts, they work to preserve social order in the midst of conflicts. They also make an important contribution as peace educators and resolvers of conflicts.

"As a nation, collective responsibility must be taken for the past mistakes in order to create peace and stability," the women emphasize.

Expounding on gender balance, equality and affirmative action, the women demand that there must be at least 30 per cent representation of women at all levels of decision making. This must include local councils, cabinet and all commissions and boards. Special effort must be made to encourage and support women to stand as candidates in all elections at all levels. Marriage and motherhood must not be used to disqualify candidacy of an individual, they add.

Presidential candidates and voters are urged to regard women as producers of wealth and not as objects of welfare. The manifesto advocates for women participation in all economic decision-making activities and calls for at least a 50 per cent share by women of the government-instituted national rural credit scheme locally known as "Entandikwa" - initial capital.

On violence against women, the manifesto says in all societies, to a greater or lesser degree, women and girls are subject to physical, sexual and psychological abuse that cuts across lines of income, class and culture, in both public and private life. They often face rape, sexual abuse, sexual harassment and intimidation at the workplace. Such acts of violence violate and impair or nullify women's enjoyment of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

The Uganda women therefore demand that their rights must be seen to be human rights and their lives and rights must be protected accordingly. In particular, when women suffer violence, the information they give should be treated with sensitivity, dignity, concern and confidentiality by those in authority. The women also demand the immediate reestablishment of special laws and family courts to deal with domestic violence.

The manifesto further points out that whereas the constitution guarantees the rights of the family based on marriage, other forms of families such as single-headed families and child-headed families need to be recognised and protected.

Lastly, the manifesto highlights the issue of women and health. It states women's health involves their emotional, social and physical well being. It is determined by the social, political and economic context of their lives, as well as by biology. The enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of physical and mental health is vital for the life and well-being of women.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


247 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Mining Costing Lives, Environmental Degradation


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996


LENGTH: 947 words


 

LONDON - As African countries vie with each other to produce more gold and other minerals, the human cost resulting from mining is becoming high as accidents coupled with environmental degradation cloud proceeds that this industry brings to the people.

The International Labour Organisation (ILO) has described mining as "one of the world's most hazardous sectors, causing more than 15,000 deaths a year."

South Africa is the continent's biggest producer of gold and according to Pik Botha, the country's Minister for Mineral and Energy Affairs, "each tonne of gold mined in the country costs one life and 12 serious injuries."

A Guinean researching on the lifestyle of African miners says; "Most African miners are condemned to high noise levels, heat and other harms that would not be tolerated in other parts of the world." 

Sully Cisse, a mining engineer notes in the findings that unlike miners in other parts of the world, African miners do not have protective gears.

The uncontrolled small scale miners have to "contend with dangerous working conditions. For those underground, frequent rockfalls, mudslides, fires from overturned lamps, poor ventilation, dust and smoke concentrations are among risks," according to a recent report by the UK-based PANOS institute.

In addition, it has become widely accepted that small-scale mining "destroys vegetation as hillsides are cleared when miners follow a vein of gold. Forest is also felled to make way for airstrips and working areas," adds Panos.

The report cites effects of mining in other parts of the world and says "medium scale operators use great suction pumps set on floating barges which undermine river banks, creating huge waste piles which alter the flow and currents. This can drastically change the landscape, often endangering villages on the banks, and causes excessive situation which can reduce the efficiency of hydroelectric projects.

In the case of large scale mining, the report says "in the process of mining billions of tonnes of ore, whole mountainsides can be gouged out, leading to the severe loss of topsoil, habitat, trees and vegetation."

Unfortunately, with hunger and poverty staring majority of Africans in the face, the gory effects of mining are bound to be ignored for short term benefits.

Some politicians say with some justification that the continent's crisis could be likened to facing the deep blue sea or the devil. The devil being the mining activities and the deep blue sea, staying put waiting for God.

As discussions on the environmental effect of mining continue Alan Burt, a London-based environmentalist says the situation is becoming very serious as it is no longer the environment alone that is being destroyed but small scale miners are poisoning themselves with the use of mercury.

The process of extracting minerals with mercury has become widespread all over Africa and health workers say the trend has increased so much so that the alarm has to be sounded to warn people of the dangers involved in using this chemical.

According to a UK magazine Ecologist, "people exposed to mercury for an average of 30 months, or who lived within 500 metres of a source of mercury, show some clinical symptoms of poisoning.

Mercury enters the body through inhalation, ingestion and skin absorption. Much of it is passed out in urine, but high exposure can result in the metal being deposited in the central nervous system. Chronic poisoning can lead to insomnia, severe tremors, brain damage, and even death. By entering the placenta, it can cause birth defects.

The chemical does not only poison those who use it, water used in the production process carries mercury into river-systems and as unregulated mining increases it is not clear how much mercury is being washed into African river systems.

To fight the phenomenon, the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) has recommended the prohibition of mercury and suggested that alternative gravity-based technologies should be used. This is however not likely to be accepted among Africa's small scale miners.

UNEP officials say retorts, which eliminate mercury gas given off during the burning process and burn just as quickly can now be made easily. Gold diggers can also use sponge filters which can be attached to furnaces to reduce the risk that they are open to when they use mercury.

The miners can also use sluice gates and traps to help prevent mercury from spilling into river-systems and other processes that can cleanse and recycle mercury.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


248 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Malawi Rift In Coalition As Key Leader Quits Cabinet


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996


LENGTH: 667 words


 

BLANTYRE - Malawian President Bakili Muluzi reshuffled his cabinet on May 2 after coalition partner Chakufwa Chihana tendered his resignation as Vice-President and Minister for Irrigation and Water Development, throwing the ruling circles into uncertainty.

Chihana, leader of the Alliance for Democracy (AFORD), who agreed on the coalition pact last year with Muluzi's ruling United Democratic Front (UDF), resigned the same day saying that he would devote more of his time to his party work, a statement issued by his aides said.

The statement said his decision was endorsed on May 1 by AFORD's executive committee. 

Surprisingly, Muluzi did not drop any AFORD ministers in the reshuffle, but instead dismissed Health Minister Sam Mpasu whom he gave the post of secretary general of the UDF, which was held by Harry Thompson.

Mpasu was involved in a corruption scandal when he was Education Minister and there were opposition demands that he must resign to make room for an official investigation into his role of ordering, at an expensive rate, about four million notebooks from a British supplier.

Relations between the two coalition partners started to cool in December when Chihana accused the UDF of lacking transparency, good governance and engaging in high-level corruption and threatened to pull out of the coalition. The coalition sought to consolidate democratic gains and bind the two parties to a coordinated working relationship in parliament.

Muluzi has denied the allegations of corruption saying there was no proof of such practices. But Chihana's resignation took a dramatic turn on May 7 when AFORD's secretary-general Mapopa Chipeta, a right-hand man of Chihana, criticised him, saying he did not discuss his decision to step down with other AFORD national executive members.

"Chihana has personal political ambitions and should not force others to side with him," Chipeta was quoted by the local media as saying on May 7. AFORD will meet on June 2 to review the coalition accord hammered out last year with the ruling (UDF) of President Bakili Muluzi. Under the accord, Muluzi appointed five ministers from AFORD and sent two senior AFORD leaders into diplomatic postings.

The June 2 meeting will specifically "discuss the stand of those who are still in government" - a topic which will generate heated debate among the five ministers and most AFORD supporters. Key leaders want the party to abrogate the coalition, formed to consolidate democracy and bind the two parties to a coordinated working relationship in parliament.

Chipata, a likely candidate to succeed Chihana as second vice- president said: "Chihana should have remained in the government to help solve the country's problems for the benefit of suffering Malawians," pointing out: "If you are a leader you face both good and bad things."

Chihana, who only makes public rallies in his stronghold of the northern region, told supporters on May 3 in Mzuzu that he resigned because: "I felt I had let the people down since their aspirations were not realised."

"The lives of the majority of the people are deteriorating everyday, while only a few people in powerful positions are enjoying the sweat. We should not play jokes or cards with the lives of Malawians," Chihana had stressed in his resignation announcement.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


249 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


SOUTH AFRICA Parliament Adopts Landmark Constitution


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996


LENGTH: 894 words


 

CAPE TOWN - The South African parliament overwhelmingly adopted the country's landmark constitution on May 8, the first to be drafted by a multi-racial parliament.

The bill, the result of two years of hard bargaining between the country's widely divided parties, needed a two-thirds majority in the 490-strong Constitutional Assembly comprised of all members of the two houses of parliament.

It obtained 421 votes in favour, two against and 10 abstentions -- but the vote had to be taken twice when some members hit the wrong buttons on the electronic voting system to give a first, erroneous result of 420 for, two against and one abstention.

After the first vote, legislators chanting "ANC", broke into a popular liberation song that translates as "bring me my machine gun," and danced around their benches -- only to be called to order for the second, decisive round of polling. 

That the constitution would obtain the required two-thirds was given after agreements reached late on May 7 by the country's two biggest parties, Mandela's African National Congress (ANC) and deputy president Frederick de Klerk's National Party (NP).

The two agreed on compromise wordings shortly before midnight on clauses dealing with lockouts, property rights and education.

"South Africa today undergoes her rebirth, cleansed of a horrible past, matured from a tentative beginning and reaching out to the future with confidence," President Nelson Mandela declared after the vote.

"The nation teetered on a knife edge over the past few days, with reports of intractable deadlocks and an abyss in waiting," Mandela said

"But aren't South Africans a wonderful people, to whom the words 'deadlock' and 'miracle' have come to nestle in comfortable proximity," he added.

The liberal Democratic Party and the black nationalist Pan Africanist Congress voted for the new constitution, while the white right-wing Freedom Front abstained.

The votes against were from the two representatives of the South African Christian Democratic Party, which deems the new basic law ungodly.

The Zulu nationalist Inkatha Freedom Party was absent from the proceedings, having pulled out of the constitution-writing process in February 1995, accusing the ANC of reneging on a pre-electoral promise of international mediation on provincial rights.

Mandela called on blacks and whites to stop thinking of themselves as separate entities and only as South Africans who, he said, played a major role in drafting the constitution.

"In the final analysis," he said, the praise we are apt to heap upon ourselves appears misplaced against the backdrop of the active participation of the people," and vowed that with the new constitution, "Never and never again shall the laws of our land rend our people apart or legalise their oppression and repression."

Before the vote, an emotional Constitutional Assembly Chairman Cyril Ramaphosa called the event "the birthday of the South African rainbow nation."

Deputy President Thabo Mbeki said the tough but successful constitution writing process would be an inspiration to the entire African continent.

"This thing that we have done today, in this small corner of a great continent that has contributed so decisively to the evolution of humanity, says that Africa reaffirms she is continuing to rise from the ashes," he said.

De Klerk was more circumspect, only saying: "It is not a perfect constitution. But it is a reasonable starting point."

Ramaphosa, who will leave parliament for the private sector once the basic law gets the final green light from the Constitutional Court, could barely check his emotions as he thanked his colleagues, with particular emphasis on NP secretary-general Roelf Meyer.

The two men are widely credited with being the architects of South Africa's peaceful transition to democracy.

In a long and difficult period of negotiation lasting from Mandela's 1990 release from prison to the final concessions hammered out late May 7, Ramaphosa, a poor black policeman's son who became a union leader, and Meyer, the attorney scion of a wealthy white farming family, became close friends and, for many, symbols of the new, post-apartheid South Africa.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


250 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Algeria Eighteen Dead In Hostage Drama


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996


LENGTH: 947 words


 

ALGERIA - Eighteen people, all but two of them Islamic extremists, were killed when Algerian security forces launched an assault overnight on a building where armed Islamic rebels were holed up with hostages, Algerian radio reported on May 7.

The radio said a policeman and a civilian had died in the dawn assault, while witnesses earlier said several people suffering from shock had been taken to hospital.

The drama began overnight on May 5 when police attempted to raid an apartment building in Birmandreis, a southern suburb of Algiers, where the extremists were holed up.

Three or four of the Islamic rebels and at least one police officer were killed during the initial assault after which police surrounded the building and sealed off the area. 

The extremists responded with a hail of gunfire and took families living in the building hostage. Security forces evacuated other families.

On May 7, press reports said the leader of the Armed Islamic Group (GIA), Djamel Zitouni, was among the extremists along with Said Omar, believed responsible for several spectacular attacks in recent months.

The GIA is considered the most radical of Algeria's Islamic fundamentalist armed groups vying to topple the secular government since January 1992, when the military-backed regime annulled elections that an Islamic party was poised to win, and which has killed tens of thousands of people since.

The incident came only days after Algerian President Liamine Zeroual announced that legislative elections would be held by June 1997 and would be followed by local polls.

Zeroual on May 5 told a meeting of media executives -- his first since his election last November -- that the elections would be preceded by a mid-year national conference grouping "all the forces of the nation" and by a referendum on amending the constitution, the official news agency reported.

State radio said the referendum would be held before the end of the year. Zeroual made the announcement following the first phase of discussions held last month with various political leaders and parties, excluding the banned Islamic Salvation Front (FSI).

Zeroual was elected last November 16 with 61.01 per cent of the vote in the first multi-party presidential ballot in Algeria's history. Voter participation in the presidential poll was 75 per cent.

The poll was boycotted by the National Liberation Front, formerly Algeria's sole political party, and the Socialist Forces Front, which was then allied with the FIS.

The two parties, however, took part last month in discussions concerning the planned legislative elections and the talks are due to resume by the end of this month.

Absent from the discussions was the FIS, which began its campaign to topple the secular government after the army intervened in January 1992 to cancel the second round of elections which the now- banned FIS was poised to win.

Zeroual was quoted by the Algerian Press Service as saying that the preliminary discussions held in April "took place in a serene and realistic environment thus, leading us to hope of widespread participation by the political establishment in the next elections."

The agency also said that the national conference preceding the elections would "debate the major issues and the protection of the multi-party system."

Zeroual's press conference on May 5 took place against a backdrop of violence in recent days in which a former Interior Minister and two other people were killed in two separate incidents by suspected fundamentalists.

The former minister, Mohamed Hardi, was killed on May 4 by three armed gunmen in the car park of a state-owned firm, security officials said.

He was the second former Interior Minister to be killed, after Babou Kabkr Belakid was killed last year in downtown Algiers.

While Minister between 1992 and 93, Hardi had taken a hardline stance against the FIS after a wave of attacks on Algerian intellectuals. Private newspapers also reported on May 5 that two people were killed and 15 injured when a homemade bomb exploded at a bus stop in Tizi-Ouzou, the main town in the Kabylie region.

The blast and Hardi's murder come amid a wave of unpublicized attacks in Algeria, as the government seeks to deprive Islamic fundamentalists of publicity in the latest phase of the four-year civil war which has claimed the lives of nearly 50,000 people, mostly civilians.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


251 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Lobbyists Discontented With Outcome Of Land Mines Meeting


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 14, 1996


LENGTH: 667 words


 

GENEVA, SWITZERLAND - A number of organizations have voiced disapproval after delegates meeting in Geneva, Switzerland, from April 22 to May 3 adopted new rules on the use of landmines but ignored demands for an outright ban.

An inter-governmental conference revising the landmines protocol of the 1980 UN Conventional Weapons Convention agreed to outlaw undetectable antipersonnel mines, also known as "dumb mines", and put tighter restrictions on self-destructing mines also known as "smarter" mines.

In a press release, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) Vice-President, Eric Roethlisberger, said the amended landmine protocol was "woefully inadequate." 

Speaking at the close of the two-week conference, the Vice- President said that "the Landmines Committee of the Red Cross (LCRC) considers as woefully inadequate the initial legal response to the increasingly devastating effects of mines as represented by the results of the Review Conference.

"The horror of the immense human suffering caused by landmines is set to continue, and (this amendment) will do little to change this situation," Roethlisberger warned.

The Geneva meeting, which brought together delegates from 65 governments and scores of non-governmental and religious organizations agreed, on among other issues; the prohibition of the use of all undetectable anti-personnel (AP) landmines; that "remotely delivered" AP mines must be designed to self-destruct within 30 days with 90 per cent reliability that the party that lays the mines will be responsible for clearing them, and that the protocol's rules apply to both internal and international conflicts.

Furthermore, the protocol prohibited the export and import of outlawed undetectable mines.

However these measures did not impress a big number of Non- Governmental Organisations and religious groups who came together in 1991 and founded the International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL).

The ICBL is a worldwide coalition of more than 450 non-governmental agencies and religious organizations which has been lobbying for a total ban on landmines.

But the total ban also anticipated by more than 30 governments as well as the United Nations and the International Red Cross, will not have to wait for at least five years.

UN Secretary General Dr. Boutros Boutros-Ghali was one of the leaders who voiced disapproval of the Geneva meeting's outcome. "I must register my deep disappointment that the progress achieved falls so far short of what I had hoped for at this review conference," Dr. Boutros-Ghali is reported to have said in a statement read to the conference on his behalf.

"The next review conference of the convention will take place in five year's time," he added. "Our estimate is that by the year 2001 an additional 50,000 human beings will have been killed and a further 80,000 injured by landmines," he concluded.

Of the more than 100 million landmines deployed all over the world, 30 million are believed to have been planted across at least 18 African countries.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


252 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Maize Surplus In Three Southern Countries


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 10, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia is among the three nations in the Southern African region expecting a good grain harvest this season.

A senior economist at Southern African Development Community's (SADC) early warning unit, Phumzile Mdladla, disclosed in an interview yesterday that among the eleven country's of the Southern African region, only three countries would record good harvests.

"Despite the good rains this season most countries are anticipating deficits in their grain harvest except for only three countries namely Zambia, South Africa and Zimbabwe which expect to record surpluses," Mdladla said in an interview at the on-going grain marketing workshop. 

Mdladla, however, assured that the surpluses in these three countries would adequately cover the deficiencies that will be experienced by the other countries.

" A total surplus of 3.14 million tonnes will be recorded against the collective deficit of 1.29 million tonnes of white maize," Mdladla said.

According to information from the regional centre, South Africa expects the largest harvest with a surplus of 2.950 million tonnes followed by 255,000 tonnes by Zambia and lastly Zimbabwe's 207,000 tonnes.

For Zimbabwe, it is not known if the surplus would be open for exports as its policy is to have a total of over 900,000 tonnes in its strategic reserves, making the anticipated surplus far below the required grain.

Mdladla disclosed that despite receiving good rains, Malawi had recorded a deficit following high costs of fertiliser and farming inputs which most of its farmers found difficult to acquire.

And representing the private trade sector, Grain Growers and Marketing Association chairman, George Lloyd attributed the anticipated 'bumper' harvest to good rains and increased planting by farmers.

And Cargil South Africa has shown interest in sourcing maize from Zambia .

Commenting on Zambia's harvest in relation to the Larger Grain Borer invasion, managing director of Cargil South Africa Limited, Thad Goff, felt this would have little impact on his company's intentions to source grain from the country.

"We are aware of the LGB but we feel that this will not have any problem with our intentions to source maize grain from Zambia," he said. " We have better contacts with the international markets and we'll look for the best market for Zambia's maize."


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


253 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Zambia's Copper Ranking Drops


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 14, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia, which in 1964 was rated the world's third major copper producing country and is currently in tenth position, will drop to thirteenth position, a ZCCM official disclosed in Lusaka yesterday.

Speaking at a Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) one week workshop for journalists which started in Lusaka yesterday, corporate affairs director, Pius Maambo, said the lack of investment since 1973 has led to decreased copper production.

Maambo said the only hope for the revitalisation of the country's mining industry lay in the on-going privatisation, especially the Konkola Deep Mining Project. 

Maambo said ZCCM is waiting for Anglo American, the largest of the company's B' shareholders, to announce the consortium of investors who will undertake the Konkola Deep Mining Project at a cost of $650 million.

Anglo American Southern Africa executive, Jack Holmes, said last month that Anglo will be announcing the consortium by the end of May.

The company needs a further $2 billion to develop other projects which were dropped in 1993 when the copper price on the world market plunged to an all time low.

Prices fell from just over one dollar per pound of copper to 72 cents , tightening the company's cash flow.

At the same time there was a temporary gain in the value of the Kwacha which also contributed to low production as it caused the ZCCM earnings to be drastically reduced. The company lost about $90 million in 1993 when the Kwacha gained from K551 to the dollar to K344.

To cover the company's loss, production expenses were kept as low as possible. Most capital projects were suspended while employees' fringe benefits had to be reduced.

"This affected the workers' morale and has been another factor to the low production figures," Maambo observed.

Currently, Zambia produces about 300,000 tonnes of copper annually compared to 500,000 ten years ago.

Though the country can only expect revenue from Konkola in about eight years time, Maambo said it is better to invest in the future than wait and create the current depressing situation.

He also urged that Zambia invests in other sectors of the economy to lessen the country's dependence on the copper production industry.

"Chile, the world's largest copper producer, produces 1.6 million tonnes of copper annually and copper contributes 48 per cent to Chile's Gross Domestic Product (GDP). Meanwhile, Zambia's 300,000 tonnes contribute 95 per cent to the country's GDP," he observed.

Maambo called for urgent utilisation of Zambia's agricultural and tourism potential.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Poor Economies Affect Living Standards


BYLINE: Zambian News Aengy May 14, 1996


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - World Health Organisation (WHO) Representative to Zambia Dr.Wilfred Boayue has attributted the declining living standards in the African Region to the poor performance of the economies in the region.

Speaking when he opened a training workshop on 'Participatory Hygiene Promotion for Control of Diarrhoeal Diseases' at Pan African Institute for Development in Kabwe today, Dr. Boayue said the extreme degree of poverty in the region had resulted into overcrowding of cities, unhealthy water supply, manultrition and the spread of diseases among other health hazzards. 

He said that diarrhoeal diseases were among the major causes of morbidity and mortality especially in children and urged the participants to come up with workable plan for solving the problem.

'You have the opportunity to learn how to empower the people to analyse their problems and find practical solutions. This is the central theme that should not escape you during this workshop,' Dr. Boayue said.

He urged the participants to exercise patience and strength so as to allow the community to participate with them in diagonising it's health problems and sorting out appropriate solutions and said that their efforts would be meaningless if this was not done.

'If the community has ownership of the initiative, it will survive long after we have gone. If on the other hand, it is seen as being driven from the outside, it will disappear as soon as the outside hand is withdrawn,' Dr. Boayue said.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

Africa News


May, 1996


PARLIAMENT PRESS GALLERY Zambia


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 10, 1996 by Christine Mwelwa and Wesley Ng'andu


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Lusaka - Debate on the Constitutional Amendment Bill continued in Parliament today with a nominated Member of Parliament asking the House to clearly define who was an indigenous Zambian.

Contributing to the debate on the Constitutional Amendment Bill of 1996 Environment Minister, William Harrington, said that he was not comfortable with a clause in the Constitution that says a person intending to stand as President should be an indigenious zambian.

Mr Harrington said unless the clause on the citizenship was re-defined, the majority of Zambians will not qualify to stand as presidents because most tribes in Zambia only migrated from other countries in the year 1500.

He said only the Ila and Tonga's are indigenous Zambians because they were already in the country even before other tribes started coming in. 

The minister wondered whether the clause meant that only Ila's and Tonga's will qualify to stand as presidents.

Raising a point of order Solwezi West Member of Parliament, Mr Kuliye Kafupi wondered how Mr Harrington could debate the citizenship of a president when he had not mentioned where coloureds migrated from.

The speaker ignored the point of order and made no ruling but Mr Harrington caused laughter when he said coloureds came as a result of the warm and cardinal relationship that exist between Africa and Europe.

Mr Harrington in conclusion appealed to the opposition UNIP to came back and contribute to the on-going debate saying it was not too late for them to come back.

UNIP walked out of the House for the third time today.

Legal Affairs Minister, Dr Remmy Mushota, today told the House that a national referendum would only be necessary if part three (3) and article 79 of the constitution were to be amemded.

Contributing to the on going Constitutional Amendment Bill debate he said under Article 62 and Section (1) of Article 79, it was only parliament which had the sole power to amend or include some provisions on the constitution.

Dr Mushota argued that government was merely introducing clause 34 on the presidential aspirant citizenship and 65 on the bill of chiefs, an Act he said did not require a referendum.

He said calls to go for a Constituent Assembly in law was a vacuum and proposing for an establishment of a law to enable it happen was unpractical because the methodology to effect constitutional reforms were already vested in parliament by article 62 and 79 (1).

Dr Mushota meanwhile, said that government would not accept to go to meetings where nationals could not respect their own republican president.

He expressed disappointment at what the opposition did to the President at the recent inter-party meeting, saying even in the traditional Zambian set-up such a thing could not be allowed.

Science, Technology and Vocational Training Minister, Dr Kabunda Kayongo, urged all Women Lobby Groups to lobby government to consider introducing a quota system for women so that gender aspects could be included in government policies if equal power sharing could be realised.

Contributing to the debate on the Constitutional Amendment Bill, Dr Kayongo observed that presently not many women were making headway in politics and other spheres of national life.

And Deputy Minister in the office of the president, Eric Silwamba, urged UNIP to go back for debate because it was not yet too late for them to forward their views.

He said in 1991 the MMD did not find it too late to negotiate with the then ruling UNIP even when the bill was already in second reading.

Deputy Minister, Kangwa Nsuluka, proposed in parliament that the minimun period of attaining Zambian citizenship be extended to 30 years.

Mr Nsuluka said the current minimun of ten (10) years has made it very easy for foreigners to claim citizenship because it was very simplified.

Mr Nsuluka said the increase in the number of foreigners in the country has contributed to the upswing of problems.

And Chimbamilonga Member of Parliament, Mr Samuel Mukupa proposed that to deter foreigners from penetrating into leadership, a presidential aspirant should submit 600 supporters from each province who are of Zambian origin. He further proposed that for a parliamentarian to show proof of his support, he should submit not less than 50 indeginious Zambian supporters and not the current requirement of only nine.

Gwembe Member of Parliament, Mr Jacob Kantina urged the House not to make the same mistake the British Government did of giving Zambia to Dr Kenneth Kaunda (a Nyansalander).

"With this Constitution we have bought a net that will catch big fish", he said.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Big Game On Rampage


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 10, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Livingstone - Elephants are on the rampage destroying crops in Mulobezi, in Sesheke district and concerned villagers have appealed to the department of wildlife to correct the situation before all crops for this year are devoured by the hungry beasts.

Machele Ward Councillor in Mulobezi, George Kalaluka, said in Livingstone today that so far three fields have been devoured by the rampaging elephants. They have on several occasions reported their presence to Mulanga and Mulobezi wildlife camps but no corrective action had been taken.

''Elephants are destroying crops for the villagers in Mulobezi and in Machele ward three fields have been destroyed but wildlife say they are under instructions not to kill any elephant,'' Mr Kalaluka said.

He said last year five fields of maize and sorghum and millet were destroyed but nothing was done.

The villagers, Mr Kalaluka, said were now demanding that government sets up a compensation fund from which villagers could be compensated from should their crops get destroyed by wildlife.

He said in the past elephants used to be killed and meat given to villagers whose crops were destroyed to exchange for grain with other people. This, he said, saved families, unlike now when families were left to the mercy of the animals without due recourse.

Mr Kalaluka has expressed fears that if the elephants are not warded off, Mulobezi would face another year of hunger this year. He said the villagers had been expecting good food crops this year had it not been for the destruction by elephants.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

May, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology 'American' Pest Threatensz Cotton Crop


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency May 11, 1996


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Chibombo - The expected cotton bumper harvest in Zambia this year, may be reduced drastically following the destruction of large hectares of the crop in some parts of the country by 'American Boreworms'.

This came to light during a regional field day sponsored by LONRHO Zambia Limited held in Lubinga area east of Chibombo boma yesterday. 

Farmers in the area disclosed that several fields of cotton have been destroyed by the worms and blamed the problem on the delay by LONRHO to provide drugs and spraying knowhow.

LONRHO Western Regional Agricultural Manager, Kenneth Malamwize, confirmed that the worms and late distribution of spray chemicals would affect the cotton production in some parts of the country.

Malamwize who described the response by farmers in the country to invest in cotton production as oerwhelming said the company would take all possible measures to avoid a recurrence of the problem next year.

Zambia Students Union: We Can't Be Bought,


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 10, 1996 by Kunda Mwila


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - University of Zambia Students Union (UNZASU) vice-president Joseph Munsanje has dismissed allegations by a pro-ruling MMD student group that his executive has been bought by the opposition to incite confusion at campus.

"The story of money is very new to us in the union ," Munsanje said in an interview yesterday. "It is only a disillusioned group which is trying to fabricate such malicious information against the union leadership. "Our position is that we would like to deliver a point that the government should withdraw the bill and a general consensus be set to iron-out contentious issues in the constitution bill."

A pro-MMD student group, calling itself UNZA-Pressure Group, issued a statement to the government owned and controlled media that some union officials have been given K1.5 million by opposition UNIP to incite students to fan confusions.

And UNZASU president Emmanuel Tembo has accused the pro-government student group of misguiding students.

"There is this group calling itself the 'Pressure Group' which is working to destroy student conscious on important national issues," Tembo charged in an interview yesterday.

And University of Zambia Law Association (UNZALAW) has come out in support of the UNZASU executive's decision to demonstrate against government's complacency over the Constitution.

"We are very concerned with most of the clauses in the constitution bill," said UNZALAW president Patrick Siyampwili in an interview yesterday. "We are therefore appealing to the government to withdraw the bill from parliament and let it be debated by the general public."

Business and Finance 'New' Passenger Train Launched


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 10, 1996 by Mervin Syafunko


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Lusaka - A daytime only passenger train is being launched by Zambia Railways. 

The train, to be called Mukuba Express, will run between Lusaka and Kitwe on a daily basis departing both Lusaka and Kitwe at 09:00 hours.

Speaking in an interview yesterday transport and communication transport ministry permanent secretary, Ronald Mukuma, said Mukuba Express will be followed in August by another daytime passenger train operating between Lusaka and Livingstone.

Mukuma said the trains were not new and had just been reconditioned at the Zambia Railways workshop at a cost of about K200 million.

According Mukuma the trains have shower rooms, liquor bars and restaurants.

The coaches are in three classes.

May, 1996


Zambia Lack Of Funds Delays College Re-opening


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 14, 1996 by George Jambaw


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - Government will not re-open Lusaka's agriculture college, Natural Resources Development College (NRDC), because of lack of funds.

But the move has angered students who quickly accused the current government of not valuing education. 

In an interview yesterday, the students' union, NARDESU, secretary-general Fidelis Mbalazi, charged that the students were against the decision by government to postpone the re-openning of the institution indefinitely.

"We are very much against the decision to extended the opening of our institution considering that some of the students were to write their final exams in July," Mbalazi carped. " Our government should please value education."

Government had extended the re-openning of the agriculture college for the second time after the institution failed to open as per academic calender early this month.

According to the minutes obtained by students from the Ministry of Agriculture, under the which institution falls, K112 million was needed for the re-openning of the college.

"We have been informed that K112m was needed if the institution was to re-open, but if it is a serious government let it fund the institution the soonest possible time instead of funding campaign exercise," Mbalazi demanded. " The government was also aware of our academic calendar and it should claim to run short of funds."

May, 1996


Zambia 'Death' Threat Haunts Unions


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 14, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - Anti-trade union forces in the country are growing and are posing a serious challenge to the survival of the labour movement, warned ZCTU secretary general Alec Chirwa in Lusaka yesterday.

Chirwa made the warning at the opening of the Zambia Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU) tripartite workshop on trade union integration at Lusaka's Andrews Motel yesterday. 

"The challenge is that of uniting the trade union movements as one solid force," Chirwa said. "All what this is requires is that trade unions begin making strategies that will address the difficulties now at hand."

Chirwa said the fragmentation of the trade union movement was not a strange development given the current socio-economic and political environment. "There is unknown fear among certain circles that makes a strong, united and independent union not desirable," Chirwa said. " As such there is a lot of pressure to fragment the trade union movement so that it is weakened." Speaking at the same workshop labour minister Newstead Zimba said the government was aware of the developments that were taking place in the labour movement.

"I am informed that this high level workshop will tackle themes related to the weaknesses and disintegration of the labour movement and map out possible ways to re-invigorate the labour movement in Zambia," Zimba said.
