Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Mandela Quickly Fills Cabinet Gaps


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 14, 1996


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Johannesburg - President Nelson Mandela surprised the country by swiftly replacing the National Party cabinet ministers, cutting down the size of the cabinet from 27 to 25, and bringing back Pallo Jordan, fired from the cabinet only a month ago.

Most of the ministers who received promotions are former deputy ministers. The new ministers are:

# Pallo Jordan, returned as minister of environmental affairs and tourism. Speculation is that the outcry that followed Jordan's sacking caused Mandela to look more favourably upon reinstating him, although to a more junior position.

# Valli Moosa, minister of provincial affairs and constitutional development (he was previously deputy minister in the same department). Moosa, once a leading figure in the United Democratic Front, played a key role in the negotations that led up to the April 1994 elections.

# Land Affairs minister Derek Hanekom now takes over agriculture as well. With his well-publicised sympathies for the landless, Hanekom may find himself facing strong antagonism from established farming interests.

# Deputy Minister of home affairs Pennuel Maduna moves to Mineral and Energy Affairs. Although he has no experience in this key portfolio, he has won a reputation for competence. He was one of the ANC's first "peace negotiators" with the De Klerk government.

# Geraldine Fraser Moleketsi becomes minister of welfare and population development (she was previously the deputy minister). Only 36 years old, she is a former personal assistant to Joe Slovo and Chris Hani.

The smaller cabinet means that Mandela is not obliged to give an extra seat to Inkatha. The new cabinet takes office on July 1.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


263 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large NGOs Call For Voice In Trade Policy Decisions


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 3520 words


 

Johannesburg - The following declaration was issued by the conference of African Non-governmental Organizations (NGOs) meeting in Midrand, South Africa from 24-28 April 1996, prior to the latest United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD IX).

INTRODUCTION

This declaration emerges from the discussions amongst African NGOs, labour, religious and other civil society organisations who came together in a parallel conference prior to UNCTAD IX. With the participation of similar organisations from other countries we exchanged experiences and ideas around issues of trade and development, and voiced our concerns about the impact of the global economic system upon our communities and countries.

We share a common vision of a world which recognises its essential interdependence while embracing human diversity in all its forms; where justice and equity for all peoples is the first priority, and in which principles of democracy and popular participation are universally upheld so that the creation of a peaceful, cooperative and sustainable future is secured.

The current system of globalisation and liberalisation has had devastating effects upon African economies. Our countries have been pushed backwards into increasing debt, de-industrialisation, agricultural decline, environmental degradation, poverty and deepening inequality. Those worse affected, such as children, youth and women, are already at the margins of society. Financial and physical resources continue to be drained out of Africa. Its marginalisation is both a product of an inequitable international system and of factors internal to African economies and polities. 

We oppose a system which places growth above all other goals, including human well-being, and which undermines national economic development and social security. We see that this system creates incentives for capital to externalise its social and environmental costs. It over-exploits and destroys the natural environment and encourages the unsustainable use of resources. It turns social services into commodities out of reach of the poor, generates jobless growth, derogates the rights of workers and undermines trade union and other democratic rights.

This global system has resulted in an ever greater concentration of power and control over resources into the hands of a relatively few transnational corporations and financial institutions. This process has exacerbated inequalities within and between countries, actively encouraged competition for investment and financial resources, and discouraged regional cooperation and integration amongst African countries. However, we affirm that globalisation and liberalisation are not irresistible processes but are the product of human agencies and can therefore be influenced and changed.

With respect to UNCTAD itself, we are concerned that it has largely taken on board the 'realities' of the liberalising globalised world order, although it does adopt a more holistic and questioning approach and raises issues of particular concern to the developing world. We are concerned at the relative inaccessibility of UNCTAD to the voices of non-governmental organisations and social movement representatives. Nonetheless, we believe that UNCTAD can play a useful role as a monitoring, research and policy development organisation and as a capacity building and technical support institution to governments and non-governmental forces in Africa.

In coming together prior to UNCTAD IX we have reached the following conclusions:

1. GLOBALISATION AND LIBERALISATION

We see that it is the strategies of business organisations and the interventions of financial institutions and governments that have produced the inter-linked processes of globalisation and liberalisation. Globalisation requires - and is reinforced by - the liberalisation or 'deregulation' of investment and capital movements, trade in goods and services, communications and other national and international economic transactions.

African countries have for many years already been subject to such liberalisation processes through the imposition of structural adjustment programmes (SAPs). The neo-liberal economic paradigm makes our governments unresponsive to our basic economic and social needs, forces open our economies to the advantage of external traders and investors and makes African countries ever more dependent upon the richer industrialised countries and their transnational corporations. Our countries are being recolonised, and the responsibility of our governments to us is being replaced by their responsiveness to the needs and interests of TNCs and their home governments.

In this context we make the following key recommendations:

1.1 AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS must heed the calls from their non-governmental organisations and social movements to resist the imposition of SAPs and other liberalisation programmes. These are damaging to people and economies and to governments' own policy independence and relevance.

1.2 AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS must be transparent in their dealings with the Bretton Woods Institutions and other external agencies and, by providing full information and resources to their own people, enable us to be more effective players and active partners in the struggles against liberalisation programmes.

1.3 AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS must take responsibility for their own actions and not use the pretext of their obligations to external agencies and international forces as excuses for their own faults and t heir failures to respond to the democratic demands and development needs of their own people.

1.4 UNCTAD as a research and capacity building organisation focused particularly upon the needs of less/least developed countries must support the right, and provide the technical and policy backup f or governmental and non-governmental organisations and social movements in Africa, to pursue development programmes that are relevant to their visions and needs.

1.5 UNCTAD must resist the global hegemony of the neo-liberal paradigm and legitimise the creation of development policies based upon national and local diversities and democratic rights.

2 FINANCIAL FLOWS AND INVESTMENT

The attraction of foreign investment through the creation of 'conducive conditions' are presumed - including by UNCTAD - to be the essential pre-condition for economic development worldwide. However, as African countries are encouraged to compete with each other for such foreign investment they aggravate their divisions and their dependence upon, and exploitation by, profit-seeking foreign investors.

Our experience of foreign investment in Africa is that it is minuscule in scale, concentrated in the extractive sectors, and while it has limited positive linkages into our economies it has many negative economic, social and environmental effects. The purported necessity to attract foreign investment is utilised by financial institutions and foreign governments as an instrument to impose their policies upon our governments. In the same way debt obligations are deliberately maintained by creditors - particularly the Bretton Woods Institutions - on account of the policy leverage it gives them over governments and countries under debt management programmes.

In this context we make the following key recommendations:

2.1 AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS must resist such dependence upon foreign investment by mobilising all possible internal financial sources and development resources, including community, cooperative, and national public and private enterprise. Furthermore, governments must play direct social and economic development roles on more democratic, participatory and accountable bases than hitherto.

2.2 AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS should have recourse to Official Development Assistance (ODA) while they work towards mobilising alternative resources. Such ODA should be allocated through transparent consultative processes and utilised in appropriate and accountable ways.

2.3 AFRICAN COUNTRIES must insist on the cancellation of external debts that cannot be repaid in order to enable the mobilisation of internal resources for investment. Any further external borrowing must be subject to clearly defined development aims and transparent democratic consultations and controls.

2.4 UNCTAD should conduct objective analyses of, and monitor, the operations of transnational corporations (TNCs) around the world, especially their effects on local communities, national economies and the environment. The UNCTAD investment division should operate within the perspective of the former UNCTC, instead of seeing its role as servicing the interests of TNCs.

2.5 UNCTAD should continue its work on monitoring the nature and effects of the astronomical and volatile speculative international financial flows promoted by financial deregulation and liberalisation. It should produce effective proposals for regulatory controls upon such dangerous financial forces.

3 TRADE AND DEVELOPMENT ISSUES

The new multilateral rules-based trade regime that emerged out of the Uruguay Round of GATT has removed theoretically the unilateralist threats and pressures by strong countries that have long featured in international trade relations. However, neither it its creation, nor in its content and application is the new world trade regime, under the World Trade Organisation (WTO), an equitable or impartial system.

UNCTAD and other international agencies are already calculating that, of the hundreds of billions of dollars of increased trade that is anticipated as a result of the more open trade system, Africa w ill actually lose a further US$2.5-3bn in the immediate future. Although these are described as mere 'transitional costs', trade liberalisation has had profoundly damaging effects upon African countries, particularly in the area of de-industrialisation. We see the new trade rules as a device to give legal force on the international plane to the trade liberalisation programmes already being imposed within the countries of Africa.

In this context we make the following key proposals:

3.1 AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS must adopt joint negotiating positions in the forthcoming meeting of the WTO in Singapore at the end of this year in order to expose and oppose the limitations that Trade Related Investment Measures (TRIMs) will impose upon national investment strategies. They must also resist the inclusion within the WTO of the proposed Multilateral Investment Agreement (MIA). This would remove any governmental regulatory controls, open up African countries to foreign investors completely, and destroy local enterprises and farms. 3.2 AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS must similarly oppose the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) which is forcing countries to open up their service sectors to transnational corporations. At the same time, Trade Related Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPs) are imposing further financial and legal restrictions on access to technology, with the danger of the further appropriation by private enterprise of the world's resources and human knowledge.

3.3. While powerful governments are creating conditions for the rapid opening up of the markets of developing countries, AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS must struggle together for the right to formulate and utilise appropriate trade and development strategies for their countries. This includes targeted and transitional tariff policies and other instruments in the interests of their economies and peoples.

3.4 AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS must resist trade arrangements which result in the continent being used as a dumping ground for dirty industries and hazardous materials. They must resist the over - exploitation of natural resources for trade and debt-related payments. The imposition of disguised trade-related protectionist environmental standards act as a further non-tariff barrier to the continent's ex ports.

3.5 UNCTAD must provide analyses, information and technical support to LDCs in all future trade and other international economic negotiations to ensure that the subordination and sidelining of their interests and needs, that characterised the Uruguay Round, does not happen again.

3.6 UNCTAD must monitor independently the world trade system to counter the bias against the LDCs and to ensure that the WTO does not become yet another international institution, like the IMF and the World Bank, utilised by the most powerful industrialised countries in the service of their own interests.

4 REGIONAL ECONOMIC INTEGRATION

Harmonisation, coordination and cooperation in technical, economic, environmental, social and political spheres is essential in an increasingly integrated and interdependent world. Such cooperation is particularly important for African countries. It is the essential basis for them to combine their resources and form larger markets, and achieve economies of scale in investment and production. This would enable them to create appropriate forms of self-sustaining development, as well as participate more effectively - to the degree and in the directions that they judge necessary - in a highly competitive world economy.

UNCTAD acknowledges the importance of regional integration for LDCs, but there are contradictory trends and conflicting strategies in this sphere of international relations, as in others. In Africa w e see our governments paying mere lip service to the aims of regional and continental integration. While signing formal cooperation and integration agreements they continue to have recourse to unilateral rather than multilateral strategies and pursue policies that create competition rather than cooperation between potential development partners.

In this context we make the following key proposals:

4.1 AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS must resist the impetus toward 'solo' integration into a hostile global economy that is being promoted by SAPs and other unilateral liberalisation programmes.

4.2 AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS must enter into serious multilateral negotiations with fellow members of formal regional agreements and turn these into real processes of cooperation and integration; while at the same time recognising and supporting multifaceted and informal processes of cross-border trade and other forms of bottom-up cooperation and integration.

4.3 AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS must make the entire process of regional cooperation and integration more transparent and democratic. It is only on the basis of direct popular participation, and as a people- driven process, that regional integration will be real, sustainable and secure, and where the rich diversity of peoples' cultures will be respected and built upon.

4.4 UNCTAD must support regional integration amongst LDCs by all means, including the defence, extension and utilisation of the 'special and differential' provisions inserted into the Uruguay Round a s a gesture towards the particular difficulties of LDCs. Fragile as these concessions are, the allowances for negotiated multilateral preferential and free trade agreements amongst LDCs must be upheld and implemented.

4.5 At the same time, UNCTAD also has a potentially important role to play in monitoring international trade patterns and trade agreements - particularly the latest strategies being utilised by the powerful blocs of industrialised countries to coopt or integrate existing or potential regional groupings in the rest of the world into their respective free trade areas. These competitive struggles a re reminiscent of the 19th century scramble to carve up the world into competing 'spheres of influence' and colonial empires.

5 THE ROLE AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANISATIONS.

We must develop our own capacities to analyse and understand the implications of globalisation and liberalisation. In this respect, NGOs must prioritise capacity building, as well as lobbying governments and international agencies, such as UNCTAD, toward the creation of an enabling environment for this.

It is evident that we African NGOs could do more advocacy and lobbying among civil society and towards our governments if we have information and effective analyses. In this context we are convinced that it is essential for NGOs, popular civil society organisations, academics, labour, religious and other democratic social movements to be partners in development endeavours at all levels - policy- making, negotiations, agreement monitoring and so on.

Therefore we recommend that:

5.1 NGOs demand from our governments, UNCTAD and other international organisations full information and participation in the decision-making processes on all agreements and processes relating to questions of international trade and development.

5.2 NGOs utilise such sources, together with our own independent research and experiences, to develop effective input into national, regional, and international debates and negotiations on these issues.

5.3 NGOs draw upon the experiences and understanding of our communities and constituencies in improving popular understanding of the local and national implications of globalisation and liberalisation. Popular civil society organisations should be able to evaluate and measure economic growth and development on the basis of peoples' indicators.

5.4 NGOs, as organised participants in the struggles for democracy and development in our countries, must link into national, regional and continental networks to ensure the most effective sharing of experiences and information, with coordinated campaigns and programmes of action.

5.5 NGOs must create effective and mutually supportive alliances with counterpart organisations and networks in other countries of the South and the North on the basis of our shared problems, our concern for our planet and our common humanity.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


264 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Development Ministers Call for ECA's Renewal


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 6, 1996 by Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 480 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - African development planning ministers began Monday in Addis Ababa their 22nd annual meeting amid calls to reinvigorate the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA).

The call was contained in speeches by the current chairman of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi and U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali during the opening session.

In a keynote address Zenawi said change was long overdue at ECA, "which was beginning to lose momentum... and limping along almost on the brink of being overtaken by irrelevance." 

Boutros-Ghali, in a message, also said reform at ECA was essential for it to meet the increasing demands of member states "for greater value for money, cost-effectiveness and economy the way the United Nations delivers its services."

Zenawi paid tribute to ECA Executive Secretary Kingsley Amoako "for the wisdom he has shown in quickly grasping the serious challenge" the commission was facing, by preparing the renewal program to grapple with the tasks ahead.

Boutros-Ghali encouraged the renewal process being undertaken under Amoako, saying it complements his own efforts to improve the commission's efficiency and effectiveness.

He said the renewal will enable the ECA to play a pivotal role in the application of the United Nation's Special Initiative on Africa to add momentum to the continent's development.

The recently launched 25 billion-U.S-dollar initiative aims to finance such activities as basic health, education, food security, water and sanitation, good governance and comprehensive peace-building.

Amoako said the renewal program's three guiding principles are excellence, cost effectiveness and partnership to create alliance for Africa's development.

The ministerial conference at the new U.N. conference center is expected to endorse ECA's renewal program.

The program sets four strategic directions with new orientation for the commission.

The conference's theme is "Meeting the challenges of Africa's development in the 21st century: The role of the Economic Commission for Africa."


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Libya Orders Medical Check-up for African Workers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 6, 1996 by Ali Dellali, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 494 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - The Libyan health ministry ordered all public and private companies employing foreign African laborers to submit them for an "emergency medical check-up".

In a statement issued here, the ministry based its decision on recent reports by the World Health Organization (WHO) on a meningitis outbreak in several sub-Saharan African countries, including Ghana, Mali, Nigeria and Chad.

This is not a "discriminatory measure," said the director of public health, Dr. Fayadan Hamza. 

In a telephone interview from his Syrte office, 450 kilometers (279 miles) east of Tripoli, Hamza said the check-up was a "preventive measure in the interest of the African workers and the Libyan population."

"We did not order the closure of borders nor did we ban African labor from entering the country. We acted in compliance with the WHO report and in the interest of our compatriots and of our Arab and African brothers," Hamza said.

"The hot weather conditions now prevailing in Libya, especially in the southern regions as well as in the towns on the Mediterranean coast favour the spread of the disease," he said.

WHO said in its recent report that countries like Chad, Ghana, Mali and Niger have about 15,000 people infected with meningitis, which has so far killed 3,600 people.

Libya hosts more than one million African workers, mainly from Sahelian countries. They are concentrated in the region of Sebha, the capital of Fezzan, 800 kilometers (496 miles) south of Tripoli, but also in Tripoli and Benghazi, 1,050 kilometers (651 miles) south of Tripoli.

So far, only one patient, from Chad, has been found with the disease, according to Dr. Mohamed Gamati, the director of the infectious diseases department at Tripoli's University Teaching Hospital.

Meanwhile, the Executive Director of Health Affairs in the Tripoli region, Dr. Abdul-Rahmane Charef, said, "A few cases are under observation. But, there is nothing definite yet, and the results might prove negative."

According to the census conducted last year, 450,000 Sudanese, 500,000 Chadians, 30,000 Nigeriens, 17,000 Malians and as many Ghanaians and Nigerians live and work in Libya. Some 55,000 other Africans of various nationalities also work there.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Uganda Army to Step in to Curb Violence during Elections


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 6, 1996 by Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 587 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Uganda's army council has resolved that the country's armed forces will step in to curb any violence during and after this week's presidential elections.

"The UPDF (Uganda Peoples' Defense Forces), in collaboration with other law enforcement agencies, shall take firm and decisive action against perpetrators of violence and those that reject the method of resolving political differences by constitutional means," the council said Sunday.

The council, the highest decision-making body of the UPDF, made the decision at its weekend meeting chaired by the minister of state for defense, Amama Mbabazi. 

"Any person, or group of persons who, before, during and after the elections, engages in any acts of violence, threats or intimidation or, in any other way acts or even attempts to act, contrary to the provisions of the constitution, shall be isolated, and firmly, ruthlessly and decisively dealt with," the council said.

Ugandans go to the polls Thursday to elect a new president. The incumbent, Yoweri Museveni, who came to power in January 1986 after five years of guerilla warfare, is being challenged by Paul Ssemwogerere, his one-time deputy prime minister and minister of foreign affairs. Little known politican Mohamed Mayanja is also in the race.

The council's statement comes at a time of public debates on whether the army will accept any leader other than Museveni.

The council has listed 12 of Uganda's 39 districts, including Kampala, the capital, as areas where unrest is being created "by criminal elements who want to disrupt the electoral process and destroy the peace, security and stability of the country."

Asked Monday whether he thought that council's statement would be accepted as sincere since he was one of Museveni's campaign managers, Mbabazi said: "You see I am capable of acting professionally. And the army council, which I chair, is a professional body".

Meanwhile, Museveni announced that the government has sent an extra army brigade to northern Uganda "to sweep the area clean" of rebel activity in order to ensure peaceful elections.

He told the nation, in a radio broadcast Sunday, that there would be massive deployment of security forces throughout the country to ensure that voters were not intimidated on polling day.

"We (UPDF) have never been stronger thaN we are," Museveni said.

Local press reports said rebels of the Lords Resistance Army, operating in northern Uganda, have been instructing people in the area to vote for Ssemwogerere.

"For the last 30 years, I have fought...so that people can vote their leaders. Do not be intimidated, we have tremendous means to deal with all multiple threats", Museveni said.

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Ruling Zambian Party Walks Out of Interparty Talks


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 6, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 587 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba and officials of his ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) Monday in Lusaka walked out of scheduled interparty talks with opposition leaders.

The incident occurred after the opposition side objected to him chairing the consultations, aimed at ironing out disagreements over the country's draft constitution.

A meeting last week also failed because of procedural details, particularly on the chairmanship. Chiluba and his delegation boycotted it because the MMD wants Chiluba to chair the talks while the opposition is calling for a neutral chairperson. 

Last week's consultations, which involved officials of both parties, were supervised by church representatives.

Today, opposition leaders shouted down MMD national chairman, Sikota Wina, when he tried to introduce Chiluba as the chairman.

Later, MMD national secretary Michael Sata blamed talks' abortion on the opposition leaders, who stayed on to continue the consultations among themselves.

"It is clear to us (government) that you are not serious about the talks. We have plenty of other things to do and cannot be bogged down by the question of chairmanship," Sata said as he announced MMD's decision to call off the consultation.

After the walkout, opposition leaders elected the chairman of the Law Association of Zambia to chair their session, which they said was intended to plan the next strategy.

The talks were called by the government under pressure from the opposition and other stakeholders, in a bid to defuse rising political tension before this year's second multiparty elections.

Tension has been building since the government introduced in parliament a constitutional amendment bill that would bar first generation Zambians from becoming president.

If the bill becomes law, former President Kenneth Kaunda would be prevented from challenging Chiluba, who beat him in 1991.

The opposition has also accused the government of mismanaging the just-ended voters registration exercise.

Opposition leaders have also claimed the government engaged a private Israeli firm, Nikuv, to help in updating the voter registration, to rig the elections. The election date has not been announced.

Political leaders who spoke after the MMD delegation left the meeting were almost unanimous in calling for the withdrawal of the constitutional bill presented to parliament last week. Others called for fresh registration of voters.

UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda, who spoke first, said government should not expect citizens to respect a constitution in which they had no say.

Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia Ex-Warlord Speaks on War-Ravaged Liberia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 6, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 680 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Former Liberian rebel leader, Prince Yormie Johnson, said Monday in Lagos the West African Peace Monitoring Force (ECOMOG) in Liberia should be empowered to enforce the peace in his war-torn country.

"Liberia has deteriorated into total anarchy, and only ECOMOG can save the situation," Johnson told PANA in Lagos before the leaders of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) met in Accra.

ECOWAS sent ECOMOG to Liberia in August 1990 to separate the warring factions, then fighting President Samuel Doe's government in Monrovia. Doe was killed in September 1990 by forces loyal to Johnson's Independent National Patriotic Front of Liberia, a splinter group from Charles Taylor's Patriotic Front. 

Johnson, in exile in Nigeria since 1992, said the situation in his country had gone beyond what a peace keeping force could handle.

He said ECOWAS, which brokered the August 1995 agreement on Liberia, was partly to blame for the escalation of hostilities in the last three weeks.

"The faction leaders ought to have been disarmed first before being allowed to sit on the ruling State Council," Johnson said.

"They are armed and so do not feel obliged to obey the state laws," he said. "Everyone must be disarmed before talking peace and not the other way round."

He had some hard words for Taylor, saying "his ambition to rule Liberia by force" was largely to blame for the protracted war.

"You cannot shoot your way to power with the AK-47 (rifle), it will not work," Johnson said.

The decision of the Liberian Council of State, of which Taylor is a member, to arrest another rebel leader, Roosevelt Johnson, on murder charges, triggered the latest breakdown of law and order in the country.

Prince Johnson said while he did not support the desposed ULIMO-J leader, "Taylor has no moral justification to charge anybody with murder, when he himself murdered many people and committed other atrocities."

He said Taylor should drop his insistence on pursuing Krahn leader Johnson to surrender.

However, he said Johnson could be tried by a properly constituted court if there was any proven charges against him, while he surrenders himself to ECOMOG and not to any factions.

"No faction should assume leadership of the country," the ex-warlord said, quoting the 60-page book he wrote in 1991 on "The Gun That Liberates Should Not Rule."

Turning to the United States, he said Washington's role in Liberia had been less than satisfactory.

"They have continued to play the same role they played in 1990, basically watching us kill ourselves," Johnson said.

He said America had a duty to do more for Liberia, since most Liberians trace their roots to the United States.

Liberia, Africa's first republic, was founded in 1847 by freed slaves from the United States.

But the six-year-old war has devastated the West African country, killing some 150,000 people and made refugees of half of its estimated 2.5 million population.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia Roosevelt Johnson Says Abuja Accord Failed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 547 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Roosevelt Johnson, leader of the ULIMO-J, one of Liberia's warring factions, said Monday the peace accord signed by the factions in Abuja last August, has failed and should be changed.

At a press conference in Accra, Johnson accused Charles Taylor and Alhaji G.V. Kromah, leaders of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and ULIMO-K, respectively, of violating the accord.

Johnson is in Accra for a special summit of the Heads of State Committee of Nine on Liberia set up by the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS). 

The summit, which opens Tuesday in the Ghanaian capital, will assess the situation in Liberia and find solutions to problems hindering the implementation of the accord.

Although a key component--the establishment of a Council of State--is in place, other provisions of the accord such as disarmament, encampment of combatants and the holding of elections, have not been implemented.

The outbreak of fighting between Johnson's forces and those of Taylor and Kromah early in April has worsened the situation.

Reports quote Taylor and Kromah as saying they will not attend the summit.

Johnson said the two are "greedy for power."

"They want to take power through the force of arms," Johnson said. "My presence in Accra shows that I am prepared for peace and democracy."

He said the six-member Council of State gave themselves the title of "Collective Presidency" instead of "Vice-Chairmen" as stipulated in the accord.

He denied that the recent fighting started because he ordered one of his bodyguards to be killed.

"The main motive is that the two (Taylor and Kromah) want me out of the way. I have said I am prepared to face a legally constituted court to clear the charges and although my lawyers have written to that effect, up till now I have not been served with any writ.

"ULIMO-J will fight today and tomorrow in the pursuit of freedom, peace and democracy", Johnson said.

He called for the return to constitutional rule and the order that prevailed in Liberia before the civil war started in 1989.

"Taylor said his aim was to rid Liberia of Doe and corrupt governance," Johnson said. "Doe has been dead for about six years now, but the war still rages on. Now is the time for Taylor to honor his words and hand in his arms".

Johnson said he wants a society which is free of arms and that he is prepared to stop fighting for that cause.

Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-Currencies Stable Week for African Currencies


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 7, 1996 by Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 254 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - After previous weeks' turmoil, major African currencies reported quiet trading this week.

The South African rand opened the week averaging 4.43 to the dollar from 4.38 on the same day last week. 

The usually volatile New Zaire exchanged at the mean rate of 33,300 from 33,272, for one greenback in the previous week.

Reports from Lagos Tuesday said the Nigerian naira continued to gain ground, up from 85 to the dollar at the beginning of this year, to 82.5 to the greenback in the parallel market.

(Nigeria operates a two-tier currency market under which the official rate used for government transactions is fixed at 22 naira to one U.S. dollar. The parallel rate finds its level in-between regular currency auctions operated by the central bank).

Elsewhere, the CFA franc, in use in 13 French-speaking African countries, moved up from the nominal rate of 515.6 to 515.3 for one U.S. dollar.

In Dakar Tuesday, the CFA franc traded at 500 (buying) and 530 (selling) for one dollar from 507 (buying) and 524 (selling) on the same day last week.

May, 1996


Niger Niger's Election to Cost 6 million U.S. dollars


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 7, 1996


LENGTH: 214 words


 

NIAMEY, Niger (PANA) - The chairman of the Independent Election Commission of Niger, Maidadji Mainassara, said Tuesday the upcoming polls in his country will cost 3.141 billion F CFA (about 6.22 million U.S. dollars).

Niger will hold a constitutional referendum May 12, to be followed by the first round of the presidential poll on July 7, with the second ballot on July 20. Local and legislative elections will be held after the new president's inauguration.

The chairman told journalists that the government has asked donors to help fund the election.

Mainassara said of the donors contacted only France pledged to provide 200 million F CFA.

He added that the United Nations Environment Program pledged to provide funds in July.

Col. Ibrahim Bare Mainassara, who seized power in Niamey on Jan. 27 has already declared his candidacy as an independent.

Africa News


May, 1996


Uganda Ugandan Presidential Candidates to Debate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 7, 1996 by Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Uganda's three presidential candidates face each other in a crucial public debate Tuesday night in Kampala, in what is seen to be a turning point in the 39-day election campaign.

The debate, on the theme "The Uganda I want to build," is two days before the polls Thursday. Babatunde Thomas, of Nigeria, the United Nations Development Program representative in Uganda, will moderate the debate.

The debate, organized by the Interim Electoral Commission, is modelled after a similar forum held in neighboring Tanzania before its multiparty general elections in October 1995.

The IEC took over the debate from two non-governmental organizations, the Uganda Think Tank Foundation (UTTF) and the Friedrich Ebert Foundation, after the Inter-Political Forces Cooperation (IPFC), the union of parties sponsoring Paul Ssemwogerere, showed unwillingness to attend, seeing the UTTF as being Pro-Museveni front.

Each of the three aspirants--Yoweri Museveni, Paul Ssemwogerere and Mohamed Mayanja--will be given five minutes to present their resume and issue a political declaration on the theme.

After the political statements, each candidate can challenge his opponents' presentation in three minutes.

Then each of the candidates will give his ideas on seven major issues--agriculture, economy, security, corruption, children, national unity and good neighborliness.

Wafula Oguttu, a UTTF member, said each candidate will be allowed 300 supporters in the hall. However, they are not expected to wear candidates' T-shirts, portraits or posters, nor sing in favor of their candidate.

The debate will be carried live on Uganda Radio and Television. However, the print media is barred from reporting on the debate Wednesday because of fears of distortions by the opposition.

273 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Zambian Parliament Begins Constitutional Debate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 7, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya and Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 774 words


 

LUSAKA, ZAMBIA (PANA) - Zambia's parliament began debate Tuesday on the controversial constitutional amendment bill that seeks to bar first generation Zambians from contesting for the post of republican president.

Zambia's ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy, which tabled the bill, proposes that only Zambian-born citizens with parents born in the country should be the only eligible to vie for the office of the president.

If passed, the bill would disqualify Kenneth Kaunda from another term as president. Born in Zambia of Malawian parents, he served as the country's first president, for 27 years, since independence in 1964. He has challenged the incumbent, President Frederick Chiluba, in presidential elections due this year. 

The main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) is demanding the bill's withdrawal, saying it is a recipe for civil strife and a negation of the country's declared commitment to democracy.

"It is not right that we should set the stage for strife," said Lavu Mulimba, the UNIP member who tabled the motion.

He said the new law could erode any hope that citizens have in the constitution as a guarantor of their freedoms.

Parliamentarians of both the ruling and oppostion parties listened as the speaker, Robinson Nabulyato, implored the house to be "critical and objective" in its debate.

"I wish to remind honorable members that the house is debating a bill that has attracted the attention of (the country) and that could affect the whole country," he said.

The bill contains other very contentious issues. Among them is a measure which would ban traditional chiefs from participating in partisan politics. Instead a House of Chiefs would be set up to address traditional matters.

Mulimba challenged government's claim to be acting according to the wishes of Zambians on the citizenship issue.

He said only 36 of the 996 petitioners to the Mwanakatwe Constitutional Review Commission favored the measure on the citizenship clause.

But supporting the measure, Deputy Information Minister Valentine Kayope quoted the Bible and cited political philosophers on the need for having indigenous rulers to maintain national sovereignty and security.

Kayope accused Kaunda of killing political opponents including his one-time vice-president, Simon Kapwepwe, and former Prime Minister Nalumino Mundia.

Kayope said the idea of having a Zambian indigene as president was mooted well before independence in 1964. He accused former British colonial masters of imposing Kaunda on the country so he could serve their and other foreign interests.

Opposition leaders, who met in the capital Tuesday at interparty consultations that were boycotted by President Frederick Chiluba and his ruling party, have also demanded that the bill be withdrawn.

In a joint communique, the opposition appealed to government to discuss the differences emanating from the constitutional amendments.

Independent observers who attended Tuesday's parliamentary debate thought that government members in the house had already made up their minds about voting in favor of the citizenship clause.

The observers also believe that members of the ruling party would endorse the proposal to declare Zambia a Christian nation in the constitution.

Chiluba, last week, addressed a party caucus of his parliamentarians at which political observers believe the party decided to block Kaunda who is campaigning to challenge the incumbent.

Kaunda lost power to Chiluba and the MMD in 1991, in the country's first multiparty elections in 17 years. Kaunda held power for 27 years since independence in 1964.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


274 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Abiola Family Feud Deepens


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 7, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The rift in the family of detained Nigerian politician, Moshood Abiola, over his treason trial has deepened with two senior lawyers locked in a legal battle over who should defend the detainee.

The controversy pitting Abiola's most senior wife, Kudirat against his son, Kola, stalled his trial proceedings Monday in Lagos. 

Godwin Ajayi, Abiola's lead attorney until February when Kola wrote to end his brief, had filed a suit at the Lagos Federal High Court asking for accelerated hearing of the case.

But Kola Abiola claimed his father had mandated him to tell Ajayi to stop representing him because of lack of progress in the case.

The elder Abiola, the acclaimed winner of the June 1993 presidential election annulled by the last military regime of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, is standing trial for declaring himself president of Nigeria in June 1994.

When Ajayi's suit came up for hearing Monday, another senior Lagos lawyer, Rotimi Williams, told the court he was the new counsel to Abiola. Then, Williams requested the court to strike off Ajayi's case.

Abiola's wife, Kudirat, who was in court along with Abiola's three children, including Kola, insisted that Ajayi should continue with the case.

In a 55-point affidavit, she admitted the rift in the family and accused her son of spareheading the group that wanted Abiola to renounce his claim to the presidency.

Judge Babatunde Belgore, who could not hide his consternation, adjourned the case until May 13.

Political observers say the family feud could further prolong the politician's trial, which has already seen the withdrawal of several judges who claimed they had been accused by Abiola's team of bias.

In response to local and international appeals for his release, the administration of Gen. Sani Abacha has said the trial will go ahead.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


275 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Cameroon Cameroon Calls for Urgent U.N. Mission to Bakassi


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 7, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 534 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - Cameroon asked the United Nations to dispatch an urgent fact-finding mission to the disputed Bakassi peninsula, where fighting has again flared between it and Nigeria.

"There is an urgent need to begin the fact-finding mission which the (UN) secretary-general had proposed...and which the Security Council had approved in principle," Cameroon Foreign Minister Ferdinand Oyono said in a letter to the Security Council.

Oyono said in his letter released Tuesday in New York, the "increasing gravity" of the situation on the peninsula, where clashes between Nigeria and Cameroon have escalated in recent days, necessitates sending a mission as soon as possible. 

Nigeria has accused Cameroon of aggravating the situation on the peninsula, where forces of both countries have clashed intermitently since 1994.

Last week, Nigeria's permanent representative to the United Nations, Ibrahim Gambari, reported the latest flare-up to the Security Council, alleging that Cameroon had been attacking Nigeria's position with gun boats and heavy weapons.

Oyono alleged in the letter that the latest clash started when Nigeria launched attacks on Cameroon's army positions beginning April 21, and that Nigeria was planning a full-scale offensive.

"Nigeria's deployment of more and more troops and military equipment during the past few weeks is a clear indication of its intention to launch a large-scale offensive as part of its plan to annex the peninsula," he said.

He warned that Cameroon would make the "supreme sacrifice" to defend its territorial integrity.

Asked if there was any plan to send the mission soon, a U.N. spokesperson, Sylvana Foa, said the secretary-general would discuss the issue with his advisers in the department of political affairs and the department of peace-keeping operations before taking a decision.

"We understand that the situation in Bakassi peninsula has heated up considerably over the last few days," she said.

The Security Council has repeatedly urged the two countries to seek a peaceful settlement of the dispute but so far has refrained from taking further action. Cameroon also reported the dispute to the Organization of African Unity and the International Court of Justice at the Hague.

In a provisional ruling March 15, the court called on the two countries to desist from any action that could prejudice the rights of the other after a judgment is rendered.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


276 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia African Foreign Ministers Meet on Liberia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 7, 1996


LENGTH: 827 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Foreign ministers of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) Committee of Nine are due to meet in Accra today to prepare for a summit on the escalation of fighting in Liberia.

ECOWAS Chairman Jerry Rawlings has called the two-day emergency meeting to consider the fighting that started April 6.

The meeting will be attended by Cote D'Ivoire, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Mali, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone and Togo. 

Officials here say the summit will discuss the latest fighting in the Liberian capital of Monrovia and try to secure a lasting cease-fire.

The summit hopes to put the Abuja peace accord, signed in August last year, back on track and to define a new role for the West African peace monitoring force in Liberia, ECOMOG, in the face of renewed hostilities.

The Abuja accord, designed to return Liberia to civilian rule, is far behind schedule. It is yet to secure the encampment, disarmament, and the integration of combatants into society -- all crucial military aspect of the agreement.

The summit is expected to be attended by Dane Smith, a special representative of U.S. President Bill Clinton; James Jonah, the U.N. secretary-general's special envoy, and O.A.U. Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim.

The chairman of Liberia's ruling Council of State, Wilton Sankawulo, and council members Tamba Tallor, Oscar Quiah and George Boley are in the country for the summit.

However, council members Charles Taylor, the leader of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia, and Alhaji Kromah, the leader of one of the factions of the United Liberation Front (ULIMO), have said they will not attend.

Rawlings told Sankawulo Monday that some West African countries had turned away shiploads of Liberian refugees because their resources were overtaxed.

Jonah, the U.N. official, said West Africans were fed up with Liberia's inability to end the war and that the summit would likely demostrate this frustration.

"Therefore, it is up to those who have the interest of Liberia at heart to strive to bring durable peace to the war-ravaged country," he said.

"I know the war has taken a long time, but some have taken as long as ten to fifteen years," Sankowulo said. "It is easy to start a war but difficult to achieve peace."

Fighting erupted in Monrovia when government forces tried to arrest Roosevelt Johnson, leader of another faction of ULIMO, and have him tried for murder. Johnson, who was earlier dismissed from the cabinet as minister of rural development, resisted arrest and was holed up in the Barclay Military Training Center with his Krahn forces.

Fighters loyal to Taylor and Kromah, who made up the bulk of the government forces sent to arrest Johnson, have been pounding the barracks but have met stiff resistance.

Several attempts by Ghanaian negotiators, U.N. and U.S. officials, including Assistant Secretary of State George Moose, have failed to secure a cease-fire.

Johnson was flown out of Monrovia in a U.S. helicopter last week to attend the Accra meeting. He told a press conference in Accra today that Taylor and Kromah were "greedy for power."

"They want to take power through the force of arms," Johnson said. "My presence in Accra shows that I am prepared for peace and democracy."

But Johnson said the Abuja accord had been violated by Taylor and Kromah and needed to be changed.

"ULIMO-J will fight today and tomorrow in the pursuit of freedom, peace and democracy," Johnson said.

Rawlings called for a cease-fire Saturday from 1 am GMT Sunday to promote security in Monrovia and provide the right atmosphere for the emergency summit. However, fighting continued sporadically Monday.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


277 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Meningitis Belt Moving South


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 8, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Cerebro-spinal meningitis killed 11,850 Africans between January and May 6 this year, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).

The epidemic, according to the Brazzaville-based WHO Africa regional office, affected 101,850 people in 14 states.

The disease's belt, which by mid March was confined to eight west and central African countries, is now spreading southwards, with Mozambique and Zaire joining the list. 

Libya recently ordered employers of workers from sub-Saharan Africa to send them for meningitis check-up following the discovery of a Chadian labourer who showed signs of the disease.

Quoting cases reported in Brazzaville between April 14 and 29, the WHO's list showed that Nigeria had recorded 5,802 meningitis-related deaths between January and May.

Burkina Faso came second with 3,941 deaths and 38,821 cases, followed by Niger, where the disease killed 1,186 people out of 12,316 patients.

In Mali, 605 people died of the disease out of the 5,091 who contracted meningococcus, the bacteria that causes cerebral-spinal meningitis.

Chad had 85 deaths out of 896 cases while Benin buried 84 out of 699 patients. In Togo, the disease killed 76 out of 440 cases and in the Central African Republic 22 deaths were recorded out of 155 cases.

Other countries which reported deaths and cases were Malawi which recorded 29 deaths out of 269 cases, Tanzania (eight deaths out of 99 cases), Mozambique (six deaths out of 21 cases) while Cameroon had one death out of five cases. Ghana had only 18 cases but no deaths.

Medical experts say meningococcus is present and lies dormant in the nasal membranes of most healthy persons. The mucus in the membranes and the natural immune system subdue the germ, preventing it from reaching the spinal cord and the brain.

In case the immune system is weakened, especially during the dry season, the germ attacks the spinal cord and brain, causing paralysis and eventually death.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


278 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Uganda Presidential Candidates Debate Flops In Uganda


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 8, 1996 by Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 374 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - The "great" debate between the three presidential candidates contesting Thursday's elections in Uganda flopped Tuesday after two of the aspirants failed to show up.

Only the little known candidate, Muhammed Mayanja, showed up. Diplomats and members of the press were kept uninformed about the reasons for the cancellation of the debate until the last minute when a member of the Interim Election Commission, Charles Owor, made the announcement.

He said that even after extensive consultations and preparations were made to hold the debate, the commission was receiving conflicting signals from the camps of the two stay-away candidates, incumbent President Yoweri Museveni and his main challenger, Paul Ssemwogerere.

"Early this (Tuesday) evening, it was a question of we are coming, we are not coming from both candidates Museveni and Ssemwogerere," Interim Election Commission Chairman Stephen Akabway said.

United States Ambassador Michael Southwick said Ugandans had missed a great opportunity to assess the candidates.

"It would have been good for Uganda if this debate had taken place but since it hasn't, it is not a catastrophe," an official from the Germany Embassy said.

"We agreed we should hold the debate but since they have not come shows they have fear to confront me," candidate Mayanja said.

The highly touted debate, which was supposed to be chaired by the United Nations Development Programme representative in Uganda, Babatunde Thomas, marked the end of 39 days of election campaigns.

The election, the first in 16 years, will witness some 8.5 million voters choosing Uganda's first directly elected president. The results are expected to be announced Saturday and a new president sworn-in Sunday.

Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Abiola's Wife Charged With Conspiracy


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 8, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 494 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Kudirat Abiola, senior wife of detained Nigerian politician Moshood Abiola, appeared before a Lagos magistrate's court Wednesday on a two-count charge of conspiracy and false publication.

The prosecution said Kudirat, who was arrested by police Tuesday, is to answer charges for alleged conspiracy to commit a misdemeanor and false publication with intent to cause public fear.

She appeared at the Igbosere Magistrate's Court with two men, one of whom was identified as a printer. They all pleaded not guilty and were granted bail in the sum of 10,000 naira each (444.4 U.S. dollars). 

"I am very happy it's over for now, there is nothing in the charges, nothing," Kudirat told journalists after her release on bail.

The case was adjourned till May 28.

Kudirat has been critical of the military government over the incaceration of her husband.

Moshood Abiola is the acclaimed winner of the June 1993 presidential election annulled by the last military regime. He is facing trial for treasonable felony for declaring himself president of Nigeria in June 1994.

A senior police spokesman told PANA the publications for which kudirat was being charged included exercise books with pictures of her husband describing him as "President Elect," and others saying, "Abacha get out, Abiola form a national government now, victory for democracy, victory for Nigeria."

This is an apparent reference to Gen. Sani Abacha, Nigeria's current military ruler.

Deputy inspector-general of police operations, Nuhu Aliyu, said "these are exercise books, the kind used by children."

At a public function in Lagos last month, Kudirat alleged that the government had taken steps likely to destroy the family financially.

She accused government of refusing to pay millions of naira owed to her company and those of her husband for contract jobs they had carried out.

She has also been locked in a family feud with Abiola's eldest son, Kola, over the choice of the husband's defence lawyer in the treason trial.

She wants the original attorney, Godwin Ajayi, retained. But Abiola's son wants another senior Lagos lawyer, Rotimi Williams, to take over his father's defence.

A case to resolve this issue is in a Lagos court.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

280 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa South Africa Gets New Constitution


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 8, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 614 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - South Africa adopted Wednesday a new democratic constitution, after a last minute compromise on some thorny issues, by the country's ruling coalition, the African National Congress (ANC) and the National Party (NP).

A release from the South African High Commission in Lusaka said the Assembly, which met overnight in Cape Town, arrived at a compromise early Wednesday, on some of the sticky clauses.

These included the issues of property rights and the right of employers to lock out striking workers. The other was the emotive issue of single language schools demanded by the NP of second vice-president Frederick de Klerk. 

The National Party members wanted employers to be given the right to lock out striking workers and single language schools. The ANC opposed the clause, saying it was discriminatory and a "hang over" from the apartheid era.

Political observers in Lusaka said the agreement has averted a possible costly referendum and or an early election.

According to the High Commission's statement, the agreement was made possible by the NP's compromise on education and labour. It said the ANC also gave in on the NP's demands for stronger private property guarantees.

The NP had sought a single language policy for schools. But this was seen by the ANC as an attempt to entrench Afrikaans, the language of the former ruling white Boer community, to the exclusion of the majority African population.

South African schools also offer lessons in English and several other indigenous languages. Senior ANC negotiators were quoted Wednesday saying that they supported multi-language schools to promote racial integration.

The NP, which generally represents the more affluent white population, had also sought tougher action against striking workers, including loss of jobs.

The ANC is the senior partner in South Africa's ruling coalition, established in 1994 following Nelson Mandela's election as president in April that year.

The new constitution guarantees some administrative autonomy to the country's regions. It also enshrines the principle of equal rights for all South Africans, irrespective of racial, religious and other distinctions.

This reverses the policy of white supremacy and racial segregation, which was adopted by the National Party in 1948, under the former prime minister, Hendrik Verwood.

The adoption of the constitution marks the climax of a democratization process that began with Mandela's release by De Klerk, after 27 years of imprisonment.

His release was followed by negotiations that effectively ended apartheid two years ago and ushered the new political order.

Mandela was inaugurated president May 10, 1994, on an interim constitution accepted by the various political stakeholders in the country.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


281 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Chinese President Seeks To Win Back African Friends


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 8, 1996 by Nicholas Ibewuike, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, is making a six-nation African tour aimed at countering diplomatic gains made by Taiwan at the expense of Beijing.

From Kenya, Zemin will visit Ethiopia, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Mali and Egypt. 

The Chinese ambassador in Nigeria, Lu Fengding, said at a lecture in Lagos Tuesday, that the visit is part of efforts by Beijing to strengthen political, economic and cultural cooperation with the continent.

But analysts see the Chinese leader's tour as a diplomatic offensive to offset Taiwan's diplomatic gains in Africa at the expense of mainland China.

Chinese diplomats accuse Taipei of using huge financial and material rewards to secure recognition from needy African countries.

The most recent was Senegal, which spanked decades-long close ties with Beijing to recognise Taiwan to the chagrin of Chinese authorities who regard the island state as a renegade province.

Nine other African countries -- Burkina Faso, Central African Republic, Guinea-Bissau, Gambia, Liberia, Malawi, Niger, Swaziland and South Africa -- have already recognised Taiwan and now maintain close political and economic ties with it.

Speaking at the lecture on "China and the World" at the Nigerian Institute of International Affairs, Fengding said China had always maintained cordial relations with Africa.

"There will be no peace in the world without Africa," which comprises one-third of the United Nations, he added.

The envoy also denounced what he called interference in the internal affairs of countries for the pursuit of human rights.

"Human rights in the world should be through dialogue on the basis of equality and mutual respect among nations," he said.

Taiwan, which has one of the worlds, strongest economies, is among ten leading capital exporters.

Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia ECOWAS Ministerial Meeting Draws Up Agenda


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 8, 1996


LENGTH: 494 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - The ministerial meeting of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) Committee of Nine on Liberia adjourned Wednesday morning after an all-night session.

Ghana's Foreign Minister Obed Asamoah said the recess was to allow for the fine-tuning of the agenda for the committee's summit level meeting, which opens later in the day.

Among other issues, the ministers had discussed a proposal to review the role of Ecomog, the West African peace monitoring force in Liberia. 

They also suggested the cessation of ongoing hostilities between forces of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia and ULIMO - K, on one hand and those loyal to Major-Gen. Roosevelt Johnson, leader of ULIMO-J, on the other.

In his report to the ministers, Asamoah urged them to consider the non-recognition by West Africa of any Liberian government which came about through force.

He called for the cessation of reported unilateral arrests and detention of people by Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia forces, safe corridors for Johnson's forces from the besieged Barclay Training Centre barracks and an end to inflammatory broadcasts on Taylor's radio station.

Asamoah said the mandate of the peacekeeping force should be redefined and a new national army trained.

In his report to the ministers, the Ecomog field commander, Maj.- Gen. John M. Inienger, called on West African leaders to consider the complete withdrawal of the peacekeeping force if they cannot strengthen it to contain the new dimension of the Liberian crisis.

He said apart from the impotency of Ecomog, due to inadequate manpower and poor logistics, warring faction leaders serving on the Council of State continued to interfere and obstruct its activities.

Maj.-Gen. Inienger said recent outbreak of fighting within Monrovia, had punctured the Abuja Accord.

"...The question of sovereignty has been used to re-write certain portions of the Abuja Accord," he said, adding that the crisis was increasingly becoming factional and tribal in nature.

"..The main battle is yet to be fought since all parties to the conflict remain recalcitrant to the pleas by ECOWAS, the United Nations and the international community, to withdraw their fighters from the safe haven of Monrovia, " Inienger cautioned.

May, 1996


Zambia Minister Resigns Over Draft Constitution


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 8, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian Minister of Works and Supply, Simon Zukas, has resigned from the government of President Frederick Chiluba.

Zukas, in a statement issued through the official Zambia News Agency (ZANA), said he tendered his resignation Wednesday afternoon, to President Chiluba. 

"I have been obliged to do this in order to (be free to) give the nation my views on national issues, in the debate on the constitution and the forthcoming presidential election," he said.

He said he considered the issues to be of national importance and above party politics.

"I do feel that for this to be so, the air must first be cleared as to the basis for presidential candidates in this election," he added.

Zukas was apparently referring to ongoing controversy on a draft amendment to the constitution, which bars first generation Zambians from aspiring to become president.

The opposition has rejected the amendment, saying it seeks to ban former president Kenneth Kaunda, from challenging Chiluba in presidential polls scheduled to be held later this year.

Opposition members of the parliament staged a walk-out when debates on the amendment resumed Wednesday. The Zambian parliament is dominated by Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy.

Zukas is the second cabinet minister to resign from the government, barely weeks after Commerce, Trade and Industry Minister, Dipak Patel, quit the cabinet.

May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Nigeria Warns On Aborted Liberia Summit


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 9, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 480 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria warned Thursday that leaders of West African economic group, Ecowas, were getting "fed up" with the fighting in Liberia.

Following the abortion of an Ecowas summit on Liberia because of poor attendance, Nigeria's defence headquarters said in lagos the warring factions in Liberia should know that the patience of the international community is running out on the country's crisis.

Ecowas has a peace keeping force in Liberia, known as Ecomog, whose troop size is now 5-6,000 troops, down from 10-12,000 when the force was first sent to the country in 1990. 

The summit of the Ecowas special Committee of Nine Countries --Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast, Gambia, Ghana, Malawi, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone and Togo --was cancelled by Ghana Wednesday after only the heads of state, Ghana and Sierra Leone, showed up.

Brig.Gen Fred Chijuka, Nigeria's defence spokesman told PANA in an interview the fact that the crucial meeting failed was a pointer that Ecowas leaders were "getting fed up" with the intransigence of the Liberian warlords.

The Accra summit was to have followed a meeting of the nine countries' foreign ministers on the renewed fighting in Liberia.

Chijuka said "Liberians should not take countries assisting them for granted... Everybody is getting fed up with their tricks."

He said the failure of the meeting "is a very serious signal that (the Liberians) might have to go it all alone."

Factional fighting erupted again in Monrovia April 6 following attempts by the ruling Liberian Council of State to arrest for alleged murder Roosevelt Johnson, sacked from the council.

Johnson, deposed Krahn leader of Ulimo-J faction, was for almost two weeks holed up in Monrovia's Barclay Training Centre under seige by forces of Charles Taylor's Patriotic Front and Alhaji Kromah's Ulimo-K.

He was later flown out to Accra for the summit that never took place.

The six-year-old war launched by Taylor from Cote d'Ivoire on 24 December 1989.

The war in Africa's first republic founded in 1847 by freed slaves from the United States, has reportedly killed more than 150,000 people and rendered refugees about half of Liberia's estimated 2.5 million population.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Opposition MPs Stage Second Walk-Out


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 9, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 694 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Members from Zambia's main opposition party, the United National Independence Party (UNIP), Thursday staged a second walkout when parliament resumed debate on a controversial constitution amendment bill.

UNIP members first walked out of the house Wednesday protesting refusal by the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) of President Frederick Chiluba to withdraw the disputed bill pending broader national consensus on some of the more controversial proposals.

The party is particularly unhappy about the citizenship clause barring citizens with parents born outside Zambia from contesting for the post of president. It is also unhappy about another clause seeking to enshrine in the constitution President Chiluba's declaration of Zambia as "a Christian nation." 

The walkout left only Akashambatwa Mbikusita Lewanika of the opposition national party in the house, which is dominated by the MMD.

The UNIP members were, however, in the house during the "question and answer" parliamentary session on various matters.

But all the 23 left as soon as Speaker Robinson Nabulyato called on Lewanika to continue his debate on the constitution amendment bill.

In his contribution, Lewanika accused the government of deploying "chameleon and Animal Farm" political deception to enact a constitution.

"No one can mistake a place and a time, where and when, a national leadership has risen to the occasion of moving towards determining a national consensus in good faith that reconciles differences in the nation," said the opposition member.

He said that the timing of the new "discriminatory constitution" on the eve of general elections scheduled for this year, justified widespread suspicions that it was intended to be selective and victimise some citizens.

Rather than "standing the test of time", as claimed by the ruling party, the new constitution would only last for as long as the MMD remained in power, he said.

"It is my hope that if the MMD have failed to rise to the challenge to give this country a constitution to last the test of time, a new generation of serious, patriotic and nationalistic Zambians would emerge and do it," he added.

Zambia, he said, needed a constitution that enhanced peoples' human rights, maintained law and order and accommodated minorities and weaker sections of the society.

The controversy over the proposed constitution has so far caused the resignations of two cabinet ministers.

Works and Supply Minister Simon Zukas quit Wednesday saying he wanted to be "free" to air his views on the matter as a backbencher.

Zukas, who is of Lithuanian extraction, was not in the house during the walkout by the UNIP members.

Commerce and Trade Minister Dipka Patel, an Asian, was the first to resign over what he called his "irreconcilable differences" with cabinet colleagues over the constitution.

Chiluba's government has brought the constitutional debate to parliament in defiance of calls by the opposition and other sections of the society to submit it to a constituent assembly.

They argue this would ensure maximum national consensus on areas of disagreement.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


286 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Mugabe Rules Out OAU Action Against Nigeria


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 9, 1996


LENGTH: 520 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe ruled out the possibility of Nigeria's suspension from the Organization of African Unity (OAU) at its forthcoming summit in Cameroon, as punishment over human rights violations.

Addressing a press conference here Thursday, he said Nigeria, which is facing some tough measures from fellow Commonwealth member states, would not be punished by the group of African states.

"The spirit of brotherliness prevails even where wrongs are recogmised and taking measures against a brotherly state is not easy. 

"African states have a problem that we are not strong enough to criticize ourselves, so Nigeria will not be punished by OAU unless some sanctions become United Nations-imposed."

Nigeria was last year suspended from the Commonwealth, a group comprising Britain, its former colonies and an outsider, Mozambique, after the execution of nine minority human rights activists.

The Nigerian military regime, headed by Gen. Sani Abacha, was warned to put its house in order or face tougher measures from the Commonwealth.

The organization created a ministerial group to follow up the situation in Nigeria. However, last month, the Nigerian government refused to meet the group led by Zimbabwe's Foreign Minister Stan Mudenge.

The group held its meeting in April, in London, and decided to take further steps against Nigeria.

The measures included downgrading diplomatic relations between Nigeria and Commonwealth countries, imposing visa restrictions on members of the Nigerian military government, and a ban of air links with other club countries.

The OAU summit, scheduled for June, will be held in Cameroon, a Commonwealth nation. If the host nation adopts the above measures, Nigerian government leaders may not be able to attend the continental body's 32nd summit.

However, Mugabe told today's news conference that Zimbabwe would not take an individual stance against Nigeria, until discussions with other Southern African Development Community (SADC) countries, which are all members of the Commonwealth, were complete.

"We are looking at how our region will react to the recommendations made by the group. The SADC countries will get together and respond to the call for tougher measures against Nigeria," he said.

The measures are expected to be adopted by next month.

LANGUAGE: English
