Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Africa: Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 10, 1996 by Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 627 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - South Africa's new constitution, the withdrawal of the National Party (NP) from that country's government of national unity and the aborted Liberia summit were the main subjects of editorials in African newspapers this week.

The Sowetan, published in Johannesburg, said the adoption of the constitution by the South African parliament was hailed by all, "except the most cynical", as a historic landmark in the long struggle to transform South Africa into a true democracy.

Because it is a product of negotiation and compromise, the constitution is by definition a document that does not exclusively reflect the view of any one party. 

"From a party political point of view this may be far from ideal. But a constitution that is not based on the will of any one political party will be a good thing for the national building process," it said.

Another South African daily, Business Day, said that the mood surrounding the adoption of the constitution Wednesday was almost reminiscent of the surges of national unity last seen at the general election and presidential inauguration of 1994.

"Almost, but not quite," it said. "Acknowledgement of incipient problems has not been swept away in the euphoria this time -- and that is not a bad thing. The most important factor was the near-unanimous support for the document among participants.

"With the constitutional issues now resolved, the focus must turn to effective governance, particularly in the economic sphere. That is South Africa's real incipient crisis," concluded the daily.

Dakar's Sud Quotidien said the NP's publicly stated reasons for leaving -- to provide a real opposition to the African National Congress (ANC) -- "were far" from convincing.

"The truth is that since the death of apartheid, the National Party has found it difficult to make its mark within the context of an era of racial equality," it said.

It added: "The withdrawal seems to be motivated more by a desire to reconcile with a part of the white community than because of a deepening rift with the ANC."

Commenting before the poorly attended ECOWAS emergency summit on Liberia, the daily wondered whether this would the last meeting in trying to end the six-year factional war.

"Certain foreign ministers have not hidden their exasperation at the upsurge of violence in this country," it said.

Noting that Taylor was the "principal factor" for war in the country it said, "his absence at the meeting, and that of his ally, Alhaji Kromah, works against them."

"Hopefully", it added, "the same error will not be made in Liberia as was in Sierra Leone: to organize elections in the middle of a civil war. Here (in Liberia) the belligerents are more numerous, and seem to be more power hungry than their Sierra Leonean neighbors."

Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Police Fail to Produce Abiola In Court


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 10, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 480 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Police failed Friday to bring detained Nigerian politician Moshood Abiola, on trial for treasonable felony, before a judge who had ordered that he be brought to court to give testimony.

Justice Chris Senlong of the Abuja high court Wednesday ordered Nigeria's inspector-general of police to produce Abiola in court so that he can help to resolve a family controversy over the choice of his defence counsel.

But there was another twist to the legal battle after one of the two controversial defence lawyers, Rotimi Williams, announced he was in receipt of a motion for stay of execution on the court order directing the police to produce Abiola in court. 

The motion was issued by the solicitor general, Tobechukwu Onwugbufor, who said he wanted to appeal against the court order.

Williams, who is locked in a legal battle to wrest the defence of Abiola from the previous lead attorney, Gabriel Ajayi, protested that the motion was improperly served on him. He said it was only brought to his notice a few hours before the court sitting.

Williams described the motion as "frivolous, vexatious and shameless," saying at least, a 48-hour notice was needed.

The senior lawyer then asked for an adjourment.

Onwugbufor objected to Williams' comments, which he said amounted to dictating to the court.

Ruling on the motion, Justice Senlong agreed with the solicitor general that the motion was proper and adjourned the case until July 3.

Abiola's senior wife, Kudirat, told journalists she was disappointed that her husband was not brought to court.

She claimed she had not seen him for almost two years.

The millionaire-politician is the presumed winner of the June 1993 pesidential election, annulled by the last military regime.

He is facing trial for treason after declaring himself president of Nigeria in June 1994.

Kudirat, who is on bail from a Lagos court on two separate charges of conspiracy and false publication, is leading a splinter group in Abiola's family, that wants Ajayi to continue with the millionaire's defence.

But Abiola's senior son, Kola, says he prefers Williams.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Zimbabwe Memorial Service For Ron Brown in Harare


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 10, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's new finance minister, Herbert Murerwa, Friday said the late United States Commerce Secretary, Ron Brown, had a clear vision for the economic emancipation of the African continent.

Speaking at a memorial service organized in honour of Brown in Harare, Murerwa said the U.S. government official, who died in an air crash last month, was a man who had the unwavering desire to see the upliftment of African economies. 

"In Brown, we have lost a man who had a vision to see Africa, southern Africa in particular, becoming economically stable," he said.

The memorial service, organized by Zimbabwean businessmen, was attended by several diplomats, business leaders and U.S. citizens resident in Zimbabwe.

Among speakers at the service was the U.S. ambassador to Zimbabwe, Johnny Carson, and businessman, Strive Masiyiwa, a board member of the Southern African Enterprise Development Fund (SAEDF), which Brown helped to establish.

In his tribute, Carson urged those who had the opportunity to interact with Brown to ensure that his dream of an economically stable African continent was fulfilled.

"We have to ensure that the dream that Brown had does not die with his death," Carson said.

The late commerce secretary was instrumental in the establishment of the SAEDF, a one-billion-zimdollar (100 million U.S. dollars) credit facility funded by the United States government, to help small and medium-scale enterprises in the region.

He met several African leaders and business people during an investment tour of five African countries, including Zimbabwe, Feb. 17-25.

Brown and more than 30 other Americans died in an air crash in Croatia April 3, while on a business trip to countries of former Yugoslavia.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


290 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Zambian MP Walks Out Over Racial Remarks


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 10, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 680 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A Zambian member of parliament of Asian origin, Abdul Hamir, Friday walked out of parliament, complaining against racial remarks during the ongoing constitutional amendment bill debate in Lusaka.

Hamir is a member of the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD), which is seeking to change the constitution so that only Zambians whose both parents were born in the country could vie for the post of president.

He rose on a point of order to tell the house that he felt "hurt and uncomfortable" about the racial remarks. He then stormed out. 

"I am hurt and uncomfortable to come to the House because of the language of colour where we are seen to be different from other races," he said.

On Thursday, former Commerce and Trade Minister Dipak Patel, also of Asian origin, stormed out of parliament for similar reasons. Patel resigned earlier this year over fundamental differences with his colleagues in government on the issue of citizenship.

Two days ago, Works and Supply Minister Simon Zukas quit the cabinet, saying he wanted to be free of government discipline to speak his mind on the citizenship clause in the proposed constitution.

President Frederick Chiluba's government has proposed that only Zambian-born citizens, with their parents also born in the country, should hold the post of president.

The main opposition United National Independence Party, UNIP, Friday boycotted the constitutional debate for the third day running, to protest the government's refusal to withdraw the controversial bill.

Zukas and Patel were not in parliament when Hamir walked out Friday. Other notable absentees included Guy Scot, who has British origins and Yusuf Badat, who is of Asian extraction.

Badat was Thursday booed by fellow MMD parliamentarians when he tried to explain that the "indigenous" requirement for presidential candidates could create complications. He said that it was impossible to know who was a real patriot in Zambia.

Environment Minister William Harrington, who is of mixed race, told parliament Friday that the presidential clause needed amendment. He said the provision was discriminatory and would result in many Zambians being barred from standing for president.

Harrington said there was need to define who is an indigeneous Zambian.

"Unless the word indigenous is clearly defined, I will have nothing to do with the amendment of the bill," Harrington said.

He said if someone went back in history to 1500 and read about the Bantu migration, then only the Ila people of southern Zambia would qualify to be called indigenous.

"If the constitution bill is not amended, then only the Ilas will rule Zambia," Harrigton said.

The deputy minister for technical education and vocational training, Kangwa Nsuluka, suggested Friday that former president Kenneth Kaunda's citizenship be revoked because, he alleged, it was fraudulently conferred by the British former colonial government.

Kaunda, who had Malawian parents and is seeking to challenge Chiluba in this year's presidential elections, is generally believed to be the target of the proposed constitutional amendment.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


291 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Uganda Museveni Leads In Presidential Poll


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency May 10, 1996 by Moses Draku , PANA Correspondent


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Provisional results from Thursday's presidential elections in Uganda indicate that the incumbent, Yoweri Museveni, is leading the with 77.8 percent of the votes cast.

He polled 69,922 of the 86,569 votes and appears to have made a near clean sweep in western Uganda, his home area. 

However, his main rival, Paul Ssemwogerere, appears to have performed strongly in the northern districts of Gulu and in parts of West Nile and Kampala. He polled 16,097 votes or 19.3 percent of all ballots.

The third challenger, Muhammed Mayanja, got 2,392 votes, the equivalent of 2.9 percent of the votes.

Voting was peaceful in most parts of the country, even in the war-torn Gulu district, despite earlier predictions of violence and hooliganism. But there was a heavy army presence in the area.

Voter turnout in the capital, Kampala, was poor. The returning officer, Gordon Tumwesigye, put the turnout at an average of 50 percent.

Meanwhile, Museveni vowed to crush any uprising that may erupt in the wake of the elections.

"We have deployed security personnel massively, including militias, and we shall contain the situation in case of any uprising," he told journalists shortly after casting his vote in his country home in Nyabushozi, Mbarara district.

The winner is expected to be declared Saturday and the new president sworn-in Sunday.


LOAD-DATE: May 15, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa ANC Executive Committee Discusses Political Changes


BYLINE: African National Congress (ANC) May 13, 1996


LENGTH: 845 words


 

Cape Town - The ANC NEC (National Executive Committee) met in Cape Town on 11 and 12 May as part of its regular schedule of meetings.

The main issues that were discussed were an appraisal of the current political and economic situation, a review of the ANC's preparation for local government election in the Western Cape and KwaZulu Natal, and a discussion of the ANC's state of organisation. Reviewing the current political situation, the NEC congratulated ANC constitutional assembly members for their role in piloting through one of the most progressive constitutions in the world, a constitution that reflects the aspirations of the people of our country. 

The NEC agreed that the departure of the NP from cabinet marked a further step in normalising our democratic dispensation. The immediate reason for the departure are the strategic crisis that the NP confronts and serious internal division within it.

Nation building, reconciliation, reconstruction and development are realities which are broader than a constitutionally entrenched coalition and indeed the latter have often hampered the fuller realisation of these goals.

The ANC reasserts its commitment to the ongoing pursuits of these key tasks. The ANC NEC expects that all sections of the NP will commit themselves unambiguously to pursuing their political objectives within the framework of, and by upholding, our new constitution and respect for the country's laws.

On the current economic situation the NEC expressed its conviction that the fundamentals of our economy are sound and so too are government policy. We are convinced these are views shared by long term investors, both domestically and internationally.

The NEC expressed its support for all our ministers involved in economic affairs. The only sustainable path forward lies in the effective implementation of our growth and development path informed by the RDP vision.

The NEC expressed its support for the Truth and Reconciliation commission and congratulated it for the work it has done so far. The ANC reiterates its commitment to lend its fullest cooperation to the commission.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


293 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


BYLINE: South African Communications Service May 10, 1996


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Cape Town - Statement by President Nelson Mandela on the National Party's withdrawal from the Government of National Unity, May 9,1996.

Deputy-President FW de Klerk informed me earlier today that the National Party had decided to withdraw from the Government of National Unity.

As you are aware, the leadership of the National Party has emphasised that their withdrawal is not an expression of lack of confidence in our multi-party democracy, the rules of which are contained in the constitution which we together adopted yesterday. 

On the contrary, it reflects the fact that the National Party recognises that our young democracy has come of age, and would need a vigorous opposition unfettered by its participation in the Executive. We respect their judgement on this matter; as well as the party political considerations which precipitated their decision.

As I emphasised yesterday after the adoption of the new constitution, unity and reconciliation within our society depend not so much on enforced coalitions among parties. They are indelibly written in the hearts of the overwhelming majority of South Africa's people. This is a course that the government and the ANC have chosen to pursue in the interest of our country. It is a course that we will pursue with even more vigour in the coming months and years.
The policies that the Government of National Unity has been executing are premised on the needs and aspirations of all the country's people. This applies to all areas of endeavour, underpinned by the Reconstruction and Development Programme, to improve the quality of life of the people through sound economic policies of fiscal rectitude and other measures to promote growth and development.

These policies will not change. Instead they will be promoted with even more focus.

Though the imperative of Government of National Unity was written into the interim constitution, the onus was on parties which attained more then 10% of the vote in April 1994, voluntarily to decide whether or not to take positions in cabinet.

As the majority party, the ANC welcomed the fact that the NP and IFP decided to take part in the Executive, especially in the early days of our delicate transition.

I wish to thank Deputy President FW de Klerk and his colleagues for the constructive role that they have played. I am confident that we shall continue to work together in pursuit of the country's interests, and that their withdrawal will have the effect of strengthening, rather than weakening, their commitment to the country's political, security and economic interests.

Indeed, we are firmly of the view that the National Party has a continuing responsibility to contribute to the process of eradicating the legacy of apartheid which they created. As such, we hope that their decision to play a more active role as an opposition party, does not mean obstructing the process of transformation or defending apartheid privilege.

In this regard, I also wish to reassure all South Africans that the course that we have undertaken as a nation is bigger than any party or individual.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


294 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Western Sahara (DOCUMENT) Boutros Ghali Says Cooperation Lacking on Referendum


BYLINE: United Nations May 10, 1996


LENGTH: 494 words


 

United Nations - During the daily briefing on May 9, Sylvana Foa, spokesman for Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, said the Secretary-General's report on Western Sahara had gone to the Security Council.

In his last report to the Council, he said he hoped the identification process could resume without delay. Unfortunately, as a result of the positions of the parties, all efforts to resume that process had failed. "In fact, we have identified now 60,000 persons, but there are 156,924 applicants remaining to be identified." 

She said that, in his report, the Secretary-General concluded that the willingness did not exist to give MINURSO (United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara) the cooperation needed for it to resume and complete the identification process within a reasonable period of time. It was stalemated, and he was recommending that the process be suspended until such time as the parties provided convincing evidence that they were fully committed to resuming it without further obstacles.

"This means that remaining members of the identification commission will leave the area at the end of May this year", she said, "with the exception of a few who will stay behind to close up shop and get their records all together".

The civilian police component would also be withdrawn except for a very small number which would be kept to maintain contact with both sides. On the military side, the maintenance of the cease-fire had been a major achievement for MINURSO and, therefore, the Secretary-General was recommending that the presence be considered still essential.
The Secretary-General was, however, proposing that it be reduced by 20 per cent from 288 to 230 military personnel. At the end of the day, said the Secretary-General, the United Nations could not abandon its responsibility to seek a political settlement. He was proposing to maintain a political office headed by his acting representative, and also a liaison office. The offices would maintain a dialogue with the parties and the two neighbouring countries, Ms. Foa continued.

He concluded his report by stating that, "although the conditions don't exist today to achieve the settlement plan, we mustn't let all our efforts go to waste, and we must build on the achievements we have made so far -- the identification of 60,000 people, the maintenance of the cease-fire. He is asking for a six-month extension of MINURSO's mandate".


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


295 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Shell Statement on Ogoni Clean Up


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 10, 1996


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Washington, DC - Following is a statement issued by the Shell Oil Company subsidiary in Nigeria on Wednesday, May 8, 1996:

The Shell Petroleum Development Company of Nigeria Ltd (SPDC) offered today a plan for action in Ogoniland if agreement is reached with all Ogoni communities that company staff can return to the area in safety.

The first priority will be to clean up all oil spills -- whether or not due to sabotage -- that have happened since the company withdrew staff in 1993, and make safe all facilities.

At the same time SPDC will begin to rehabilitate its past community projects where necessary and take over their maintenance to ensure they remain in good condition. 

It will also investigate with communities the need for further development projects in the area, such as a youth training scheme and healthcare in line with the company's community assistance programme throughout its area of operations.

Brian Anderson, Managing Director of SPDC, said: "These proposals are offered in the spirit of reconciliation. All we need to start the process is the assurance of all Ogoni communities that our staff can work safely in Ogoniland."

The priority is to tackle those problems facing the Ogoni people where SPDC can help, rather than to restart production. When SPDC withdrew from Ogoniland, production from the area was some 28,000 barrels a day which represented about three percent of SPDC's total production.

Mr Anderson said: "The Ogoni dispute has been characterised by a continuing circle of accusations and recriminations, and we want to help break that circle. Making impossible demands on Shell or ignoring the grievances of the Ogonis is not the answer. We need to find solutions."

SPDC's plan of action would happen only following full discussion and the formal agreement of all factions and communities in Ogoniland and the Rivers State Government. Mr Anderson said: "These proposals demonstrate our commitment to reconciliation. This is what we would like to do, but we cannot do it alone and we offer these proposals for discussion with Ogoni communities and the State Government.

"We would not wish any actions on our part -- however well intentioned -- to be the cause of any strife between the Ogoni people. It is vital that we have the support of the communities in which we work. That is why we are adamant that we will not work behind a security shield, and why we have made it quite clear we will not go back until we are welcomed by all Ogoni people."

Mr Anderson said that SPDC has a continuing concern about the situation in Ogoniland. "This is why we have continued to provide humanitarian aid since we withdrew. We have also continued to make scholarships available to Ogoni students, and to fund the Bori farm in Ogoni which supplies much needed crop materials to Ogoni farmers free of charge."

SPDC believes the first step must be agreement among Ogonis to settle their own differences and agree a common future. Shell will continue to talk to all those people, both inside and outside Nigeria, who have a concern and interest in encouraging new initiatives which may lead to a way forward.

"The priority must be to start down the road to reconciliation, and ensure that Ogoniland becomes a safe place to live and work again for both the Ogoni people, Shell and everyone else," said Mr Anderson.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

May, 1996


Zambia Faulty Machines Creates Coca-Cola Shortage in Zambia


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 9, 1996 by Elias Kamanga


LENGTH: 187 words


 
Lusaka - Production of Coca cola at the Copperbelt Bottling company in Kitwe has come to a halt due to faulty machines.

There has been no official explanation from the company over the shortage of Coca cola, but sources revealed that production came to a standstill on Thursday last week. 

Sources at the company said the machines had not been serviced for a long time, causing them to wear out fast.

"Production has been off since Thursday last week due to faulty machines. I think its time management looked at the machines," said a machine operator at the company.

Management could not respond to a Post query on the matter.

The low production has however boosted business for Cadbury Schweppes' Crush and Sport Cola which have filled most of the retail outlets.

297 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Youth Launch Tree Planting


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 9, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 547 words


 
Lusaka - The Danish funded Petauke Youth Skills Training Centre(PAMO) has launched an ambitious tree planting programme in a bid to fight the environmental problems related to deforestation and to ensure a steady supply of timber for its future production.

Being the pioneer youth furniture-factory in the country, the centre in partnership with the Forestry Department in Petauke, the area's Chief Nyamphande, and the Danish Association for International Co-operation(DAICO) have since planted between 4,000 to 5,000 trees covering about four hectares of land from late last year when the tree planting project was initiated.

The centre's production mananger, Crispin Chirwa, felt there was need to seriously address the problem of deforestation. 

"We can see how deforestation is gradually becoming a big problem. When I came to Petauke in 1978 there was forest everywhere, now the area is all bare," Chirwa observed adding: "If this tendency continues we will face serious problems like soil erosion within a few years and being a consumer of timber, PAMO has a responsibility for the deforestation and can't run away from it."

Chirwa disclosed that it was up to organisations like his (users of timber) to start planting new trees if the forests were to be maintained.

A new plantation covering a total area of 10-20 hectares of land is expected to be planted at an estimated cost of K10 million under the funding of the Danish government in a bid to replenish the depleting forestry plantations around Petauke.

Among the trees that are being planted are the much sought after local hardwoods, Mukwa and Melina whose numbers in the forests are rapidly decreasing.

Also commenting on the development, district forest officer, Duetronomy Kasaro feared that with the current high consumption of the hardwoods without replanting had put a risk of extinction.

"Mukwa is a threatened specie. With the present cutting rate there will be no Mukwa left for commercial use in this area in the next five years, " Kasaro said.

On that background, PAMO has decided to plant a high percentage of indegenous trees.

According to a press statement from the DAICO, it will take 60 years before the newly planted Mukwa can start being used but already after 10 years, fast growing trees like melina can be used for furniture production.

A steady supply of timber will be provided after a 20 year period.

PAMO was set up in 1982 to help train youths in carpentry, tailors and bricklayers.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


298 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Opposition Walks Out of Parliament


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 9, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba and Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Lusaka - National Party leader Akashambatwa Mbikusita Lewanika remained in his seat as the majority of the opposition UNIP walked out of parliament yesterday saying he must put it on record that there was objection to MMD's impudence.

UNIP walked out of parliament in protest against the government's decision to adopt the Constitution of Zambia (Amendment) Bill without establishing consensus on it.

The moves follows failure of the inter-party talks on Monday which had hoped to work out a last minute compromise over the hugely criticised document. MMD led by President Chiluba then walked out of the talks after failing to agree on who would chair the meeting. 

Kasenengwa UNIP member of parliament Patrick Mvunga who led the walkout from the House yesterday morning said the real issue was the method of adoption of the constitution and not the citizenship of the president or the length of the term of office.

"UNIP's position is that the constitution should be adopted by a constituent assembly," Mvunga said. "We fully adopt what the citizen's convention said which is that the constitution should be adopted through a constituent assembly."

He regretted that MMD seemed to have made up its mind about what they wanted to do making it a waste of time to debate the bill.

"We want to exercise our democratic right to dissent, we won't participate in the process of enactment," he said.

Mvunga complained that MMD had closed its doors to dialogue but he was challenged by Vice-president Godfrey Miyanda who said it was not true because the government had conceded to demands of the judiciary and was ready to listen some more.

Miyanda further said he had written to Mvunga and UNIP member of parliament for Petauke Lavu Mulimba in addition to National Party president Humphrey Mulemba for them to indicate specific areas needing discussion but they had not responded to the invitation.

"We are ready to listen at all stages of the bill if you seriously want to debate we are ready to listen but if you want to walk out you are free," he said.

Mvunga insisted that the opposition had not been invited for dialogue and would therefore not take part in the enactment of the bill.

Mulimba said in an interview yesterday that from the way MMD members of parliament have been debating, it showed they were not ready to compromise but he hinted that UNIP could return if the ruling party showed it could be flexible.

"Changes are made at the committee stage, we will be watching closely what happens there," he said.

Chadiza UNIP member of parliament Panji Kaunda shared the same view.

National Party secretary general Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika however said he sympathised with UNIP for the action they had taken saying: "they are definitely entitled to it, it is understandable."

However, he said the National Party would not follow the UNIP example because this was the end of the world.

"MMD has made other attempts to bulldoze parliament and they have failed despite their numbers," he said. "We will continue to put pressure and continue the struggle. Principally we must put it on record that we objected and we shall speak to the full."

He said the amendments in the bill were designed to meet MMD's immediate need of winning the forthcoming elections and were likely to be changed by another government once in power.

"I hope we won't have to wait long to have a genuinely democratic government concerned about democracy than party politics," he said.

Zambia Democratic Congress vice-president Kasuka Mutukwa said in an interview that he sympathised with UNIP for the action they had taken but he regretted that MMD was not ready to listen to reason.

"The MMD leadership has reached a stage where consensus is not important," he said. "To them might is right and they are legislating the constitution against the cries of the majority."

Foundation for Democratic Process(FODEP) secretary Bishop John Mambo described the walk out as a "sad development"

LANGUAGE: English

May, 1996


Zambia Over Two Million Registered


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency (Lusaka) May 8, 1996 by


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - About 2.3 million people registered as voters during the registration exercise which took place between January and March this year.

The Elections Office revealed this in Lusaka today when it said 2,305,453 people registered as voters out of an estimated population of eight million people, most of whom were elligible to register as voters. 

The number shows a decline of 20.8 percent from the 2,914,441 who are on the current register and it is still lower by 14.5 percent from the 1987 figure of 2,697,047 registered voters.

The Copperbelt had about 412,414 people who registered as voters, seconded by Eastern Province with 308,195, Southern had 307,749 registered voters, Lusaka 304,545 while Northern Province had 247,120.

Western Province had 212,380 registered voters, Central Province had 194,042 and Luapula being the least with only 177,759 people who registered as voters.

May, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia Turns Down Uganda Invitation


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 9, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia has turned down an invitation to play Uganda in an international friendly match in Kampala enroute to the World Cup qualifer against Sudan next month because of security reasons and a tight programme.

According to Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) general secretary, Hermann Mpashi, Uganda has offered to host Zambia in a two-match series but FAZ has informed the East Africans that it will not send the national team there because of the rebel war in that country and southern part of Sudan. 

"We were offered to play Uganda but we have requested that it will not be possible for us to send the team because the programme will be tight around that time, and also we felt it would be risk to send the team to war-like conditions before such a big match like the world cup," said Mpashi, who explained that Uganda may be called instead because it would also cost FAZ a lot to fly the team to Uganda and back to Kenya to connect to Sudan.

Uganda is engulfed in rebel-war fighting with some sections of its citizens opposed to the government, and also it harbours Southern Sudan freedom fighters rocked in a decades old war with the Islamic government of Sudan.

Zambia Students March To Protest Constitution


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency (Lusaka) May 9, 1996 by


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - University of Zambia students are today set to march to parliament to demonstrate against government's decision to proceed with the adoption and enactment of the constitution without establishing popular consensus.

The decision was reached at a crisis general meeting addressed by UNZASU President Emmanuel Tembo last night. 

There was near confusion at the university as a small pro MMD group opposed to the UNZASU action openly campaigned against their move.From Page One

Tembo had to lead his team to force some undecided students to attend the meeting after forcibly locking up the university library.

The meeting later proceeded and the students unanimously resolved to protest against government action and urge it to withdraw the controversial constitutional bill from parliament.

302 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Draft of Voters' Role To Be Ready in July


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency (Lusaka) May 9, 1996 by


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Lusaka - The first draft of the long awaited new voters register, which is being prepared by the Israeli company, Nikuv Computers, should be ready for inspection by the end of July.

Briefing members of the press, who this morning toured the company's offices at Mulungushi International Conference Centre to familiarise themselves with progress on the exercise, Project Manager, Gershom Korda, said the first phase of the project was completed yesterday and that both the draft voters roll and voters cards should be ready by the end of July.

He said that the company had finished the most difficult part of the data processing which was that of capturing details and feeding them in the computers. 

For now the company has safely stored details of all registered voters throughout the country in an exercise which was started last January and had to be postponed several times due to poor responce from potential voters.

At the height of operations Nikuv had employed 270 persons on an equal number of computers who fed details into computers from documents submitted by the Elections Office, who handled the initial phase of the data capturing process.

At the close of business yesterday, however, the number of workers had to be reduced from 270 to 17 and that it will further be reduced to about five once all major works have been dealt with.

Mr. Korda ruled out the possibility of his company conniving with the ruling Movement for Multi-Party Democracy to come up with register which will allow for the rigging of both presidential and parliamentary elections.

He said sentiments by some opposition politicians that the company would also do a shoddy job were unfounded adding that all throughout the process of collecting and storing data the company had maintained maximum vigilance reinforced by a 24-hour security cordon placed on the operational centre by Zambia Police.

Mr. Korda showed press persons the entire process from the 'receiving bay' where duplicates and bound copies of voters' registration forms were being delivered to the company by the Elections Office under police guard up to the computers where data stored had to be entered twice in order to eliminate negligent mistakes.

Mr. Korda insisted that arrangements put in place did not allow for rigging adding that this could only be engineered at source, which so far has is unlikely since nobody has cast aspersions at the Elections Office, which has done its job most diligently and impartially.

Afterwards Mr.. Korda showed reporters a sample of the cards which will be given to registered voters for use in the coming elections.

He also explained that contrarily to earlier reports the cards will not be made in Israel but in Lusaka to further lessen suspicions of rigging.

Apart from press persons the company has extended invitations to all sections of the community including leaders of opposition parties, the Church Non-Governmental Organisations and Diplomats accredited to Zambia.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia UNIP Walks Out Over Constitution


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency (Lusaka) May 9, 1996


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - United National Independence Party members in parliament today walked out of the House again - the second time in two days - over the Constitutional Amendment Bill.

The members were lead by Kasenengwa Member of Parliament, Professor Patrick Mvunga, immediately the House was about to resume debating the Constitutional Amendment Bill. 

The members had earlier in the day attended and participated in deliberations based on a question and answer session before they finally walked out of the House leaving only National Party secretary, Mr. Akashabatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika on opposition seats.

Yesterday, UNIP members again walked out and said they were not ready to participate in the enactment of the bill when a consensus on the mode of adopting it has not been reached.

They said UNIP will only take part once invited to an inter-party meeting at which the mode of adopting the constitution will be reached.

And contributing to the debate on the bill Mr. Mbikusita-Lewanika regretted that it was like the house was debating on one particular person he did not name.

Mr. Mbikusita-Lewanika also said, in a three hour contribution, that a comfortable national concession has not been achieved on the mode of adopting the constitution.

He noted that submissions to the Mwanakatwe Constitutional Review Commision had proposed that the draft constitution be adopted by a constituent assembly and that government should follow the people's wish over the matter.

The MP said government has the responsibility to take instructions from the people who voted for them.

He said Zambians should have reached an agreement on the process of the constitution adding a national concessus has not been adequately provided on the matter.

May, 1996


Zambia Indaba On With or Without Ruling MMD


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 10, 1996 by Mervin Syafunko


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - National Party and Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) yesterday committed themselves to attending Monday's inter- party meeting with, or without, the ruling MMD.

NP vice-president, Daniel Lisulo, said the aim of the meeting would be to reach an agreement in the interest of the people. 

"We are going ahead with the meeting with or without the MMD," Lisulo said in an interview yesterday. " If the MMD will not attend we shall then know as opposition parties what move to take next but we don't want any crisis."

And ZDC deputy general secretary, Azwell Banda, said there was no peaceful for dialogue and negotiation and it was a pity the MMD leadership does not recognise and appreciate this fact.

"We as opposition parties have agreed to meet on Monday so we can know what to do next but the government must realise it is important that the key stake holder political parties meet because dialogue and and negotiations are the only peaceful solutions to everything," Banda said in an interview yesterday. "There is no substitute."

But MMD national chairman, Sikota Wina, on Tuesday maintained that his party would not bother to attend the meeting because of the issue of neutral chairman.

But Banda charged that people of Wina's likes had political back ground which knew no peaceful and productive negotiations.

"He is talking like that because of his political background which is void of moral and no sufficient integrity," Banda charged. " All he would like is to satisfy his ego and doesn't qualify to be on leadership levels."


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

305 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Maize surplus for Zambia, Zimbabwe and South Africa


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 10, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia is among the three nations in the Southern African region expecting a good grain harvest this season.

A senior economist at Southern African Development Community's (SADC) early warning unit, Phumzile Mdladla, disclosed in an interview yesterday that among the eleven country's of the Southern African region, only three countries would record good harvests.

"Despite the good rains this season most countries are anticipating deficits in their grain harvest except for only three countries namely Zambia, South Africa and Zimbabwe which expect to record surpluses," Mdladla said in an interview at the on-going grain marketing workshop. 

Mdladla, however, assured that the surpluses in these three countries would adequately cover the deficiencies that will be experienced by the other countries.

" A total surplus of 3.14 million tonnes will be recorded against the collective deficit of 1.29 million tonnes of white maize," Mdladla said.

According to information from the regional centre, South Africa expects the largest harvest with a surplus of 2.950 million tonnes followed by 255,000 tonnes by Zambia and lastly Zimbabwe's 207,000 tonnes.

For Zimbabwe, it is not known if the surplus would be open for exports as its policy is to have a total of over 900,000 tonnes in its strategic reserves, making the anticipated surplus far below the required grain.

Mdladla disclosed that despite receiving good rains, Malawi had recorded a deficit following high costs of fertiliser and farming inputs which most of its farmers found difficult to acquire.

And representing the private trade sector, Grain Growers and Marketing Association chairman, George Lloyd attributed the anticipated 'bumper' harvest to good rains and increased planting by farmers.

And Cargil South Africa has shown interest in sourcing maize from Zambia .

Commenting on Zambia's harvest in relation to the Larger Grain Borer invasion, managing director of Cargil South Africa Limited, Thad Goff, felt this would have little impact on his company's intentions to source grain from the country.

"We are aware of the LGB but we feel that this will not have any problem with our intentions to source maize grain from Zambia," he said. " We have better contacts with the international markets and we'll look for the best market for Zambia's maize."


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


306 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia President Warned Not to Pick Fights


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 10, 1996 by Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba has been advised that his decision to fight everyone who questioned the political practices of his regime would soon boomerang.

Speaking in an interview yesterday opposition Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) deputy general secretary Azwell Banda warned President Chiluba of the consequences of alienating himself, his government and the country from the rest of the world by picking up fights with the international community including, most recently, her neighbours.

Banda was reacting to recent announcements by the government that it was now bitter with Botswana President and head of the Frontline States, Quet Masire, for proposing to dialogue with Zambia over her current political situation.

And former president Kenneth Kaunda, himself twice leader of the Frontline States, yesterday defended President Masire's initiative but denied he had any influence in it as claimed by President Chiluba's government. 

"We feel very embarrassed about the damage government is doing to this country. You cannot go punching everyone from Western donors to your own neighbours in the region," Banda said. "We will soon find ourselves totally isolated.

Banda said the government has insulted and picked at almost every key Western donor souring relations unnecessarily and regretted that this has now extended to respectable neighbours like President Masire and and South African president Nelson Mandela.

"Masire is a Frontline heads of state chairman. There is an issue of regional stability here," Banda said. "What happens politically in Zambia has an impact on the stability of the region."

He said ZDC's position was that the government should welcome international initiative and broaden its perception of local problems.

MMD national chairman Sikota Wina announced on a live radio programme this week that President Chiluba had taken offence at the letter from the Front Line leader, President Masire.

"President Chiluba has rejected the meeting proposal because there are more problems in other countries than Zambia," Wina said. "There is no crisis in Zambia."

MMD suspects that President Masire is working at the instigation of the opposition UNIP led by former President Kenneth Kaunda whom President Chiluba is trying to block from contesting the Zambian presidency through the introduction of restrictive constitutional provisions.

And Botswana acting High Commissioner to Zambia, Clement Mphusu, said he would react after liaising with the government officials in Gaborone but doubted President Masire would have any ill motive in seeking dialogue with Zambia.

"I do not even know if President Masire really wrote that letter which I too only heard being refered to on radio and television," Mphusu said in an interview last night. "Our President has been involved in many regional initiatives but I do not know if he would want to initiate such a move in bad faith."

But former President Kaunda said President Masire was in order and it was unlikely the initiative was his alone.

"When a member state is seen to be headed for trouble it is the duty of the Frontline States to talk with the member and advise," President Kaunda said. "This is normally done only after consultation with the other members."

He denied he had anything to do with the initiative.

"They are barking a wrong tree, " President Kaunda said.

But President Chiluba yesterday maintained Zambia is not in a crisis and insisted everything was under control.

Speaking to two foreign journalists based in Harare at State House, President Chiluba yesterday said the situation in the country was normal and that if there had been a crisis, he would have appealed for international assistance.

"I wish to say that there is no crisis in Zambia, if the situation were so, I would have appealed for international help," President Chiluba said.

He revealed that there had been some unfavourable sentiments expressed by the donor community on the manner the Constitution was being handled but he defended his the government's stand on the matter.

"Constitutional matters should be left to the citizens to decide for themselves," President Chiluba said. "Whether or not we go wrong or right is our business."

Threats of civil strife have been sounded over President Chiluba's stand on adopting the constitution without reaching consensus and the handling of the voters roll.

There have been physical and violent inter-party clashes which have left some people wounded while coercive arms of the government have been involved in various acts of human rights violations.

General good governance principles have been of worry both locally and abroad.

The government has lately been on a war path with diplomats from Germany, Norway and most recently British High Commissioner for commenting on such issues.

The government sponsored negative press reports, in the state owned and controlled newspapers, attacking diplomats who the authorities believe are opposed the government's political practices.

The government has also declared it could do without Western donors if they will not shut up on the way it handles local issues.

Foundation for democratic Process Secretary Bishop John Mambo said external concern is coming from events at home.

"The outside is reacting because of the worrying heat that is here. It really looks like trouble would erupt," Bishop Mambo said in an interview yesterday. "That is why we are insisting locally that all parties involved should dialogue."

And early last year the government, through the Inspector General of Police, had accused some unnamed neighbouring country of training opposition insurgents to come and topple the government of President Chiluba.

And the fears of civil strife have been expressed by the church, NGOs, trade unions, and opposition politicians.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa State Department Decries Nigeria-Cameroon Clash


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 10, 1996


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Washington, DC - "The United States deplores the resumption of fighting
in the border region between Cameroon and Nigeria," the U.S. State
Department announced May 10. Following is the text of a statement by spokesman Nicholas Burns, as prepared for delivery:

The United States deplores the resumption of fighting in the border region between Cameroon and Nigeria, and calls for an immediate cessation to the hostilities. 

We urge both sides to resolve territorial claims by peaceful means, through negotiations or dispute resolution mechanisms. In this particular case, both sides should continue to seek resolution through the international Court of Justice (ICJ).

The United States also urges both sides to accept the immediate dispatch to the region of a U.N. or other mutually acceptable fact-finding mission to investigate the situation.

Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa U.S. Urges Angolans to Move More Quickly on Peace


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 13, 1996


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Washington, DC - The following is the text of remarks on May 8 by U.S. Ambassador Karl Inderfurth during the debate in the United Nations Security Council, which voted unanimously to extend the mandate of the UN Angola Verification Mission (UNAVEM) for two months:
Mr. President, throughout the peace process, the United States has fulfilled its commitment to be Angola's partner for peace. We have steadfastly condemned all violations of the Lusaka Protocol, and insisted that both sides honor their commitments in a comprehensive and transparent fashion. We have also acknowledged actions, taken by either side, that advance the cause of peace and national reconciliation. This course of action, we believe, increases the credibility of the Lusaka process in the eyes of the parties, the Angolan people, and the international community. 

In this spirit, we must criticize delays in quartering yet at the same time welcome recent progress in the process of quartering UNITA troops. As of May 6, more than 30,000 UNITA soldiers had officially registered, with the total expected to rise to 35,000 by the end of this week, which would represent more than half of UNITA's declared troops levels. The last-minute movements of thousands of troops to quartering areas in the final days before the renewal of UNAVEM's mandate is typical of UNITA's pattern of lurching forward in fits and starts towards its goals. This pattern does not help cement faith in UNITA's overall commitment to the peace process. It is essential that UNITA continue the quartering process without further delay or interruption. Unless real soldiers bearing real weapons are quartered, the peace process will not move forward. It is also essential that the Angolan government complete its obligations to pull back its forces and barrack the anti-riot police, under UNAVEM's supervision, without delay or subterfuge.

Both sides must work together to finalize arrangements for military integration, including reaching agreement on the eighteen UNITA generals who are to be a part of the joint military command. The deadline for their completion is now May 15 -- far beyond the date initially forecast for the conclusion of the military talks. The delay has meant that some of the UNITA troops have now been in quartering areas for several months. They are eager to be either demobilized or integrated into the joint army. Both sides must work together to ensure that UNITA personnel move quickly out of the temporary quartering areas.

This resolution reflects the Security Council's continuing impatience with the overall slow pace of the implementation of the Lusaka Protocol. We expect the parties to live up to the agreements they reached in Libreville, and to the May Calendar of Actions they freely adopted. During the next two months we expect to see the formation of a joint military command and the commencement of the integration of UNITA forces into the Armed Forces of Angola, the essential foundation for the Government of National Reconciliation.

During the next two months we also expect to see the two parties take decisive action on one of the most urgent problems facing Angola -- the threat posed by landmines. The United Nations estimates that there are between nine and fifteen million landmines in Angola. It estimates that eight million Angolans, of a total population of just under thirteen million, live in mine-infested areas of the country. Exact numbers of mine casualties in Angola are impossible to obtain, but current estimates of amputees range from 40,000 to 70,000, with an additional 70,000 killed by landmines.

Mr. President, the suffering of Angolans as a result of this plague of landmines will not end with the coming of peace. These hidden killers will continue to haunt Angola for years to come, adding to the number of casualties every week, destroying lives, hopes and dreams, and slowing economic recovery. It is for that reason that the Council, in its Presidential Statement of April 24, 1996, and today's resolution, has called for the Government and UNITA to destroy their stockpiles of landmines and to begin this process by a joint public action to underscore the commitment of both parties to get rid of these horrific weapons.

We are hopeful that such an action -- in the form of a joint public ceremony involving Government and UNITA officials -- could be scheduled in the near future. We would also like to acknowledge the step taken yesterday by the government in which 300 landmines held in the central military zone were destroyed.

We wish to commend the Secretary-General's Special Representative, Maitre Beye, the Force Commander of UNAVEM and all the personnel of UNAVEM III for their dedicated and courageous service in the cause of peace. We also wish to acknowledge the generosity of the troop contributing countries, eight of which are members of this Council.

Mr. President, in closing, the U.S. wishes to remind the parties, once again, of the urgent need to take advantage of this window of opportunity to bring peace, reconciliation and recovery to their country. The Angolan people have suffered enough.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


309 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Angola Unita Calls UN Report 'Misleading'


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 13, 1996


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Washington, DC - The following statement was issued by the Free Angola Information Service, which is registered with the Justice Department as an agent of the Angolan opposition movement Unita:

Jardo Muekalia, the UNITA representative in Washington, expressed concern that the United Nations Secretary General's April 30 report on the United Nations Verification Mission (UNAVEM III) provides an incomplete and misleading picture of the complex Angolan reality. He said, "The Secretary General's report does not reflect the latest developments on the ground, and its unbalanced approach encourages hard-liners who are still committed to a military solution. Its central flaw is that it reduces the peace process to the quartering of UNITA soldiers and ignores or glosses over the Government's obligations. In addition, it fails to address critical issues like the continued presence of mercenaries in the Government ranks or the failure of the Government to withdraw its troops back to the barracks in Benguela, Cuanza Sul and Huambo provinces where more than 24,000 UNITA soldiers have reported to UN supervised quartering areas and disarmed." 

Muekalia pointed out, "On the contrary, the Government has concentrated troops and mat6riel in strategic areas which threaten the quartering areas without an adequate response by UNAVEM. This creates a psychology of fear and has slowed down the quartering process."

The UNITA Representative expressed pride that UNITA had carried out its commitment to Special Representative Alioune Blondin Beye and President Clinton's Special Envoy, Paul Hare, by quartering 30,000 soldiers by May 8. In fact, 31,443 soldiers, more than half of its troop strength, was registered and disarmed in quartering areas by today, May 6. This contrasts with the failure of the Government to initiate the collection of more than 700,000 illegal military weapons in civilian hands in Luanda or to send even 20 percent of the Rapid Intervention Police to the barracks.

Jardo Muekalia said that the Government was dragging its feet in passing an amnesty law that covers the entire period of the war, back to 1975. "This is easy and can be accomplished with the stroke of a pen. Failure to expeditiously pass a comprehensive amnesty law gives rise to suspicions in UNITA that the Government wants to try UNITA military officials for war crimes as it has threatened so many times in the past."

The UNITA Representative concluded, "President Savimbi and the entire UNITA leadership are committed to the full implementation of the Lusaka Protocol as the key to a durable peace and genuine reconciliation in our country. A balanced, judicious approach is needed. Playing the blaming game is counterproductive. The Government, UNITA and UNAVEM must all expeditiously fulfill their obligations. The peace process must be seen as a set of reciprocal obligations."

For further information, contact: 202-775-0958 Free Angola Information Service, PO Box 65463, Washington, D.C. 20035-5463. Tel: (202) 775-0958.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Business and Finance French Business Group Tours Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 10, 1996


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Addis Ababa - French businessmen who are on a working tour here, yesterday expressed keen interest to invest in Ethiopia in the fields of water, irrigation, trade, electricity, and air transport services. 

During talks with members of the Addis Ababa Chamber of Commerce, the French trade mission exchanged information that would enable it open up new vistas of co-operation with its Ethiopian counterpart.

The trade mission, which comprises owners of big French companies and firms, expressed willingness to actively engage itself in exchanging factory spare parts and commercial products.

The four-men trade mission arrived here Wednesday to explore possible investment co-operation with Ethiopian businessmen, leader of the mission told ENA.

May, 1996


United States and Africa Ethiopia's Meles Meets U.S. Trade Mission


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 10, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Addis Ababa - Prime Minister Meles Zenawi yesterday received and held talks in his office with the visiting American trade mission on the situation in Ethiopia and Ethio-US relations.

The prime minister briefed the American delegation on the policies mapped out and measures being taken by his government with the aim of bringing about rapid economic development in the country. 

There are plenty of investment opportunities for American investors, Ato Meles told the mission, adding the current visit of the delegation would further consolidate the existing ties and co-operation between Ethiopia and the United States.

He said the structural adjustment programmes carried out so far have registered commendable results in speeding up economic development.

Members of the delegation said their visit to Ethiopia has enabled them to identify fields of American investment and opened a window of opportunity for knowing the country better than ever before.

The visit, they said, will also help consolidate bilateral relations and co-operation between the two countries.

Ethiopian members of the delegation said Ethiopians residing in the U.S. were desirous of coming to their country and investing in various devevelopment sectors.

The objective reality in Ethiopia is entirely different from what they hear in the U.S, they said.

The positive development trends in this country should clearly be explained to Ethiopians in the U.S. with a particular emphasis on those in Washington D.C.

The trade mission is comprising members from the agricultural, industrial, mineral, transport, finance, insurance and communications sectors of the country.
