Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Commission Puts Down Reconciliation Roots


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 10, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Johannesburg - The lesson from this week's truth commission hearings in Durban is that the effects of the organisation's work can never be easily predicted.

Instead of hearing evidence from mainly ANC- aligned victims -- as was widely expected because of an Inkatha boycott -- the commission ended up strengthening its non-partisan image and its prospects of helping to reconcile divided parties in the war-torn province.

Three important happenings caused this sudden turnabout for the fortunes of the process of truth and reconciliation in KwaZulu-Natal: Magoo Bar bomb victims' demands for ANC-bomber Robert McBride's government post to be withdrawn; requests from Stompie Seipai's mother that Winnie Mandela's role in the murder of her son be more fully investigated; and a dramatic decision by the Inkatha Freedom Party to take part in some of the commission's hearings.

Commission chairman Archbishop Desmond Tutu hinted strongly at a press conference on Wednesday night that perpetrators of human rights violations should not be rewarded. "We would obviously want to be as consistent as possible with that objective" he said. "We want to promote a culture of human rights which shows respect for victims and does not add to their pain." 

Tutu was responding to requests from relatives of Marchelle Gerrard, one of the three people killed in the 1986 bomb attack on the Magoo's Bar in Durban, for McBride to removed from public office. "The fact that we are contributing to his upkeep (as taxpayers) is inconceivable," was the way one of Gerrard's sisters, Sharon Welgemoed, approached the commission this week.

Tutu also indicated the commission would adopt a tough line of inquiry in the case of Stompie Seipai, a young ANC activist from Tumahole in the Free State who was killed by members of Winnie Mandela's bodyguard brigade in the 1980s.

Responding to questions about whether the commission's investigative unit would probe Winnie Mandela's apparent role in the murder, Tutu said: "There is no reason why we are not going to look into this with the most rigorous concern ... If we need to subpoena the president we will subpoena the president. No one is above the particular laws the commission has been set up under."

Then Ziba Jiyane, general secretary of the Inkatha Freedom Party, seemed to underscore a realisation that the truth commission wasn't simply going to dwell on cases in which people involved in the ANC's struggle against apartheid suffered persecution. He announced this week that the IFP would make use of the commission's ability to recommend compensation for victims of human rights abuse and to grant amnesty to IFP members already convicted of political crimes.

Jiyane told the Mail & Guardian, however, that Inkatha would not appear at public hearings of the commission to defend its position because the truth body had "been set up without the consensus of all parties".

Tutu welcomed the move but responded by saying it was not possible for any party to participate selectively in the commission's processes. He pointed out that all amnesty applications required full disclosure of all human rights violations before they could be considered. Applications for reparations could also, in terms of the law, only be considered after being referred by the amnesty committee or the human rights violations committee.

"No party can avoid public scrutiny once it uses any of the committees of the commission," said Tutu. "It is in the interests of all parties to tell their side of the story. We are keen to stress we want to tell the whole story."

The unexpected ability of the commission to bolster its non-partisan image in the wake of this week's hearings in KwaZulu-Natal may just give it a chance to promote a bit of reconciliation. He told the M & G that Inkatha's decision would have important repercussions for the commission's objectives. "Once victims come to the commission they relate with each other. They begin to see each other as all victims of the same process and that is a beginning for reconciliation."


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


327 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa ANC Scores High With Constitution


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 10, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 2507 words


 

Johannesburg - The Constitution has become a yardstick of the success and strength of the political parties, and will do much to define them in the eyes of the public in the run-up to the 1999 general elections. reports

WHERE does the Constitutional Assembly leave the African National Congress? "In a league of its own."

The ANC has, during the last two years of constitution-making, negotiated its election promises of April 1994 (and more) through into the final constitutional text.

By its conviction and dogged, sometimes ruthless, negotiating style, the ANC has been able to free itself from the worst of the compromises it made in the interim Constitution, defining itself to its voters as the political movement that has not only brought freedom to South Africans, but also entrenched it.

It's likely that the majority of the population will be impressed.

Of all the constitutional victories the ANC scored, the settlement on centre-provincial relations was the easiest, given that at one stage of constitutional debate, federalism was the most sensitive of all constitutional issues. 

With the introduction of the Council of Provinces and the concept of co-operative government, the ANC has put itself firmly in control of both the centre and provincial interests, considerably lessening the powers of maverick provinces run by opposition parties (the Western Cape and KwaZulu-Natal) to buck the centre, and diminishing the threat of federalism to ANC national control.

The most dramatic of the ANC victories concerned the "three-pack" of clauses in the Bill of Rights. Over the past two weeks, the National Party stuck fast to positions on labour relations, property and education, hoping to push the ANC to the edge, and thus to an agreement.

Marathon all-nighters notwithstanding, the ANC refused to be eye-balled into accepting the NP's desire to entrench, as a constitutional right, the apartheid-derived system of mother- tongue, single-medium, state-subsidised schools, offering the Nats a sop to this instead.

The ANC also refused, with labour's backing and some say Cosatu's insistence, to put in a lock-out clause in the Labour Relations Bill, thereby seeming to champion the interests of the workers against employers. Further, the ANC formulated the property clause in such a way that it could be claimed as a "tool for land reform".

Also chalked in as victory on the score-board is the ANC's refusal to allow the NP to introduce any form of executive power-sharing. The ANC steadfastly refused to recognise traditional leadership in government and continued to insist on gender equality. It has also had success in outlawing racist hate- speech.

The ANC can also claim credit for being the chief architect of the Local Government chapter, elevating municipal governance to an independent tier of government with a constitutional guaranteed slice of national revenue. Further, the ANC takes the credit for ensuring that all South Africa's 11 languages have equal standing, replacing the interim Constitution's preference for English and Afrikaans.

There is a great deal for the ANC to boast about on the eve of local government elections.

The ANC is also in the lucky position of being able to boast about the concessions it made, to ensure that other political parties remained on board, thereby giving the text the legitimacy it desperately needs to enshrine it in the hearts of all South Africans, not just in the law.

By giving the Freedom Front its Cultural Commission and a self-determination principle, by giving the leader of the NP status as the Leader of the Opposition, and by bending to the Democratic Party and lobbyists from left and right on many issues in the Bill of Rights and elsewhere, the ANC showed itself to be just generous-spirited enough not to be type- cast as a bully -- even though it was the largest, most aggressive boy in the playground.

Finally, the opportunity the CA has given to the party's secretary general, Cyril Ramaphosa, to champion human rights, civil liberties, justice and good government with the most engaging of smiles can only enhance the party's standing in the eyes of the public.

While Wednesday was a day for all South Africans to be proud, it must have been a special day of jubilation for ANC leadership because it set the party on the road to the final new South Africa with everything it needs for success and an electoral victory in 1999.

Where does the CA process leave the Inkatha Freedom Party?

"Sore, sulky losers."

It was a sad reflection on Inkatha that only five journalists came to a special four-hour workshop on the evils of the final Constitution held at Parliament this week. Most of them only stayed an hour, refusing more cake and tea, to return to the CA, believing what MP's had to say there was ultimately more relevant to the public at this stage.

The general opinion among all constitutional players, from the presidential office to the Pan Africanist Congress, was that Inkatha has marginalised itself by refusing to return to the CA to fight its case for greater provincial autonomy there and that its views would have had an impact on the Constitution had they not left.

Inkatha theoreticians, and legal advisor Mario Ambrosini, will have their day at the certification of the Constitution at the Constitutional Court, where they will argue that this final draft is in fact unconstitutional because it diminishes provincial power and boosts the power of the centre.

While their argument in this respect has much weight -- the provincial powers have been decreased in comparison to the interim Constitution -- their refusal to participate does not help them, partly because nobody hears their side of the story in the media.

Where does this leave the NP? "Compromised."

They tried so hard to win through opposition, but in the end the NP's greatest art is compromise. An early attempt to further power- sharing in the final Constitution was beaten down by the ANC leaving Deputy President FW de Klerk with nothing more than the title of Leader of the Opposition.

With stated intention of ensuring federalism in the final Constitution, Secretary General Roelf Meyer agreed to a system of co-operative government that would clip the wings of the NP's only premier, Hernus Kriel, in the Council of Provinces.

Promising to fight to the last for single- medium, mother-tongue, state-subsidised schools, Meyer agreed to an education clause that makes their objective a possibility, but not a constitutional right.

The ANC played the NP carefully from the start, knowing full well that they needed the NP's vote to get the two-thirds majority to pass the Constitution, and that once the NP's support for the text was secured, it would make it harder for the DP and the FF to vote against the text.

The cultivated relationship between Roelf Meyer and Cyril Ramaphosa, and the spontaneous camaraderie that developed between Ramaphosa and NP MP Leon Wessels, and then between a number of NP and ANC stalwarts, helped to move the process along in, it was claimed, "a spirit of give and take". Much of the NP's success lay in the quieter process of finding common ground with the ANC, a party whose ideology they used to oppose vehemently.

The NP was in the difficult position of having to juggle constituencies -- on the one hand it had its loyalties to the traditional Afrikaner constituency, but it was also trying to court the emerging black bourgeoisie, coloured nationalists in the Western Cape, and big and small business. In the end, the party compromised on the aspirations of all three, but unlike Inkatha, participated gracefully in the final ceremony for the sake of South Africa and a position as opposition and for the common good.

The announcement that the NP will pull out of the Government on National Unity, to better fulfil an opposition role, does not come as a surprise.

Where does this leave the DP?

"Optimistic"

The ANC's spontaneous applause for DP leader Tony Leon during his earnest speech at the adoption ceremony on Wednesday took some by surprise. The aggression and fearlessness with which the DP took on the ANC directly during the Constitution-making process did not endear him to either ANC leaders or back-benchers.

The party locked horns frequently with the ANC, particularly over the Bill of Rights, on the issues of property, civil liberties, equality, labour relations, federalism and checks and balances on government leaders, wanting ultimately to secure greater freedom for individuals and the market, and wanting to check the power of central government and politicians.

In the final instance, it did not win all its battles; it lost many of the big ones, but it refused to compromise on its principles, defining it as a stauncher opposition to the ANC than the NP.

While the NP is still coming to terms with its loss of political power -- now finally confirmed by the new constitutional text -- the DP is resigned to having more influence than power, and by living by wit and stamina rather than popularity. It is difficult to pinpoint all the instances in which DP arguments have impacted on the final draft, but their accumulative effect is great, given their size and their past.

The DP kept the world guessing to the last moment, whether it would support the final draft -- of which so much was decided by the ANC and the NP -- but, in the end, Leon confirmed the party's support, optimistic that it would act as a "shield behind which ordinary South Africans can be secured in the fastness of their rights".

But the optimism is underscored by a wariness that the way to hell can be paved by good intentions.

Where does this leave the FF?

"Sustained, but abstaining."

The FF's decision not to vote one way or the other on the final Constitution surprised many ANC MPs, if their cries of dismay at the final adoption ceremony were anything to go by, because the ANC believed it had given "the General" -- FF leader Constand Viljoen -- what he wanted.

In many respects they had. The FF say they are satisfied that the Constitution acknowledges collective rights, self-determination and creates a commission that will protect the cultural and other rights of minorities. They are also pleased that the introduction of the final Constitution will not end the life of the Volkstaat Council.

However, the FF believes that the agreement on the education clause, which does not entrench Afrikaner single-medium schools, was too much of a compromise for them to accept, and with their constituency in mind, they decided they could not vote for the Constitution.

FF negotiator Corne Mulder said that he had been receiving telephone calls of support for their position, and that their principled stand on education had shown up the NP's weak compromise on education.

Throughout this process, the FF has steadfastly stuck to its ground, but it has not taken the opportunity to expand its political horizons and fight for anybody else but white Afrikaners. FF sources said when the deals came through "we are in exactly the same position as we were when the interim Constitution was finalised".

And the Pan Africanist Congress?

"Amused."

PAC leader Clarence Makwetu cracked joke after joke at the adoption ceremony, announcing the PAC's support for the text although it departed from many of the party's principles. He said he was particularly pleased that it ended power-sharing, but was disappointed that the GNU would continue until 1999.

Finally the African Christian Democratic Party?

"Still a believer."

Now that the process is over, it is quite safe to say that nobody took the ACDP seriously, except for the CA administration which noted all the remarks its representatives made.

The ACDP's point of departure was that the Bible overrode the provisions of any Constitution, as does God's will. It voted against the adoption of the Constitution.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


328 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Nats Make Last-Minute Grab for Pensions


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 10, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Johannesburg - Sly to the last, the National Party attempted to win constitutional guarantees for special pensions for long-serving parliamentarians, just before the end of the constitutional negotiations.

It was with some surprise that the waiting hordes of journalists heard, in the last nail- biting night, that the NP had added a new proposal on the table for discussion, along with the property, labour relations and education clauses. 

While the latter three were matters of principle, this new one was a matter of pocket. During the multi-party negotiations in Kempton Park, the NP MPs negotiated constitutional guarantees for pensions for those who had served in the old apartheid Parliament, and to balance it out, those who had served the ANC in Umkhonto weSizwe. In effect, the guarantee means that many Nat MPs who served in the last Parliament and are in the new one are receiving double pay -- a pension for apartheid days service as well as their current salary package. The NP wanted a guarantee in the final Constitution that this double privilege would not be taken away, once the interim Constitution fell away.

The Nats were hoping that by introducing this proposal so late, and with everyone so desperate for agreement, the ANC would concede their wish to avoid a deadlock.

ANC sources said that they called the Nats' bluff on that Tuesday night, challenging them to force a deadlock on a matter of pensions, and to take the consequences. At that stage, the NP took the proposal off the table, knowing that the adoption of the Constitution would overshadow this small incident, and that it was unlikely to make headline news.

"You're right, it doesn't look good," said an NP source late Tuesday.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


329 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa After 48 Years, The Nats Are Out


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 10, 1996 by Gaye Davis


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Johannesburg - The Mandela-De Klerk era ended at noon on Thursday. The National Party announced it is to quit the Government of National Unity, ending its 48-year stretch in the executive.

National Party leader FW de Klerk said yesterday the decision to quit the GNU did not mean an end to good co-operation, but it has left President Nelson Mandela faced with finding six Cabinet ministers and three deputies by June 30, when the withdrawal takes effect. 

The decision was taken at an emergency meeting of the party's federal executive committee Thursday morning and later endorsed by the NP's parliamentary caucus.

The decision was due to have been taken at a meeting of the NP's federal council this coming Tuesday. Instead, as the rand went spiraling downwards in the wake of De Klerk's remarks during the adoption of the new Constitution on Wednesday that the NP was seriously considering withdrawing from the GNU, provincial leaders were urgently summoned to Cape Town for yesterday's meeting.

Mandela, on a walkabout in Mitchell's Plain, was informed of the decision by De Klerk by phone shortly before the NP leader faced the press.

De Klerk said Mandela's reaction was "cool"; he took notes and "did not try to discuss the merits with me". De Klerk thanked Mandela for the "good working relationship we could have enjoyed".

Party insiders said De Klerk had made up his mind some time ago that he wanted to quit the GNU but faced opposition from within the party.

Behind De Klerk's thinking lay the realisation that the new Constitution marked a fresh phase in politics and a strategically opportune moment to quit the GNU, rather than wait for its formal expiry in 1999.

This would allow the party to focus on being an effective opposition without the hindrance of being party to decisions at executive level. It would also smooth internal rifts over the NP's lack of opposition profile and continued participation in the GNU.

The opposing view -- held by party secretary general Roelf Meyer, was that it would be better to make the most of the last few years of power -- sharing and remain an influence in government. De Klerk was understood to be keen to take a quick decision and put an end to uncertainty.

Debate within the party over the issue came to a head this week as it faced up to voting in favour of a Constitution which it felt to be flawed. It was time for the debate to come out into the open. Being the junior partner in government and an effective opposition is very difficult. Now we are in a transitional moment it is the time to do this, a NP source said.

Provincial leadership will be allowed to make their own decision with regard to staying in or pulling out and the timing of whatever they decide. It is likely Gauteng will opt to stay in.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


330 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Mandela Calls Constitution 'Historic'


BYLINE: South African Broadcasting Corporation May 8, 1996


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Cape Town - South African President Nelson Mandela says the country's new constitution's signals a historic step beyond the interim arrangements which legally obliged the nation's representatives to work together across the racial and political divide.

Addressing the constitutional assembly, Mr. Mandela said the new constitution obliged government to strive to improve the quality of life of South Africans and to promote the development of independent civil society structures. He said the South African nation had affirmed today in no uncertain terms that it was mature enough to derive strength, trust and unity from its tapestry of language, religious and cultural attributes. 

Mr. Mandela said the government was extremely proud that the new constitution asserted equality among South Africa's languages; and that, for the first time the languages particularly of the Khoi, Nama and San communities would receive the attention they deserved after years of being trampled upon in the most humiliating and degrading manner. He also said many new provisions on gender issues reflected the progress made towards securing equality for women who had suffered too many deprivations because of their gender.

The new constitution was adopted by the Constitutional Assembly on Wednesday by 421 votes to two, with ten abstentions. The African National Congress, the National Party, the Democratic Party and the Pan Africanist Congress voted in favour of it, the African Christian Democratic Party against it, while the Freedom Front abstained. The Senate had to vote separately on aspects of the constitution affecting the provinces. Here the vote was 79 for and none against, while three Freedom Front Senators abstained. The vote count excluded those of the Inkatha Freedom Party of South Africa, which withdrew from the Constitutional Assembly last year.

Agreement on three issues that threatened to delay the adoption of South Africa's new constitution was announced at eleven o'clock on Tuesday night, after last-minute talks on the outstanding issues. The negotiators said the agreement on the education issue included a compromise clause stipulating that single-medium institutions were an alternative that could be taken into account by the state. Agreement was also reached on the lockout and property rights clauses. The National Party attempted a late-night amendment on a new point, asking that pensions be guaranteed in the constitution. However, this was rejected by the African National Congress and did not stand in the way of the agreement.

The Pan Africanist Congress and the Freedom Front reserved their positions on the education clause. The Democratic Party said that it intended to approach the Constitutional Court because a clause permitting employers to lock out striking workers was not in the constitution. The National Party has reserved its position on this clause.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


331 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa A deal at the very last moment


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 8, 1996


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Johannesburg - After more than a week of deadlocked talks, the ANC and National Party finally agreed on a new constitution -- just a few minutes past midnight last night. The agreement means that the new constitution is now certain to be voted into law in parliament this morning, ruling out the need for an emergency referendum. 

Most of the debate in the final week was about allaying white fears. On the three major areas of disagreement, compromise has been reached largely by avoiding the issues.

The first sticking point was single-medium schooling, which the National Party insisted upon and the ANC opposed. The compromise education clause says that single medium schooling is one of the alternatives the state must consider in determining education policy "where this is practical".

The second sticking point was the "lock-out" clause, in which the ANC sided with Cosatu in arguing that employers did not have the right to lock striking employees out of plants. The compromise avoids the issue by referring to existing labour legislation and calling for consultation on any further changes with both union and employer organisations.

On the third issue, property rights, the state has the limited right to land reform, except where mineral rights -- the major area of disagreement --- are involved. Private property rights are now enshrined.

The Democratic Party has objected to the compromise clauses, particularly the lock-out clause, which leader Tony Leon described as "a victory for Cosatu". The Inkatha Freedom Party has boycotted the entire constitutional negotiations, and is unlikely to vote in favour. The Pan Africanist Congress is unhappy with the compromise education clause, but is likely to vote in favour.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


332 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa Defense Official Briefs Congress on Liberia


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 8, 1996


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Washington - Following is the text of a statement by Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for African Affairs Vincent D. Kern before the
Subcommittee on Africa in the U.S. House of Representatives on May 8.

Thank you for the opportunity to be here today to talk briefly about the crisis in Liberia.

We find the current situation in Liberia very disturbing. Sporadic gunfire continues to be heard in the capital and thousands of Liberians have fled or are trying to escape the fighting in Liberia. Last Monday, fighters loyal to Charles Taylor again skirmished with fighters of Roosevelt Johnson near the U.S. Embassy compound. Several rounds, apparently directed, hit the perimeter of the embassy. Some U.S. Marines, whose total is about 200 on the embassy compound, fired back in self-defense; no injuries resulted from the incoming rounds or those fired by the Marines. 

Three earlier incidents involving U.S. Marines at the embassy compound occurred on the afternoon and evening of April 30. In the first incident a Marine was slightly injured when a bullet grazed his neck (he has since returned to duty). In the second and third incidents the Marines returned fire at groups of armed fighters, killing five attackers and wounding a sixth. A Marine was slightly injured in the cheek from flying wood splinters when rounds hit a plywood cover (he too has returned to duty); no injuries resulted from the third incident.

U.S. forces operating in Liberia are under the general rules of engagement (ROE) for all U.S. forces deployed to a potentially hostile area. Those ROE include the right of self-defense including preemptive actions to ensure safety should someone show hostile intent.

An Amphibious Ready Group (ARG), consisting of three U.S. Navy vessels and a logistics ship, continues to operate off the coast of Liberia, approximately 25 miles offshore. There are some 2,200 Marines and 1,100 sailors associated with those ships. The ARG's normal rotation schedule would bring it back to the U.S. beginning mid-July.

The U.S. troops currently in Monrovia and off the coast are there to reinforce the security of the embassy and to carry out the in extremis evacuation of American citizens. The U.S. has no intention of using our troops to stabilize the city or to perform other military functions off the immediate U.S. Embassy compound.

As Assistant Secretary Moose testified, U.S. forces have successfully evacuated over 2,300 people from Monrovia, 461 of whom are American citizens. We continue to evacuate Americans and selected third-country nationals as they arrive at the embassy.

The total cost for Operation Assured Response is not available at this time. Under a memorandum of understanding between the Department of Defense and the Department of State, the Department of Defense is collecting costs related to Liberia's Noncombatant Evacuation Operation (NEO). Additionally, SECDEF (the secretary of defense) has approved non-DOD, space-available travel via regularly scheduled milair (military air) between Freetown, Sierra Leone, (and) Monrovia.

The U.S. has a long and proud history of humanitarian assistance to those in need. DOD possesses a unique capability for providing critical, specific assets while working as part of a U.S.-coordinated interagency and international effort. During FY 95, the DOD Office of Humanitarian and Refugee Affairs, in support of NGOs and PVOs, shipped 320 tons of pharmaceuticals, medical equipment and supplies, and school supplies to Liberia.

Pending your questions, I thank you.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


333 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa House Africa Subcommittee Chair on Liberia


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 8, 1996


LENGTH: 747 words


 
Washington - Following is an excerpt provided by the United States Information Agency of a statement as prepared for delivery by Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-FL), who chairs the subcommittee on Africa in the U.S. House of Representatives, on May 8.

Today the Subcommittee meets to address the crisis in Liberia -- an issue that affects the U.S. and all of us at many different levels, with humanitarian, political, and security concerns clamoring for an immediate end to the killing.

The breakdown of law and order in Liberia, the loss of innocent lives, the massive destruction that has taken place in Monrovia over the course of the past several weeks, are cause for grave concern for the U.S., the African continent, and for the international community. It is a situation that strikes at the very fiber of human compassion, as thousands are threatened and displaced by the increased hostilities. It is a situation reminiscent of other recent conflicts with the potential to become a humanitarian cataclysm, spilling over into neighboring countries and destabilizing the entire region. 

However, the crisis in Liberia is indicative of a far greater problem, a disease that is slowly infecting countries in Africa, creating an environment of conflict and turmoil -- this is, the contradiction between the goals of the people of these African countries, and the personal interests and recalcitrant behavior of political and rebel leaders.

It has been emphasized many times during the course of hearings held by this Subcommittee, but it must be mentioned again.

The people of Liberia desperately want peace; yet it is the faction leaders who repeatedly choose to pursue their political objectives through violent means with a total disregard for the suffering inflicted on their fellow Liberians. The people of Liberia want a cease-fire and a return to normalcy. The people of Liberia want to see their country flourish once again.

While certain problems created by the war will be difficult to surpass, it is clear that Liberia's economic future holds much potential if the war ends soon and political stability takes a firm hold. Specifically to U.S. interests, many believe that Liberia could once again become an important strategic, diplomatic, and economic partner to the U.S.

Nevertheless, none of this will be possible until rebel leaders set aside their appetite for power and place the well-being of their country above their personal desires. The time is now for rebel leaders to return to negotiations and end the fighting.

The U.S. and the international community are ready and willing to help, but only if there is a demonstrable commitment to the peace process and to a cease-fire.

Outside actors cannot secure a future of peace and prosperity to Liberia. They cannot build a sense of national unity until the feuding leaders demonstrate that they are ready for peace themselves. The U.S. and the international community can ameliorate the pain and suffering that are the effects of the fighting, but only the rebel leaders can end the crisis.

The U.S. has long worked toward an end to the bloodshed and a reconciliation that will allow all the people of Liberia to live in peace. Throughout, we have been filled with optimism that this goal would be achieved but, after 13 peace agreements implemented and then broken, our hopes have quickly turned to disappointment.

Today, however, we are once again filled with expectations as an ECOWAS (Economic Community of West African States) summit is taking place in Accra, Ghana, with certain rebel leaders and representatives of the various factions. This could be the crucial turning point.

This is certainly what we are all hoping for.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


334 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa State Department: Liberia's 'Bleakest Moment'


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 8, 1996


LENGTH: 2054 words


 

Washington - Following is the text of a statement, as prepared for delivery, by the U.S. assistant secretary of state for African affairs, George Moose, before the Subcommittee on Africa of the House of Representatives
Good afternoon. I appear before you today at one of the bleakest moments in Liberia's history. Monrovia, once a safe haven for more than one million civilians, lies in ruins, the result of fierce fighting by Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) and Alhaji Kromah's United Liberation Movement for Democracy (ULIMO-K) rebels against Roosevelt Johnson's breakaway faction of ULIMO (ULIMO-J, comprised primarily of ethnic Krahns). More than 80,000 Liberians have been left homeless. Thousands have fled or are trying to flee the fighting in the capital. At least 100 peacekeepers have lost their lives attempting to restore security in the city and its environs. At this point we do not know how many Liberian fighters and civilians have been killed.

A U.S. airlift has evacuated more than 2,300 people from Monrovia, including 461 American citizens. The U.S. Embassy staff has been drawn down to 22 official Americans. All of the United Nations agencies, international organizations and non-governmental organizations compounds have been looted and their staffs forced to leave the country. In just three weeks the fighters, many of whom are child soldiers, have caused an estimated $40 million in damages, including $20 million in equipment and supplies lost by relief organizations. 

I want to take a moment to commend Ambassador William Milam and his staff at the embassy in Monrovia, and the Department of Defense's task force for successfully carrying out the evacuation under very difficult circumstances. The task force was remarkably effective in getting the assets necessary for an effective evacuation in place in the region on very short notice. I also want to commend Ambassador Milam and his courageous staff for immediately stepping in to help deliver food, water, and medical supplies to the homeless and displaced after almost all NGOs were forced to leave. Since April 10, the U.S. Embassy and World Food Program have delivered nearly 2,000 metric tons of food in Monrovia and surrounding areas, thereby averting a humanitarian disaster.

The Abuja Accord: What Went Wrong?

All of the Liberian warring factions signed the Abuja Accord on August 19, 1995. Although it was one in a long series of Liberian peace accords which have attempted to resolve the civil conflict begun in 1989, it held such promise. Charles Taylor and the Nigerians had resolved their differences and were on board, the faction leaders were beginning to work together on the Council of State to implement the accord's disarmament provisions, and the ECOWAS (Economic Community of West African States) countries were committed to the peace process. What went wrong?

First and foremost, we now know faction leaders did not wholeheartedly commit themselves to the peace process but apparently pursued multiple strategies -- one for peace, the other for war. While pursuing a political solution as members of the new Council of State in Monrovia, they continued their high-stakes warfare in the countryside for control and exploitation of Liberia's rich resources -- timber, diamonds, gold, and rubber. In the meantime, faction leaders hid large caches of arms and munitions in Monrovia and brought hundreds of their armed fighters into the city as "bodyguards."

The West African peacekeepers (ECOMOG), who have been in Liberia since 1990 and are largely supported by troop-contributing countries, are responsible for providing security for Liberia and accomplishing the encampment and disarmament of combatants. ECOMOG troop size, which was around 10-12,000 when it successfully defended Monrovia in 1990 and 1992 from attacks and fended off a coup attempt by a Krahn general in September 1994, has been substantially reduced to about 5-6,000 troops. Some of the unpaid ECOMOG troops have gone into business for themselves. In December, ECOMOG troops were attacked and defeated by ULIMO-J rebels at Tubmanburg. ECOMOG suffered heavy casualties (as many as 60 soldiers may have been killed), lost much of its heavy equipment, and suffered a terrible blow to its morale.

Another significant factor was that overall support for the peace process, including support for ECOMOG, was slow in coming and has not been at the level we had hoped would be committed. At the October 27 U.N. Donors Conference, we pledged $75 million dollars for the peace process, including $10 million for logistical support (leased trucks and helicopters) for ECOMOG. Other potential donors were leary of committing significant resources up-front given the failure of 12 previous peace accords. Still other donors had prohibitions on assistance to non-U.N. peacekeeping operations.

What We Are Doing

We consider the Abuja Accord -- an interim government, disarmament, demobilization, and the holding of free and fair elections -- the best framework for a permanent solution. Despite its current difficulties, we believe ECOMOG can again become an effective peacekeeping force.

We have strongly condemned the recent outbreak of fighting -- both in private conversations with faction leaders and in public statements -- and urged all the factions to restore the cease-fire, withdraw their fighters and weapons from Monrovia, and return to the peace process.

On April 21 we dispatched a high-level diplomatic team comprised of representatives from the State Department, National Security Council, and the Joint Staff to work with Ambassador Milam and an ECOWAS delegation sent by Ghanaian President Rawlings to put the peace process back on track.

We have also initiated an International Contact Group on Liberia (ICGL), which held its first meeting in Geneva April 26. The focus of the Contact Group's discussions was on how the international community could respond to recent developments in Liberia in a way which could positively influence the peace process. Representatives of 12 nations attended the first meeting; I was heartened by their commitment to continue to work for the cause of peace in Liberia.

From Geneva I went to Accra, where I consulted with President Rawlings on how to get the peace process back on track. On April 30 I went to Monrovia to urge faction leaders to pursue their political objectives through negotiation, not force. Due to the fighting and uncertainty of the security situation I was unable to leave the embassy compound. Although I did speak with Roosevelt Johnson, I was unable to reach Charles Taylor or Alhaji Kromah despite repeated efforts. They thereby missed an opportunity to demonstrate their commitment to peace.

On May 3, in response to renewed fighting in blatant disregard of the April 19 cease-fire, we announced the reimposition of visa restrictions barring entry into the United States of Liberians, their families, close associates, and others who obstruct the peace process. We are asking other members of the international community to implement a similar travel ban. We are also prepared to consider other measures to demonstrate our intolerance of the faction leaders' obstruction of the peace process. We have told faction leaders that we will not recognize any government coming to power by force and we will actively work with the international community to isolate, ostracize, and reject, both politically and economically, any leader who comes to power by force.

Next Steps

The challenge that confronts the United States and other friends and supporters of Liberia is to give the Abuja peace process another chance to succeed. The situation in Monrovia must be stabilized. Fighters must withdraw from the capital and Monrovia must once again become a safe haven. Faction leaders must agree to abandon violence in favor of a political process for settling differences.

We will continue our vigorous support for ECOWAS' efforts to achieve a negotiated solution to the current crisis and to reaffirm a peace process which encompasses disarmament, demobilization, and the holding of free and fair democratic elections.

As we speak, Special Presidential Envoy for Liberia Ambassador Dane Smith is representing the United States at a special ECOWAS emergency summit meeting in Accra to which all members of the Liberian Council of State have been invited. This meeting is a critical step in putting the peace process back on track. We hope the Accra summit will reaffirm the Abuja Accord as the best framework for settlement of the Liberian crisis, that ECOWAS countries will commit to applying even greater pressure on the factions to respect the peace process and that there will be serious discussion of bolstering ECOMOG's peacekeeping capabilities.

Ending arms flows into Liberia remains critical to halting the current fighting. We are pressing for tougher enforcement of the 1992 U.N. arms embargo and are asking other countries to join us in this effort.

We are also looking at ways to increase our support for ECOMOG. If ECOMOG can demonstrate a renewed capacity to play a neutral and effective peacekeeping role, we would be prepared to make available approximately $30 million from existing resources in equipment and other additional assistance. Although some ECOMOG troops failed to do their duty during the recent fighting and may have participated in the looting, others performed commendably. I want to note again that more than 100 ECOMOG soldiers have died in the past three weeks in Liberia defending the capital.

In conclusion, Madam Chairman, for moral, humanitarian, and political reasons, we choose to remain deeply engaged, even though we realize just how formidable the challenges have become. I want to stress the high priority this administration places on returning Liberia to civilian, democratic rule. The people of Liberia have suffered too long from this tragic conflict. The time for peace has come. I want to thank you and other members of your subcommittee for your support for peace and democracy in Liberia and throughout Africa.

Liberia is an example of the risks and hardships faced by our people in the field every day as they seek to advance U.S. interests and protect American citizens. These are among the major issues at stake in the foreign affairs budget. If we are going to continue to be a leader in world affairs, we need the resources necessary to do so.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Ethiopia Foreign Minister Says Ethiopia Has Better Image


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 3, 1996


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Addis Ababa - Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin announced here that the activities carried out by his ministry over the past eight months and the corresponding results have significantly changed the image of Ethiopia.

In an explanation he gave to the regular meeting of the House of Peoples' Representatives Tuesday. Ato Seyoum said Ethiopia today is not a token of starvation, war and human sufferings but symbol of peace and stability, economic co-operation and mutual assistance. 

Ethiopia has a strong desire for good neighbourliness but this desire has to be supported by the parties in question if it is to bear fruit, the minister said, adding its relations are seriously being affected by the policy of international terrorism pursued by the government in Khartoum.

Except with the Sudan, Ethiopia's relations with the rest of its neighbours have been successful, Ato Seyoum said and cited the principles of mutual respect, the respect for the sovereignty of nations and non interference in the internal affairs of others as the basis of the foreign relations policy of Ethiopia.

He said, Ethiopia has forged good relations with southern Africa and the Magreb countries such as Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, the Republic of South Africa, Algeria and Tunisia.

Similarly, the country has consolidated friendly ties and good relations with European, North American and Asian countries, he added.

According to the foreign minister, efforts to improve relations with the Middle East and Gulf countries have not brought about the anticipated results.

Speaking on the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ato Seyoum said it is the oldest of all similar ministers in Africa but paradoxically enough has very few qualified staff.

He said efforts have been made to gradually solve the problem of skilled man power and impeding structure through successive measures taken immediately after the transitional government assumed power in 1991.

The minister has responded to questions on Ethiopia's foreign relations posed by members of the House of Peoples' Representatives.

The meeting has also approved with some minor amendments the proclamation providing for the establishment of the defence force of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


336 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Arts, Culture and Entertainment (DOCUMENT) African Headwear Featured In New Exhibit


BYLINE: Smithsonian Institution (Washington) May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Washington, DC - More than 180 traditional and contemporary hats, headdresses and headties from throughout Africa are featured in the exhibition "Crowning Achievements: African Arts of Dressing the Head," opening May 8 at the Smithsonian's National Museum of African Art, 950 Independence Ave. S.W.

On view through August 18 the exhibition was organized by the UCLA Fowler Museum of Cultural History. From Washington "Crowning Achievements travels to the Hood Museum of Art at Dartmouth College (September 21 to December 1) and to the High Museum of Art in Atlanta (April 22, 1997 to June 15, 1997)

Composed of an array of forms and an enormous range of materials, the objects in the exhibition represent a cross-cultural survey of Africa's dynamic arts of personal adornment. The works -- dating from the early 1800s to present -- examine the significance of headwear across Africa as well as in the African Diaspora. In addition to works from the Fowler Museum, "Crowning Achievements" includes objects from the National Museum of Natural History, the National Museum of African Art, the Museum of International Folk Art (Santa Fe) and from private collections. 

"These works of art illustrate how people use hats to construct social identities and to enhance and transform their lives," said Mary Jo Arnoldi, National History curator of African ethnology and art. Arnoldi and Christine Mullen Kreamer, a museum exhibit developer, served as guest curators.

In Africa, as in many cultures, hats and hair define social status, age or gender and transmit important messages about the attitudes, values and beliefs that shape the human experience. "Crowning Achievements", interpreting African headwear with an emphasis on individual identity, explores the material artistry, spiritual value, historical origins and stylistic influences of the objects. Related clothing, African hairdressing signs and photographs augment the presentation.

"The National Museum of African Art is delighted to host this rich and celebratory exhibition and to have participated by providing photographs from the Eliot Elisofon Photographic Archives to both the exhibition and the accompanying catalog," said Phillip Ravenhill, chief curator at the museum.

Following and introductory section, the exhibition offers an in-depth view of 12 provocative hats, including a Yoruba beaded crown, a Gola fiber hat, a Sudanese chain-mail helmet, an Ethiopian silver crown and a Herero woman's leather headdress. They represent a wide geographic range of cultural styles which employ a diversity of materials and exhibit technical expertise. The curators have provided information on the cultures that produced the hats as well as the techniques of construction, the symbolic importance of materials and forms chosen by the hat makers. How the hats came into the collection is also explained.

Like hats, hairstyles are excellent vehicles for visual expression. Another section features elaborate wigs, hairpieces, hairpins combs and headrests.

A section on everyday and special hats features informal or everyday hats and special-occasion wear. Aesthetically and regionally diverse, these hats illustrate issues of style and symbolism, purpose and personal choice.

Though often beautiful in form and technique, everyday wear tends to be made of durable, inexpensive material. Some of these hats are from calabashes incised with curvilinear designs and others derived from reeds, grasses and tree fibers are transformed into wearable art. The creation of headwear for special occasions, in contrast, involves the use of precious or exotic materials, and the result displays a high degree of decorative embellishment that conveys power, wealth and prestige. Whether intended for kings, brides or diviners, these hats may fulfill a multitude of functions. For example, such special headwear as the exuberantly beaded bicorn Pende chief's headdress can serve as a visual metaphor for political power.

The sculptural art of wrapping the head -- featuring men's and women's headties and turbans that highlight the elegant expressions of this widespread custom in Africa -- is presented in a slide show in this section of the exhibit. Highlighted are headwrapping traditions among Tuareg and Hausa men and among Yoruba women.

Headwear serves as an important material symbol of rank and title. Issues of status are investigated in the next segment of the exhibition, which compares the full range of headgear used by two societies in Zaire -- the Kuba and the Lega.

The final part of the exhibition looks at the significant impact African styles have on international style as it traces contemporary trans-Atlantic connections between Africa and America. Today, hats made of, or inspired by, Ghanaian kente cloth or Bamana mud-cloth from Mali and the Islamic-style cloth skullcaps have hit the urban fashion scene outside the continent. A selection of hats from Los Angeles' African marketplace offers an excellent case study of the range of African-influenced headwear available for sale in major American cities. The hats evoke ties to Egypt, African Islam and Jamaican Rastafarianism.

In addition to two free gallery hand-outs, the museum is offering a series of exhibition-related activities this spring and summer including lectures, workshops and children's programs. For a free schedule, call (202) 357-4600 ext. 291.

A 185 page illustrated exhibition catalog, which sells for $45 in hardback or $27 in paperback, is available in the museum shop.

The National Museum of Art is open daily from 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission is free. The museum's TTY number is (202) 357-4814. The Smithsonian Home Page on the World Wide Web (http://www.si.edu) includes information on the museum.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


337 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Journalists Celebrate World Press Freedom Day


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 5, 1996


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Lusaka - Zambian Journalists today made a show of strength and reaffirmed their belief in a free press when they came together to commemorate World Freedom Day - which is set aside for writers by the United Nations.

Various speakers assured media persons that they were with them all the way but that they themselves as practitioners should show the way by giving committment to the cause.

The Zambia Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU) told them it believes freedom to information should not be a privilege of the few, but a right of every Zambian. 

It reaffirmed its support for those who fought for their basic freedom adding that it has not departed from what it did in 1991 when they supported MMD for just governance.

Speaking at Freedom Statue to commemorate World Freedom Day, which falls today, ZCTU Vice-President, Austin Liato, urged journalists to unite and guard against government's pressure to try and make them its mouth-piece.

"You have in the past been used as government's tools for its propaganda. The time has come for you to unite and reject such a pressure," he said.

Speaking at the same ceremony, Media Institute for Southern Africa (MISA) Governor in Zambia, Fanwell Chembo, said despite government being a signatory to the world free press declaration of 1991 signed in Namibia, it has continued to bulldoze the press.

In a solidality message to mark the occassion, Zambia Information Services (ZIS) Director, Patrick Jabani, said in a multi-party democracy, the press should carry non-partisan civic education campaigns and information.

In a message read on his behalf by ZIS acting Newspapers Manager, Davis Mukuka, Jabani said his department will strive to keep up to date with people's views, concerns and efforts to meet their obligations.

Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) urged government to fully implement media reforms and attract private investment in the profession to enable the media flourish extensively.

Commemorating the media World Freedom Day President, Alfred Zulu said true democracy could only be attained when the press had autonomy.

"The full attainment of a democratic society can only have its true meaning when the press has autonomy as a free establishment", he said.

Zulu, therefore, called on all governments in Southern Africa to privatise and integrate the media in the democratisation process.

He said such integration would facilitate the rapid emergence of rapid pluralist society, protect human rights and use political pluralism as a major tool in resolving conflicts within and between nations.

Zulu charged it should be noted that press freedom has necessarily been recognised as a bill of human rights by the United Nations, the Commonwealth, European Union and the Organisation of African Unity and the Organisation of American States.

He urged celebrating journalists to keep in mind about their numerous colleagues through out the world who were tortured, killed and persecuted for their support of democracy.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


338 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Multi-Party 'Indaba" Flops As Plot Uncovered


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Lusaka - The big meeting which was planned for today for all leaders of political parties in Zambia failed to take place after some opposition heads tried to impose 'impossible pre-conditions' for their attendance.

President Frederick Chiluba, afterwards, told a State House press briefing that the unravelling of the big 'indaba' had been engineered by some leaders of opposition political parties who wanted to sneak in the much talked about constituent assembly via the back door by first creating a semblance of a political crisis in the nation.

Mr Chiluba said his government fully regretted the flop of the meeting but that it will not sit idly by while some opposition parties tried to usurp power through the use of unconstitutional means.

''In spite of what happened this morning my government shall continue to dialogue with the various interest groups in the nation including opposition political parties,'' Mr Chiluba said. 

The President did not single out any political party for special blame but he was catergorical enough that opposition parties have squandered chance of dialogue adding that he left the whole sordid affair to the nation which shall best judge who is to blame.

Mr Chiluba reminded the nation that ever since his government came into office it had left doors wide open for frank and intimate discussions with other political parties and that was why it had been found necessary to include opposition political leaders on government business trips so they could help keep lines of communication ever open between government and opposition parties.

However, some opposition parties had taken this to be a sign of weakness and that was why under the guise of pre-conditions, they had now wanted to forment a crisis which would have called into questionthe legality of a bona fide and legitimate government.

''I am happy to report that the crisis which was about to be formented by opposition parties has failed and we remain firmly in control of the situation and hope to advance the agenda of running the nation,'' Mr Chiluba said.

Alluding to the biggest reason for the none-holding of the inter-party meeting earlier today, Mr Chiluba explained that there was no way in which his government could abdicate its responsibility over chairmanship because it still legitimately enjoys the support of most Zambians.

He explained that there was no parallel between what happened in 1991 when a neutral chairman had to be called in, to replace Dr Kaunda, at an inter-party meeting held in Lusaka because the UNIP government at that time had lost legitimacy and the very support of the people as this was later underscored by the election result which followed those talks.

The Movement for Multi-Party Democracy, therefore, cannot be compared to the UNIP Government of 1991 because it was legitimately put into office by the majority of Zambians who up to today are still very much in support of its policies and programmes.

In this regard, then, it would be wrong for opposition leaders to twist the hand of government for a concession which they did not deserve, Mr Chiluba said.

Presidents of opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) and Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) on Sunday attached a pre-condition for their attending the inter-party meeting and this was that the 'indaba' should be chaired by a neutral person from either the judiciary or clergy and not President Chiluba because he is an interested party.

But this pre-condition was outrightly rejected by Government which felt it would be setting a very bad precedent and indirectly give away what rightfully belongs to it and not opposition parties for the sake of accomodating opposing views.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


339 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Bigger Bank Notes Soon Available


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The long awaited K10,000, K5,000 and K1,000 bank notes will soon be in circulation, Bank of Zambia announced in Lusaka today.

Addressing a press briefing, Bank of Zambia Governor, Dr Jacob Mwanza, said the initial consignment would be introduced on the market in two weeks time. He however, added that the full impact of the circulation would be felt next month.

He advised the public to closely examine the features of the new bank notes, which will be displayed on posters, to avoid being cheated with forged notes.

The distinguishing features are that the colour of the African fish eagle on the K10,000 is blue; purple and maroon on the K5,000 and K1,000 notes respectively.

Dr Mwanza said higher denominations of money would reduce the public's risks of carrying big bundles of money which can easily be identified by thieves. He added that it will also save time when effecting transactions at banks.

The total cost in both printing and freight costs amounted to 857,600 British pounds.

Dr Mwanza ruled out the possibility that the introduction of the high denominations would spark inflation in the country, saying inflation could only be sparked if there was an excess supply of money.

He said as lower denominations of money go back to the Central Bank, higher denominations would merely be replacing them in circulation and hence, there would be no increase in money supply and velocity which facilitate inflation.

Dr Mwanza added that lower denominations such as K20, and K50, notes would eventually be phased out and replaced with coins.

He said it was costly to continue printing lower denomination notes, saying it was better to print coins instead which are not printed as frequently as notes.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

May, 1996


Zambia Airmen in Relief Operations


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Zambezi - A Zambia Air Force (ZAF) helicopter has arrived in Zambezi today to start airlifting relief food to over 30,000 starving people living on Zambezi west bank.

According to public relations officer, Captain Gabriel Kunda who is also the field spokesman said the exercise of delivering the relief maize will start tomorrow Tuesday and it will take 10 days to finish the operation. 

Captain Kunda said Zambezi has favourable weather and no big mountains to disrupt the operation adding that the 10-days will be sufficient to deliver the 525 by 50kg bags of yellow maize unless there would be unseen circumstances to interupt them.

He said the relief maize will be airlifted to Zambezi west where hunger has hit most of the areas of Kayenge, Mwange, Nguyuvu, Mufula, Nachikayi, Muzwiza, Milomboi, Matondo and Muyembe.

And Programme Against Malunutrition chairman, David Crowdac, said people from the west bank were starving as their food stocks had run out some months ago.

He said the situation there was critical.

Zambia Opposition May Boycott Party Indaba


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 6, 1996 by A Staff Writer


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition UNIP will not attend today's inter-party talks if President Frederick Chiluba insists on being in the chair.

UNIP president, former Zambian president Kenneth Kaunda, told Copperbelt University students that when the MMD in 1991 rejected that he chair an inter-party meeting, he obliged. 

"When they said I should not chair the meeting and asked the church to do that, I did not object because that is how democrats operate," Kaunda said. "And at that time I was still Republican president. I did not refuse to go to Mulungushi to attend the meeting."

MMD national secretary, health minister Michael Sata, last week announced that President Chiluba would chair the inter-party meeting.

The Zambia Democratic Congress(ZDC) also warned last week that they will not attend the meeting if President Chiluba insists on being in the chair.

Sports - General Boxing: Light Welterweight Ordered To Fight


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 6, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - Felix "The Hammer" Bwalya has been given a chance to have a crack at the Commonwealth light-welterweight champion, now held by Britain's Paul "Iron" Ryan.

The Commonwealth Boxing Council (CBC) two weeks ago ordered Ryan to fight Bwalya, Zambia's light-welterweight champion. 

"All this time, Ryan has been avoiding to fight Bwalya," Yusuf Seedat, Bwalya's handler, said in an interview on Saturday. "It is good that finally, the CBC has mandated him to fight Bwalya, Ryan will now see who the real champion is."

But the fight has to be delayed for at least another month as Ryan's licence has been suspended by the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBC).

"Ryan is mandated to defend against Bwalya. In view of the temporary suspension of his licence for medical reasons by the British Boxing Board, an extension is being granted to Ryan and the position will be reviewed again within about a month of today's date," reads CBC's letter of April 18 to Seedat.

Sports - Soccer Zambia: National Team Recalls Chilombo


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 6, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - Hector Chilombo, the towering City of Lusaka defender, has been recalled to the national soccer squad.

"I was asked by Poulsen to join the national team when it comes to Lusaka on Tuesday," Chilombo disclosed in an interview at Woodlands stadium on Saturday. "I feel it is an honour and I will try my best."

But when asked which new players he had called to join camp, Poulsen who was watching the Nkwazi- City match, said he will make an announcement later in the week.

"I may get some players from this match," Poulsen said. " But I think it is better to wait maybe after some days when I can decide."

Poulsen was also busy inquiring about City's winger, Rodwell Kilambe.

And Chilombo walked out of Woodlands Stadium with K60,000 after winning the City of Lusaka player of the month award for April.

The award is sponsored by Lusaka lawyer and City fan, Sunday Nkonde.

344 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Kwacha 'Stabilises'


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 6, 1996 by Chilomba Mwondela


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - The kwacha has now stabilised, assured Bank of Zambia governor Jacob Mwanza at a press briefing last Friday.

Introducing new kwacka denominations, Mwanza said adverse exchange movements were expected in the first quarter of the year "due to irregularities in certain areas of the financial sector". 

"Inflation increased early this year because the demands made on the kwacha went up," Mwanza said. " There were maize imports, companies had to remit dividends, there was a diminishing of stocks on the stock market, and there was also the low ZCCM supplies."

However, the governor dismissed any evidence of capital flight.

"It is easier to control money movement on the streets but not money kept by businesses or crooks," Mwanza explained. "The country used to lose US$400 million annually until the economy was liberalised and people realised they could keep their money without threat of it being grabbed by the government."

Mwanza added: "Exporters are now encouraged to export more because they know they can enjoy the benefits of their forex earnings."

The governor also assured that although the free market had its own risks on the whole it had been proven the world over to be a better system than enforcing restrictions on money movements.

The Kwacha's value rallied slightly at close of business on Friday. It was buying at K1, 230 in bureaux around town and selling at K1,260 compared to K1, 240 and K1, 275 respectively the week before.

The Bank of Zambia will this week start releasing new denominations of Kwacha namely, K1,000, K5,000 and K10,000 notes. The governor said these notes will take about a month to be fully integrated into the money system.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Journalists Groups Differ On Regulatory Body


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia May 6, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba and Sam Kujuda


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - Principal divisions emerged at the height of World Press Freedom day when two media bodies differed on the legislation of a media regulatory body.

The Zambia chapter of the Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) said in Lusaka yesterday it was "totally" opposed to any form of legislated controls of the media as advocated by the Press Association of Zambia (PAZA) .

PAZA issued a statement on Saturday, a day after the labour movement, students and human rights groups met in Lusaka to commemorate World Press Freedom Day organised by MISA, claiming it has been given mandate by media organisations to be an umbrella body of journalists in Zambia and to sponsor the legislation of a media driven regulatory body. 

But in a counter reaction MISA denied being part of any such agreements.

"Zambia has more than enough restrictive laws that seriously hinder the development of professional journalism.

"The repeal of these laws, and not the enactment of new ones like a Media council Act, should be the priority of all those who cherish press freedom," said Zambia Chapter, MISA chairman Fanwell Chembo and member Joseph Mkandawire in a press statement.

"Any legislated body, whether enacted with the support of media organisations like PAZA, will never have the support of MISA," the MISA statement further read.

MISA also denied it would mandate PAZA, predominantly made up of government employed journalists to be the umbrella body of media work in Zambia.

"MISA has among its members individuals and organisations that voluntarily opted not to belong to PAZA and their right to free association will be scrupulously respected. They will not be brought into PAZA by any other way - direct or indirect."

According to a PAZA joint press statement released earlier by chairman John Musukuma and secretary Moses Walubita MISA and ZUJ were, effective this month, going to share offices with PAZA but MISA has denied it would ever do this.

May, 1996


Malawi Corruption Charges Spark Debate in Malawi


BYLINE: Malawi News Online May 3, 1996


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Blantyre - Addressing a rally on 27 April in Nkhata-Bay, north Malawi, AFORD President and Second Vice-President in the coalition government, Chakufwa Chihana, accused the ruling UDF and the opposition MCP, of corruption. He said AFORD was the main and only broker in Malawi, without which the country would slide into what he called chaos and confusion.

He accused both the UDF and MCP of being corrupt and not having the capability to govern, saying the two parties were corrupt in terms of political ideas and lacked the conception of how to plan the economic future of the country. 

UDF Publicity Secretary, Cassim Chilumpha, and MCP Acting Secretary General, Lovemore Munlo, challenged Chihana to come in the open with evidence of the corruption and accused him of irresponsibility. Chilumpha said his party was sick and tired of Chihana's allegations, saying if he thinks he is righteous he should leave government because a clean person cannot mix with corrupt people unless he is corrupt himself. For his part, Munlo described Chihana as "a failure through and through in this part of Africa," adding he had no morals at all.

In another development, AFORD's Central Region Committee on 28 April unanimously joined their northern region counterparts and agreed that their party should pull out of the government, citing, among other reasons, UDF's failure to fulfill its pre-election campaign promises and soaring commodity prices.

Meanwhile, a commission of inquiry set up to probe the cause of the fire that gutted the office of the General Manager of Malawi Petroleum Control Commission in October 1995, has reached its conclusion. It has establised that the operation was planned by Aubrey Chalira, PCC's Financial Controller, to defraud the PCC of US$73,000.

Following the findings the Financial Controller was sacked from his job and the fraud referred to police for further investigation.

The commission recommended an improvement in the security and management of the parastatal organisation. A petroleum supply study, coordinated by the Energy and Mining Ministry and assisted by the World Bank, is currently underway and it is hoped the findings will help improve management of the commission.

Malawi Paper And Pulp Project For Shores Of Lake Malawi


BYLINE: Malawi News Online May 3, 1996


LENGTH: 134 words


 

Blantyre -A proposal for a paper and pulp project to be established at Chintheche on the shores of Lake Malawi, has been resuscitated after a decade on the shelf. The project was shelved in the 1980s because of fears that the effluent caused would destroy the aquatic life of the lake.

A memorandum of understanding has now been signed between Birla Engineering Services of India and Malawi's Viphya Corporation Limited, paving the way for the project. Under the agreement, a number of other projects are to be implemented, including manufacture of organic fertilisers and charcoal briquettes.
