Africa News


May, 1996


Malawi Cultural Practices May Be Recipe for HIV


BYLINE: Malawi News Online May 3, 1996


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Blantyre - Health and social worker's in Malawi say that some of the country's traditional cultural practices and beliefs are a recipe for the spread of HIV.

Experts say, that a decade after they began sounding the alarm about the potential dangers of some of these harmful and archaic practices, people still want to do things in the same way as their forefathers before them.

Take "Jando" or "msondo", for example. Practised among the Yao and Moslem communities in southern and central Malawi, these are initiation rites where boys and girls, some as young as six, are introduced to sexual practice. At such ceremonies, they are encouraged to prove their sexual "fire power" - known locally as "kutaya fumbi" or "removing the dust". 

Another tradition is "wife inheritance", called "chokolo" or "kuhara", and practised in almost all parts of the country though most common in northern Malawi. "Chokolo" is whereby a man marries the widow of his late brother or relative.

Professor George Liomba, former manager of the National AIDS Control Programme (NACP), says that in Malawi, diseases are not understood in terms of viruses, bacteria, etc. Rather in terms of supernatural powers, possessed by villains who use them to make others ill. "As a result, some people ignore messages from the NACP and rather go to traditional healers. They wear charms around their waists during sexual intercourse to prevent them from contracting HIV.

Liomba says, "These are traditions and beliefs handed down from their forefathers and are refusing to be shaken off because, as their custodians maintain, they have stood the test of time." He also said that recognising these customs and practices is not to condemn them, as there are many good reasons why these cultural practices have been developed.

However, there is a need to adapt them to make them safer and, in some cases, stop them altogether. A countrywide campaign, started last week, will now scrutinise the cultural practices that may have a bearing on the spread of AIDS/HIV.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


349 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Sudan Bishop Max Continues Rights Battle With Khartoum


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 6, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Nairobi - When a delegation of 200 bishops, priests, sisters and other Catholic faithful went to Rome from Khartoum, Sudan last March for the beatification of Bishop Colombo, three state security people imposed themselves on them.

And after the formal beatification, the three men insisted they too would go on the pilgrimage to Assisi, Verona, Loreto, Milano and other shrines relevant to the occasion.

One person who was not impressed by all this, is the soft-spoken bishop of El Obeid, the Right Rev. Macram Max Gassis. He joined the delegation in Rome and quite early on objected to state security presence in the midst of a purely religious affair. 

"We saw they were determined to come up to the beatification, so we said okay. They could see the ceremony and return to Khartoum. But these men were determined to have their way - they had come for the whole period of the pilgrimage."

It was all part and parcel of Khartoum's policy of harassment of the churches, asserts Bishop Macram. This harassment has the prime purpose of reducing the churches to an insignificant minority. It is a tactic to paralyse the avenues of expansion of the church in Sudan," he adds.

For nearly 10 years now, Bishop Macram has been persona non grata in that part of his diocese under government control. Today he flies into areas controlled by the Sudan Peoples Liberation Army, (SPLA). He sees it as his cardinal duty to let the world understand the numerous trials and tribulations that the churches have to surmount in Sudan.

When the Pope visited Sudan in the early 90s, a number of Episcopalian and Catholic bishops said in a letter to the Pontiff, that while Khartoum may roll out the red carpet for him, he should keep in mind that the regime remained essentially ruthless and blood thirsty. "Their hands drip with the blood of innocent people..." the Sudanese clergy said in part.

Bishop Macram says he has no regrets reminding people in such strong language of the happenings in Sudan. Those who wish to witness this should visit southern Kordofan area of northern Sudan which encompasses the Nuba mountains, parts of El Obeid, Wau, Rumbek and Malakal Dioceses. "These are the areas of northern Sudan that are inhabited by African ethnic groups - the Nuba and the Dinka; an area where the regime's policy of Jihad or Holy War is acutely in evidence today."

Some 3 million people live within this area of southern Kordofan which demarcates northern and southern Sudan.

On March 23 to 24, a contingent comprising some 700 government of Sudan soldiers from the El Saraf el Ahmer garrison, descended on villages in Kondor and Toror in the Nuba mountains and set about looting and burning anything in sight. "More than 1,000 families are now homeless and without food," lamented Bishop Macram who flew into the Nuba mountains from Nairobi on April 14 and 15.

As a sign of contempt for the people, the soldiers urinated and defecated on the food stores or burnt granaries to ashes.

But most painful of all is that the marauding troops did not respect the sanctity of the churches in the area. They desecrated the Holy Eucharist and tabernacle, broke to pieces the figure of Christ on the cross, looted the statue of Mary and other church items, including benches and vestments. "To anybody who thinks this is propaganda, I say I have video pictures of what happened in those villages on that fateful day."

The bishop says the motive for these inhuman actions, is to make the people insecure and thus force them into "peace camps" on government held territory in Southern Kordofan. "The people are routinely promised food and medicines in these camps but the women and girls are raped or taken as concubines while children are taken into slavery. All this is in Gasper Biro's report on the human rights situation in Sudan."

Gasper Biro is the Hungarian United Nation's Special Rapporteur on Sudan. His most recent report on the situation was released in Geneva last February 20. It says extra judicial killings, disappearance of people, abduction of children for slavery and women and girls for concubinage or rape et cetera, are a way of life in Sudan. Biro, like Bishop Macram, is persona non grata in Sudan.

On the suggestion that what was happening in southern Kordofan was a purely regional affair, Bishop Macram is emphatic that Khartoum was quite aware. "They are quite aware and they have the power to stop it if they so wished," he toldAPS.

Could peace come to Sudan in his lifetime? Bishop Macram who is 58 years old, says the way forward lies in Khartoum subscribing to two fundamental principles: The principle of self determination for the South, Nuba mountains and other marginalised areas like southern Blue Nile and Southern Darfur; and The Principle of separation of religion from politics.

Unfortunately, asserts Bishop Macram, "in their narrow-mindedness, the rulers in Khartoum think that by admitting self determination for the South, this would entail separation of North and South.

"In reality determination entails not only separation but possibilities for consolidation of the union or a confederal or federal arrangement."

Bishop Macram revealed to APS that he had fully recovered from cancer of the bile duct. "My recovery is a miracle." He thanked the Jesuit community at Georgetown University in the United States for the help they gave him during the time of his illness. He was particularly thankful to Father Byron of the Jesuit institute who encouraged him to go to Georgetown in 1989, the same year he was declared persona non grata in Sudan.

Bishop Macram says with his new lease of life he intends to redouble his efforts to make the world aware of what was happening in Sudan. He would travel more often into SPLA controlled areas in Southern Sudan.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


350 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Madagascar


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 6, 1996 by A. Rakotondrandria


LENGTH: 2067 words


 

Antanarivo - President Albert Zafy, who came to power in a 1993 election following two years of widespread pro-democracy activity, is now under attack.

On April 15, Rev. Richard Andriamanjato, the Speaker of Madagascar's National Assembly, announced, on behalf of the most influential pro- presidential faction that they would "no longer back personalities but ideas." And that, as a result, the faction would be renamed "Rally for the Third Republic" (RP3R) instead of "Pro-Presidential Group". In clear terms, they are no longer "pro-presidential."

On April 12, another prominent member of the same faction, Mr. Alain Ramaroson, who is the leader of Rasalama Forces Vives - a large coalition of political and civil society bodies which constitutes Zafy's single largest political support - said that his group "no longer shared the same views as President Zafy". 

These two men were Zafy's most outspoken supporters. At the very least, these two statements constitute a last warning. And as expected, President Zafy reacted promptly in an address to the nation on April 20, promising to hold new discussions with his rebellious supporters, but only after he meets International Monetary Fund (IMF) Director-General who is due to visit Madagascar soon.

Reacting with disappointment to Zafy's April 20 address, the RP3R said on April 22 said that the entire government including the prime minister had to go.

RP3R members have been calling for an immediate cabinet reshuffle over the last six months but to no avail. They claim that Zafy's National Union for Democracy and Development (UNDD) party is over- represented within the government, which they term as "political sidelining.

In fact things are more complicated for the president, and this "last warning", more than simple family feuds, may prove fatal to his tenure of office.

Indeed this is not the first blow to Zafy's political base. Already a number of political groups which backed him during the 1993 presidential election have defected to the opposition. This category also includes others which ruled with him after his election - that of former Prime Minister Francisque Ravony and of former Industry Minister H. Razafimahaleo.

The civil service, which played a crucial role in the 1991 popular demonstrations leading to the fall of former President Didier Ratsiraka, last January held protests over unkept promises of better terms of service. Judges have been sporadically going on strike over the leadership's reluctance to put in place the independent judicial power enshrined in the Constitution. And Finance Ministry employees recently went on a 10-day strike which paralyzed foreign trade, calling for the sacking of the Finance Minister, a Zafy protege.

Urban workers are finding themselves squeezed by an apparently irreversible decline of their purchasing power, a decline which the President has not been able to contain although his powers were reinforced by a constitutional referendum about six months ago.

The urban workers are obviously losing patience. The Malagasy Consumers' Association (ASCOMA), a sort of loudspeaker for their concerns, recently raised its voice over an "unfair amount" of oil price hike. This prompted the Energy Ministry and the National Oil Company to give immediate extensive explanations.

Antananarivo University students conducted street demos a few weeks ago over a cut in the amount of their grants, which resulted from the new budget voted by an opposition-dominated Parliament. Antsiranana University students too also went on strike over the same issue.

The business community, along with a large section of technocrats and educated Malagasies, which have all from the onset always been doubtful of Zafy's ability and competence to rule the country, decry the current failure by the leadership to conclude agreements with the Bretton Woods Institutions (after five years of deadlock).

This statement seemingly closes all doors to any serious development in the economy of this Indian Ocean island off the South-East African coast. The Rev. Richard Andriamanjato, a prominent Protestant church leader (he was former general secretary of the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches-AACC) and current speaker of the National Assembly, is described by Malagasy political observers as the major stumbling block to the resumption of normal relations between this country and World Bank and IMF.

Where does the church stand in all these developments in Madagascar? After appealing to the president, about six months ago, to act to address the "considerable degradation of people's life, in all aspects", church leaders of the Madagascar Christian Council (FFKM) held separate meetings with Zafy and his prime minister on April 1 and 3, 1996.

Although nothing was disclosed about the main issues discussed, the simple fact that the FFKM - supposed to be a "politically neutral" body, although unity among Church leaders was very instrumental to Madagascar's transition to democracy - decided to make its voice heard at the highest levels, shows how serious the current situation is. The Church in this country is considered the "barometer of tolerance," particularly in political affairs.

Already, the Church viewed with some suspicion Zafy's personal attention to various traditional Malagasy "pagan" ritual ceremonies (given new prominence by his regime for cultural identity purposes) and to a new Freemasonry Grand Lodge chartered recently.

And on April 26, Malagasy church leaders announced that they would, under the prophetic role of the Church, monitor closely how President Zafy would implement the promises he made to the nation on April 20. In a statement read in the capital, Antananarivo, Rev. Josoa Rakotonirainy, the Secretary-General of the Christian Council of Madagascar (FFKM) reminded the President of his promise to strengthen democracy and decentralization, to "clean up" the state apparatus and reshuffle the cabinet. The FFKM stressed that as an elder, the president would have to keep his promises.

In short, Zafy is facing increasing protest from almost all quarters. Most of these protests are centred on the president's alleged incompetence to rule the country.

Very surprisingly and ironically, even his own cabinet ministers also at one time joined outspoken critics, lamenting that they could not work under the new budget. However, they did not show any intention to resign.

The new budget was voted by a Parliament currently dominated by the Opposition, a real peculiarity. In fact, Malagasy politics has always, to a certain extent, been an arena of squabbling power bases and shifting alliances whose key operators are mainly power-hungry individualistic factions obsessed with short-term political gains.

But this already self-destructive feature of Malagasy politics seems to have been immortalized by a new concept which, in all likelihood, underlies the current political system. The concept was described more or less openly but furtively - and proudly - by the same Rev. Richard Andriamanjato as "variable-geometry democracy", referring presumably to a sort of self-regulating or self-balancing mechanism aimed at preventing any possible domination of the political arena by a single party.

Translated into facts, the doctrine results however in an elusive and shifty majority within the yet unexperienced Parliament. And since elusive majority also means elusive support, President Zafy finds himself ruling without "reliable" support and is therefore vulnerable to the most trivial issues threatening the "interests" of the political factions.

Although the president managed on a few occasions to superimpose another "order" on that highly volatile political arena, by striking the old tribalistic chord of coastal-Merina rivalry (coastal people said to be of "African" origin, and Merina people of "Asian" origin), this time the trick may not work.

Indeed among those who are persistently calling for him to resign are prominent coastal politicians, and since the current balance of forces is clearly not in his favour, other coastal politicians might well prefer recruiting another coastal man to replace him.

Apart from his own party (a very small party now strengthened by the magic of political patronage), the only possible "allies" remaining for President Zafy may be the inertia of the Army and rural voters, as well as the fact that Malagasy people have become contemptuous of the political community as a whole.

The Army, though urged by some opposition political parties to take over power, seems to be still busy forging a new image in a democratic era where its slightest departure from a neutral stance would raise eyebrows.

Rural voters - unless they are bullied by Zafy's political operators pushing to turn the president's party into a strong ruling party - may continue to view him as "that humble president who bothered to visit us in our remote village" (Zafy has not stopped criss-crossing the whole country for about five years now).

And to be able to stay until the 1998 presidential elections, Zafy may also count on a new feature of Malagasy society; people's general disillusion at and contempt to the political community as a whole as well as on their lack of interest in anything related to political activism. A phenomenon which also explains why the opposition is currently finding it difficult to gather meaningful popular support for their cause.

But the more and more organized and united opposition, operating both from within and from outside Parliament is increasing its pressures. Majority-holder opposition Mps, frustrated by the president's reluctance to recognize their "right" (as a majority) to govern, vow to resort eventually to an "impeachment" move provided in the Constitution.

Former President Ratsiraka, now in France for health reasons, has called for early presidential elections.

Meanwhile, another opposition group, the SFFF (Platform for Reflection on National Recovery), operating from outside the Parliament through what it calls "street democracy" (demos, calls for general strike, etc.), says that Zafy has to leave office by May 1996, adding that so far peaceful means to oust him have proved inefficient.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


351 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large High-Level UN Session Emphasizes Africa Focus


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Nairobi - For the first time in his capacity as the chairman of the United Nations Administrative Committee Coordination (ACC), United Nations Secretary General Dr. Boutros Boutros Ghali visited Kenya to preside over the ACC meeting from April 28 to 30.

ACC is the highest level coordination body in the UN system, whose members include the executive heads of all United Nations organizations and agencies.

The meeting in the Kenyan capital was the first of the twice-yearly ACC session to be held in a developing country. 

The high level meeting focused on the implementation of the new UN Special Initiative for Africa which was launched by United Nations system through a global tele-conference in cooperation with the World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF) on March 15.

In remarks broadcast world-wide, the Secretary-General called on the global community to join in an effort intended to benefit millions of people in Africa.

"This is the first time the United Nations will work in an integrated manner to promote development of an entire continent," the Secretary General stated on his arrival in Kenya.

The meeting also discussed the development of a system wide approach to implement programmes of action adopted at the international conference and summits convened over the past three years.

On the second day of his visit Dr. Boutros Boutros Ghali met Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi at State House here.

During the meeting at which President Moi pledged his full support for United Nations activities for peace and security in Africa, the two leaders reviewed issues of peace and security with special reference to situations in Rwanda, Burundi, Somalia and Sudan.

Also discussed at State House is the series of United Nations initiatives to reverse the trend of political and economic marginalisation of Africa.

Responding to questions from the press as to why it had taken too long to end marginalization and develop Africa, Dr. Ghali said development problems cannot be solved in a moment.

He charged that with the end of the Cold War a few years ago, Africa is still experiencing donor fatigue characterized by internal wars.

"Efforts to contain marginalization have been mentioned in meetings in China, Japan and Korea," said Dr. Ghali, adding that it is important to have inter agency participation in solving the problem.

Dr. Boutros Boutros Ghali stated that efforts are underway to see to it that in the coming 10 years Africans will have less foreign assessors. This phenomenon will be replaced by great market economy on education, health and sanitation.

He dismissed allegations that the United Nations offices are to be transferred elsewhere outside Africa, saying; "I have heard these stupid stories for the last 20 years."

The Secretary-General agreed with criticisms over withdrawal of peace keeping forces in Rwanda, saying any human organizations may have successes and failures "but this was the member states' decision."

Asked how confident the UN is to raise 25 billion dollars for the newly launched UN Initiative for Africa with the prevailing financial problem in his organization, Dr. Ghali said there is enough support for the UN as an instrument to promote peace, national reconciliation, settling disputes and dealing with refugee problems.

While in Kenya, Dr. Ghali also received a delegation of African Ambassadors accredited to the United Nations office in Nairobi.

The meeting agreed on the importance of retaining the United Nations office in Nairobi (UNON) as the only centre in the developing world.

Dr. Ghali cautioned that the financial situation of the UN and budget reduction voted by the General Assembly had led to the present financial difficulties felt by the office.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


352 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Angola Returning Refugees Face Landmine Threat


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Windhoek - Some Angolan refugees, who would be repatriated back home when a church-sponsored programme gets underway are likely to be affected by landmines planted all over the country, according to a regional conference on church refugee activities in Southern Africa, held here from April 22 to 24.

And the 40 delegates to the conference who included church refugee workers, church leaders and officials from the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) and the Geneva-based World Council of Churches (WCC), recommended that Angolan churches should be ready to give the returnees guidance.

Henry Odraa-Raga, the AACC Project Officer for Refugee and Emergency Services, who attended the conference, says the proposed repatriation programme is scheduled to take off mid this year. 

"But this will depend on many things. These include the proposed visit to Angola by both the chairman and the Secretary of the AACC refugee regional committee for southern African region, Rev. White Rakuba and Rev. Shirley Diworlf respectively," Odraa-Raga toldAPS.

He pointed out that the outcome of the visit by representatives of the refugee committee to Angola will form a basis for the financial commitment and modalities to be used to implement the repatriation programme.

Quoting some statistics presented at the conference by an official from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), Mr. Odraa-Raga said there were an estimated 120,000 Angolan refugees in Zambia, 200,000 in Zaire and another 5,000 in Namibia.

According to Mr. Odraa-Raga, the conference for the Southern African region was part of the AACC/WCC efforts to regionalise the refugee activities on the African continent.

"We have already held one for Eastern Africa region and we are scheduled to hold a combined one for Western and Central Africa regions in Accra, Ghana from May 20 to 26," noted the AACC Project Officer.

The week-long conference, which was attended by among others the AACC General Secretary, Rev. Jose Chipenda, the head of the Refugee and Emergency Services at the WCC, Mr. Melaku Kifle and the General Secretary of the Council of Churches in Namibia, Rev. Dr. Ngeno Nakamhela, discussed various subjects under the topic "Southern African Churches in Ministry with Uprooted People".

Addressing the meeting, Rev. Chipenda welcomed the idea of "regionalising" the church sponsored refugee activities in Africa.

"The aim behind the move is to take the refugee issues closer to the people and churches in general. As churches, refugee and church workers,let us help the entire church in Africa realise this dream," he said.

In his address, Rev. Nakamhela noted that during the years of the struggle for independence, the Namibian churches ministered to people uprooted by the system of migrant labour.

Another group of people uprooted in Namibia's recent past were those who went into exile during the struggle for independence, Rev. Nakamhela further told the conference delegates.

After independence in 1990, the churches rendered counselling services to families of exiles and those repatriated. The churches were also active in Namibia's resettlement programme for thousands of people who returned from exile in other parts of Africa, Europe and North America, the CCN General Secretary told the meeting.

Angola, which has faced one of the most intensified civil wars since independence in 1975, has some 638,430 internally displaced people.

Other statistics show that the country is severely affected by between 9 to 10 million land mines.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

353 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Church Asked To Facilitate Free Flow Of Information


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Nairobi - It is important that the Church creates an enabling environment that facilitates free flow of information both within the church structures and in society at large.

These sentiments were expressed at a recent workshop here which brought together Church communication workers drawn from Anglican, Presbyterian, Methodist and African Instituted churches countrywide.

The 35 participants discussing various topics under the theme, "Communication for Participatory Democracy: How will they know? agreed that one cannot participate without information.

However, hierarchical structures are such that information is left to the top of the structures, and the majority who will be affected by any decisions made never quite understand the circumstances surrounding certain decisions. 

The communicator thus has the vital role of being the bridge builder between the hierarchy and members as well as among the members so that all can be persuaded to take a level ground to change their society for the better.

Workshop participants noted there was a need for the church to create a value system for society by exploring good values and recognizing her ethical and moral mission as the conscience of society. This would in turn enable participatory communication that allows the free flow of information, challenging authoritarian and autocratic tendencies. The church should also be a fore-runner in recognizing the role of women and changing society's thinking on the political and social status of women.

Communicators were urged on their part to research well by especially being sensitive to people's needs and know what is in the public interest. They should strive to remain beyond manipulation, identify with the marginalised in society and give a voice to those from whom one has been taken away.

Among issues highlighted was the lobbying for a community radio service to meet the needs of rural people who presently have no form of community expression other than local dances and informal meetings.

According to Bishop Horace Etemesi of the Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) Diocese of Butere, Western Kenya, community expression such as dances and local songs should also be used to compose Christian songs so that people are not uprooted from their cultural roots when they adopt Christianity.

In giving guidelines towards "developing a media policy for the church", Bishop Etemesi said media have a prophetic mission and one working in that sphere is bound to face tremendous challenges, suffering and sometimes even ridicule.

But one must be courageous enough, having studied the best means of communication and the risks involved to move right ahead with the venture. One must be careful to reach the targeted audience and be willing to stand by the truth no matter the consequences, noted the CPK clergy.

One should also find out what the targeted audience likes reading, in what language, how often and also know what radio programmes they listen to. There is also a need to have an in-built evaluating process that checks the goals against achievements, disparities and their causes as well as committee or board performance. The question: "What is unique about our product?" should be asked.

The Rev. Joyce Karuri (Anglican), the World Association for Christian Communication-Africa Region (WACC-AR) Treasurer, lamented that although the Bible is the most political book ever published and 70 per cent of Kenyans are Christians, very few of them hear their civil and political rights advanced from the pulpit.

She noted that Christ was never the passive observer but rather the active participant in cleansing the temple when it was turned into a den of trade. He actively participated in setting things right.

The Rev. Martha Ngugi observed that among the ranks of ordained ministers, men still enjoyed better benefits than women for similar jobs. For instance, although both men and women go through the same theological training programmes, it is automatic for a man to be ordained while a woman takes a much longer time.

The chances of promotion up to the level of Bishop are obviously higher for the man and this means better terms of service, better salaries and other emoluments.

Yet God shows no partiality when He uses people in His vineyard as instruments for restoring order in the world.

Rev. Ngugi advises the various women groups found in the churches to stand together in unity to challenge the policies, structures and patterns which prevent them from holding decision making positions. She urges the media to continually play up the positive image of women as achievers and keep this agenda high.

Ms. Jane Gitau, Director of Communication in the CPK cautioned church leaders against taking the influence of mass media or congregations for granted. She said mass media not only challenge the faith of believers but also present a plurality of faiths with impartiality. They reveal the fact that Christianity is not the unchallenged world religion it was assumed to be 50 years ago.

Gitau observed that Christian communication must be revolutionized by awakening the conscience and reflecting the cooperate witness of the Church as a healer, liberator and giver of life. It must enable the people articulate their own needs, serve truth and challenge falsehood as well as be prophetic.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Cameroon and Nigeria Embroiled in Peninsula Dispute


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Lagos - Cameroonian forces in the disputed Bakassi peninsula have killed one Nigerian soldier and left two other wounded in an ambush on April 24, Defence Ministry deputy spokesman Colonel Godwin Ugbo announced here on April 26.

Ugbo said a Nigerian military vehicle carrying out a routine patrol of Nigerian positions in the border territory on the Gulf of Guinea was ambushed in an attack and accused Cameroon of carrying out offensive operations since the start of the week, although the situation had calmed down by April 26.

On April 26, Nigerian Information Minister Walter Ofonagoro said skirmishes had taken place on April 21 and April 23, and blamed the Cameroon side for opening fire first on both occasions.

The minister warned Cameroon to cease and desist from further acts of aggression on Bakassi, a continued escalation of the conflict in the peninsula cannot serve any useful purpose. 

On April 25, Brigadier-General Victor Malu, commander of the Nigerian 82nd division at Enugu in the east of the country, whose forces are deployed in the peninsula, held a meeting with his officers and the captain of the vessel Victor Ombu, chief of naval forces in the east of the country.

Nigerian press reports gave no details of the meeting, held in Calabar, the capital of the southeastern Cross River state.

But on April 27, Cameroon counter-accused Nigeria of launching new attacks on its territory in breach of its international obligations and demanded that Abuja pull back its troops to the positions it occupied on the disputed Bakassi peninsula last February.

Foreign Minister Ferdinand Oyono said in a statement that Nigerian troops had attacked Cameroon troops on the peninsula "on April 21, 22, 23 and 24."

The object of the attacks, he said, was "to occupy positions ever deeper in Cameroon territory."

The attacks were "a flagrant violation" of a March 5 ruling by the International Court of Justice in the Hague, calling on the two sides to pull back to positions they held before February 3, he said.

The statement was Yaounde's first official reaction to a series of frontier incidents reported by Nigeria over the past few days.

The Bakassi peninsula is an area of some 1,000 square kilometers, believed to be rich in oil as well as fish stocks.

Both countries massed soldiers there following clashes early in 1994. At some points, their troops' positions are only about 100 metres apart.

The last clashes occurred in February, leaving four dead and 13 wounded on the Nigerian side, Nigerian press reports said. Cameroon radio spoke of one dead on each side.

In late March, the International Court of Justice in the Hague, which had been asked by the two countries to rule on the dispute, called for troops on both sides to pull back to positions they held before February 3.

The court also asked them to refrain from all military operations on the peninsula, and to respect ceasefire agreements reached by their Foreign Ministers in Kara, Togo on February 17.

On April 24, sources close to the Red Cross said the Cameroonian authorities were still holding 30 Nigerian civilians taken prisoner during clashes on the disputed border territory of the Bakassi Peninsula in February.

Representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) in Yaounde have visited the detainees and confirmed that they were civilians taken prisoner by Cameroonian troops during fighting on the Gulf of Guinea peninsula between February 3 and 17.

But the Nigerian Defence Ministry spokesman General Fred Chijuka denied the Cameroonian government's claim that they were holding 30 Nigerian military prisoners-of-war, including a general, saying the detainees were Nigerian fishermen captured by the Cameroonian forces.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


355 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large Pan-African Consultation Examines Theology and Culture


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Nakuru,Kenya - African theologians have been asked to help interpret the gospel message according to the people's cultures.

This appeal was made by theologians attending a pan-African consultation here, some 160 kilometres north-west of Nairobi. The 15 participants called upon fellow theologians to make a serious analysis of African cultures and bring new African insights that are needed for the growth and understanding of the church in Africa. 

According to the communique issued at the end of the April 14 to 20 consultation, the African theological hermeneutical (scriptural interpretation) framework that is emerging raises concerns over elements in African cultures and in the Christian tradition that are not consistent with the gospel.

The week-long meeting was jointly organised by the department of Theology and the Christian Education and Family Life Education Programme of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC).

The communique pointed out that results of the study process on gospel and culture at the national level show that Africans have affirmed the gospel as the Good News of Salvation.

But because the gospel came with a different cultural garb, churches in Africa have been struggling to make it relevant to their value system in spiritual matters, the statement added.

The gospel read and interpreted by an African, must be heard speaking to Africans in a language that they understand, noted the theologians. They added; "The language and interpretation must bring Africans together and do away with divisions that are killing the African race.

The participants also discussed the influence of mega cultures which they argued, threatens the future of African cultures and the hope for generations to come.

They observed that the existence of African instituted churches and emergence of new churches such as the Rima church in South Africa, among others, is a sign of the dissatisfaction from the missionary oriented churches and the cultural influence that accompany their mission.

According to the meeting participants, the African cultures have been trampled upon and "thus our understanding of and living the gospel expectations is seriously compromised."

The inhuman division of the African continent which includes the cries and bleeding of African children in Rwanda, Burundi, Sudan, Somalia, Liberia, Sierra Leone and elsewhere, "challenges us to ask whether the gospel has equipped us as African churches to say or do anything about these situations," observed the theologians.

In his opening speech, the AACC General Secretary, Rev. Jose Chipenda stressed the centrality for the study process of gospel and culture for the church in Africa.

"The study is central for the church in Africa, especially at this time when the continent is faced with issues of globalisation, privatisation and fragmentation," said Rev. Chipenda.

Stressing that the gospel is the future of mankind, the AACC head stressed that the question at hand is: "How do we use it to bring unity among the people of the world and Africans especially?"

According to the communique, the study will form the position paper to be presented at the forthcoming World Conference on Mission and Evangelism which will be organised by the World Council of Churches (WCC) in Brazil later this year.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


356 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia Peace Hopes Nosedive Following Heavy Fighting In Monrovia


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Monrovia - Hopes for peace have nosedived in the Liberian capital as rival gunmen fought in the streets of Monrovia on May 1, forcing hundreds more civilians to flee to a residential compound that has become a teeming makeshift refugee camp.

The militias traded gunfire near the Barclay Training Centre, a military barracks that has been at the centre of the latest flareup in Liberia's six-year-old civil war.

Sporadic machine gun fire could also be heard at Mamba Point, where most embassies are located. 

Fighting had spread to that area on April 30, and US marines guarding the American Embassy shot unidentified gunmen who had opened fire on the facility. Three Liberians were killed, US officials said in Washington.

It was the first clash in Monrovia involving US forces. The fighting that has ravaged the city since April 6 pits Krahn fighters against gunmen loyal to warlords Charles Taylor and Alhaji Kromah, both of whom sit on a collegial presidency formed under a peace agreement signed in August.

It all started when police acting on orders from Taylor tried to arrest Roosevelt Johnson, former leader of a Krahn faction, on charges of murder. Johnson's fighters went on a rampage, and the city quickly degenerated into violent anarchy.

The Krahn forces overran part of Mamba Point on May 1, but pulled out when the rival militias showed up.

A ceasefire in force for nine days was shattered on April 29 when the presidential palace was attacked.

The U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, George Moose, was supposed to meet with factional leaders on April 30 to try to restore the ceasefire, but the meetings were cancelled because of the fighting.

Moose, the US administration's top official on Africa, who had arrived in Monrovia on April 30 to try to break the elusive jinx bedeviling the battling factions, had to spend the night in the embassy and left on May 1 following the failure of his mediation attempts.

Moose, who had been planning a six-nation tour, was not able to speak to any of the leaders of the battling factions in Monrovia before his unscheduled departure for Washington via Abidjan in neighbouring Ivory Coast.

The city was calm overnight but heavy machine gun fire erupted at dawn outside the Barclay barracks, a Krahn stronghold.

Several hundred women and children were seen fleeing to Greystone, a residential compound near the US embassy, joining the estimated 25,000 displaced persons already there.

Nearly 270 US marines are in Monrovia guarding American diplomatic installations. They are part of a larger expeditionary force of 2,939 troops, most of whom are stationed off the coast of five US warships.

The Liberian crisis led the US military to evacuate over 2,000 US citizens and other foreign nationals.

The peace accord signed last August was this west African country's 11th attempt at ending the civil war that broke out in 1990 when Taylor led a rebel force that invaded from the north and ousted longtime dictator Samuel Doe.

The collegial presidency formed under the accord is an interim government that is supposed to lead the country to elections.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Nigeria Religious Tension Leads To Clash In Kano


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Lagos - Muslims observing a religious holiday in the northern city of Kano attacked Christians praying nearby and left about 20 people injured, four of them seriously, residents said on April 29.

The clash occurred on April 28 at Bayero University in Kano. The injured included a Briton who teaches geography at the institution. He was treated in hospital for deep cuts on his head, face and arms, the residents said. 

They said the incident occurred as a group of Muslims were praying on a field to mark the Islamic feast of Eid al-Adha, which marks the end of the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca.

The Muslims, who said they had been disturbed by the Christians, also broke windows and doors in the lecture hall where the Christians were praying, residents said.

The Christians at the university have not been allowed to build a church so they use classrooms as places of worship.

Kano, capital of the state of the same name and Nigeria's second largest commercial centre, is predominantly Muslim and over the past 15 years, it has seen many religious clashes.

The latest clash comes only two weeks since Nigerian military junta of General Sani Abacha sacked the northern Nigerian-based spiritual Muslim leader Ibrahim Dasuki on charges that he misused funds donated for the building of mosques and for other purposes and replaced him with a new leader, Mohammed Maccido, who took over on April 21.

According to reports published here on April 29, Muslims in southern Nigeria have questioned the authority of the new northern-based leader of the country's Muslim community, the first time the authority of Nigeria's Muslim leader, known as the Sultan of Sokoto, has been openly challenged. Sokoto is a city in northern Nigeria.

Kazeem Akerede, president of the League of Imams and Alfas (Islamic teachers) in eight states in the southwest and in central Kwara and Kogi states, challenged whether Maccido or any occupant of that office is in fact the spiritual leader of all Nigerian Muslims, who number 47.2 million out of a population of more than 100 million.

Speaking at a news conference at Akure on April 29, Akerede said that the sultan "is only a traditional ruler in his town but not a spiritual leader of all Muslims in the country."

He said that the sultan's leadership of the Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs did not automatically make him head of Islamic faith in Nigeria, as the council "was not for all Muslims.

Religion is not a political party but a spiritual matter and our guidance springs from the Koran," added Akerede.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


358 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Sudan UN Sanctions Readied for Khartoum


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service May 6, 1996


LENGTH: 627 words


 

United Nations- Diplomatic sanctions against Sudan adopted by the United Nations Security Council take effect on May 10 over Khartoum's presumed links with terrorism and its refusal to extradite terrorists who tried to murder Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak at last June's Organisation of African Unity (OAU) summit in the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa.

The mild sanctions, aimed at securing the extradition of Islamic suspects wanted in connection with the assassination attempt on Mubarak, were contained in resolution 1053 adopted here on April 26.

But two states in the 15-member Council, China and Russia, signaled their unease about imposing sanctions by abstaining in the vote. 

Several speakers noted that the resolution provided for discussion of possible further measures against Khartoum in July, and expressed concern about the use of the sanctions weapon which they said could backfire against the international community.

The measures which come into force at 0401 GMT on May 10 provide for travel restrictions affecting Sudanese government officials and diplomats, and cutbacks in the number and level of Sudanese diplomatic missions worldwide.

The resolution also calls on Khartoum to desist from supporting terrorism, a charge strongly denied by Sudanese Ambassador Ali Mohamed Osman Yassin.

The resolution, co-sponsored by five non-aligned countries including Sudan's neighbour Egypt, was the subject of tough negotiations for weeks and Egyptian ambassador Nabil Elaraby stressed that the Council had taken pains to ensure that the Sudanese people would not be hurt.

While Russia and China abstained in the vote for various stated reasons, the United States ambassador had warned that his country "did not believe the sanctions outlined in this resolution were sufficient to convince the government of Sudan to cease its sponsorship of international terrorism."

At the same time the Security Council was imposing sanctions on Sudan, the US State Department also announced that Sudan would remain on its "black list" of seven countries that support terrorism which, which it promised to release on April 30.

But Arab states, including Egypt whose president was the victim of the assassination attempt, had also balked at imposing harsh international sanctions against a third Arab government, after Iraq and Libya.

The Sudanese ambassador noted that his country was the third in the region to be hit by sanctions, saying: "Can we consider this a coincidence, or is this a deliberate scheme against that region, its cultures, its peoples, and its faiths," and protested that the Security Council, which called on Sudan to "ensure extradition to Ethiopia of the three suspects sheltered in Sudan," had failed to take note of Khartoum's efforts to track down the suspects.

The resolution provides for the Security Council to discuss Sudan's compliance with the resolution 60 days after May 10, and to decide then whether further measures are necessary.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

May, 1996


Ethiopia Third Prosecution Witness in Derg Trial


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency May 2, 1996


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Addis Ababa - The third witness of the prosecutor said he has not heard members of the then ruling Derg forwarding at their general meeting the idea of bringing the 59 officials of the Derg before the court of justice prior to passing a capital punishment on the victims.

The individual who began witnessing Monday said the participants of the meeting were armed with dangerous weapons other than hand guns. 

The meeting was undemocratic, highly dominated by the dictatorship of Colonel Mengistu Haile mariam, he added.

The witness said he was not sure whether or not all members of the Derg had participated in the meeting held at the Grand Palace in 1974.

The witness had served with the then ground force in different capacities and was the chairman of the so called Revolutionary Campaign Co-ordinating Committee.

The First Bench of the Central High Court in yesterday s session has heard the cross examinations on the third witness while continuing to hear the fourth witness of the prosecutor.

360 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa High Drama In Constitutional Danger Zone


BYLINE: The Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 3, 1996 by Gaye Davis


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

Johannesburg - Scenes of high political drama played out in Parliament's old Assembly chamber early on Thursday morning when African National Congress negotiators declared deadlocks with the National Party on single-medium instruction, property rights and the employers' right to lockout.

The crisis, culminating at the end of a marathon all-night session of the Constitutional Committee, brought the process to the brink of collapsing into deadlock- breaking mechanisms provided for in the interim Constitution - setting negotiators face-to-face with the possibility of the country having to go to a referendum.

The ANC was committed to going the referendum route if the deadlock could not be broken, ANC MP Carl Niehaus said on Thursday. "Warning lights are flicking. We feel so strongly about it that we are prepared to go that route, rather than compromise," he told the Mail & Guardian. 

Efforts to resolve the impasse were to resume on Thursday after party caucuses. The Constitutional Committee was to reconvene on Friday to consider ANC proposals on the issues. The parties agreed to try to resolve the three outstanding issues before 10am on Friday.

The Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) has meanwhile called a special meeting of its central executive committee for Monday, when it will consider the progress made. Cosatu secretary general Sam Shilowa told the M&G the federation would mobilise its members if there was no agreement, focusing action - in tandem with the ANC - on a referendum.

Exhausted negotiators left the chamber around 5.30am on Thursday with a warning from a disappointed Constitutional Assembly co-chair Cyril Ramaphosa ringing in their ears: "The route we may embark upon in the next 24 hours, if we do not reach agreement, could well spell disaster for our country. The entire world had hoped we would draft a Constitution in peace," he said.

After ANC negotiators declared they were unable to reach agreement with the NP on the three issues, NP negotiator Roelf Meyer said his party believed resolution was possible, and declared the NP's commitment to reaching agreement. His proposal for a 24-hour adjournment, "to put in every effort on resolving the outstanding matters", was carried.

ANC negotiator Valli Moosa expressed doubts, however. Moosa said for the ANC, the three rights - all issues around which apartheid had revolved - were central to South Africa's transformation. To compromise would be "a betrayal of victims of apartheid".

Moosa was no longer certain agreement was possible. The ANC would table amendments on the issues on Friday: "If there is no agreement, we will in any case ask for a decision so that the Bill tabled does not have blank spaces."

When the Constitution is tabled for the vote, it will be voted on as a whole, not clause by clause. Should the NP vote against it, the ANC will still be able to reach a 51% majority. In terms of the deadlock-breaking mechanisms, the Bill then goes to a panel of experts, which must present a new draft within 30 days.

If a fresh vote still fails to reach the required two-third's majority, the ANC will have the option of drawing up its own text. All deals and compromises reached between the parties so far would, in this event, probably fall away.

Adoption of the new text would require only a simple majority. It would then have to be certified by the Constitutional Court as compatible with the 34 principles in the interim Constitution. If certified, it would then go before the country in a referendum, and would be adopted if there was a 60% majority.

Ramaphosa started sifting through the deadlock-breaking mechanisms at 3am on Thursday, "when it became clear to me these outstanding matters were becoming unresolvable", putting the process in the "danger zone".

He warned that if negotiators took "a wrong turn in the next 24 hours", they "could do something to regret for many months, if not years, to come".

The country's transition was still fragile, he added. Resorting to the deadlock-breaking mechanism had implications for the country in terms of the economy, race relations and reconciliation: "All sorts of things start coming undone - the centre may not hold."

Some might think it "fashionable" to hold to a position "and even become a bit arrogant and say to hell with them", but it was time to think about South Africa, he said. "For me this is a very sad moment. One had hoped we would never reach this stage." Based on his experience over the past months of the spirit of give and take in resolving problems, he had been "brimming with optimism and sending out positive signals that we would resolve our problems".

Earlier, Ramaphosa listened to ANC negotiators reporting on the deadlocks. MP Blade Nzimande said the ANC was trying to accommodate every language group in the country with a clause allowing education in the language of choice where reasonably practicable. The NP's desire to have single-medium instruction entrenched signalled a return to Verwoerdian apartheid.

Baleka Kgositsile said the NP was not negotiating in good faith on the property clause: political agreement was reached last Sunday based on a formulation agreed to at the Arniston bosberaad two weeks ago.

Willie Hofmeyr said the ANC had tried to accommodate the NP on the lockout clause, as well as its fears on the other issues. The deadlocks all focused on where the NP was trying to depart from internationally accepted rights in a bid to preserve privilege.

Roelf Meyer told the gathering the transparency of the Consitution process meant both the ANC and NP had come under pressure from constituencies outside the Assembly and that parties alone were not to blame for the impasse.

He told the M&G the ANC and Cosatu had been unable to agree on the lockout clause, an assertion denied by ANC MP Phillip Dexter, one of the South African Communist Party representatives in alliance talks on the issue.

"The NP's game all along was to try to split the alliance on the issue because it knew the ANC was under pressure from employers as well as from Cosatu. The game has been to drive a wedge between the ANC and Cosatu.

"The leadership of the ANC has been absolutely firm on the issue. It has considered ways of dealing with the problem, but will not put lockout into the Constitution, whether in drag or through the back door."

Shilowa said alliance talks had been easier than those with ANC negotiators who were "in the heat of things". He said: "We were dealing with a situation where the ANC would want to ensure that a referendum would not be a result of lack of trying (to reach agreement) on the ANC's part."


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


361 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Somalia No End In Sight For Banana War


BYLINE: The Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 3, 1996 by Moyiga Nduru


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Johannesburg - A banana war between two of Somalia's main warlords is under way over the control of the lucrative banana export trade.

The forces of General Mohamed Farah Aideed, the self-proclaimed president of Somalia, are pitted against the militiamen of his former financier, Ali Hassan Osman "Atto".

Aideed needs the revenues, estimated at around $800 000 a month, to pay his soldiers as he tries to establish his control in the Bay and Bakol regions and take on the Rahenweyne clan. Atto, in a lose alliance with another self- proclaimed president, Ali Mahdi Mohammed based in northern Mogadishu, wants to deny him. 

Renewed clashes beginning last month have left scores of people dead, as business leaders and elders attempt to negotiate a truce.

"What's happening in Mogadishu is an economic war; an attempt to control the port of Merca and Somalia's lucrative banana trade. That's why the fighting is not being joined by other Somali factions," says Hussein Ali Dualleh of the Nairobi-based Somali Affairs Monitoring Committee.

Atto and Ali Mahdi blocked Aideed from using Mogadishu port last October. Fighting again flared in March when Atto demanded that the warlord either share the revenues from Merca or see that port closed.

In the battle that followed, Aideed's forces were overrun. A full-scale war was averted after elders of the Habir Gedir clan, to which the two warlords belong, persuaded Atto to withdraw.

As they pulled back to Mogadishu, Atto's militia felt "humiliated and bitter", according to a Somali elder who refused to be named, "and they immediately attacked Aideed's forces. That's the origin of the present conflict."

Before Somalia collapsed into the anarchy of warlord politics with the overthrow of former dictator Siad Barre in 1991, the country was earning some $20-million annually from banana exports. That represented around 15% of the country's total export earnings.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Zaire Russian Pilots Go On Trial


BYLINE: The Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 3, 1996 by Chris McGreal


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Johannesburg - The judge rattled his bell in a vain attempt to restore order in the crowded Kinshasa courtroom. But most eyes were on the Zairean television reporter who had marched to the bench and fired off the question on many lips.

"Everybody knows these men are guilty. Why are you wasting everybody's time?" he scolded a defence lawyer. 

As a murmur of agreement swept the room, the two Russian defendants looked despondently about.

"You can't just determine who's guilty. You can't prejudge," their lawyer said.

Some spectators agreed, but only because they harboured theories of cover-ups, gun-running and even sorcery in the presidential palace.

In the dock stood Nicolai Kazarine and Andrei Gouskov, Russian pilots who had been in Zaire just three days in January when their cargo plane barely lifted off from the heart of Kinshasa before dropping back to earth in the midst of a bustling market at the end of the runway.

As the propellers carved their way through the stalls, 225 people died. The carnage was so complete that only 66 bodies were identified.

The prosecutor, Jean Mukenge Bisumbule, alleges that the old Soviet Antonov plane was travelling at barely half the required speed when it lifted off. Mukenge blames an excess of vodka for the pilots' slow reactions.

Kazarine, dressed in a worn T-shirt, frayed track-suit bottoms and flip flops, denies he was drunk. He claims the plane was grossly overloaded by a Zairean official who falsified documents and has since disappeared.

"The prosecutor accused us of being drunk without any proof. All these attempts to abuse us are to divert the court from the real causes of the catastrophe. The company overloaded the plane and wants to blame us," Kazarine said.

The Russians have been in jail for three months, supposedly to protect them from victims' relatives. But some survivors who attend each session of the trial, usually held on one day a week, say the real criminals are government officials who permitted a market at the end of a runway. Others, such as Dimba Lutomadio, who saw her 65-year-old mother killed and her younger sister lose an arm, see a conspiracy.

"This trial is a masquerade. The lawyers are creating confusion so we do not find out what really happened. They were not taking it seriously so we stopped them outside here and told them we would burn their cars. Now they have admitted that the plane was chartered by a general close to President Mobutu. Now we want to know where that plane was going and what it was doing," she said.

While the charter company, African Air, insists in court that the flight was carrying food to southern Zaire, the pilots say from their cells that they were on an illegal mission to deliver supplies to Unita rebels in Angola.

"African Air couldn't file a flight plan to Angola because these flights are illegal. That's why they gave our flight plan as Kahemba (in Zaire). I've done it many times before, but I don't know if there were weapons on board - we didn't check the boxes," Kazarine said.

But the word in Kinshasa's shanty towns is that President Mobutu sese Seko engineered the plane crash as part of some ritual Satanic sacrifice to bolster his power. The president is also blamed for a series of bus crashes, a train wreck and even a cholera outbreak.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


363 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zimbabwe A New Independent Voice Arrives


BYLINE: The Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 3, 1996 by Richard Saunders


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

Johannesburg - A new independent newspaper will hit Zimbabwe's streets next week in an effort to keep alive a faltering voice in the national press.

The Zimbabwe Independent, a business-oriented weekly, comes in the wake of a crisis in the independent press which has seen many publications disappear or teeter on the brink of financial collapse.

After blossoming in the wake of political liberalisation in the late Eighties, Zimbabwe's celebrated private sector press has been buffeted in the Nineties by the strong winds of economic reform.

High interest rates, soaring production costs and restricted consumer demand led to shrinking margins. As a result the commercial foundations of the private sector press have been severely eroded, and the scope and national reach of published opinion has narrowed. Zimbabweans might now feel freer to criticise government and debate national policy, but there are few places where their voices can be heard. 

After a flurry of publishing activity featuring a rash of new titles in the early Nineties, Zimbabwe's publishing giants reasserted themselves. Today the market is dominated more than ever by Zimpapers, the publicly owned government-controlled chain which publishes six papers, including four weeklies and the country's only two dailies.

But, whereas Zimpapers wields unchallenged command of market share, it no longer leads opinion.

"In the early Nineties ordinary Zimbabweans had a brief taste of a free press, and they liked it," says Independent assistant editor Iden Wetherall.

"Since then space has opened in the media market, because the broad readership has become more sophisticated. Zimbabweans will no longer accept news which is hidden, distorted or massaged by editors unashamedly beholden to the government."

Zimpapers' primary unearned advantage rests in the fact there are few alternatives.

A clutch of smaller monthlies and weeklies, addressing themselves to narrower communities, have mostly shied away from trying to establish a broad national presence. A limited set of popular magazines, which have been more politically adventurous, have had muted impact because of their limited publication frequency and distribution.

On the other hand, newspapers which have tried to break the Zimpapers monopoly have been confronted by the enormous and rising costs involved - and by a government jealous off its privileged access to the national press.

The latest victim of tightening margins and the ruling party's political sensitivities is Modus Publications, where spiralling debt fuelled by punishing interest rates forced the closure of two papers and the editorial reining-in of a third, the respected Financial Gazette.

Once a leading exponent of critical opinion and debate, the Gazette's editorial independence gradually fell prey to demands from Modus's owners, themselves under pressure from their creditors at the government- controlled Zimbank.

In the wake of management's increasing admonition to ease up on criticism of the government and ruling party, Gazette editor Trevor Ncube and several other senior editorial staff left the paper this year.

Since then, Modus has struggled to maintain the Gazette's traditional readership and advertising base. Staff and infrastructure have been pared back sharply, in a desperate attempt to cut costs and stay afloat.

All of this - the financial collapse of Modus and the political crumbling of Zimpapers' legitimacy - has left a gaping hole at the heart of the Zimbabwean newspaper market, which the Independent aims to fill.

With solid capital, management and editorial resources (including a translocated senior editorial team from Modus, headed by former Gazette editor Ncube), there is a good chance it will succeed. Nonetheless, the paper's backing raises questions about where the Independent's support comes from, and which national voice it represents.

The Independent's leading investors, Clive Murphy and Clive Wilson, have been important players in the local industry since the Eighties, when both were involved in the ownership and management of the Gazette. In 1989 they sold their controlling interest in Modus to the company's curent owners, a consortium of black businessmen led by former Zimpapers CEO, Elias Rusike. In the following years Murphy and Wilson consolidated a new publishing company and developed a national distribution agency, both of which will now help support the Independent.

If the origins of the paper's capital backing expose it to populist attacks from government and an increasingly militant black business "indigenisation" lobby, the composition of the Independent's editorial staff make it difficult to sustain this line of criticism.

The editorial team insists it has been given firm guarantees of editorial autonomy by the Independent's owners, and that the previous editorial line developed during tenure at the black-owned Modus will be maintained. That stance included support for meaningful "black empowerment" measures, as well as government's punishing economic reform programme.

But both these positions may well become sticking points for the Independent in the current era of indigenisation politics, which has seen pressure groups calling for the rapid indigenisation of the economy.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


364 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Truth Commission: Two Tales Of Contrasting Trauma


BYLINE: The Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 3, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

Johannesburg - For some people just telling their story is a comfort, but the truth commission is finding it harder to solve some of the other problems.

Two very different people walked into Johannesburg's Central Methodist Church this week and, beneath the stained-glass images of Christ on the way to Calvary, sat to tell harrowing tales which tested to the full the truth commission's offer of comfort and catharsis.

George Dube's story begins with a relentless diet of fish and beans in an Umkhonto weSizwe training camp in Angola. He explained how, fed up with the meals that were upsetting his ulcers, he sold some belongings to an Angolan soldier for a bus fare to Luanda where he would explain the problem to his commanders. 

On the way to the bus stop some Angolan policemen stopped him. Dube could not speak Portuguese. They could not speak English. He had old Angolan currency on him. And he had grown a beard. The Angolans deduced he was one of Jonas Savimbi's foreign mercenaries and took him to a nearby prison.

Dube spent three years there during which time he was joined by another 11 ANC members suspected of being spies. He says there were regular beatings by the Angolan warders and one of his friends, Tom Mabinda, was shot dead in front of him by the guards.

His account of prison conditions deviates into an account of the appalling food. People in the audience giggle at the cranky man who has clearly become obsessed with the workings of his stomach.

It is around 4pm and the hearings are running two hours late. One of the commissioners, Bongani Finca, tries to hurry him up.

Dube says the group was transferred to an ANC rehabilitation centre after staging a hunger strike. There they were forced to do hard labour. "I was beaten every day. It would be your lucky day if you were not beaten ... I have seen movies about slavery and they way we treated it was like hell," he claims. "I prayed that I would wake up being dead ... that they would separate my soul from my body."

There were regular torture sessions to extract confessions from the spies. "I didn't know what to tell them because I have never been a spy."

Three years later Dube and some of the others were released and sent to a camp in Uganda. "The commissar said 'Congress sometimes makes a mistake'." And the detainees were told they would be sent back to the camp if they told anyone of their experiences.

Is there anything else he would like to tell the commission, asks Finca. "Listen my friend they used to make us run to the toilet. There was no walking there. And then you couldn't sit there and reflect. It was half a minute and you were out." And when he asked for stomach pills he got headache pills and headache pills when he wanted stomach pills.

More giggles from the gallery.

Finca asks if there is any request Dube would like to put to the commission. He explains he had tried courses in bricklaying, farming and cooking at the ANC camps but failed all of them. "I still want to learn to be a chef because I like cooking. I was asking them to send me to a school like this very school for cooking which I wanted."

Dube appears to be a lonely and confused man unable to find any coherent explanation of the trauma he has been through other than that he complained of eating too much beans and fish. Psychologists describe the condition as shattered cognition.

And when he walked out of the church it was clear that, unlike the man depicted in the beautiful windows above him, Dube had not found the meaning and understanding that would be his first step on the road to healing. Nor is he likely to find any place in a school for cooks.

For Hawa Timol it must have been very different.

The ailing old lady on crutches, flanked by caring and nurturing sons, explains in broken Gujerati how the security police broke her heart when they came to say her son, Ahmed Timol, had jumped from the 10th floor of John Vorster Square.

"I told the man he should go home and ask his wife what it means for a mother to rear a child and never see him," she says.

Later, after repeated raids and interrogations, they came again to say her other son, Mohammed, would only be released from detention if he agreed to work as an informer. "I told them that if my body had a zip they could open it and see how I was aching inside."

This time there is no laughter in the gallery, only tears and a lump in every throat.

Mohammed Timol, who survived his term in jail after the brothers were arrested in 1963, explains how his brother had worked in the underground of the South African Communist Party and the ANC.

For him and his mother, it is intensely gratifying that Ahmed is receiving the recognition he deserves. "He was one of the many South Africans, young and old, to bring about a democratic dispensation in South Africa." He asks that the school in Roodepoort where he taught be given the name Ahmed Timol.

They know why he died and, to use chairman Archbishop Desmond Tutu's words, their appearance at the commission is an exquisite example of how just being given the chance to tell it "brings Christ's ointment into their hearts and souls".

The commission is like a treadmill of truth. There is a tension between the need for succinct and well-organised information and the patience and time needed to help victims reorganise their basic understanding of what happened to them.

Sometimes, when there is a yawning gap between the need for caring on the part of commissioners and pressure to speed things up so the distressing business can get done for the day, its cathartic intent breaks down. So the Dubes of the struggle present the truth body with a formidable challenge.

"One needs to separate out the different needs and wants that victims have and also have a finer understanding of the various types of victims who appear before the commission. They are people with very different expectations," says Brandon Hamber, a psychologist at the Centre for the Study of Violence and Reconciliation.

For some, reparations will be more important than the public hearings. Various groups have raised different requests for compensation at the commission. Some have asked for welfare grants. Others want symbolic recognition in the form of tombstone or a moument. In the Eastern Cape there was a common call for help with the education of young victims.

"The most profoundly worrying group is young people from the twilight period in the 1990s. Many of them probably played the role of victim, witness and perpetrator during the violence of the time. They are young and resentful and face a bleak future. It is hard to say how the commission will respond to their needs," says Hamber.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa Court Ruling Could Paralyze Truth Commission


BYLINE: The Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) May 3, 1996 by Mungo Soggot


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Johannesburg - The truth commission could be paralysed by being forced to operate like a normal court after the Cape Supreme Court's decision this week to allow retired policemen access to truth commission documents, lawyers said this week.

They said the decision could set a precedent which opened the gap for other judgments to order the commission to cross-examine witnesses - a move which would slow down the commission's proceedings considerably.

Judge E King on Tuesday ordered the Truth and Reconciliation Commission not to hear any evidence affecting the two policemen - retired police Brigadier Jan Abraham and retired General Nicolaas Jacobus Janse van Rensburg - until they had been given advance warning of any evidence which might implicate them. The policemen were also granted access to the commission's documents. 

Lawyers, who cautioned they had examined the controversial judgement, said it appeared the policemen and others could now seek interdicts ordering the commission to gag or censor witnesses.

In letters to the policemen, the commission has alleged that they were connected with the disappearance or poisoning of someone in Port Elizabeth in 1981. Sapa reported Judge King said: "This is a test case and if it has far- reaching implications then so be it."

One prominent constitutional lawyer said the judgment appeared to have struck a balance between ensuring the commission carried out its exposure of apartheid's horrors as dictated by the interim Constitution, and protecting the right of individuals not to have their reputation assaulted.

He said that although the Cape Supreme Court decision set an important precedent, it did not mean that other provinces could not take a different line. There was also a chance the commission could appeal against the decision.

Another lawyer said there was a danger the decision set a precedent which would make the commission function like a court, slowing down its proceedings considerably.

He pointed to the ominous reaction to the judgment by four former national police commissioners, who warned the commission that it would be hit with similar court applications if it did not allow the cross- examination of witnesses.

Mike Geldenhuys, Johan Coetzee, Hennie de Witt and Johan van der Merwe told Sapa: "The way in which members and former members of the police have been placed in a bad light by some vague allegations, generalisations, hearsay evidence and apparent untruths cannot be tolerated any further."

The legislation which set up the commission does not stipulate that witnesses should be cross-examined and it provides witnesses with a qualified privilege. This gives them a defence to defamation providing their evidence is not motivated by malice and providing it reflects their honest belief.

Judge King's judgment, which was still being examined by the truth commissioners at the time of going to press, is not the first legal challenge to the commission.

Last month the families of several leading apartheid victims sought an interdict against the commission's amnesty committee, arguing that the granting of amnesties violated their constitutional right to civil actions against their relatives' killers and torturers. Judgment in this case has yet to be given.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
