Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large (DOCUMENT) Nigeria and Kenya Two of the World's Worst Press "Enemies"


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (New York) May 2, 1996


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

New York - The leaders of China, Nigeria, Turkey and Kenya are among 10 world figures identified by the U.S.-based Committee to Protect Journalists as "Enemies of the Press." All are responsible for brutal campaigns against journalists and press freedom, as documented by CPJ in its ongoing monitoring of press freedom violations worldwide. The "Enemies of the Press" list is released annually on May 3, World Press Freedom Day.

Heading the list for the second straight year is Abu Abdul Rahman Amin, the head of Algeria's rebel Armed Islamic Group, who claims responsibility for many of the 58 assassinations of journalists in Algeria since 1993. 

"Each of these 10 men is actively committed to the eradication of the independent press, " said William A. Orme, Jr., executive director of CPJ. ""Scores of working journalists were killed, imprisoned, or driven into exile as a result of their direct or covert actions."

The Enemies of the Press:
1. Abu Abdul Rahman Amin, leader of the Armed Islamic Group of Algeria. His insurgent faction has claimed responsibility for many of the 58 assassinations of journalists in Algeria over the past three years. Rahman Amin has threatened all secular journalists with death. "Those who fight with the pen," he proclaimed, "shall die by the sword."

2. China's leader, Deng Xiaoping. China's nonagenarian strongman may no longer run his government on a daily basis, but his ruling philosophy-"socialism with Chinese characteristics"-continues to serve as a pretext for the complete suppression of independent reporting. When it takes over Hong Kong in June 1997, Deng's regime is expected to muzzle one of the most vibrant and pluralistic news centers in all of Asia. As the man who ordered the June 1989 crackdown in Tiananmen Square, which included the imprisonment of China's leading journalists, Deng is directly responsible for restricting the press freedom rights of more than one-fifth of the world's population.

3. Nigerian President Sani Abacha persecutes independent journalists by ordering or encouraging editorial office bombings, seizures of periodicals and equipment, and the arbitrary detention of journalists, often without charges. One result is a steady stream into exile of the profession's best and brightest. For those who stay, the risks are great: in 1995 four journalists were sentenced by a secret military tribunal to 15 years in prison for reporting on dissident army officers accused of plotting the overthrow the regime.

4. Turkey's Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz runs a government that at any given moment holds more journalists in jail than any other in the world. Yilmaz has done nothing to improve on his predecessor Tansu Ciller's dismal press freedom record. At the end of 1995, CPJ documented 51 cases of Turkish journalists who were then in jail simply for exercising their profession. Most were imprisoned for reporting that was allegedly sympathetic to the Kurdish cause. Despite international criticism, Yilmaz has so far chosen to retain and enforce the notorious Articles 7 and 8 of the Anti-Terror Law and Article 312 of the Penal Code, which effectively criminalize independent news reporting about separatist movements, army counterinsurgency tactics, Islamic fundamentalism, and other topics central to the country's political life.

5. Tajikistan's President Emomali Rakhmonov. President Rakhmonov has overseen the systematic elimination of independent Tajik news media. The paramilitary forces he commanded during the recent civil war were responsible for many of the 27 death-squad killings of journalists between 1992 and 1994. All independent local news organizations have been forced to close, and hundreds of Tajik journalists are in hiding or in exile. The repressive Rakhmanov regime is wholly dependent on Russian military and economic aid.

6. Indonesia's President Suharto. President Suharto has orchestrated a two-year-long crackdown on the country's independent press. After banning three leading newsweeklies in June 1994, his regime brutally suppressed demonstrations by journalists and others against the closures. Last September, the leader of the only independent journalists union, Ahmad Taufik, and his colleague Eko Maryadi were sentenced to three years in prison for publishing an unlicensed magazine and supposedly subjecting the government to "hostility, hatred, and contempt." At least 80 members of Taufik's union, the Alliance of Independent Journalists, have been fired from their jobs due to government pressure.

7. Cuba's President Fidel Castro. Cuba remains the only country in the Americas without any independent publications or broadcasters. Reporters not employed by state media are not allowed to own or operate a computer or a fax machine. Independent local journalists who attempt to send news dispatches to clients abroad face such retaliatory measures as internal travel bans, overnight detentions , the harassment of friends and relatives, seizures of equipment, and threats of prolonged imprisonment.

8. Saudi Arabia's King Fahd bin Abdulaziz Ibn Saud. King Fahd uses his enormous financial and diplomatic clout to silence dissenting voices not just in Ryadh but throughout the Arab world. The Saudi press, though privately owned, is one of the most restricted in the world. King Fahd must approve the hiring of editors; he also can (and does) dismiss them at will. More disturbing still, the Saudi royal family has acquired the most important international Arab periodicals and broadcast outlets and uses its influence to suppress all criticism-indeed, all serious examination-of its business interests and diplomatic entanglements.

9. Kenya's President Daniel arap Moi. President Moi has declared war on the independent press and widened his net to include foreign correspondents. Critical coverage of Moi has been decreed a criminal offense, while newspapers and printers have been arbitrarily closed for publishing opposing viewpoints. Journalists covering the trial of human rights activist Koigi wa Wamwere were physically attacked by pro-government thugs. The government last year introduced a restrictive new press law, including government-mandated "codes of conduct" for journalists, only to withdraw the initiative in the face of fierce international condemnation.

10. Slovakia's Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar. In his latest assault on press freedom, the thin-skinned prime minister pushed through parliament an amendment to the Criminal Code that would imprison journalists and others found guilty of "spreading false information abroad." Since Meciar dismissed all but one of the 18 members of the state radio and television supervising councils in November 1994, the Slovakian broadcasters have become mouthpieces and apologists for the prime minister's increasingly autocratic rule. This backslide into repression bodes ill not only for Slovakia but for all of post-communist Central Europe.

The Committee to Protect Journalists documents and responds to press freedom abuses around the world. CPJ works to get detained journalists out of jail, directs international campaigns of protest against repressive governments, and provides practical safety information to reporters assigned to dangerous areas. CPJ is a nonpartisan, nonprofit organization financed wholly by donations from individuals, private foundations, and news organizations. More information about press freedom in more than 100 countries can be found in CPJ's annual report, "Attacks on the Press in 1995," available on CPJ's new World Wide Web site, http://www.cpj.org.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


381 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia Opposition Parties Lose Nikuv Battle


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 3, 1996 by George Jambwa and Masautso Phiri


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition UNIP and the Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) yesterday lost their bid in the Lusaka High Court to have the contract between the government and Nikuv Computers Limited, declared "null and void".

In a highly disputed judgment, described as "timid" by opposition parties, High Court commissioner Bonaventure Mutale, reluctantly declined to nullify the contract and the voters' register.

Commissioner Mutale could also not declare the US$18 million contract null and void because there was nothing in the appendix or the contract describing what the company was contracted to do.

In his judgment, commissioner Mutale found that although the exercise was fraught with irregularities, both in the employment of electoral officers and in the registration of voters, he was reluctant to declare the contract null and void. He stated that he found it difficult to nullify the contract when government had already paid US$6.87 million in tax payer's money and which action he felt would be disruptive to the country. 

"By this point the reason to quash it is unsuccessful," read Mutale in his two hour judgment.

Mutale also found that Nikuv was not registered in Zambia but said no evidence was adduced as to whether it was registered outside Zambia or not.

He agreed with the two applicants on this but said it was not enough to warrant the nullification of the contract because such an omission could only attract a criminal offence.

He instead advised the registrar of companies and the Director of Public Prosecution to prosecute Nikuv Computers Limited officials for flouting the country's laws.

The commissioner further agreed with the two applicants who argued that under the Constitution and the Electoral Act, the duty to register voters solely rests with the Electoral Commission and that the function cannot be delegated to the second respondent.

Commissioner Mutale, however, found that the Electoral Commission had done the registration of voters and had not abdicated its role. He said Nikuv was merely inputting data and later the production of voters cards.

Commissioner Mutale also agreed with the two political parties that it was wrong for the government to attempt to exclude the courts as they did in section 29 of the contract and to classify the contract as "secret".

"Although the contract was treated as classified 'secret' by the first respondent I lastly make no order to nullify it," commissioner Mutale ruled.

Reacting to the ruling soon after judgment was delivered, Liberal Progressive Front leader Rodger Chongwe blamed judges for their timidity.

"The judiciary is its own casualty until such a time they are ready to stand up for the people,"Chongwe charged in an interview yesterday at the Lusaka High Court . " It is not enough to say there is interference from the executive when judges fail to make a judgment."

Chongwe added: "It is not interference from the executive, it's the timidity of judges. It is sad that even lawyers in private practice fear standing up for the people."

And UNIP secretary general Sebastian Zulu, the second applicant in the matter, said the judgment clearly showed they had won the case because the court had found that registration was fraught with irregularities.

"The judge found that officers were appointed in their official capacity instead of by name as individuals," Zulu said. "Once he finds this it means that what they have done is null and void because they have no power to register."

Zulu dismissed commissioner Mutale's argument that the money spent persuaded him not to declare the register null and void.

"Consideration of money spent is absolutely irrelevant. If there is chaos in this country would you value it at $6 million?" Zulu asked. " What has money spent got to do with law when an act is illegal?"

Another lawyer who listened to the judgment said: "It's obvious that there is a lot of pressure on the judges."

And immediately after commissioner Mutale's judgment, Nosiku Kawanambulu, representing UNIP and LPF, applied for a stay of execution of judgment pending an appeal to the Supreme Court.

Commissioner Mutale who expressed his displeasure at the absence of the government lawyers set May 6 for the State's submission and his ruling on whether to stay the judgment or not.

"I do not understand how they can stay away when the state was represented by the Solicitor-General on this matter," commissioner Mutale said, advising Kawanambulu to express his displeasure to the government.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


382 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Business and Finance Zambia's Brewery Competition Fierce


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 3, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

Lusaka - Northern Breweries, the Copperbelt-based brewers of the popular Rhino lager and now awaiting privatisation are competing favourably on the beer market, though the company's profits are yet to be announced.

Surprisingly, its recently launched Rhino lager seems to be holding its own against Anglo American Corporation Zambia Breweries' Mosi . Unlike Mosi which is being brewed under the supervision of South African experts, Rhino is a product of the local 'boys' -- brewed in Zambia by Zambians for Zambians.

"Privatisation is one of the ingredients of the Structural Adjustment Programme. Its aim was to sell the badly administered parastatals to private individuals who could concentrate on running a profitable business and not on creating jobs as was the case with the parastatals,"said Muna Nakalonga, Coordinator of the Economics Association of Zambia. 

"Nevertheless, not all parastatals were badly run. ZESCO is a good example of a parastatal which maintained a steady pace. From what we can see of Northern Breweries, it is also doing well though it remains a parastatal."

On April 1, two years ago Zambia Breweries was officially taken over by ZamAnglo Industrial Corporation, the Zambian subsidiary of the South African mining giant, Anglo American Corporation.

The sale was on condition that the Lusaka brewery and the Northern division brewery in Ndola be split into two autonomous companies. Anglo had to forego their preemptive rights and sanction the government's decision to split the company when they were given a wholesome price of US$13 million for the Lusaka brewery.

And from then on, the struggle for lager hegemony between the two companies was set in motion.

According to the Zambia Privatisation Agency (ZPA), it was necessary to separate the two plants to ensure competition on the market.

After privatisation in April 1994, Lusaka Breweries allowed Northern Breweries only 12 months in which to come up with their own brand name, labels and patent. August 27, 1995 was the deadline for Northern Breweries to stop brewing Mosi and using its label.

In July 1994, ZPA finalised the transfer of Northern Breweries, formerly under ZIMCO, the then holding company of most state enterprises, to Northern Breweries PLc.

Meanwhile, Lusaka Breweries introduced new management from South Africa and halted production of a new beer, Kariba, deciding instead to invest $5 million to restructure its plant. But there were no retrenchments, as expected by the workers' union.

In 12 months, Northern Breweries on the copperbelt worked hard to introduce two new brands on the market, Ndola Supreme lager and Rhino, at a cost of over K1 billion.

And until one of Zambia's greatest entertainer and play actor Sauzande, in a television advertisement, told the public that he was "Anaza", Rhino was clearly not a famous lager, especially outside the Copperbelt.

But it seems Northern Breweries when launching its two lagers, in July and August 1995, had problems identifying the social class that really matters for its brands to succeed.

"At first, I thought it was a copyright advert! It seemed to be a beer for rich foreigners," said Esnart Tembo of Libala in Lusaka.

Ndola Supreme lager, with 4.5 per cent alcohol content, was released on August 2, just after the launch of Rhino with same alcohol percentage. But at best, the launch of the two beers was described as lukewarm by experienced marketers.

"They could have taken advantage of the commercial shows on the Copperbelt which coincided with their product launches but they seemed to have lost grip of their market," said Paul Kaluba, a regional marketing manager with Coca Cola.

"I think they had problems with distribution. Or maybe they were just learning to operate on the open market," observed Tony Equamo of Ndola.

In an interview in Ndola, Northern Breweries managing director Matthews Mulanda said all logistics had been put in place to ensure the brewery continued operations despite being severed from central breweries in Lusaka.

Fortunately for Rhino, the government in an unprecedented move had cut excise duty on beer from 125 to 100 per cent in January 1995. Some businessmen believe the measure helped prop up Northern Breweries.

"Otherwise they would not have survived the production costs after losing a viable market like Lusaka so suddenly," said Sunday Ngwenya of Mataela Bar in Lusaka.

Currently, Mosi on the Copperbelt is rarely found in pubs.

"We can't afford Mosi at K600 a bottle. One 'Shakers' at K550 is enough for the two of us and when I make a bit of money, I go for Rhino at K500," said Jasper Mambilima, a Ndola Taxi Driver.

Indeed, Rhino is now awash on the Copperbelt and has amazingly managed to turn the tide of public opinion in the country.

"It is very good beer and does not even leave you with a hangover in the morning," said Brian Mulenga of Lusaka.

Northern Breweries managing director Mulanda said he had plans to increase beer output from 4.5 million to 9 million cases a year.

Meanwhile, Mosi has also been vigorously campaigning for a share of their slipping market though from all accounts, they are barely holding on to the northern half of the country.

"Aah, there is no Mosi here. You can go to a hotel if you want Mosi," advised a sympathetic cab driver in the Ndola town centre on enquiry.

"What do you expect?" asked Lusaka Breweries marketing manager Morris McClurg. "A local brewery must be able to satisfy its customers. We do the same for Lusaka."

McClurg insisted that Chingola was still Mosi- prone though he agreed that the rest of the Copperbelt was leaning towards Rhino.

He said the Lusaka brewery's production of Mosi had not reduced but remained the same as last year at 75 million litres a year.

While Rhino is doing everything possible to stick to the K500 mark, Mosi has been coursing the price path and now sells at K650.

Lusaka Breweries management explained in an interview that the new Mosi prices are due to the high production costs as a result of increased taxation.

But both companies declined to give details on the status of their balance sheets. They could only point to the amount of investment being poured into their companies.

Northern Breweries have received orders for weekly supplies of 2,000 crates of Rhino lager from a company called Jefcom Impex of South Africa. Apart from that, the brewery has installed two boilers and plans to introduce plastic beer bottles and canned beer.

But regardless of the notable progress made by Northern Breweries, ZPA chief executive Valentine Chitalu said the company was soon to be privatised and three buyers had been shortlisted. And ZPA sources said Lonhro might emerge as the likely winner.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


May, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia: National Team To Shift Camp


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 3, 1996 by Reuben TOnga


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia national soccer team will on Tuesday shift its training camp from Luanshya Lusaka as preparations for a clash against Malawi hot up.

Camp manager Solly Pandor, in an interview yesterday, disclosed that the team, which has been camping in Luanshya is moving to start training at the BP sports complex in Lusaka to intensify preparations for an international friendly against Malawi on May 9 and 10. 

The team broke camp on Wednesday to allow players to feature for their clubs in league matches.

Pandor further disclosed that only Chambishi Blackburn's striker, Emmaunel Siwale is yet to join the team.

"It is only Siwale who hasn't yet reported to camp, all the others are there," Pandor said. "But Kingsley Ntoshya has been asked to take a rest because of injuries, otherwise everybody else including Dennis Lota is in camp."

May, 1996


Business and Finance Kenya Denies Advocating COMESA Split


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 3, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 93 words


 

Lusaka - Kenya has denied allegations made last year that it was amongst countries which were advocating for the split of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA).

According to the commercial attache at the Kenya High Commission, F. Makanga, "Kenya is solidly for COMESA not only by sayings but also by deeds" and that is why it sent a trade mission to Zambia in April.

385 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Africa-at-Large 'Southern African Journalists Ignoring Environmental Issues'


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 3, 1996 by Sundie Sinkala


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Kariba - Southern African journalists have been accused of neglecting environmental issues in preference to political and disaster news.

Journalists and the media in the region have not attempted to take keen interest in the many environmental problems affecting the people in order to bring awareness to their communities. 

Opening an environmental reporting workshop for Southern African Development Community ( SADC) countries in Kariba on Monday, Zimbabwean deputy environment and tourism minister, Edward Chiringa, said environmental reporting by journalists in the region has been sacrificed for political news .

Chiringa said the important subject of environment had been left in the hands of the foreign media which is not representing the correct position of the situation because they don't understand the local situation well.

He told the more than 20 journalists from the SADC region that there was need to rework the journalism training programme so that environmental subjects are incorporated in it.

"There should be a deliberate effort to incorporate environmental reporting in these training programmes," he said. " The current situation is not encouraging."

The minister also challenged governments in the region to come up with appropriate measures to ensure that funds raised for conservation of the environment are properly safeguarded.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia: Mwila May Trek To South Africa


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) May 3, 1996 by Brian Malama


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Lusaka - Melvin Mwila has been offered a deal to play for South Africa's Kaiser Chiefs, the Power Dynamos winger disclosed in an interview in Kitwe yesterday. 

But Mwila, who had sneaked out of the country without the permission or knowledge of Power officials, has been put on suspension and the club claims to know nothing about his South African professional soccer deals.

"I impressed many South African teams, including Orlando Pirates, Spur Amazulu and Sundowners," Mwila said. " But I was offered a two-year contract at Kaiser Chiefs."

Melvin, who arrived yesterday from South Africa, said however that he is yet to seal the deal as talks have to start between Kaiser Chiefs and Power Dynamos.

387 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Zambia News From Parliament


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency May 2, 1996 by Henry Ngilazi and Christine Mwelwa


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Lusaka - The Vice President, Brigadier-General Godfrey Miyanda disclosed in Parliament today that seven Zambians were shot by Namibian security forces, between January 1991 and January 1996 along the Zambia-Namibia common border.

General Miyanda said two cases involving the shootings at the border have been taken to court. He, however, assured parliament that the shootings have subsided mostly because of the 'good neighbourly' between President Chiluba and his Namibian counter-part, President Sam Nujoma and also through the Zambia/Namibia Joint Permanent Commission. 

General Miyanda was answering a question from Sesheke Member of Parliament (MMD), Richard Nganga, who wanted to know what positive results have been achieved on the compensation of Zambians shot along the border.

Parliament heard that the three defunct banks owed the Bank of Zambia about K65.1 billion in overdrafts on maize marketing.

Finance Deputy Minister, Koshita Sheng'amo, said in Lusaka that Meridien Bank Biao, Commerce Bank and African Commerical Bank owed Bank of Zambia about K65.1 billion in total between January 1995 and December 1995. Mr Sheng'amo said Meridien Bank owed BOZ about K44.2 billion while Commerce Bank's debt was at K10.9 billion and K10 billion for the African Commerical Bank.

Mr Sheng'amo also disclosed that about seven foreign banks were operating in the country from January to December last year. He said all the seven are still operating and non has been closed so far. The minister said the banks are Barclays, Standard Chartered, Stanbic, Indo-Zambia, Citi Bank, Cavmont, Inter-Market and the Discount.

About K8 billion was spent on the maintenance of the Zambia national team football players and officials during the Africa Cup of Nations competitions held in 1994 and 1996.

Sport, Youth and Child Development Minister, Leautenant-Colonel Patrick Kamfumukache, told parliament today that about K411,651,700 was spent on players and officials during the Africa Cup of Nations competitions held in Tunisia in 1994. Lt-Col. Kamfumukache said another K411,558,774 was spent on the players and officials during the Africa Cup competitions held this year in South Africa.

Col. Kamfumukache said the team performed well in both competitions but were only unlucky to have taken the second and third positions respectively.

A total number of 60 journalists resigned from the government owned media between January 1992 and January 1996 on account of poor salaries and deplorable working conditions and they left for greener pastures.

Information and Broadcasting Services Minister, Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, told parliament in Lusaka today that 25 resigned from the Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation (ZNBC), 10 from the Zambia Information Services (ZIS) and another 25 from the Zambia News Agency (ZANA). He, however, said that continuous dialogue has been progressing on ways and means of improving conditions of services in the three news organisations. He noted that the 60 journalists who resigned were mostly of degree and diploma holders who opted to work for the privately owned media in search of better incentives.

Defence Minister, Ben Mwila, said nine military helicopters were destroyed by fire in the hanger at the Samora Machel Air-base in Mbala between January 1989 and December 1992.

Answering a question from Member of Parliament for Mbala (UNIP), Yoram Chungu, the defence chief said the fire was caused by sabotage since investigations revealed that fuel tanks were left open to drip out. Mr Mwila said the government in the process lost a total of 7,120,000 United States dollars worth of property. He, however, refused to tell the House what measures were taken to prevent a future recurrence saying such defence matters should be left to be dealt with internally in the ministry.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


388 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


South Africa (DOCUMENT) Labor Group Hails 'Positive' Strike Action


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 2, 1996


LENGTH: 3120 words


 

Johannesburg - The following is a statement issued by the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) on the 24-hour general strike of April 30, 1996:

Today several millions heeded the call by COSATU for workers to embark on a general strike and occupy the streets in defence of their constitutional demands. COSATU is overwhelmed by the positive response of workers to its call. Initial estimation shows that 75% of workers in major industrial areas heeded the call. This being the first general strike after democratic elections shows that workers are not prepared to leave their future and demands to only those they elected into parliament. 

The strike comes with the background of threats of dismissals, disciplinary actions, lock-outs, and blackmailing. The fact that workers ignored all these threats from anti working class forces comes as no surprise to COSATU. Even the last minute attempt by the big capital blue eyed boys in the form of Democratic Party's Tony Leon, who yesterday declared our strike illegal, could not deter workers' resolve to fight in support of their legitimate demands. COSATU once more demonstrated that it has an organisational capacity to mobilise workers within a short period of time if there is a need. The strike was announced on the 20 April 1996 and in 6 working days we were able to pull more than 325 000 workers in the streets of major towns with millions heeding the call for a strike. It is a tribute to workers that despite the transport and logistical problems they faced, so many were prepared to come to the cities. In Klerksdorp alone more than 20 000 workers in the mines were left stranded without transport. There are dozens of such examples across the country as in most townships there were no running trains and busses. (See attached details of members who attended different rallies.) We also attach a separate statement for SACTWU indicating the levels of support in the clothing and textile industry.

We are particularly pleased that in true COSATU tradition, our strike was not accompanied by violence and intimidation. Despite the volatile situation in KwaZulu Natal, we were able to have a solid support from workers in that region. We are disappointed at the reported sporadic incidents of violence and intimidation in some of the townships in KwaZulu Natal.

We are reiterating our call to our members to remain on their toes for further actions as may be necessitated by the developments in the Constitutional Assembly. We are making a call to big business and National Party to drop their undemocratic demands. We hope that even at this late hour they shall review their current position and realise that our members together with the rest of the democratic South Africa shall not be held hostage by minority interests. We call on the African National Congress to stand firm on their positions and reject any clever formulation that will bring the principles on issues on dispute back on the constitution.

With regard to the lock-out clause, COSATU is interested in one thing - the removal of the entire clause. We will continue to reject any clever formulation that is intended to bring the lock-out clause in the constitution through the back door.

We acknowledge the participation of NACTU and whoever else supported us in our marches.

We call on employers who have threatened workers with lock-out action on the 03 May 1996 when they return, not to risk a chain of reaction by workers in defence of each other.

REPORT ON THE STRIKE:

North West:

Klerksdorp

Marchers marched to the offices of the NP where a memorandum was handed over to John Dow of the NP Local Council in Klerksdorp.

An estimated number of 22 000 mine workers were left stranded without transport.

15 000 Workers participated in the march.

Vereeniging

10 000 marchers went to NP offices but there was no one waiting to receive the memorandum. An unidentified person received it. The march ended at 12h10.

Mafikeng

Started at 11:00 hrs from Mafikeng square through Montshiwa to NWDC.

7 000 attended the march and the Memorandum was handed in at 12:30.

Western Cape:

About 15 000 marchers went to parliament. Tony Leon wanted to address the marchers but was refused. The DP refused to accept the memorandum.

Northern Cape/OFS

Kimberly

Workers marched to DP Offices to hand over and read to them memorandam. DP wanted to give them a memorandum, but the workers told them that they have to march if they wanted to give them a memorandum.

A number of 3000-4000 marchers was estimated. They handed the memorandum to NP offices, and headed for Taung rally.

No further reports on other areas were received.

Mpumalanga:

Secunda Stadium

5 000 people marched to the offices of the NP. The march ended peacefully at 14h00.

Nelspruit

The march in Nelspruit had an attendance of about 5000 workers. The march started at Valencia Stadium in Nelspruit at 12h00 and proceeded to the national Party offices in Brown Street.

The DP and BSA did not arrive to receive their memorandums and Mr Meyer of the NP refused to accept their memorandums. The local has written a letter to them to arrange for the handing of memorandums.

The march was well supported by alliance partners.

Witbank

The march started at 10:00 hrs, Ackerville Stadium to the Chamber of Business. Very few people in town and industrial areas totally deserted. 13:55 the memorandum was handed to the President of the Chamber of Business. They said they will respond in writing to Cosatu Head Office. Workers went back to the stadium and there was a report on May Day. Estimation is, +- 1500 people.

Piet Retief

A rally was held at Thandukukhanya Stadium at 11:00. They did not apply for the march to take place. Shops operating but industrial areas deserted. Public transport unaffected.

The rally was poorly attended +- 500 people.

Breyten

264 NUM members from TSELENTIS Collieries marched from the mine to NP office in Breyten.

Middelburg

March started at 9h00 from Mhluzi to Town Council offices. March was peaceful and attended by +- 1000. About 40% people did go to work.

Northern Transvaal:

Pietersburg

There were plus minus 10 000 - 15 000 marchers. The DP received the memorandum but they also wanted to issue theirs to the marchers but the marchers refused.

The march ended peacefully.

Rustenburg

The march started at 11:00hrs. There were about 5000 - 10000 marchers. The memorandum was submitted to the NP.

Pretoria

Attendance was exceptional. Estimation is 96000. No violence has been reported, the atmosphere was calm.

Marchers changed the venue, they no longer went to the DP Offices. They marched to the Union Building to submit the memorandum to DP Offices because the NP was not prepared to read it. They had a problem because DP wanted to allow only 500 people in their offices.

Two people from NP received memorandum and the marchers are going back to Brown Street where the march started.

Eastern Cape:

King Williams Town

2 500 people gathered at the gathering point of Town Square in front of the Offices of the Magistrate at 12:00hrs.

Port Elizabeth

Estimated more than 5000 workers participated, the march was peaceful.

Umtata

March took place to the Transkei Chamber of Commerce. No estimate figures supplied.

Queenstown

March took place to the Chamber of Business. No estimate figures supplied.

Grahamstown

A march to the Town Hall of Grahamstown where NP and Business representative received the memorandum.

Adelaide

A general meeting was held and attended by 150.

Uitenhage

A march took place, no estimate number available.

Butterworth

A march to the Chamber of Business took place, Les Hollbrook refused to accept the memorandum delivered by Alfred Mtsi.

Idutywa

Plus minus 800 people marched on the offices of business representatives to deliver a memorandum. The memorandum was received.

Witwatersrand:

Johannesburg

March took place, memorandums submitted to DP, NP, JSE. Estimated 80 000 people attended.

KwaZulu-Natal

Isithebe

People marched to the NP Offices, no estimated figures available.

Umlazi

There were barricades this morning and people monitoring them. They have been taken down now and the roads are open. SAHRWU members are still in Teyhuis Hostel. Shots have been fired from the hostel opposite Teyhuis Hostel. The town is quiet. They estimate 80% absenteeism in Durban. No serious injuries.

Kwamashu

100% stayaway - no buses or trains.

Eshowe

March planned but cancelled because of misunderstanding of the call.

Newcaste

Total stayaway. No incident reported.

Empangeni

Total stayaway with no incident.

Ladysmith

Total stayaway. No incident reported.

Kokstad

Total stayaway. No incident reported.

Pietermaritzburg

Total Stayaway. No incident reported.

PARTICIPATION IN THE COSATU ONE DAY GENERAL STRIKE, 30 APRIL 1996 - PRELIMINARY FIGURES FOR THE CLOTHING, TEXTILE AND FOOTWEAR INDUSTRY.

Summary

Estimated support for the strike among clothing, textile and leather footwear workers were as follows:

Natal: 75 000 workers (85%) Eastern Cape: 20 000 workers (75%) Western Cape: 43 000 workers (57%) Gauteng/NW Prov 22 000 workers (85%) Free State/NCape 11 000 workers (70%)

In all, about 171 000 textile, clothing and footwear workers took part in the strike. This equals 76% of the combined employment in the industry.

Below we set out some details. Note that the information covers only clothing, textile and footwear (CTF) workers, and is based on the latest available information.

Natal:

In Pinetown, 100% of members in the CTF industry took part in the strike.

In the Durban clothing industry, the participation rate was 80 - 90%. All the key factories closed down, including Frame, Romatex, Seardell and David Whiteheads.

We estimate that the overall participation rate in the strike in the province for the CTF sectors was 85%. Accordingly, at least 75 000 workers from these sectors were on strike today.

Eastern Cape:

In Port Elizabeth, 80% of the CTF industry took part in the strike, while in the greater East London area, it was 70%.

We estimate that the overall participation rate in the strike in the province for the CTF industry was 75%. Thus abut 20 000 workers from the three sectors supported the strike.

Western Cape:

Participation in the strike varied greatly, from support of 10% up to 100% being registered.

The textile workers largely supported the strike, and a number of large factories in the Boland, South Cape area and Epping closed down for the day. Support in the clothing and footwear industry was more mixed. In the Atlantis area, about 80% of clothing workers supported the strike. In areas such as Salt River, support was much lower, with many factories reporting 30% support for the strike. Some workplace in Parow had less than 10% absenteeism. There were on the other hand a number of clothing factories in the Cape Peninsula area, including a number of small and medium enterprises, who closed down completely for the day and where support for the strike was 100%.

Given these large variations, we compiled figures from a sample of 75 companies covering all three sectors, and the clothing retail sector. We estimate that the overall participation in these companies was 57%. The earlier rate, released at noon today, based on a sample of 63 companies, was 65%. Based on the lower 57% participation rate, a total of 43 000 workers in the textile, clothing and footwear industry supported the strike.

Gauteng and North West Province:

In Johannesburg, a 90% support was registered for the strike. In some of the decentralised areas, all workers observed the strike.

We estimate a participation rate of about 85% for the two provinces, and thus 22 000 workers in the three sectors were on strike.

Free State and N Cape:

Support for the strike was strong in Qwa Qwa, Kimberley and Botshabelo.

We estimate a participation rate of about 70%. Thus about 11 000 workers in the three sectors were on strike.

Preliminary figures released by SACTWU head office at 16h00 on 30 April 1996.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

389 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Arts, Culture and Entertainment New Dates for Southern African Film & TV Market


BYLINE: Film and TV Market Initiative May 2, 1996


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Johannesburg - The first Southern African International Film and Television Market which was scheduled to be held from 9 - 15 June, 1996 in Cape Town has been postponed to 13 - 17 November, 1996.

The decision to move the market back a few months was taken by the Board of the Southern African Film & Television Market Initiative (Section 21 Company - Association Not For Gain), based on the fact that the Market has grown far larger than anticipated with numerous ongoing enquiries from all over the world and, therefore, more fundraising and time, is essential to host this international event effectively. Other reasons include the fact that many international visitors are more in favour of a summer Market, given that many have location scouting on their agenda,

An official Film & TV Market office, by kind donation from the SABC, is now established and fully functional. Operational officers for this Market appointed by the Board include Gaby Keyser (Managing Director), Dezi Rorich (Market Director), Basetsana Thokoane (Director, Fundraising) and Carmel Adonis (Market Administrator). Chairperson of the Board is Richard Ishmail. 

Objectives: Given the explosive growth of film and television production in Southern Africa, and the increasing global interest in this region, it is now essential to host a formal Market which will -- under one roof -- introduce a new world of filmmaking in what is rapidly becoming one of the most sought after production centres in the world.

A priority is to open up dialogue not only internationally, but also with neighbouring territories in Africa, provide education and training through interaction and workshops with global film community, and develop new and young talent in the region. This international meeting platform will be an opportunity to:

* introduce foreign filmmakers and television to the unique character and culture of this region.

* discover opportunities in one of the greatest film locations in the world

* meet and trade with the Southern African business media, and find out about the commercial potential of this industry * gain information about locations, professional crews, talent, sophisticated production and post-production facilities and equipment, and other support services in the Southern African entertainment industry

* meet co-producing partners and exchange ideas with colleagues

* exhibit product

* view unseen product from the African continent

* learn about the changing face of the broadcasting industry

* meet an emerging generation of filmmakers and discover their cultural expression

The Programme of the Market includes --

The Business of Film - seminars covering Legal, Finance and Insurance topics.

*South Africa's 2nd International Media Exchange brought to the Market by Katrina Wood of the MediaXchange. A group of senior film and television professionals will discuss the mutual benefits of co-production and joint ventures with South Africa.

* A Co-Production Market to provide contact between film and television makers and financiers, both for ideas in developing and finished product. Sessions will be held each morning addressed by the visiting specialists concerning script development, financing and production, marketing and distribution, and secondary markets.

Training and Education featuring - An informative perspective on global changes and trends, and interactive technologies, and through an Advisory process Writers and Directors can workshop with professionals

Trade - Features, Documentaries, TV Product, this Buyers and Sellers market invites product for exhibition or representation. Screening facilities available on 35mm, 16mm and Video.

Shorts Showcase - An opportunity for first time Southern African filmmakers to exhibit their films.

African Focus - This program will exhibit completed product from the African continent, which can proudly boast some internationally competitive motion pictures. South African distributors FRU (Film Resource Unit) will premiere African feature films. A range of titles will be available for distribution.

Southern African Locations Expo - Will provide a guide to filming in numerous African countries. Community and Local Government liaison services are invited to participate. This Expo aims to be a helpful and informative guide for all on-location needs and production planning in these spectacular, diverse and hospitable regions.

The Market will also see the Inauguration of a new Southern African Script Fund, and the launch of the South African chapter of the international association, Women In Film

Marketing of the Market kicked off at the A.F.M. (American Film Market) where the response was extremely positive and key organisations pledged their support and involvement. The international Trades were all extremely interested in exhibiting for the first time in Southern Africa. The Market was also introduced at Screen Africa stand on the international Television Show in London, which so far has seen the greatest response from top calibre broadcasters, and film and television producers. Marketing continues at the current MIP Television Market in Cannes.

Invitations are currently being issued to global film and television makers, distributors and producers, as well as representatives of international Film Commissions, Institutions and Industry Affiliates. Within the Southern African industry enormous excitement exists for its first international Market, and expectations are high

For further information contact Film and TV Market Initiative, Tel: (27-11) 714-3229 or 714-3215. Fax: (27-11) 714-3275 or Motion Picture Marketing International, Tel: (27-11) 442 4790. Fax: (27-11) 447 2111. Web: http://www.showdata.org.za/market Email: saftvm@sabc.co.za


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


390 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


United States and Africa Corporate Executives On Trade Mission


BYLINE: The Corporate Council on Africa (Washington, D.C.) May 2, 1996


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Washington, DC - Beginning April 30, the Corporate Council on Africa delegation of American is leading businesses on a ten day trade and investment mission to Ethiopia and Eritrea. The Mission will be headed by senior executives of The Coca-Cola Company, Mobil Oil, AT&T, Anadarko Petroleum, F.C. Schaffer and Associates, and Equator Bank Limited. The purpose of the visit is to expand the commercial relationship between the United States and these two African countries by forging solid business partnerships. According to both the Eritrean and Ethiopian Embassies in Washington, this is the largest trade delegation of U.S. executives to ever visit these countries.

Eritrea, Africa's newest country gained its independence from Ethiopia in May 1993. Located strategically along the Red Sea in the Horn of Africa, this country of four million people is engaged in an effort to build a new national. Eritrea's economic development will be fueled by a combination of crude oil reserves, strategic minerals, and financing from the international community. 

Eritrea possesses over 670 miles of coastline along the Red Sea. In addition to its mainland, Eritrea is made up of over 350 islands in the Red Sea, of which 210 comprise the Dehalak Archipelago. In close proximity to the Middle East, tourism in this region of Eritrea is rapidly growing, offering many opportunities in the hotel and tourism industries. The natural deep-water harbor in Massawa will permit Eritrea to serve as a gateway of goods for East and Central Africa, and the Middle East.

Ethiopia, making a strong recovery after twenty one years of totalitarian rule, is aggressively seeking to reclaim its place as one of Africa's wealthiest nations. Possessing Africa's second largest market with over 60 million people, Ethiopia is poised for a period of rapid economic growth that will be fueled by its agricultural and mineral wealth, as well as a bold initiative to build a modern network of roads and transportation.

Ethiopia possesses trade and investment opportunities n almost every commercial sector. The development of strategic mineral deposits such as gold, platinum, marble, copper, and potash, as well as expanded agricultural production, will place huge demands on Ethiopia's infrastructure which will need to be completely modernized over the next decade. Demand from the Ethiopian consumer, who is expected to benefit from Ethiopia's new policies of economic and political liberalization, will create opportunities in a broad range of industries, from electronics and construction materials to basic consumer and health care products.

Other American companies and individuals participating on the mission include: Adeemera Enterprises, Inc., Allied International Marketing Corporation, Bay Area World Trade Center BTB Trading Carson Services, Inc., Development Concepts, Inc., Eli Lilly & Company, General Motors Corp., Global Business Access, Ltd., Hebret, Inc., Honeywell, IBEX Group, International Wireless Incorporated, ITEPS Limited, Inc., Mid-West Textiles, Inc., MWI Corporation., Navistar International, Pegasus Gold Corp., Mr. Jeffrey Prosser, SEAIR Transport Services, Inc., Spatial Data Institute, Standard Commercial Tobacco Co., State of Georgia, Takeze Production, TDC Energy, The Westar Group, Towill, Inc.

The corporate Council is a non-profit organization of over 90 American businesses and individuals whose goal is to promote policies in both Africa and the United States that will build and strengthen the African private sector. To this end, the Council is committed to working with the governments of Africa and the United States, as well as the African private sector, to improve the trade and investment climate in Africa, and to increase the commercial interaction between the American and African private sectors.

The Council believes that the growth of jobs and new enterprises in Africa will form the foundation for Africa's economic development. By fueling economic growth, new trade and investment in Africa has the potential to contribute, ultimately, to the material well-being and prosperity of the African people. In simple terms, the Council believes that profitable U.S. commercial involvement in Africa will create jobs and begin the cycle of building a market on this continent of approximately 600 million people.

The Corporate Council on Africa was founded in 1992.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


391 of 391 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1996


Liberia Liberians March in Washington For Peace


BYLINE: Africa News Service May 2, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1987 words


 

Washington, D.C. - The following statement was issued by participants in an April 26 march from the White House to Capitol Hill by several thousand Liberians and others in support of peace.

We, Liberians residing in the United States of America, representing a cross section of our people, along with our international friends, are gathered in Washington, D.C. for a peaceful demonstration. This represents the largest gathering ever of Liberians in the United States, united with one voice, petitioning the American Government to assist our country in its darkest hour of peril.

We have come in unity and solidarity to express our profound appreciation and thanks to the international community, especially the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the Organization of African Unity(OAU), the European Union, the United Nations and the United States of America as well as many non-governmental organizations, for their continued efforts toward ending the Liberian civil war. This civil war, which has been raging over the past six and a half years, has claimed the lives of nearly 200,000 people, mostly defenseless civilians, and created approximately two million refugees and displaced persons. These tragic developments have devastated the entire country and its already fragile infrastructure. 

The long suffering Liberian people have worked strenuously and steadfastly in pursuit of, and maintained a spirit of hope for, a peaceful resolution of the conflict, but peace continues to elude them, despite the numerous peace accords which the warring factions have signed over the past six years.

These accords have resulted in the formation of several interim governments, either with the consent of, or controlled by, the warring factions, but have failed to end the war and bring peace, primarily because the said warring factions have consistently and defiantly violated the terms of these agreements with impunity.

The peace-keeping force ECOMOG, which was sent to Liberia by ECOWAS leaders in 1990, continues to make great and supreme sacrifices. But inadequate funding, manpower and logistics have compromised ECOMOG's ability to implement its mandate of peace-keeping and enforcement.

We are cognizant of the fact that Liberians in the USA have heretofore failed to present a united front with a common message on the Liberian crisis. This failure has contributed in part to the prolonged crisis, which has resulted in the near annihilation of our people, the massive and widespread destruction of our country, the utter humiliation of Liberians and the looming dissolution of Liberia's sovereignty. It is for these urgent and compelling reasons that we have come to express the sentiments and desires of the majority of our people in Liberia, Africa, the United States and other parts of the world, who are crying for and demanding peace.

We are aware of the swift and decisive action which the United States Government, in the wake of the latest crisis, has taken within the past several days, in deploying a contingent of troops on the ground Monrovia, and providing $30 million for material and logistical support for the peacekeeping operation. We are also aware of the high-powered delegation, headed by Deputy Assistant Secretary of State William Twaddell, which the Clinton Administration has sent to Liberia to work with ECOWAS and the combatants in the search for a lasting solution to the crisis. From the depths of our hearts we extend to President Clinton and the American Government and people our gratitude for these concrete and timely initiatives.

At this juncture, we respectfully appeal to President Clinton and the American Government to continue to exercise U.S. leadership in the search for a lasting solution to the Liberian crisis. Specifically, we call on the United States to:

1) ASSIST ECOMOG in the enforcement and maintenance of the cease fire;

2) ASSIST in the implementation of immediate and total disarmament and demobilization of all armed factions;

3) ASSIST in reconfirming and enforcing the UN Security Council resolution prohibiting the supply of arms to the warring faction in Liberia;

4) CREATE favorable conditions for immediate relief assistance of food, water and medical supplies to the general population, and facilitate the return of all relief agencies to the country;

5) PROMOTE and encourage the establishment of a neutral interim governing body that will administer the affairs of state within the framework of the ECOWAS Peace Initiative and without the participation of the war lords. To this end, the war lords must go!

6) ASSIST in organizing the repatriation and rehabilitation of the hundreds of thousands of Liberians who are internally displaced and those now living as refugees in various West African countries, notable Guinea, Sierra Leone, Cote d'Ivoire, The Gambia, Ghana and Nigeria;

7) ASSIST in the development and implementation of the machinery for free and fair democratic elections;

8) ASSIST in the establishment of a United Nations committee to investigate and try persons accused of widespread human rights abuses during the civil war;

9) HELP in mobilizing the international community for the allocation of financial and other resources for the restoration, rehabilitation and reconstruction of post-civil war Liberia;

10) GRANT permanent legal immigrant status to Liberians residing in the United States, as has been done with many other foreign nationals during times of upheaval in their countries.

The history of the founding of the United States of America is associated with the quest for freedom , liberty and justice. It may be helpful to remind American citizens that Liberia was founded by the American Colonization Society--an initiative that was funded by an Act of Congress. Given the long-standing cordial relationship which has existed between Liberia and the United States, we do not deem it necessary to reiterate the reasons we earnestly believe the USA should help Liberia in her most painful hour. However, we would like only to remind our American allies of Liberia's modest, enduring contribution in supporting and bolstering United States leadership in the world, especially in matters of economic and foreign policy:

*Liberia is the oldest and most consistent ally of the United States on the African continent;

*Liberia fought on the side of the United States and its allies in World Wars I and II;

*Since the 1930s, and through World War II, the Korean and Vietnam wars, Liberia has been the chief supplier of natural rubber to American factories. During World War II, this commodity was critical for US aircraft and other military vehicles;

*Liberia joined the USA and her allies in supporting the United Nations resolution establishing the State of Israel in 1948, and cast the deciding vote for that historic realization;

Because of the 'special relationship' that has existed between the two countries, Liberia voted with the United States at the United Nations on most issues critical and strategic to Washington, including Vietnam, despite the West African nation's membership in the Non-Aligned Movement;

*By providing a home, in Careysburg and Brewerville, for the powerful Voice of America (VOA) relay station beamed to the continents of Africa and South America, Liberia was also instrumental in helping the USA achieve its global communication objectives, critical to her victory in the Cold War;

*Liberia houses the United States' OMEGA Navigational Tracking Station, one of eight around the world, to guide shipping traffic in the Eastern Atlantic and along the West African coast;

*The lion's share of America's security communication traffic was channeled through Liberia for decades;

*Historically, Liberia has been an economic and trade partner of the United States, its very first in Africa. Several major U.S. corporations have maintained long-standing investments in Liberia, among them U.S. Steel, Bethlehem Steel, Firestone, B.F. Goodrich, United States Trading Company; Farrell Lines, Pan American World Airways(Pan Am), Sun Oil as well as major investors in timber, fisheries, oil and mineral exploration;

*The United States being the only remaining super power and the world leader of democracy, should play a more active and more direct role in helping to restore peace, law and order and democracy in Liberia.

*Over the past six years the international community, led by the United States, has made a positive and decisive difference in peace-keeping operations in many troubled parts of the world, including East and Central Africa, the Middle East, Latin America, Haiti and now Bosnia. The situation in Haiti was an internal conflict. The situation in Bosnia is an internal conflict. So is the situation in Liberia, with which the USA has maintained far longer, closer, more cordial and more mutually beneficial relations?

As earlier indicated, considerable international efforts have been expended to bring peace to Liberia, but these have failed to bear fruit, due largely to the inadequacy of financial and logistical support for the West African peace-keeping force ECOMOG, and more especially to the prolonged intransigence of the war lords.. We are convinced that only direct United States intervention can make te decisive difference in helping ECOMOG to bring about an end to the civil war and the peaceful transfer of power to a democratically elected government.

We earnestly hope and pray that President Clinton, the Government and people of the United States will come to the aid of America's oldest African friend and ally, and save her from catastrophe and extinction.

We, Liberians residing in the United States, are prepared to do all in our power, now and in the future, for peace, reconciliation, reconstruction, democracy and good government in our country.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
